description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Hockey is supposed to be fun, but this season has not been too enjoyable for the Rangers.

title: Be Careful What You Wish For
description: A comic fable that squanders its twisted-fairy-tale concept, The Brass Teapot observes the insidious effects of greed on a young, broke couple. When Alice (Juno Temple) and John (Michael Angarano) acquire a teapot that spits out cash every time they hurt themselves, they leap into the good life through self-inflicted hard knocks but learn a valuable lesson when other people want their stuff.

title: Inquiry Is Sought Into Death of Castro Critic
Psychiatrist Reported Suspect in Theater Shooting as Threat
description: DENVER  A month before James E. Holmes was accused of carrying out a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater, his university psychiatrist reported that Mr. Holmes had been having homicidal thoughts and was harassing her in e-mails and text messages, according to documents released Thursday.

title: Back in Brooklyn, Nets Falter Again in Third Quarter
description: The lights went out. Players bounced together in unison on the herringbone floor for the first time in 18 days. Fireworks shot into the air. The Nets were back in Brooklyn, and a sellout crowd at Barclays Center was treated to a close game and a frenetic finish.

title: Whom Do You Trust on Climate Change?
description: THE HAGUE As the debate on global warming steadily drifts away from whether it is real toward how it will affect our future, a new British study looks at the sources people trust to stay informed on the issue.

title: Obama Budget to Include Cuts to Programs in Hopes of Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama next week will take the political risk of formally proposing cuts to Social Security and Medicare in his annual budget in an effort to demonstrate his willingness to compromise with Republicans and revive prospects for a long-term deficit-reduction deal, administration officials say.

title: Word of the Day | malefactor
description: malefactor \ma-l-fak-tr\ noun

title: Skiing Gulmarg Means Thrills Beyond the Powder
description: In early March, a white sport utility vehicle, crammed with a group of tourists from Germany, Austria, Switzerland and the United States, left the famous Kashmiri ski resort of Gulmarg well after dark. As the vehicle sped toward Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, the driver, Bashir, gripped the steering wheel and nervously scanned the road ahead.

title: In Uncertain Season, Old Combination Works Fine
description: There were echoes Thursday of the greatest moment this young stadium has ever hosted, back in 2009, when the Yankees won the World Series. Andy Pettitte started that night and Mariano Rivera finished. The Yankees took their place on baseballs mountaintop, where they believe they always belong. King of the hill, top of the heap.

title: Boise for Davis Cup? The City Has Advantages
description: BOISE, Idaho  Novak Djokovic is the top-ranked mens tennis player in the world. He is so intelligent, so engaging, so interested in current affairs that speculation about his post-playing days often touches on the possibility of a political career back home in Serbia.

title: Brandon Cronenberg on Antiviral
description: The writer and director discusses his film about a clinic that sells the diseases of celebrities to its clients.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 7 A.M. (13) SESAME STREET In three new People in Your Neighborhood segments Murray Monster visits Lincoln Center, where he interviews performers about their careers. In this first installment he and the Spanish-speaking lamb Ovejita join the New York City Ballet dancers Kristen Segin, Alina Dronova, Callie Bachman and Sara Adams (above, with Murray) in the studio, where the women illustrate terms like barre and pli and demonstrate how they use their bodies to tell stories. Then Murray and Ovejita put on tutus and join the ballerinas in an excerpt from Peter Martinss staging of Swan Lake.

title: Backing Into His Fathers Footsteps
description: Body horror and biological obsessions have often been present in the gooey, sometimes shocking films of the Canadian director David Cronenberg. So it may not be surprising that the debut feature from Brandon Cronenberg, the son of the man once called the baron of blood, has similar themes. But what is surprising is how small a role his fathers films may have played in the making of his own.

title: News Quiz | April 5, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Clip: The Angels Share
description: A scene from The Angels Share, directed by Ken Loach.

title: Buddhist-Muslim Tensions Spread as 8 Detainees Die in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Simmering religious and ethnic violence in Myanmar spread beyond its borders on Friday when a brawl broke out at an immigration center in Indonesia between Muslim and Buddhist detainees, leaving 8 dead and 15 wounded, officials said.

title: Building Collapse Near Mumbai Kills at Least 72
description: 1:47 a.m. | Updated NEW DELHI  The death toll from the collapse of a building near Mumbai rose to at least 72 people on Saturday, two days after the disaster that underscored the prevalence of illegal and shoddy construction ending in disaster.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 5
description: NEWS A visit to the Kachin region of Myanmar is a sobering reminder of how much hatred and mistrust exist between the majority Burman and the ethnic minorities who live in the countrys highlands. Thomas Fuller reports from Myitkyina, Myanmar.

title: Schools Adopt Restorative Justice as Alternative to Zero-Tolerance Policies
description: In Opening Up, Students Transform a Vicious Circle, Patricia Leigh Brown writes about a new approach to student discipline issues that is taking root in some schools.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 5, 2013
description: This question was written by Katherine Schulten from a Style section article, You Named Me Brutus? Really?

title: Norways New Photographic Landscape
description: Helge Skodvin was not on a typical road trip  he was about halfway between mainland Norway and the North Pole. Mr. Skodvin, a photographer from the west coast of Norway, was driving around the Svalbard archipelago searching for cars.

title: How Would You Feel About a Computer Grading Your Essays?
description: Technology is becoming more and more important in schools and education, but is there a limit to what computers should do in the classroom?

title: Are Ads Moving Past the Standard Indian Housewife?
description: If I won a rupee every time an Indian commercial stereotyped women, I could have bought a Ford Figo to use as storage space.

title: North Korea Events Complicate Nuclear Talks With Iran
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  North Korea is more than 2,500 miles from the resumed nuclear negotiations that got under way here Friday between Iran and the six big powers, but North Koreas nuclear-arms bombast and the cautious foreign response are hanging over the negotiations in unsettling ways.

title: Tensions With North Korea Unsettle Souths Economy
description: SEOUL  North Koreas torrent of threats  and the matching show of military power and political resolve from the United States and South Korea  began showing signs of unsettling foreign investors confidence Friday.

title: Bangkok SkyTrain Fund Raises $2.1 Billion in I.P.O.
description: HONG KONG  A fund controlled by the operator of Bangkoks sprawling SkyTrain urban rail system raised a record 62.53 billion baht, or $2.13 billion, on Friday in the largest initial public offering anywhere by a Thai company.

title: Big Detroit Iron Meets Cosmic-Themed Dinosaur Art
description: Kenny Scharf sees a world colored by ravenous dinosaur toys, rocket ships and outrageous Cadillac fins. As an artist, Mr. Scharf is known for his Day-Glo disco installations and swirling candy-color cartoon murals, but he has also emerged as an avid car customizer over the last 30 years, transforming classic cars into moving, fantastical pop sculptures.

title: South Koreans at Norths Edge Cope With Threat of War
description: MUNSAN, South Korea  As Lee Jae-eun retrieved her squirming twins from day care and loaded them into a two-seat stroller, she barely glanced up at the olive green Blackhawk helicopter that swept overhead, just above the high-rise apartment buildings.

title: The Early Word: Risk
description: In Todays Times:

title: Remembering Jack Pardee, One of the Junction Boys
description: Jack Pardee had a 40-year football career, as a player and coach, including 15 seasons as one of the N.F.L.s solid and steady outside linebackers of the 1960s and early 70s. Pardee died on Monday of gallbladder cancer. He was 76. A few thoughts:

title: Leaving South Africa for the Gothic Wonderland
description: I know where I am going to university this fall! Here is a look at the diary Ive kept:

title: HMV Stores to Be Sold to Private Equity Firm
description: LONDON  The private equity firm Hilco Consumer Capital agreed on Friday to buy more than 140 stores of the British music retailer HMV as part of a rescue deal after the company went into bankruptcy earlier this year.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 2
description: Baseball trivia games are a dime a dozen, and the answers are usually just a Google search away. Baseball  from scouting to fantasy games to a catcher calling for a pitch  is all about what is going to happen next. So the Bats Blog team thought it would test our readers predictive skills throughout the season with three questions about each upcoming week. Feel free to lean on research, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: B&B Owner Responds to Web Site Review
description: Criticism can be hard to take, especially when your business is your home. Last week, however, Nancy Galloway and Andre Laporte welcomed our comments and suggestions as to how to improve their inns Web site. It is like having a great editor, Ms. Galloway said. You need someone who is looking at your work with a fresh perspective. I am too close to our site and the comments were quite helpful and we are taking many to heart.

title: Daily Report: Breathing Room for Whitman at H.P.
description: In another upheaval for the board of Hewlett-Packard, the company said on Thursday that Raymond J. Lane, its embattled chairman, was stepping down from that post just two weeks after his narrow re-election. Two other directors departed the board entirely, Quentin Hardy reports on Friday in The New York Times.

title: Rat Chase Backfires at Reactor in Japan
description: TOKYO  Workers at the stricken Fukushima nuclear power plant who were installing wire nets Friday to keep rats away from a vital cooling system instead tripped that system, causing it to fail for the second time in weeks.

title: For Cyprus, Gaslight at the End of Tunnel?
description: LONDON  If there are any bright spots in the gloom surrounding the economy of Cyprus, one place to look would be about 170 kilometers south of the coastal city of Limassol. There, about 1,700 meters below the surface of the Mediterranean Sea, is a potentially lucrative natural gas field called Aphrodite.

title: At H.P., Activist Steps Up
description: AT H.P., ACTIVIST STEPS UP | The board of Hewlett-Packard, under criticism for overseeing the disastrous acquisition of the British software maker Autonomy, is being shaken up. The chairman, Raymond J. Lane, gave up that post on Thursday and was succeeded on an interim basis by Ralph V. Whitworth, the activist hedge fund manager who joined the board in 2011. Two other directors left the board altogether.

title: From the Negative 71st Parallel, (Near) End Transmission
description: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee in Antarctica.

title: Homegrown Efforts to Recruit Women in Silicon Valley
description: Silicon Valley is not exactly known for its diversity. So when Andreessen Horowitz, the venture capital firm, wanted to make sure its job postings were reaching the most diverse audience possible, its partners did what most people in Silicon Valley do when they spot a problem. They turned to software.

title: Friday Reading: How the I.R.S. Punishes Working Parents
Opinion Report: Regulations
description: From the editorial page

title: Desperately Seeking Serious Approval
description: Sigh. So Obama is going with the chained CPI thing in his latest proposal  changing the price index used for Social Security cost adjustments. This is, purely and simply, a benefit cut.

title: Judge Strikes Down Age Limits on Morning-After Pill
description: A federal judge on Friday ordered that the most common morning-after pill be made available over the counter for all ages, instead of requiring a prescription for girls 16 and younger. But his acidly worded decision raises a broader question about whether a cabinet secretary can decide on a drugs availability for reasons other than its safety and effectiveness.

title: Shopping and Anxiety
description: Dear Diary:

title: Hiring in U.S. Tapers Off as Economy Fails to Gain Speed
description: It looks as if the spring swoon is back.

title: Cover Story? FX Apologizes for Error That Cut Off The Americans
description: In this brave new world of serialized television dramas every minute counts. Miss the closing moments of your favorite show and you could lose out on crucial plot details that send its story spinning off in new and unexpected directions. But when your beloved FX cold war-era spy drama is cut off before its conclusion by your overeager DVR, whom do you blame? The C.I.A.? The K.G.B.? HBO?

title: Knowosphere at Work: Farmer-to-Farmer Video Advice Boosting Yields
description: David Bornstein, the author of How to Change the World and contributor to the Fixes blog here at The Times, has written a spectacular post  Where YouTube Meets the Farm  describing Digital Green, a successful effort to extend the reach of social workers and agricultural extension services in India through community-shot videos that explain innovative steps taken by farmers to boost yields or income.

title: Common Core Practice | Narrative, Argumentative and Informative Writing About Baseball
description: The 2013 major league baseball season began this week, and Sarah Gross, Jonathan Olsen and their New Jersey students many among them passionate Yankees or Mets fans  couldnt pass up the opportunity to explore Americas pastime for this weeks writing prompts.

title: Q&A: Cleaning Up Outdated Gmail Contacts
description: Q.

title: U.N. Agency Suspends Food Aid in Gaza After Protesters Break Into Its Compound
description: JERUSALEM  The United Nations Relief and Works Agency has indefinitely suspended food distribution in the Gaza Strip after protesters angry over the cancellation of a cash assistance program for the poor stormed the agencys main compound in Gaza City on Thursday, an official said Friday.

title: UBS Aided Purchase of Stake in Chinese Insurer
description: SHANGHAI  The Swiss banking giant UBS made a $5.5 billion loan early this year to help a Thai company acquire a 15.6 percent stake in Chinas Ping An Insurance Group, according to people briefed on the deal.

title: When in Rome, Eat Like an Expat
description: Rome is one of the worlds best food cities, but it can be pretty darn hard to find a good meal in this town, and pretty easy to find a bad one, too. Thats where The Rome Digest comes in. A joint venture by five of the citys leading Anglophone food-and-wine experts, this new site aims to demystify and declutter the decisions around eating and drinking in the city, distilling its offerings down to 100 carefully curated, vigorously vetted need-to-know locations.

title: Reclaiming a Knicks Title
description: The two videotapes that contain Game 5 of the 1973 N.B.A. finals had broken down chemically, turning them soft and sticky. They would not budge in a tape deck.

title: Thoughts Before Briefly Leaving the Grid
description: Ill be out of the office and off the grid for a few days, but before I go, a couple of thoughts:

title: Gang Rape Defendant Hopes to Join Indian Air Force
description: NEW DELHI Vinay Sharma, one of the six defendants in the Delhi gang rape case, has asked the court to let him take a written selection exam for the Indian Air Force on Sunday, as he still hopes to join the military branchs clerical department.

title: Beneath the Kilt, a Modern Scotland
description: In the new comedy The Angels Share four young unemployed Glaswegians dressed in kilts set out on a journey into the Scottish Highlands. The soundtrack even features the infectious anthem Im Gonna Be (500 Miles) by their countrymen the Proclaimers. But these miscreants could not belong less to the mountains and glens north of the Highland line.

title: Depression, Not Ended
description: Lousy jobs report. OK, you dont want to put too much stress on one months numbers, yada yada, but it doesnt look at all good.

title: Sequestration and the Jobs Report
description: The March jobs report came in much weaker than expected, with employers adding just 88,000 workers over the course of the month. Did sequestration  the $85 billion in mandatory budget cuts that Congress never managed to unwind, despite promises to the contrary  take a bite?

title: The Superhero Who Leapt Color Lines
description: Watching the movie 42 brings to mind the ending to John Fords fine 1962 western, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. A newspaperman (and the viewer) has learned from James Stewart the truth about who really gunned down the evil Valance years before. But rather than run with the story, the newsman rips it up and flings it into the stove. His reason? When the legend becomes fact, he says, print the legend.

title: The Curse of Ataturk
description: ISTANBUL  How happy is the one who says I am a Turk, said Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, speaking in an emotional finale of a speech in 1933  a time when Turkey was still trying to forge a national identity out of the ruins of the Ottoman Empire. The notion seemed simple enough: If you think youre Turkish, then you are.

title: Louis C. K. and the Ballad of Jack Dall
description: When Louis C. K. gets excited about something, he really gets excited. Case in point: in a recent interview with the Arts & Leisure section of The Times, he expounded on many subjects, including his coming HBO special, Oh My God, his work with Woody Allen on Blue Jasmine and the number of years he believes he has left in his career. But when the topic of conversation turned to David Lynch, the Blue Velvet and Mulholland Dr. filmmaker, a certain gleam appeared in his eye. Over the next several minutes, Louis C. K. enthusiastically recounted the story of how he cast Mr. Lynch on Louie in the role of Jack Dall, an inscrutable entertainment-industry veteran who trains the Louie character for a fateful audition to replace David Letterman on Late Show.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Chicago Sun-Times: Roger Ebert on not being able to eat: From that time I began to replace what I had lost with what I remembered.  Melissa Clark

title: Parsing Racial Politics in the 50s
description: China Gate

title: Punkd
description: In 1972 I designed Hillys Gazette for Hilly Kristals eponymous bar before he opened the famed CBGB. I missed the punk scene by about two years because I was a hippie. Punks hated hippies. At least thats what John Holmstrom told me years after hippiedom and punkdom had run their respective courses. Holmstrom was a co-founder  along with Ged Dunn Jr. and Eddie Legs McNeil  as well as an editor, designer, illustrator and letterer of Punk, the magazine that helped put the music on the map. When I was art director of The New York Times Op-Ed page, he showed me his illustration portfolio. The stiff linear crosshatch style was not the right tone for The Times, and I was not impressed by his comics-style hand-lettered magazine. I now realize what a cultural and historical bellwether it was.

title: Prize-Writing
description: In January, the 133-year-old Library Journal announced the creation of a new annual prize: the Amanda Foreman Award for best acknowledgments. Laugh all you like; it was one of the proudest moments of my life. I knew how much effort had been expended in making those acknowledgments as comprehensive and accurate as possible; but I never thought anyone else would notice.

title: La Famiglia
description: Early in Christopher Castellanis new novel, All This Talk of Love, Frankie Grasso wonders whether he and his family are at the end of something. Frankie is a 30-ish graduate student in English literature, still a long way from the end of (for one thing) his dissertation. An answer begins to take shape when his sister, an affluent stay-at-home mom who has never strayed far from their childhood home in Delaware, organizes a family trip to Santa Cecilia, the village in Italy where their parents grew up. For all of the Grassos, the very idea of the trip stirs up thoughts of old losses, ghosts that shadow the present, prompted by the dissonant fact that like many if not most Italian-Americans, Antonio and Maddalena Grasso enshrined in their children a glowing image of things Italian yet never took them to Italy or even taught them the language. Feeling oneself at the end of something, this slyly ambitious novel suggests, may well be the existential condition of being Italian-American.

title: The President Proposes . . .
description: Ira Katznelson heard his first political argument around the family table a few weeks before the presidential election of 1952. His grandmother started it, as only a grandmother can, by announcing that she wasnt going to vote. Katznelsons parents, who adored Adlai Stevenson, were suitably shocked. But Bubbeh Frima held her ground. Since Roosevelt, she insisted, they are all pygmies.

title: Life Stages
description: Double Feature is a lame title for a novel that is epic, ambitious and dedicated to the uncontainable. Nor is the jacket of service; it shows a couple of old movie tickets when it needs a scrum of characters, not getting anywhere but being their talkative and irrepressible selves. Id guess that this novel  Owen Kings first, after an esteemed story collection  was compiled over a period of years, possibly as a series of short stories about a group of characters. The novel is maybe a third too long, chiefly because as he wanders around King can hardly see a place, a face or a chair without embarking on a wordy, if not literary, description of it. This might have been cut by someone (why not King?) who can see that brevity is his best quality. But he may be a tricky man to edit or organize. He should persevere, for when he is good  and that is often enough to make a page turner of this book  he has a captivating energy, a precision and a fondness for people that are rare and that make the reader doubly impatient for him to do what he does best.

title: Book of Ruth
description: A family story: My mothers friend Frika, a Viennese Jew, managed to leave Austria for America after the Anschluss. She knew if she were caught smuggling out the means of subsistence, she would be arrested. So she wore her money on her hat, in the form of a diamond brooch, which  thus flaunted  passed for fake. When the Nazis at the border asked what she was taking with her, she replied, Only what you see! And they let her through.

title: Leading Off: College Sports Really Bad Day
description: If you are among those who love college sports in all their flawed glory, dont want the system changed no matter how rotten it has become, Thursday was not a good day for you. In fact, one spin through the news cycle might have sent you crawling under the couch cushions. Of course, you probably found some college sports administrators hiding there, so it could get crowded pretty quickly.

title: . . . Congress Disposes
description: Franklin Roosevelt enjoyed the overwhelming support of American Jews during his presidency, and the reasons are clear. In his three-plus terms from 1933 to 1945, he led the war against Hitler, supported a Jewish homeland in Palestine, appointed a Jew to the Supreme Court, chose another to be his secretary of the Treasury and surrounded himself with Jewish advisers who helped shape the laws that revolutionized the role of government in American life  what some critics sneeringly called the Jew Deal. Then, of course, there was Eleanor Roosevelt, whose concern for minorities fused the bond even tighter. When Roosevelt died in 1945, the Rabbinical Assembly of America described him, almost supernaturally, as an immortal leader of humanity and a peerless servant of God.

title: Up Front
description: In his review of Monte Reels Between Man and Beast this week, David Quammen notes that part of what made the discovery of gorillas so sensational in the Victorian era was that they were too similar to humans for comfort. As for whether attitudes have changed much, Quammen  the author of a biography of Charles Darwin, among other books  isnt so sure; in an e-mail, he cited a recent Gallup poll that found 46 percent of Americans decline to accept the reality that humans have evolved from ancestral primates. His most recent book, Spillover, is about human diseases that come to us from animals, and he arrives at the terrifying conclusion that such outbreaks are likely to become more frequent and more worrisome. The next big one might well prove devastating, he said. Still, if there is one salubrious thing about these insalubrious afflictions, such as Ebola and West Nile and AIDS and the influenzas, its that they remind us, by spilling over from nonhuman animals to humans, that we humans are just another animal.

title: Death of a Strongman
description: On March 5, Hugo Chvezs extraordinary good luck ran out at last. After decades of evading an endless string of opponents  from personal poverty to the United States government  Venezuelas democratically elected strongman finally succumbed to the one enemy he couldnt defeat. Even his ending was vintage Chvez. The perpetual showman spent the last months of his life ruling Venezuela Oz-like, by remote control from his sickbed (he even missed his own inauguration on Jan. 10). All of which makes this the perfect time for the release of Rory Carrolls Comandante: Hugo Chvezs Venezuela, a sort of political obituary for the self-declared savior of Venezuela  a charismatic champion of the poor who, during his 14 years in office, ground one of Latin Americas richest states into the dust.

title: Founding Father
description: Simn Bolvar, the Liberator, was the George Washington of South America, or so he was regarded by sundry eminences in the United States during a large part of his extraordinary career. Grandeur was his nature. He aroused adulation. He dealt a few preliminary military defeats to the Spanish imperial army, and in 1813, he entered victoriously, for the moment, into Caracas on a chariot drawn by white-gowned daughters of the leading families, as if he were a god or a Caesar. And he assumed the magnificent title of Liberator and Dictator. The chariot and the daughters deviated, it is true, from the austere Washington style, and the dictatorial honorific has hovered a little ominously over his reputation ever since, as you can see by reading Marie Aranas admiring and rueful biography, Bolvar.

title: Editors Choice
description: MIDDLE C,  by William H. Gass. (Knopf, $28.95.) From its opening notes, this unquiet bildungsroman about a family of Austrian emigrants  fakes and fraudsters who have cast themselves as Jews  is designed to detonate its middling title.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE IDEA FACTORY: Bell Labs and the Great Age of American Innovation,  by Jon Gertner. (Penguin, $17.) Bell Labs, the onetime research and development wing of AT&T, was behind many of the technological transformations that define modern life, including the transistor, lasers and cellular telephony. Gertners incisive history is filled with inspiring lessons and asks a critical question: What causes innovation?

title: App Smart Extra: More Point-and-Click Adventure Games to Try
description: My App Smart column this week was about point-and-click adventure games. These apps build on a long tradition of computer-based adventures. Great graphics and touch screens on todays tablets and smartphones make these games much more fun to play than before. The idea is that you interact with items in the games various scenes by tapping on the graphics, solving puzzles as the games story progresses.

title: The Shrinking Ranks of the Working
description: Just when you thought it might be safe for the Fed to begin to think about taking its foot off the accelerator, along comes a jobs report that makes the employment picture look much less rosy than we had thought.

title: Inside the List
description: NUCLEAR FAMILY: The town of Oak Ridge, Tenn., didnt exist before World War II, but by mid-1945 it had 75,000 residents and used more electricity than New York City. Why? Because, as Denise Kiernan explains in The Girls of Atomic City  new at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list  thats where the government set up the Manhattan Projects top secret uranium enriching facilities, staffed almost entirely by young women who didnt learn what they were working on until the first bomb fell on Hiroshima.

title: Ghosts of Budapest
description: Are you experiencing any of the following: (1) A thirst for palinka? (2) A yearning for Budapest, though the closest youve ever come is the Hungarian Pastry Shop in Manhattan? (3) An urge to deploy diacritical marks over every other vowel? If so, you may be suffering from Hungarophilia. My own case dates to my mid-20s, when I discovered Peter Nadass novel A Book of Memories. Its high-Modernist aspirations were just one of the ways this contemporary masterpiece seemed to issue from a more distinguished past. Fascinated, I began reading every living Hungarian novelist I could find in English: Imre Kertesz, Laszlo Krasznahorkai. . . . By the time I got to Peter Esterhazys Celestial Harmonies, I, too, was dreaming of palaces with swirling towers and flapping banners gazing at their reflections in the mirror of the lake.

title: The Messenger and the Message
description: In todays febrile cultural and religious climate, what project could be more fraught than writing a biography of Muhammad? The worldwide protests at The Innocence of Muslims, 14 minutes of trashy provocation posted on YouTube, are a terrible reminder to the would-be biographer that the life story of the prophet of Islam is not material about which one is free to have a take. Lesley Hazletons First Muslim is a book written by a white woman of dual American and British citizenship, published in America more than a decade after the 9/11 attacks. For many believers it is already  even before it is read, if it is read at all  an object of suspicion, something to be defended against, in case it should turn out to be yet another insult, another cruel parody of a story such an author has no business telling.

title: Roger and Me
description: As a lifelong Mets fan (you can tell by a photo of me at age 10 dressed as Keith Hernandez for Halloween, and my current aura of despair), Id hoped Mike Piazza  one of few genuine heroes on the team post-80s  would be voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame earlier this year, his first time on the ballot. Alas, he fell 98 votes short of the 75 percent required for induction, most likely passed over because of a suspicion that he, like some other power hitters of his generation, took steroids  a rumor addressed at length in his strategically timed memoir, Long Shot.

title: A Death in Venice
description: Theres an autumnal tone to Donna Leons latest Venetian mystery, THE GOLDEN EGG (Atlantic Monthly, $26), that suits the melancholy mood of Commissario Guido Brunetti when he looks into the suspicious death of Davide Cavanella, the deaf and mentally disabled man who worked for his neighborhood dry cleaner. It strikes Brunetti as sad, as well as sinister, that hes unable to find any public record of Davide, that his mother cant produce her sons birth or baptismal certificates, school documents or any other verification of his life. In the eyes of the state, Davide never existed. It daunted Brunetti, the pathos of it.

title: Movies That Spill Beyond the Screen
description: For almost its entire life, cinema has been proclaimed a dying medium, under threat from talkies, television, home video and now digital technology. One increasingly popular response to this eternal lament is to think of cinema as a live art.

title: Mark Knopfler Cancels Shows in Russia
description: Mark Knopfler canceled two concerts in Russia on Thursday to protest what he sees as the governments harassment of human rights groups there, the BBC reported.

title: Gang Rape Defendants at Risk in Tihar Jail, Lawyers and Family Say
description: NEW DELHI  Ram Singh, one of the men accused in the Delhi gang rape, was cremated in his family village in Rajasthan two days after he was found hanging in his jail cell on March 11. The body his family received was in horrific condition, family members said in interviews last weekend, making them believe more strongly than ever that he did not commit suicide.

title: Kim Jong-uns Spanish Mouthpiece
description: LONDON  Kim Jong-un may lead the worlds most isolated state, but the North Korean leader is not entirely without foreign allies as tensions rise on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Rutgers Tries to Calm Furor as More Officials Quit
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  As Rutgers officials tried Friday to calm the public furor over their handling of abusive behavior by the Scarlet Knights mens basketball coach, the university president and athletic director presented conflicting depictions of who was responsible for the decision to keep the coach on staff after administrators first learned of his behavior.

title: Teenagers in The Times | March 2013
description: Each month we round up all the latest articles and multimedia published on NYTimes.com about young people, so that teachers and students can find this rich collection of nonfiction writing all in one place.

title: Talking Things Out Until the Duck Quacks
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Youve Been Doing a Fantastic Job. Just One Thing ...
description: MOST of us think we know how to give feedback. Positive comments are better  and more useful  than negative ones. And if you do have to point out something wrong, start with a compliment, move on to the problem, then end on a high note.

title: Baldness as a Signal of Heart Disease Risk
description: Baldness may indicate an increased risk for coronary heart disease.

title: Champions Without Egos
description: Earl Monroe and Walt Frazier reflect on their playing days.

title: This Weeks Movies: Trance, Upstream Color and The Company You Keep
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review Upstream Color, Trance and The Company You Keep. Find all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Overseas Finances Can Trip Up Americans Abroad
description: LIVING and working abroad may sound romantic. But having a financial life in more than one country  if one of those countries is the United States  is becoming increasingly complicated.

title: China Escalates Its Response to Outbreak of Avian Flu
description: BEIJING  With confirmation that a sixth person has died from a mysterious avian-borne virus, Chinese officials escalated their response on Friday, advising people to avoid live poultry, sending virologists to chicken farms across the country and slaughtering more than 20,000 birds at a wholesale market in Shanghai where the virus, known as H7N9, was detected in a pigeon.

title: Clinton Continues Her Advocacy for Womens Rights as Private Citizen
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a glimpse on Friday of how she will fill her at least temporary role as a private advocate for women and girls, walking arm in arm with Tina Brown at the Women in the World Conference, an annual womens rights event sponsored by Newsweek and The Daily Beast, which Ms. Brown oversees.

title: Renovations and Hope on a Block Once Marked by Blight
description: You do not want to mess with Arnaldo Rivera on Kelly Street. He had heard plenty about this crescent-shaped block off Intervale Avenue in the South Bronx. Drug dealers and addicts had holed up in filthy, crumbling apartments scattered among five buildings that were among the citys worst. He was ready. He had a gun.

title: Little Accountability for Directors, Despite Poor Performance
description: Aficionados of good corporate governance shouldnt get too excited about the fact that two Hewlett-Packard directors are leaving the board and a third, Raymond J. Lane, is stepping down as chairman.

title: Marriage Equality Tipping Point
description: Florida Senator Bill Nelson, who said last week that marriage is between a man and a woman, said yesterday that he supports marriage equality. If we are endowed by our creator with rights, then why shouldnt those be attainable by gays and lesbians? he wrote in a statement to The Tampa Bay Times. Simply put, if the Lord made homosexuals as well as heterosexuals, why should I discriminate against their civil marriage? I shouldnt, and I wont. So I will add my name to the petition of senators asking the Supreme Court to declare the law that prohibits gay marriage unconstitutional.

title: A Bankruptcy, and Now a Pension Test
description: Stockton, Calif.,  has been allowed into Chapter 9 bankruptcy.

title: Closets, Please, and the Bigger the Better
description: When Apartment J in a Prospect Heights co-op went on the market last summer, 120 people streamed through to see it. At packed open houses, potential buyers marveled at the beautifully renovated kitchen, the privacy-friendly split bedroom layout, and the proximity to Prospect Park.

title: Salazar Looks Back on a Joyful Run as Interior Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  Ken Salazar, a man of unnaturally sunny disposition in an often gloomy town, may be the happiest person in the Obama administration these days. He is going home to Colorado next week, provided his successor as interior secretary is confirmed as expected.

title: The Gun Report: April 5, 2013
description: As regular readers know, the Gun Report has become somewhat obsessed with the many cases of  lets not mince words here  reckless endangerment, where a parent or guardian leaves a loaded gun around the house, which is found by a small child, who then accidentally discharges it, killing or maiming either herself or someone else.We understand how heart-wrenching this must be for the parents, who will have to face their grief and guilt for the rest of their lives.Having said that, however, we also think that if prosecutors took these parents to court on a consistent basis, these incidents would dramatically decrease. The prospect of going to jail would convince people to lock up their guns.

title: Why Did Frannys Cross the Road? To Grow
description: Imagine moving from a studio apartment to a classic six. That seemed to be the theme as Francine Stephens showed off the new Frannys, opening Monday in Park Slope, Brooklyn, across Flatbush Avenue from the original. Were kind of growing in every way: the space, the kitchen, the menu, she said.

title: A Basketball Blowout and Its Celebration Raise Theological Questions
description: During the next several days, the mens college basketball season will culminate with the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Something like 15 million viewers will take in the telecasts, and they will reasonably assume they are watching the most important games of the year.

title: Over the Rainbow
description: Nearly three years ago, Ambra Medda, the wunderkind co-founder and director of Design Miami (and Design Miami/Basel), announced that she was resigning from the high-profile fairs that she helped start in 2005, leaving the design world to wonder what her next move would be. Well, shes made it, and, perhaps not surprisingly, its a Web site. LArcoBaleno (Italian for The Rainbow), which will go live in late May, bills itself as a content and marketplace site devoted to collectible design.

title: Crops and Music, Each in Its Season
description: As a child John Eliot Gardiner saw Johann Sebastian Bach every day. He would pass him on his way to the dining room, where he sang Bach motets with his parents and siblings after meals. He would glance up at Bach, returning from accompanying his mother in an aria from a cantata, in which he played the obbligato violin part. The portrait of the ruddy-faced and bewigged Bach painted in 1748 by Elias Gottlob Haussmann hung above the staircase of the family home in Dorset, England, on loan from its owner, a German musician who had befriended Mr. Gardiners father in the interwar years then settled in a nearby village.

title: The She and He Who Create as We
description: Tights and point shoes, bunions and tape, a prince and his princess: in dance, certain things always go together. But another kind of pairing, the choreographic duo, hasnt always been so successful. Sol Len and Paul Lightfoot of Nederlands Dans Theater are an exception.

title: Two More Democrats Switch on Same-Sex Marriage
description: Two more senators announced their support for same-sex marriage Friday, becoming the latest in a flood of lawmakers switching their positions on the issue.

title: Image of the Day: April 5
Off the Charts: Junk Glitters
description: Global issuance of high-yield bonds  also known as junk bonds  reached a record $133 billion in the first quarter of 2013.

title: Junk Bonds Get Junkier, but Still Sell Briskly
description: JUNK bonds have never been more popular, even if they no longer deserve to be called high-yield bonds, the more polite description that Wall Street prefers.

title: Who Made That Ferris Wheel?
description: I leave it to you, ladies and gentlemen, to say if the wheel is still in my head, George Ferris called out to a crowd at the Chicago Worlds Fair in 1893. Skeptics had joked that the young engineer would never build the giant whirligig that spun in his imagination. That day, his steel behemoth towered over the fairgrounds, its spokes gleaming in the sunlight; it could accommodate more than 2,000 riders at once.

title: Raiders of the Lost Privy
description: On a sunny afternoon in March 2005, Diana diZerega Wall, a professor of anthropology at City College, stood in my West Village garden, pointing to a low wall that ran along the back perimeter. Part of it would need to be removed, she said. You understand, she added, that we are not bricklayers. We cannot put the wall back. I smiled, appreciatively. No one was confusing her with a bricklayer, I assured her.

title: Making the Impossible Veggie Burger
description: This weeks cover article by Mark Bittman is about a new crop of restaurant chains selling healthful, vegan or vegetarian versions of traditional fast-food items like burgers and buffalo wings. To convey the idea that these vegetable-based products may be the future of fast food, we decided to make an over-the-top vegan burger by squeezing different vegetables inside a multigrain bun.

title: The 3.24.13 Issue
description: THE EPIC UPS AND DOWNS OF PETER GELB

title: Should You Tip an Immigration Officer?
description: My family and I traveled through a number of countries in Southeast Asia. Upon leaving Cambodia, the immigration officer asked me in a pleasant but direct voice, Do you have a tip for me? I pretended not to understand the nature of his question. He then repeated his request. With some apprehension, I gave him $5. Should I have given the immigration officer the tip and, by extension, help to perpetuate the nations insidious corruption? Should I have reported the incident? (Given the pernicious nature of Cambodian justice, I have genuine concerns that the officers punishment would not fit the pettiness of the offense.) LEON WEAVER, REDDING, CONN.

title: Making Your Own Backyard Paradise
description: How much does it cost to have a beautiful yard? We asked Mark Word of Mark Word Design, a landscape and construction company in Austin, Tex., to look at photographs of a home in Dallas (above) and give us outdoor-makeover options from least to most expensive. Before I started the design, I made a choice to make this more of an outdoor room, he said. I imagined this was for a family with kids and that theyd be using it all the time.

title: Mark Pincus Thinks Angry Birds Wont Hurt Your Kids
description: You are the founder and C.E.O. of Zynga, a company responsible for addictive games like FarmVille and the forthcoming Draw Something 2. You know, every time I see my 4-year-old son playing Angry Birds on my phone, I imagine that his little brain is rotting.  I can commiserate because I have twin 2 - year-olds, and theyve mastered the iPod Touch. I dont think its rotting their brains, if you compare what its replacing  TV. My kids are mastering puzzles, its challenging their thinking. I want to ultimately reward them with screen-time minutes for chores and achievements.

title: Hedge Fund America
description: Still thinking about debt; and it seems to me that theres an important aspect of the story that isnt getting any play, namely, the extent to which US debt has in effect been issued to buy assets overseas.

title: How to Buy a Perfectly Peculiar Tree
description: Ordinary trees offer shade, privacy, visual interest. Extraordinary trees  rare, oddly shaped or just plain huge  provide something else altogether. They can serve as sculptural centerpieces to a yard or perfectly complement architectural details. Most tree nurseries keep some odd ducks in their inventory, but a few, including the three listed below, specialize in unusual specimens they either grow themselves or purchase during regular scouting missions of public and private land. As a general rule, the more unusual the tree, the higher the price. But as Todd Forrest of the New York Botanical Garden says: Planting a tree transforms the landscape. And planting a cool tree adds value to your home.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Monte Reel talks about Between Man and Beast; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Ada Calhoun discusses Mike Piazzas memoir; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Daniel Craig and Rachel Weisz to Star in Pinters Betrayal on Broadway
description: The latest burst of Broadway star casting will come from Britain this fall: The actors Daniel Craig (a k a the reigning 007) and Rachel Weisz (an Oscar winner for The Constant Gardener), who are married in real life, will play the husband and wife in Harold Pinters Betrayal, press representatives for the producer Scott Rudin said Friday. The Tony Award winner Mike Nichols will direct.

title: Payment for Act of Kindness: 2 Days in Car Trunk at Age 89
description: LINCOLN, Del. A steel-haired woman, 89 years old and an inch short of five feet, sat on a pillow in the drivers seat of her Buick LeSabre, just thinking. Parked outside a convenience store on one of the last days of winter, she was considering a pre-Easter treat for herself: an ice cream cone. Butter pecan.

title: April 7  13
description: All Manner Of Guitarists

title: The Richmond Bread Riot
description: Richmond, Va., was the capital of the Confederacy, but by early 1863 it was a miserable place to be. With the Union controlling much of Virginias Tidewater and coastal North Carolina, inland cities like Richmond were starving. Fields in central Virginia and the Shenandoah Valley went unattended as soldiers were kept at their posts. The rail system and the James River canal were overtaxed trying to provision and equip the men on the front. What food did make it through was sold at sky-high prices by speculators and merchants.

title: Marriage and Historical Inevitability
description: And now to finish up my triptych of replies to Kevin Drum on marriage. Heres his conclusion:

title: Based on Relative Yields, Stocks Look Cheap
description: My Off the Charts column this week looks at the popularity of junk bonds. Since 1999, they have outperformed stocks during both bull and bear markets. Issuance of such bonds has risen to record levels around the world, and yields are at historic lows.

title: How to Cut Up a Whole Chicken
description: Not only do you save money by cutting up a whole chicken yourself, but you also get the backbone to make stock. Melissa Clark demonstrates how.

title: A Whole Chicken Is Greater Than the Sum of Its Pieces
description: I used to think the only reason to buy a whole chicken was to actually cook it whole. Why buy one for a recipe calling for parts when the supermarket will cut up the bird for you?

title: The First Signs of Spring in Brooklyn
description: The bloom has begun.

title: A Phoenix Is Rising on Point
description: In the early days of Dance Theater of Harlem its members, charged with proving to the world that black dancers could master ballet, needed a certain pluck. It was a group of young dancers that went out and carried their own lights and did lecture-demonstrations and started performing, said Laveen Naidu, 45, the organizations executive director.

title: Ballet Returns to Harlem
description: In 2004, the Dance Theater of Harlem, crippled by $2.3 million debt, was forced to put its company on hiatus. This April, the dance company reopens.

title: Even After New Highs, the Rally May Last
description: Is the party over?

title: Book Review Podcast: Planet of the Ape
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, David Quammen reviews Monte Reels Between Man and Beast, the story of the 19th-century explorer Paul Du Chaillu, who returned from Africa with evidence that a creature of myth  the gorilla  actually existed. Mr. Quammen writes:

title: Caregiving From Another Continent
description: Every day at 6 a.m., Sunil Pande phones his parents in Gurgaon, India, which is part of the greater New Delhi metropolitan area.

title: Kafkas Monkey
description: Kathryn Hunter plays an ape who plays a man in a solo show at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.

title: Separation Anxiety
description: When babies are born, they lie on their mothers breasts, wild heartbeat to wild heartbeat, and start the long introduction that winds itself around to their eventual separation. When my son Jacob was born, I didnt know that I was ever supposed to put him down. He napped on my chest, and when his eyes opened, they were always greeted by my own. I nursed, rocked and changed his diapers until his eyelids grew heavy again, then I settled him back down on me, rubbing the two-square-inch patch of his tiny back.

title: With Little Fanfare, a Womens Team Takes the Field
description: The players on the offensive line, wearing helmets and shoulder pads, were crouched down on the field in Brooklyn. Green 20! Green 20! 10 hut! shouted the quarterback. The football was handed off to a running back who rushed up the middle before being tackled by several defenders. The whistle blew. Soon practice was over and the teams coach, Richard Harrigan, offered words of praise, Good job, ladies, bring it home. Sharks on three. One. Two. Three. Sharks!

title: Movie Review | 'Upstream Color'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Upstream Color."

title: Hunting Your Own Dinner
description: As the buck rises from its bed in the underbrush 40 yards away, every cell in my body decides to attempt a jailbreak. Im in my hunting stand, 24 feet up a tulip poplar, where Ive been concealed for four hours waiting for a deer to pass. And this one has been right in front of me the whole time. I would like to come to my feet, but my legs are shaking too hard.

title: End of the Adventure for an Enigmatic Heiress
description: This New York Times Magazine cover story from1989 marked what the author, David Margolick, now calls the last hurrah of Barbara Piasecka Johnson, a Polish-born immigrant who married into the Johnson & Johnson fortune. Margolick, a former New York Times reporter, wrote about Johnsons attempt to become a heroine in her native country by donating as much as $100 million to rescue the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, an effort coordinated by the labor activist Lech Walesa. After what Margolick calls her marvelous P.R. stunt failed, and sometime after his article was published, he told me, Johnson fell off the face of the earth. She died on Monday.

title: Engineering Serendipity
description: WHEN Yahoo banned its employees from working from home in February, the reasons it gave had less to do with productivity than serendipity. Some of the best decisions and insights come from hallway and cafeteria discussions, meeting new people, and impromptu team meetings, explained the accompanying memo. The message was clear: doing your best work solo cant compete with lingering around the coffee machine waiting for inspiration in the form of a colleague  to strike.

title: Movie Review | 'Trance'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Trance."

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Amsterdam; Outer Banks, N.C.; San Francisco; Dallas
description: Flower Parade, Amsterdam This event sounds tame, but dont let the title fool you. Think large Thanksgiving Day parade floats (above) covered in flowers. The weekend begins with a parade on April 19 in Noordwijk and continues on April 20 with a 15-mile procession to Haarlem, where the floats are illuminated in the evening and remain on view through April 21. In other words, good luck avoiding it.

title: In Stitches
description: For her first designer collaboration, the textile designer Emily Kroll teamed up with the fashion designer Araks Yeramyan to create limited-edition quilts with repurposed materials from the Araks fall/winter 2013 collection. The quilts are an ode to traditional American craftsmanship, each handmade in Sugar Valley, Pa., by Amish artisans piecing together the panels of hunter green neoprene, lavender silk and cobalt blue wool to create a Bauhaus-like canvas that can be mounted on the wall as piece of art or simply draped over the bed for a chic nights sleep.

title: Movie Review | 'The Company You Keep'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews The Company You Keep.

title: Nanny Charged in 2 Killings Is Found Mentally Fit for Trial
description: The nanny charged with fatally stabbing two children she cared for on the Upper West Side last fall has been found fit to proceed to trial by two psychiatrists, a judge said on Friday.

title: Making Big Plans for Small Artichokes
description: Large globe artichokes are delicious, and so is the ritual of eating them: plucking the leaves one at a time, savoring the edible bits, and scooping out and discarding the hairy choke before digging into the meaty heart.

title: Behind the Scenes at Red Rooster
description: A time-lapse video of the magazine's photo shoot.

title: New Albums by the Strokes and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs
description: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss new albums by two influential New York bands. The Strokes and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs once helped end a mysterious drought in New York rock, but as the scene and the city have evolved, both bands have had to wrestle with the question of how to expand a deceptively simple baseline sound.

title: Kuroda on Schedule to Make His Next Start
description: DETROIT  Hiroki Kuroda threw a bullpen session Friday morning at Comerica Park. Despite a sore right finger, he remains on schedule to make his next start Monday in Cleveland.

title: Collinss Job Goes Beyond Basketball at Northwestern
description: EVANSTON, Ill. Northwestern rolled out everything short of a purple carpet to introduce new mens basketball Coach Chris Collins on Tuesday.

title: American in Panama Reflects on His Cult Classic, Now Reissued
description: R. M. Kosters novel The Prince is one of those cult classics that is hard to classify, and so is its author. He is an American writing in English, but he writes from and about Latin America, his home for more than 50 years, in the fantastical style associated with Gabriel Garca Mrquez and other Spanish-language writers.

title: Why Sanford vs. Colbert Busch Could Be Competitive
description: Former Gov. Mark Sanford won a runoff election this week, securing the Republican nomination for South Carolinas First Congressional District. He will face the Democratic nominee, Elizabeth Colbert Busch, in a May 7 general election.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The chef Marcus Samuelsson and his wife, Maya Haile, have started Three Goats, a nonprofit organization to help children in their native Ethiopia. They are starting their fund-raising efforts on Sunday with an event from 6 to 9 p.m. at Ginnys Supper Club, 310 Lenox Avenue in Harlem. There will be cocktails, appetizers, entertainment and a silent auction and raffle. Tickets, available online, are $150 per person, and proceeds benefit the organization.

title: Visions of a Perfect College
description: Im getting ready for what could be a rough month of decision-making. Instead of waiting to be surprised with a potential conflict, Im taking the time now to decide what factors I want to keep in mind when deciding where I want to go to college.

title: The First 100 Dates Were Just a Warm-Up
description: By the time Twist Phelan met Jack Chapple online in October 2009, she was 100 times better at dishing out rejection than accepting it.

title: The Sweet Spot | Amateur Pursuits
description: People do the darndest things. In this weeks episode David Carr and A. O. Scott scour The Timess newsroom for moonlighting musicians, dancers and artists.

title: Business or Pleasure? Try Both
description: IT WAS HAPPY HOUR in Austin, Tex. The sun was sinking, and music was rising on East Sixth Street, a strip of bars and clubs with names the kid in you wants to shout out loud: Chuggin Monkey, Dizzy Rooster, Jackalope. Closed to cars, the street was a thoroughfare for musicians, party promoters and people looking for beer and a good time. Little by little they found it, disappearing into bars and re-emerging on balconies, drinking from plastic cups and pulling on light jackets as a March wind blew, a reminder that spring was still just out of reach.

title: A Few Niches in Closet History
description: A playful look at the evolution and growth of the closet in New York City real estate.

title: Drought on the Range
description: The United States cattle herd is at its lowest level in 60 years, largely because of the drought. Many ranchers are struggling to hang on.

title: Glimmers of Jewish Glory Days in Baltimore
description: I grew up on stories about the glory days of Jewish Baltimore, when, in my fathers telling, Jews were really Jews. He told stories about walking to shul, or synagogue, with his father and uncles, seeing men and women in their Shabbat finery promenading after services, and sitting in awe as the great Viennese-trained cantor, Abba Yosef Weisgal, cried out to the heavens under the soaring ceiling of Congregation Chizuk Amuno in Reservoir Hill, the Baltimore neighborhood that my forebears called home.

title: A Stubborn Drought Tests Texas Ranchers
description: BLOOMING GROVE, Tex.  Gary Price is a rarity among cattle ranchers these days. Hes making money on his herd of 200 cows in this tiny town about an hour south of Dallas-Fort Worth.

title: Jewish History in Baltimore
description: Exploring a 19th-century synagogue and a street once known as Corned Beef Row.

title: Tourism in Javas Land of Ghosts
description: As we neared the top, a monotone world surrounded us. The thickening fog stitched gray rocks to the sky. Piles of volcanic ash sat, untrammeled, in driveways, as innocuous as autumn leaves. The narrow road snaked ever upward, passing emergency shelters and informal checkpoints.

title: Facing a Fear of Flying
description: When Julia Cameron, the author of many books, including the popular spiritual guide to developing your creativity, The Artists Way, moved to Santa Fe, N.M., a few years ago, she found herself flying once a month to teach writing classes and workshops in New York. The frequency of the trips made her long-standing fear of flying unbearable  and embarrassing.

title: Obama Budget Is Dismissed by G.O.P. and Attacked by Left
description: WASHINGTON  The speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, waved aside reports on Friday that President Obama would seek a new budget compromise next week, accusing the president of again demanding tax increases in exchange for modest entitlement savings.

title: The Sweet Spot | Amateur Pursuits
description: People do the darndest things. In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott scour The Timess newsroom for moonlighting musicians, dancers and artists.

title: Popcast: New Albums by the Strokes and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs
description: On this weeks Popcast, Jon Pareles, the chief pop critic for The Times, talks to the host, Ben Ratliff, about two new albums by New York bands: the Strokes, formed in 1998, and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, formed in 2000.

title: Judge Approves MF Global Liquidation Plan
description: A day after MF Globals bankruptcy trustee hinted he might sue top executives for negligent conduct, his separate plan to liquidate the firm secured court approval, ushering in a final phase of a case that rattled Wall Street and prompted a federal investigation.

title: Ware Takes a Break, But Will Attend Louisvilles Game
description: ATLANTA  On Friday afternoon, dozens of reporters crowded into Breakout Room No. 1, where Louisville guard Kevin Ware, he of the gruesome leg injury in the N.C.A.A. tournament, was scheduled to speak. A placard with Wares name rested on the table. Scribes lined the wall. Cameras crowded together in the back.

title: The Employment Rate
description: Spare a moment for an overlooked economic indicator: The employment rate.

title: Two Dog Owners Arrested on Animal Cruelty Charges
description: Bentley, a fluffy shih tzu mix who lived in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was administered a beating that fractured his skull and jaw and caused brain hemorrhaging, animal welfare officials said.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Batman Team Back on Top
description: The unstoppable team of Scott Snyder and Greg Capullo is at No. 1 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, with Batman: The City of Owls, in which the caped crusader combats an evil tied to the earliest days of Gotham City. The top spot is not unfamiliar to Mr. Snyder and Mr. Capullo  they were there last month with Batman: Night of the Owls, another chapter in the superheros battle against the Court of Owls.

title: Vain Glorious | Olfactive Studio
description: Images and perfumes have always been linked, says Cline Verleure, a 20-year fragrance industry veteran based in Paris. When we smell a perfume, it gives us images in our heads, like a landscape or a scene. A few years ago, she decided to explore this relationship further by asking perfumers to collaborate with photographers on a series of eau de parfums inspired by the visual artists works. Thus, Olfactive Studio was born, and the French brands five highly concentrated unisex scents arrive in the United States on April 8. The perfumers are able to create on a spiritual level. Olivier Cresp, who worked on the Flash Back fragrance with the photographer Laurent Segretier, says theres a new and special freedom in starting with the visual, Verleure notes. Her current favorite in the lineup is Lumire Blanche, a milky yet fresh and spicy concoction from the perfumer Sidonie Lancesseur, who drew her inspiration from the famed photographer Massimo Vitalis picture of sunbathers gathered on the ivory-hued Scala dei Turchi cliff in southern Sicily. To fully experience the connection between the visual and olfactory elements, Verleure suggests first choosing a scent based on the image, which adorns the fragrance box, and then smelling the juice second. Pick the photo that gives you the most emotion, and you will really like that perfume. It works! she says.

title: Stock From Every Chicken
description: In todays video I demonstrate how to cut up a whole chicken, which is a worthwhile thing to know and not at all hard. I also show how to take the chicken back (and neck and innards, if your chicken came with them  not all of them do) and turn it into a small batch of chicken stock. I usually make the stock immediately after cutting up the chicken, but you could also save the back for later. You could freeze it if youve got the freezer space or, if you want to combine it with the leftover bones from the chicken you are cooking, like I did with the chicken curry that I describe in this weeks column, you can stick the back in the fridge for a day or two.

title: The Dark Side of Verbs-as-Nouns
description: In my previous essay, I wrote about nominalization  the deployment as nouns of words we mostly expect to encounter as verbs or adjectives. Aware of many peoples tendency to vilify this kind of usage, I speculated about the psychology behind it. I was interested in thinking about why someone might prefer Do you have a solve for this problem? to Can you solve this problem?

title: Easing Access to Contraception
description: The Timess Pam Belluck explains how the emergency nature of the morning-after pill pushed a federal judge to increase its availability.

title: Q & A
description: Dreaming of a Solarium

title: Friday Night Music: Fleetwood Mac
description: Its only Friday afternoon, but I have places to go and things to do.

title: Outside the Studio, Ramping Up the Funk
description: On the way from the studio to the stage, Jessie Wares songs got a big boost of funk and soul.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Baby Who Wont Eat Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 3-month-old baby who stopped eating and became weak. More than 700 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. More than 100 nailed the diagnosis. And I loved all the discussion!

title: Reclaim the Center
description: Not surprisingly, troubled economic times often beget proselytizers of wacky, extreme ideas. The stagflation of the 1970s blessed us with damaging wage and price controls and the utterly counterintuitive supply-side notion  famously drawn on a napkin  that cutting taxes would lead to higher tax revenues.

title: Even Its Players Learned About Wichita State on the Fly
description: ATLANTA  Do you know much about Wichita State University? No? You are not alone. Even the players on this years Final Four surprise team admitted to having little institutional knowledge about the university of roughly 12,000 undergraduates located in the largest city in Kansas.

title: Examining a Humor Born of Many Struggles
description: The choreographer Camille A. Brown begins Mr. TOL E. RAncE, a look at race, stereotypes and the way humor plays into them, with a video montage of numbers from minstrel shows. During the screening her dancers, wearing suspenders, gray suits and caps, quietly assemble onto a darkened stage as if in mourning.

title: Off the Shelf | Light Years
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Paradigm Shift | Tools for Life
description: After its sneak preview in January at the fall 2013 Prada mens fashion shows, Tools for Life, the furniture collection designed for Knoll by OMA, the architecture office that was co-founded by Rem Koolhaas, will make its official debut next week during the Salone Internazionale del Mobile in Milan. The collection, which will be on view April 9 and 10 at Pradas exhibition space at Via Fogazzaro 36, consists of pieces that address the increasingly blurred boundaries between working and living space by being kinetic rather than static. As Koolhaas said, his goal was to create furniture that performs in very precise but also in completely unpredictable ways and indeed, flexibility is the key here. A massive, heavily engineered piece called the 04 Counter consists of three horizontal bars that stack like a wall, but which can also pivot and cantilever, transforming the piece from room divider to piazza, as Benjamin Pardo, Knolls design director, called it, adding, Once people discover that the object moves, they want to engage with it.

title: A Motivational Thread Ties the Junction Boys to Rutgers
description: The death of Jack Pardee on Monday and the firing of the Rutgers mens basketball coach Mike Rice on Wednesday bring us to a compelling intersection of coaching norms and excessive behavior. They also remind us that the good old days werent all that good.

title: Financial Lessons for American Expatriates
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the tax rules in the United States that can trip up Americans living abroad. The rules have become tougher as the United States tries to find secret overseas accounts. And the rules are also affecting more people as more Americans find job opportunities far from home.

title: Malala Yousafzai Announces Grant for Girls Education
description: Malala Yousafzai, the teenaged Pakistani girl who was shot by the Taliban in 2012 because of her activism for girls education, has announced the first grant in an international fund set up in her name.

title: Raps Peter Pan Considers Alternatives
description: There are so many ways to be young: ignore responsibility, look wide-eyed at the world, rile up elders, dont deliver on promises, make fun of the incomprehensible, avoid feeling, believe in yourself over all others. Its part liability, part opportunity. Sometimes its a fixed condition, sometimes its a choice.

title: Vibrations From Brazil, Church and Deep in Your Headphones
description: Ensemble Pearl

title: A 2-Bedroom With a Home for the Car
description: It wasnt that Jennifer Song Kim liked moving so often, but that moving was a small and temporary hardship far outweighed by the chance to live in a new neighborhood. So she and Richard Kim, who were married a little more than four years ago, moved within Manhattan every time their lease was up.

title: Big Ticket | $10.2 Million for Sweeping Vistas
description: A duplex penthouse distinguished by a pair of romantic Moorish-style arched brick terraces near the top of the Barbizon/63, at 140 East 63rd Street, sold for $10,182,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Appily Ever After: A Smartphone Shrink
description: When I was a kid, my favorite toy was the Magic 8 Ball. There was something immensely comforting about asking this little gizmo a question (Will I find true love?), shaking it and then seeing the answer that would bubble to the top of the screen: Outlook good.

title: Wheelies: The Dear Leader Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Week in Review: Lessons From Top Women on Wall Street
description: Blame abounds over a flawed foreclosure review. | A lawsuit by the ex-wife of the SAC Capital founder is revived on appeal. | DealBooks special section: women in a mans world. | S.E.C. sets rules for disclosures using social media. | Andrew Ross Sorkin asks a $25 million question over a bid for Dell. | Pay for boards at banks soars amid cutbacks.

title: If Its Aliens, at Least They Wont Be Naked
description: Lots of outlets  Nickelodeon, ABC Family, the Disney Channel  have taken aim at that elusive, possibly nonexistent swath of Americans who just want to be able to watch television together as a family without worrying that something distasteful or inappropriate for children will pop up. But everyone seems to have a different idea of what kind of content that demographic craves.

title: Rundown and Cluttered, a Sacred Space for Music Prepares to Move
description: Four-fifty West 41st Street, a rundown blue-tiled former warehouse by the Lincoln Tunnel, is the unimpressive sort of city architecture that you walk by without noticing. A shaky elevator ride up to the sixth floor, and the rooms behind the white door hold a trove of bland metal desks overflowing with papers and office plants growing down a shelf of books.

title: A Bartenders Sojourn, Garnished With Adventure
description: PARIS  Its already 10:15 at night and Colin Field has been waiting for nearly three hours in a windowless, overheated bar at the back of a taco shop in the Marais district to create his new cocktail.

title: Boeings 787 Takes Flight to Assess New Battery
description: A Boeing 787 flew for nearly two hours on Friday in a flight that wrapped up the companys tests of modifications meant to prevent fires in its lithium-ion batteries.

title: MF Global Bankruptcy Saga
description: Whereas bailouts and rescues often obscure the dirty details of exactly why a particular financial institution failed, bankruptcies have a way of bringing everything to light.

title: Ex-Senator Is Tempted by Neighbor
description: If the special Senate election in Massachusetts has put the political cognoscenti to sleep, a possible race in neighboring New Hampshire may wake them up.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 5
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: A Quick Electronic Signature at the Car Rental Office, and Then Trouble
description: Sandra McKinnon knew the drill after three trips from Oakland, Calif., to Tulsa, Okla., to visit her elderly father. When she went to pick up a rental car, she would have to decide whether to buy the insurance.

title: Bending a Club Legend to His Own Purposes
description: One thing musicians often say about playing at the Village Vanguard, New Yorks oldest extant jazz club, is that you have to make your peace with the ghosts in the room. What that means has less to do with the spirit realm than with the specters of historical memory shaped by famous recordings and firsthand experiences, and made all the more immediate by the photographic portraits on the wall.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A six-bedroom colonial in New Rochelle, N.Y., that includes a stained glass dome, and a Tudor with a patio and pool in Nassau County, N.Y.

title: Obama Apologizes for Praising Attorney Generals Looks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama late Thursday night called Kamala Harris, the California attorney general, and apologized to her for telling a group of wealthy donors that she is the best-looking attorney general in the country.

title: Everybody Loses in This Beauty Contest
description: MY GUESS IS, in the pause following President Obamas comment by far the best-looking attorney general in the country  after he had praised Kamala Harriss achievements  some guests at the private fund-raiser in California cringed and said to themselves, Oh, no  he went there.

title: Running Into Problems at the Car Rental Counter
description: If youve ever rented a car, you know the questions that you need to be prepared to answer at the rental counter: Do you want insurance? Do you need it?

title: One Fish, Two Fish
description: Everyone knows fish is good for you, but many of us get stuck eating the same varieties  tuna, cod, salmon and shrimp. This week Martha Rose Shulman explores the flavor and benefits of trying new types of fish.

title: How Skeptics and Believers Can Connect
description: STANFORD, Calif.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Brooklyn Heights studio with a panoramic view, a SoHo prewar one-bedroom and an Upper West Side apartment with two bedrooms and a working fireplace.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 5
description: More photographs.

title: Ask Well: More Repetitions vs. More Weight?
description: Question:

title: Looking Ahead at Mad Men
description: Logan Hill and Sloane Crosley predict what season six of Mad Men has in store for viewers.

title: Do We Really Hate Anne Hathaway?
description: Will they ever stop hating on Anne Hathaway?

title: Embassy Warning Joins Drumbeat of North Korea Threats
description: MOSCOW  The North Korean government on Friday advised Russia and other countries to consider evacuating their embassies in Pyongyang amid rising tension there, Russias foreign minister said.

title: Hybrid Drivers Wanted
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Every major car company has its own DNA, a set of qualities that make it clear to drivers that they are behind the wheel of a Chevy, a Toyota or a BMW. And just like a healthy humans genetic code, automotive DNA should be an immutable thing, regardless of the technology powering the wheels.

title: Volkswagens New Frontier
description: The Jetta Hybrid represents uncharted territory for VW, whose identity is fundamentally characterized by the rumble of an efficient internal-combustion engine.

title: The Economys Spring Slide
description: The Timess Catherine Rampell and Nathaniel Popper on how slow payroll growth affects a struggling recovery.

title: A Cocktail of Beers, Pencils and a Model
description: Sunday nights used to be slow at Macri Park, a no-nonsense neighborhood bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But on a recent evening, patrons jammed into banquettes and sat on the floor, all eyeing Danny Casner, a 28-year-old tattooed bike messenger who wore nothing but black American Apparel underwear and checkered Vans.

title: Diesel Efficiency With a Solar Enhancement
description: TESTED: 2013 Volkswagen Beetle TDI convertible

title: How Do I Get My Child Into _____?
description: April 12 | Updated  Read Sarah Kramers interview with Robert Sanft.

title: Ebert Was a Critic Whose Sting Was Salved by Caring
description: By midafternoon on Thursday the digital common was crowded with mourners. #Ebert and #RIPEbert crowded out all the other hashtags on Twitter. Every movie blogger, entertainment journalist, critic and film buff who had crossed paths with Roger Ebert or absorbed his influence  which is to say just about all of us  posted an elegy or a reminiscence. Along with those collegial and filial tributes came salutes from filmmakers and a statement from the White House after his death at 70, almost surely the first time a film critic has been eulogized by a president.

title: The Catch of the Day in Amphawa
description: Vendors in the floating market of Amphawa, Thailand, display a recent catch of seafood from their small boats. Amphawa is located about an hour west of Bangkok, in the Samut Songkhram province. The picturesque village is known for canals that feed off the Mae Khlong River, where visitors can dine from the boats.

title: F.A.A. Delays Closings of Airport Towers Forced by Cuts
description: LEESBURG, Va.  The Federal Aviation Administration said Friday that it would delay closing control towers at 149 airports until June to allow for safety analyses and to attempt to resolve multiple legal challenges.

title: Wrestlings Private Equity Champion
description: Michael Novogratz, a principal at the Fortress Investment Group and former Princeton wrestler, is trying to score an emergency takedown.
