Since the International Olympic Committee voted to eliminate wrestling starting in 2020, Mr. Novogratz has been working the phones from a war room inside Fortresss 46th-floor headquarters in Midtown Manhattan.

title: The New WRX Concept Shows Off Subarus New Design Language
description: Osamu Namba, theSubaru design chief, made a surprise appearance at the New York International Auto Show last week for the unveiling of the new WRX concept. In an interview at the companys stand, he said the car presented the companys new design language, parts of which were seen in the Viziv concept shown at the Geneva auto show in March. As the most extreme of Subaru designs, the WRX offers the company a chance to render the new vocabulary in striking form.

title: The First Lady of Yoga
description: Vaguely indicating the lower torso, the word core has been rippling (as it were) through American fitness programs for about a decade. But the yogini Colleen Saidman Yee likes to be more specific.

title: As Workload Overwhelms, Cars Are Set to Intervene
description: Heading south on Route 34 toward Jersey Shore beaches on a summer weekend, drivers confront a daunting array of highway quirks, not limited to jughandle intersections and baffling exit signs.

title: Outside the Red Rooster, a Rare Break in the Bustle
description: In this weekends Food & Drink Issue, youll find something you might never otherwise see: nearly 130 employees of Marcus Samuelssons Harlem restaurant, Red Rooster, gathered in one place, and standing still. Stephen Wilkes photographed the group around 10 a.m. on a Saturday, and everyone  from the line cooks to the dishwashers to the chef himself  wore their work outfits. You can watch a time-lapse video of the shoot above, and see some behind-the-scenes photos of the day below.

title: Managing a Drivers Many Inputs
description: The study of driver workload management is progressing alongside the efforts of the planners who dream up new generations of infotainment features.

title: Mad, Mad World
description: Each week the author Sloane Crosley and the journalist Logan Hill will chat here about all things Mad Men.

title: A New Element for a Lawyers Victory, Long After Death
description: The vote on Thursday by Alabama lawmakers to issue posthumous pardons to the nine Scottsboro Boys would have pleased Samuel S. Leibowitz of Brooklyn.

title: Guide Revisions Provoke Uproar
description: Proposed changes to the used-car Buyers Guide required by the Federal Trade Commission have been criticized by consumer groups and the attorneys general of 22 states, who say the revisions would be a setback in consumer protection.

title: The Search for 9/11 Remains Goes On
description: Update, May 17: The office of the chief medical examiner is sifting through 590 cubic yards of material excavated from around the World Trade Center in search of fragments that may be human remains. On Thursday, two such fragments were recovered from the Vehicle Security Center area. That brought the total to 78 since work began on April 1; 44 from the C-Grid area outside the World Financial Center, 34 from the Vehicle Security Center.

title: Yankees Lose Another Shortstop Against the Tigers
description: DETROIT  It was six months ago that the Yankees were knocked out of the postseason here in humiliating fashion, barely scoring a run in Detroits four-game sweep. On Friday, the Yankees returned and immediately encountered more of the same.

title: Comparing Italian TV to The Truman Show, Italian Blogger Calls for Sweeping Reform
description: Beppe Grillo, the Italian populist who started the insurgent Five Star Movement online after he was barred from state television channels for his political comedy, plans to press for sweeping reform of Italys public broadcaster RAI through new legislation.

title: The Fries-With-That Economy
description: One of the more striking patterns in the recovery has been the fast clip of low-wage job growth. The best example of this is probably in food services and drinking places, which have been adding jobs for 37 consecutive months. (Employment over all has been growing for 30 consecutive months.) Over that time, eating and drinking places have added 856,200 jobs.

title: Donating Their No. 26 Jerseys to Aid Newtown
description: HAMDEN, Conn.  Dave Clarke, the womens soccer coach at Quinnipiac University, was exchanging instant messages with Lauren Carmody Grenier, a former team captain, on the morning of Dec. 14. It was the type of online tte--tte in which spelling and punctuation were secondary to speed.

title: The Highest-Paid C.E.O.s
description: 100 of the most highly paid chief executives at U.S. public companies in 2012.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Mali, China and Gaza Strip.

title: Anheuser-Busch Merger Deal Clears an Antitrust Hurdle
description: 8:46 p.m. | Updated

title: Bill Cunningham | Parading
description: On Fifth Avenue, the public still enjoys dressing up for Easter and making their own looks.

title: An Ensemble in Flux Plays Pieces From Its Past
description: In the long months that have passed since the conductor James Levine resigned from his position as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in September 2011, the ensemble has seemed caught up in questions of what it is and what it will be. Mr. Levines seven-season tenure brought artistic progress but also mounting frustration regarding his increasing inability to work due to injury and illness.

title: Queer Theory May Not Have a Beat, but Academicians Can Still Dance to It
description: The gender theorist Judith Butler has been assailed by critics as the academic worlds worst writer. But on Thursday night at the downtown performance space Dixon Place, she was celebrated as the Girl From Ipanema.

title: Young, Quicksilver and Never Daunted
description: For its premiere in 1984 at City Center, Murray Louiss Four Brubeck Pieces was accompanied by none other than the Dave Brubeck Quartet. When Juilliard students danced the work on Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, the four Brubeck songs were played by a crack quartet of Juilliard jazz musicians. Not a bad substitute, really.

title: Fisker Automotive Lays Off Majority of Employees
description: Fisker Automotive, the maker of a $100,000-and-up plug-in hybrid luxury sedan, said on Friday that about three-quarters of its workers had been let go to allow the company to work through its current financial challenges.

title: JPMorgan Works to Avert Split of Chief and Chairman Roles
description: JPMorgan Chase is working behind the scenes to avert a major potential embarrassment.

title: Traditional Polish Fare for the Early Birds
description: The cozy dining room at Krakowiak Restaurant is nothing fancy, and the service is brisk, but the plain food is carefully prepared, thoughtfully presented and delicious in a way that recalls a past era. That could explain the steady stream of customers on my visits, maybe half of them in their 60s or older, all of them entering as if they knew every nook in the place.

title: Photo Replay: April 5
description: A view of the day in sports, including wall-to-wall defense in Denver.

title: Discuss Tensions on the Korean Peninsula
description: As our colleague Martin Fackler reports, Despite the steady drum beat of war talk, life seems to go on as usual in most of South Korea, even near the heavily fortified border that separates the American ally from the increasingly belligerent North.

title: Beyond the Whimsy, Sushi With Ambition
description: Once upon a time there was Once Upon a Moose, a quirky little landmark of a lunch place that you took your mother to for tea and an omelet after browsing the used books in one of the eclectic cliff-top shops down the street. It had a run for decades in its prime corner spot in tiny Sea Cliff; then the site was briefly home to Olives by the Sea, a boho tapas bistro.

title: Week in Pictures, April 4
description: A look back at the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Investigation Report on Mike Rice
description: A report by outside counsel commissioned by Rutgers on how to handle concerns of abusive behavior by Mike Rice, who was fired this week as the mens basketball coach.

title: Dell Offers to Reimburse Icahn for Deal Work, With Strings Attached
description: A special committee of Dells board offered on Friday to reimburse Carl C. Icahn up to $25 million worth of expenses tied to a possible bid for the computer company  provided that he plays nicely.

title: From Scratch, Making Meals Appear
description: The drab-gray exterior of 50 West does little to attract attention, and compared with the towering pink neon and gleaming chrome facade of a neighboring diner, it appears to be a model of discretion. That sense of subtlety is reinforced by rooms simply decorated with honey oak paneling, washed-mango paint, a few mirrors and glass chandeliers.

title: U.S. and Japan Agree on Returning Okinawa Land
description: TOKYO  The United States and Japan agreed Friday on a new timetable for the return to Japan of a Marine airfield and other military bases on Okinawa, moving to solve a long-festering issue that has bedeviled Americas ties with its largest Asian ally.

title: Jacoby Open Swiss Teams at Spring Nationals
description: ST. LOUIS  On the final day of the Spring Nationals here last month, the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams were captured by Richard Schwartz of Aventura, Fla.; Allan Graves of St. Johnsbury, Vt.; Boye Brogeland and Espen Lindqvist from Norway; and Jon Baldursson and Thorlakur Jonsson from Iceland.

title: Fake Twitter Followers Become Multimillion-Dollar Business
description: Far from slowing, the market for fake Twitter followers seems to be taking off.

title: Germans See Hope in Leak for Fighting Tax Evasion
description: BERLIN  Typically, major countries issue ringing denunciations when privacy guarantees are breached and secret information is disclosed, particularly when such disclosures concern those nations wealthiest individuals. But the leak this week of information on tens of thousands of offshore accounts, many set up by German banks, was received with glee by German officials.

title: A Mixture of Mexican Hustle and Charm
description: On our first visit to Guapo Cocina Mexicana, two of my guests stood outside and peered through the plate-glass window while I fed the parking meter. By the time I joined them, they wore big grins: the manager of the restaurant, sensing an opportunity, had come out into the cold and handed them coupons for free margaritas. It was this mix of hustle and charm offensive  and lively, well-priced, authentic Mexican dishes  that had us developing a little crush on Guapo.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: To the Editor:

description: Not since 1979 has such a small share of the population been working or actively looking for a job.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Ten Years Later, McNamara Hopes Hes Still on Target
description: ATLANTA  A smile worked its way across Gerry McNamaras face as he described the 10-year-old feeling that will never be forgotten. His eyes widened, his mouth perked up and he failed to contain the grin of a shooter talking about a time the basket never seemed bigger.

title: Assaults in Istanbul
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Composer Who Escapes Easy Labels
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The path to the music room in Steven Mackeys spacious Princeton home is lined with toys: a phalanx of toddler-size vehicles, a toy kitchen, a Thomas the Tank Engine table crisscrossed with rail tracks. Next to the brightly colored plastic objects, the black grand piano takes on the wryly amused look of a buttoned-up uncle at a birthday party, besieged on all sides by cheerful chaos.

title: Week in Pictures for April 5
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a baby giraffe, the Yankees opening day and political corruption.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Street Art of the Arab World on YouTube
description: The Cairene journalist and blogger Soraya Morayef, who has written extensively about the Egyptian revolutions graffiti, has produced a series of new video reports on street art of the Arab world, as part of a series for MOCAtv, the YouTube channel of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Silicon Valley Poverty and Verizon Contracts
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Family Seeks Return of a Matisse Seized by the Nazis
description: The heirs of a French art dealer are demanding that a Norwegian museum return one of its featured paintings, a Matisse that was confiscated by the Nazis in 1941 in Paris.

title: An Unorthodox Look at a Presidents Home
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.  Early last year, shortly after Theodore Roosevelts stately home, Sagamore Hill, was closed to the public for a three-year, $7.2 million restoration, a photographer who uses the name Xiomro was allowed into the 23-room mansion to take pictures. Many of the homes 14,000 objects had already been placed in storage or moved elsewhere, and he didnt have to stand behind the velvet ropes that prevent ordinary visitors from getting too close to the elaborate wallpaper, fancy woodwork and handsome fireplace mantels of the house where the 26th president lived from 1887 until his death in 1919 (except when he lived in the White House from 1901 to 1909).

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Drawing Evolves, Testing Its Boundaries
description: While drawing once served an auxiliary function  that is, as studies for paintings, sculpture and architecture  over the last century it became a stand-alone medium. And like other art media in this age of cultural and technological flux and innovation, its definition is often pushed to the limits. You can sense this just from the title of Extreme Drawing at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Settlement Is Reached With Family in Slaying
description: MIAMI  The parents of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed teenager who was shot by George Zimmerman last year, have settled a wrongful-death lawsuit against the homeowners association in the gated community where he was killed.

title: Cuomo Picks Judge in City to Fill Spot at Top Court
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo nominated Justice Sheila Abdus-Salaam on Friday to fill a vacancy on the states highest court, and if confirmed, she would become the first African-American woman to serve on it.

title: Interfaith Unions: A Mixed Blessing
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

title: In Jodhpurs, Hailing Caesar With Seduction
description: The director David McVicars imaginative, daffy and affecting production of Handels Giulio Cesare, which opened at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night, is new to the company but not to the opera world. It was introduced at the Glyndebourne Festival in England in 2005, has played there and elsewhere since then, and is available on DVD.

title: Giulio Cesare
description: An imaginative Giulio Cesare at the Metropolitan Opera, with David Daniels and Natalie Dessay.

title: Rubio, Amid Planning, Is Yet to Commit on Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON  When Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, last appeared with a bipartisan group of senators to discuss their plans for a broad overhaul of the nations immigration laws, he looked optimistic, apple-cheeked  and slightly nervous.

title: Steak for Two, Please, With a Side of Bribes
description: One day in December, a member of the New York State Assembly walked into Peter Luger, the Brooklyn steakhouse against which all others are compared.

title: If the Church Is Serious About Welcoming Gays...
description: IN an Easter morning appearance on ABCs This Week, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, spoke words that some gay and lesbian Catholics thought they might never hear.

title: Americas Left Bank
description: Greenwich Village was, from the beginning, home to the citys outliers, New Yorkers who for one reason or another escaped or were exiled from the teeming, pestilent, Tory, boss-controlled and buttoned-down tip of Downtown Manhattan to the Left Bank of America.

title: With All Its Titles, Bayern Munich Hungers for an Elusive One
description: BERLIN  They wear red uniforms, have an unfair concentration of top athletic talent and are crushing the rest of their league into submission. They are not the Miami Heat, but Germanys F.C. Bayern Munich.

title: U.S. Spurns California Move for Greater Say on Prisons
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge on Friday rejected Californias motion to regain control of mental health care in its prisons, ruling that the quality of care failed to meet standards required by the Constitution. The move dealt a blow to Gov. Jerry Browns broader efforts to bring the prisons back under the states authority.

title: As Brazils Influence Expands, So Does a Campaign Strategists Success
description: SO PAULO, Brazil

title: Breach Through Fire Island Also Divides Opinions
description: FIRE ISLAND, N.Y.  If on some stretches of this barrier island the scars of Hurricane Sandy are fading, at a spot called Old Inlet, a physical reminder of the storm remains: a channel, now 856 feet wide, through which seawater pours into the Great South Bay. The breach, in a federal wilderness area at the eastern end of the island, has already helped clean the much-compromised bay.

title: A Shaman, Coaxing Sobriety
description: One by one they squeezed into a meeting room at a Harlem needle exchange on Thursday  roughly two dozen men and women with drug problems  and Dimitri Mugianis, 50, greeted them all.

title: Recent Polling on Nationwide Gun Control
description: Recent Polling on Nationwide Gun Control

title: A Suburban Standoff
description: For the past year, the 32-year-old mayor of Ellisville, Mo., has been at war with its City Council, which is now trying to remove him from office.

title: Impeachment Proceedings Break a Small Towns Quiet
description: ELLISVILLE, Mo.  At a glance, this town of 9,000 offers the peaceful allure of suburban American life: good schools, tranquil, neatly manicured housing developments and large strip malls accommodating myriad retail needs.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. Thomas F. Byrnes, who became New York Citys chief of detectives in 1880, is often credited with establishing the first extensive illustrated police catalog of known criminals, as the F.Y.I. column of Jan. 20 reported. But hadnt the New York Police Department opened a rogues gallery of photographs of villains well before his time?

title: Jury Still Out on Killer of Psychologist
description: Jurors in the trial of David Tarloff, a schizophrenic man charged in the 2008 murder of an Upper East Side psychologist, finished their third day of deliberations on Friday without reaching a verdict.

title: Local Stop: Bay Ridge
description: In Bay Ridge, urban meets suburban, and many cultures mingle.

title: Detecting Shift, U.S. Makes Case to China on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, detecting what it sees as a shift in decades of Chinese support for North Korea, is pressuring Chinas new president, Xi Jinping, to crack down on the regime in Pyongyang or face a heightened American military presence in its region.

title: Texas Police Seeking Clues to How Killer Got in Home
description: KAUFMAN, Tex.  Investigators looking for clues in the killing of the local district attorney and his wife are trying to answer a key question about the crime: did the couple know the person or people who shot them?

title: Players Club Removes Director Amid Turmoil
description: The Players, a 124-year-old private club on Gramercy Park, removed its long-serving executive director this week amid charges of financial mismanagement, several members and employees said on Friday.

title: Death Again Visits a Racecourse on Trial
description: AINTREE, England  The death of a second horse in two days at the Grand National meeting at Aintree Racecourse has dampened spirits on the eve of the 166th running of the Grand National steeplechase, a race that animal rights groups declared to be on a yellow card after a run of 18 deaths in the past 20 years, including four in the past two races.

title: Where Urban Meets Suburban
description: Looped by parkways and bounded to the west by shoreline, Bay Ridge looks self-contained on a map: an island at the edge of Brooklyn. But the neighborhood is anything but insular. Italian specialty shops, Turkish diners, Norwegian delis and Lebanese restaurants along Third and Fourth Avenues suggest its richly diverse population. And Bay Ridges streets seem similarly mixed  decidedly urban on one block, suburban on the next.

title: Hepatitis Alert for Restaurants Diners
description: Diners who recently ate at a West Village restaurant may be at risk of contracting hepatitis A and should be vaccinated, the New York City health department said on Friday.

title: Storm Debris Transformed by a Treehouse Architect, or a Big Bird
description: Of all the trees toppled in the city by Hurricane Sandy, perhaps none had been more lovely than those in public gardens and arboretums. At Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the storms victims included Persian ironwood, persimmon, black walnut and Japanese flowering cherry trees.

title: U.N. Says It Is Running Out of Money to Assist Wave of Refugees From Syria
description: GENEVA  The United Nations will soon have to start cutting off lifesaving aid to people fleeing the war in Syria because the exodus has far outstripped financial support from international donors, one agency at the center of the humanitarian relief effort warned on Friday.

title: Good Sense on the Morning-After Pill
description: A federal district judge in New York has overturned the Obama administrations ban preventing girls younger than 17 from purchasing emergency contraceptive pills over the counter. It was a well-deserved rebuke to a politically motivated decision that overrode sound science and the health needs of young girls in order to placate political opponents of emergency contraception.

title: A Tax Scandal Adds to French Malaise
description: France is reeling from a scandal all but guaranteed to widen the chasm between its recession-battered voters and a Socialist government still peddling fiscal austerity.

title: Hunger Strike at Guantnamo
description: The hunger strike that has spread since early February among the 166 detainees still at Guantnamo Bay is again exposing the lawlessness of the system that marooned them there. The government claims that around 40 detainees are taking part. Lawyers for detainees report that their clients say around 130 detainees in one part of the prison have taken part.

title: Progress on Okinawa
description: Tensions in Okinawa over the American military presence on that island have festered for decades. On Friday, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan showed political leadership by agreeing with the United States on a timetable for reducing the size of the American force and returning some land used as a military base.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Apr. 6, 2013
description: "I started crawling. Id stop for a few minutes, then start crawling again.

title: Crosswords, Cooking and Other Sports
description: Last week, Ron Darling, the retired starting pitcher for the New York Mets, returned to work as an announcer for his former team on TBS and SportsNet New York. Mr. Darling, 52, is doing commentary at several games a week, including Sundays against the Miami Marlins at Citi Field. During the season, Mr. Darling, who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with his wife, Joanna, an interior designer, spends his Sundays at the ballpark; the rest of the year, his weekends are more family-oriented.

title: Carmine Infantino, Reviver of Batman and Flash, Dies at 87
description: Carmine Infantino  the man who SAVED BATMAN!  died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Infantino, a celebrated comic-book artist who also drew the Flash, was 87.

title: Video Reviews Can Be Accidental Game Changers
description: ATLANTA  The last 10 minutes of a college basketball game will never be described as crisp. Between television stoppages and a never-ending procession of coaches timeouts, the average fan watching an N.C.A.A. tournament game often sees an abundance of commercials, countless team huddles and the odd spurt of game action, which typically has all the rhythm of rush-hour traffic.

title: Corrections: April 6, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Less Culpable, but With Longer Sentences
description: PHOENIX  Members of a white supremacy group descended on a home here 11 years ago to scare a man into paying back the $200 his roommate had accused him of stealing. The attack ended in the mans death.

title: Debating Death Penalties
description: Prosecutors in many of the states that carry the death penalty have to weigh the high cost of mounting a capital trial against the likelihood of a conviction when deciding whom to charge.

title: Label for the Bee Gees
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  One of the most wonderful and frustrating aspects of solving a Saturday crossword puzzle is the tease: just enough stuff you know in order to get a toehold, combined with tough-as-nails clues that stop you dead in your tracks the first time you look through them.

title: U.S. Attorney Added Staff to Fight Corruption
description: The two federal cases that mesmerized Albany this week  a state senator accused of trying to bribe his way onto the New York City mayoral ballot and an assemblyman charged with taking payoffs to write made-to-order legislation  come as federal prosecutors in Manhattan have increased their focus on political corruption, officials said on Friday.

title: Ties Between Congress and the Tax Lobby
description: Analysis of lobby filings show ties between Congress and the tax lobby.

title: Back in Majors, Pitcher Maine Denies Lying to Mets in 2010
description: The last five pitches of John Maines time with the Mets were the most painful of his career, not because of what he felt in his shoulder, but because of what was said about him afterward.

title: Paying Respect to Ancestors
description: Families gathered at a cemetery in Westchester County to honor their ancestors before the Chinese festival Qingming.

title: Chinese Families Celebrate Qingming Festival in New York
description: VALHALLA, N.Y.  Three generations of the Cung family gathered at Kensico Cemetery in Westchester County last Sunday to place cans of guava juice, paper money, paper dress shoes and a paper copy of a Louis Vuitton purse before the headstone of Lien Sau Khau, the family matriarch. The offerings were later set aflame, sending them to Ms. Lien to use in the other world.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 5, 2013

title: New Name Near Top Isnt a Shock to Everyone
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The appearance near the top of the Kraft Nabisco Championship leader board of Jodi Ewart Shadoff, a nonwinner on the L.P.G.A. Tour, came as no surprise to the sports anchor where she lives in Sarasota, Fla. He pointed out that Ewart Shadoff ranked second on the tour in greens in regulation and was in the top 25 in driving accuracy.

title: Asteroid Wanted in NASA Project
description: The budget being readiedby the Obama administration has one item that mightsound outlandish: nabbingan asteroid.

title: Renaissance in Grand Central
description: Members of the Renaissance Street Singers perform free concerts in Grand Central Terminal over the winter months.

title: First Traveler on Unusual Route to Masters
description: As dusk settled over Augusta National Golf Club in January, John Peterson prepared to play the famous par-3 12th hole, the most photographed golf real estate in the world. The moment was overwhelming, so he backed away from the ball.

title:
In Connecticut,
New Firearms
Limits Faced
Uphill Fight
description: HARTFORD  Almost from the moment that Adam Lanza ended his siege, it seemed that Connecticut, dominated by Democrats and already with some of the nations toughest gun laws, would quickly pass sweeping new restrictions on firearms.

title: Veterans Programs Are Set for Raise in Spending Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Facing growing criticism from Congress, veterans groups and even late-night television hosts, the Obama administration announced on Friday that it would include significant increases for veterans programs, including money for mental health services, in the budget it unveils next week.

title: Why Rutgers Blinked
description: ATLANTA

title: A New Era in Political Corruption
description: Have you ever noticed how high the bar is when it comes to getting arrested for political corruption? Really, you practically have to go around with a sign that says Will Trade Influence for Cash.

title: The Young are the Restless
description: The surge of generational change continues in this country, altering the cultural landscape with a speed and intensity that has rarely  if ever  been seen before.

title: Giants Raise Banner and Remind Cardinals How They Won It
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The last time the Giants raised a championship banner, after their 2010 World Series victory, it came on a wave of civic incredulity that such a thing could happen after a 56-year dry spell.

title: Singing Sacred Songs in Secular Spots
description: On a recent Sunday afternoon, 17 people with sheet music gathered in a semicircle in the Graybar Passage at Grand Central Terminal. People streamed by. After a brief warm-up, the groups conductor, John Hetland, dressed in dark jeans and a green plaid shirt, lifted his hands and the chorus began its a cappella rendition of a polyphonic hymn, Kyrie, by the 15th-century German composer Heinrich Finck.

title: Burnsides Police State
description: Near dawn on March 24, 1863, Maj. Gen. Ambrose E. Burnside stepped off a train in Cincinnati. The tall, bald, magnificently bewhiskered soldier arrived from Washington to take command of the Armys Department of the Ohio, an enormous command that encompassed Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Illinois and most of Kentucky. His orders from the War Department were to collect troops and prepare to lead an invasion of eastern Tennessee. In the meantime, though, he also had to deal with the roiling antiwar politics of the Ohio Valley.

title: A Final Round of Applause
description: Elaine Stritch, now 88, is packing it in, but not quietly, of course.

title: Robert Remini, Exhaustive Andrew Jackson Biographer, Dies at 91
description: Robert V. Remini, an admired historian best known for his study of Andrew Jackson, including an exhaustive three-volume biography that traced how the seventh president harnessed his populist appeal to wield unusual executive power, died on March 28 in Evanston, Ill. He was 91.

title: Newcomer to Penguins Beats Lundqvist and Rangers in Shootout
description: PITTSBURGH  The game had a playoff feel to it, fast and desperate, hard-hitting and angry, with accusations flying afterward like pucks and errant elbows. The Penguins won, 2-1, in a shootout, but the Rangers were encouraged by a tenacious performance that earned them a precious point in the standings.

title: Exiting, Stage Center
description: Elaine Stritch is leaving New York.

title: Knicks Win 11th Straight as Anthony Hits 40 Again
description: Amid the dreamscape that has been the Knicks recent surge, various obstacles have threatened to derail them, though none with much success.

title: Editor Who Wrote of Racism in Cuba Loses His Post, Colleagues Say
description: MEXICO CITY  The editor of a publishing house in Cuba who wrote a critical article in The New York Times opinion section about persistent racial inequality on the island, something revolutionaries proudly say has lessened, has been removed from his post, associates said on Friday.

title: Arrests by the Fashion Police
description: Here is a vignette from March 2013: A 24-year-old gay man named Yhatzine Lafontain is leaving a restaurant late at night with a friend on Roosevelt Avenue and 95th Street in Queens. Both are dressed as women, Mr. Lafontain in a jacket, short dress and heels. Exchanging goodbyes outside, they are approached by a man who tells them they look good.

title: Newly Rebuilding Marlins Beat Long-Rebuilding Mets
description: A year ago, when the Mets and the Marlins first faced each other at Citi Field, the question entering the series was how fans would receive shortstop Jose Reyes, who had left New York to sign a big free-agent contract with Miami in the off-season. Would they cheer? Would they boo?

title: Williams Sisters Win Four Times in One Day
description: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C.  Unusual things can bloom after a heavy rainfall. Witness Fridays unorthodox but highly entertaining schedule at the Family Circle Cup, which featured a quadruple-header for the Williams sisters.

title: Programs Change, but Pitinos Methods Do Not
description: ATLANTA  The laboratory back then was Case Gymnasium, a cozy cedar closet of an arena that must have felt like a casino floor to the mens basketball team at Boston University. The windows were taped over for practice, and the clocks were, too. Rick Pitino was a first-time head coach who possessed the energy of an uncoiled spring, and to change what he considered a culture of losing at B.U., he needed his players to run and run and run  two, three, sometimes even four times a day.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) DARK SHADOWS (2012) Johnny Depp, above, summons the spirit of the romantic vampire hero Barnabas Collins in Tim Burtons revisiting of a 1960s daytime soap opera. Eva Green plays the maid Angelique, who paws at Barnabass body. Bella Heathcote is Josette, who runs off with his heart. Threes a crowd, and the witchy Angelique casts a spell that leaves Josette dead and Barnabas bereft  and leads to a timeout in a deep grave, where, after 200 years of entombment, he awakes in 1972, like a thirstier Rip Van Winkle. Barnabass liberation does the same for Mr. Depps performance, and its delightful to watch how the actor handles the vampires readjustment to the world of the living, which, after he has thrown back some invigorating human Slurpees and faced down a demon (a car), he does with both lofty entitlement and abject bewilderment, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Dark Shadows isnt among Mr. Burtons most richly realized works, but its very enjoyable, visually sumptuous and, despite its lugubrious source material and a sporadic tremor of violence, surprisingly effervescent, she added. And while there may not be any deeper resonance lurking in his Dark Shadows  the show first surfaced in the middle of the Vietnam War, when real horror was playing out daily in the news  Mr. Burtons gift for deviant beauty and laughter has its own liberating power.

title: Michigan Assistant a Showman, Too
description: ATLANTA  Somehow, they all work, the varied elements of Bacari Alexanders story. Somehow, it all ties together, from the streets of Detroit to the Harlem Globetrotters to the Michigan Wolverines, from nutcrackers to construction hard hats to sledgehammers, from custom suits to Magic Circles to basketballs that spin forever on his index fingers.

title: Online Betting Site Intrade Faces Liquidation
description: The online betting Web site Intrade, which gained widespread notice for serving as a predictions platform for elections and events not related to sports, is facing liquidation because of a $700,000 cash shortfall, a development that comes a month after it halted trading and froze its customer accounts.

title: 73 Knicks, Including Jackson, Get a Garden Welcome
description: Phil Jackson does not spend much time wading in old memories or romanticizing his past. He is not the sentimental type. But when the 1973 Knicks call, Jackson answers.

title: Final Four at a Glance
description: A look at the Final Four teams in the mens N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Uncovering Lost Footage
description: MSG Network hired Maurice Schechter to restore damaged tapes and prepare them to be televised as part of its 40th anniversary commemoration of the Knicks second title.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 6
description: NEWS North Koreas torrent of threats  and the matching show of military power and political resolve from the United States and South Korea  began showing signs of unsettling foreign investors confidence Friday. South Korean stocks slumped 1.64 percent Friday in a selling spree among foreign investors that analysts attributed to jitters over North Korea. The South Korean won also sank against the U.S. dollar.  Choe Sang-hun reports from Seoul.

title: The Early Word: Calamity
description: Todays Times

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Haryana: President Pranab Mukherjee rejected the mercy petition of Dharampal, who was convicted of raping a woman in Sonepat, Haryana, in 1991 and murdering five members of the victims family, The Indian Express reported. He will be hanged next week, the report said.

title: Of Karaoke Kings and Pinball Wizards. Whats Your Pleasure?
description: As I worked on This Is Who Rules the Bars of New York, my roundup in this weekends Food & Drink Issue of people who excel in activities like trivia and Ping-Pong at bars, I thought a lot about what exactly constitutes a bar pastime. Darts and pinball seem obvious. Bocce and drawing, less so.

title: Sunni Leader Is Named Prime Minister in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tammam Salam, scion of a prominent political family, was officially named the new prime minister of Lebanon on Saturday after receiving a string of endorsements from the countrys warring factions over the past few days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nuclear Talks With Iran End Without Accord or Plans for Another Round
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Negotiations over Irans disputed nuclear program broke off Saturday with scant signs of progress, much less an agreement on tighter controls demanded by six world powers in exchange for some easing of sanctions that have a stranglehold on the Iranian economy.

title: We Get Results, Japan Edition
description: Let it not be said that the scribblings of academic economists have no effect. Some of us have been urging the Bank of Japan to get truly aggressive and adventurous on monetary policy  and its happening!

title: Europe Doesnt Trust Its Politicians. Whats the Alternative?
description: LONDON  Is Europes long-running economic drama in danger of turning into a political crisis?

title: Five Killed in Years Deadliest Attack on Americans in Afghanistan
Self- Improvement in a Bull Market
description: THE stock market is up, and your home  if you own one  is probably worth more than it was at the real estate markets nadir. So the odds are that you are feeling a bit better about your financial self these days.

title: Mandela Released From Hospital
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela, South Africas first black president, was discharged from a hospital on Saturday after a nine-day stay to receive treatment for pneumonia, the South African government said.

title: In Exchange-Traded Funds, a Variable Worth Watching
description: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds that track indexes may sound like straightforward investments. Because they tend to have low fees and can be used to build diversified portfolios, as well as for esoteric strategies, E.T.F.s are wildly popular among individual and institutional investors alike. But even when E.T.F.s appear simple, there may be more risk than meets the eye.

title: Why Solar Power Stocks Are Still Earthbound
description: LONG-SUFFERING investors in solar energy stocks had reason to enjoy the first six weeks of 2013. After several years of poor performance while the overall market advanced, solar and other green energy technologies were market leaders early this year.

title: Money Funds, Waiting for the Fog to Lift
description: THIS is the kind of market that makes cautious investors long for the comfort of cash.

title: A Low-Growth World Can Also Mean High Profits
description: ECONOMIC growth has been subdued for so long that conditions that used to seem like busts are starting to look like booms.

title: The Kitchen-Table Sequester
description: KNOW whos really great? Our elected representatives in Washington, thats who.

title: Vows: Headhunter / Matchmaker
description: For work, Andy Hunter matches executives with jobs; for fun he matches hearts. He and his wife, Sarah Hunter, have played matchmaker for five married couples, including a niece, Sally King McBride.

title: Variety: An Ideal Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I loved this acrostic, and not just because Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are two of my favorite constructors. It just has so many things going for it.

title: Latecomers, Flocking to the Party
description: AFTER long spurning the bull market for fear of being burned again, investors have finally given in this year. They have abandoned their aversion to stock funds, pouring more money into them in January than in any other month ever.

title: 2 Weeks Before Iraqi Local Elections, Deadly Bombs Hit Campaign Event
description: BAGHDAD  Two explosions, the first from a suicide bomber and the second from a homemade bomb, ripped through a tent at a political rally on Saturday in Baquba, north of the capital, where voters and candidates had gathered for lunch.

title: Woods, Putting Well and Seemingly at Peace, Is Masters Favorite Again
description: Like the towering oak outside Augusta Nationals clubhouse, Tiger Woods will cast a considerable shadow over this years Masters. With his trunk once again in perfect alignment over putts, Woods, a four-time champion, arrives at the mens first major of the year as the worlds No. 1 golfer and the prohibitive favorite.

title: Imagining the Majors With No Nicklaus or Woods
description: Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods  you cant have one without the other. As the Masters approaches, they embody a golf question for the ages. You cant discuss Jacks record 18 major titles without wondering if Tiger, who has 14, will surpass him.

title: A Gun Guys Argument
description: The Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera talks to Dan Baum, a gun owner and a self-described liberal, about the role gun guys can play in solving the problem of violence in America.

title: Thinking Small, and Winning Big, at Three Funds
description: BACK in the 1970s, the British economist E. F. Schumacher declared that Small Is Beautiful, in a short book that was part environmental manifesto and part broadside against corporate bigness.

title: Health Policy Is in Flux, and So Are 2 Health Funds
description: THE Affordable Care Act, a k a Obamacare, isnt the only upheaval in the health care sector lately. Health care mutual funds have experienced tumult, too.

title: In Shift, Police Advise Taking an Active Role to Counter Mass Attacks
description: The speed and deadliness of recent high-profile shootings have prompted police departments to recommend fleeing, hiding or fighting in the event of a mass attack, instead of remaining passive and waiting for help.

title: Recruiting a Recruiter for Your Next Job
description: Q. Some of your friends and colleagues have used a recruiter to find jobs, and you are thinking of doing the same. How do you find good recruiters in your industry?

title: Cover to Cover, and Beyond
description: ALTHOUGH most of the mail that comes to the public editors office can be described as frustrated complaints (Misleading headline! Wrongheaded columnist! Enough about Brooklyn already!), there is a second category of correspondence. Lets call it perfectly reasonable questions.

title: Turning Around a Life Adrift
description: JONESBORO, Ark.

title: Florida Algae Bloom Leads to Record Manatee Deaths
description: Floridas endangered manatees, already reeling from an unexplained string of deaths in the states east coast rivers, have died in record numbers from a toxic red algae bloom that appears each year off the states west coast, state officials and wildlife experts say.

title: Ebbets, His Team and His Ballpark
description: Charles H. Ebbets grew up on Spring Street in Manhattan, but he became inextricably linked with Brooklyn by the time he was a young man.

title: What Gun Lovers Think
description: IN most respects, Dan Baum is a political liberal. But he has always had a thing for guns and has just written a book, Gun Guys: A Road Trip, which is part gun country travelogue and part meditation on what it means to be a gun lover at this particular moment. Baum, who lives in Colorado, agreed to come to New York, where he grew up, to debate the issue with me.

title: Big Thoughts, Early On
description: I WAS born in Hong Kong and immigrated to the United States with my family when I was 4. I spent most of my childhood in Chicago. My elementary school had no program in English as a second language, so I was placed in a class for students with speech impediments. It worked out well because we had to pronounce sounds over and over, and Im told that I dont have an accent today.

title: Shifting Our Retirement Savings Into Automatic
description: MANY problems are so complex that even if we had the money to fix them, we wouldnt know how to do it. Fixing inner-city schools, reducing obesity, creating peace in the Middle East are just a few examples.

title: How Texas Became Texas and Why It Matters
description: AS a Texas-raised journalist, I can tell you two things with confidence about my native state. One, its economy has been humming nicely for years. Two, this appears to greatly offend a certain breed of Northern writer, several of whom have descended on the state in an attempt to rebut stories of a Texas miracle. Their reports, Erica Grieder writes, have contributed to a widespread impression that Texas is corrupt, callous, racist, theocratic, stupid, belligerent, and most of all, dangerous.

title: Europes Markets, No Longer in Lock Step
description: ALTHOUGH the overall European economy is stuck in neutral at best, the regions stock market may have turned a corner in the first quarter.

title: The Infinity Pool of Executive Pay
description: RELAX. Sit back. And forget, for a moment, those pesky shareholders and bothersome boards, the regulations, the investigations and all the other headaches of being a chief executive today.

title: If Shareholders Say Enough Already, the Board May Listen
description: RAISES may be hard-won for most American workers these days, but for those fortunate few in the executive suite, the pay increases just keep on coming. Last year, the median chief executive at a United States company with more than $5 billion in revenue received about $14 million, 2.8 percent more than in 2011, according to an annual pay analysis conducted by Equilar. The 2012 increase, though relatively modest, still represents a raise for most of those who inhabit the corner office (and whose companies had filed the data by the end of March).

title: Far From Reservation, Sisters Lead Louisville
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Louisville had just advanced to the womens Final Four, and the sisters Shoni and Jude Schimmel had helped cut the nets in celebration, a rare achievement for American Indian athletes. But it was not the biggest family news of the day.

title: At Intersection of Fading Eras in Womens Game
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: First, Make Sure Your Idea Works on a Small Stage
description: This interview with  Francesca Zambello, general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Festival and artistic director of the Washington National Opera, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Dont Know Much About Gun Laws
description: IN polls, a slight majority of Americans consistently say that we need better enforcement of our gun laws. But theres a problem with that: many dont really know what our gun laws are.

title: Bayern Munich Clinches Bundesliga Title
description: Bayern Munich made history in Germany on Saturday when Bastian Schweinsteigers backheel flick off a crossing pass from Philipp Lahm gave the club from Bavaria its 23rd title with six games left in the season.

title: Day of the Hunter
description: PEOPLE who rhapsodize about the glory of hunting never mention what an unfair fight it is.

title: Drivers Are Still Distracted, Study Finds
description: At any moment during daylight hours, according to a new government study, 660,000 Americans are using cellphones or other electronic devices while driving.

title: Finally, Maybe, at Last
description: Look to Washington in the next week or so for the first legislative rumblings of the great battle over comprehensive immigration reform, 2013. The effort will end either in collapse and failure, followed by years of political recriminations, or, amazingly, a big fat bill.

title: Ready to Cut the Cord?
description: How easy is it to live without cable TV? I have been finding out for the last several months while staying with a friend who, like several people I know, does not subscribe to cable or satellite TV. So far, thanks to Netflix and Amazon Primes streaming of movies and TV shows, I havent missed cable TV much, except maybe the HBO show Girls. And when the sixth season of Mad Men kicks off on Sunday, Ill keep up with the dark lives of Don Draper and company by buying the whole season on iTunes for $22.99, and watching the episodes as they become available for download each week. Come May, when I move into my own place, Ill have to make a decision: Should I join the ranks of the so-called cord cutters, who rely solely on Netflix, iTunes and the rest of the Internet for TV (or use high-definition TV antennas to get broadcast stations)?

title: The Secrets of Princeton
description: SUSAN PATTON, the Princeton alumna who became famous for her letter urging Ivy League women to use their college years to find a mate, has been denounced as a traitor to feminism, to coeducation, to the university ideal. But really shes something much more interesting: a traitor to her class.

title: A Year in Trees
description: SOMEONE asked me the other day how I had gotten over the sudden death of someone I loved. What I wanted to say but found myself unable to explain (for it would have sounded too strange) was that I learned a good deal about moving through grief from some trees I once knew. They were not my trees. I didnt plant them. I lived in an apartment surrounded by them. The only tending done was to give them my full attention over the course of four seasons.

title: Calamity for Our Most Beneficent Insect
description: Every beekeeper, small or large, hobbyist or commercial, knows that honeybees are in trouble. Over the past decade, bee colonies have been dying in increasing numbers. Last year was especially bad. Perhaps as many as half the hives kept by commercial beekeepers died in 2012. The loss has created a crisis among fruit and vegetable growers, who depend on bees to pollinate their crops.

title: Pity the Men on Top
description: WHEN I dream about my father, as I do even though he has been dead for more than a quarter of a century, I always wake up when I hear the crunch of tires rolling over rock salt  an unmistakable sound evoking the winters of my Michigan childhood in the 1950s and early 60s. Dad, an accountant, would pull his car out of our icy driveway and head for his office long before first light. This was tax season, and he could keep his business and our family financially afloat only by working 80-hour weeks.

title: How Weve Wasted Our Timeout
description: YES, its true  a crisis is a terrible thing to waste. But a timeout is also a terrible thing to waste, and as I look at the world today I wonder if thats exactly what weve just done. Weve wasted a five-year timeout from geopolitics, and if we dont wake up and get our act together as a country  and if the Chinese, Russians and Europeans dont do the same  were all really going to regret it.

title: Suburban Disequilibrium
description: A little pocket of Los Angeles County tucked into the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains reflects a crucial facet of suburban life. Theres tiny, wealthy Bradbury, a town that prides itself on having one of the richest ZIP codes in Los Angeles, where a house is on the market for $68.8 million. A couple of miles to the east is Azusa. This modest suburb is more than two-thirds Latino, a town of working families whose incomes and home values are a sliver of the wealth nearby.

title: Wearing a Badge, and a Video Camera
description: HERES a fraught encounter: one police officer, one civilian and anger felt by one or both. Afterward, it may be hard to sort out who did what to whom.

title: J. B. Straubel
description: J. B. Straubel is a founder and the chief technical officer of Tesla Motors in Palo Alto, Calif. The company makes electric vehicles that some compare to Apple products in terms of obsessive attention to design, intuitive user interface and expense.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Tackling Global Warming
description: Readers urge carbon taxes, lifestyle changes and a new term.

title: The Atlanta Teacher Aptitude Test (ATAT)
description: Please use a sharp No. 2 pencil and gloves to fill in each circle completely or maybe a little less.

title: Wars on Drugs
description: LAST year, more active-duty soldiers committed suicide than died in battle. This fact has been reported so often that it has almost lost its jolting force. Almost.

title: Trading in the Dark
description: Stocks dropped on Friday, after the dismal employment report for March forced investors to rethink the recent rally. Stock prices have been driven up by easy money from the Federal Reserve, but the jobs picture indicates that little of the Feds largess has made its way to Main Street, where unemployment remains high.

title: The Arab Spring Started in Iraq
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Getting Serious About a Texas-Size Drought
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Courts Without Judges
description: The number of vacancies on the nations federal courts has reached an astonishingly high level, creating a serious shortage of judges and undermining the ability of the nations court system to bestow justice.

title: Can We Get Hillary Without the Foolery?
description: PLEASE dont ask me this anymore.

title: Out of the Spotlight, a Lucrative Payday
description: OUR annual list of highly compensated executives includes some astonishing salaries. But they are not necessarily the richest compensation packages out there.

title: African North Americans and the War
description: Thomas Peter Riggs was not like most soldiers. A private in the 54th Massachusetts regiment, his race would have stood out first to contemporary observers: Riggs was black, and his unit was the first to be organized in the North, after President Lincoln and the Union Army acquiesced to expanding the power of the Emancipation Proclamation with African-Americans fighting as soldiers.

title: How Memoirists Mold the Truth
description: In the wake of horrible family rows, short of leaving my father, my mother would do something that shook the foundations of my childhood. She would step into our living room and, spurred by rage, spite and last-ditch efforts to restore order in her life, she would single-handedly move all the furniture around. The sofa was relegated to the place held by an imposing bookcase. The bookcase would be shunted over to a corner that belonged to an unassuming cabinet, now demoted to another corner where it sat in the dark under the terrified gaze of two leather armchairs squatting in the maelstrom.

title: Green Clay, in Use at Only One Tour Stop, Shows Promise
description: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C.  The dimensions of the tennis courts are standard, but the surface is unique at the Family Circle Cup in this island community outside Charleston.

title: A Secret Deal on Drones, Sealed in Blood
description: Nek Muhammad knew he was being followed.

title: Blue Jays Have Task of Keeping Fans Who Returned
description: TORONTO  Among the Blue Jays fans expressing caution about the extraordinary buildup of hope and hype for the 2013 season, there was Joe Carter, the smiling symbol of the franchises glory days, doling out restraint.

title: High Speeds, Injuries and Competition Lead to Renewed Safety Focus
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va.  Denny Hamlin stood atop his hauler at Martinsville Speedway on Friday and watched as Mark Martin wheeled the No. 11 Toyota around the track during Sprint Cup practice. That was Hamlins racecar, the number he drove for 264 consecutive Cup races since late 2005. His streak will not reach 265.

title: An Autograph Collector With Special Access
description: Don Schulze is the pitching coach for the Midland RockHounds, a minor league affiliate of the Oakland Athletics, two rungs below the majors. In 1985, after Schulze had gone 3-6 for the Cleveland Indians, Topps rewarded him with card No. 93 in its annual baseball card set.

title: On an Aching Roster, a Knick Prefers to Forgo Ice
description: After a recent game in Utah, at the end of the Knicks Western trip, Kurt Thomas had his right foot in a large bucket of ice. Across the room, Jason Kidd held a bag of ice against his left wrist. J. R. Smith iced his shins and ankles, Iman Shumpert both knees.

title: Brazil Opens Inquiry Into Claims of Wrongdoing by Ex-President
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils Public Ministry, a body of independent public prosecutors, has begun an investigation into a claim connecting former President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva to a vast vote-buying scheme that involved the channeling of funds to the governing Workers Party.

title: A Final Four Star, and a Mere Footnote
description: With Michigan back in the mens Final Four for the first time in 20 years, the video of Chris Webbers attempted timeout at the end of the 1993 national championship game between Michigan and North Carolina will surely be shown again and again.

title: College Games on Television? That Might Work
description: CHICAGO  Eddie Einhorn is not going to the mens Final Four this year. There will be no buzzer-beaters for him, no monster dunks, no shining moments.

title: Before Playoffs, a Few Defeats May Actually Help
description: It may sound ridiculous to declare six better than four or five, but when it comes to playoff seedings in the Eastern Conference, you could certainly make the argument that it would be better to be worse.

title: Damaged Nuclear Plant in Japan Leaks Toxic Water
description: TOKYO  Tens of thousands of gallons of radioactive water leaked from a large underground storage pool at Japans crippled nuclear plant, and thousands more gallons could seep out before the faulty pool can be emptied, the plants operator said Saturday.

title: A Thinking Mans Player Never Stops Thinking
description: Jerry Lucas found it easier than most to let go. He had a couple of years remaining on his contract with the Knicks when he retired in 1974, but he wanted to do something more important with his life. He had a plan. Lucas always had a plan.

title: A Bloated Contract Keeps a Player Stuck in Place
description: When is a contract too rich for a players own good? It is an odd question, but one that comes up repeatedly in the strange case of Vancouver goalie Roberto Luongo.

title: F.B.I. Investigating Former Rutgers Assistant
description: The F.B.I. is investigating whether the assistant at Rutgers who first voiced concerns about the abusive behavior of his boss, Mike Rice, tried to extort the university.

title: No TV? No Subscription? No Problem
description: LAST Sunday afternoon, some friends and I were hanging out in a local bar, talking about what wed be doing that evening. It turned out that we all had the same plan: to watch the season premiere of Game of Thrones. But only one person in our group had a cable television subscription to HBO, where it is shown. The rest of us had a crafty workaround.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 7
description: Dan Pfeiffer, senior adviser to President Obama, joins ABCs This Week and Fox News Sunday to discuss topics including tension with North Korea, the presidents budget proposal and negotiations on immigration and gun control.

title: Household Debt, vs. the Governments
description: Household Debt, vs . the Governments

title: A Footnote in a Trade, Buck Now Matters to Mets
description: John Buck began the year as an afterthought, the footnote to the package of players who arrived this winter from the Toronto Blue Jays for R. A. Dickey, the Mets former ace. Rather, it was the pair of young prospects in the deal  catcher Travis dArnaud and the right-handed pitcher Noah Syndergaard  who garnered all the attention.

title: A Delicate Dance for Los Angeles Mayoral Candidates
description: Organized labor has loomed large in a race where the two candidates have little separating them ideologically.

title: Union Views Loom Large as Los Angeles Picks a Mayor
description: LOS ANGELES  They are both Democrats with years of experience at City Hall, who have both chided and courted labor unions over the years. Now, in a race with little separating them ideologically, the two candidates for mayor face the challenge of simultaneously fighting over this powerful force in Los Angeles politics while trying to convince weary voters that they will be independent enough to force unions to accept cutbacks needed to solve the citys looming budget problems.

title: J. David Kuo, Who Split From Bush Faith Effort, Dies at 44
description: WASHINGTON  J. David Kuo, an evangelical Christian who was a leader in President George W. Bushs faith initiative but who later became a critic of it, died on Friday. He was 44.

title: Fitting Rearrangements
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Some puzzles are fun right out of the box, and others you have to work a bit before you uncover all of the nuggets of cleverness. This one by Matt Ginsberg was a bit of both.

title: On Matters of Transportation, Some Dare to Bring Up Taxes, Tolls and Debt
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: The First D.H. Reflects on How the Position Changed the Game
description: On April 6, 1973, at Fenway Park, Ron Blomberg became the first player in major league history to start in a game then take a position on the bench instead of on the field. Blomberg, a .293 hitter during a career spent mostly with the Yankees, was the first designated hitter. Blomberg was drafted first over all in 1967, by the Yankees, after being a standout in baseball, basketball and track in high school in Georgia.

title: An Exoneration After Decades, and a Conviction
description: If not for the 25 years that Michael Morton spent battling to prove his innocence from behind bars, the police might never have captured the man who authorities believe killed Mr. Mortons wife and another Austin woman, said Lisa Tanner, the prosecutor, days after securing Mark Alan Norwoods capital conviction.

title: Destroying Syrias Past
description: In 2013, C.J. Chivers examined how Syrias archaeological heritage was imperiled by war, facing threats that range from collateral damage from ordnance to pilfering for the black market.

title: Grave Robbers and War Steal Syrias History
description: TELL MARDIKH, Syria  Ali Shibleh crawled through a two-foot-high tunnel until reaching a slightly larger subterranean space. He swung his flashlights beam into the dark.

title: Tensions Over North Korea Rattle the Souths Economy and Its Foreign Investors
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Threats by North Korea and displays of military resolve by South Korea and the United States have begun to unsettle foreign investors confidence in the South, creating a secondary layer of worries for Seoul and Washington.

title: Rumors About Uzbekistan Leaders Health Set Off Succession Debate
description: MOSCOW  The president of Uzbekistan, a white-haired man in a suit, rose from his seat at an annual spring festival and swung his hips, clapped his hands and danced a vigorous little jig.

title: Myanmar Grapples With Ethnic Tensions
description: Analysts are divided on what deteriorating relations between the Kachin people and the countrys government mean for overall moves toward democracy and economic liberalization.

title: Saudis to Delay a Measure Deporting Foreign Workers
description: CAIRO  Almost two weeks after Saudi Arabia started deporting thousands of foreign workers from Yemen and other countries in a crackdown that drew protests from local business owners and foreign diplomats, Saudi officials on Saturday reversed course and announced a three-month grace period for the workers, according to the official Saudi news agency.

title: Ahead of the Market
description: How three of the top performers of the first quarter of 2013 fared against the market  and against their peer groups of funds.

title: Scientists See Cruelty in Killing Method Used in Japans Dolphin Roundup
description: April 7, 10:19 p.m. | Updated below |In a new peer-reviewed study, scientists assess the killing method employed by the dolphin hunters of Taiji, Japan, by watching video recorded surreptitiously in 2011 by a German dolphin-protection group, AtlanticBlue. The still image at right is from the video, which can be seen here (but be forewarned; this is not suitable for children  or many adults, for that matter).

title: Ralph Sanchez, Founder of Major Speedway, Dies at 64
description: Ralph Sanchez, a Cuban-born businessman who brought auto racing to the streets of Miami in the 1980s and later built a major speedway in a city devastated by Hurricane Andrew, died on Monday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 64.

title: Lawrence Fuchs, Expert on Immigration, Dies at 86
description: Lawrence H. Fuchs, a scholar of American ethnicity who as a federal government adviser helped lay the groundwork for the last major overhaul of American immigration law, in 1986, died on March 17 at his home in Canton, Mass. He was 86.

title: In History Departments, Its Up With Capitalism
description: A specter is haunting university history departments: the specter of capitalism.

title: Edith Schaeffer, Definer of Christian Family Values, Dies at 98
description: Edith Schaeffer, founder with her husband, Francis Schaeffer, of a Swiss commune considered the theological birthplace of the American religious right, and author of many popular books that helped define conservative Christian family values for a worldwide evangelical audience, mainly female, died on March 30 in Gryon, Switzerland. She was 98.

title: The View From the Top Row
description: ATLANTA  With 74,000 seats available in the Georgia Dome, somebody had to watch from far enough away where binoculars and extra Kleenex to deal with nosebleeds would come in handy.

title: Robert Ward, Composed Prizewinning Crucible Opera, Dies at 95
description: Robert Ward, an American composer whose best-known work, an operatic setting of Arthur Millers drama The Crucible, won the 1962 Pulitzer Prize for music, died on Wednesday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 95.

title: No. 1 Player Gets a Chance to Pick Off the World Champ
description: The Candidates Tournament to select a challenger for the world champion Viswanathan Anand ended on Monday with one of the most exciting finishes in chess history. Magnus Carlsen tied for first with Vladimir Kramnik, but by virtue of having won more games than Kramnik, Carlsen was declared the winner. And both players lost in the final round.

title: Yanks Off to Worst Start in 7 Years as Pitching Falters Again
description: DETROIT  Less than a week into the season, all the dire predictions about how bad the Yankees would be, especially in the first month, are looking quite accurate, but for the wrong reasons.

title: Matthew Warren, Son of Influential Minister, Dies at 27
description: The 27-year-old son of the Rev. Rick Warren, one of Americas most influential religious leaders, committed suicide, Mr. Warren said in an e-mail released on Saturday to staff members and congregants at his 20,000-member Saddleback Valley Community Church.

title: Tax Lobby Builds Ties to Chairman of Finance Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Restaurant chains like McDonalds want to keep their lucrative tax credit for hiring veterans. Altria, the tobacco giant, wants to cut the corporate tax rate. And Sapphire Energy, a small alternative energy company, is determined to protect a tax incentive it believes could turn algae into a popular motor fuel.

title: Behind Early, Tested Late, Almost There
description: ATLANTA  In Louisvilles first 160 minutes of basketball this N.C.A.A. tournament, its faithful could count how many times they were even moderately worried about their Cardinals on one hand. With five fingers down.

title: As Derby Favorite, Verrazano Beats Traffic in Queens
description: Verrazano came to New York, the city that boasts the bridge for which he is named, undefeated and bearing the title of early Kentucky Derby favorite.

title: Taping of Farm Cruelty Is Becoming the Crime
description: On one covert video, farm workers illegally burn the ankles of Tennessee walking horses with chemicals. Another captures workers in Wyoming punching and kicking pigs and flinging piglets into the air. And at one of the countrys largest egg suppliers, a video shows hens caged alongside rotting bird corpses, while workers burn and snap off the beaks of young chicks.

title: Was This Aston Villa Goal Worth $50 Million?
description: Two years ago, Deloittes Alan Switzer, writing in The Telegraph, pegged the first-year cost of relegation from the Premier League at 25 million (about $38 million), a figure that has almost certainly risen  doubled even?  since he calculated it.

title: Lundqvist Stops 48 Shots andSaves 2 Precious Points for Rangers
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  If the Rangers needed a breather after back-to-back games against Eastern Conference-leading Pittsburgh and before two critical meetings with Toronto this week, the schedule offered this kindness on Saturday night: a trip to Carolina. The fading Hurricanes had lost 10 of their last 11 games and had to play without the injured Alexander Semin, their second-leading scorer.

title: Semifinal Between Venus and Serena Williams Ends in Rout
description: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C.  The first match between Venus and Serena Williams in nearly four years drew the largest crowd in the Family Circle Cups history, with 9,538 fans on hand Saturday to watch Serena defeat her older sister, 6-1, 6-2, in a semifinal that lasted just 54 minutes.

title: Rutgers Officials Long Knew of Coachs Actions
description: They first saw the video Nov. 26, the Monday after Thanksgiving, inside an office in Piscataway, N.J., but it was hardly the first time that senior Rutgers officials had heard of the troubling behavior of Mike Rice, the mens basketball coach.

title: Kerry Moves to Help Turkey and Israel to Restore Ties
description: ISTANBUL  Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Istanbul early Sunday morning to encourage Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to move ahead with his commitment to normalize relations with Israel.

title: For Wares, Games Have Been Tough to Watch
description: ATLANTA  Passengers on the express bus from Throgs Neck in the Bronx to East 23rd Street in Manhattan last Monday morning might have wondered why their driver was wearing sunglasses on a cloudy day. Kevin Ware Sr., the father of Louisvilles famously injured guard, said he had no choice.

title: A Win-Win for Pitino
description: You might say Louisville coach Rick Pitino hit the daily double Saturday. Three time zones west of Atlanta, where his team tamed Wichita State in the N.C.A.A. Final Four semifinals, Pitinos prized 3-year-old thoroughbred Goldencents captured the Santa Anita Derby in Arcadia, Calif.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 7
description: Everywhere I go now, I think about exits and doorways and potential places to hide and things to barricade and fight back with.

title: Nets Are Lackluster but Squeak by Bobcats
description: The Nets had eight games left in the regular season when the last-place Charlotte Bobcats came to town Saturday, in what was assumed would be a figurative stroll in the park as Brooklyn built toward the postseason.

title: A Question of Taste
description: Perhaps lazy summer days simply conjure understatement, but suddenly fancy kitchens and the hyper-styled meals they produce feel overcooked.

title: Corrections: April 7, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Ashley Chow, Timothy Wong
description: Ashley Ellen Chow, a daughter of Anita Liu Chow and Dr. Michael Hung Chow of Nashua, N.H., was married Saturday to Timothy Henry Wong, the son of Barbara Ngor Wong and Steven H. Wong of Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Paul Kim, a Southern Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Redeemer Fellowship Church in Watertown, Mass.

title: Abigail Taylor, Rockford Sansom
description: Abigail Marie Taylor and Rockford Allen Sansom were married Saturday at the Laurie Beechman Theater in New York. Michael W. Fortune, a magistrate judge of Knox County Juvenile Court in Knoxville, Tenn., officiated.

title: Elizabeth Hinton, Mathew Spooner
description: Elizabeth Kai Hinton and Mathew Patrick Spooner were married Saturday at the James L. Crawford Elks Lodge in Ann Arbor, Mich. Gail A. Farley, a friend of the brides family who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Alice Beauheim and Andrew Borene
description: Alice Diana Beauheim and Andrew Melanchthon Borene were married Friday by Judge John R. Tunheim of the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, at the Minneapolis courthouse in which he sits.

title: Garrett Hall, Zachary Howell
description: Garrett Glenn Hall and Zachary William Howell were married Monday in their apartment in New York. Nicholas Domitrovich, a friend of the couple who is a Universal Life minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Megan Martin, Brian Long
description: Megan Leigh Martin and Brian Patrick Long were married Saturday evening at Cicada, a restaurant in Los Angeles. The Rev. Bob Schneider, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Cara Nelson, Jason Stern
description: Cara Avery Nelson and Jason Matthew Stern were married Saturday evening at Temple Sinai of Roslyn in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Gordon officiated.

title: Elizabeth Sidel and Christopher ONeill
description: Acquaintances Are Reunited by Spam

title: Jordan Fasbender, Christos Papapetrou
description: Jordan Rachel Fasbender, a daughter of Edyse Vogel and Bob E. Fasbender of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Christos Gus Papapetrou, the son of Helen Laliotis Papapetrou and Gus C. Papapetrou of Closter, N.J. Chief Judge Loretta A. Preska of Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: Christine Frogozo, Erik Stromquist
description: Christine de Jesus Frogozo and Erik Franklin Stromquist were married Saturday evening at Urban Studio, an event space in Portland, Ore. Daniel Savage, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Michele Calabrese, Anthony DiFato Jr.
description: Michele Jean Calabrese and Anthony DiFato Jr. were married Saturday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, N.Y. The Rev. John Gilmartin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Mallory Zalkin, Brett Weinberg
description: Mallory Robin Zalkin and Brett Harris Weinberg were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Cantor Bradley Hyman officiated.

title: Jamira Cotton and Cameron Johnson
description: Studying Together Seals a Bond

title: Two Child-Rearing Stories on the Way to a Major
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Behind most decorated female golfers is a devoted father. They are easy to spot during their daughters rounds this week at Mission Hills Country Club, skulking in the shadows like burglars casing their next target. Their children are their most precious jewels, and they will go to great lengths to give them the chance to shine.

title: Christina Keener, Andrew Allen
description: Christina Lucretia Keener and Andrew Robert Allen were married Friday at St. Michaels Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Elizabeth G. Maxwell, the churchs interim pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Swati Murthy and Nikhil Joshi
description: Dr. Swati Vadrevu Murthy and Dr. Nikhil Prakash Joshi were married Saturday at the Woodcliff Hotel & Spa in Rochester. Pandit Venkatachari Samudrala led the ceremony, with Pandit Narasimha Samudrala also taking part.

title: Laura Kaufman and Adam Rothschild
description: Laura Beth Kaufman, a daughter of Judith Richter Kaufman and Steven J. Kaufman of New York, was married in Philadelphia Saturday evening to Adam Gilbert Rothschild, a son of Deborah Menaker Rothschild and Dr. David Rothschild of Williamstown, Mass. Rabbi Joshua Bolton officiated at the Horticulture Center in Fairmount Park, with the assistance of Elana T. Friedman, a rabbinical student at Reconstructionist Rabbinical College in Wyncote, Pa.

title: Dennis Lampkowski, Douglas Wagner
description: Dennis Lampkowski and Gary Douglas Wagner were married Tuesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Shannon Kelley, Robert Shaw III
description: Shannon Marie Kelley, the daughter of Kathleen Frechette Kelley and Allan R. Kelley of Miami Shores, Fla., was married there Saturday to Robert William Shaw III, the son of Michelle Bowdring Shaw and Mr. Shaw II of McLean, Va. The Rev. Pedro M. Corces, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

title: Christopher Schelling and Augusten Burroughs
description: Christopher Robert Schelling, a literary agent, and the writer Augusten Burroughs, who is also his client, were married Monday at Staten Island Borough Hall. Edison Stewart, the deputy city clerk for Staten Island, officiated.

title: Michigan Forces Syracuse Out of Comfort Zone, and Tournament
