description: Q. Nuts are good for you, but is there a difference between raw nuts and roasted nuts?

title: L.A.s Modern Architecture
description: The Getty Trusts initiative celebrates the buildings that shaped the metropolis in the postwar period.

title: With Incentive, Monkeys Can Coordinate
description: Researchers have found that monkeys can cooperate to solve a problem, demonstrating that coordination among groups does not necessarily require language. The scientists, who report their findings in the journal Current Biology, had a group of vervet monkeys play a game called the forbidden circle. A single low-ranking female was trained to open a container holding a large amount of food  but only when dominant monkeys in the group stayed outside an imaginary circle. For anyone to get any treats, they all had to coordinate their activity and show restraint.

title: Online Habits Coming Slowly to Older Adults
description: Older adults hit a digital milestone last year: For the first time since the Pew Research Centers Internet and American Life Project began conducting surveys, a majority (53 percent) of people over age 65 used the Internet. The proportion has since inched upward, to 54 percent.

title: Brash Christie Plays Rutgers Circumspectly
description: It does not take much for Gov. Chris Christieof New Jersey to uncork his temper. He has called a Navy combat veteran an idiot, suggested reporters take the bat to a lawmaker in her 70s, and gone taunt-to-taunt with detractors on the boardwalk and in countless town hall meetings.

title: Protein Linked to Development Problems
description: The French geneticist Jrme Lejeune discovered more than 50 years ago that Down syndrome is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. But to this day it has remained a mystery why that results in impaired physical and cognitive development. Now researchers at the Sanford-Burnham Medical Research Institute think they have found a clue.

title: Which Governors Are Most Vulnerable in 2014?
description: A lot can change before Election Day next year, when 36 states will vote for governor. But at this early stage  when decisions on whether to run or retire are considered and made  10 of the 32 governors who are eligible to run for re-election have net negative approval ratings in their states.

title: Navy Deploying Laser Weapon Prototype Near Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The Navy is going to sea for the first time with a laser attack weapon that has been shown in tests to disable patrol boats and blind or destroy surveillance drones.

title: Annette Funicello, 70, Dies; Beloved as a Mouseketeer and a Star of Beach Movies
description: Annette Funicello, who won Americas heart as a 12-year-old in Mickey Mouse ears, captivated adolescent baby boomers in slightly spicy beach movies and later championed people with multiple sclerosis, a disease she had for more than 25 years, died on Monday in Bakersfield, Calif. She was 70.

title: U.S. Navy Laser Weapon Demonstration
description: A look, provided by the United States Navy, at how its laser attack weapon works. The video is silent.

title: The ECB, OMT, and Moral Hazard
description: Back in 2011 and again in the summer of 2012, a number of economists pleaded with the European Central Bank to intervene in sovereign bond markets, buying troubled nations debt to stop the doom loop of plunging bond prices and financial distress that was pushing the euro to the brink. The objection from austerians was always that this would create moral hazard: it would let countries off the hook, and lead them to slack off on their belt-tightening.

title: Theres No Place Like a New Home, Ads Assert
description: It almost sounds like the start of a childrens riddle: When is a new home not a new home? But according to a campaign being backed by a consortium of big home builders, a new home is not truly new unless it is newly built.

title: Rebuilding the Shores, Increasing the Risks
description: This might be a good time to take a look at the most important environmental law that nobody has ever heard of.

title: Hoping for One More Yes Before High School Ends
description: The other weekend, I left the sunny, beautiful city of Cleveland for three days to temporarily relocate to the even sunnier, more beautiful Youngstown, Ohio, where the Ohio High School Speech League would be holding its annual state championship debate tournament.

title: A Pantry Staple With Nutritional Punch
description: Nuts in general have a lot going for them when it comes to nutritional benefits, and of all nuts walnuts may be the king. Enough scientific studies have shown proof of their cholesterol-lowering properties that the Food and Drug Administration accepted a petition filed by the California Walnut Commission in 2004 to allow them to list this is a health claim. Walnuts are also associated with a reduced risk of heart disease and inflammation, perhaps because of their high vitamin E and omega-3 content and the presence of antioxidant-rich phenolic acids, tannins and flavonoids in their skins.

title: In a Blue Stadium, Kelley Roots for the Cardinals
description: CLEVELAND  In the seventh inning of the Yankees game against the Detroit Tigers on Sunday, the giant video screen at Comerica Park displayed a sign in support of the Michigan mens basketball teams title hopes that read, Go Blue.

title: Video Highlights From Annette Funicellos Career
description: Annette Funicello, who grew from a child actor on Walt Disneys Mickey Mouse Club in the 1950s into a bikini-clad pop star in 60s films such as Muscle Beach Party, died on Monday at 70. Below are some highlights from her career as the queen of teen:

title: Margaret Thatcher, Prime Minister
description: Margaret Thatcher, who died of a stroke on Monday at age 87, transformed Britain more thoroughly than any other prime minister of the past half-century. She was a pathbreaker from the moment she took office in 1979 as Britains first, and so far only, female prime minister. And she was the rare conservative leader to come not from the upper echelons of Britains class-obsessed society, but from a modest apartment above her fathers grocery.

title: Finding Our Way and Inventing Musical Instruments
description: MUSIC

title: Cuomo, Citing New Scandals in Legislature, Vows a Push to Change Laws
description: In the wake of two corruption cases announced last week that led to the arrests of members of the State Legislature, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that he would push for changes to the states election and campaign fund-raising laws, declaring, Never waste a crisis, as they say.

title: Footage of Bomb Blast in Damascus
description: Video from Syria shows the aftermath of the explosion that tore through central Damascus on Monday, killing at least 15 people and wounding more than 50, bringing the countrys two-year-old civil war to the heart of the city and its Central Bank, schools, shops and office buildings.

title: Really? Musical Training and Language Skills Enhance One Another
description: THE FACTS

title: The Fine Line Between Political Intelligence and Insider Trading
description: Life in Washington is all about information  who will support or oppose an initiative, how will an agency address an issue in its rules, and when will a decision be announced. The pervasive role of the government in the economy makes that information particularly valuable to investors. And that can lead some to get a jump on the market if they learn about changes in policy before others.

title: Annette Funicello, 1942-2013
description: Ms. Funicello, an original Mouseketeer who later described herself as the queen of teen, died on Monday in Bakersfield, Calif. She was 70.

title: Green Bean and Fava Bean Salad With Walnuts
description: You can toast the walnuts if you choose, but you dont have to. I like both versions.

title: Fill-In | Paris Employs a Few Black Sheep to Tend, and Eat, a City Field
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 12 paragraphs of the article Paris Employs a Few Black Sheep to Tend, and Eat, a City Field by Scott Sayare.

title: For Some, No Tears Lost for Thatchers Death
description: John McDonagh, a taxi driver and lifelong resident of Middle Village, Queens, was driving his yellow cab in the wee hours on Monday when his cellphone began lighting up with a flurry of text messages from Irish friends saying that Margaret Thatcher had died.The messages were not mournful.

title: Celebrating L.A.s Modern Architecture
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Dining Calendar
description: Books

title: South Dakotan Is Latest Senate Democrat to Back Same-Sex Marriage
description: Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota has become the latest Senate Democrat to announce his support for same-sex marriage, saying his views have evolved sufficiently to support marriage equality legislation.

title: More Than The Iron Lady': Margaret Thatcher, Cultural Icon
description: The ladys not for turning, Margaret Thatcher famously said in an early speech. But almost from the moment she moved into 10 Downing Street in 1979, Mrs. Thatcher, who died on Monday at 87, was most definitely for filming, recording, and generally excoriating by British artists and writers who saw a rich target in her stiff-necked conservative politics and stiffer coiffure.

title: Geffen Donates $25 Million to Film Museum Project
description: LOS ANGELES  This city already has the Geffen Playhouse for the performing arts and the Geffen Contemporary at the Museum of Contemporary Art, a visual arts space. Now add the David Geffen Theater, a significant new movie site.

title: When Weather Changes, Grasshopper Turns Locust
description: As recently as 1963, plagues of ravenous desert locusts could stretch across continents, blanketing lands from West Africa to India up to 14 years at a time. Today, with pesticides and early eradication efforts, such biblical swarms no longer occur. But as farmers in Sudan, Egypt, Israel and Saudi Arabia can currently attest, locust swarms remain a serious regional threat.

title: Cablevisions Actions Illegal, Board Says
description: The National Labor Relations Board said on Monday that it planned to file a complaint charging Cablevision with making illegal threats and offering improper inducements to its employees in the Bronx to discourage them from voting to unionize.

title: Mache and Endive Salad With Clementines and Walnuts
description: Mache, a delicate green with a mild, subtle flavor, packs quite a nutritional punch, as it is high in omega-3s (as are walnuts) and folic acid. The salad is simple to throw together, but its flavors are complex, with sweet juicy mandarin (or tangerine or clementine sections), crunchy bitter endive and walnuts, soft and almost sweet mache, and vibrant fresh herbs. The recipe will serve 4 to 6 but I admit to eating a good half of this salad when I tested it.

title: Profiles in Science, the Promise of Chiplets, an Exploding World of Pseudo-Academia
description: Denise Grady profiles Elizabeth Blackburn, a Nobel laureate in medicine who thinks the ends of your DNA might hold the key to long-term health. John Markoff talks possible tech revolution in the form of new flexible circuits. Gina Kolata on the murky world of non-professional science publishing.

title: Hall Election Completes One of Games Great Comebacks
description: NEW ORLEANS  Almost three decades later, people remember the back-to-back 50-point games with the Knicks in Texas, the quick-release turnaround jumper on the way up, the preternatural ability to slither through the tiniest cracks in transition defense along the left side on the fast break.

title: Online Reviews of Senior Housing Options, With Caveats
description: The operators of A Place for Mom, a commercial housing referral service for older adults, have introduced an affiliated Web site aimed at providing consumer reviews of senior care locations.

title: Wary of China, Companies Head to Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Tiffany & Company is quietly building a diamond-polishing factory in Cambodia, a country popularly associated more with killing fields and land mines than baubles.

title: Monday Motorsports: Normalcy Returns to Nascar
description: Normalcy, or what passes for it in Nascar, returned to the Sprint Cup series on Sunday as the five-time champion Jimmie Johnson led the most laps at Martinsville, scored his eighth victory at the Virginia track and regained the series points lead.

title: N.F.L. Asked to Explain Teams Combine Questions
description: The N.F.L. will meet with members of the New York attorney generals office Tuesday to explain its investigation into why players at the scouting combine in February were asked questions that may have pertained to sexual orientation, like Do you like girls?

title: Portugal Warns Citizens of More Economic Pain
description: MADRID  Portugal was once seen as a role model in the euro debt crisis as its conservative government stuck to the stringent terms of a 78 billion euro bailout negotiated with international creditors two years ago. But it has now earned a very different distinction as the test case of the limits of the austerity plans that have been prescribed across Southern Europe.

title: A.I.G. Seeks to Bar Greenberg From Suing U.S. on Its Behalf
description: 5:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Advice Shifts on Feeding Baby
description: Anyone who has cared for a baby knows that its easy to become preoccupied with what goes in one end  with what you feed her and how  and to regard what comes out the other end with a kind of fascination, as if the diaper contained messages and auguries.

title: Tiny Chiplets: A New Level of Micro Manufacturing
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Under a microscope, four slivers of silicon  electronic circuits called chiplets  perform an elaborate, jerky dance as if controlled by a hidden puppet master. Then on command, they all settle with pinpoint accuracy, precisely touching a pattern of circuit wires, each at just the right point of contact.

title: At Augusta, Tianlang Is Happy to Be a Student
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  There is nothing ordinary about the life of Guan Tianlang, the 14-year-old from China who on Thursday will become the youngest competitor in the history of the Masters. That did not stop the English-speaking press from trying to draw out of Guan all the ways he is like a typical teenager, as if there is such a thing.

title: Senate Gives White Its Unanimous Consent for S.E.C.
description: The Senate on Monday confirmed Mary Jo White as head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, dismissing concerns about her close ties to the Wall Street banks she will now oversee.

title: The Academy of Country Music Awards Red Carpet
description: While Miranda Lambert was the star of the awards, taking home three trophies, other singers shone on the red carpet.

title: Adelman at 1,000 Wins
description: MINNEAPOLIS  On Saturday, a night after a tepid defensive effort and missed free throws down the stretch handed him his 703rd career loss instead of his 1,000 career win, Minnesota Timberwolves Coach Rick Adelman stood beside his wife, Mary Kay, on the floor of the Target Center. The game had been eerily similar to Fridays loss to the Raptors: double-digit leads had evaporated, key free throws had found iron instead of twine.

title: The Thatcher Legacy in Full
description: Reading the obituaries for Margaret Thatcher, dead today at eighty-seven, it strikes me that her relatively long post-political afterlife  its been twenty-three years since she left Downing Street, almost a generationhas probably made it easier to get some distance on her era, and to marry an appreciation for her achievements with a judicious weighing of her legacy in full. Im particularly struck by the appropriate dose of the tragic sense that runs through a number of admiring right-of-center appreciations. Start with this passage fromAndrew Sullivans moving eulogy, in which he explains how Thatcherism turned out to be a much more complicated thing than many analyses contain:

title: Universities Get Middling Grades in Helping Poor
description: Prominent American and Canadian research universities earned mostly Cs on the first report card assessing how much their laboratories benefit the worlds poor.

title: In Performance: Adam Kantor
description: Adam Kantor, accompanied by Gary Sieger on guitar, performs an excerpt from If I Didnt Believe in You from Jason Robert Browns musical The Last Five Years, at Second Stage Theater.

title: Justice Breyer Inducted Into French Academy
description: PARIS  Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who has worked hard to perfect his French in his spare time, was inducted on Monday as a foreign member of the Frances Acadmie des Sciences Morales et Politiques, one of the five academies of the Institut de France.

title: Keeping Score: Which Team Has the Stats of a Champion?
description: Carlton J. Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay P. Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. They have previously written about the B.C.S.national title game, this years Super Bowl and last years N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Private Maps and Google Glass Ban
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Mad Men Season 6 Premiere Draws 3.4 Million Viewers
description: AMC lost about nine million viewers in a week, but it still celebrated a solid return Sunday night for its most prestigious drama, Mad Men.

title: Protesters and Merkel Criticize Putin, Who Wears a Smile
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday publicly expressed her governments disapproval of the way nongovernmental organizations are treated by the Kremlin, and she did so in the presence of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, making her the first Western leader known to have told him so directly.

title: In Swallow Magazine, the Food, Sights and Scents of Mexico City
description: Its hard to stand out in the crowded field of food publications. But Swallow Magazine may do just that with its latest issue,on Mexico City, which includes a scratch-and-sniff feature that also brings you the smells of the sprawling metropolis.

title: THL to Buy CompuCom, a Technology Services Firm
description: The private equity firm THL Partners agreed on Monday to buy CompuCom Systems, a privately held information technology services provider, from another private equity firm.

title: With Help From Nature, a Town Aims to Be a Solar Capital
description: LANCASTER, Calif.  There are at least two things to know about this high desert city. One, the sun just keeps on shining. Two, the citys mayor, a class-action lawyer named R. Rex Parris, just keeps on competing.

title: Security Delays Have You Upset? You Havent Been to Kinshasa
description: AS head of Jhpiego, Im flying overseas almost all the time, mostly to meet with ministers of health or to meet the teams in the field who are working to train doctors and midwives. I figure I have about one weekend home a month. In 2012, I flew about 350,000 miles. Im really lucky I have an understanding husband. He greets me at the airport at the end of nearly every trip with flowers and a smile.

title: Not So Pumped Up About G.E.s Latest Deal
description: General Electric shareholders are closing the gusher on bolt-on oil deals. Their reaction to the conglomerates $3 billion purchase of Lufkin Industries is more realistic than the wowed reception given to an earlier acquisition. Lufkin, whose technology helps increase production for aging oil wells, is a strong player in a growing sector. But previous deals did little for margins, and the latest one doesnt come cheap.

title: Journalist in Russia, Badly Beaten in 2008, Dies
description: MOSCOW  The Russian journalist Mikhail Beketov, who became a symbol of Russias culture of impunity after he was brutally beaten in 2008, died of heart failure on Monday, his lawyer announced.

title: The Noisy Clatter of Traveling
description: Noise, to a business traveler, can be something as simple as a conversation on a train or a plane or as unrelenting as the sound of a jet engine on a seven-hour flight.

title: Greenhouse Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Morning-After Pill Is Not a Cure-All
description: If a recent federal court ruling stands, any young woman will be able to walk into her neighborhood drugstore, find the morning-after pill near the shelves stocked with condoms and KY Jelly and buy it  no questions asked.

title: A Bus Ride, With Donuts
description: DEN HAAG, the Netherlands  The alarm always seems to go off much too early the morning after a game.

title: Surprise Path to Better Sex: Hip Surgery
description: Want better sex? Consider getting a new hip or knee.

title: Milan Furniture Fair | New and Newer
description: This years Salone Internazionale del Mobile has plenty to offer, whether its new furniture or re-imaginings of classic pieces.

title: Guest Post: Hungary, The Public Relations Offensive
description: First link fixed

title: Readers Respond to the Death of Margaret Thatcher
description: Readers discuss Margaret Thatchers reputation as the Iron Lady of British politics and the effectiveness of her policies.

title: Milan Furniture Fair | Haas Brothers for Versace
description: Nikolai and Simon Haas, the L.A.-based twins known for their design collaborations with Peter Marino and Mario Testino, are adding another boldfaced name to their roster: Versace. Tomorrow, their design project with Versace Home  a 12-piece homage to Donatellas style  makes its debut at Salone del Mobile in Milan. Watch the making of The Donatella Chair in this video by Alexa Karolinski.

title: Life as a Race Against a Diagnosis
description: While undressing for bed one night in 2009, Susan Spencer-Wendel noticed that the muscles in her left palm had disappeared, leaving a scrawny pile of tendons and bones. Her right hand was fine. She let out a yelp and showed the hand to her husband, who told her to go to the doctor. She was 42.

title: Hidden Salt (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Competition for Young Golfers at Augusta
description: Billy Payne, the chairman of Augusta National Golf Club, announced on Monday the formation of a nationwide Drive, Chip and Putt Championship for children ages 7 to 15. Inspired by the N.F.L.s punt, pass and kick competition, and created in concert with the U.S. Golf Association and the PGA of America, the contest will consist of local and regional qualifiers in four separate age classifications for boys and girls (7-9, 10-11, 12-13, 14-15).

title: Battle Heats Up Over Fate of Troubled Energy Buyout
description: The biggest private equity buyout ever  the $45 billion deal for the Texas energy giant TXU in 2007  has been steadily sliding toward becoming one of the biggest busts.

title: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble highlights three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: Microsoft Sheds Old TV Baggage to Focus on New Xbox
description: 4:01 p.m. | Updated Added detail about the A.M.D. chip in the new Xbox.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Spain and Egypt.

title: The Senator From Paranoia
description: A single filibuster a few weeks ago about the perils of domestic drone strikes turned Senator Rand Paul into a political celebrity. Now, having been swaddled in cable-TV warmth, he clearly wants more. He is not likely to get any legislation passed in a Senate controlled by centrist Democrats, but he has demonstrated a marked talent for stoking the fear of an authoritarian government and getting like-minded lawmakers to join him in resisting its dangers.

title: Early Line for 2016: A Vice President Whos an Underdog
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. showed up late at an event last week, saying he was delayed because the president keeps those meetings going longer. But he walked into a Hillary Clinton crowd. Outside, supporters hoisted signs urging her to run for president. Inside, she was greeted as a hero.

title: Airlines Weigh The Pounds
description: Probably because Ive been at this for 14 years, people assume I have ready answers for many often-asked air travel questions, starting with, How can I always find the lowest fare? To this I reply reluctantly, I have absolutely no idea.

title: In Europe, New Protest Over Google
description: BRUSSELS  European antitrust regulators have received a formal complaint about Googles Android operating system for mobile devices, even as they move to the final stages of their inquiry into the companys search practices.

title: J.C. Penney Ousts Chief of 17 Months
description: After a troublesome 17-month run, Ron Johnson is out as chief executive of J. C. Penney, and with that, the most closely watched revival effort in retail in recent memory is in danger of disintegrating.

title: Maggie and Gorby
description: On the evening of March 31, 1987, viewers in the Soviet Union turned on their TV sets and watched (Id bet no one turned it off) an astonishing spectacle. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, concluding a visit to Moscow, was pitted against three of the state-controlled medias most polished propagandists. For 50 minutes, she tied them in knots, shifting between firm diplomacy and patient, school-marmish exposition, with  whenever one of the interviewers tried to interrupt  flashes of Trunchbull discipline. Even by the standards of the day  Mikhail Gorbachevs cascade of glasnost, the thawing of the Cold War  the Thatcher interview was amazing. She articulated a peace-through-strength line on nuclear and conventional arms control, disclosing along the way facts that Soviet viewers had never read or heard in their media about their own arsenals. (A transcript is here.) She heaped praise on Gorbachev but, at a time when Gorbachev and President Reagan were indulging in talk about a world without nuclear weapons, Thatcher explained to viewers the European view that only nuclear deterrence had sustained 40 years of peace. The interview ran uncut.

title: Lilly Pulitzers Legacy
description: Ms. Pulitzer, the Palm Beach princess of prints, created an enduring fashion uniform for wealthy socialites and jet setters.

title: Charting Her Own Course
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Scientists are trained to be skeptics, and Elizabeth H. Blackburn considers herself one of the biggest. Show her the data, and be ready to defend it.

title: Talking to Elizabeth Blackburn
description: Elizabeth H. Blackburn, who shared the 2009 Nobel Prize in medicine, talks about her work on telomeres, and when she knew she wanted to be a scientist.

title: Old-Fashioned Tweets, Shaken With a Twist
description: As Rosie Schaaps drinking buddy and editor, Im excited to announce that she will be taking hold of the magazines Twitter handle (@NYTMag) all week. Following the guest-tweeters Adam Sternbergh and Adam Davidson, she will be not only our first female guest tweeter but also our first non-Adam guest tweeter. Take that, glass ceiling!

title: Explorations of Wholes and Halves
description: Before (w)hole, again starts, its choreographer, Marya Wethers, lies sprawled on the floor in sweats, her face covered by a knit hat. Beside her are one sock, one boot, one boxing glove. Theres a fork but no spoon, a jar of peanut butter but no jelly. Among these halves, her body looks abandoned.

title: U.S. Diplomat Asks Auction House to Delay Sale of Hopi Items
description: The United States Embassy in Paris has asked a French auction house to consider postponing its Friday sale of Hopi artifacts and let tribal leaders examine them to assess their origins and authenticity.

title: A Brooklyn Jester Had an Enduring Comic Brew That Was True
description: To people over a certain age it no doubt seems incredible that people under a certain age have to be told who Danny Kaye was. In the middle of the last century Kaye was one of the countrys biggest stars, working his nimble, quick-tongued brand of comedy into a career that bridged eras and genres: radio, stage, film, records, television. For decades you would have to have lived in a cave to not know his work.

title: Bespoke Works for Ensemble Whose Focus Is New Music
description: When Alarm Will Sound, the unusually versatile, reliably exhilarating new-music ensemble, made its Zankel Hall debut in 2006, Carnegie Hall celebrated the occasion with a newly commissioned work, Wolfgang Rihms Will Sound. As the groups borderless tastes and voracious appetite became better known, the ensemble and its admirable artistic director, Alan Pierson, inspired more composers to tailor pieces for its superb players. On Saturday night Alarm Will Sound returned to Zankel for a fashionably late outing meant to showcase its bespoke canon.

title: Classic Idiom, Prodigious in Its Variety
description: For the last 20 years, the dancers Surupa Sen and Bijayini Satpathy have lived in Nrityagram, a village in southern India dedicated to the classical Odissi style of dance. The commitment shows. Only decades of single-minded devotion could explain the perfection of each of these artists alone. Only decades of shared practice could account for their uncanny coordination together.

title: Be Fruitful and Simplify!
description: Simple.

title: Woods Returns the Favor, Offering Stricker Advice
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  If Steve Stricker wins the Masters this week on the strength of a miraculous chip, like Larry Mize in 1987 or Tiger Woods in 2005, Woods will be able to consider his debt repaid.

title: Knowing Its Enemy (and Friends)
description: The first audience member brought onstage during Green Days show at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sunday night was just a kid  maybe 12, maybe younger. He clambered up during the second tune, Know Your Enemy, and before long, Billie Joe Armstrong, the bands frontman, caught his ear for some coaching. The kid nodded intently. And then, precisely on cue, he executed a perfect stage dive.

title: A Look at One Students Engagement Index
description: The CourseSmart page for Carol Johnson, shared with her permission.

title: Moving an Asteroid, Mapping the Brain and More
description: Moving an asteroid is a huge idea, according to scientists at the Keck Institute for Space Studies at the California Institute of Technology, who should know. Never has a celestial object been moved by humans.

title: Performing Together, Though Not Necessarily Onstage
description: The adjective mechanical, when applied to a musical performance, often implies technical perfection without artistry. But given how often machines freeze or break down, any work requiring the cooperation of myriad gadgets is indeed Playing it Unsafe, as the American Composers Orchestra aptly titles its series of new works.

title: China Still Dominates, but Some Manufacturers Look Elsewhere
description: While China maintains its overwhelming dominance in manufacturing, multinational companies are looking for ways to limit their reliance on factories there. A look at Asias economic output and growth.

title: Same Story, Different Screens: A Video Game Thats Also a Series
description: Video games adapted from movies and television shows are, with a few notable exceptions, uniformly terrible. Movies adapted from video games are even worse. Think  or try not to  of Super Mario Bros., starring Bob Hoskins, John Leguizamo and Dennis Hopper, or of Street Fighter, starring Jean-Claude Van Damme and Raul Julia.

title: Latin Makes an Appearance on Finnish Radio. News at VI.
description: HELSINKI  Leah Whittington, an English professor at Harvard, catches the news bulletins on her iPod while strolling to classes. Daniel Blanchard, a professional countertenor in Paris, used to listen on shortwave radio, but now he uses an iPod, too. The BBC? NPR? No, its a weekly summary of world events and news broadcast by Finnish state radio  not in Finnish, but in classical Latin.

title: After Split by Band, a Singer Grows Up
description: PARAMORE

title: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
description: Candice Childress, a high school senior in Las Vegas, has been admitted to the University of Arizona.

title: J.C. Penney Turns to Chief Who Dealt With Activist Investors
description: To end Ron Johnsons tortured 17-month tenure as J.C. Penneys chief executive, the embattled retailer is turning to the man who ceded his seat to Mr. Johnson amid pressure from activist investors.

title: For First Masters, Colsaerts Consults Nicklaus
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  As part of his preparation for his first Masters, Nicolas Colsaerts of Belgium sat down for an hour last week with Jack Nicklaus, a six-time winner at Augusta National, an experience akin to being coached by Michael Phelps on how to swim the 200 butterfly.

title: Folger Librarian Headed to the Harry Ransom Center
description: In the rare book and manuscript trade, G.T.T.  gone to Texas  has long been slang for treasures snapped up by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. Soon, Stephen Enniss, the head librarian of the Folger Shakespeare Library, will become the latest rarity to get the designation.

title: Memories of Polo Grounds on Anniversary of Final Opener
description: Ebbets Field is in the spotlight this year because the long-departed home of the Brooklyn Dodgers is in the centennial of its birth. But this is also a significant month for the Polo Grounds, the other New York home for National League baseball that succumbed to the wrecking ball decades ago.

title: Margaret Thatcher: Her Journey From Aspiring Politician to World Leader
description: Margaret Thatcher, born a grocers daughter, entered politics in her early 20s, and despite initial setbacks she became one of the most influential figures of the 20th century.

title: A Choice to Name Names, or Else
description: There is only one female character in Finks, a bracing play about McCarthyism by Joe Gilford, but its the kind of role actresses live for, and Miriam Silverman is giving it an attention-getting turn at the Ensemble Studio Theater. The play works subject matter that has already been pretty thoroughly mined, but this brisk, muscular production  based on the lives of the playwrights parents  quickly leaves you not caring that youve visited the territory before.

title: Margaret Thatcher in Her Own Words
description: Key speeches, letters and interviews from the life and career of the first woman to become prime minister of Britain.

title: Solar Self-Sufficiency
description: Lancaster, a high desert city in California, is attempting to become the standard-bearer of municipalities that can successfully convert sunshine into electricity.

title: Chile Exhumes Nobel Poets Body to Investigate Claim of Poisoning
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The remains of Chiles Nobel Prize-winning poet, Pablo Neruda, were exhumed Monday so that they could be examined for signs of whether he might have died of poisoning instead of cancer, the widely believed cause for almost 40 years.

title: Contest Over: Hands on a Hardbody Will Close This Weekend
description: The new Broadway musical Hands on a Hardbody will close after this Saturday evenings performance, the producers announced on Monday night, succumbing to weak ticket sales after opening on March 21 to mixed reviews. When it closes the production will have played 28 previews and 28 regular performances.

title: Climate Campaigners Try Flooding the (Comment) Zone
description: Katherine Bagley has filed a thorough, interesting piece for InsideClimate News examining efforts by climate campaigners to build their online presence through more engagement in comments on articles or blog posts on global warming. One weapon in the new push is a Web site that automatically searches for comment opportunities.

title: A Campaign Fights the Cigarette Butt, a Ubiquitous Pollutant
description: LIKE that of the American Lung Association, much of the work of Legacy, a 14-year-old antismoking organization, is aimed at exposing the health risks of cigarettes. Legacys Truth campaign, for example, tries to dissuade youths from picking up the habit, while its Ex program helps adults quit.

title: Intersection: Style Outside MoMA PS1
description: On a recent chilly afternoon in Long Island City, we talked to a few visitors (and an employee) about how they put personal touches on their transitional spring looks.

title: Criticism of Cuomo Grows as the Problems in Albany Endure
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo once called himself the sheriff of State Street.

title: 2 Networks Hint at Leaving the Airwaves
description: Executives in charge of Fox and Univision raised the prospect Monday of one day moving their programming off the broadcast airwaves and exclusively onto cable in a stepped-up response to Aereo, a streaming TV service.

title: Harold M. Schmeck, 89, Times Science Writer, Dies
description: Harold M. Schmeck Jr., a science writer for The New York Times for more than 30 years who specialized in covering medical research, from the space age to the era of genetic medicine, died on April 1 in Hyannis, Mass. He was 89.

title: Kerry to Focus on Palestinian Economy as Part of Peace Process
description: JERUSALEM  Secretary of State John Kerry signaled Monday that he is hoping to use the economic development of Palestinian areas on the West Bank as a means to build support for a new set of Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Private Development Feared in City-Owned Complex
description: Along the walkway of the Washington Houses community center, past a flier for talent show auditions flapping in the wind, a bright yellow mural reads, in part: Thrive, Not Just Survive. Inside the squat building of drab cinder block one recent morning, grayed men and women chatted over Spanish-language newspapers and lunchtime ravioli. In another room down the hall, a group of students took a G.E.D. practice exam, set on turning their lives around.

title: Ex-Regulator Says Reactors Are Flawed
description: WASHINGTON  All 104 nuclear power reactors now in operation in the United States have a safety problem that cannot be fixed and they should be replaced with newer technology, the former chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Monday. Shutting them all down at once is not practical, he said, but he supports phasing them out rather than trying to extend their lives.

title: Exchanges Are Moving to Curb Private Trades
description: The chief executives of the three largest stock exchanges are joining forces for the first time to push regulators to rein in the increasing amount of trading that is moving off public exchanges and onto platforms like so-called dark pools.

title: Did Thatcher Turn Britain Around?
description: There will presumably be a lot of commentary about Margaret Thatcher over the next few days, although probably nothing like the Reagasm of 2004. And there will in particular be many assertions that Thatcher turned around a moribund British economy. So, is this right?

title: Amid Criticism, Pentagon Seeks Overhaul of the Court-Martial System
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon announced Monday that it would ask Congress to overhaul the court-martial system used to prosecute the nearly 5,000 service members annually accused of crimes, scaling back the power of senior commanders to overturn convictions and dismiss charges.

title: Guest Post: The Dependence of the Central Bank
description: Another post from Kim Lane Scheppele, regarding the resignation of the deputy governor of Hungarys central bank:

title: No Lawyer for Miles, So One Rural State Offers Pay
description: MARTIN, S.D.  Rural Americans are increasingly without lawyers even as law school graduates are increasingly without jobs. Just 2 percent of small law practices are in rural areas, where nearly a fifth of the country lives, recent data show.

title: Factories Rise in Cambodia
description: Foreign companies are flocking to Cambodia as a way to limit their overwhelming reliance on factories in China, where wages are surging.

title: Its Not Me
description: Ive been told that theres a commenter on Zero Hedge who is pretending to be me. Not so. I publish my column and this blog; there is a Twitter account, NYTimeskrugman, that is a Times robot that tweets titles of columns and blog posts; and thats it. I dont leave comments on other blogs, I dont have another Twitter account, Facebook account, Google Plus account, or any of that. Hey, I am trying to have a life.

title: Sixty Years Ago, an Unbeaten Season for Golfer
description: The 50th anniversary of Jack Nicklauss first Masters victory has been a much discussed milestone ahead of this years tournament at Augusta National Golf Club. But there is another significant anniversary this year.

title: Authority Fined $3.5 Million for Lapses in Airport Safety Training
description: The operator of the major airports in the New York metropolitan region has agreed to pay $3.5 million for failing to train its police officers to perform rescues and fight fires, under a settlement agreement announced Monday by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Egyptian Violence Raises Anxiety Over Islamists Rhetoric About Minorities
description: As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim reported, violence erupted on Sunday after unknown assailants attacked a funeral at Cairos Coptic Orthodox Cathedral, killing one and injuring scores at the seat of the Coptic Church and home of its spiritual leader, Pope Tawadros II.

title: Teacher Knows if Youve Done the E-Reading
description: SAN ANTONIO  Several Texas A&M professors know something that generations of teachers could only hope to guess: whether students are reading their textbooks.

title: A Rivalry That Is Friendly but Also Quite One-Sided
description: NEW ORLEANS  Notwithstanding the imminent dissolution of the existing Big East Conference, or the possibility of what would be a most surprising defeat in the womens national championship game, Louisville Coach Jeff Walz failed to foresee the end of dominance anytime soon for Geno Auriemma and his stalwart Connecticut program.

title: Bloomberg, Holding Nose, Opened Wallet
description: To listen to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last week was to call to mind a dyspeptic duke.

title: The Vigorous Virtues
description: The 1990 Tory coup against Margaret Thatcher was the most intense political event Ive covered. The Conservative politicians who were trying to remove her from party leadership and the prime ministers office knew they were toppling a person who was their political and moral superior. They knew she had earned the right to face the country in an election one last time, rather than be deposed by the supposed lieutenants in her own party. They sensed there would be some Shakespearean retribution for the act of disloyalty they were engaged in. They went around rubbing their hands like Lady Macbeth trying to expunge the sin even as they were committing it.

title: Thatchers Divided Isle
description: LONDON

title: Thatcher, Reagan and Their Special Relationship
description: THE Iron Lady was an inappropriate epithet for Margaret Thatcher. She disliked it, but learned to use it to her advantage. For those who knew her in her prime, however, it did not do justice to her.

title: The Military Prep School Scam
description: Is there any institution of higher learning that isnt gaming the system to gain athletic advantage? Ive come to believe the answer is no.

title: When ICE Ran Amok
description: In a series of raids in suburban New York in 2006 and 2007, agents of Immigration and Customs Enforcement burst into private homes in the dead of night, without warrants, looking for undocumented immigrants, often in the wrong houses. They pounded on doors, terrorized innocent residents, ineptly drew guns on police officers who were supposed to be their partners, and found hardly any of the gang members they were hunting. It was a stunning display of aggression and incompetence.

title: Open the Slaughterhouses
description: WASHINGTON

title: Gruesome Ads That Work
description: There is limited value in telling smokers that their deadly habit may kill them. They already know that, yet most ignore the warnings. But showing smokers gruesome images of people who have been maimed or disfigured by tobacco seems to have a much bigger effect.

title: Hail, Hail, Freedom in Cyprus
description: On the island of Cyprus, the filmmaker Iva Radivojevic explores how the economic crisis has contributed to a rise in hostility toward immigrants.

title: President Obamas Speech on Gun Control
description: Speaking in Connecticut, the president implored Congress to consider gun-control measures, saying, this is not about politics, this is about the right thing for families.

title: Hail, Hail, Freedom in Cyprus
description: In 1992, when I was 12 years old, my Croat-Serbian family left Yugoslavia to escape ethnic unrest. We relocated to the beautiful Mediterranean island of Cyprus, only to find ourselves in another ethnically divided land.

title: Even in Death, Chvez Is a Powerful Presence
description: SAN FELIPE, Venezuela  Nicols Maduro is certainly not the first political candidate to invoke the name and legacy of a dead leader to win votes. But he may be the first to say that his political mentor, President Hugo Chvez, visited him from beyond the grave in the form of a little bird.

title: Key to Fighting Alzheimers Costs: New Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Trip to Cuba by Beyonc and Jay-Z Is Investigated
description: MEXICO CITY  The United States Treasury Department has begun investigating whether Jay-Z and Beyonc  musics royal couple  violated the trade embargo against Cuba by traveling to the island two weeks ago during their wedding anniversary, according to officials and a person who helped arrange their visit.

title: What Reform Will Require
description: The latest scandals from Albany have generated a slew of proposals to clear out New Yorks political swamp. After the arrests of a state senator, an assemblyman, a City Council member, a suburban mayor and two Republican Party leaders last week on various corruption charges, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said he was preparing a list of reforms and tougher penalties to repair the system and  though this will take some doing  the states badly tarnished reputation.

title: Cano and Hafner Power the Yankees Over a Familiar Managerial Foe
description: CLEVELAND  Soon after he was hired to manage the Indians last October, Terry Francona found a place to live within two blocks of Progressive Field, choosing to stay close to the stadium, as he had done when he managed at Fenway Park for eight years.

title: Rite of a Taxpayer
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Beauty, in Plain Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rules Against Veteran Who Fought Alongside Syrian Rebels
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  In his brief but sensational sojourn in the Syrian civil war, Eric G. Harroun made a bit of a splash. He loaded Facebook and YouTube with scenes from the battlefield and gibes at the government of President Bashar al-Assad. In Web postings by both sides in the bloody conflict, he was The American  a former Army private from Arizona fighting with the Syrian opposition.

title: Citing Cuts, Lawyers Seek Relief in Terrorism Case
description: Federal public defenders who are representing a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden on terrorism charges urged a judge on Monday not to hold an early trial because automatic government budget cuts were requiring furloughs of lawyers in their office.

title: Aggrieved U.N. Whistle-Blower Seeks Withholding of American Funds
description: A United Nations whistle-blower who prevailed in a landmark case that exposed evidence of retribution against internal criticism, but who was awarded only a tiny fraction of his claimed financial losses, sought help from Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday, asking him to withhold 15 percent of the American governments United Nations budget allocation.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Apr. 9, 2013
description: A hospital will not last long with no doctors, and a courthouse and judicial system with no lawyers faces the same grim future.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 8, 2013

title: Slightly Fewer Children Eligible for Gifted Classes in New York
description: The number of children qualifying for seats in gifted programs in New York City public schools declined slightly this year after the Department of Education overhauled its admissions process in part to combat a recent explosion in eligibility.

title: Kissinger on Thatchers Leadership
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said Margaret Thatchers unwavering style as British prime minister defined leadership in a time of hesitation and indecision.

title: Peter Workman, Book Publisher With an Eye for Hits, Dies at 74
description: Peter Workman, the founder of Workman Publishing, whose knack for landing best-selling trade books like What to Expect When Youre Expecting, and The Silver Palate Cookbook built his company into one of the few remaining independent book publishers in the country, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Womans Corpse Lay Hidden for Hours on Tracks at Subway Station
description: She entered the subway system sometime around 1 a.m. on Sunday, dressed in dark clothes and dark boots as if coming from a night on the town. By the afternoon, her lifeless body lay among the soot-darkened track ties and trash under Canal Street.

title: Student Loan Rate Set to Rise, Despite Lack of Support
description: The interest rate on many student loans is scheduled to double on July 1, to 6.8 percent from 3.4 percent  just as it was last year, when in the midst of an election campaign, Congress voted to extend the lower rate.

title: Corrections: April 9, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Dont Bring Me Down
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Getting your first acceptance from Will Shortz as a crossword puzzle constructor is a thrilling moment. Its not quite like anything else Ive ever experienced, and I think I actually hyperventilated when I read his note. In fact, I highly recommend giving constructing a try just to get the e-mail.

title: Senate Talks on Farmworker Program Inch Forward
description: WASHINGTON  After hitting a snag last week, negotiations in the Senate for an agricultural workers program  the last piece of a broad overhaul of the nations immigration laws  appeared to be coming back from the brink on Monday.

title: A Governor Retrenches on a Big Idea
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  In a short address Monday on the first day of the legislative session, Gov. Bobby Jindal described why his next big plan  a plan that had been applauded by conservative pundits nationally, pitched at meetings around the state and promoted in slickly produced commercials  was crucial to Louisianas success.

title: Jurors Hint at Deadlock Over Killing of Therapist
description: The jury considering murder charges against David Tarloff, a schizophrenic man accused of killing a psychologist in her Upper East Side office five years ago, sent a note to the judge Monday afternoon suggesting they might not be able to reach a verdict.

title: N.C.A.A. Needs Overhauling at Top
description: ATLANTA

title: Desecration on Doorways in Brooklyn
description: Someone set fire to nearly a dozen Jewish religious symbols outside residents front doors in a Brooklyn apartment building on Monday, prompting an investigation by the Police Departments Hate Crimes Task Force.

title: Serbia: Kosovo Deal Is Rejected
description: Serbia on Monday rejected a European Union deal on Kosovo aimed at overcoming ethnic enmities, throwing into doubt its plans to join the bloc. Serbia had until Tuesday to say whether it would accept an agreement in which Serbia would tacitly accept the authority of the government in Pristina in northern Kosovo in return for receiving a start date for negotiations to join the European Union. Kosovo declared independence from Serbia in 2008.

title: Canada: Report on Taser Death
description: A coroner ruled Monday that the death of a Polish immigrant after he was repeatedly stunned with a police Taser in the Vancouver airport was a homicide. The fatal confrontation between members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Robert Dziekanski in 2007 was captured on video and led to a debate in Canada about the use of Tasers. The coroners report was delayed because of a special public inquiry. The new finding has no legal consequences for the police. While no criminal charges were laid against the four officers, they have been charged with perjury related to their testimony to the inquiry.

title: Afghanistan: Bomb Kills 9
description: A roadside bomb killed at least nine civilians on a public bus on Monday. The attack, which also wounded at least 20 people, occurred in the Sayad Abad district of Wardak Province, an area seen as a strategic staging ground for insurgent attacks on Kabul, said Fazal Karim Muslim, the district governor. Last week, 44 civilians were killed in an insurgent attack on a government compound in Farah Province. On Saturday, a suicide bomber struck a convoy of Afghan and coalition officials, killing five Americans in Zabul Province. And in Kunar Province, at least 10 children were killed Saturday in an airstrike called in by American and Afghan troops who were pursuing a Taliban commander.

title: Rangers, Trailing Most of the Game, Forge a Tie, Then Quickly Lose It
description: TORONTO  Coach John Tortorella lamented the breakdown that cost the Rangers the game.

title: Ed Fisher, New Yorker Cartoonist, Dies at 86
description: Ed Fisher, whose culturally savvy cartoons, featured in The New Yorker for nearly 50 years, made wry sport of modern life, frequently matching images from history or folklore with captions in an up-to-date mode, died on April 3 in Canaan, Conn. He was 86.

title: In London, Remembering Thatcher
description: Londoners reflect on Margaret Thatchers legacy.

title: Mets Harvey Outshines Phillies Halladay
description: PHILADELPHIA  The contrast was striking: an aging pitcher descending, a young pitcher ascending, their paths meeting for a few compelling hours.

title: KPMG Fires a Senior Partner in an Insider Trading Episode
description: KPMG said late Monday night it had fired a senior partner in its Los Angeles office after learning that he had provided inside information to an unnamed individual who then used that information in stock trades involving several West Coast companies.

title: Knicks Run Fueled by the Shooting of Two Hot Hands
description: In the three-month span from Dec. 16 to March 16, the Knicks played 41 games, lost 21 of them and never stopped referring to themselves as championship contenders  a world-class case of cognitive dissonance.

title: Afghanistan: 2 French Civilians Are Freed
description: Months after their separate kidnappings in Afghanistan, two French civilians were free of their captors on Monday, French and Afghan officials said. One of the men, identified as a freelance photojournalist, escaped his captors in Wardak Province and was transferred to Frances embassy in Kabul, an Afghan Interior Ministry spokesman said. The man, identified as Pierre Borghi, had been taken hostage on a street in Kabul in November by four armed men, the spokesman said, according to Reuters. French officials had made no public statement regarding the capture of Mr. Borghi or the other man, whose identity was not announced but whom French news media identified as a humanitarian aid worker. French news media and the families of French captives typically publicize hostage situations; such was not the case for either of the men freed on Monday, whose cases were not included by French officials or advocacy groups in their tallies of hostages throughout the world.

title: Wary of North Korea, Japan Puts Missile Defense in Tokyo
description: TOKYO  The Japanese Army set up a battery of interceptor missiles on the grounds of the Defense Ministry in central Tokyo on Tuesday, as the nation girded itself for a possible missile test by North Korea, maybe as soon as this week.

title: Rivals for Kerry Senate Seat Debate
description: LOWELL, Mass.  The Democratic primary for the nomination to fill the United States Senate seat recently vacated by the wealthy John Kerry is becoming a low-key tussle over which candidates roots are more humble.

title: A Football Widows Traumatic Journey
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  The end of Ralph Wenzel as his wife knew him began in January 2007. They were descending a flight of stairs at San Francisco International Airport, on their way to the baggage claim, after a two-week trip to Hawaii.

title: Despite Abbreviated Spring, Murphy Starts Strong
description: PHILADELPHIA  Second baseman Daniel Murphy has earned a reputation as a meticulous worker, an obsessive calibrator and recalibrator of his swing.

title: Garden Mania
description: This seasons haute couture shows in Paris were inspired by nature.

title: Word of the Day | utopia
description: utopia \yu-to-pe-\ noun

title: No. 1 at the Start, and No. 1 at the Finish
description: ATLANTA  Behind the Louisville bench, those in cardinal red remained on their feet in the final minutes, unable to sit down, or feel comfortable, or breathe. Peyton Siva drove and Gorgui Dieng swatted and Luke Hancock launched 3-pointers. Here was Louisville, the top seed in this N.C.A.A. tournament, playing like it until the end.

title: Images of Dead Pigs Reduce Chinas Appetite for Pork, Keep Prices Down
description: HONG KONG  Consumer prices rose less than expected last month in China as the unappetizing and widely televised spectacle of thousands of dead pigs floating upstream from Shanghai helped push pork prices down sharply, the government reported on Tuesday.

title: For 2 Unheralded Players, a 3-Point Shootout
description: ATLANTA  The nets did not move. That is how pure their jumpers were. In they went, again and again, from 21 feet and beyond, shot by a Michigan freshman named Spike and a Louisville junior named Luke. No one dared miss, and neither did. It was the highest-stakes game of Horse they had ever played  on the raised court of the Georgia Dome, a national championship the prize  and, perhaps, the unlikeliest one, too.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE GIRL WHO PLAYED WITH FIRE (2010) Noomi Rapace, above, reprises her role as Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker, and Michael Nyqvist is Mikael Blomkvist, the crusading journalist who is her confidant and alter ego, in this sequel to The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, based on the second novel in the Swedish trilogy by Stieg Larsson and directed by Daniel Alfredson. The plot this time concerns a young journalist and his girlfriend, a graduate student, who have been investigating a sex-trafficking ring with patrons high up the political chain. It is Ms. Rapaces fierce and sly performance, more than the themes or the plot, that sustains The Girl Who Played With Fire, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Without her, it would be a not bad procedural, touching on some knotty contemporary issues and infused with a paranoia that is at once unsettling and comforting. But, he added, Ms. Rapace, tiny and agile, her steely rage showing now and then the tiniest crack of vulnerability, belongs to another dimension altogether. She makes this movie good enough, but also makes you wish it were much better.

title: The Time the Iron Lady Turned Before China
description: 4:28 a.m. | Updated BEIJING  The ladys not for turning, Margaret Thatcher, who died on Monday, told an audience of fellow Conservatives in Britain in late 1980. The phrase would become a signature of her personality and governing style.

title: The Phillies and Their Ace Have Lost Their Touch
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: News Quiz | April 9, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Louisville Wins Championship
description: The Louisville Cardinals beat the Michigan Wolverines, 82-76, for the N.C.A.A. championship.

title: North Korea Warns It Is on Brink of Nuclear War With South
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As North Korea warned foreigners on Tuesday that they might want to leave South Korea because the peninsula was on the brink of nuclear war  a statement that analysts dismissed as hyperbole  the American commander in the Pacific expressed worries that the Norths young leader, Kim Jong-un, might not have left himself an easy exit to reduce tensions.

title: Britons Reflect on Divided Views of Thatcher Legacy
description: LONDON  With broadcasters, columnists and editorialists absorbed in chronicling Margaret Thatchers life, times and demise, Britons on Tuesday mulled the ideological divide that her critics and even some of her admirers depicted as deepening during her years as prime minister.

title: IHT Quick Read, April 9
description: NEWS A group of Googles rivals filed an antitrust complaint alleging abuse of its mobile Android software. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: Nuclear Plant in Japan Has Leak in Other Tank
description: The operator of Japans crippled nuclear plant halted an emergency operation Tuesday to pump thousands of gallons of radioactive water from a leaking underground storage pool after workers discovered that a similar pool, to which the water was being transferred, was also leaking.

title: For Farmers in Bihar, A Simple Solution for More Crops
description: Muzaffarpur, BIHAR  On a recent spring afternoon, Susheela Devi, 50, was excitedly preparing to sow maize and okra on her one-and-a-half-acre plot.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 9, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Opinion piece Remembering an Easter Miracle in Northern Ireland by Colum McCann

title: Margaret Thatcher, Former British Prime Minister, Dies
description: In Tributes Pour In for Margaret Thatcher, Alan Cowell and John F. Burns write about how the former British prime minister is being remembered after her death on Monday.

title: Shooting Weddings, for Better or for Worse
description: Bill McCullough played pedal steel guitar for Knife in the Water, an Austin, Tex., band whose sound was the perfect soundtrack for downing a fifth of bourbon alone in your car, parked outside your exs house in the dead of winter. Unfortunately, he wasnt much of a drinker. So, while his bandmates hit the bar after the sound check, he would wander, taking pictures with a camera he brought with him on the road. Working nooks and crannies and finding odd angles, he rediscovered his love of photography.

title: How a Single Spy Helped Turn Pakistan Against the United States
description: The burly American was escorted by Pakistani policemen into a crowded interrogation room. Amid a clatter of ringing mobile phones and cross talk among the cops speaking a mishmash of Urdu, Punjabi and English, the investigator tried to decipher the facts of the case.

title: How Does Your School Deal With Students Who Misbehave?
description: No matter what kind of school you attend, students sometimes get in trouble. Maybe they get into a fight, get caught cheating, pull a prank, use alcohol or an illegal drug, or disrespect a teacher or another student. What happens next?

title: Gunman Kills 13 People in Serbian Village
description: WARSAW  A 60-year-old man went on a shooting rampage in a village near Belgrade, Serbia, early Tuesday, killing 13 people, including his son, his mother and a 2-year-old child, before attempting suicide, Serbian police officials and news reports said.

title: Bards Early Experiment
description: In Bards new high school, an escape from Newarks mean streets.

title: The Early Word: In Remembrance
description: Todays Times

title: Rigorous Schools Put College Dreams Into Practice
description: ALONG his block in Newarks West Ward, where drugs are endemic and the young residents talk about shootings with alarming nonchalance, Najee Little is known as the smart kid. He got all As his sophomore year, breezing through math and awing his English teachers. His mother, a day care worker, and father, who does odd jobs to make ends meet, have high aspirations for him. They want him to earn a college degree.

title: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions on Making the Final College Decision
description: The Choice has invited Marie Bigham, a former college admissions officer and veteran college counselor, and Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert, to answer your questions about comparing financial aid offers and deciding where to enroll in the blogs virtual Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

title: Americas Most Profitable Export Is Cash
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Billabong in Talks Over $300 Million Takeover
description: Billabong International is trying to avoid a total wipeout.

title: Processing Credit Cards and Anger
description: Id like to thank everyone who took time to comment on my posts on searching for credit card processing. Many of those comments shed additional light on aspects of the experience that I, for the sake of brevity and clarity, left out. As I hope I made clear, the world of card processing is extremely complex. Here are a few further thoughts, in no particular order:

title: Are Front Yards the New Backyards?
description: To supplement the Key section on real estate and design in last weekends magazine, which focused on outdoor living, we asked readers to send in front-yard photos. Heres a slide show of some of our favorites, which among other things feature rows of lavender in North Carolina, a sturdy tree in Joplin and flamingos in the snow in Massachusetts. Thanks to everyone who participated.

title: Daily Report: Keeping Tabs on Students E-Reading
description: Educators from nine universities are testing technology from a Silicon Valley start-up company, CourseSmart, allowing them to track their students progress with digital textbooks, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times.

title: China Reports 2 More Deaths From Bird Flu
description: Chinas state media confirmed that two more people in the eastern part of the country had died Tuesday from the H7N9 virus, bringing the total number of fatalities to nine.

title: J.C. Penney Ousts a Leader Ackman Championed
description: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman had bet on Ron Johnson as the man to revive the fortunes of J.C. Penney. But on Monday the embattled retailer ousted Mr. Johnson, its chief executive of 17 months, going back to the previous C.E.O., Myron E. Ullman III.

title: Who Knew That Greenwich, Conn., Was a Model of Equality?
description: Manuel Bonilla looked at me, confused. I had just asked him if he worried about entering his son into the Greenwich, Conn., public-school system. Greenwich, of course, is one of the wealthiest towns in America, home to hedge-fund billionaires like Steven A. Cohen, who has a world-renowned art collection and had a private ice rink. Bonilla is a handyman whose family struggles to make the rent. Wasnt he just a little concerned that his child would feel self-conscious?

title: Phrases We Love Too Much
description: Why all the channeling?

title: In Performance: Adam Kantor of The Last Five Years
description: Jason Robert Browns 2002 musical The Last Five Years is a two-character show about a couple, Jamie and Cathy, whose relationship is deteriorating. The story uses an unconventional chronology: Jamies arc begins when he meets Cathy and then progresses forward, while Cathys begins with the couples parting kiss and runs backward. In this number, Adam Kantor, who plays Jamie, is accompanied by Gary Sieger on guitar in an excerpt from If I Didnt Believe in You. The show, directed by Mr. Brown, continues through May 12 at Second Stage Theater.

title: Opinion Report: Margaret Thatcher
description: From the editorial page

title: Not Your Average Jane Doe
description: TEL AVIV  Her name is Riki Cohen, she is 37 and a teacher, and she lives in Hadera, a small city between Tel Aviv and Haifa. She has three children and a husband who works in the high-tech sector. Together, the Cohens earn just over $5,500 a month. They travel abroad every two years and worry about having to assist their children financially well into adulthood. Also, they are imaginary.

title: A Conversation With: Author Ariel Dorfman
description: Ariel Dorfman is a Chilean-American writer, poet, playwright and essayist. He went into political exile in 1973 when President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile died in a military coup and his democratically elected government was overthrown. Mr. Dorfman has been a strong voice against political oppression and human rights abuses. His notable works include Death and the Maiden, a play that was turned into a Hollywood film in 1994 by the same name. After living in Europe for several years, he settled in the United States and has taught literature and Latin American studies at Duke University for nearly three decades.

title: A Baby in Business Class
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Past Is Present
description: See the interactive slide show

title: SeaWorld Seeks Up to $540 Million in I.P.O.
description: The theme park operator SeaWorld Entertainment is looking to make a showy market debut, as it seeks to raise up to $540 million in its initial public offering.

title: Image of the Day: April 9
Reporting Under Thatchers Gaze
description: LONDON  It was impossible to report on Margaret Thatcher up close without occasionally falling victim to the icy stare.

title: On the Tracks, and Out of Time
description: The other day, a Philadelphia man made headlines when he saved someone who had fallen from a train platform. Back in December in New York, Victor Samuel, 43, an information-services account manager from Queens, did something similar, jumping to the subway tracks to rescue a disoriented man. Mr. Samuel tells how it feels to have 400 tons of train bearing down on you.

title: Lifted by Gun Control Issue, Democrat Wins House Seat
description: CHICAGO  Robin Kelly, whose stance on stricter federal gun laws brought a cascade of super PAC support to her campaign earlier this year, easily won the Congressional seat resigned by Jesse L. Jackson Jr. in a special election here Tuesday.

title: A Great Briton
description: Margaret Thatcher, Britains Iron Lady, was a political lightning rod.

title: KPMG Cancels Audits Over Insider Trading Inquiry
description: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

title: Guns and Money
description: On Wednesday, President Obama will unveil his first budget proposal since the massacre in Newtown, Connecticut. One thing to look for is whether he will challenge the quiet weakening of gun enforcement embedded in the recently signed Continuing Resolution, the stopgap spending plan for the second half of this fiscal year.

title: Ivan Fischer Returning to Mostly Mozart Festival With Some New Tricks
description: Along with meticulous musical preparation, the inventive conductor Ivan Fischer likes to mix up orchestra seatings and strew singers amid the instrumentalists. He polls audiences for their choice of encore. At the Mostly Mozart Festival two years ago Mr. Fischer used a chorus to create human tableau sets for a concert version of Don Giovanni.

title: What Were Reading
description: Science Daily: Radical mutterings from the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society: a runny egg yolk may not be the most delicious egg yolk after all.  Julia Moskin

title: The Return of the Ramayana
description: NEW DELHI  The news last month that Amish Tripathi was offered $1 million to write his next series of books astounded Indias English-language publishing industry. Advances of even $25,000 are rare here, and Tripathi still isnt sure of the new works precise theme. That the deal was struck simply on the success of his 2010 trilogy about Shiva, the Hindu deity, is the starkest measure yet that Indian mythology has become the most marketable segment of Indias English-language book market.

title: Before Meeting Syrian Opposition, Kerry Says U.S. Is Considering More Support
description: LONDON  On the eve of a meeting with the Syrian opposition, Secretary of State John Kerry said Tuesday that the Obama administration was weighing stepped-up efforts to support the rebel fighters, and that such proposals had been front and center in administration discussions over the past week.

title: McCandlish Phillips, Who Exposed a Jewish Klansman, Is Dead at 85
description: McCandlish Phillips, a former reporter for The New York Times who wrote one of the most famous articles in the newspapers history  exposing the Orthodox Jewish background of a senior Ku Klux Klan official  before forsaking journalism to spread the Gospel, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Wheelies: The Not-So-Fast Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: After an Audience Vote, Billy Elliot Musical Keeps an Anti-Thatcher Song
description: Even as much of Britain mourned the death of Margaret Thatcher on Monday, the West End production of Billy Elliot the Musical went ahead that evening with a song that refers to celebrating her death. The BBC reported that the musical, adapted from the Stephen Daldry movie, retained the number Merry Christmas Maggie Thatcher when it was performed on Monday night at the Victoria Palace theater in London, after its audience voted in favor of keeping it.

title: U.N. Relief Agency Resumes Full Operation in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The United Nations Relief and Works Agency said that it was resuming full operations in Gaza on Tuesday, reversing a decision to suspend food distribution after protesters stormed its main compound on Thursday. The agency provides staples and other services in Gaza for 815,000 Palestinian refugees and their descendants, nearly half the population of the Hamas-run enclave. The protesters were angry about the cancellation of a cash-assistance program for the poor because of a budget deficit. The agency said in a statement that it was reopening its installations across Gaza based on assurances from local parties, but that it would be forced to close them again if its staff or facilities were threatened or its operations hindered by demonstrations.

title: Tuesday Reading: Hip Surgery for a Better Sex Life
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Gun Report: April 9, 2013
description: Some readers think we dont pay enough attention to defensive gun use. We have a couple of examples today, but there is a rarely reported dark side to relying on firearms for self-protection.

title: Q&A: Requesting Refunds From Google Play
description: Q.

title: Lobbyists Fighting Spending Cuts Find Ally in Group That Often Backs Them
description: As one of the countrys largest and oldest conservative advocacy groups, the American Conservative Union has long fought to rein in federal spending and limit the size of government.

title: Doing the Math
description: Wonkblog links to a lovely piece by E.O. Wilson on how much math you need to do research. Wilsons answer is, not much; and I agree with a caveat. The caveat is this: at least in the areas I work in, you do need some mathematical intuition, even if you dont necessarily need to know a lot of formal theorems.

title: [Video] Intersection: Spring Style in Long Island City
description: For the latest Intersection video, we went to Long Island City, Queens, and visited MoMA PS1, the contemporary art space. On a recent chilly afternoon, we talked to a few visitors and an employee about how they put personal touches on their transitional spring looks.

title: Deficit Derangement Syndrome
description: This Dylan Matthews piece on the evils people perceive from deficits, and why theyre almost all wrong, is a must-read. I would quibble with a few points  in particular, it really doesnt matter how much of our public debt foreigners own, what matters is our overall net international investment position (do we as a country owe more to foreigners than they owe to us). And I wish hed made the no-crowding-out point in terms of the state of the economy, not just actual interest rates. But these are minor points, and the overall thrust of the piece is excellent.

title: Video: An Explosion 160 Feet Below Grand Central
description: Those who enjoy watching things blowing up (and nobody getting hurt) and men playing with toys should get a kick out of this video provided on Tuesday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: David Axelrod Writing a Memoir
description: David Axelrod, the political strategist behind the rise of President Obama, has signed with Penguin Press to write a memoir, the publisher said Tuesday morning. Release is slated for fall 2014.

title: Big Dell Shareholder Prefers 2 Rival Bids
description: One of the most vocal critics of Dells proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder has clearly not been swayed by the argument for the buyout made in the companys recent proxy statement.

title: Israeli Court Sentences U.S. Immigrant to 2 Life Terms
description: JERUSALEM  A Jerusalem court on Tuesday sentenced an American immigrant convicted of killing two Palestinians in 1997 to two consecutive life terms in prison, as well as additional time for attempted murders, weapons violations and incitement to violence or terrorism. Known as the Jewish terrorist, Yaakov (Jack) Teitel, an extremist who lived in a West Bank settlement, was convicted of other crimes including bombings in 2008 that wounded a leftist Israeli professor and a teenage boy belonging to a community of Jews who believe in Jesus. Mr. Teitel was also ordered to pay compensation to the families of the victims.

title: Albany Riveted by Double Life of an Assemblyman and Informer
description: On a drizzly Monday in Albany, Nelson L. Castro, in sharp red tie, rose on the floor of the State Assembly to welcome a delegation of fellow Dominican-Americans visiting from New York City. The 199th anniversary of the birth of Juan Pablo Duarte, a founding father of the Dominican Republic, was approaching, and Mr. Castro had prepared a resolution to honor him.

title: Mary Roachs Inside View
