description: Mary Roachs new book, Gulp, induces both belly laughs and the occasional gag reflex as it explores what happens to food as it passes through a persons alimentary canal. We asked the 54-year-old author of Stiff and Bonk, who lives in the Bay Area, about the bites and sips that take the fantastic voyage past her mischievous grin.

title: Champions League Quarterfinals Matchday 3
description: Four teams entered, two teams left but what an exit it was.

title: Best Illustrated Childrens Books 2008
description: The Book Review chooses the years 10 best illustrated childrens books.

title: A Singular Life, an All Too Common End
description: The long list of roles Margaret Thatcher played during her 87 years  potent politician, free-market evangelist, labor antagonist, dominant global leader  includes the one she never publicly discussed: person with dementia.

title: An Envelope Emblazoned With a Huge Youre In!
description: I was under the (erroneous) impression, established by movies (whod have thought?), that when college acceptance letters came, they arrived in blank white envelopes too large to carry notice of inheritance from some stuffy great-aunt and too small for, well, a pipe bomb, though both could, conceivably, smell of mildew and shattered dreams.

title: Thatcher, Through Bold British Headlines
description: In Westminster, Londoners remember Margaret Thatcher while picking up their favorite newspapers, each splashed with its own take on the former prime minister.

title: Photo Replay: April 9
description: A view of the day in sports, including the European weight lifting championships in Tirana, Albania.

title: First Checks to Be Issued in Mortgage Settlement
description: The nations top banking regulators have some good news for some troubled homeowners: the checks will be in the mail soon.

title: A Book by Its Covers
description: A collection of Great Gatsby editions offers an illuminating cross section of 83 years of book design.

title: Game of Thrones, Not Mad Men, Had the Bigger Sunday Night
description: The real hit drama on cable last Sunday night was not Mad Men, even with all the talk in the news media about its premiere; the clear winner was Game of Thrones on HBO.

title: Triple Play: Week 1 Results
description: The Dodgers Clayton Kershaw (0.00 earned run average) dominated his fellow aces in our first question of the season. But then, thats what happens when you dont give up any runs in two starts.

title: He Held On to His Play Until She Could Be in It
description: In The Revisionist, playing through April 27 in a Rattlestick Playwrights Theater production, Jesse Eisenberg, the plays author, stars as David, a young American who goes to visit a second cousin in Poland, where he hopes to finish work on his science-fiction novel. The cousin, Maria, played by Vanessa Redgrave, is harboring deep secrets. During a recent interview at the 179-seat Cherry Lane Theater, where the play is being staged Off Broadway, Mr. Eisenberg and Ms. Redgrave sat on a well-worn sofa that looked as if it might have been dragged out of a freshman-floor TV lounge.

title: Knicks Chandler Doubtful for Wizards Game
description: Tyson Chandler is again having discomfort in his neck and was considered doubtful for the Knicks game against the Washington Wizards on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. His status for the final five regular-season games was unclear.

title: A Student Debt Repayment Option for Some Parents
description: Parents who take out federal Parent Plus loans to help pay for their childrens college education typically dont qualify for some breaks available to student borrowers themselves, like repayment options that take their income into account.

title: Former British Bank Chief to Give Up Knighthood
description: LONDON  For some British bankers, a knighthood is not for life.

title: Torn Between Two Start-Up Communities
description: Most start-ups fail.Its a fact.Its also a fact that I dont consider failure an option. I started Fashioning Change in San Diego where I went through the Founder Institute, a tech accelerator that connected me to some of the top technology minds in San Diego and around the country. I entered the program as the only social enterprise, as one of the youngest participants and as the only woman of the 23 entrepreneurs accepted.

title: A Book by its Covers
description: Francis Coradal-Cugats original cover art for The Great Gatsby, which Baz Luhrmann brings to the big screen next month, depicts a disembodied face floating in a night sky. It is one of the lasting images in literature, but that hasnt kept book designers from trying to outdo it. The scholar and F. Scott Fitzgerald biographer Matthew J. Bruccoli spent his adult life stockpiling those efforts  pulpy paperbacks, fancy slip-covers, French-flapped foreign editions  and today his trove is not only one of the worlds most complete collections but also an illuminating cross section of 83 years of book design. Now housed at the University of South Carolina, the collection is worth several million dollars but Bruccoli, who died in 2008, claimed he was never motivated by money. You dont buy books as an investment, he said. You buy them because it gives you pleasure to read them, to touch them . . . to see them on shelves.

title: For Margaret Thatcher, a Wardrobe Was Armor
description: THE LIPS OF MARILYN MONROE and the eyes of Caligula was a neat summing up of the power woman presented by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: Gun Control Meets an Unforgiving Math in Congress
description: In Colorado, a state of hunters and sportsmen, the Democrats who control state government acted last month not only to expand background checks for gun sales, but also to ban the kind of high-capacity magazines that gunmen have used in recent mass shootings in Newtown, Conn., Aurora, Colo., and Tucson.

title: A Very Busy Man Behind the Syrian Civil Wars Casualty Count
description: COVENTRY, England  Military analysts in Washington follow its body counts of Syrian and rebel soldiers to gauge the course of the war. The United Nations and human rights organizations scour its descriptions of civilian killings for evidence in possible war crimes trials. Major news organizations, including this one, cite its casualty figures.

title: Fleetwood Mac to Release New Songs
description: Fleetwood Mac plans to release an EP of new songs in the near future, Lindsey Buckingham, the groups lead singer and guitarist, said during a concert in Philadelphia on Saturday, according to Rolling Stone magazine. Introducing one of the songs during the show at the Wells Fargo Center, Mr. Buckingham said the group had gone into the studio last year and recorded several original tracks, calling the material the best stuff we have done in a long time. He said the band would release a few of the songs in a few days, then the group proceeded to play one of them, a mid-temp rock song called Sad Angel.

title: When East Meets West, Parents and Grandparents Collide
description: When I was eight months pregnant, my British husband and I were living in my native country of India. I dont know how  and I wish I did, so that Id know to avoid these awkward detours in conversation in the future  but chatting with my mother one afternoon, I landed on the subject of car seats. How my husband and I intended to buy one so that we could, you know, bring the baby home safely.

title: A Medical Service Using the Cloud
description: Practice Fusion is a company that offers doctors cloud-based electronic medical records software for managing relationships with patients and big parts of the health care industry. It also seems like a good place to explore feelings about privacy, and the business of Big Data.

title: Worth Your Weight in Gold
description: Travelers taking the carrier Samoa Air have an incentive besides health and vanity to shed a few pounds. The airline has adopted a policy of charging its passengers according to what they weigh.

title: A Pasta Dish Straight From the Pantry
description: In Whats for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diners Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: In Praise of the Profile, Before the Age of Public Relations
description: The one thing these three books have in common is that they were written before the celebrity-industrial complex was fully formed, when a journalist could still push past an artists P.R. phalanx and come back with a story that possessed real feeling and offbeat detail.

title: Oyster Farm Caught Up in Pipeline Politics
description: POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE, Calif.  Seen from a nearby hilltop, the Drakes Bay Oyster Company is a cluster of shacks with faded white walls. One patched roof appears at risk of being blown away by the next Pacific squall. A dozen workers on a small weather-beaten dock were busy handling a batch of oysters harvested on a recent morning, separating the mollusks on a single rusty conveyor belt.

title: After Talks End, Iran Announces an Expansion of Nuclear Fuel Production
description: MOSCOW  Irans president announced an expansion of the countrys uranium production and claimed other atomic energy advances on Tuesday, striking a pugnacious tone in the aftermath of diplomatic talks that ended in an impasse with the big powers last weekend in Kazakhstan.

title: The Falklands Without Thatcher
Silence on Awkward Topics at Inauguration of Kenyas President
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Once again, a Kenyatta has taken the reins.

title: Substitution in Giulio Cesare at the Met
description: Danielle de Niese, one of the Metropolitan Operas favored sopranos, is stepping in for another, Natalie Dessay, as Cleopatra in Tuesday nights performance of Giulio Cesare by Handel, the Met said. Ms. Dessay is ill, the company said, noting that Ms. De Niese has sung the role in the same production at the Glyndebourne Festival in 2005 and at the Lyric Opera of Chicago in 2007, as well as in a different production at the Met in the 2006-7 season.

title: Updates on the Gun Debate | April 9, 2013
description: President Obama made an impassioned plea for gun control measures at a rally in Connecticut. Families who lost loved ones in the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School descended on Washington to press their case with lawmakers. Senate Republicans threatened to prevent gun control legislation from even coming up for debate as states around the country decide to both strengthen and weaken gun laws.

title: Pitinos Week Kept Getting Better
description: ATLANTA

title: Japan Re-Emerges in the Aerospace Arena With a New Jet
description: TOKYO  As a small boy, Teruaki Kawai watched wide-eyed as American DC-3s took off and landed at a small airport across an inlet from his home on the Hiroshima coast.

title: How Thatcher Changed Britain
description: The Times's Alan Cowell and Marcus Mabry analyze the significance of the Margaret Thatcher years.

title: He Got the Finicky French to Eat His Veggies
description: LOUVIERS, France  Baptiste Bourdon wipes his muddy hands on his jeans and shakes the curls out of his eyes, which are aimed at the sky.

title: New Guidelines Call for Broad Changes in Science Education
description: Educators unveiled new guidelines on Tuesday that call for sweeping changes in the way science is taught in the United States  including, for the first time, a recommendation that climate change be taught as early as middle school.

title: Whos No. 1? The Knicks and Anthony
description: The resurgent Knicks are finally No. 1: in jersey sales.

title: Living in Saugatuck, Conn.
description: Part of Westport, the community is known for its water views and lively commercial district.

title: What I-95 Hasnt Put Asunder
description: Drivers in general may be reduced to cursing  silently or otherwise  as they inch along Interstate 95 in parts of Connecticut during rush hour. But for many of the 2,500 or so residents of Saugatuck, a waterside slice of Westport 48 miles from Manhattan, the dislike is almost personal.

title: Renault Shows Edgy Concept at Milan Furniture Fair
description: Renault unveiled a striking blue concept car by Ross Lovegrove, aBritish furniture and product designer, at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile di Milano furniture show on Monday. The electric city car, dubbed the TwinZ, has center opening doors and is dotted, outside and in, with hundreds of LEDs. The project was the idea of Laurens van den Acker, the Renault design director.

title: Bird Flu Concerns and North Korean Jitters
description: China has now confirmed 28 cases of infection with the bird flu virus H7N9. Eight people have died. The government has learned many lessons from the SARS outbreak in 2003 and subsequent cover-up, and so far the World Health Organization has publicly praised Chinas handling of this new flu variant.

title: A Wild-Card Pairing for Coconut Curry
description: Many people would simply pair beer with Melissa Clarks rich coconut curry, a wise and sensible choice. Pilsner, Saison, Belgian white ales, India pale ales and any other tart, bracing brew would do nicely. But many wines would work surprisingly well, too. There are the versatile usuals, of course: Champagne, off-dry German rieslings, demi-sec Vouvrays, crisp sauvignon blancs. I think a good amontillado sherry would be delicious; assertive enough to cut through the richness of the coconut milk and reflect the sweet, spicy, herbal flavors.

title: If You Like Jos Feliciano, Try Ben Howard
Lews Visit to Europe Reveals a Wide Policy Divide
description: PARIS  The two-day effort by the United States Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, to persuade Europe to consider shifting its focus from budget balance to growth highlighted a deep trans-Atlantic policy gulf that is likely to leave Europe as a drag on the global economy.

title: Threat to Block Debate on Guns Appears to Fade in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Several Senate Republicans said Tuesday that they would not participate in a filibuster of the first major gun control bill since 1993, as Democrats appeared on the verge of overcoming a blockade threatened by a group of conservatives before a word of debate on the measure was uttered.

title: Murder Ballad to Sing Again in Union Square
description: Murder Ballad, a rock musical by Julia Jordan and the singer-songwriter Juliana Nash, will return for nine weeks at the Union Square Theater, starting May 7. Staged in a barroom setting in which the actors roamed through the audience, the show had a sold-out premiere run last fall at Manhattan Theater Clubs Studio at Stage II.

title: The Sugar Hiding in Everyday Foods
description: Weve written about the dangers of sugar many times, and we know that sodas are chock full of it. But what about everyday foods? Today we bring you an excellent video by Buzzfeed revealing the astonishing amount of sugar in foods we dont associate with being necessarily sugary. What do you think has more sugar: baked beans or Monster Energy Drink? Youd be surprised.

title: Coptic Christian Leader in Egypt Criticizes Government Over Violence
description: CAIRO  The leader of the Coptic Orthodox Church accused President Mohamed Morsis government on Tuesday of delinquency and misjudgments for failing to prevent sectarian street-fighting that escalated into an attack on the churchs main cathedral after a funeral mass over the weekend, leaving at least six Christians dead.

title: What Do You Think of the New Next Generation Science Standards?
description: Updated | April 10

title: The Top Republicans to Watch in Congress
description: The Timess Rick Berke, Ashley Parker and Jeremy Peters pick the top Republicans to watch as Congress debates gun legislation and immigration reform.

title: A Good Drink, Hold the Pretense
description: Prizefighter, a bar in the Bay Area, doesnt look like much at first glance. Its in a boxy brick building with a lot of space but not much in the way of distinctive dcor. Its not even in San Francisco, but in Emeryville, a small community in the East Bay.

title: The Top Democrats to Watch in Congress
description: The Timess Rick Berke, Ashley Parker and Jeremy Peters pick the top Democrats to watch as Congress debates gun legislation and immigration reform.

title: GSN Considers Adding Church-Based Dating Show
description: Spurred by the success of an original game show that rewards knowledge of the Bible rather than, say, how much grocery items cost at the supermarket checkout, the GSN cable channel is considering a dating show with a religious twist: congregations will seek suitable mates for single parishioners.

title: Holding Silvan': Letting Go of a Life and an Ideal About Death
description: After Monica Wesolowska gave birth to her first child, a healthy-seeming boy, things took a fast and grim turn: her son, Silvan, was taken from her arms for observation, rushed unexpectedly through hospital hallways and ultimately given the worst possible prognosis.

title: Feeling For | Gelareh Mizrahis Skateboards
description: Its no secret that the fashion crowd has a certain affinity for skate style. The designer Gelareh Mizrahi is no exception; shes tricked out her skateboards with python skin. Mizrahis extravagant board isnt for every day, but it does add a little authenticity to the graphic Kenzo hoodies and Celine slip-ons favored by the fashion set.

title: With Popularity Fading at Home, Is Jindal the New Romney?
description: Mondays article on the nations least popular governors did not include Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, because he is not up for re-election in 2014. (Louisianas next gubernatorial election will be in 2015, and Mr. Jindal will not be eligible, having served two consecutive terms.) But recent surveys suggest that Mr. Jindal has become very unpopular in his home state amid a series of battles on fiscal policy. A March poll from Southern Media & Opinion Research put Mr. Jindals approval rating at just 38 percent, against 60 percent disapproval. His numbers had been similarly poor in a February survey by Public Policy Polling.

title: Worlds Tech Companies Look to Brussels to Resolve Antitrust Complaints
description: BRUSSELS  When the European competition commissioner needs to communicate with the chairman of Google, he doesnt have to send an emissary or even pick up the phone.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Tax Deduction Envy
Long-Term Care Costs Rising
description: The cost of long-term care in nursing homes and assisted-living sites is increasing at a dramatic pace compared with the cost of in-home care, an annual industry survey finds.

title: A Headphone Thats an Oldie but a Goodie
description: Youd think newer always means better. Especially for headphones, where it seems a new model is minted every hour.

title: Front Burner
description: To Prepare: Whole-Wheat Pasta and Its Cousins

title: Bump in Ratings for Mens College Basketball Final
description: Once again, sports proved to be an attraction that defies the general erosion of networks ratings, as CBSs coverage of Mondays N.C.A.A. championship mens basketball game pulled in 23.4 million viewers, up 12 percent from the game a year ago.

title: In Blacks, Alzheimers Study Finds Same Variant Genes as in Whites
description: African-Americans have a slightly higher risk of Alzheimers disease than people of largely European ancestry, but there is no major genetic difference that could account for the slight excess risk, new research shows.

title: Timing of Senate Immigration Bill Remains Unclear
description: 6:09 p.m. | Updated Will the bipartisan group of eight senators hoping to overhaul the nations immigration laws meet their unofficial deadline of introducing legislation by the end of this week?

title: The First Signs of Spring
description: Ah, the first sunny and warm day of spring in New York. If you were out on Fifth Avenue at lunchtime, you would have seen just about everyone smiling a bit more brightly than usual.

title: Crowded Courtroom for N.F.L. Lawsuit
description: PHILADELPHIA  The two legal teams, the one for the N.F.L. and the one for the retired players suing the league for negligence and fraud, were stacked with top talent, including litigators who have argued in front of the Supreme Court.

title: This Time, Chicken Little Is Striking It Rich
description: As a longtime enthusiastic consumer (and, in more recent years, purveyor) of apocalyptic narratives, I empathized readily with the obsessive anxieties of Mitchell Zukor, the protagonist of Nathaniel Richs new novel, Odds Against Tomorrow. Mitchell, were told on the very first page, dreams of an erupting supervolcano that would bury North America under a foot of hot ash.

title: The Performance-Driven Progressive and the Collapsing Conservative
description: A quick study in contrast.

title: Colleagues Recall Steady Rise of a Young Diplomat Killed in Afghanistan
description: She was an unassuming young diplomat, only 25, who greeted journalists at the heavily fortified American Embassy gates in Kabul, escorting them to interviews and impressing them with her organization and her studied wish to build bridges between Afghan and American cultures.

title: The Essence of College Sports
description: There is a lot wrong with college basketball, but the N.C.A.A. still provides a lot of great opportunities for young athletes, as was evident again in this years tournament.

title: Iraqs Branch of  Al Qaeda Merges With Syria Jihadists
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iraqs branch of Al Qaeda said Tuesday that it had merged with the Nusra Front, a group of jihadists fighting to topple President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, in a marriage that appeared to strengthen the role of Islamic militants in the Syrian insurgency and further complicate Western assistance efforts.

title: J.C. Penney Shows How the Market Overvalues the C.E.O.
description: The debacle at J.C. Penney exposes a glaring inefficiency in how the market values corporate chieftains.

title: Where Japanese Canon and American Bar Food Collide
description: At the izakaya, drinking is primary, and food is secondary.

title: Soaking Up the Sake
description: Now that sushi is sold in supermarkets and ramen has come to food courts, what next?

title: Ask Well: Exercising Before Bedtime
description: Question:

title: Bed Bug on Synthetic Surface
description: Researchers tracked how bed bugs reacted to a synthetic surface designed to impede their movement.

title: Cuomo Offers Plan to Fight Corruption After Arrests
description: Responding to the arrests last week of two state lawmakers on bribery charges, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that he would propose legislation that would make it easier for district attorneys to prosecute public corruption and that would stiffen penalties for rogue politicians.

title: Coney Island, 12:10 P.M.
Bed Bug on Leaf
description: Researchers tracked how bedbugs would get stuck on certain types of leaves.

title: Early Verdi, and Sparks Are Already Flying
description: What everyone who attended a concert by the Opera Orchestra of New York at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night seemed to be thinking when the show was over might have been summarized in a Twitter post: Michael Fabiano OMG. The sentiment was evident whenever that tenor opened his mouth, to judge by the prolonged ovations and shouts that followed.

title: Going Off the Itinerary and Finding Lifelong Memories
description: The best travel moments are almost always unplanned. But going off-script often requires risking the most valuable commodity a traveler has: time. We need to give up a sure thing (a major museum, a picturesque waterfall, a buzzed-about bistro) for the unknown (turning down a dirt road, approaching a stranger, stepping through a door).

title: Online, Latvians Ideas Can Bloom Into Law
description: CESIS, Latvia  Pulling up to a snow-covered front yard in this pretty little town last month, Alexander Grunte pointed to the chain-link fence, where a sad-eyed yellow mutt was tied up. Theyre so happy to get attention, he said of the dog, which had jumped up and started barking. Sometimes, its almost like theyre crying.

title: Impressed by 14-Year-Old, Woods Looks Back  and Forward
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The moderator for Tiger Woodss interview session Tuesday noted that Woods was making his 19th Masters appearance, a number that gave him pause.

title: In U.S., South Korean Makes Case for Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON  On a day when North Korea warned expatriates in the South to evacuate because the country was on the brink of nuclear war  a statement the American Embassy in Seoul dismissed as hyperbole  a prominent member of South Koreas Parliament argued in Washington on Tuesday that the time had come for the South to build its own nuclear weapons.

title: A Scientist and a Comedian Walk Into a Confirmation Hearing
description: Heres what happens when a scientist goes through the Washington version of social niceties.

title: Poets Nightmare in Chinese Prison
description: BRUSSELS  Liao Yiwu was a reluctant dissident.

title: The End Seems Near for a Sellout Streak at Fenway Park
description: Chicago Cubs fans may disagree, but all streaks ultimately come to an end. On Wednesday night, the Boston Red Sox may fail to sell out Fenway Park for the first time in nearly a decade.

title: Milan Furniture Fair | New and Newer
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: From Mexico, Some Lessons for Europe
description: I was in Mexico City in the summer of 1981, just out of high school, when Mexicos president, Jos Lpez Portillo, announced he would defend the peso like a dog against speculative attacks.

title: Video: The Essence of College Sports
description: There is a lot wrong with college basketball, but the N.C.A.A. still provides a lot of great opportunities for young athletes, as was evident again during this years tournament, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Islanders Schedule First Game at Barclays Center
description: After almost a years delay, the Islanders and the Devils will play the first N.H.L. game at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sept. 21.

title: Winds and Record Heat Spark Brush Fires Throughout Region
description: As temperatures soared into the 80s, breaking records across the region, gusts drove flames across dried-out vegetation and sparked widespread brush fires on Tuesday, with areas along the New Jersey Turnpike in Hudson and Bergen Counties engulfed.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Turkey, Mali and China.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: Taliban Defend New Perch in Northern Pakistan, Gaining Sway as Election Nears
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  When Taliban fighters swept into the Tirah Valley of northern Pakistan last month, grabbing a remote but strategic area that was previously known for criminal activity, Pakistans military seized a chance to bloody the insurgents before they dug in.

title: The Envelope, Please: Bryan Stromer
description: Bryan Stromer, a high school senior in New York City, is excited to attend Vanderbilt University in the fall, after having experienced Southern hospitality for the first time during a campus visit.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Texting on Sherlock and Ethereal Images
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: In the Clear Light of Day, the Follies of the Night
description: Ah, the proverbial morning after, with its elation, deflation, confusion, humiliation, shock. It always brings some flood of pungent emotion, anyway, often different from whatever sentiment abounded under the comforting cover of night.

title: Job Openings Rise, but Unemployment Stays High
description: The Labor Department has released its latest report on job openings and labor turnover today, which showed that job vacancies were at their post-recession high in February. But we still have a strangely high unemployment rate relative to the job openings rate, at least when compared with the relationship these two variables had before the recession began.

title: Oxheart and Underbelly
description: Two restaurants that spotlight Houstons ambitious dining scene.

title: Laureates Urge No Cuts to Budgets for Research
description: More than 50 Nobel laureates are urging Congress to spare the federal science establishment from the looming budget cuts known as the sequester, saying that research has endured years of budget reductions and that additional cuts could endanger the innovation engine that is essential to our economy.

title: Rangers Send Miller Back to Minors
description: The Rangers assigned forward J.T. Miller to Connecticut of the American Hockey League on Tuesday, signaling a probable end to this seasons largely unsuccessful experimentation with rookies.

title: G.M. Returns to Facebook for a Test, for Now
description: A party to what had been one of the biggest recent divorces on Madison Avenue may be having second thoughts.

title: The Ad Campaign: Quinn and a Smoke-Filled Room
description: It is a fairly typical political advertisement: cheesy production values, overwrought narration and a soundtrack of ominous piano music playing over the unsmiling visage of the ads target, Ms. Quinn.

title: Paris Judge Orders Hearing on Auction Sale of Hopi Artifacts
description: A lawyer has convinced a Paris judge to hold a hearing Thursday to determine the legality of a sale of sacred Hopi Indian artifacts by the Nret-Minet auction house that is scheduled for Friday.

title: Making Houston a Destination
description: HOUSTON  Just about everybody who has been to Oxheart goes on about the flavors that its chef, Justin Yu, pulls from vegetables. I want to talk about the turkey.

title: A Cubist Trove
description: Consisting of 33 Picassos, 17 Braques, 14 Lgers and 14 works by Gris, the Leonard A. Lauder Cubist Collection has been promised to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In this feature, Emily Braun, the curator of the collection, discusses highlights.

title: A Billion-Dollar Gift Gives the Met a New Perspective (Cubist)
description: In one of the most significant gifts in the history of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the philanthropist and cosmetics tycoon Leonard A. Lauder has promised the institution his collection of 78 Cubist paintings, drawings and sculptures.

title: Christies China Debut
description: The Timess David Gillen spoke with Christies C.E.O. Steven Murphy about the tastes of the Chinese as the company prepares to be the first independent auction house in mainland China.

title: Taking Country Less Conservative
description: These are country musics postmilitarization years. A decade ago, there were songs about strong soldiers and a just war, weeping soldiers and unimpeachable ideology  the genre latched onto the political moment and held fast like a remora.

title: Christies Is Poised to Auction Art in China
description: SHANGHAI  Christies auction house said Tuesday it had been granted a license that would enable it to become the first international auction house to operate independently in China, which has overtaken the United States as the worlds largest art and auction market.

title: Old Songs and Regret, the Anger Still Fresh
description: The kid gloves were off when Fleetwood Mac performed its old songs at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. Damn your love! Damn your lies! Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks sang, bitter and enraged, in The Chain, from Fleetwood Macs 1977 album, Rumours, which has sold 19 million copies in the United States and was reissued in an expanded version this year.

title: Vain Glorious | The New California Barber Shop
description: Sometimes, all you need is a sign. After clerking at a grocery store and touring as a musician for 11 years, Brian Girgus decided it was time for a life change and looking back, assessed what it would take: I realized I should cut hair. I always did it anyways for girlfriends, myself or other friends. He committed to working long nights after class and taking out a bank loan to finance barber school, until one incredible chance encounter with lady luck. I went thrift shopping and tried on a coat, Girgus said, and in that coat found all of the money I needed for school, in cash. On the first day of classes, he paid for his tuition in full.

title: A Rickshaw For Womens Rights
description: In March, a three-wheeled auto-rickshaw, painted red to represent strength and female solidarity, alighted in Lower Parel, Mumbai signaling the end of a 10-day journey that started in Delhi by way of Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat and the union territory of Daman.

title: New Video Games
description: TIGER WOODS PGA TOUR 14

title: Alec Baldwin Said to Be in Talks to Join NBCs Late-Night Lineup
description: A well-known name is the latest to surface in the populated field of late night television hosts: Alec Baldwin.

title: With Reporters Death, Recalling the Days Before He Stood Out
description: The great McCandlish Phillips was 81 when I called him in 2009 to ask about his time as a police reporter in New York in the 1950s. It was not a period he recalled fondly.

title: F.B.I. Looking Into Allegations That McConnells Campaign Was Wiretapped
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was looking into allegations by Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky that political opponents bugged his campaign headquarters.

title: An 8th National Title, Built on Spirit, Not Stars
description: NEW ORLEANS  As the current Big East Conference held its confetti farewell Tuesday night in womens basketball, Connecticut left with the most coveted of parting gifts: its eighth national title.

title: New Jersey Condo Market Heats Up as Demand Surges
description: WEEHAWKEN, N.J.  After years of stagnating sales, the New Jersey condominium market is finally warming up, with developers building again and potential owners buying from floor plans.

title: Lots of Federal Property to Sell, but Its Not That Easy
description: WASHINGTON  As government agencies are forced to do more with less, the General Services Administration has stepped up its efforts to dispose of surplus government buildings across the country in new and more profitable ways, instead of simply auctioning them off.

title: Madison Square Garden Says It Will Not Be Uprooted From Penn Station
description: Madison Square Garden wants everyone to know: it isnt going anywhere.

title: Obama Chef Told to Plan Some Time Off
description: Although President Obama is unlikely to miss any meals, the White House kitchen will be missing its assistant chef, if only for a few days every now and then. Sam Kass, who cooks dinner for Mr. Obama several nights a week and is also his senior adviser on nutrition policy, is one of 480 White House employees who were expected to receive furlough notices stemming from the across-the-board budget cuts known as sequestration.

title: Kovalchuk, Return Still Unclear, Practices With the Reeling Devils
description: NEWARK  Ilya Kovalchuk practiced with the Devils for the first time since he injured his right shoulder on March 23, offering a ray of hope for a skidding team working to stay optimistic.

title: A New Buyer for Status-Symbol Horses in Spain: The Abattoir
description: CHAPINERA, Spain  Like his father and grandfather before him, Alberto Martn breeds horses, raising them on two farms, one of them here on the outskirts of Madrid. But even as a third-generation breeder, nothing in his experience had prepared him for times like these. Over the last two years, Mr. Martn says he has been forced to sell 50 of his 70 beloved mares for about $400 each. That is all the slaughterhouse would pay.

title: Arrest Made in Stabbings at Texas College
description: At least 14 people were injured, four of them seriously, in stabbing attacks at a community college campus in a Houston suburb on Tuesday, the authorities said.

title: Staal Says His Return to Ice Will Include a Helmet Visor
description: As he writhed on the Madison Square Garden ice in agony March 5 after being struck in the eye by a deflected slap shot, Rangers defenseman Marc Staal was ruing his decision not to wear a helmet visor.

title: Marty Blake, Sharp Judge of N.B.A. Talent, Dies at 86
description: Marty Blake, a basketball executive whose capacious memory, keen eye for talent and relentless appetite for scouring gymnasiums in remote places made him perhaps the most valuable scout in the history of the National Basketball Association, died on Sunday in Alpharetta, Ga. He was 86.

title: How a Leafy Folk Remedy Stopped Bedbugs in Their Tracks
description: Generations of Eastern European housewives doing battle against bedbugs spread bean leaves around the floor of an infested room at night. In the morning, the leaves would be covered with bedbugs that had somehow been trapped there. The leaves, and the pests, were collected and burned  by the pound, in extreme infestations.

title: Obama Nominates 3 to Serve on Labor Relations Board
description: President Obama announced three nominations to the National Labor Relations Board on Tuesday to complete a package of five nominees  three Democrats and two Republicans  that the administration hopes Senate Republicans will approve to end the boards unusual limbo.

title: Jeter Takes Next Step Forward by Running Sprints
description: CLEVELAND  Despite his sorrow over his favorite college basketball team, the Michigan Wolverines, losing in the national championship game Monday night, Derek Jeter was back at work Tuesday.

title: Hollande Finds His Gift Camel Was Consumed
description: PARIS  As if President Franois Hollande of France did not have enough trouble with a stagnant economy and a scandal over his former budget ministers secret overseas bank accounts, now his camel has been eaten.

title: Jason Griffith
description: Mr. Griffith, 36, is a founder and a chief executive of SiteCompli, a real estate technology company that provides monitoring services to owners and managers of commercial and residential buildings, helping them comply with the myriad rules and regulations within various New York City agencies.

title: Upstart Party in Italy Occupies a Parliament That Is Already Paralyzed
description: ROME  Just when Italians thought their politics could not get any stranger, on Tuesday they did. That was when members of the Five Star Movement of Beppe Grillo decided to occupy Parliament, a step that would seem unnecessary since voters had already sent them there to occupy 163 of its 945 seats.

title: As Governor Steers Maryland to the Left, Talk Turns to 2016
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  As the Maryland Senate debated a crackdown on guns last week, one Republican after another objected that amendments were being smothered by the Democratic majority in its haste to send Gov. Martin OMalley the bill he wanted.

title: Broadcasters Circle Wagons Against a TV Streaming Upstart
description: When Chase Carey, Rupert Murdochs top deputy at News Corporation, told broadcasters on Monday about his contingency plan to turn the Fox network into something available only on cable, he knew policy makers would be listening, too. But a few of them were busy that day, meeting with Chet Kanojia, the very man who had provoked Mr. Careys stark warning.

title: Peace Envoys From Taliban at Loose Ends in Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar  When a handful of Taliban emissaries flew into Qatar on an American plane in 2010, the Obama administration hoped they would help negotiate a peace deal that could stabilize Afghanistan and allow the United States a graceful exit.

title: Dutch Reporter Spends Night in Cairo Jail After Citizens Arrest
description: A Dutch reporter in Cairo spent Monday night in jail after the owner of a cafe detained her on suspicion of spreading European culture and endangering Egypts national security by looking for subjects to interview for a story about youth unemployment.

title: Suit Settled With Occupy Wall St. Over Seizure of Library at a Park
description: As myriad court battles pitting the Occupy Wall Street movement against New York City agencies proceed, protesters claimed a victory on Tuesday, based not on how they were treated, but on how their books were mistreated.

title: Chiefs Silicon Valley Stardom Quickly Clashed at J.C. Penney
description: Maybe it was the ice sculptures. Or the order to stock slim, European-style mens suits. Or the swagger of a protg of the mighty Steve Jobs.

title: Canadian Visits U.S. to Promote Oil Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  Alison Redford, the premier of the Canadian province that is home to the oil sands formations that would supply the proposed Keystone XL pipeline to the United States, said Tuesday that critics of the project had distorted its environmental effects and exaggerated the impact of developing the oil.

title: Some Former Players Recall Rice Positively
description: Mike Rice was brusque, short-tempered and intense, but former basketball players at Robert Morris did not recognize him in the video of his outbursts at Rutgers.

title: Amid Drought, Water Board in New Mexico Confronts State Over Supply
description: A small water agency in southern New Mexico has moved to force state agencies that control water distribution to deprive some users of their supplies.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: A FoxNews.com Reporter Is Facing Jail for Refusing to Identify Police Sources
description: In one of the first major cases of a reporter facing prison since Judith Miller refused to identify a confidential source, a Fox news reporter is being asked to turn over information from her reporting on the theater shooting in Aurora, Colo., last summer.

title: Missouri: Mayor Impeached in Feud With City Council
description: The City Council of Ellisville voted 5 to 1 on Monday to remove its mayor, Adam Paul, 32, with whom it began feuding almost as soon as he took office last April.

title: Watson Wears Heart on Sleeve of His Green Jacket
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Bubba Watson cried on the final green after his victory in last years Masters.

title: Compromise Is Proposed on Western Wall Praying
description: JERUSALEM  Natan Sharansky, the chairman of the Jewish Agency, outlined new ideas on Tuesday for making the Western Wall a place where all Jews could pray comfortably, after tensions over rituals there peaked in recent months and caused discord between the Israeli authorities and Jewish leaders abroad.

title: Nicklaus Still Expects Woods to Set Record
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  On the 50th anniversary of his first Masters victory in 1963, Jack Nicklaus on Tuesday met with reporters to reminisce, although the questions were often about the future.

title: Frances Chief Rabbi Declines to Resign Over Plagiarism
description: PARIS  The chief rabbi of France, under pressure to resign since he admitted plagiarizing parts of a book on Jewish meditations, acknowledged significant moral errors in a radio interview Tuesday night, but said he would not step down.

title: An Appreciation of Perseverance
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Lost in the Supermarket
description: Last year, it seemed, every book about food that crossed my desk  other than those about cooking, of course  seemed to have one of two titles: How I Moved to Brooklyn and Became a Roof-Gardening Butcher or The Gluten-Free Diet Saved My Life, and It Can Save Yours.

title: Three Obama Nominees Encounter No Opposition at Senate Confirmation Hearings
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas three nominees to run Medicare and Medicaid, the Energy Department and the Office of Management and Budget sailed through their separate Senate confirmation hearings on Tuesday and appeared to be on track to win approval from the committees, though none of the panels voted on the nominations.

title: On Korean Peninsula, South Koreans and Foreigners React to Tensions
description: The North Korean government has hinted at new military provocations in the coming days, testing global leaders and consuming headlines almost everywhere. Last week, we asked readers who live on the Korean Peninsula or have family members there to weigh in on how the escalating tensions affect them and what the South Korean government and the international community should do to address those tensions. You can still join the discussion by submitting a comment in the thread below, in English or Korean, or post your thoughts on Twitter, with the hashtag #NYTWorld. We will update this post with a selection of views.

title: A Solution for Penney May Be to Sell Itself, or Some of Its Assets
description: Two years ago, William A. Ackman, a newly minted board member of J. C. Penney, quietly met with the man he hoped would lead the struggling retailer to a brighter future.

title: Disturbing Pablo Nerudas Rest
description: AMHERST, Mass.

title: A Killers Notebook, a Reporters Rights
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Stay Cool. Call North Koreas Bluff.
description: SEOUL, South Korea

title: Obama Pushes His Choice for Position on Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON  With a coordination and an energy that echo a Supreme Court nomination fight, the Obama administration is pushing for the confirmation of a senior Justice Department lawyer to the countrys most prestigious appellate court. If the effort fails, it could lead to a confrontation with the Senate over the long-simmering issue of judicial nominees.

title: Eating With Our Eyes Closed
description: The food that comes from factory farms is ultimately consumed by the public, which gives the public an interest in knowing how that food is produced. But in most of the major agricultural states, laws have been introduced or passed that would make it illegal to gather evidence, by filming or photography, about the internal operations of factory farms where animals are being raised.

title: Worry Over Attention Deficit Cases
description: It is hard not to be concerned about the large number of children who have been given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, a condition that impairs the ability to focus on a task or to control impulses. A new analysis of government data found that almost one in five boys of high school age in the United States and 11 percent of school-age children over all had been reported to have the disorder at some point in their lives. The troubling question is whether they had or still have A.D.H.D. that actually needs treatment with potent drugs.

title: Not Enough Reform on Derivatives
description: On Thursday, several bills to pre-empt the regulation of derivatives will be the focus of a hearing in the House Financial Services Committee. The bills, which have already passed the Agriculture Committee, must be stopped if the world is to be made safe from reckless risk-taking by banks. As it turns out, Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas and the new head of the Financial Services Committee, may be the man to stop them.

title: Former Regulators Find a Home With a Powerful Firm
description: The consulting firm is filled with so many former bureaucrats and political insiders that it has become known as Wall Streets shadow regulator.

title: Jets Sign Dawan Landry
description: The Jets secondary has swapped Landry brothers. To fill the void at safety created when LaRon Landry left for Indianapolis, the Jets signed his older brother Dawan, who spent the last two seasons in Jacksonville.

title: The Public Wants Background Checks
description: On Thursday, the full Senate is scheduled to take its first procedural vote on a bill designed to keep guns out of criminal hands, more than three months after the school massacre in Newtown, Conn. In those few months, much of the urgency has seeped out of the search for solutions to gun violence. That return to complacency is reflected in the difficulty in reaching bipartisan agreement on which bill will reach the floor.

title: In the Markets, at Least, Fannie and Freddie Still Astound
description: The mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac continue to astound  and not in a very encouraging way.

title: Facebook Grabs for Your Phone. What Gives?
description: Facebook, man. Unbelievable. Second-most-visited Web site in the world. Frequented monthly by one-sixth of the earths population. Primary source of news for half of Americas young people.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Apr. 10, 2013
description: "In one fell swoop this puts the Met at the forefront of early-20th-century art.

Bette Midler on Her Return to Broadway
description: Ms. Midler discusses her return to the theater in the one-woman play Ill Eat You Last: A Chat With Sue Mengers.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Creates Committee to Study Decline of Blacks in the Majors
description: Commissioner Bud Selig said Tuesday that he was creating a 17-member diversity task force to study and address the issue of on-field participation by African-Americans in Major League Baseball.

title: A Tale of Three Women
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Qualities of the Squid, as Observed in the Capitol
description: In nature, the octopus and the squid are known for their quick-changing colors, allowing them to blend into any environment. Lacking spines, they can slip through the tiniest crevices. Yet they have tremendous strength in their tentacles, which are lined with suction-cup structures that have so much power they can burst an artery in a human, capsize boats, or stay fixed to a rock until they are good and ready to let go.

title: The Arab Quarter Century
description: I guess its official now: The term Arab Spring has to be retired. There is nothing springlike going on. The broader, but still vaguely hopeful, Arab Awakening also no longer seems valid, given all that has been awakened. And so the strategist Anthony Cordesman is probably right when he argues: Its best we now speak of the Arab Decade or the Arab Quarter Century  a long period of intrastate and intraregional instability, in which a struggle for both the future of Islam and the future of the individual Arab nations blend together into a clash within a civilization. The ending: TBD.

title: Corrections: April 10, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: He Always Had a Point
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  I know what youre thinking. This puzzle was way too easy for a Wednesday. But look again.

title: Amnesty International Reports on Death Penalty Trends
description: At least four countries that had not used the death penalty in some time  India, Japan, Pakistan and Gambia  resumed doing so last year, the rights organization Amnesty International says in its annual compilation of capital punishment trends.

title: Probation for Ex-Director of Nonprofit Group Tied to Assemblyman
description: A woman who worked for more than 30 years as the director of a nonprofit organization long controlled by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez was sentenced to probation on Tuesday for providing fake documents in response to a grand jury subpoena.

title: Cuba Trip by Star Pair Was Legal, Official Says
description: MEXICO CITY  They may have had fun and, yes, it was their wedding anniversary. But Jay-Z and Beyonc did not break the law by going to Cuba two weeks ago, the Treasury Department said Tuesday.

title: Schumer Says Storm Victims Deserve Aid for Self-Help
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer is urging New York City officials to make federal money available to homeowners who paid for their own repairs for damage caused by Hurricane Sandy.

title: 3-Homer Barrage Puts Early End to Gees Night
description: PHILADELPHIA  Even upon returning to normal health this winter, Dillon Gee was always going to need some time to regain a feel for his pitches, to re-establish the rhythm that unraveled during his extended hiatus.

title: Russia Takes Legal Action Against Election Monitors
description: MOSCOW  The federal Justice Ministry opened a legal case on Tuesday against Russias only independent election monitoring organization, charging that the group, Golos, and its executive director had violated a controversial new law by failing to register as a foreign agent.

title: A Frontier State Passes Gun Measures
description: Colorado, a state of hunters and sportsmen that the president has said treasures its Second Amendment rights, has taken action on gun restrictions, while measures in Washington have stalled.

title: Nets Cruise Toward Playoffs, With Evans Suddenly a Force
description: Closing in on the fourth seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs, the Nets wasted little time dispatching the Philadelphia 76ers on Tuesday, 104-83, at Barclays Center.

title: Sick-Pay Deal Lets Steinem Back Quinn for Mayor
description: Gloria Steinem, the feminist writer and activist, said on Tuesday that she would endorse Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, in the New York mayoral race.

title: Law School Group Incites Fury With Choice to Honor Carter
description: When editors of The Cardozo Journal of Conflict Resolution, a scholarly publication from the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School, decided to bestow this years International Advocate for Peace award on former President Jimmy Carter, they sought to honor his decades as a mediator and humanitarian. But in the process, they ignited a sizable conflict of their own.

title: Fireworks by Knicks, Followed by a Title
description: Nearly two decades had passed since the Atlantic Division had been colored in hues of orange and blue, and the Knicks emerged Tuesday night like a team that was in a rush to end the drought, as soon and as emphatically as possible.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 9, 2013

title: Jury Pool in Ex-Aides Trial Will Be Queried About Liu
description: Prospective jurors in the trial of a former campaign treasurer for John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor, will be questioned about their impressions of Mr. Liu and whether that would affect their ability to be fair and impartial, a court document shows.

title: A Republican Split
description: Republicans are divided on whether to consider new gun legislation.

title: With Canos Help, a Lineup Expected to Struggle Keeps Slugging
description: CLEVELAND  The only pitch that Robinson Cano did not see well on Tuesday, it seems, was the one that hit Kevin Youkilis square in the shoulder. That pitch likely was Canos fault, but there was a good reason he missed it.

title: 4-Year-Old Boy Fatally Shoots 6-Year-Old in New Jersey
description: A 6-year-old New Jersey boy died on Tuesday after being shot in the head a day earlier by his 4-year-old neighbor while they were playing outside, according to the police and local news media reports.

title: South Sudan: U.N. Soldiers Killed
description: Five United Nations peacekeepers were killed in an ambush in a rebellion-racked region of South Sudan, United Nations officials said Tuesday. The peacekeepers, who were Indian, were attacked while escorting a convoy through Jonglei State. At least seven civilians were also killed. Indian news media reported that rebels attacked the peacekeepers with assault rifles and rocket-propelled grenades.

title: Judge Tells Ex-Chief of Police Not to Turn Testimony Into a Speech
description: As the highest-ranking chief of the New York Police Department, Joseph J. Esposito was long accustomed to delivering blow-by-blow commentary on the departments crime-fighting strategies.

title: Bigas Luna Dies at 67; Spanish Films Shepherd
description: Bigas Luna, an iconoclastic film director who emerged after the Franco dictatorship to portray the new Spain as engagingly and perplexingly robust and later discovered the stars Penlope Cruz and Javier Bardem, died on Saturday at his home in Tarragona, Spain. He was 67.

title: N.C.A.A. Womens Final
description: In the most lopsided title game ever, the Connecticut Huskies cruised to a 33-point rout of Louisville to win their eighth national championship.

title: The Naked Truth
description: Jeff Koons illustrates a poem by Matthea Harvey on the pleasure and peril of opening up.

title: Getting a Brain Boost Through Exercise
description: Two new experiments, one involving people and the other animals, suggest that regular exercise can substantially improve memory, although different types of exercise seem to affect the brain quite differently. The news may offer consolation for the growing numbers of us who are entering age groups most at risk for cognitive decline.

title: Arming Cable Against the Open Internet
description: Cable television companies are distressed about how quickly Internet and mobile viewing are stealing customers. Now, technology firms want to sell them ways to offer the personal choice of mobile, while justifying the goodies that come to someone who pays for a subscription.

title: Report Identifies Companies Vulnerable to Activist Takeovers
description: Looking for a juicy takeover candidate?

title: T-Mobile USA Sweetens iPhone 5 Deal With Trade-In Program
description: T-Mobile USA, the struggling phone carrier, really wants you to switch to its network  so badly that it will give you a break on a brand-new iPhone in exchange for an old one.

title: Word of the Day | hale
description: hale \hal\ adjective

title: Coming and Going at  the Energy Department
description: Just as the Senate moved toward approving a new energy secretary, the departments third-in-command is announcing his departure.

title: Shumperts Hair Design Runs Afoul of the League
description: Iman Shumpert, among the Knicks, has been transformed the most this season  both on the court and in his appearance. Shumpert had a successful rookie season last year, yet almost everything has changed about him.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (BBC America) SPIES OF WARSAW In the conclusion of this two-part mini-series based on the novel by Alan Furst, Col. Jean-Franois Mercier (David Tennant, foreground above), a French military attach in Warsaw, goes undercover in Czechoslovakia as he searches for the man who can lead him into the Nazi war machine. Anna Skarbek (Janet Montgomery), his mistress and a lawyer for the League of Nations, receives devastating news about her former lover, the Russian journalist Maxim Mostov (Piotr Baumann), and flees to Spain on a mission of mercy. The drama has an almost comic-book adherence to stereotype, from the dashing Polish nobleman to the sallow, pockmarked Nazi border guard, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. On the other hand, there is nothing more satisfying than a prewar espionage story that shows, up close and told-you-so, how most of Europe slept through Hitlers rise. She added, There are many impediments to true love in Spies of Warsaw, but Mercier, solitary and sorrowful, learns to trust his heart  and not the Maginot Line.

title: Who Suffered Most?
News Quiz | April 10, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Malaysia Sets Elections in Big Test for Ruling Party
description: HONG KONG  Malaysia scheduled national elections for May 5 on Wednesday, setting the stage for the biggest test of the governing partys dominance since the country gained independence from Britain more than five decades ago.

title: Missiles and Memorial Stones: Figuring Out North Korea and China
description: BEIJING  Everybody is watching North Korea closely: Will it launch a ballistic missile? Destroy Seoul? Or, on an entirely different note, hold an international marathon in Pyongyang on Sunday to mark the birthday on April 15 of the nations founder, Kim Il-sung, as Japans NHK World has reported, citing North Koreas state-run news agency?

title: K.K.R. Hires New Chief for Japanese Unit
description: HONG KONG  Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Wednesday appointed a new chief executive at its Japanese unit, part of a series of recent hirings at the private equity giant as it gets set to close a new $6 billion Asia fund.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 10
description: NEWS As North Korea warned foreigners on Tuesday that they might want to leave South Korea because the peninsula was on the brink of nuclear war  a statement that analysts dismissed as hyperbole  the American commander in the Pacific expressed worries that the Norths young leader, Kim Jong-un, might not have left himself an easy exit to reduce tensions. Choe Sang-hun reports from Seoul, and David E. Sanger from Washington.

title: A Conversation With: Social Activist Arun Gandhi
description: NEW YORK CITY  Arun Gandhi, Mahatma Gandhis 79-year-old social activist grandson, might seem an unlikely fashion model, but he walked the runway Monday night in Manhattan, wearing a kilt, no less, for charity.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 10, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Attacks Used the Internet Against Itself to Clog Traffic.

title: Syrian Civil War Imperils Countrys Archaeological Heritage
description: In Grave Robbers and War Steal Syrias History, C. J. Chivers writes about how the Syrian civil war is imperiling the countrys archaeological heritage.

title: Horse Meat Problems Resurface Across Europe
description: LONDON  After disappearing briefly from public view, the scandal over horse meat sold as beef re-emerged on Wednesday with an alert over 50,000 tons of meat sold across Europe and an earlier recall of a product in Britain containing a veterinary drug banned from the human food chain.

title: Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedins Post-Scandal Playbook
description: One day in early February, I met Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin for breakfast at the Gramercy Park Hotel, one of their regular joints, just a few blocks from their apartment on Park Avenue South. The first thing Weiner said when I sat down was that their 13-month-old son, Jordan, had just moments ago taken his first step. They were both giddy, kvelling with baby-pride, especially Weiner, who, with all his free time, has become his sons primary caretaker. This is what life is like now for the man whose name is invariably followed in print by some version of the disgraced former congressman who sent out a lewd picture of himself via Twitter. He seems to spend much of his time within a five-block radius of his apartment: going to the park with Jordan; picking up his wifes dry cleaning and doing the grocery shopping; eating at his brother Jasons two restaurants in the neighborhood. This is what happens after a scandal: Ranks are closed and the world shrinks to a tiny dot. It is a life in retreat. And for a man who was known, pre-scandal, for his overweening ambition, his constant presence on cable news, his hard-charging schedule that verged on lunacy, well, it has been quite a change.

title: The Gang Legacy of Central Americas Wars
description: Donna De Cesare had just walked into the AIDS ward at a public hospital in El Salvadorone day in 1989 when a young voice greeted her.

title: Do You Ever Seek Advice on the Internet?
description: What did we do before the Internet? How did we know how to shoot a basketball or shake hands properly? Now we can seek the specific advice we want whenever we want it.

title: Anthony Weiner Is Weighing a Run for Mayor
description: Saying that he would like, at some point, to ask people to give me a second chance, Anthony D. Weiner, the former congressman who resigned in 2011 amid a scandal over his lewd online behavior, is mulling a run for mayor this year because its now or maybe never for me.

title: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions on Making the Final College Decision
description: The Choice has invited Marie Bigham, a former college admissions officer and veteran college counselor, and Mark Kantrowitz, a financial-aid expert, to answer your questions about comparing financial aid offers and deciding where to enroll in the blogs virtual Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

title: Varieties of Not Working
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: When Best Friends Can Visit
description: A year and a half ago, Ruth London lay in intensive care in a hospital in Boca Raton, Fla., with severe pneumonia, delirious and hallucinating that she was in jail.

title: Parliament Debates Thatcher Legacy, as Vitriol Flows Online and in Streets
description: LONDON  If Margaret Thatcher stirred deep divisions in her political life, death changed almost nothing.

title: Quinn Loses Popularity, but Retains Lead in Mayoral Race, Poll Finds
description: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, remains the front-runner among Democrats pursuing the mayors seat, but her support among New Yorkers fell to its lowest level in five months, according to a poll released on Wednesday.

title: The Early Word: Clearings
description: Todays Times

title: When Home Is a Campus Parking Lot
description: COULD I live in a van? I looked over the Craigslist ads, took a bus to Johns used car dealership in Raleigh, N.C., and scanned the rows of sedans, trucks and SUVs in search of my new home.

title: U.S. and South Korea Put Forces on Alert for Missile Test by North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  American and South Korean troops increased alert levels on Wednesday as South Koreas foreign minister warned that North Korea could launch its medium-range Musudan missile any time from now.

title: Chinas Former Rail Minister Is Charged With Corruption
description: HONG KONG  Chinas former railways minister, reviled by state-run media and many Chinese bloggers after a deadly high-speed train crash in the summer of 2011 and lurid allegations of high living, has been formally charged with corruption and abuse of power, the state-run Xinhua news agency said on Wednesday.

title: Bank of America Hires Goldman M.&A. Executive
description: LONDON  Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that it had hired Luigi Rizzo from Goldman Sachs to become head of mergers and acquisitions for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

title: Italy and France Pose Grave Risks to Euro Zone, Report Says
description: BRUSSELS  The struggling economies of France and Italy are out of step with better-performing countries like Germany, raising the prospect of more trouble for the euro zone, the European Unions top economics official warned Wednesday.

title: Using Retirement Money to Start a Business
description: Youre thinking about starting a company. Youve decided that the best bet is to buy a franchise. This will give you a leg up because someone else has done the heavy lifting and can give you a road map for success. Youve discussed opening the business with your spouse, and your spouse is supportive. The only problem is that you need to raise $300,000 to get the franchise off the ground.

title: Antique Tractor Sale Will Be Crawling With Caterpillars
description: A collection of nearly 100 antique tractors, mostly of the bright-yellow Caterpillar variety, will be auctioned at 10 a.m. Wednesday in Trout Run, Pa.

title: Obama Budget Opens Rift for Democrats on Social Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas new budget has opened a debate over what it means to be a progressive Democrat in an age of austerity and defines him as a president willing to take on the two pillars of his party  Medicare and Social Security  created by Democratic presidents.

title: By the Teeth of Their Skin
description: CAIRO  You may have missed it, but April 4 was International Topless Jihad Day. Announced by Femen, the radical feminist group that originated in Ukraine, it was organized in solidarity with Amina Tyler, a 19-year-old Tunisian woman who last month sparked a storm in Tunisia by posting two topless photos of herself online. In one, she faces the camera with both hands held up defiantly, her middle fingers unfurled; her torso bears an inscription cursing your morals. In the other photo, she wrote my body belongs to me and is not a source of anyones honor.

title: Shadow Regulator Under Scrutiny
description: Mary L. Schapiro, who ran the Securities and Exchange Commission until last year, is only the latest former political insider to join the Promontory Financial Group, which has such a star-studded roster of former bureaucrats that it has become known as Wall Streets shadow regulator. With these connections, the firm has emerged as a major power broker in Washington, helping Wall Street navigate an onslaught of new rules and regulatory scrutiny, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook.

title: Daily Report: Aereos Inroads Bring Sharp Reaction From Networks
description: Aereo is a service that scoops up the free signals of local television stations and streams them to the phones and computers of paying subscribers. Because Aereo cuts off the stations from the retransmission fees that they have grown to depend on, they are determined to shut down the service  even, the station owners say, if they have to go cable-only, Brian Stelter reports in Wednesdays New York Times.

title: After Years of Playing Bette, Another Role
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Its all about the bosom, Bette Midler says as she slinks down in an armchair, arches her back and steadies her breasts until they are horizontal enough to balance an ashtray.

title: Wednesday Reading: The Rewards of Going Off Itinerary
Poor Nations Fight, Rich Nations Pay
description: When the United Nations peacekeeping forces face a violent conflict, as they did in South Sudan this week, odds are high that a South Asian soldier will be among the injured or killed.

title: Opinion Report: A.D.H.D.
description: From the editorial page

title: Snow Leopards at the Zoo
description: Dear Diary:

title: Margaret Thatchers True Heir
description: As Bruce Bartlett points out, the Margaret Thatcher American conservatives admire bears little resemblance to the British Prime Minister of the same name. In particular, she did hardly anything to scale down the British welfare state (although she did make a hash of retirement security  more on that in a later post). Heres one indicator, from the Institute for Fiscal Studies (pdf):

title: Beautiful Ruins
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: How Robert Schimmel Got the Last Word on Showtimes Inside Comedy
description: As David Steinberg remembers it, his interview with Robert Schimmel was a hilarious reflection on an often tragic life.

title: Times Writer Tangles With the Ethics of Password-Sharing
description: If you watch HBO or use Netflix by using a friends password, thus managing to avoid paying for the service yourself, is that acceptable digital-native behavior or is it piracy?

title: A Senators Search for an Ally Keeps a Gun Bill Alive
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Joe Manchin III so craved a pro-gun-rights Republican as a partner for a bill to expand background checks on gun buyers that he took to buttonholing senators on the in-house subway that ferries them from their offices to the Capitol, making his pitch while his colleagues were trapped with him in the tiny car.

title: By Accident, Fed Gives Early Data to Banks
description: The Federal Reserve alerted bank officials on Tuesday that policy makers were considering a shift on when to begin easing back on stimulus efforts, a day before the news was released publicly, but it insisted there was no evidence traders on Wall Street had benefited from what was called an error.

title: Chelsea: Kind of Blue
description: It is only April, but already Chelsea and its equipment sponsor Adidas are looking ahead to next season, when the club will begin anew its quest to win Englands Premier League  and sell thousands of new jerseys.

title: Advice for Couples About Their Sex Lives, Part 1
description: Readers recently submitted questions about male sexuality to Dr. Ronald F. Levant, a professor of psychology and director of the Psychology Department Counseling Clinic at the University of Akron. Dr. Levant was president of the American Psychological Association and is an author or editor of 14 books, including Men and Sex: New Psychological Perspectives. Dr. Levant asked the counselors that he supervises in his clinic, all Ph.D. students in psychology who see a broad range of clients, to help him compose answers to these questions. Thanks are due to Mike Aguilar, Brittany Baker, Natalie Grandy, Craig Libman and Arielle Riutort. Because of the large number of submissions, not every question was addressed. In particular, they were not able to answer questions on medical issues, as their expertise is psychological, not medical. More answers will be posted next week.

title: Census Takes a Look at New Yorkers Migration Patterns
description: So much for Horace Greeley. Between 2006 and 2010, more people, on average, moved to Manhattan from Los Angeles annually (3,251) than, for example, from Suffolk County (2,301). And more moved to Manhattan from Brooklyn (11,469) than from any other county in the United States or from any other country. (Europe was second.)

title: Europe Urged to Make a U-Turn on Austerity
description: LONDON  Austerity in Europe is under fire, and not just from protesters.

title: The iPad as Childs Easel
description: IPad cases for children abound these days, but if your intention is to create a childs easel, ArtSee Studio from WowWee ($40) is the best bet. Designed to offer both protection against drops and reduce the chance a preschooler might end up in your email, the plastic case includes a home button lock, a rubber-tipped stylus and five stamps of the variety you might find at the post office. Instead of ink, each stamp has a unique dot pattern that triggers an artistic effect when placed against the iPads screen. Want to add a swimming dolphin? Use the sticker stamp. Want to make your dolphin move? Use the Arrow stamp, and trace a course. After you snap your iPad into the holder and download the free app, called ArtSee Studio, your child is free to sketch. One weak point  our testers found it hard to undo a sticker once it has been placed. But they were impressed by the powerful drawing options, which include such wonders as a rainbow crayon. Saving projects is automatic, and there is a set of games like connect the dots and concentration.  The case fits all generations of iPads.Download the app here.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: The fight to save a family-owned oyster bed in Northern California has thrown together some very strange bedfellows, including Alice Waters and Republicans trying to promote the Keystone XL pipeline and drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.  Patrick Farrell

title: Gunman Attacks Police Officer Guarding Polio Workers in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A gunman shot and killed one policeman and wounded another on Wednesday as they provided security for a team of polio eradication health workers in northwestern Pakistan, according to government officials.

title: Paolo Soleri, Architect of Counterculture, Dies at 93
description: Paolo Soleri, a visionary architect who was best known as the designer and oracle of Arcosanti, a settlement in the Arizona high desert that became a symbol of hippie-era utopianism and a prescient environmentalism, died on Tuesday at Cosanti, his home in Paradise Valley, Ariz. He was 93.

title: Updates on the Gun Debate | April 10, 2013
description: Two senators announce a bipartisan compromise on background checks. Michelle Obama wades into the gun debate. Newtown families urge Republican senators to vote instead of filibuster.

title: Russian Ballerina Natalia Osipova Joins Londons Royal Ballet
description: LONDON  It was only 18 months ago that the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova shocked the dance world by leaving the Bolshoi Ballet, where she was considered a major star, to join the lesser-known Mikhailovsky Ballet in St. Petersburg. But on Monday, the Royal Opera House announced that Ms. Osipova would join the Royal Ballet as a principal dancer for the 2013-14 season. The announcement came hot on the heels of Ms. Osipovas wholesale conquest of this city during the Mikhailovskys recent two-week engagement here.

title: If American and US Airways Merge, What Should Fliers Expect?
description: American Airlines is on its way to becoming the biggest airline in the world after winning bankruptcy-court approval to merge with US Airways. Maybe you dont fly those airlines often, but heres why you should care: the consolidation of two major carriers might affect how seamlessly you can fly. It might affect what you pay. It might even affect your miles strategy.

title: Hotel Review: The Saguaro in Scottsdale, Ariz.
description: Upshot

title: Restaurant Report: Shanik in Seattle
description: Encouraged by the flowering of Seattles once-industrial South Lake Union neighborhood, the areas restaurants now reflect a veritable United Nations of world cuisines. One of the latest and most celebrated is Indian, by way of the fertile mind of Meeru Dhalwala, half of the husband-wife team behind Vijs, the outpost of nontraditional Indian cuisine in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: When is a Person Not a Human? When its a Dolphin, or Chimp, or
description: After I wrote over the weekend about new research on the killing method employed in the dolphin roundups undertaken in Taiji, Japan, a fascinating comment on the rights of nonhuman persons was posted by Thomas I. White, who is the Conrad N. Hilton Professor in Business Ethics at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles.

title: The East Village of Mad Men Versus the Real Neighborhood in the 1960s
description: April 11 | Correction Appended

title: The Bow Tie Is Back Behind the Bar
description: Bills Food & Drink, the high-end Manhattan restaurant that opened last fall, has a new bartender. And hes no stranger to Midtown, or to Midtown drinkers.

title: Imaginary Grownups
description: So the Obama budget is out, Social Security cuts and all. Why is this happening?

title: Gleacher in Deal Talks Again
description: Will the second time be the charm for Gleacher & Company?

title: Fed Says Minutes Were Inadvertently Released
description: The Federal Reserve was forced to release the latest minutes of its monthly policy-making meeting five hours early Wednesday, after they were inadvertently distributed Tuesday to more than 100 Congressional staff members and trade organization officials.

title: Q&A: Replacing a Damaged Power Cord
description: Q.

title: Handicapping the Masters
description: The Masters begins Thursday, and Michael Rosenberg at Sports Illustrated thinks Tiger Woods will win, one reason being his putting: He has done two things exceptionally well: Avoided three-putts (he is No. 4 on tour), and rammed home putts from 5 to 20 feet.
