Those are a function of great putting more than luck.

title: KPMG and the Pain That Comes of Breached Trust
description: Trust can be breached  even on the golf course.

title: Applied Arts
description: For the last several years, the coolest design schools were those, like Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, that turned out the most conceptual work, much of it laced with social commentary. But now the school whose name seems to be everywhere is the CAL/University of Art and Design Lausanne. Like many of its peers, the 192-year-old Swiss institution offers an undergraduate degree in industrial design. But unlike many schools, it also has something called the Master of Advanced Studies in Design for Luxury and Craftsmanship, which was founded five years ago and has made a name for itself through its collaborations  with luxury goods companies like Baccarat, Christofle, Bernardaud and Audemars Piguet  that bring new ideas to old-line manufacturers.

title: Subway on Way? Maps Tell You
description: Google Maps has added information on public transportation in several cities. The service now provides up-to-date departure times for seven New York City (above) subway lines and for buses and trams in the greater Salt Lake City area, and service alerts for Washingtons Metrorail subway. Updates are available in many other major cities, including London, Madrid and San Diego.

title: Spider-Man Legal Fight Ends in Artistic Divorce
description: After more than a year of brinkmanship at the negotiating table the producers of the musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark and their former director, Julie Taymor, announced on Wednesday that they had settled their acrimonious legal battle over profits, copyright claims and artistic credit for the $75 million show, the most expensive in Broadway history.

title: The Gun Report: April 10, 2013
description: Reports of drive-by shootings first dominated the headlines in the 1980s, and were largely associated with the infamous Los Angeles gang wars as well as the drug trade in cities such as Chicago. But readers of our daily report will notice that such shootings are not a remnant of the Reagan-Thatcher years: theyre happening all the time, in Texas, Alabama, Tennesseeand now Tupelo, Mississippi. Thats where Carol, the 39-year-old Asian elephant used in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, was shot in a drive-by early Tuesday morning. At around 2:00 a.m., someone fired his gun into the BancorpSouth Arena parking lot where the circus animals were being kept.

title: The Scale of the Presidents Budget
description: How spending in President Obamas 2014 budget compares with proposals from both parties and historical averages.

title: Moving to a Place Where Strangers on the Street Say Hello
description: My main goal for spring break was to visit Vanderbilt University. Even though I had been admitted in January as a Posse Scholar, I had yet to see the campus for myself. So, my parents and I got on a plane and arrived in Nashville on a Sunday.

title: Man Accused of Burning Jewish Symbols Is in Police Custody
description: Updated, 12:03 p.m. | The suspect in this weeks hate-crime burning of a dozen Jewish doorway adornments in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is in custody, a law enforcement official said Wednesday.

title: Obamas Budget Proposal
description: The White Houses complete budget proposal for the 2014 fiscal year.

title: If You Need More Time to File Your Tax Return
description: Tax Day is next Monday. If you havent filed your taxes yet, should you be considering filing for an extension?

title: Dozens Injured in Tamil Nadu Train Accident
description: Chennai, TAMIL NADU  One person was killed and at least 27 people were injured early Wednesday morning after the derailment of nearly half of the coaches of a 24-car train traveling from the eastern state of Bihar to the southern state of Karnataka.

title: Image of the Day: April 10
$25,000 Dance Prize Goes to Michelle Dorrance
description: Jacobs Pillow, the dance festival and school in the Berkshires, will award its seventh annual Jacobs Pillow Dance Award to Michelle Dorrance, the tap dancer and choreographer whose company, Dorrance Dance, is known for its blend of inventiveness, virtuosity and musicality.

title: Brave Young Heroine
description: On the Broadway stage a heroine named Matilda is showing that magical things can happen to brainy, confident and righteous little girls. Meanwhile, in a new graphic novel, a blue-haired child named Hilda is proving much the same point. In Matildas case, what must be overcome is a world of foolish and powerful adults. For Hilda, the obstacle is a new town, Trolberg, where a well-meaning butinsensitive group of peers prove insufficient armor against an unfamiliar and seemingly forbidding environment.

title: G.E. Turns to the Crowd for Help in Creating Consumer Products
description: General Electric has been making a serious push in recent years into the so-called Internet of Things, where all kinds of devices connect to the Internet, creating a constant stream of data about how theyre working. Now it is hoping to crowd-source consumer uses for technologies it has developed for things like power plant turbines and medical imaging equipment.

title: Riding the Momentum Created by a Cheeky Video
description: In March 2012, a video promoting a razor-blade business called Dollar Shave Club took YouTube by storm. It featured the companys founder, Michael Dubin, who had spent the bulk of his career in digital media and marketing and had performed improvisational comedy as a hobby, walking briskly through a warehouse as he issued off-color wisecracks and encouraged men to buy his razor blades on a subscription basis for as little as $2 a month.

title: Chrysler Will Recall 213,000 Vehicles in Five Actions
description: Chrysler will recall more than 213,000 vehicles in five actions for problems that include driveshaft failures, underhood fires, stalling and air-bag malfunctions, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: City Introduces Online Database for Its Potters Field
description: For more than a century, to be buried on Hart Island, off the coast of the Bronx, was to be essentially forgotten.

title: A Peek Into Your Closet
description: We asked readers to submit images of their masterpieces of organization. Here are some of their responses.

title: MTV Cancels the Reality Series Buckwild
description: MTV has decided to cancel the reality series Buckwild,' nine days after the death of one of its cast members, the network said on Wednesday.

title: Has Your Business Tried Video Marketing?
description: Weve just published a Conversation with Michael Dubin, a founder of Dollar Shave Club, the razor-blade business that got its start with a promotional video that went viral in March 2012. It featured Mr. Dubin walking briskly through a warehouse as he issued off-color wisecracks and encouraged men to buy his razor blades on a subscription basis for as little as $2 a month.

title: A Photograph With Legs
description: Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

title: Robert G. Edwards Dies at 87; Changed Rules of Conception With First Test Tube Baby
description: Robert G. Edwards, who opened a new era in medicine when he joined a colleague in developing in vitro fertilization, enabling millions of infertile couples to bring children into the world and women to have babies even in menopause, died on Wednesday at his home near Cambridge, England. Dr. Edwards, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for his breakthrough, was 87.

title: Notes on Deborah Madisons Onion Tart and Asparagus Salad
description: This months book for Recipe Lab is Vegetable Literacy by Deborah Madison, and our live chat is coming up this Tuesday at 3:30 p.m. Eastern. This will be your chance to ask her everything and anything about vegetable cookery, or about the recipes I hope youre planning to try out before then. (You can find the recipes here; you can see how they come together in the video below.)

title: A Traditional Hungarian Home Overlooking Lake Balaton
description: A four-bedroom stone house with a swimming pool is on the market for $2.9 million.

title: House Hunting in... Hungary
description: A HOME ON LAKE BALATON IN WESTERN HUNGARY

title: A Bipartisan Gun Deal
description: The Timess David Leonhardt and Jonathan Weisman discuss the path ahead with new gun safety laws set to hit the Senate floor soon.

title: Study of Babies Did Not Disclose Risks, U.S. Finds
description: A federal agency has found that a number of prestigious universities failed to tell more than a thousand families in a government-financed study of oxygen levels for extremely premature babies that the risks could include increased chances of blindness or death.

title: Rangers Face Crucial Rematch With Toronto
description: With nine games remaining in the lockout-shortened N.H.L. season, every point is crucial for the Rangers if they are to make the playoffs.

title: The Fall of Satans Kingdom
description: [T]he crowning act of this war ought to be by the navyI pray you give us Charleston if possiblefor the Fall of Charleston is the fall of Satans Kingdom. Asst. Navy Secretary Gustavus Fox to Admiral Samuel F. DuPont, June 3, 1862

title: Spokesman Quits After French Rabbi Admits Plagiarism
description: PARIS  The spokesman for the chief rabbi of France, who has refused to quit his post despite admitting to plagiarism and lying about his qualifications, quit himself on Wednesday, French news agencies reported.

title: G.M. Goes to Germany to Reaffirm Support for Opel
description: RSSELSHEIM, GERMANY  As they prepare to meet with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, top managers of General Motors sought to dispel any doubts about the companys commitment to its unprofitable Opel unit in Europe, reiterating plans to invest billions in new models and break even by the middle of the decade.

title: A U.S. Soccer Stars Declaration of Independence
description: LYON, France  The latest attempt at a womens professional soccer league in the United States begins this weekend, so the stars of the American team from the London Olympics have, for the most part, returned to preaching the gospel stateside. Abby Wambach, the powerful striker, is with a team in Rochester; Alex Morgan, the pixieish, pink-headband-wearing poster girl, is in Portland, Ore.; and Hope Solo, the mercurial goalkeeper and Dancing With the Stars alumna, would be in Seattle were it not for a wrist injury.

title: Properties for $995,000
description: A Chicago penthouse one block from Lake Michigan, an Italianate revival in Memphis and a house in Colorado Springs with mountain views.

title: What You Get for ... $995,000
description: CHICAGO

title: Army Judge Raises Burden in Privates Trial on Leaks
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The military prosecutors seeking to have Pfc. Bradley Manning convicted of violating the Espionage Act over his release of secret government files to WikiLeaks will face an additional burden at his court-martial under a ruling on Wednesday by a military judge.

title: Architectural Masterpiece in Moscow Under Grave Threat, Preservationists Say
description: MOSCOW  The Russian avant-garde architect Konstantin Melnikovs seminal cylindrical house in Moscow, which has inspired architects around the world for nearly a century, is gravely threatened by construction of a large multipurpose complex abutting its tiny backyard, Russian and international preservationists say.

title: Obama Likes Some Sin Taxes More Than Others
description: President Obamas budget continues the Democratic preference for cigarette taxes over alcohol or soda taxes  even though alcohol and soda consumption may cost society more money than smoking.

title: A Vocabulary Site Shows How to Tailor Online Education
description: The recent excitement about online learning has mostly been focused on the power of technology to distribute and democratize education. At the forefront has been the rise of massive open online courses, or MOOCs, which have been magnets for attention and investment.

title: What Makes a Successful Stepfather?
description: How mothers and their new partners feel about becoming a stepfamily is one thing, and how the children involved feel is quite another. In 2009, more than 7 percent of children lived with at least one stepparent, yet much of the research and writing on the topic centers on how the adults navigate their new family dynamic.

title: Highlights From Obamas Budget Proposal
description: 11:10 p.m. | Updated  A condensed version of this post is available here.

title: High Low | Dr. Martens Sneakers
description: Injecting a tinge of athletic spirit to its archive of iconic punk-cult classics, the British shoe brand Dr. Martens introduces a new line of sneaker-inspired footwear for the spring season. The Farrell style, the standout in the new collection, combines the classic Dr. Martens air-cushioned wedge sole with a sleek smooth leather upper available in three colors (black, navy and cherry). Resembling many of the chunky-soled shoes that have treaded the runway in recent collections of Raf Simons, Acne and Marni, the Dr. Martens Farrell is a fresh alternative that can be worn with as much regularity as a favorite sneaker. And for under $100, its difficult not to want all three.

title: Martyl Langsdorf, Doomsday Clock Designer, Dies at 96
description: Martyl Langsdorfs clock has yet to strike midnight.

title: Checking Your Own Bags
description: Hawaiian Airlines has become the first domestic carrier to extend the concept of self-check-in to luggage. The airline recently began allowing passengers at check-in kiosks at Honolulu International Airport to weigh and tag their bags. The move is expected to cut check-in time, already down to a slim eight minutes, in half, according to Hawaiian.

title: 10 Mistakes of the Iraq War
description: In 2003, Col. Ted Spain was deployed to Iraq as the commander of the 18th Military Police Brigade. His task was to rebuild the Iraqi police force, establish a detention system and forge a new model for law and order in the country. But on the ground, he says, this task was made impossible by a lack of manpower, limited resources and the rising animosity of the Iraqi people. When he retired in 2004, the military police were still struggling to put these systems in place, and law and order seemed a distant goal.

title: Brains as Clear as Jell-O for Scientists to Explore
description: The visible brain has arrived  the consistency of Jell-O, as transparent and colorful as a childs model, but vastly more useful.

title: Parliament Debates Thatcher
description: Prime Minister David Cameron and members of Parliament pay tribute to Margaret Thatcher.

title: From the Audience to the Stage at the Metropolitan Opera
description: The soprano Danielle de Niese came for a relaxing evening at the Metropolitan Opera  in the audience  with her husband and parents on Tuesday night. Instead, she found herself onstage.

title: Tentative Settlement Reached in Labor Dispute at St. Paul Chamber Orchestra
description: The St. Paul Chamber Orchestras musicians and management have tentatively settled one of the stickiest labor disputes of the musical world this season, a conflict that has caused the cancellation of concerts since October.

title: Champions League Quarterfinals: Matchday 4
description: When does four minus two equal four? Today.

title: Political Introspection
description: David Brooks: Have you noticed that there have been twice as many essays on Margaret Thatcher as there are English speakers on earth?

title: Thatcher as Theater: A Prime Minister Playwrights Couldnt Resist
description: LONDON  Margaret Thatcher didnt have much time for one of Britains defining qualities  its abundance of theater  but theater people certainly had plenty of time for her. If only antagonistically.

title: Two National Theater Directors to Depart
description: Having just celebrated his 10th anniversary as artistic director of Londons National Theater, Nicholas Hytner announced on Wednesday that he would leave his position at the end of March 2015. Nick Starr, who became the companys executive director in 2002, also announced that he would leave the theater in 2014. Mr. Hytner and Mr. Starr have been a powerful team, and Mr. Starr told The Guardian that the two planned to work together on future projects.

title: Dinner Diplomacy, This Time at the White House
description: WASHINGTON  If President Obama meant his new budget proposal to be an olive branch to Republicans, he had a chance to test their reaction in person on Wednesday night as he hosted a dozen senators from the opposition party for dinner at the White House.

title: Court Expresses Antipathy for S.E.C. in Handling of Madoff Case
description: A federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that Bernard L. Madoffs investors cannot sue the Securities and Exchange Commission for not uncovering his fraud, but at the same time blasted the agency for its failings.

title: Postal Service Halts Push to End Delivery of Mail on Saturdays
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service on Wednesday backed away from its plan to stop Saturday mail delivery, criticizing Congress for taking the cost-cutting proposal off the table.

title: Shopping Snapshots: April 11
description: Cutout dresses will be big for spring; Bao Bao Wan presents little ones pendants; the black-and-white patterns come in a range of styles: platforms, heels, sandals; and other shopping news.

title: How the Cubs Explain the Cosmos
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.April means the arrival of a new baseball season. More than a few intellectuals have described the game in quasi-religious terms, crediting baseball with the capacity to add meaning and texture to life. A recent book by the embattled N.Y.U. president John Sexton even makes an explicit case for Baseball as a Road to God.

title: Jury Lineups Announced for Tribeca Film Festival
description: Imagine a cocktail party populated by recognizable guests who would otherwise probably never hang out together: some of them are highly knowledgeable about movies, some have made movies, others have appeared in movies and still others have at least seen some movies. Hold that image in your mind and tally off the boldface names in attendance, and you may come up with rosters not unlike the  shall we say, heterogeneous  juries that will preside over this years Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Hofstra Hires New Basketball Coach
description: Hofstra named Joe Mihalich its new mens basketball coach Wednesday, ending a monthlong search to replace Mo Cassara, who was fired in March after three seasons.

title: Strike Over Pickpockets Shuts the Louvre
description: PARIS The Louvre museum was shut on Wednesday after 200 guards and surveillance agents went on strike to protest the growing number of often violent pickpockets who prey on them and tourists.

title: Turning Street View Images Into Time-Lapse Films
description: Hyperlapse videos are a variation of traditional time lapse filmmaking in which the camera travels while also panning, rotating and tilting. The effect can be striking or dizzying. But under normal circumstances, coordinating all that action and turning it into a film is exceedingly complex and time consuming.

title: Broad Outlines of Senate Immigration Agreement Emerge
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of senators has largely agreed on a broad immigration bill that would require tough border measures to be in place before illegal immigrants could take the first steps to become American citizens, according to several people familiar with drafts of the legislation.

title: Timberlakes 20/20 Experience Rolls On at No. 1
description: Justin Timberlakes latest album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a third week, beating new albums by the Band Perry and the rapper Tyler, the Creator.

title: Justice for All? Teaching About Crime and Punishment in America
description: The United States holds a larger proportion of its population in prison than any other nation in the world. How has this happened, and is it a problem? In this lesson, students will consider whether the nations system for addressing crime is effective and consistent with its Constitutional ideals of equality under the law.

title: When the Present Is Past It Looks Much Prettier
description: Andr Aciman is a connoisseur of nostalgia, like a contemporary Proust. A French-speaking Jew expelled from Egypt with his family in the early 1960s, when he was 15, he now lives in New York and writes in precise and elegant English. But in his novels and memoirs he takes a certain melancholy pleasure in considering himself a permanent exile, which is for him less a condition of displacement than one of disappointment and vacillation. Wherever he finds himself hes less happy than where he was just before, and you sometimes get the sense that he feels truly at home only in memory, in the places he reconstructs for himself on the page.

title: Arab Israeli Is Accused of Joining Rebels in Syrian Revolt
description: JERUSALEM  A district court on Wednesday charged an Arab citizen of Israel with crimes including contact with a foreign agent after he traveled to Syria to fight alongside the rebels, Shin Bet, Israels internal security agency, said in a statement.

title: Arrests of 2 Officials Lead to a Tense Village Meeting
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.  It would have been a routine gathering of this communitys governing body except for one salient and looming fact: It was the first meeting since the mayor and the deputy mayor had been arrested in a complicated and brazen federal corruption case that also ensnared a state senator and a New York City councilman.

title: A Hide-Out From the Ordinary
description: IT HAS BEEN SOME TIME since a new store, the brick-and-mortar kind, for those of you who can remember, has set out to do something more surprising than sell clothes. But then, entertaining the customer has become a low-priority line item on most retailers budgets these days.

title: Country Music Hall of Fame Names New Members
description: Kenny Rogers, Bobby Bare and Cowboy Jack Clement will be inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum later this year, the Country Music Association announced at a news conference on Wednesday.

title: ConocoPhillips Suspends Its Arctic Drilling Plans
description: HOUSTON  ConocoPhillips announced on Wednesday that it was suspending its plans to drill in Alaskan Arctic waters in 2014 because of uncertainties over federal regulatory and permitting standards.

title: Hollande Creates a Prosecutor for Fraud and Vows to End Tax Havens
description: PARIS  Buffeted by a political scandal, a stagnant economy and angry public reaction to an investigative report about secret offshore bank accounts, President Franois Hollande on Wednesday announced the creation of a position of special prosecutor to pursue cases of corruption and tax fraud, and vowed to eradicate tax havens in Europe and the world.

title: Girl Scout Cookies as a Tax Deduction
description: Last weekend, The Wall Street Journal ran an article on how some states, like Idaho, tax the sale of Girl Scout cookies. That got us thinking about another tax-related question having to do with Samoas and other Girl Scout treats.

title: Steinem on Thatcher
description: Margaret Thatcher, who died on Monday at 87, was the first female prime minister of Britain and, for a time, among the most powerful women in the world. But her conservative politics and dismissive attitude toward womens libbers (her words) made Mrs. Thatcher a complicated figure for feminists, even after she withdrew from public life.

title: Candidates React to Weiner Speculation
description: At a candidates forum in the Bronx, The Timess Stephen Farrell spoke with some of the mayoral candidates about the news that Anthony Weiner is considering a run.

title: Melissa Harris-Perrys Uncontroversial Comment About Children
description: If you send your children to public school, are they still your children? If you trust that should they fall off their bike while riding along on the sidewalk in front of the neighbors house, he might run out with a Band-Aid, is that the end of the nuclear family? Does taking support for those children, in the form of the Childrens Health Insurance Program, Head Start or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, mean you have you ceded your place as mother or father to the collective?

title: Roman Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Man of Our Time
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wilder Way
description: See the interactive slide show

title: Measuring Inflation for Social Security
description: 4/11/13 | Updated to restore an omitted paragraph on the effect on the oldest retirees.

title: Ghana Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankings Crocodile Tears
description: The story is told of a young heir whose family fell on times hard times and he could no longer afford to keep his polo ponies. He still had a big house and enough trust fund income to make a paid career optional, but it was hard to look his polo-playing friends in the face. The shame was almost unbearable.

title: The Answer to Too Big to Fail?
description: Senators Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, and David Vitter, R-Louisiana, have a new bill that would make banks keep much higher levels of capital. Not surprisingly, representatives for the financial industry are already claiming that such a requirement would ruin the economy.

title: The Power of Talking to Your Baby
description: By the time a poor child is 1 year old, she has most likely already fallen behind middle-class children in her ability to talk, understand and learn. The gap between poor children and wealthier ones widens each year, and by high school it has become a chasm. American attempts to close this gap in schools have largely failed, and a consensus is starting to build that these attempts must start long before school  before preschool, perhaps even before birth.

title: First Hudson Yards Tower Signs Three Major Tenants
description: There was a time when developers and city officials thought that the citys financial institutions would lead the development of the rail yards on the Far West Side of Manhattan.

title: Disney Studios Lays Off 150 Employees
description: LOS ANGELES  Walt Disney Studios, which employs 7,000 people, on Wednesday laid off 150 workers, including a few relatively senior executives in movie publicity and the DVD department.

title: Vacation Behind Him, Stoudemire Will Revisit Israel as Coach
description: As players did layup drills in a high school gymnasium in Toronto one afternoon in August, John Dore disappeared briefly and returned with a tall guest wearing a black skullcap.

title: T Magazine at Design Week
description: A host of boldface names celebrated Deborah Needlemans latest design issue at Design Week in Milan.

title: Relighting Sarfatti
description: A look at Gino Sarfattis lighting designs.

title: Beyonc to Headline Philadelphia Music Festival
description: Jay-Z did not have to look far for a singer to headline the second annual Budweiser Made in America music festival in Philadelphia  his wife Beyonc will be at the top of the bill, Billboard reported.

title: Hood by Air Has a Fashion Moment
description: The fashion show was running an hour late, but no one seemed to mind. The rapper Waka Flocka Flame took a seat near the artist Terence Koh. Tank and Bambi, two miniature Pomeranians with more than 3,000 followers on Instagram, sat front row with their owner, the creative director Nicola Formichetti. Then, with a smoke-filled spectacle of bluish lasers and flickering LED signs, a mash-up of post-apocalyptic, post-Internet looks was unveiled.

title: Weiner Jolts Mayors Race by Saying He May Enter It
description: John C. Liu was effusive in his encouragement, but offered this pearl of wisdom: Just stop tweeting.

title: A Baseball Golden Age?
description: Thats the bold claim advanced last week by Michael Brendan Dougherty, who just took a step away from political writing to found a baseball newsletter (news-email?) called The Slurve, and who gives a great interviewabout the decision here. His case that baseball is peaking acknowledges the sports various difficulties (the Hall of Fames steroid problems, the pace of games, the Florida Marlins), but then follows with this:

title: Leaked Report to Egypts President Implicates Army in Torture and Killing of Civilians
description: A leaked report published on Wednesday by The Guardian implicates Egypts armed forces of participating in the disappearance, torture and killing of civilians across the country during the 2011 Egyptian revolution, an uprising in which the military initially professed neutrality before President Hosni Mubarak was removed from power.

title: Sleep Less, Weigh More
description: A new study suggests that adolescent obesity could be decreased if teenagers got more sleep, and the heaviest would benefit most.

title: Beyonc and Jay-Zs Cuba Trip Was Approved, Treasury Dept. Says
description: As it turns out, Beyonc and Jay-Z were never in much danger of serving the 10-year jail sentence, or paying the $250,000 fine, that their visit to Cuba last week supposedly might have cost them. Treasury Department regulations prohibit Americans from traveling to Cuba unless authorized by a general or specific license, and several Florida lawmakers have raised strong objections.

title: Lilly Pulitzers Uniforms for an Entire Class
description: In the days after the passing of Lilly Pulitzer, who died on Sunday and whose memorial service will take place Thursday at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach, Fla., the memories of her loyal customers and friends (the two were often interchangeable) flooded back.

title: Jolts From Life: Christian Wiman Talks About My Bright Abyss
description: In My Bright Abyss: Meditation of a Modern Believer, the poet and essayist Christian Wiman writes about his religious faith, which intensified after he met his future wife and then intensified again when he was afflicted with a rare type of cancer at the age of 39. In his review, Dwight Garner called it a slim and simmering book that works both sides of the tracks  the intellectual and the mystical  in its considerations of faith. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Wiman discussed why hes a Christian, the writers who mean the most to him, the state of his health and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Scouting Report
description: Even if youre not Coachella bound, the Los Angeles-based designer Cynthia Vincent has stocked her Elizabeth Street store with festival-ready wares that include silk ikat shorts ($198) and embroidered ankle boots ($374). They will look equally cool in the suddenly hot city as they will in Indio, Calif. At 253 Elizabeth Street, (646) 707-3830.

title: T Salone Party
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Ex-SAC Trader Gets Court Permission for African Honeymoon
description: Donald Longueuil, a former employee of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, has big for plans when he gets out of prison.

title: Budget Embodies Obamas Vision for Remaking Economy
description: President Obama used the first budget of his second term to sketch out his vision for an economy with more lasting economic growth and less income inequality than the country has experienced in more than a decade.

title: Looking Into the Decline in African-American Players
description: Every player in the major leagues will wear No. 42 on Monday as baseball pays its annual tribute to Jackie Robinson, who integrated the game in 1947 and whose life story will play out in movie theaters nationwide this weekend. Yet few of the players wearing Robinsons number will be African-American, a trend that has grown increasingly troubling to major league officials.

title: Scene City: A Party Warhol Would Have Loved
description: Shopping as art, for the New York Academy of Arts Tribeca Ball.

title: 12-Year-Old Building at MoMA Is Doomed
description: When a new home for the American Folk Art Museum opened on West 53d Street in Manhattan in 2001 it was hailed as a harbinger of hope for the city after the Sept. 11 attacks and praised for its bold architecture.

title: Questions on a Study of the Cost of Federal Regulation
description: In late March, Representative Tammy Duckworth, a Democrat from Illinois, announced a new bill promising regulatory relief to small businesses. But what caught The Agendas eye was Ms. Duckworths justification for the legislation. For businesses with less than 20 employees, she said in the press release, the annual cost of federal regulation can be over $10,000 per worker.

title: Chinas Actions in Flu Cases Draw Critics
description: HONG KONG  Of all the mysteries surrounding the emergence of a new and deadly strain of avian influenza around Shanghai, one of the biggest is why Chinas hundreds of medical and veterinary labs did not spot the problem sooner  or if they did, why it was not disclosed.

title: A Budget Focus on Inequality
description: The great economic focus of the White House, the financial crisis and recession aside, has been inequality.

title: Cooking Onion Tart and Asparagus
description: Julia Moskin makes two recipes from Deborah Madisons new cookbook, Vegetable Literacy: fragrant onion tart and asparagus with salsa verde and scarlet onions.

title: Evidence a Reporter Was More Than a One-Story Wonder
description: McCandlish Phillips, the masterly former New York Times reporter who died on Tuesday, was about a lot more than exposing a Jewish-born Ku Klux Klansman, although that is what he is often remembered for. His deceptively simple-sounding declarative voice could make just about any subject seem irresistibly droll.

title: How to Lighten the Crush of E-Mail
description: E-mail is  the worst. Between alerts from Facebook, newsletters from Groupon, reply-all e-mail chains, work brainstorming sessions and social coordinating, the in-box becomes a daunting pit of quicksand. At a certain point, even the most dogged among us give up.

title: Calculating the Cost of Revenge: The Price Is Always High
description: How can an art form be updated while maintaining its integrity? Thats the challenge when staging traditional dance for modern audiences. Sophiline Cheam Shapiro, the choreographer and director of Khmer Arts Ensemble, succeeds at this more than most. A Bend in the River, performed by an all-female cast at the Joyce Theater, isnt flawless. Yet in it Ms. Shapiro peels back a layer of Cambodian classical dance  liberating the movement from heavy costuming  and shows the potential of its undulating flow.

title: Independent Spirit
description: With her eye for the unusual, the ancient and the brightly colored, Irene Silvagni orchestrates her Provencal retreat into a wonderfully imperfect harmony.

title: A Venture Capital Partnership for Google Glass Apps
description: Three prominent venture capital funds want software developers to know they are on the hunt for apps and software for Google Glass, the companys Internet-connected glasses.

title: 2 Investors Give $35 Million to Brown
description: Brown University has some well-placed friends in Silicon Valley.

title: Spinning Her Brand of Mysticism and Moves
description: What is Sufi Kathak? As the Indian dancer Manjari Chaturvedi made abundantly clear during her New York debut at Symphony Space on Tuesday, Sufi Kathak is a dance style invented by Manjari Chaturvedi. It borrows from Kathak, an Indian classical dance with both Hindu and Muslim roots, to express the mysticism of Sufi poetry and music.

title: Goldman Reaches Deal to Let C.E.O. Be Chairman
description: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive and chairman of Goldman Sachs, is keeping both of those roles.

title: Bluegrass and Jazz, Meeting in More Than the Middle
description: Chris Thile and Brad Mehldau come from different worlds but the same species, and whatever feels unlikely about their pairing is eclipsed by what feels perfectly natural. Mr. Thile, the mandolinist and singer with Punch Brothers, is a progressive-bluegrass pacesetter; Mr. Mehldau is the most influential jazz pianist of the last 20 years. Both are team players who can still give the impression of aesthetic self-containment. Both love Bach and the Beatles, and both have developed fan bases bigger and broader (and younger) than their genre silos can accommodate.

title: Deutsche Telekom Sweetens T-Mobile Bid for MetroPCS
description: 6:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iran, Pakistan, Gaza City and Kashmir.

title: Making the American Dream a Two-Week Endeavor
description: The Moment, a new reality series on USA in which people are given the chance to try out for the dream job they thought had passed them by, wants us to root for the weekly hopeful, of course. But heres the thing: Success for those people would mean that the Western educational and economic systems are giant houses of cards and that everything we have come to believe about how the socio-economic structure ought to work is a lie.

title: Man With Ties to Karzai Dies in a Military Raid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A special operations raid meant to disrupt a Taliban arms operation in southern Afghanistan ended in the death of a man with family ties to the Afghan presidents inner circle, leading to tensions between regional officials and the military, officials say.

title: Tour Bus Rolls On, Newbies Included
description: Despite one of musics most positive names the veteran quintet Yes has seen more than its share of turbulence and rivalries over a life span that has now reached its 45th year. A hard-touring institution, the current Yes came to the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night for a show comprising three of its most durable albums: all from the 1970s, each played from start to finish.

title: Building Numerical Literacy in the Very Young
description: My children adore tablets and theyre now so accustomed to touch screens that their fingerprints can be seen on my TV set when they forget it doesnt work that way. But my wife and I are careful about the apps they can use. Although weve installed a few that are purely games, there are many inspiring educational apps that are just as much fun. Their numeracy skills have definitely been helped by the counting and math apps.

title: Heeding Between the Lines
description: The jazz drummer Jeff Ballards new band, Fairgrounds, makes the sound of between and among. Its somewhere between a trio and a quintet; among free play and funk and mainstream jazz models of the 50s and 60s; between acoustic and electric; among flowing and limpid and fractured phrasing.

title: The 2014 Maserati Ghibli Aims to Be a 5 Series Fighter
description: Automotive conglomerates can produce the strangest things, like, say, a diesel-powered Maserati. The company released the first official photos Monday of the four-door 2014 Ghibli sedan, which will be introduced at the Shanghai Motor Show next week.

title: The Mezzo-Sopranos Guide to Bilingual Education
description: The two halves of the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonards recital on Tuesday evening at Zankel Hall reflected the two sides of her ancestry. Her mother is Argentine and her father is from the United States, so before intermission she sang Spanish songs and after it American ones, including new pieces by Jennifer Higdon, Glen Roven and Ben Moore.

title: This Weeks Links: HTML5 Dev Conf Edition
description: 12:18 p.m. | Updated  A few of the videos are now available.Last week, I attended the HTML5 Dev Conf in San Francisco. Overall the event was quite illuminating; I got a strong sense of where the web development community sees itself, and where it would like to go. This weeks links are to slides of talks I heard, as well as some I couldnt attend but heard good things about. This is by no means an exhaustive list. (A few of the videos are now available; look for more on the HTML5 Dev Conf video page.)

title: I Went to a Movie and an Art Exhibition Broke Out
description: Cultural events are reaching ever-wider audiences through various conduits these days, including HD simulcasts and screenings of operas and plays in movie theaters. Last year an art exhibition received this treatment for the first time. The result was Leonardo Live, an HD film tour of the acclaimed (and thronged) exhibition Leonardo da Vinci: Painter in the Court of Milan, a blockbuster at the National Gallery in London. It was directed by the documentary maker Phil Grabsky.

title: At Howard University, Rand Paul Argues Republican Case to Black Voters
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky stepped inside an auditorium at Howard Universitys School of Business on Wednesday to deliver a message to young black voters: the Republican Party wants you back.

title: Unsealed Indictment of Nelson L. Castro
description: Read the unsealed indictment of Nelson L. Castro.

title: Facebook Refines Ad Targeting
description: Bought granola at the supermarket lately? Expect to see an ad soon on your Facebook page for something that fits your granola-buying profile.

title: U.S. Efforts to Regulate Consultants Face Big Obstacles
description: Federal regulators are facing pressure from Capitol Hill to rein in a multibillion-dollar consulting industry after the companies stumbled during their recent review of mortgage foreclosure abuses. But the efforts could be stymied, given regulators close ties to consultants and limited legal authority to penalize them.

title: Tightrope Artist Reveals Tricks (No Craning of Necks Required)
description: This time, Philippe Petit was only a couple of feet off the ground.

title: An Easy Chair (Accent on Easy)
description: The latest collaboration between the Denmark-based manufacturer Fritz Hansen and the Spanish designer Jaime Hayon is an easy chair with serene lines and a name (Ro) that means tranquillity in Danish. Mr. Hayon was asked to create a piece for relaxation and reflection; he started by thinking about the shape of the human body.

title: Sales at Future Perfect, Canvas and Others
description: Furniture, rugs and home accessories are up to 70 percent off at the Future Perfect, through April 21 (the Oscar armchair by Matthew Hilton for SCP, usually $4,288, is $3,064; the Nos Da Arthur pouffe by Donna Wilson, usually $783, is $392); 115 North Sixth Street (Berry Street), Brooklyn, (718) 599-6278, thefutureperfect.com.

title: Whats Wrong With the Chapter 14 Proposal
description: On Thursday, I am speaking at New York Universitys Stern School of Business on a panel on Dodd-Franks orderly liquidation authority. It seemed like an appropriate time to discuss why, although Im no huge fan of the authority, I also have my doubts about its leading alternative.

title: A New Spirit in the Material World
description: Trained in Japan, England and Guatemala, Hiroko Takeda, the Brooklyn-based textile artist, is not easily characterized as modern, classic or futurist. Her collection, which intermingles silk and metal, mohair and linen, is all that and more. Whether weaving a throw on a traditional loom or knitting a huge architectural commission in black metallic thread, Ms. Takeda experiments with color, texture and technique. After working for storied textile firms in Tokyo, Kyoto and New York, she struck out on her own in 2010. Since then, Calvin Klein Home, Urban Zen and Christian Dior have commissioned one-of-a-kind pieces as artwork for their stores. Custom fabrics can cost $200 to $600 a yard, not including setup fees, and a 75-by-25-inch panel of her intricate Giant Waffle Cartography series can be priced upward of $1,500. Information: (917) 676-8329 or hirokotakeda.com.

title: Now Your Backsplash Can Move With You
description: Thin magnetic plywood tiles dyed to look like classic quilt patterns: thats the innovation of Moonish, a company founded by Giovanna and Matt Taylor. The married couple, who silk-screen the 6-by-6-inch tiles in their wood shop in Greenpoint, in Brooklyn, had never done design work before. He is the lead singer in the indie rock group Mamal of Paradise; she used to work in the film and music industry.

title: Post-Breakup Bungalow
description: A house and a marriage in shambles. At least one was fixed.

title: Magazine Ready, Except the Marriage
description: In October 2011, our real estate agent sent us a listing for a short sale a block away from where we were renting. Considering the area  Echo Park, a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood in Los Angeles  I knew it was a good deal, on paper at least.

title: For Baccarat, a Language Other Than Glass
description: The Brazilian brothers Fernando and Humberto Campana have designed luxurious furniture and accessories made with humble materials like cardboard, rope and even stuffed animals (though not all at the same time). And this week, during the furniture fair in Milan, they are presenting lamps for Baccarat that introduce bamboo and wicker to the materials palette of the French glassware company.

title: A Creative Mind in Motion
description: It would be only a slight exaggeration to say that you cant toss a meatball in Milan this week without hitting a project by Ferruccio Laviani. The Italian designer is highly visible at the international furniture fair, which opened Tuesday. Not only is he introducing lights and furniture for a passel of companies, including Kartell, Foscarini and Emmemobili, but he also designed their booths.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I plan to reduce the clutter in my home by putting everything in the closet. Do I need to worry about what buyers will think of my overstuffed closets?

title: Shopping for Brass Accessories
description: Anna Karlin, a British-born designer, says that brass is blingy without being tacky.

title: Star Hurls Musical Barbs Before Venezuelas Vote
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Political campaigns in Venezuela often can seem like a battle of the bands. Songs written for the campaigns blast from huge speakers at rallies and from the backs of trucks that drive around cities where candidates appear. Campaigns vie to come up with the catchiest tunes to energize their supporters at rallies that are often beer-fueled street parties.

title: Brass Accessories
description: AFTER YEARS OF TAKING A BACK SEAT to other metals, brass is enjoying a newfound popularity. Why? Its beautiful, tactile and earthy, said Anna Karlin, a British-born designer based in New York. Its blingy without being tacky.

title: Re-Lighting Sarfatti
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: How to Make a Basic Studio Look Monumental
description: Just keep it simple.

title: The Refined Studio
description: By his own admission, Paul Palandjian is a guy who has always been rigorously focused: Harvard-educated, a former professional tennis player and the scion of a family of real estate developers who joined the family business. His tastes were conservative, particularly in architecture. After all, he grew up outside Boston.

title: A Thiefs Trick: Turn a Filing Cabinet Into Electronics
description: How many computer hard drives can you fit in one filing cabinet box?

title: The HTC One Deserves Its Place in the Spotlight
description: Remember HTC? For a long time, this Taiwanese phone maker seemed to be on a roll. Its Android phones kept making gadget headlines.

title: Time-Traveling
description: Visiting Sylvester Manor on Shelter Island can feel like returning to the 17th century.

title: Life on the Plantation
description: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y.  Imagine going to your great-aunts funeral and unexpectedly being offered an estate that harked back to the 17th century, complete with a plantation house where slaves once slept in the attic.

title: Television, D.C.s Dark Mirror
description: Modern series set in Washington, D.C., tend to present the city as a place full of reprobates.

title: PC Sales Still in a Slump, Despite New Offerings
description: It should be one of the most exciting periods in years for people looking to buy new PCs, with a new version of Windows on sale and shelves full of slick touch-screen devices to run it.

title: Tim Hetherington, in Film and Indelible
description: A new documentary by Sebastian Junger explores the life and work of his friend and colleague Tim Hetherington.

title: Inspired by Brights of Spring
description: Metallic, frosty or pearly, colors come out to play on nails or lips, for a refreshing change of seasons.

title: Spring Fashion: Take Me to September
description: A highly selective, woman-friendly, not too-too pricey mix of spring clothes youll want to wear.

title: Spring Fashion: Picky, Picky
description: A critics practical, and ornery, guide to spring shopping (but dont hold her to it).

title: Suspect Dead After Taking Firefighters Hostage in Georgia
description: Updated| 8:18 P.M.  A heavily armed man is dead after the police stormed his suburban Atlanta home to rescue four firefighters taken hostage when they responded to a 911 call for medical attention to the house on Wednesday, officials said at the scene in Suwanee, Ga.

title: Picky, Picky: A Critics Spring Fashion Guide
description: The other day I wandered into Cline on Madison Avenue. I was looking for spring clothes. Actually, I girded myself for the trip. Ever since I found a pair of black Cline trousers at Barneys with a hangtag that said I could always get that same style year in and year out, Ive thrown my hat to Barneys, at least for Cline.

title: NBC Renews Last Call With Carson Daly
description: NBC announced on Wednesday that it had renewed its late-night show Last Call with Carson Daly as the host, confirming his spot in the networks prime-time lineup for a 13th year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,179 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Seeking Relief, Banks Shift Risk to Murkier Corners
description: Banks have been shedding risky assets to show regulators that they are not as vulnerable as they were during the financial crisis. In some cases, however, the assets dont actually move  the bank just shifts the risk to another institution.

title: Mets Still Havent Settled on a Leadoff Hitter
description: PHILADELPHIA  The No. 1 spot in the Mets lineup remained a revolving door Wednesday as Manager Terry Collins employed his third leadoff hitter of the week during the teams series finale against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Stan Isaacs, Cheeky Columnist, Dies at 83
description: Stan Isaacs, a longtime sports reporter and commentator for Newsday who wrote the quirky column Out of Left Field, died on April 2 at an assisted living facility in Haverford, Pa. He was 83.

title: Cuba Returns Couple Who Fled With Sons in Custody Fight
description: MIAMI  A Florida couple who are accused of kidnapping their two young boys after losing custody last week and then fleeing to Cuba were brought back to the United States on Wednesday and arrested in Tampa, a rare moment of cooperation between two hostile countries and one that sidestepped a possible international custody battle.

title: Photo Replay: April 10
description: Family and old friends gather at Augusta National on the day before the Masters.

title: Tumblr to End Storyboard and Dismiss 3 Employees
description: Tumblr, the popular social blogging site, said Tuesday night that it would shut Storyboard, the multimedia news blog that it had created to report on its own community and that it had started only last May.

title: Swatting Hoax Tests the Police and Stars Alike
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The 911 call came in late Monday afternoon. Two men with guns, one wearing a bulletproof vest, were storming the home of the actor Russell Brand, tucked away on a crest in the Hollywood Hills.

title: White House Budget Curbs Some Deductions for the Wealthy
description: President Obama is no longer pressing to raise income tax rates on the rich. But that doesnt mean he thinks the wealthy are paying enough in taxes.

title: An Exhibition for Students Who Lost Art in a Studio Fire
description: A painters art is irreplaceable, so it was no surprise that 44 seniors at Pratt Institute were heartsick, many of them left sobbing, when their studios and the paintings they kept there went up in flames in February in a middle-of-the-night fire at the art and design schools historic Main Building in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Foundation Releasing Aid to Families in Newtown
description: Facing complaints that money raised in the wake of the killings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., was not being distributed promptly to the families it was intended for, the foundation charged with distributing the largest pool of aid said this week that it would distribute $4 million to 40 families directly affected by the massacre.

title: Nearly 70 Years Later, a New Round of Auschwitz Prosecutions
description: BERLIN  They worked as guards at the Holocausts most notorious death camp, and nearly seven decades later they may finally be brought to account before a court of law.

title: Tips Traded on Golf Course Led to KPMG Executives Downfall
description: 10:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Miles Apart in Connecticut, Now Even Closer at Frozen Four
description: HAMDEN, Conn.  Yale and Quinnipiac are roughly 15 minutes apart, linked by Whitney Avenue. The universities may be close geographically, but that connecting thoroughfare remains their only real bond.

title: Helena Carroll, 84, Actress of Stage and Screen, Dies
description: Helena Carroll, an Irish actress known for her stage, film and television appearances in the United States, died on March 31 in Marina del Rey, Calif. She was 84.

title: Happiness, Beyond the Data
description: Happiness studies are booming in the social sciences, and governments are moving toward quantitative measures of a nations overall happiness, meant to supplement traditional measures of wealth and productivity. The resulting studies have a high noise-to-signal ratio, but we can expect that work with an aura of scientific rigor on something as important as happiness is going to be taken seriously. Still, our first-person experience and reflection can catch crucial truths about happiness that escape the quantitative net.

title: After KPMG, Audit Firms Reconsider Procedures
description: Accounting firms are being forced to take a fresh look at their practices in the wake of an insider-trading scandal involving one of KPMGs top auditors, as new rules requiring more transparency by the firms are already being considered.

title: Loopholes in Gun Laws Allow Buyers to Skirt Checks
description: When Zina Haughton, 42, got a restraining order against her husband, Radcliffe, last October  she told a court that his threats terrorize my every waking moment  he became ineligible to buy a gun under federal law. But he found a way around that: he bought a gun from a private seller he found on the Internet who, unlike federally licensed dealers, was not legally required to check his background.

title: Child Migrants, Alone in Court
description: LOS ANGELES

title: In China, Feudal Answers for Modern Problems
description: BEIJING

title: Yipes, Its Congress on the Move
description: Wow, theres a lot going on in Washington! Budgets are flying all over the place. The Senate might actually start voting on a gun bill Thursday. And immigration reform has now gotten so far that the House of Representatives has a bipartisan Gang of Eight working on it.

title: At Augusta, Attention Is Back on the Golf
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Hope Leaves the Shadows at the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON

title: Mental Illness in California Prisons
description: There are about 33,000 mentally ill prisoners in state prisons in California, close to 30 percent of the prison population. The number of suicides in state prisons has soared in recent years, to about 24 suicides per 100,000 inmates a year, a rate about 48 percent higher than the national average.

title: From Poverty to a Top-Tier College
description: Because educational opportunity has much to do with upward mobility, it is distressing that low-income students who qualify for top-tier colleges rarely end up there. Flummoxed by the admissions process and scared off by what they think will be unmanageable costs, many of these students settle for lesser colleges with lower graduation rates, less financial aid (which means more debt) and less marketable degrees.

title: The Presidents Budget
description: President Obama knew full well that many Democrats and liberals would be sharply critical of his decision to propose reducing the Social Security cost-of-living adjustment, one of the centerpieces of his 2014 budget, which was released on Wednesday. In fact, he was counting on it. He wanted to show that he was willing to antagonize his supporters to get a budget compromise, putting Republicans on the spot to do the same.

title: Questions for a Young Immigration-Rights Activist
description: The video for "El Hielo, or The Ice, by the Los Angeles-based band La Santa Cecilia, was shot with a cast of undocumented immigrants, some of them leaders in the immigrant-rights movement. One is Erika Andiola, 25, of Mesa, Ariz., a 2009 graduate of Arizona State University and one of the founders of DRM Action Coalition, a group pushing for the Dream Act, a bill to grant legal status to unauthorized immigrants who were brought to the United States as children, as she was. Ms. Andiola made national headlines in January when her mother and brother were detained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement and then released after a fierce outcry by immigrant groups. Ms. Andiola, like thousands of others, has had her deportation temporarily stayed under President Obamas deferred action program. She now works as an aide to Representative Kyrsten Sinema, a Democrat of Arizona. In Washington on Wednesday, before the rally for immigrant citizenship on the law of the Capitol, Ms. Andiola spoke with The Times. The interview has been edited and condensed.

title: Denouncing Serbian Tilt, U.S. Boycotts U.N. Meeting
description: The United States boycotted a United Nations General Assembly meeting on Wednesday, organized by the former Serbian foreign minister who is the bodys current president, that in theory was about the role of international criminal justice but appeared to be a thinly disguised Serb complaint forum about the war-crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

title: A Hobbled Messi Helps Barcelona Advance
description: For nearly an hour, the Barcelona fans at Camp Nou divided their gazes between the action on the field and the movement  or lack of it, really  on the teams bench.

title: In Political Campaigns, Do You Get What You Pay For?
description: Mark Hanna, the Republican Party political boss, famously declared at the outset of the McKinley-Bryan campaign of 1896: There are two things that are important in politics. The first is money, and I cant remember the second.

title: Move to Widen Help for Syrian Rebels Gains Speed in West
description: LONDON  A long-debated move by Western nations to expand support for Syrias opposition gained momentum on Wednesday, with the United States poised to increase its nonlethal aid to rebel groups and pressure building to lift a European Union embargo on sending arms to Syria.

title: Man Takes Firefighters Hostage and Dies in Raid, Police Say
description: ATLANTA  A man who the police said was in deep financial trouble called firefighters to his house in a suburb north of Atlanta and then held them hostage for almost four hours until he died by gunfire as the police stormed the house Wednesday evening.

title: California Examines Puzzling Trend of Horses Sudden Deaths
description: Seemingly healthy racehorses have been dropping dead at an alarming rate in California, perplexing researchers and attracting the attention of regulators. The three-time Kentucky Derby-winning trainer Bob Baffert has had seven horses die suddenly in the last 16 months, necropsies revealed.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 10, 2013

title: Excerpts From the Taxi Compliments File
description: Taxi drivers in New York City are known to generate hostility, disgust or, if particularly fortunate, indifference among New Yorkers. Rare is the case when passengers have something nice to say about cabbies. Rarer still are the people, so taken with their drivers, who call 311 to register their compliments. Yet a total of roughly 700 compliments were received by the service in 2012. The following is a sampling of some of the more unusual entries, which include a story about a lost engagement ring and the offer of a gift made by a late relative:

title: Taboo on Speaking Ill of the Dead Widely Ignored Online After Thatchers Death
description: Even in ancient Sparta, apparently, people had to be advised to resist the urge to speak ill of the dead. According to Diogenes Laertius, among the precepts held dear by Chilon of Sparta was that of the dead, nothing but good should be spoken.

title: Killings Stir Questions on Indonesia Military Overhaul
description: JAKARTA  Soon after midnight on March 23, a group of heavily armed, masked men forced their way inside a prison near the Indonesian city of Yogyakarta and summarily executed four recently arrived detainees with gunshots to the head.

title: 'Accidental Racist' and Lyrical Provocation
Food Politics Creates Rift in Panel on Labeling
description: The politics of genetically modified food has created a rift in a policy-setting committee of the influential Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics that demonstrates the difficulty in finding anyone  anywhere  who doesnt already have an opinion on the issue.

title: City Report Looks at Subway Link to New Jersey
description: The plan to build a new rail terminal beneath Grand Central Terminal had its skeptics. A Second Avenue subway has seemed an impossible dream for decades. So perhaps it is plausible that on some faraway date, a traveler will walk out of a Mets game in Flushing, Queens, board the No. 7 train, ride beneath two rivers, and get off in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Gold, Long a Secure Investment, Loses Its Luster
description: Below the streets of Lower Manhattan, in the vault of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the worlds largest trove of gold  half a million bars  has lost about $75 billion of its value. In Fort Knox, Ky., at the United States Bullion Depository, the damage totals $50 billion.

title: Obama Moves to Block Horse Slaughter
description: The Obama administration has included a proposal in its 2014 budget that would effectively ban the slaughter of horses for human consumption.

title: Informer in Assembly, Accused of Perjury, Apologizes
description: Nelson L. Castro, a Democrat who resigned from the State Assembly to avoid prosecution on perjury charges, apologized on Wednesday for his misconduct, but insisted that throughout his time in office he had worked hard for his West Bronx district even as he also secretly cooperated with state and federal investigations of public corruption.

title: Tracking Student Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Live, in the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Priesthood, Old Is New
description: To the Editor:

title: Repression in Kazakhstan
description: To the Editor:

title: Libraries and Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivy League Confidential: Secrets Bared!
Corrections: April 11, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Something You Might Make
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  It has been unseasonably warm here in the Northeast (not that Im complaining), so Im very grateful for the fruity ADES Jim Hilger provides for us at 1 Across as we start out today.

title: Judge Questions Legality of Fee for Bike Tour
description: An effort by New York City to charge a nonprofit bicycling group nearly $1 million for the cost of policing its annual citywide bike tour appeared to be in jeopardy on Wednesday, when a judge seemed unpersuaded by the citys arguments.

title: Bieber Backs a Debit Card for Teenagers, From Parents
description: JUSTIN BIEBER earned $55 million in 2012, according to Forbes, but in new videos for the SpendSmart Payments Company, which offers a prepaid debit card for teenagers, the singer talks about his modest upbringing.

title: Nemesis for Knicks, Bulls Loom as Streak Busters
description: For 24 days and 13 games, across seven cities, two countries and three time zones, the Knicks have crushed every challenger, obliterated every obstacle, eradicated all doubts and left little to prove in the fleeting days of this revitalizing season.

title: New Solar Process Gets More Out of Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department is preparing to test a new way for solar power to make electricity: using the suns heat to increase the energy content of natural gas.

title: Carter Gets Peace Award at Law School, Despite Criticism
description: Despite complaints from some students and alumni before the event, an award ceremony honoring former President Jimmy Carter took place without incident on Wednesday at the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School in Greenwich Village.

title: Rand Paul Goes to Howard
description: The Republican Party is struggling with its future. Will it be a regional, Congressional party fighting a last-gasp battle for a shrinking base in a David and Goliath war against ominously expanding federal government? Or will it become a national, presidential party capable of adapting to a new American reality of diversity and expression in which the government serves an essential function in regulating public safety, providing a safety net and serving as a safeguard against discrimination?

title: Mishaps Underscore Weaknesses of Japanese Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO  More than two years after multiple meltdowns at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, a series of recent mishaps  including a blackout set off by a dead rat and the discovery of leaks of thousands of gallons of radioactive water  have underscored just how vulnerable the plant remains.

title: Next on the List for Coney Island: A New Theater
description: A deal has been reached to give the revived Coney Island amusement area a new 5,000-seat music hall and theater, partly on the vacant site of a well-known terra cotta landmark, Brooklyn officials said on Wednesday.

title: Shootout Specialist Comes Through for Rangers
description: A shootout goal from the player called the Norwegian Hobbit and a lucky bounce off an apologetic linesman helped the Rangers to an important 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

title: In Season of Goodbyes, Rivera Is Saying Thanks
description: CLEVELAND  In a room beneath the stands at Progressive Field on Wednesday, Mariano Rivera sheepishly walloped a bass drum with a stick, producing the sound that has echoed in his ears here for 19 years.

title: Israel: Rabbi Says He Wont Fight Plan on Western Wall
description: JERUSALEM  Shmuel Rabinowitz, the Orthodox rabbi of the Western Wall, said Wednesday that he would not oppose a proposal  to create a new area of prayer for Jews wishing to worship in a less traditional, more egalitarian style at a southern section of the wall known as Robinsons Arch.

title: Sometimes, Riders Find a Cabby Worth Praising
description: There is perhaps no more judgmental perch than the back seat of a New York City taxicab.

title: Yemen: President Set to Purge Military Leadership
description: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi announced a purge of Yemens military leadership on Wednesday that could sideline relatives of his autocratic predecessor, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who agreed to step down in November 2011 but whose continued influence has troubled Yemens brittle transition. Mr. Hadi restructured the military in December, but the moves announced Wednesday were more far-reaching, removing Mr. Salehs son and two nephews from powerful security posts as well as from the country. Officials said that Mr. Salehs son, who was the head of the Republican Guard, had been appointed ambassador to the United Arab Emirates, and that the nephews had been made military attaches in Ethiopia and Germany.

title: Obamas Mix of Taxes and Spending
description: The presidents 2014 budget includes $1.4 trillion in spending cuts and tax hikes over 10 years compared with current policies.

title: Egypt: Qatar Offers Support With Bond Purchase
description: Qatars government announced Wednesday that it would buy billions of dollars of Egyptian government bonds, giving critical support to President Mohamed Morsi as his government struggles to mend the countrys ailing economy. Sheik Hamad bin Jassem al-Thani, Qatars foreign minister, said his government would buy Egyptian bonds worth $3 billion and was exploring the possibility of supplying Egypts natural gas exports, to ease domestic shortages. Egypt relies heavily on natural gas to produce most of its electricity and neighborhoods in Cairo are suffering from occasional blackouts.

title: China: Official Dies During Inquiry
description: BEIJING  An official from a Chinese state-owned enterprise died after an accident while being investigated for possible violations of Communist Party discipline, according to a report by China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

title: Mexico: Government Says Murders Tied to Organized Crime Have Fallen
description: MEXICO CITY  The new government here, which has complained that Mexicos image has been sullied by persistent reports of violent crime, presented data on Wednesday that it said showed that murders related to organized crime had dropped sharply.

title: Rift at Dietetics Academy
description: The politics of genetically modified food has created a rift in a policy-setting committee of the influential Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.

title: Health Care and Military Spending Bear the Brunt of Proposed Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas effort to control federal spending would require the largest cuts from the governments biggest programs  health care and the military  while preserving or increasing spending on favored initiatives like early education, manufacturing and research.

title: Once Again, Phillies Pound Hefner in First Inning
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jeremy Hefner stood on the mound here early Wednesday night, a succession of Philadelphia Phillies players orbiting him along the basepaths.

title: Easy Hearing for Obamas Choice for Court
description: WASHINGTON  Sri Srinivasan, President Obamas nominee to one of the countrys most politically significant appeals courts, breezed his way through an uneventful Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday that ended with at least one Republican saying he would support the nomination.

title: Texas Considers Backtracking on Testing
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In this state that spawned test-based accountability in public schools and spearheaded one of the nations toughest high school curriculums, lawmakers are now considering a reversal that would cut back both graduation requirements and standardized testing.

title: Muses in Motion, Captured on Camera
description: To watch a Terrence Malick movie is to be on the move. Forty years after his debut with a road movie (Badlands), he now makes truly moving pictures of a more restless sort. His characters and camera constantly chase and encircle one another, searching for some kind of connection  be it physical, emotional or spiritual.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Apr. 11, 2013
description: Im an atheist, but I thought that was kind of touching.

title: Nets, Beating Celtics, Move Closer to 4th Seed
description: BOSTON  The teams had not met since Christmas Day, when Avery Johnson still coached the Nets, and Rajon Rondo still led the Celtics. Boston embarrassed the Nets on national television then, and Johnson was fired a few days later.

title: Rhapsody in Blue (and White)
description: Designer Juan Pablo Molyneuxs dedication to historical mastery and creative rapture resulted in a spectacular design folly.

title: Bradley Finds His Footing at Roma
description: Michael Bradley has conversed in Italian with ease when handed the opportunity in the aftermath of matches in the Stadio Olimpico news media zone this season.

title: Word of the Day | gambol
description: gambol \gam-bl\ verb and noun

title: Texas: Judge to Replace Slain Prosecutor
description: Eleven days after the Kaufman County district attorney and his wife were found shot to death at their home, Gov. Rick Perry named the prosecutors replacement on Wednesday, a local judge who has become the first black woman to be a top prosecutor in Texas. The new district attorney, Erleigh Norville Wiley, was appointed for a term to expire at the next general election, in November 2014. Ms. Wiley had been the judge of the countys Court at Law since 2003, and had served 14 years in the Dallas County district attorneys office. She will lead Kaufman County prosecutors at a time of widespread fear and anxiety after the killing of an assistant district attorney, Mark E. Hasse, on Jan. 31 and the deaths of the district attorney, Mike McLelland, and his wife, Cynthia, last month.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8:30 P.M. (13) LA CLEMENZA DI TITO Elina Garanca performs the trouser role of Sesto, the devoted lover of the vengeful princess Vitellia (Barbara Frittoli), whom she persuades to assassinate the Roman emperor Tito (Giuseppe Filianoti) in this Metropolitan Opera performance of Mozarts opera featuring Jean-Pierre Ponnelles 1984 staging. Kate Lindsey and Lucy Crowe (from right above) round out the cast as the young lovers Annio and Servilia. In an alert, engaged performance with a well-balanced ensemble, whats best in Clemenza cuts to the quick with the elegance and efficacy found in all of Mozarts finest works, Steve Smith wrote in The New York Times when the production was revived in November. Happily, it was just that kind of account that Harry Bicket, an English conductor closely associated with early-music groups and period-instrument players, elicited from the Met cast, chorus and orchestra.

title: Around the Country, Cries for Immigration Reform
description: Several tens of thousands of immigrants and advocates held rallies in Washington and other cities, as lawmakers continued to iron out legislation measures.

title: Religious Remark Confirmed in Irish Abortion Case
description: DUBLIN  A woman who died after being refused a potentially lifesaving abortion even while she was having a miscarriage was told that her repeated pleas could not be granted because Ireland is a Catholic country, an inquest has confirmed.

title: A Shot at Redemption Is Washed Away
description: CLEVELAND  Ivan Nova was looking forward to getting back on the mound Wednesday to help erase the memory of a poor outing in his last game, on Friday, but rain washed away the chance.

title: Kaziranga Remains a Success Story, Despite Rising Poaching
description: Kaziranga, ASSAM  One challenge facing any visitor to one of Indias tiger parks is actually seeing a tiger. Often, people leave without ever catching a glimpse.

title: News Quiz | April 11, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Carson, a Hope of Conservatives, Declines Speech After Furor
description: Dr. Benjamin Carson, a Johns Hopkins University neurosurgeon who has emerged as a rising star in conservative political circles, has canceled plans to appear as the graduation speaker at the universitys medical school after a furor over his provocative remarks about same-sex marriage.

title: Story of Womens Labor Camp Abuse Unnerves Even China
description: 8:50 a.m. | Updated BEIJING  In September 2011, 62-year-old Wang Guilan walked out of the Masanjia re-education through labor camp in Chinas northeastern Liaoning province with a rolled-up diary, written on waterproof material, hidden in her vagina. Guards had searched her before she left but had missed the document, by a fellow inmate called Liu Hua, recounting the torture taking place in the camp on a daily basis.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra to Tour China
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra is holding firm to plans for regular, lengthy visits to China. The orchestra said on Thursday it would tour the country from May 29 to June 10 and offer master classes, coaching sessions and workshops with young music students and local professional orchestra musicians. The orchestra made a similar visit last May, saying it would become a regular affair.

title: In Assam, Searching for New Crops and Farming Methods for Depleted Soil
description: Boralapar, ASSAM  For generations, the annual monsoon cycle blessed the upper Assam village of Boralapar with ideal conditions for paddy farming. Moderate annual flooding of the Dorpang River, a small tributary of the Brahmaputra River, enhanced the rich, loamy soil with a yearly booster dose of river-borne nutrients.

title: Captains Charged in Hong Kong Boat Collision That Killed 39
description: HONG KONG  The Hong Kong police on Thursday filed manslaughter charges against the captains of two boats that collided off Lamma Island in October, an accident that took the lives of 39 people in the citys deadliest maritime disaster in more than four decades.

title: Military in Syria Is Accused of Massacre
description: Syrian military forces have moved aggressively to retake territory lost to the insurgency in the countrys south over the past few days, antigovernment activists reported Thursday, and in one contested town at least 60 civilians, including women and children, were killed in what the opposition called a government-ordered atrocity motivated by revenge.

title: Filmmakers Capture Chaos After Airstrikes in Syria
description: Human Rights Watch accused the Syrian authorities Thursday of ordering indiscriminate and in some cases deliberate airstrikes against civilians, in a report released on Thursday along with a video summary that included dramatic footage of the chaos and bloodshed on the ground in the immediate aftermath of such attacks. According to the rights group, its report, is based on visits to 50 sites of government air strikes in opposition-controlled areas in Aleppo, Idlib, and Latakia governorates, and more than 140 interviews with witnesses and victims.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 11
