description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Early Word: Budget
description: In Todays Times:

title: Damaged by Hurricane Sandy, Verizons Jazz-Age Frescoes Glow Again
description: Hurricane Sandy damaged even what it could not touch.

title: Daily Report: Tumblr Shutters a News Blog, Not Yet a Year Old
description: Tumblr, the popular social blogging site, shut Storyboard, the multimedia news blog that it created last May report on its own community, Leslie Kaufman reports in Thursdays New York Times.

title: France Debates the Merits of the Bra
description: LONDON  Only in France.

title: Twirling in Oklahoma, a Dervish for Love
description: In Terrence Malicks films  he has made six so far, three in this century  it is usually possible to discern, beneath the blossoms of metaphor and the philosophical foliage, the trellis of a more or less conventional plot. The Thin Red Line is a combat picture. The Tree of Life is a nostalgic coming-of-age story. And To the Wonder, Mr. Malicks latest, is a romantic melodrama whose major characters fall tragically and beautifully in and out of love.

title: What Were Reading
description: Slice: Could the post-Sandy pizza at the reopened Totonnos in Coney Island truly be better than the pre-Sandy version? Or is it just sheer gratitude that makes it taste that way?  Julia Moskin

title: Poetry Pairing | The Hill
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches The Hill, by Joshua Mehigan with Many Cemeteries Damaged, but Green-Wood Bore the Brunt of the Storm by David W. Dunlap.

title: Consultants to Banks Are Sharply Questioned on Independence
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

title: Good Patients, Bad Patients
description: He was the kind of patient I went to medical school for.

title: The Gun Report: April 11, 2013
description: We all know the terrible toll a mass shooting can take on human life: 26 people can be gunned down in a matter of seconds. But how does that compare to a mass stabbing?

title: Options if You Cant Pay Your Income Taxes
description: Monday is the deadline for filing your federal income tax return. What if you owe taxes, but dont have enough money to pay them?

title: Q&A: Installing Microsoft Office on Multiple Machines
description: Q.

title: Clive James: By the Book
description: The novelist, critic, poet and author, most recently, of a new translation of Dantes Divine Comedy relishes his defense of Philip Larkin: Spraying cold water on a witch hunt is one of the duties that a critic should be ready to perform.

title: Vonn Makes Her Masters Debut
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The Olympic ski racing champion Lindsey Vonn waited at a table on the Augusta National Golf Club veranda next to the putting practice green Thursday morning as Tiger Woods completed his final warm-up swings before his 10:45 a.m. tee time.

title: Why Bayern and Dortmund Success Might Be Bad for Joachim Lw
description: Last weekend Bayern Munich won the Bundesliga title. That in itself wasnt particularly surprising: the newly crowned Deutscher Meisters have claimed the so-called salad dish trophy 22 times, pushing their collection of national championships to a dominating 23.

title: A Fine Feather
description: In From Europe With Love , opening May 2 at the Cristina Grajales gallery in SoHo, the Paris-based designer Sam Baron reinterprets traditional European design with what he calls a kind of French sense of humor. He applies a champagne-colored lacquer to Louis XVI-style cabinets, and deconstructs the traditional process of painting these bisque porcelain birds made by the venerable Portuguese house Vista Alegre.Through July 12; 10 Greene Street.

title: Where Do You Find Quiet in New York?
description: Where do you go to find peace in this boisterous city? With eight million New Yorkers and 50 million tourists a year all packed into 301 square miles, is there a special park bench, riverside fishing spot or underused historic site where you go to cherish the sound of silence?

title: The Tiger Anole
description: An Anolis tigrinus moved across a tree branch in Venezuela.

title: Obamas Progressive Budget
description: The first thing to be said about the budget President Obama delivered this week is that, at last, he has one. Until now his answer to the brutal specifics of the Republicans law-of-the-jungle budget has been a slogan  a balanced approach. Now he has provided (mostly) hard, credible numbers to show what he means by that slogan. I wish hed produced such a document a year ago and campaigned on it, which would strengthen his claim to a popular mandate. But give the guy credit. It was time to put up or shut up, and he put up.

title: An Embarrassment of Anoles
description: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvards Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

title: Image of the day: April 11
Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
description: WASHINGTON  Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate on Thursday voted to begin an emotionally and politically charged debate on gun safety proposals as advocates of new laws overcame a Republican filibuster threat.

title: PC Sales Data May Bolster Case for Taking Dell Private
description: It is becoming harder to believe that a turnaround of Dell  will be anything but messy  and shareholders may not want to stick around for that part.

title: Immigration Bill Expected to Focus on Work Skills
description: WASHINGTON  The sweeping immigration bill that a bipartisan group of senators is preparing will include a major new merit-based program for foreigners to become permanent legal residents based on their work skills, including both high-skilled and blue-collar workers, according to people familiar with a draft of the legislation.

title: Which Came First, the Chicken or the Wing?
description: Being vegetarian doesnt mean you lose that desire to pair your sports viewing and beer drinking with some spicy Buffalo wings. Inspired by Mark Bittmans cover article this past Sunday on healthful, veggie-friendly fast food, I spent my weekend hunting for the best vegan Buffalo wings in New York City.

title: Londons Best and Most Secretive Address
description: See the interactive slide show

title: Wireless Stereo That Really Is Stereo
description: The problem with most speaker docks is that the left and right speakers are inches apart in a single box, even fancy ones like the Bowers & Wilkins Zeppelin. They might as well be monaural. Not so the Soundfreaq Sound Platform 2. When you buy two of the wireless docks ($150 each) they recognize each other and become left and right speakers that can be separated by whatever distance Bluetooth and your room allow.

title: A Seasonal Pattern to Mental Health
description: A new study using the patterns of Google search queries suggests that mental illnesses flourish in winter and decline in summer.

title: Major Sports Leagues Prepare for the Im Gay Disclosure
description: With growing expectations in recent weeks that a gay male athlete in one of the four major professional sports leagues in the United States will soon come out publicly for the first time, the leagues have begun exploring ways to accommodate and respond to such a landmark announcement.

title: Foodie Fare
description: Inside Cherry Bombe magazines first issue.

title: Nobody Could Have Predicted
description: Top Republican Blasts Obama Budget As Shocking Attack On Seniors.

title: With Federal Budget Cuts, Something Will Be Missing From Fleet Week: The Sailors
description: How can there be a Fleet Week without the fleet?

title: The Language of Meat in a Vegetarian Butcher Shop
description: http://vimeo.com/63599404

title: Speak Up, the Internet Cant Hear You
description: The Internet might have looked very different than it does today. When Marc Andreessen and Eric Bina were building Mosaic, the browser that practically created the Web in 1993, they included the ability to annotate any page. Discussions immediately sprang up. But they quickly realized that the server to host the annotations would have had to scale to enormous size, which was not practical. So they took the feature out.

title: 36 Hours in Taipei, Taiwan
description: Nestled in a river valley and edged by low, tranquil mountains covered in tea shrubs, Taipei is home to 2.6 million people. The cultural and political center of Taiwan, it flaunts its modernity in high-tech company headquarters, an ultraefficient public transportation system and bustling retail centers. Yet it also encompasses teeming street markets, polytheistic temples, recreational green space and other vestiges of ancient traditions reflecting generations of cultural influx from nearby and far-off lands. A haven for insomniacs of all types, Taipei is truly a city that never sleeps, welcoming residents and visitors to brush up on their history, explore their spirituality and, most of all, satisfy their taste buds.

title: Touring Taipei
description: Scenes from the cultural and political center of Taiwan.

title: Creating The Glorious 54th
description: Does it not behoove every colored man, James Henry Gooding, a 26-year-old free black man from New Bedford, Mass., asked the readers of his hometown newspaper in March 1863, to consider  whether he cannot be one of the glorious 54th? New Bedford was a wealthy whaling town with a large abolitionist community, but one where many black citizens toiled in poverty. With such conditions likely in mind, Gooding believed that military service provided the key to African-American advancement. There is more dignity in carrying a musket in defense of liberty and right, he maintained, than there is in shaving a mans face, or waiting on somebodys table.

title: Climbing 100 Famous Japanese Mountains
description: When Akira Chiba reached the top of Mount Yarigatake a dozen years ago and stared out into the volcanic gas clouds that wreathed its peak, it was the realization of what for some is a long-held dream. He had just summited the last of the 100 mountains listed in a popular book by Kyuya Fukada  a goal held by many Japanese mountaineers, including Crown Prince Naruhito. Reaching the marker, though, he was not overcome with elation. He experienced the normal exhilaration of summiting a mountain and a longing for distant peaks, one that he has continued to indulge.

title: Gentle Treatment Yields Fuel Economy Rewards With Hyundai Sonata Hybrid
description: 3:38 p.m. | Updated

title: Window Shopping With a Pop Patriarch
description: Pop Art is basically about two things: ordinariness and eating. Its about daily consumption; the democratic appetite, ravenous for meat, sweets, life on the street, and getting more of everything, cheap. No artist cooked up a tastier version of the primal Pop recipe than Claes Oldenburg did in New York in the late 1950s and early 60s.

title: In Deal, 2 Men Will Be Jailed 30 Days for Beating Cat to Death
description: A father and son who beat a cat to death before leaving his carcass on a Brooklyn street pleaded guilty on Thursday to animal cruelty charges, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Oldenburg at MoMA
description: Claes Oldenburg is the focus of two exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: The Library at the Public
description: Inside the discreet bar and restaurant in the old Astor Library in NoHo.

title: Franco Biondi Santi, Brunello Winemaker, Dies at 91
description: More than 100 years ago, Franco Biondi Santis grandfather virtually invented Brunello di Montalcino, a Tuscan red wine that was little known until late in the 20th century. Since 1888, his family alone has produced it continuously.

title: Does a Streak Portend Playoff Success?
description: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Timess sports blogs.

title: Tracking Hastert Rule Violations in the House
description: In a largely unnoticed vote on Tuesday, the House passed legislation without the support of a majority of Republicans, the fourth time in 2013 that the so-called Hastert Rule was broken by the majority party.

title: Paramount Enters Resorts
description: The hospitality brand of the Paramount Pictures film studio has announced that it is opening its first resort, Damac Towers by Paramount, in Dubai, in 2015. The studio behind classics like Breakfast at Tiffanys (above) announced last year that it would license its name to a Dubai-based investment group for its hotels, which will include private screening rooms and a library of Paramount films. Hotels are also planned for Brazil, Indonesia and other countries.

title: Jay-Z Responds in Song to Critics of Cuba Trip
description: Jay-Z lashed out on Thursday at members of Congress who have raised questions about the legality of his recent trip to Cuba with Beyonc, his wife. He released a scathing rap aimed at those critics and suggested he had been falsely accused of breaking the law because of his friendship with President Obama.

title: Shh! Its Time to Eat
description: It is forever after-hours at the Library at the Public, a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled last fall from the upper recesses of the lobby at the newly renovated Public Theater, reachable by a discreetly bland stairwell. (Look to your left.) The lamps are tepid, verging on gaslight, barely adequate for reading the menu, let alone one of the books lodged at calculated intervals along the walls.

title: The Problem With Investment Banks, as Seen By a Bank
description: LONDON  As Jamie Dimon puts the final touches on JPMorgan Chases latest earnings report, scheduled to be published on Friday, the banks own analysts are raining on his parade.

title: Why Am I Paying All These Taxes?
description: Baby boomers, stand tall! This is our moment.

title: Education Life: Teaching the Techies
description: Data science is the hot new pursuit in higher education, a field spawned by the enormous amounts of data that modern technologies create  be it about the online behavior of Facebook users, tissue samples of cancer patients or crime in cities. Data scientists crunch the data, use mathematical models to analyze it, create narratives or visualizations to explain it, then suggest how to use the information to make decisions.

title: How to Value Bausch & Lomb
description: The mooted value for Bausch & Lomb needs to be re-examined through fresh lenses. The private equity firm Warburg Pincus bought the eye care company for $3.7 billion at the peak of the buyout boom and has been reportedly seeking a valuation of up to $10 billion. Even after cleaning up problems with recalls and accounting, Bausch & Lomb isnt worth a big premium to other similar companies. A figure like $8 billion makes more sense.

title: Market Sweep | Sparkling Watches
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Investigation of 1984 Sikh Massacre Continues in India
description: Laying blame for the 1984 massacre of thousands of Sikhs in India has taken center stage in Delhi again after a court reopened an investigation against the Indian National Congress Party politician Jagdish Tytler.

title: A Start-Up Spirit, Without the 18-Hour Days
description: This interview with  Sabrina Parsons, chief executive of Palo Alto Software, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Jersey Shore, Damaged by Sandy, Is Ready to Run
description: When Joe Gigas, the executive director of the New Jersey Marathon, returned to his home in Long Branch after evacuating for Hurricane Sandy, he found that the ocean had ripped off one side of his house and sucked out the contents of four rooms.

title: Fitting In at the Fitness Center
description: AT 5 feet 3 inches and 203 pounds, Julia Dalton-Brush can attest to the challenge of finding the right exercise environment. A New York makeup artist, Ms. Dalton-Brush recently started a Web site, fit-journey.com, geared to those who are considerably overweight or new to gym workouts.

title: Humble Paella
description: I was once accused by Catalans near Valencia  which is the home of paella  of knowing nothing whatsoever about paella, and of making at best what they called arroz con cosas: rice with things.

title: Hedge Funds Drop Campaign Against T-Mobiles Bid for MetroPCS
description: The most outspoken opponents of T-Mobile USAs bid for MetroPCS are backing off following an improvement in the takeover offers terms.

title: Nearly 400 People Detained in Immigration Raid in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Russian security services and immigration police raided a market in the center of St. Petersburg on Thursday and detained 378 people, many of them migrants from Central Asia and the mainly Muslim North Caucasus.

title: Court Rules for Women in Western Wall Dispute
description: JERUSALEM  In the latest twist in the struggle for the character of the Western Wall, a magistrates court here ruled on Thursday that five women who had been detained at the Jewish holy site that morning for wearing prayer shawls and singing aloud were not disturbing public order, as the police had asserted.

title: Celebrating for Longer Than 15 Minutes
description: Andy Warhol said that an artist is somebody who produces things that people dont need to have. He also said that good business is the best art. Both ideas were in play Monday night at the New York Academy of Art, the graduate school he helped found in 1982. For its annual Tribeca Ball, about 800 guests stormed the schools five floors, throwing down Champagne and opinions about the work of 110 students on display.

title: Labor Board Complaining Over Cablevisions Tactics
description: The battle between Cablevision and organized labor has dragged on for months, punctuated by protests and lawsuits, in a feud that has been particularly nasty even by most labor-management standards. Now the National Labor Relations Board has accused the company of acting illegally to avoid reaching an agreement with several hundred unionized cable installers in Brooklyn.

title: Julia Sweeney Sees the Absurd in Motherhood (and Shares)
description: Within pages of opening If Its Not One Thing, Its Your Mother by Julia Sweeney (familiar to me, and many, as a former star of Saturday Night Live and the creator of the one-woman show and memoir God Said Ha!), I felt like Id made a new friend  a funny, wry, so-cool-she-doesnt-care-about-being-cool fellow parent with a voice I loved. I asked Julia for permission to share some of the book (its below) and I also asked her (among other things) what its like to see the world through her eyes.

title: Scheduled to Play the Twins, the Mets Face Snow Instead
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Dont get the Minnesota Twins president, Dave St. Peter, started on the decision to build an open-air stadium in a city known for its brutal winters and fickle springs. The Twins benefited from favorable April weather in their first three seasons at Target Field, but St. Peter figured they were due for a problem.

title: Russia Skips Hybrids in Push for Cars Using Natural Gas
description: MOSCOW  Igor A. Samarsky of the southern Russian city of Krasnodar gets fuel economy on his 1998 Lada sedan that would make a Prius owner green with environmental envy.

title: New Yorkers Brace for Cuts in Unemployment Benefits
description: Federal benefits for New Yorkers who have been unemployed for more than six months have been gradually disappearing. Now, the ones that remain are shrinking.

title: Handling Nerves, Lynn Enjoys Strong First Round
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Minutes after his four-under par 68 made him the clubhouse leader, David Lynn said his runner-up finish at last years P.G.A. Championship helped him avoid any nervousness in his first Masters on Thursday.

title: Lincoln Scribbled Here: Strokes That Fascinate
description: NOT everybody gets it. For some people old documents, however historical, are little more than humdrum records, created to be filed for reference and cited when necessary, the documentary backdrop of grander happenings, with signatures that do no more than guarantee their authenticity. And for those with that point of view, autographed items other than formal documents  say, the back of an envelope  are merely fetishistic totems, and perhaps a little silly.

title: Getting Personal: Writing College Essays for the Common Application
Environmental Readings at Poets House
description: The Miser has never known quite what to make of W. H. Audens assertion in his poem In Memory of W. B. Yeats that poetry makes nothing happen. Did he really hold so radically modest a view of arts potential? Or was he being slyly ironic, daring us to doubt such seemingly hopeless pronouncements?

title: Officially, Theres Now No Chance of Hurricane Sandy Returning
description: There will never again be a Hurricane Sandy.

title: When Independence Means Youre on Your Own
description: In late February, Lorraine Bayless, 87, died at a California independent living facility after an employee declined to provide CPR  for more than seven minutes, even as a 911 dispatcher pleaded with her to intervene. The incident was the subject of enormous public outcry and generated widespread criticism of the facility. But it also raises important legal questions relevant to older adults and families living in similar settings.

title: Alcohol and Breast Cancer Survival
description: Alcohol consumption is known to increase the risk for breast cancer. But a new study suggests that moderate drinking has little effect on survival after diagnosis, and may reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease.

title: Director Named for New Dance School at University of Southern California
description: Jodie Gates, a dancer, choreographer and educator who is a former principal dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, has been named vice dean and director of the new Glorya Kaufman School of Dance at the University of Southern California. Ms. Gates is currently a professor of dance at the University of California, Irvine, and is the founder and artistic director of the Laguna Dance Festival in Laguna Beach, Calif. In addition to the Joffrey, she has been a principal ballerina with the Frankfurt Ballet, the Pennsylvania Ballet and other major companies. Ms. Gates will begin her position in August at the school of dance. The school was established in November 2012 by a gift from Glorya Kaufman, a philanthropist and dance patron.

title: Clip: Kon-Tiki (Norwegian Language)
description: A scene from the Norwegian language version of Kon-Tiki, with English subtitles.

title: Knicks to Waive Injured Thomas
description: CHICAGO  The history of the Knicks transformative winning streak cannot be written without Kurt Thomas, although the conclusion to this breakthrough season most certainly will be.

title: New Concerns From Germany Over European Banking Supervisor
description: DUBLIN  Germany has raised new concerns about a proposal to create a single banking supervisor for the European Union that could delay plans to help troubled lenders that finance ministers were to discuss here on Friday.

title: Never Mind Facebook; Winklevoss Twins Rule in Digital Money
description: The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler  Olympic rowers, nemeses of Mark Zuckerberg  are laying claim to a new title: bitcoin moguls.

title: Wines Leading Man Sets Down His Glass
description: To watch Jacques Lardire scoot about the cellar at the headquarters of Louis Jadot in Beaune, France, the crossroads of Burgundy, is to see a man in his element. With white hair cascading from his head like a puffy cumulus cloud, red pants the likes of which only a Frenchman could even think of carrying off, twinkling eyes magnified by spectacles and an ever-present smile, Mr. Lardire is a cross between a wizard and an elf, climbing over barrels and digging deeper into Jadots rich Burgundian holdings in a determined effort to explain the wondrous mysteries that keep Burgundy lovers so everlastingly entranced.

title: How to Write a College Application Essay
description: Our friends at The Learning Network blog have just published a lesson plan devoted to helping students prepare their essays for the Common Application, which recently released new essay prompts for the 2013-14 admission season.

title: Canadian Teenagers Suicide Ignites Calls for Review of Rape Case
description: The recent suicide of a Canadian teenager has revived outrage that the authorities did not do enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011 and bullied after photographs of the assault were shared and posted online.

title: Having Mom Do Your Laundry, to Save Money
description: When I was in high school, I visited France on an exchange program and stayed with a well-to-do family. When I returned home, I marveled that the household employed a maid who washed my clothes. My mother rolled her eyes. You have a maid here who does your laundry, she said. Me!

title: Hong Kong Operator Makes Bid for Telecom Italia
description: BERLIN  Telecom Italia on Thursday said it would formally consider an offer to merge with a smaller rival in a deal that would make the Hong Kong industrial group Hutchison Whampoa its largest shareholder.

title: Clip: 'Kon Tiki' (English Language)
description: A scene from the English language version of "Kon-Tiki."

title: Heres Hoping Understudies Arent Needed
description: Bang! Bang! The sound of artificial gunfire is not unheard-of at the theater. But the shots fired in Bullet Catch, a magic show written, directed and performed by Rob Drummond, are more unsettling than most. They come from what is presented as a real handgun, and while one shot is fired at a porcelain plate, the second is aimed straight at Mr. Drummonds head, as a volunteer from the audience, wearing ear protectors and goggles, faces him from several feet away  as if participating in a one-sided duel.

title: Keeping Score: Changing Coaches Changed Nets Late in Games
description: On Dec. 26 the Brooklyn Nets lost to the Milwaukee Bucks, their 10th loss in 13 games after a franchise-best 11-4 start.

title: Cracking the Mystery of Here to There
description: WASHINGTON  If you successfully navigate to the coordinates posted at the entrance  38 degrees 53 minutes 18 seconds north latitude and 77 degrees 1 minute 8 seconds west longitude  you will find yourself at the new permanent exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum, Time and Navigation: The Untold Story of Getting From Here to There. And if you then make your way through the 5,000 square feet devoted to this show, most of which is superbly executed, you will realize just how astounding that initial feat was: to journey to a particular spot on the globe, consulting, perhaps, no more than a pocket-size smartphone, without risk of loss of life.

title: New Yorks Longest-Serving Pastor Dies at 93
description: Msgr. Gerald Ryan, who began working as a priest in the Bronx in 1945 and went on to become the longest-serving pastor in New York and probably the country, died on Thursday at Our Lady of Consolation, a residence for ill priests, in Riverdale. He was 93.

title: Tuck Everlasting Cant Find a Parking Spot on Broadway
description: With luck, audiences wont have to live forever to see a musical adaptation of Tuck Everlasting hit Broadway, but they are going to have to wait a little longer for it. The producers of a new musical based on that Natalie Babbitt childrens novel, about a girl who meets a boy from a family of immortals, said that its planned world premiere in Boston would be delayed because there were no theaters in New York where the musical could transfer.

title: Paris Judge to Rule Friday on Hopi Artifact Sale
description: A French civil court judge heard arguments for two hours Thursday and said she will rule Friday on whether a major auction of sacred Hopi Indian artifacts can go forward in Paris despite claims by the tribe that they were stolen and that selling them is sacrilegious.

title: Citigroups Washington Push
description: Citigroups chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, understands Washingtons importance.

title: The Price of Gold (and Ron Paul)
description: The price of gold, The New York Times reported today, has fallen 17 percent since late 2011. Just on Wednesday, the price of bullion dropped $28, to $1,558 an ounce. Gold-focused mutual funds, which reached a peak value of $26.3 billion in April of 2011, have lost half of their value since then.

title: Joshua Marsh As If
description: Jeff Bailey Gallery

title: Mary Lucier: New Installation Works
description: Lennon, Weinberg

title: Senate Republicans Describe Cordial, if Not Convincing, Dinner With Obama
description: President Obama threw his second dinner party of the year for Republican senators Wednesday night, but if the first such venture in March yielded a few rounds of Kumbaya, the second was apparently more Hit the Road Jack.

title: Faith Ringgolds America: Early Works and Story Quilts
description: ACA Galleries

title: Agus Suwage: Cycle No. 2
description: Tyler Rollins Fine Art

title: Jon Kessler: The Web
description: Swiss Institute

title: Khalil Rabah: Pages, 7, 8, 9
description: e-flux

title: The Roger Vivier Legacy
description: Last night Dr. Valerie Steele, the director of the Museum at F.I.T., moderated a discussion with the Roger Vivier creative director Bruno Frisoni and the Vivier brand ambassador Ins de la Fressange to talk about the release of a vibrant new coffee table book on the history of the storied French shoe label. Images from the new tome informed the talk, which took place in the Katie Murphy Amphitheatre.

title: Google Introduces a Tool for Planning for Your Digital Afterlife
description: One of the most haunting questions facing Web companies and their users is, what happens to the stuff of our digital lives after we die?

title: Bangladesh Police Arrest Acting Editor of Pro-Opposition Paper
description: CHITTAGONG, Bangladesh  The police in Bangladesh arrested the acting editor of a pro-opposition newspaper on Thursday amid strikes by opposition forces that have frozen travel in much of the country and that are crippling its economy.

title: U.S. Embassy in Turkey Said to Be Targeted
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish police said Thursday that they had found evidence of a plot linked to Al Qaeda to bomb the United States Embassy in Ankara, a synagogue in Istanbul and other targets, from a raid on two houses in February, according to news reports.

title: Murals on the Bowery, Organized by Art Production Fund
description: ROLLDOWN STEEL MURALS

title: Wheelies: The Top-Selling Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Republican Effort to Unpack the Court
description: Liberals are tearing into a Republican plan to reduce the number of judges on the countrys most important appeals court, calling it a political ploy to keep President Obama from making the court less conservative.

title: Ex-KPMG Partner Is Charged in Insider Case
description: 11:05 p.m. | Updated

title: Romney Visits New York to Thank Donors
description: Since losing the 2012 presidential election, Mitt Romney has pumped his own gas (with wind-tousled hair), navigated Costco with his wife, Ann (stocking up on everything from bottled water to paper towels) and welcomed grandchildren 19 and 20 (twins, from his youngest son, Craig).

title: Aiding Sobriety, a Chord at a Time
description: ITS about 1,700 miles from Madison Square Garden to Willoughby Bay in Antigua, and it is hard to imagine two places more different than the grimy canyons of Midtown Manhattan and the pristine, windswept hills overlooking the Caribbean that are home to the Crossroads Center drug rehabilitation clinic.

title: To Catch a Killer Nurse
description: In 2003, the world discovered what a night nurse named Charles Cullen had been doing during the preceding 16 years. He had killed a judge, a priest and an unknown but large number of other people. He may have been the most prolific serial killer in history.

title: A Presidents Death, Recalled in Artifacts
description: A PRESIDENTS DEATH,

title: What God Wants
description: Yeeeah, Sydney! the songwriter and comedian Tim Minchin shouts into a microphone. Are you up for a . . . sing?

title: Voices Inside Their Heads
description: Mohsin Hamids latest novel boasts a startlingly distinctive voice, as commanding and unadorned as its title, How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia. But what may be most exciting about that voice  the whole book is delivered in the terse declarations of a mock self-help manual  is that its nothing like the voices we met in his two earlier novels. The first, Moth Smoke, was a moody, multipart evocation of party kids and S.U.V.s in Lahore, poetically given life by Hamid as if to the manner born; his second, The Reluctant Fundamentalist, was a fast-moving monologue from a young Pakistani, educated at Princeton and once well employed in New York (as Hamid was), whos returned to his homeland post-9/11 and lures a Daniel Pearl-like American into a confrontation.

title: Up Front
description: Dan Savage, who reviews Jeff Chus Does Jesus Really Love Me? this week, is perhaps best known for his syndicated column, Savage Love. The column first appeared in The Stranger, a Seattle weekly newspaper, in 1991, and is now published worldwide  quite an accomplishment for something that began as a joke. A gay guy giving advice to straight people about straight sex? as Savage put it in an e-mail. The plan  the joke  was that I was treating straight relationships and straight sex with the same contempt that straight advice columnists had always treated gay sex and gay relationships. I thought I could stretch the joke out for six months at most. But the column took off. It turned out that straight people really enjoyed being treated with contempt  it was a new experience for them. Twenty-plus years later, Im still writing the column.

title: Paperback Row
description: AEROGRAMMES: And Other Stories,  by Tania James. (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Jamess 2009 debut novel, Atlas of Unknowns, followed the divergent lives of two motherless sisters from Kerala, India. Her first story collection displays a similar warmhearted lyricism, as eclectic characters  a chimpanzee, a ghost, two Indian wrestlers in Edwardian London  are entangled in sticky human relationships.

title: Editors Choice
description: BETWEEN MAN AND BEAST: An Unlikely Explorer, the Evolution Debates, and the African Adventure That Took the Victorian World by Storm,  by Monte Reel. (Doubleday, $26.95.) In the age of Darwin, the discovery of gorillas caused a sensation.

title: Inside the List
description: THE LAST KEY: Paulo Coelho, the elfin guru of a novelist who unleashed The Alchemist on the world, is at No. 2 on this weeks hardcover list with a new novel, Manuscript Found in Accra  although a more forthright title might be Manuscript Found on Social Media, since Coelho assembled the book after soliciting ideas from his 6.3 million Twitter followers. The resulting volume of ponderous clichs will surprise nobody familiar with Coelho, or Twitter.

title: Hope Springs Eternal
description: When my oldest son was 3 and something didnt go quite the way he had envisioned, he would lament: I want to go back! I want to go back! Surely, one of the hardest jobs of childhood is accepting that life moves forward and when something terrible happens, it cannot be undone with either words or wishes. Two new middle-grade fantasy novels feature children on the verge of adolescence who want very much to change the course of life events, and who learn its never as simple as it may seem.

title: The Bad Guys
description: Anyone who knows children knows they are not timid when it comes to pondering ethical conundrums. Rather, as their routine cry of No fair! proves, they live for it.

title: Her Town
description: Grandparents often appear in childrens literature just so they can be taken away. At times, death provides a largely unearned teachable moment, while at others it conjures a powerful approximation of grief. Linda Urbans new novel, The Center of Everything, uses the premise of a grandparents death in a surprising way, exploring not only grief but also its occasional companions, anxiety and guilt.

title: Get Back
description: All successful novels for young adults must pass what one might call a narcissistic grandiosity test. Adolescents are, of course, at a developmental stage in which a certain level of passionate self-involvement is the norm. This is both natural and necessary. Good young adult novels must therefore reflect and dramatize the readers fantasy of being victimized and misunderstood, yet secretly possessed of powers that allow mastery of ones destiny. Consequently, the characters in Y.A. fiction tend to live in special worlds, somehow set apart from those of other people. Often, theyre either escaping from or saving their parents; if they discover a way to do both simultaneously, even better.

title: The Back Story
description: On a list of my top reading interests, the lives of kooky geezers in a fading English village dont rank high. But all it takes is a page or two of Jane Gardam to force a reconsideration. Her prose is so perceptive and fluid that it feels mentally healthful, exiling the noise and clutter of your mind as efficiently as a Schubert sonata. She could make actuarial tables pleasurable.

title: The Road to Salvation
description: A car crashes into a chickasaw plum tree in the Oklahoma panhandle, two sisters in the back seat strapped together at the wrist. Four days behind them, in Idaho, lies a remote fundamentalist compound where their father governed 50 wives. Yes, 50. Yes, he bedded them all.

title: Grave New World
description: Natural calamity has long occupied a central role in our stories; theres a pretty good one about a guy escaping a flood with some animals on a boat. After this past fall, expect several more, with Nathaniel Rich and his intelligent, exhaustively researched second novel, Odds Against Tomorrow, at the vanguard of post-Sandy catastrophe lit.

title: Bookshelf: For the Birds
description: New picture books starring a pair of goslings, animated chickens, lucky ducklings, and a boy and his bluebird.

title: Hearts Desire
description: Carol Ann Duffy, the British poet laureate, is almost unknown in this country, which makes her no worse off than blood pudding, haggis or Marmite. Britain and America are no longer divided by a common tongue  for 50 years or more, we have been listening to British music, watching British television and welcoming British writers as warmly as we once welcomed Dickens. Still, most poets dont travel well; apart from an oddity like Seamus Heaney or Derek Walcott, poets are rarely known outside their home countries (worse, theyre rarely known outside their hometowns).

title: Poetry Chronicle
description: WOMENS POETRY  Poems and Advice.  By Daisy Fried.  University of Pittsburgh, paper, $15.95.

title: Unreliable Sources
description: Michael Hainey wanted to be like his father. Since his father died when he had just turned 6, he had to base his model less on memory than on myth. His father was a Chicago newspaperman, and so Hainey romanticized the bygone world of Chicago newspapermen. He venerated good reporting. He drank Scotch on the rocks. He sensed secrets in his childhood home. His mother told him his father had died of a heart attack. I had to pry this out of her, Hainey writes in After Visiting Friends. She was vague about the circumstances. All my life, he says, Ive felt the story I was told about how my father died did not add up. An obituary mentioned that his father had been visiting friends: who? It also mentioned a strange address: where had his father gone, and why? So Hainey looked for answers.

title: A Knowing Eye
description: We know the photograph. A seated woman  hand at her jaw, skin etched with worry  looks into the middle distance. Children rest their heads on her shoulders, faces turned away; an infant lies bundled in her lap. By capturing the plight of Californias Depression-era migrant workers, Dorothea Langes Migrant Mother transformed a nations attitudes toward the poor from the moment of its publication in 1936. Today, its immediacy dulled by time and fame, it functions mainly as a visual metonym for the Great Depression. We look at it, but we no longer see it, to borrow a distinction made in Marisa Silvers phenomenal new novel, Mary Coin.

title: Bookshelf: For the Birds
description: JASPER & JOOP  A Perfect Pair: One Tidy, One Messy.  Written and illustrated by Olivier Dunrea.32 pp. Houghton Mifflin. $9.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7)

title: Pentagon Finds Nuclear Strides by North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  A new assessment by the Pentagons intelligence arm has concluded for the first time, with moderate confidence, that North Korea has learned how to make a nuclear weapon small enough to be delivered by a ballistic missile.

title: Playing at Tribeca
description: A look at some of the offerings in the 12th Tribeca Film Festival, which runs from April 17-28.

title: Twelve, Imprint of Grand Central, Names Publisher
description: Twelve, the boutique imprint of Grand Central Publishing known for releasing only one carefully selected book each month, has named its editor in chief, Deb Futter, as publisher.

title: Bitcoin Has Real-World Investors
description: The Timess Nathaniel Popper discusses Bitcoin, the online currency that has attracted a number of investors, including Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss.

title: Neo-Nazis Organizing in Prisons in Germany
description: BERLIN  They called themselves the A.D. Jail Crew and sought to band together brothers and sisters in prisons across Germany to defend loyalty, comradeship and the old values. Their aim, according to an advertisement found by the authorities who broke up the network, was to provide support for neo-Nazis serving time behind bars.

title: A New Generation Dives In to Learn the Old Language
description: Founded in 1969 to dispel the myth that blacks couldnt dance classical ballet, Dance Theater of Harlem toured internationally for decades as a shining symbol that they could. For decades there were also administrative and financial troubles, and in 2004, mounting debts forced the troupe to go on hiatus. Now it has returned, and on Wednesday at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center the nervousness was palpable. Everyone wants this company to succeed.

title: In Push for Gender Equality, Breaking Down the Boardroom Door
description: Beth A. Stewart doesnt mind making waves.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Washington, D.C., Sri Lanka, Russia and Syria.

title: How Herbalife Was Drawn Into KPMG Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Herbalife wasnt knowingly involved the insider trading scheme that revolved around a now-former KPMG partner. But the nutritional supplements company still played a major role all the same.

title: Freedom From High Society in the Sunny Outdoors
description: Shortly after the turn of the 20th century John Singer Sargent went through a midlife crisis. An American expatriate in London, he was sick of painting flattering portraits of rich people, though he could do it with such seemingly effortless panache that hed become one of Englands most celebrated artists. He began to retire from that lucrative but repetitious occupation.

title: Where the Spies Are: A Training Camp for Automotive Paparazzi
description: Brenda Priddy, an auto spy photographer, is starting a camp for people who dream of joining the ranks of car paparazzi. Starting on July 7, Ms. Priddy will lead would-be car spies through the basics of her craft in a four-day camp in the Nevada desert.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 3
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: Ellen Pao, Who Sued Kleiner Perkins, Joins Reddit
description: You still cant ask Ellen Pao anything. But Reddit announced Thursday that the former venture capitalist will now be working with the social networking site, home of the popular Ask Me Anything chats.

title: Now Thats What We Call a Softball Jersey
description: Avid followers of The New York Times Magazine softball team may remember that last years season was, by standard measures, not exactly a winning one. (Definitions of win have been known to vary.) But this year we have already scored a victory with our new jerseys, designed by Christoph Niemann, possibly while he was was running a marathon. Judging by T-shirt sales alone, it appears that our roster this year has tripled in size  although numbers were slightly skewed by Lauren (The Killer Within) Kern, who purchased two for herself, despite concerns that our outfielders will blend in with the grass.

title: TimesCast: Bitcoin Has Real-World Investors
description: The Timess Nathaniel Popper discusses Bitcoin, the online currency that has attracted a number of investors, including Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss.

title: Horror at Every Turn of a Dark Cyberjungle
description: The jittery characters who scuttle through the three stories that make up Disconnect are struggling to make their way through todays treacherous cyberwilderness. Some are predators, others prey. Nave travelers who venture into territory taken over by upstart tribes of technological outlaws risk being ambushed, fleeced and humiliated. Law enforcement is often helpless to catch up with tricksters adept at staying ahead of the game.

title: A Detached Look at Pop Art From Post-Fascist Italy
description: Giosetta Fioroni: LArgento proves that the field of postwar Italian art, though crowded at the moment, is far from exhausted. This show at the Drawing Center complements recent gallery exhibitions of Lucio Fontana, Piero Manzoni, Giorgio Griffa, Gianni Colombo and Luigi Ghirri, not to mention museum surveys of Michelangelo Pistoletto and Alighiero Boetti, introducing us to the only female member of the School of the Piazza del Popolo (named for a popular Roman artists hangout).

title: A Temperament for Trouble and a Nose for Fine Whisky
description: The Angels Share, the twinkly title of Ken Loachs new comedy, is slang for the roughly 2 percent of malt whisky that evaporates while it ages in a cask.

title: Bully Wallpaper and a Ceiling Lost in Space
description: The great halls of Grand Central, the American Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art each present different painted faces: Grand Central has a swath of the heavens at nighttime, redone 15 years ago; the natural history museum has murals of the life of Theodore Roosevelt, restored last fall; and the Metropolitan Museum, well ... where are the murals, anyway?

title: Comedy Listings for April 12-18
description: Comedy

title: Movie Listings for April 12-18
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for April 12-18
description: Pop

title: That Rookie at First Is in a New Position
description: Biographies of great athletes can be roughly sorted into three categories. There are hero-worshiping fables suitable for fourth-grade classrooms, scandalous feet-of-clay exposs and, rarest of all, narratives that link sports with significant, nonathletic historical events and social issues. In America those events and issues almost always have to do with race, which makes the life of Jackie Robinson especially ripe for sweeping, comprehensive treatment.

title: Reebok Drops Rick Ross After Protest Over Lyrics
description: Reebok cut its ties with the Miami rapper Rick Ross on Thursday because of a controversial track in which he boasted about drugging and raping a woman.

title: Jazz Listings for April 12-18
description: Jazz

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for April 12-18
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for April 12-18
description: Dance

title: Outsider Art in Philadelphia
description: Jill and Sheldon Bonovitz plan to bestow their collection of 20th-century American outsider art to the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Theater Listings for April 12-18
description: Theater

title: No More on the Outside Looking In
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jill and Sheldon Bonovitz are doing a great thing for the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and for the rest of us too. They are planning to bestow upon it their beloved, finely calibrated collection of 20th-century American outsider art.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 12-18
description: Art

title: The He-Man Who Gave Mona Lisa That Smile
description: Da Vincis Demons proposes a new definition of Renaissance man. Painting, drawing and inventing are no longer sufficient. To be the hero of a 21st-century pay-cable historical drama, Leonardo must also fight like a mixed-martial-arts star, bed the bosss mistress (the boss being Lorenzo de Medici) and solve crimes like a combination of Sherlock Holmes and Gil Grissom from CSI.

title: Take the Long View
description: During a job review, my boss told me I was in line for promotion when my supervisor moved up. Well, my supervisor left. But the boss promoted a woman who joined the company after me rather than giving me the job as promised. He said this woman will make a better manager than I would. (Im a man.) I think this is reverse-sexism, but Im not sure what to do about it. Talk to human resources, my bosss boss or just eat it? J. D.

title: Spare Times for Children for April 12-18
description: BEAUTY AND THE BEAST

title: Deficit Reduction, Minus the Reduction
description: President Obamas new budget, released on Wednesday, is stuffed with constructive ideas. It bravely outlines concrete steps to begin fixing Social Security. It flouts todays all-deficit-cutting, all-the-time mentality with important proposals for fresh spending on infrastructure and universal prekindergarten education. It includes detailed plans to close tax loopholes and raise needed revenues from the wealthy.

title: B.J. Novak, Actor and Writer, Signs Two-Book Deal
description: The comedian, actor and writer B.J. Novak has sold two books to Knopf in a seven-figure deal. The first book, a work of fiction, is expected to be published in 2014, Nicholas Latimer, a spokesman for Knopf, said Thursday.

title: Spare Times for April 12-18
description: Passages Through the Fire: Jews and the Civil War (through Aug. 11) It was not uncommon during the Civil War for family members to take opposing sides. Of the five sons of Abraham Jonas, who served as postmaster general of Quincy, Ill., and his wife, Louisa, four sided with the Confederacy  though one brother later became a Union soldier. The only one supporting the Union from the start was the youngest, Edward Jonas, above right, in an undated image.

title: Despite the Losses, So Much Gained
description: Dude was a doctor who wanted to leave medicine. We met almost 20 years ago, when he applied to a writing fellowship program at the movie studio where I was an executive.

title: Autographs Are Far Less of a Mess
description: The wormy apple doesnt fall far from the rotting tree. In saying that, I dont mean to cast aspersions on the Cronenberg family bloodline but only to point out that in his first feature, Antiviral, the 33-year-old Brandon Cronenberg exhibits the same obsession with mutilation and infection as his father, David, did in movies like Crash and The Fly.

title: Eyeing That Empty Seat
description: Arcadia opens at dusk with four people slipping out of a house like thieves. As soon as they climb into the car it becomes evident that the man and the three children with him are related. Yet when one of the kids, 12-year-old Greta (Ryan Simpkins), pauses to look at some family photographs, the air stirs. Something has happened here, but it takes time  along with many miles, a few fights, some misunderstandings and a young awakening  to know what.

title: A Festival Now Comfortable in Its Skin
description: In any life there are moments of acute awareness when you suddenly realize the degree to which youve grown up. The Tribeca Film Festival, which begins its 12th season on Wednesday, is experiencing such a flash.

title: Is It Art, or Is It Just Real Estate?
description: In the world of high-end real estate, the importance of art is surfacing in more ways than one as a theme in new condo developments.

title: The Apocalypse, for Laughs
description: It may be the end of the world, but they feel fine, even oblivious. That, at any rate, appears to be the principal, really the only point of the impishly, unfortunately titled Its a Disaster, an underbaked comedy about eight people facing their mortality. Set in the present, it mostly unfolds in a Los Angeles house within gasping distance of a large-scale catastrophe of the kind usually let loose by masters of disaster, like Roland Emmerich. The writer and director, Todd Berger, is working on a far smaller scale than his blockbuster brethren do, and that may explain why he keeps calamitous details fuzzy, using two corpses, a Hazmat suit and a murder of crows to suggest the apocalyptic big picture.

title: Emirates Laws Trap a Doctor Just Passing Through
description: JOHANNESBURG  For Dr. Cyril Karabus, it was a routine job, albeit in an exotic location. For six weeks in 2002, he filled in for another doctor in Abu Dhabi, lured like many other foreign professionals by the big paychecks that doctors, bankers, lawyers and architects can earn in the United Arab Emirates and other Persian Gulf nations.

title: Settlement to Benefit Borrowers
description: Banks and mortgage servicers often impose what is known as force- or lender-placed insurance on borrowers who allow their homeowners insurance to lapse. But a state investigation, and a resulting settlement, could rein in the outsize premiums that come with these policies, which are typically 2 to 10 times higher than standard plans, even though their coverage is more limited.

title: Acceptance Rates, Apparently, Are Poor Predictors of Getting In
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student from New Delhi, is part of The Choice class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her ninth post is below.  Tanya Abrams

title: All Over the Map in the Redistricting Fray
description: Greg Abbott is selling a redistricting nostrum, telling Texas legislators they could cut their legal risks by adopting new political maps right away.

title: Championing Women, a New League for Club Boxing Enters the Ring
description: After more than 40 years in boxing as a trainer and historian, Angelo Merino witnessed two moments at last summers London Olympics that he said validated his dedication to pumping new life into college boxing.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Penney Enlists Blackstone to Help It Raise Money
description: 10:48 p.m. | Updated

title: Texas House Bill Proposes Dropping Algebra II From Diploma Standards
description: As Texas re-examines what students must learn to earn a high school diploma, a single math course has attracted more attention than any other part of the states curriculum.

title: Oils Financial Ties to Texas Legislators
description: During a legislative hearing this year related to hydraulic fracturing, Representative James L. Keffer, Republican of Eastland, made a reference to what he thought was an unfair portrayal of the industry in the film Promised Land.

title: France: Chief Rabbi Steps Down Over Plagiarism
description: The chief rabbi of France, Gilles Bernheim, stepped down Thursday after admitting to plagiarism in at least two of his books and lying about his academic credentials.

title: Hearing in Cole Attack Is Delayed Again, This Time by E-mail Security Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Problems with defense lawyers e-mails and computer files prompted a military commission judge on Thursday to postpone a pretrial hearing that had been scheduled for next week in the case of a Guantnamo Bay detainee accused of helping to plot the 2000 bombing of the destroyer Cole.

title: Tech Firms Push to Hire More Workers From Abroad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Vishal Sankhla, an Indian engineer, is among those at the center of a storm over how to fix the nations immigration system.

title: A Plot Twist at Herbalife Draws in the Auditors
description: Herbalife, which describes itself as a global nutrition company, and which critics deride as a purveyor of overpriced products that is really a pyramid scheme preying on nave people with dreams of easy wealth, has already provided one of the best stock market dramas in years. Now, through no fault of its own, it could become a catalyst for change in the auditing profession.

title: This Weeks Movies | April 12, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on To the Wonder, 42 and Its a Disaster.

title: A Busy California Port Seeks to Grow, but a Neighbor Objects
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  Just before officials at the Port of Los Angeles unanimously approved a plan for a vast new railyard last month, the mayor of Long Beach was incensed. How dare they, he angrily asked at a public meeting, value the lives of residents on Los Angeless side of the border more than those who live in his city.

title: Bike Tour Wins Lawsuit Over City Fees
description: In a setback to efforts to defray the policing costs of large athletic events in New York City, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled on Thursday that a nonprofit bicycling group would not have to pay nearly $1 million to close roads during its citywide tour next month.

title: Rebel Keeps Kurds Guns Close at Hand in Peace Talks With Turkey
description: ZARGALI, Iraq  In a safe house made of cinder blocks and surrounded by grazing goats and sheep, nestled high in the remote mountains of northern Iraq, a Kurdish fighter who has waged a guerrilla war against Turkey for nearly three decades remains defiant in the face of peace.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Off Broadway Boutique
description: Chief among the attractions of the shop is the owner Lynn Dell Cohen, known to patrons as the Countess of Glamour.

title: U.S. Justice Dept. Releases Judges Ruling on Ex-Salvadoran General
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has released a United States immigration judges ruling ordering the deportation of a former high-ranking Salvadoran military officer over his role in the 1980 rape and murder of four American churchwomen and other crimes there.

title: Herbalife Ties to Work From Home Promoters May Draw New Scrutiny
description: Entities that promote work from home opportunities could be a new source of scrutiny for Herbalife, the nutritional products company that has become the subject of a pitched battle on Wall Street.

title: U.S. Blacklists an Iranian and His Businesses Over Violation of Sanctions
description: The United States blacklisted an affluent Iranian business executive and what it described as his multibillion-dollar money-laundering network on Thursday, accusing them of selling oil for Iran in violation of the Western economic sanctions imposed over Irans disputed nuclear program.

title: Save Wounded Knee
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D.

title: Impressive 73 for 14-Year-Old
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Before the Chinese amateur Guan Tianlang hit his first competitive shot at Augusta National Golf Club, everybody with whom he crossed paths offered glowing assessments of his game, each compliment piling up until a great wall of expectations had been constructed around his Masters debut.

title: Tell the Truth About the Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON

title: That Dastardly Computer Gave My Essay a D!
description: To the Editor:

title: Bold on Both Ends
description: Its time to entertain the possibility that President Obama is a right-wing extremist. After all, look at where hes taking the country over his second term.

title: An Americans Long March With Mao
description: Sidney Rittenberg wanted to be a revolutionary. So when the United States Army sent him to China just after World War II, he stayed on and joined the Communist Party, becoming a privileged insider, a rare foreigner among the party elite. He helped promote the Cultural Revolution, speaking at rallies all over China. And he was imprisoned, twice, spending almost 16 years in solitary confinement. (The first time, the authorities offered to release him if he returned to the United States, but he chose to remain in prison to prove his loyalty to the revolution.)

title: Sequestration of Justice
description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith is a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden and a former spokesman for Al Qaeda. He is accused of providing material support for terrorism, and, as the federal indictment against him charges, conspiring to murder United States nationals anywhere in the world.

title: Brain Disease and the N.F.L.
description: More than 4,000 retired players are suing the National Football League for failing to protect players from chronic risks of head injuries routinely inflicted in professional football games  and then willfully concealing those risks from players. In a brief summarizing the players position, lawyers say that serious head injuries cause neurocognitive decline, permanent mental disability, and even death.

title: Retreat at the Post Office
description: Any doubt about the Postal Services status as Congressional chattel was dashed Wednesday when postal officials had to retreat from their bold plan to cut most Saturday deliveries as part of a plan to save $2 billion a year for the deficit-ridden agency.

title: Baseball Pays for Clinic Documents Tied to Doping Case
description: Major League Baseballs investigation of an anti-aging clinic linked to performance-enhancing drugs has taken a new turn, with the commissioners office paying a former employee of the facility for documents related to the case. At the same time, two people briefed on the matter said, at least one player linked to the clinic has purchased documents from a former clinic employee in order to destroy them.

title: The Rugged Road for Gun Control
description: As families of the victims of the Newtown, Conn., massacre watched from the Senate gallery on Thursday, 68 senators, including 16 Republicans, voted to break a conservative filibuster to allow debate to begin on a bill that would expand background checks for most gun sales.

title: Lust for Gold
description: News flash: Recent declines in the price of gold, which is off about 17 percent from its peak, show that this price can go down as well as up. You may consider this an obvious point, but, as an article in The Times on Thursday reports, it has come as a rude shock to many small gold investors, who imagined that they were buying the safest of all assets.

title: Dressing for the Theater of Life
description: Once you get past the plumage displayed in the front window and the wall of signed photographs of stage and screen goddesses, the first thing you notice inside the Off Broadway Boutique is a circular table draped with gold lam, piled high with thick, red candles and guarded by a large vase of golden peacock feathers.

title: Two Lives Linked by Murder, Coincidence and Reconciliation
description: From across the prison visiting room on that afternoon in September 2006, Anthony Coln noticed the broad man in the glasses, an inmate assigned to take pictures. Mr. Coln, a restaurant manager, was there to visit an old friend who was doing time. He had not expected to see the man in the glasses, Michael Rowe.

title: Global Tax Dodge or Economic Boon?
Islands, and Now a Funeral, Strain Argentine-British Ties
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Argentina and Britain, whose ties were already strained over their rival claims of sovereignty over the Falkland Islands, now seem to be having trouble getting along when it comes to a funeral.

title: Obamas Budget, Followed by Cries of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chat With a Liberal Gun Enthusiast
description: To the Editor:

title: The British Class System
description: To the Editor:

title: Reliving the Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Her Woody Allen Obsession
description: Lighter than cat dander and just as likely to provoke an allergic reaction, Paris Manhattan uses a character with a Woody Allen obsession as an excuse to pilfer words and ideas far beyond its ability to synthesize them.

title: Old Hands Looking for New Action
description: As the title of Fists of Legend suggests, originality is not one of the films watchwords. For all that, this mixed-martial-arts slog from Kang Woo-suk  running more than two and a half hours, people  is not a complete chore. Shot with some wit and considerable speed, its short, sharp beatdowns are a refreshing change from the bloated action sequences favored by some of Mr. Kangs genre contemporaries.

title: Rejuvenated Garca Shares Opening-Round Lead With a 66
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Last year, the mere sight of the Augusta National Golf Club left Sergio Garca disconsolate and wondering if he would ever win a major championship.

title: New Tool for Police Officers: Records at Their Fingertips
description: As the officers walked up to the entrance of a Harlem housing project, a loose knot of people out front scattered into the damp, dark night and a few lingerers cast cold stares at the officers. One of the officers reached into his pocket and pulled out the newest tool in the Police Departments crime-fighting arsenal: a smartphone.

title: The Power of Loss
description: Their grief is so immense, their sadness so deep, that when the parents of children slaughtered in Newtown, Conn., tried this week to make a political point, most people could not see beyond the swollen red eyes. It was all hugs and pats and God forbid, we can only imagine if that had happened to us.

title: Report on 3 in China Who Died From Bird Flu Points to Severity of Strain
description: A report on three of the first patients in China to contract a new strain of bird flu paints a grim portrait of severe pneumonia, septic shock and other complications that damaged the brain, kidney and other organs. All three died.

title: Skateboard Rebels Behind the Iron Curtain
description: Described in the publicity notes as a hybrid documentary  whose degree of fictionalization is still being debated  This Aint California offers a vivid immersion in the hidden skateboarding culture of the former East Germany.

title: A Gentler Animal Farm
description: Plainly and persistently presented, the inelegantly titled American Meat argues like a fair-minded editorial for a return to more healthful methods in meat farming. Instead of playing up modern industrial farms as hell on earth, this documentary by Graham Meriwether takes a tack sympathetic to farmers in setting forth its alternative, but its still an advocacy film better suited for a class than for a cinema.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Apr. 12, 2013
description: Its remarkable. You cant turn a corner in the Capitol this week without meeting a family of a gun violence victim. Its hard to say no to these families.

title: School Vote Stirs Debate on Girls as Leaders
description: ANDOVER, Mass.  When the elite Phillips Academy here went coed in 1973, some worried that women would quickly take over this venerable institution, the alma mater of Oliver Wendell Holmes, Samuel Morse and Humphrey Bogart, not to mention both Presidents George Bush.

title: Rebel Victory in Syria Might Not Stop Conflict, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  As it cobbles together additional aid for rebel fighters there, the Obama administration believes Syria could face a protracted, bloody conflict, even if the rebels succeed in ousting President Bashar al-Assad, several officials said Thursday.

title: Round 1: Masters Replay
description: Sergio Garca grabbed a share of the lead with Australias Marc Leishman at the Masters with Tiger Woods trailing by four shots.

title: Student Election Sparks Gender Equality Debate
description: The race for school president at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., set off a debate about gender equality that engulfed the campus.

title: Kerry Heads to Asia to Reassure Allies of U.S. Support
description: MANAS, Kyrgyzstan  With tensions on high in the Korean Peninsula, Secretary of State John Kerry arrives in South Korea on Friday in an attempt to reassure American allies in the region that the United States remains committed to their defense.

title: New Woes for 2 Who Abducted Their Children
description: A mother and father who abducted their eight children from foster care in New York and set off a nationwide manhunt have been arrested on charges of falsely claiming more than $116,000 in public assistance benefits, the citys Department of Investigation said on Thursday.

title: Allegations of Test Help by Teachers
description: Investigators for a school district on Long Islands North Shore are looking into allegations that more than a dozen educators from two elementary schools improperly helped students on standardized tests, including by coaching pupils on correct answers last year during state exams, union and district officials said on Thursday.

title: Corrections: April 12, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Children of the World, Unite!
description: Rejoice, my theatergoing comrades. The childrens revolution has arrived on these shores, and it is even more glorious than we were promised. Rush now, barricade stormers of culture, to the Shubert Theater, and join the insurrection against tyranny, television, illiteracy, unjust punishment and impoverished imaginations, led by a 5-year-old La Pasionaria with a poker face and an off-the-charts I.Q.

title: Beyond the Pail
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I love all of the little factoids I learn from solving crossword puzzles. For example, I had no idea that the original CAESAR SALADs were served using whole leaves and were meant to be eaten with the fingers. I had nearly succeeded in cramming BUFFALO WINGS into 1 Across before I ran out of room and realized that this was going to take some work. But thats par for a Friday, right?

title: Jurors Deadlocked in Murder Trial
description: On the seventh day of deliberations, jurors in the trial of David Tarloff, a schizophrenic man charged with the murder of an Upper East Side psychologist five years ago, sent a note to the judge on Thursday saying they were unable to reach a verdict and had been deadlocked throughout their deliberations.

title: Matilda the Musical Opens

title: Rutgers Names Replacement for Counsel Who Resigned
description: Amid a scandal about Mike Rice, the mens basketball coach who was fired last week for abusive language and physical aggression, Rutgers University has named John J. Farmer Jr. as its new senior vice president and general counsel. Mr. Farmers predecessor, John B. Wolf, resigned last week, along with the athletic director, Tim Pernetti.

title: Cuomos Re-election Machinery Is Already at Work
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos poll numbers, although still enviable, are no longer sky-high. The coalition of business leaders that had spent millions of dollars promoting his agenda has stopped advertising. And even some of his allies have started to criticize him and his administration.

description: The Jackie Robinson I saw in 42 was different than and yet the same as the Jackie Robinson I knew as a baseball writer with the long-deceased Brooklyn Eagle and New York Journal-American.

description: The late-19th-century National Guard armory in Williamsburg, a 165,000-square-foot brick fortress with crenelated towers at the corners, has been empty for two years, and is now used mostly for film shoots.

title: Suzuki Facing Less Playing Time
description: CLEVELAND  Since becoming a regular with the Orix Blue Wave in 1994, Ichiro Suzuki has never worried about playing time. If he was healthy, he was in the starting lineup  whether the game was being played in Japan or the United States.

description: PHILADELPHIA  Charlie Manuel, the longtime manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, was sitting on the home teams bench before a game this week at Citizens Bank Park.

So he tore down his shabby headquarters on a quiet street in Flushing, Queens, and replaced it with a lavish three-story building that had marble floors, granite countertops, red carpets and a soaring chandelier.

title: Judges Deportation Order on ex-Salvadoran General
description: An immigration judges ruling ordering the deportation of former Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova over his role in the 1980 rape and murder of four American churchwomen and other crimes in El Salvador.

title: McConnell Recording Is Linked to a PAC
description: Even before Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, knew the source of an embarrassing leaked recording, he attacked the political left for wiretapping him and invoked Watergate.

title: N.H.L. and Players Union Take Lead on Gay Issues
description: With Thursdays announcement of a major initiative in support of gay inclusion, the N.H.L. and the N.H.L. Players Association have taken the lead among major mens professional sports leagues in fighting homophobia.

title: Medal of Honor Awarded to Korean War Chaplain
description: WASHINGTON  Supporters of the Rev. Emil J. Kapaun, an Army chaplain who died a prisoner in the Korean War, are still working to have him declared a Catholic saint for his lifesaving ministrations to them. But for now, they have the satisfaction of seeing him posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor at the White House.

title: Robinson Helps Bulls End Knicks Streak
description: CHICAGO  If you laid the Knicks top six big men from end to end, you would get 41 feet and 4 inches of pain, and enough sore necks, feet, knees and ankles to fill a modest orthopedic ward.

title: From Todays Paper: A Moderate Runs in Iran
description: Hassan Rowhani, right, a moderate cleric who served for years as an Iranian nuclear negotiator, said Thursday in Tehran that he would seek the presidency. Mr. Rowhani, a critic of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, resigned from his post in 2005 after Mr. Ahmadinejads election.

title: Environmental Questions Take Back Seat at Hearing for E.P.A. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  Most of the biggest challenges facing the Environmental Protection Agency  climate change, major new regulations on power plant emissions, biofuels production and enforcement of clean air and water laws  were virtually absent from Thursdays confirmation hearing for President Obamas nominee to head the agency, Gina McCarthy.

title: Lost in Translation
description: Rafael Moneo may be the greatest living architect in Europe. What does it say about American taste that weve barely heard of him?

title: Luxury of Simplicity
description: Like a spirited magpie, Marie-Helene de Taillac is attracted to the allure of shiny objects, be it in the dazzling jewels she designs or her inviting apartment in Paris.

title: The Fairest of Them All
description: The depth to which Julianne Moore inhabits a character says more about the audience than the actress. Unlocking the secret to Hollywoods most genuine star.

title: Checks Find Unsafe Practices at Compounding Pharmacies
description: After a crash inspection program, federal regulators said Thursday that they had found numerous unsafe practices at about 30 compounding pharmacies, the same type of facility responsible for the tainted drug that caused a deadly meningitis outbreak last year.

title: Where Germs Hide in Your Kitchen
description: Beware of the blender: It may be a bacteria trap.

title: Word of the Day | insomnia
description: insomnia \in-sm-ne-\ noun

title: A Conversation With: Ravi Venkatesan, Former Chairman of Microsoft India
description: It would be hard to find a more passionate advocate for doing business in India than Ravi Venkatesan, the former chairman of Microsoft India. When Mr. Venkatesan moved to India in 1996 from the United States, he was so sure he wouldnt be here long that he put his belongings in storage.

title: Schoolhouse Discipline
description: Districts around the country are weighing stationing more police officers in their schools, while critics question whether some behavior on campuses is being overly criminalized.

title: With Police in Schools, More Children in Court
description: HOUSTON  As school districts across the country consider placing more police officers in schools, youth advocates and judges are raising alarm about what they have seen in the schools where officers are already stationed: a surge in criminal charges against children for misbehavior that many believe is better handled in the principals office.

title: One on One: Douglas Rushkoff on Everything Happening Now
description: Douglas Rushkoff hurts the way only a onetime true believer can hurt. Before he taught at New York University and the New School, he was an early fan of the Internet. I was a slacker, and it seemed like a way to slack, he says. Wed all work when we felt like it. Instead of a contemplative paradise, however, the marriage of networked technology and capitalism tortures our consciousness with an incessant, demanding present. Weve attached ourselves to it, he says; We respond to things when it wants us to, which is all the time.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Sundance) ADAPTATION (2002) The director Spike Jonze and the writer Charlie Kaufman (along with his imaginary twin, Donald, who is also credited with writing the screenplay) journey into metafiction in this movie about the two Kaufmans (Nicolas Cage, in both roles) and Susan Orlean (Meryl Streep), a writer for The New Yorker whose book The Orchid Thief inspired the film. Chris Cooper won an Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as an orchid obsessive; Ms. Streep and Mr. Cage (above) also received Oscar nominations. Adaptation is, most obviously, a movie about itself, as gleefully self-referential an exercise in auto-deconstruction as you could wish, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But it is also, more deeply, a movie about its own nonexistence  a narrative that confronts both the impossibility and the desperate necessity of storytelling, and that short-circuits our expectations of coherence, plausibility and fidelity to lived reality even as it satisfies them. Common sense suggests that there could never be such a movie, but if there could, it would have to be one of the slipperiest, most fascinating and, by any sane reckoning, best movies of the year.

title: Papua New Guinea Considers Repealing Sorcery Law
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Papua New Guineas prime minister, Peter ONeill, has vowed to repeal the countrys controversial Sorcery Act after the latest in a string of brutal public killings of people accused of practicing black magic.
