description: HONG KONG  The American film Django Unchained was abruptly pulled from theaters in China on Thursday, its opening day, a surprising move that underscored the fragility of Hollywoods evolving relationship with the Chinese movie industry.

title: In Cameron and Merkel Visit, a Chance to Discuss British Role in Europe
description: BERLIN  David Cameron, the British prime minister, arrived here on Friday for what a German official called a not purely routine weekend visit that will include talks with Chancellor Angela Merkel aimed at demonstrating the close relationship between the two center-right leaders and a discussion of Britains future in the European Union.

title: Do You Spend Too Much Time Preparing for Standardized Tests?
description: From now until the end of the school year, its testing season in most parts of the country. Students take standardized tests to measure literacy and numeracy, meet graduation standards, earn course credits and gain admission to college. Has the amount of testing gone too far?

In truth, it doesnt look like much  just cubicles and meeting rooms in space donated by Google. But looks deceive; here, with little fanfare, Cornells new graduate school of applied sciences is being rolled out.

description: The board of the market operator Nasdaq OMX Group has cut the 2012 bonus of the companys chief executive, Robert Greifeld, by 62 percent, as a result of the botched Facebook initial public offering last May.

title: China Defends Vaccination of Poultry as Flu Spreads
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Agriculture Ministry issued a strongly worded defense late Friday afternoon of its policy of large-scale vaccination of poultry against the H5N1 avian influenza virus over the last decade, saying that it was not interfering with its efforts now to identify the emerging H7N9 virus.

title: Simple Natural Goodness
description: One of the baffling aspects of economic debate during this Lesser Depression, or so it seems to me, is the apparent urge of many economists to shy away from straightforward conclusions, the urge to make the simple complicated and the clear blurry. Thats certainly what seems to be happening in this round-robin from me, to Cowen/Andolfatto, to Brad DeLong.

title: In Delhi, Even My Own Car Is No Refuge From Harassment
description: NEW DELHI  In February, I was driving my car through a busy street in Connaught Place when a taxi driver began honking his horn at me. It was around noon, and honking is hardly unusual for chaotic Delhi traffic, but the driver kept angrily pounding on his horn. The noise ended only after the taxi had pulled beside me at a red light. Then the driver angled his car to block mine. I was stunned.

title: JPMorgan Kicks Off Bank Earnings
description: JPMORGAN EARNINGS SHOW STRENGTH | JPMorgan Chase said on Friday that its first-quarter profit rose 33 percent to $6.5 billion, supported by strength in the investment banking business and a surge in mortgage lending. The report, which kicked off bank earnings season, showed net earnings of $1.59 a share, exceeding analysts expectations of $5.41 billion, or $1.40 a share. Revenue was $25.8 billion, compared with $26.8 billion a year earlier.

description: Wells Fargo posted a 22 percent increase in first-quarter profit on Friday as the bank, which is the nations largest home lender, continued to notch record gains even while its mortgage machine slowed.

title: Development and Its Discontent
description: PHNOM PENH  In 2010, the Cambodian government unveiled with great fanfare the countrys first traffic overpass. The $6 million project  lit with a futuristic blue neon swoosh  was intended to ease congestion where a major boulevard that runs north-south through Phnom Penh intersects with twin bridges that cross the Bassac River, just to the east. Prime Minister Hun Sen called the Sky Bridge Project a great achievement and proclaimed that it would end traffic problems in the area.It wasnt long before commuters discovered a catch: By making it easier for motorists traveling north-south to keep going straight, the new overpass made it impossible for them to turn left onto the intersecting east-west road. The result is a mess. Now, drivers heading south who want to cross the river must first take a right and drive away for several hundred meters and then make a U-turn and head back. And motorists heading north are forced to turn right, which necessarily takes them onto the bridges  meaning that they are forced to cross the river, turn around and cross the river again. Congestion in the area is worse than ever, and the traffic more dangerous.

title: Actress Loses Suit Over Sites Posting of Her Age
description: A jury in Seattle has found against Huong Hoang, the actress who sued the Internet Movie Database and its parent company, Amazon, for posting her age without her permission. The verdict, reached in Federal Court on Thursday, rejected a breach of contract claim against IMDB by Ms. Hoang, who uses the name Junie Hoang in her screen work. Marsha J. Pechman, a judge in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, had already dropped Amazon from the case, and dismissed other claims.

title: Day 2: Highlights and Analysis From the Masters
description: The Australian Jason Day holds sole possession of the lead after 36 holes at the Masters on Friday, finishing at six under par with four birdies on the back nine. Day, who finished tied for second at the 2011 Masters, had never topped the leader board overnight at a major.Day is one shot ahead of his countryman Marc Leishman and the American veteran Fred Couples, who are tied for second at five under.Angel Cabrera, Jim Furyk, and Brandt Snedeker are tied for fourth at four under. Tiger Woods, who had his back nine derailed by a severe bounce off the flag pole on No. 15, is part of a seven-way tie for seventh.As the day wrapped up, most eyes were on the middle-to-bottom part of the scoreboard, as the cut line hovered around the name of 14-year-old Guan Tianlang of China, who just barely survived with a score of four over. Guan would have advanced more comfortably had he not been assessed a rare stroke penalty for slow play on the 17th hole. Despite the unusual ruling, Guan did not take opportunities offered to him by Tom Rinaldi of ESPN to criticize or bemoan the controversial ruling.I respect their decision, he said.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents dealt a serious blow to one of the Afghan Armys most highly regarded units on Friday, killing 13 soldiers and overrunning their remote outpost in eastern Afghanistan.

description: Intrigued. Inspired. Insulted. I summoned all three feelings as I glanced through the responses to my last post, Why I Like to Hire Great Recession Graduates. In the post, I talked about how many recent graduates  tempered by the tough economy they have experienced  are making excellent employees in fast-growth companies where a hunger to work and a will to win override the need for entitlements, praise and corner offices. In fact, I suggested, these recent graduates have adjusted to the new reality much better than some of their parents.

title: Dark Roots of a Pop Masters Sunshine
description: Paying a visit to Claes Oldenburg, one of the last surviving giants of Pop Art, youd be forgiven for expecting a wacky guy living in chaos. His crowd-pleasing masterworks  a canvas hamburger the size of a couch, a rusting clothespin as big as a house, a lipstick tall as a tree  can easily be read as giant guffaws at a pompous art world. His gorgeous sketches for those projects are as wild and woolly as could be. So yes, youd be forgiven for expecting a scene from a shaggy New Yorker cartoon by Ed Koren  forgiven, and mistaken.

title: How Social Security Cuts Could Affect Children
description: President Obamas budget includes a controversial  at least on the left  change in the way Social Security benefits are adjusted for inflation that would save the government about $130 billion over 10 years, but would reduce payments for tens of millions of Americans over time.

title: Decoding a 44-Year-Old Horoscope
description: The black folder had a cardboard, cartoon fish stapled to the front cover, indicating the birth sign: Pisces. Inside was an eight-page, all-italics work-up on me  the planets, my innate strengths and weaknesses. Cora Sitrusis of Cora Sitrusis School of Astrology Inc. had included instructions that were at times underlined (impress upon him the reason he must master such things as multiplication tables); in all caps (the horoscope shows TENDENCIES); and, very rarely, underlined and in all caps (ONCE HE LEARNS, HE NEVER FORGETS!). The horoscope was dated June 9, 1969. I was nearly 3 months old.

title: And Now, Deep Thoughts About Deep Thoughts
description: This past fall, while teaching poetry to undergraduates, I witnessed something of a literary tragedy. Each week, I asked a few students to read a contemporary literary journal of their choosing and present one poem that particularly struck them. An unmistakable pattern began to emerge. In the final week of the quarter, I voiced my discovery: Have you guys noticed that you gravitate toward poems that are like Deep Thoughts, by Jack Handey?

title: An Ethical Theory of Relativity
description: My wife and I are fairly certain that the rent invoice from our landlord was too low. We believe it was a calculation error and that we should pay the correct amount. But a friend thinks we have a right to take advantage of the error. In discussing why we disagreed, I realized that I would have no problem taking advantage of such an error on my bill from my cable provider (I believe they regularly make errors that hurt their customers  but even if that werent the case, I still would feel the same way). Is there any difference in the ethics of dealing with, say, Time Warner Cable and our landlord? DAN, NEW YORK CITY

title: The 3.31.13 Issue
description: IS GIVING THE SECRET TO GETTING AHEAD?

title: Who Made That Lipstick?
description: In the 1940s, lipstick tended to fade and smear. Women were constantly checking their teeth for red marks and repainting their mouths. Hazel Bishop  a biochemist with a background in petroleum science  set out to solve this problem. Using the tiny kitchen of her Central Park West apartment as a lab, she cooked potions in a double boiler and compounded dyes on a countertop. Sometimes so much dust escaped from her experiments that the butter in her refrigerator turned red. Lipstick had existed for centuries, of course, but Bishop hoped to create a long-lasting version for the modern woman, one that would stand up to the friction of coffee cups, cigarettes and kisses. She hit on a formula made with lanolin and dyes that penetrated deep into the skin. To demonstrate its sticking power, she persuaded her neighborhood druggist to decorate his hand with streaks of her lipstick. As he rang up purchases, the red stripes stayed bright.

title: Prairie Jazz Companion
description: A few years ago the jazz composer Maria Schneider traveled back to her hometown, Windom, Minn. She climbed a ladder with a childhood friend named Tony Thompson and found herself at the top of a silo. She looked out over the fields: acres of Thompsons bean plants moving over and past one another in the breeze. Windom, population 4,646, is the seat of Cottonwood County, near the states southwest corner. The Des Moines River flows leisurely through it. The land is smooth prairie, in all directions. The mistake people make, Schneider told me about this flat place she came from, is thinking that its flat.

title: Temple Grandin on Autism, Death, Celibacy and Cows
description: In your new book, The Autistic Brain, you seriously entertain possible links between vaccines and autism in children, links that scientists have vehemently dismissed.  Well, theres only one vaccine that could possibly be a problem, and thats the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine. Now that theyve changed the vaccine, it has fewer antigens, and that would make it a lot safer. But with the old version of the vaccine, I have not yet come across a study that looked at regressives  when a child had some speech but lost it.

title: Tobacco Thats So Brooklyn but Made in Belgium
description: We were somewhere around Barolo on the edge of the Italian wine country when my wifes 68-year-old uncle, Dario, lurched forward in the drivers seat, fished a small leather pouch from the floorboard and threw it in my lap. Semwaz! he cried, as if this were the answer to everything.

Samper, the president of the Wildlife Conservation Society, from a meeting held this week at Cambridge University to examine this question: How will Synthetic Biology and Conservation Shape the Future of Nature?

description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "It's a Disaster."

title: Fewer Are Losing Their Jobs
description: The rate of layoffs and discharges has fallen to the lowest level since the government began calculating the figure at the end of 2000, dropping below the level seen in the fall of 2006, before the Great Recession began.  More people are leaving their jobs voluntarily and more are also being hired than during the recession, but those rates remain well below the previous peaks.  Rates of firings and layoffs are highest in the construction industry, and lowest in government jobs.

title: HD Supply, Backed by Carlyle and Bain, Files for I.P.O.
description: HD Supply Holdings, an industrial distribution company owned by a group of private equity firms, filed on Friday to go public.

title: Brad Paisleys Accidental Uproar
description: New York Times op-ed columnist Charles M. Blow talks to Ben Ratliff about Brad Paisleys controversial new song Accidental Racist.

title: In a Rare Show at Radio City, Two Prizefighters Will Take the Stage
description: Frank Sinatra performed there; so did Rodney Dangerfield and Kermit the Frog.

title: Chaos Assembled, Beauty Emerges
description: At the end of the second movement of Charles Ivess Symphony No. 4 a tender melody suddenly erupts into bawdy cacophony, like a marching band lurching through a carnival fun house.

title: Leading Off: A Baseball Brawl That Hurts
description: Zack Greinke, the right-hander who signed a six-year, $147 million deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers in the off-season, broke his left collarbone Thursday night when Carlos Quentin of the San Diego Padres charged the mound after Greinke hit him in the left shoulder with a pitch.

title: Back Home in Texas, for the First Time
description: WHARTON, Tex.  This is the kind of town (population 8,832) where line-hung laundry flaps in the breeze, crows caw from 100-year-old oaks, and neighbors have you over for a Sunday supper of fried chicken and collard greens. Everyone knows everyone, so a stranger gets noticed, particularly a famous actress putting her hands in the dirt of a plowed-up cornfield.

title: The Man Who Took His Life as a Dance
description: Are we still shaking? the choreographer Bill T. Jones asked, extending a hand to Dr. Oliver Sacks, the writer and neurologist. Then he chuckled and instead went in for a hug, parting ways with him after tea at Dr. Sackss Greenwich Village apartment.

title: New Chamber Music From Lee Hyla
description: Lee Hyla: My Life on the Plains (Chamber Works)

title: Technologys Impact on the Value of Financial Advice
description: WE use technological shortcuts for things from simple tasks like booking vacations and buying books to more consequential matters like searching for a new home or trying to diagnose our ailments.

title: Gym, Tan, Laundry, Family, Talk Show
description: It could have been any house on this suburban stretch of Staten Island, with a well-worn basketball hoop outside and a sign out front warning, Beware of Dog. But here one wintry February afternoon Vinny Guadagnino, the former Jersey Shore star, was pacing from room to room of the home where he grew up, now the site of his new MTV talk show, as he awaited a visit from the pop star Kesha.

title: When Shareholder Democracy Is Sham Democracy
description: Two weeks ago, I argued that it was hard to imagine a more compelling case for ousting directors than the one posed by Hewlett-Packard.

title: The Gun Report: April 12, 2013
description: Since Roger Eberts passing last week, most obituaries have focusednaturally enoughon his witty, wide-eyed movie criticism. But in his later years he wrote on a number of topics, including gun legislation. After the massacre in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater, he wrote an Op-Ed in this newspaperarguing that there is no easy link between movies and gun violence. I think the link is between the violence and the publicity. He continued:

title: The Coda of Shuggie Otis
description: This week the first new music in almost 40 years will arrive from Shuggie Otis, one of the more enigmatic figures in pop music history. The album, Wings of Love (Epic/Legacy), with 14 previously unreleased tracks, is being packaged alongside a reissue of his previous and most celebrated recording, Inspiration Information, from 1974.

title: Common Core Practice | Pseudo-Academia, Accidental Racist and Broadcasts in Latin
description: This week, our collaborators in New Jersey got playful with both their Times choices and the writing activities they suggest for them.

title: Popcast: Accidental Racist and the Possible Value of a Flawed Song
description: This week, the New York Times Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow talks to the host Ben Ratliff about Brad Paisleys controversial new song, Accidental Racist, in which the central character  a white southerner  walks into a Starbucks and experiences a moment of clarity, or something like that, regarding the Confederate flag T-shirt hes wearing. (LL Cool J plays the barista and de facto spirit guide.)

title: Wheelies: The Fantasy Electric Truck Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Growing Up on a Musical Diet of Presley and Blondie
description: The Tennessee pop-punk band Paramore, fronted by Hayley Williams, is attempting a reintroduction. It has to. Its self-titled fourth album, just released on Fueled by Ramen, follows two years of turmoil in which the brothers Josh and Zac Farro, the nine-year-old bands founding guitarist and drummer, quit. On his blog Josh Farro called Paramore a manufactured product of a major label and accused Ms. Williams of hogging the spotlight. She stood up for her band and its authenticity on MTV. (Zac Farro later said his brother had regrets about the post.)

title: Americas Quartermaster
description: In July 1862, George B. McClellans Peninsula Campaign ended and Union forces slowly began their trek back from Virginias backwaters, stunned by their losses. But if it was a failure on the battlefield, as a logistical operation, it was a stunning success, one of the great organizational feats of human history, all thanks to one man: Quartermaster General Montgomery C. Meigs.

title: In the Hytner Era, the National Theater Hit Its Mark
description: LONDONAt last, a date has been named. Im referring not to the next general election but to a handover to come that may loom larger in the minds of culturally minded Britons. Nicholas Hytner has announced that he will step down at the end of March 2015 as artistic director of the National Theater, a position he has filled with considerable glory since 2003, over time repositioning the primacy of the three-auditorium complex as arguably the defining theatrical address in the English-speaking world.

title: A Coffee Deal for the Long Haul
description: Bart Bechts $10 billion coffee run has a dash of Warren E. Buffett about it.

title: U.S. Penalizes Russians for Human Rights Violations
description: WASHINGTON  The United States imposed new sanctions Friday on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, and Moscow vowed to retaliate as a fractious dispute between the two countries escalated further into a cold war-style, tit-for-tat clash.

title: Rare Bay Psalm Book Goes on View at Sothebys
description: One of eleven surviving copies of the Bay Psalm Book  the first book printed in what is now the United States, and one of the worlds most valuable books  will be on public view from Friday until Sunday at Sothebys in New York, in advance of a November auction where the book is expected to fetch more than $15 million.

title: Interim M.T.A. Leader Picked to Be Its Chief
description: More than three months ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority lost its chairman, Joseph J. Lhota, to a mayoral run buoyed by the subway systems rapid recovery after Hurricane Sandy.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The documentary American Meat, about the meat production industry, will open Friday at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street in Greenwich Village. There will be a panel discussion after the film. Tickets are $11 per person, and Chipotle Mexican Grill, one of the sponsors of the premiere, will hand out a free gift after the screening and at other showings over the weekend.

title: As You Watch, Invasion of the Platforms
description: Visitors to A Journal of Insomnia, part of the Storyscapes section of the forthcoming Tribeca Film Festival, will set up an appointment and, at the agreed-upon hour, receive a phone call. They will then presumably stumble sleepless to their computers, click on the Insomnia Web site and interact with one of four characters featured in the festivals foray into transmedia: the crazy-quilt crossroads of new technology, uncertain expectations and audience participation.

title: Foods Newest, Chicest Magazine: Cherry Bombe
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Florida; North Adams, Mass.
description: Solid Sound Festival, North Adams, Mass. After a one-year hiatus, this music festival, curated by and featuring the band Wilco (above), returns to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (MASS MoCA) from June 21 to 23. Throughout the museums 19th-century factory buildings and across its expansive lawns, about two dozen acts, including bands like Yo La Tengo and Neko Case and comedians like Jen Kirkman, will perform. A part of North Adamss downtown will be open for camping, and $80 round-trip bus transportation is available from New York and Boston.

title: Full Circle, Almost, for Real Sociedad
description: Fans at Anoeta saw six goals last Saturday. Two were scored by Malaga, a quarterfinalist in this seasons Champions League, but it was the four that were scored by Real Sociedad that will add to the growing sense of belief that echoes around San Sebastin these days.

title: Mets Find Out They Wont Have a Snow Day
description: 3:08 p.m. | Updated A Twins spokesman said Friday nights game is on. The club is offering free coffee and hot chocolate at the Target Field gates to anyone hardy enough to show up.

title: Jonathan Winters, Unpredictable Comic and Master of Improvisation, Dies at 87
description: Jonathan Winters, the rubber-faced comedian whose unscripted flights of fancy inspired a generation of improvisational comics, and who kept television audiences in stitches with Main Street characters like Maude Frickert, a sweet-seeming grandmother with a barbed tongue and a roving eye, died on Thursday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 87.

title: Guilt by Slippery Slope
description: One thing you have to love about the debate over gun control is the lack of inhibition. The anti-gun-control side seems especially willing to say ridiculous things, but their opponents arent shy, either.

title: April 14  20
description: Baroque Ensemble, Back in Brooklyn

title: Fifth Avenue Co-op at $25 Million
description: The eighth floor apartment includes a grand salon with design details reminiscent of a Faberge egg.

title: A Grand Paean to Royalty
description: A fancifully renovated floor-through apartment dominated by a Versailles-style salon with a coffered 18-foot-high ceiling decorated with Faberg-egg intricacy and a 40-foot-long wall of windows opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art is entering the market for the first time in nearly 40 years. The all-cash asking price for the five-bedroom four-bath co-op, which also has two powder rooms, four marble fireplaces, and a staff suite, is $25 million; the monthly maintenance is $9,750.

title: Chocolate-Crusted Banana Blondies
description: Tired of banana bread and banana muffins? Melissa Clark presents another sweet option for ripe bananas.

title: Cracking the Walnut
description: Nuts can add lots of flavor and crunch to your favorite dishes, and they just happen to be good for you. In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman celebrates the versatility of the walnut. As she writes:

title: The Week in Food
description: Lots of meat news:More evidence linking red meat consumption to heart disease: Researchers have found that bacteria in the human gut converts a nutrient common in beef into a compound that might quicken the build up of plaques in the arteries. (Just in time, Bill Gates has a new site promoting plant-based food companies like Hampton Creek Foods and Beyond Meat.)

title: One Man, Saved From Invisibility
description: What do you do for a living, Jason?

title: A Muslim College Mixes Subjects to Achieve an American Feel
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  I was a bit late for my meeting last week with 19-year-old Mussab Abouabdalla, who I hoped would explain to me why anyone would attend Zaytuna College, an unaccredited three-year-old Muslim institution with about 30 students and not even 10 professors. I found Mr. Abouabdalla at Caffe Strada. He had arranged his books on the table as if to answer my question.

title: Without the Fudge, Blondies Have More Fun
description: When I imagined a pan full of chocolate banana blondie bars, I could see exactly what I wanted. A bittersweet bottom crowned with a brown-butter, rum-scented, banana-imbued butterscotch blondie. Two distinct layers and a complex set of flavors harmonizing in every gooey bite.

title: The Sweet Spot | Thank You, Roger Ebert
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott reflect on the life of Roger Ebert, the brand he created, and the effect he had on Mr. Scotts beginnings as a film critic.

title: Start-Up Looks to Make Law Firm Billing More Transparent
description: The world of big law has been buzzing with talk about billing, especially after a client of DLA Piper accused the giant law firm of inflating bills through overstaffing andperforming unnecessary work.

title: Chvezs Lasting Impact
description: Even in death, the former leader Hugo Chvez plays an omnipresent role in Venezuelas presidential campaigns as voters prepare to elect their new leader on Sunday.

title: The Sweet Spot: Two Thumbs Up
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott reflect on the life of Roger Ebert, the brand he created and the effect he had on Mr. Scotts beginnings as a film critic.

title: Caring for a Special Member of the Family
description: Basement, attic or back of closet: those three storage options, though commonly chosen, are not the best for brides hoping to save their wedding gown for the next generation.

title: J.C. Penney Wins Ruling in Dispute With Macys
description: With Ron Johnson out, Martha Stewart is in at J. C. Penney, at least for the moment.

title: A Dads Hidden Truth of Parenting: Were All Clichs
description: Over the past few years, a new wave seems to be washing over the world: a wave of bellyaching fathers complaining about how hard it is to be a parent. There is nothing particularly original about these complaints. In fact, as in most things, women were here first. But when it comes to whining, we men are better at it, or at least much, much louder.

title: Maria Tallchief, a Dazzling Ballerina and Muse for Balanchine, Dies at 88
description: Maria Tallchief, a daughter of an Oklahoma oil family who grew up on an Indian reservation, found her way to New York and became one of the most brilliant American ballerinas of the 20th century, died on Thursday in Chicago. She was 88.

title: Fewer Americans Lose Jobs, but Hiring Is Also Down
description: AMERICAN workers are being fired or laid off less often than at any time in the last decade, the government reported this week. But companies are also less willing to hire than they used to be.

title: To Celebrate a Landmarks Law, Planting Flags in a Tiny New York
description: David Grainger is walking on the water again. One foot is upstream from the Manhattan Bridge and the other foot is downstream from the Williamsburg Bridge, and he is reaching over the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to plant a yellow flag at the intersection of Pierrepont Street and Hicks Street in Brooklyn Heights.

title: DNA Project Aims to Make Public a Companys Data on Cancer Genes
description: Anyone in the United States who wants to know if she has mutations in two breast cancer genes has little choice of where to be tested. One company alone has patents on the genes, and that company pretty much controls the market.

title: Looking for Love and Lobster Salad
description: About the last place on earth a single person with no children would expect to meet someone is at a childrens birthday party 2 states and 178 miles from home. Then again, if by chance two single people should be at such an event, they would certainly stand out in the crowd.

title: Jettisoning a Few Extra Square Feet
description: Nearly five years ago, Alyse Booth and Steve Lefkowitz bought a second home in the Berkshires, a house near a pond on four wooded acres.

title: Immigration Compromise Leaves Out Many
description: The Timess Ashley Parker on why a plan that offers a path to citizenship is a win for Senator Marco Rubio but a loss for illegal immigrants whove only recently arrived.

title: Now Listening | Ra Ra Riot, All I Fear
description: The indie rock outfit Ra Ra Riot is no stranger to old-fashioned means of music discovery. After all, the group, which first cut its chops playing house parties at Syracuse University, gained notoriety only after putting in stints at CMJ and South by Southwest and garnering positive reviews for its tireless live shows. Its fitting, then, that the band  made up of Wes Miles on vocals, Rebecca Zeller on violin, Mathieu Santos on bass and Milo Bonacci on guitar  should be fans of Record Store Day.

title: In France, Where Brunch Is Au Courant
description: My wife and I darted over to Paris for a long weekend to visit our 21-year-old son, Peter, who is spending the semester studying abroad and absorbing the numerous cultural pleasures that Europe has to offer. Unexpectedly among those pleasures, he said, Parisians are currently obsessed with brunch, a bane of the New York food-obsessed, who writhe in agony over the popular banality of bad eggs Benedict and dreadful Bloody Marys.

title: Looking Back at a Dancer With Fire
description: Images of Maria Tallchief, one of the most brilliant American ballerinas of the 20th century.

title: New York City Unveils Parking App Pilot Program
description: New York City passed a major milestone this week, introducing a new app that helps motorists find and pay for parking using a smartphone. The pilot program for the app will be near Fordham University in the Bronx and will include 264 parking spaces along nine blocks.

title: The Treasure Trove on the Ground Floor
description: New York is rife with urban legends, like the one about the nine-foot crocodile that lives in the sewers, or the one about the treasure buried on Liberty Island.

title: What Happens if You Dont Pay Your Taxes
description: People who commit tax fraud can face big fines and even imprisonment. Just ask the recently released Wesley Snipes, who had served most of a three-year sentence for not filing his taxes. The timing of his release, just ahead of the tax filing deadline, may not have been an accident; the Internal Revenue Service appears to ramp up publicity of its tax fraud cases right before April 15, a 2010 study found.

title: Big Ticket | A Reconfigured Aerie, Sold for $16.25 Million
description: An indulgent and elegant apartment on the 42nd floor of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, which was reconfigured to a two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath aerie from the original four bedrooms and six baths by the designer Jeffrey Bilhuber, sold for $16.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Q & A
description: A Disappearing Community Room

title: Last Goodbye, With Jeff Buckley Music, to Open Old Globe Season
description: The Old Globe Theater in San Diego will open its 2013-14 season with The Last Goodbye, a long-in-development adaptation of Romeo and Juliet set to the music of Jeff Buckley.

title: Video: Remembering Jonathan Winters
description: Jonathan Winters, the frenetic comedian who created many indelible characters and also had a nearly unmatched gift for wild comic improvisation, died on Thursday. He was 87.

title: Remembering Maria Tallchief in Motion
description: Maria Tallchief, one of the 20th centurys most important ballerinas, died on Thursday at 88. Ms. Tallchief, a former wife and muse of the choreographer George Balanchine, was known for dazzling audiences with her speed, energy and fire. Here are a selection of video clips of Ms. Tallchief dancing.

title: Jonathan Winters, 1925-2013
description: Jonathan Winters was a rubber-faced comedian whose unscripted flights of fancy inspired a generation of improvisational comics.

title: New Flavors in a Newark Neighborhood
description: The Ironbound district of Newark is not the sort of place that outsiders flock to.

title: Wasnt It Summer Just the Other Day?
description: What is it with this weather? A warm January, a chilly start to spring, an early-April hot spell complete with brush-fire outbreaks, and now, freezing winds driving the rain into the sockets of your skull.

title: Where the Rumble Meets the Road
description: Three Harley-Davidsons sat rumbling near the guardrail at a Yosemite National Park overlook, barely tethered stallions. One rider, wearing leather chaps and a stars and stripes helmet, laughed in the direction of our overloaded BMW R1100R, piled high with bungee-corded duffel bags and camping gear.

title: Get Back on That Steel Stallion and Ride
description: Tales from motorcycle America.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Sam Tanenhaus signs off as host, handing over the reins to Pamela Paul, the new editor of the Book Review, and hearing from past contributors.

title: Transcending Idol, Two Roles at a Time
description: LOS ANGELES  Constantine Maroulis does not want to be thought of as just  his words  that guy with the hair from American Idol.

title: Are You Ready for Some Futebol?
description: The banner-waving, anthem-singing fans of Rio de Janeiros Flamengo club formed a billowing mass of ruby-and  black-clad humanity. They moved not only in reaction to the ebbs and flows on the field far below, but also to the samba beat pounded out by musicians in the midst of the grandstand mayhem around me and my friend Doug. The bands had not stopped playing, and fans had not stopped chanting, in the 18 minutes since the game began.

title: A Taste of Soccer in Brazil
description: As the country prepares to host the World Cup, see scenes from a sport that animates the country.

title: Old Warehouses Go Beyond Storage in Raleigh, N.C.
description: A long-dormant area has started to hum with galleries and shops.

title: New Interior Secretary Is Sworn In
description: Sally Jewell officially became the 51st interior secretary on Friday, taking the oath at noon from retired Justice Sandra Day OConnor in the Supreme Courts West Conference Room, one of two formal ceremonial conference rooms at the court.

title: Two for Life, Following Their Own Destiny
description: Pat and Anne Chang will celebrate their 30th wedding anniversary on July 2, 2013. The couple live and work at Ramapo College in New Jersey, where Pat is associate vice president for student affairs and Anne is an adjunct professor from time to time. They met as graduate students at Columbia University and became engaged in a New York City subway station, which they wrote about in a letter to The New York Times in 1982. Our conversations have been edited and condensed.

title: Barack and Michelle Obamas 2012 Tax Returns
description: President and Michelle Obama released their 2012 tax returns.

title: Cicely Tysons Trip to Wharton
description: Images of Ms. Tysons tour of Wharton, Tex,, the birthplace of the playwright Horton Foote.

title: Book Review Podcast: Sam Tanenhaus Signs Off
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Dan Savage reviews Does Jesus Really Love Me? A Gay Christians Pilgrimage in Search of God in America by Jeff Chu. Mr. Savage writes:

title: On the Market in San Francisco
description: A mansion in Presidio Heights, a co-op on Russian Hill, a three-bedroom in Lower Haight, a Nob Hill home and a SOMA condo with a balcony.

title: In Mexico, Where the Waves Still Win
description: Planning a return trip to my favorite beach in the world, I was almost as apprehensive as I was excited. The last time I visited Troncones  a town of some 600 people pushed up against the Sierra Madre del Sur mountains on the Pacific coast of Mexico  was five years earlier. At the time, wed been living in San Miguel de Allende, and we occasionally drove down with our two sons and two dogs. My husband  an avowed non-beach guy  and I had come to love this village of farmers and fishermen for its rawness, its drowsy authenticity.

title: Sun and Surf in a Small Mexican Beach Town
description: Troncones offers gentle vibes and a dog-friendly atmosphere.

title: Joseph and Jill Bidens 2012 Tax Returns
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Jill Biden released their 2012 tax returns on Friday.

title: A Fur Man, Known to Insiders, Adds Some Fun
description: A FEW TIMES A YEAR, Nick Pologeorgis leaves his familys business on West 29th Street to attend the fur auctions in Toronto, Seattle and St. Petersburg, the home of the Russian sable market. His father, Stanley, started Pologeorgis Furs in 1960; after Nick graduated from Boston University in 1984 with a degree in finance, he joined the firm. His sister, Joan, works on the production side. Lately, if theres one thing Mr. Pologeorgis has noticed at the auctions, aside from rising prices (they have doubled in the last three years), its the number of Chinese bidders. No doubt the two are connected.

title: Looking for Isherwoods Berlin
description: When Christopher Isherwood moved to Berlin in 1929, the 25-year-old British novelist could not quite bring himself to settle down in one place.

title: Austria, Under Pressure, Defends Bank Secrecy Rules
description: DUBLIN  Austria will not yield to pressure to follow Luxembourg in dropping its banking secrecy rules, Finance Minister Maria Fekter said Friday, as she sought to portray Britain as one of the European Unions biggest tax havens.

title: Rights Groups, in Letter to Obama, Question Legality and Secrecy of Drone Killings
description: In a letter sent to President Obama this week, the nations leading human rights organizations questioned the legal basis for targeted killing and called for an end to the secrecy surrounding the use of drones.

title: Twitter Will Introduce a Music Application
description: Twitter is an online service where millions of people go to chat. Now the company behind it is hoping that it will also be where they go to find new music.

title: Near Cut Line, Guan Is Penalized for Slow Play
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The talk during the first day of the Masters was how the Chinese teenager Guan Tianlang seemed so far ahead of his time. At 14, he was playing with the game and the poise of a player twice his age. But on Friday, Guan was punished for dawdling, with a one-stroke penalty for slow play after the 17th hole of his second round at Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Lessons on Bacon, Sex and Nixon, Not Available in a Sitcom
description: When Louis C. K. walks onto a stage in Phoenix at the beginning of Louis C. K.: Oh My God, his new HBO stand-up special, and responds to the crowds applause with what feels like a practiced bit of false modesty  I dont necessarily agree with you but I appreciate it very much  its the only moment that feels inauthentic in the hourlong show. If he didnt agree with the audience, would he have been doing this for more than a quarter-century?

title: Welcome the Librarys Sleeping Lions: River and Dale
description: After a worldwide naming contest, the stone lions snoozing outside the Riverdale branch of the New York Public Library in the Bronx have been officially christened: River and Dale.

title: Indentured Servitude in the Persian Gulf
description: DOHA, Qatar

title: Green Light From Ivy League, but Mixed Signals From Stanford
description: The day I received a rejection letter from Washington University in St. Louis, I talked to my mentor, who currently goes to Harvard. He told me that it gets better after the first rejection.

title: Rick Ross Apologizes for Offensive Lyrics
description: A day after Reebok fired him as a spokesman, the Miami rapper Rick Ross issued a statement apologizing for his lyrics on a song that seemed to condone rape, saying they are offensive, The Associated Press reported.

title: Proving Its Depth
description: The Range Rover, subject of a complete redesign for 2013, still has the capability to carry occupants to places where most owners would never dream of driving.

title: Yes, We Have Ripe Bananas
description: This weeks column comes from my being in a constant state of having too many ripe bananas in the house. Its either that or having no ripe bananas at all. I cant seem to get into a rhythm of acquiring just the right amount, which I suppose is because what might have worked last week is either too much or not enough this week. And so it goes.

title: What the Brain Can Tell Us About Art
description: THIS month, President Obama unveiled a breathtakingly ambitious initiative to map the human brain, the ultimate goal of which is to understand the workings of the human mind in biological terms.

title: Charting Vampire Weekends New Album
description: The New York indie rock band  Vampire Weekend will release its third album, Modern Vampires of the City, on XL on May 14. The artist Andrew Kuo breaks down two new songs, Step and Diane Young, whose video features Saabs burning against a Manhattan cityscape.

title: Week in Review: From Banes of Zuckerberg to Bitcoin Moguls
description: Never mind Facebook; the Winklevoss twins rule in digital money. | An ex-KPMG partner is charged in insider case. | Seeking relief, banks are shift risk to murkier corners. | Ex-regulators are finding a home with a powerful firm. | A solution for Penney may be to sell itself, or some of its assets. | A battle is heating up over the fate of a troubled energy buyout.

title: Goldman Raises Directors Pay by 500 Shares
description: Goldman Sachs directors are getting a pay raise.

title: Raj Chetty Wins the John Bates Clark Medal
description: Raj Chetty, an economist at Harvard University, has won the 2013 John Bates Clark Medal, a laurel considered by many economists to be second only to the Nobel Prize.

title: Mad Men Predictions: What Do You Think Will Happen Sunday?
description: On the season premiere of Mad Men, Don Draper showed up drunk at a funeral and his ex-wife, Betty, showed up brunet after a foray to the East Village. Though its a sure bet Don will be drinking again on Sundays episode (when does he not?), any guesses on what else will happen? In a new feature, heres your chance to make your predictions. Check back next week to see how you did.

title: Consultant Recants in Chevron Pollution Case in Ecuador
description: HOUSTON  An environmental case that has pitted Chevron against Ecuadorean Amazon villagers for two decades has taken another bizarre twist, with an American consulting firm now recanting research favorable to the villagers claims of pollution in remote tracts of jungle.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers:  Scott Snyders  American Vampire
description: The writer Scott Snyder seems to be making a home out of our hardcover list. This week, Volume 5 of American Vampire, about a new breed of bloodsucker, enters the list at No. 2. (He is also the writer behind the Batman stories at No. 1 and No. 8.) In this latest installment of American Vampire, Mr. Snyder has been blessed with two gifted collaborators: Rafael Albuquerque, the original series artist, and Dustin Nguyen, who illustrates a spin-off story included in this collection. Though vampires have seemingly given up their number one status in pop culture to zombies, Mr. Snyder proves there are still plenty of tales to tell about these creatures of the night. Mr. Nguyen lends his wonderfully expressive and moody art to an adventure involving the hunt for the granddaddy of all vampires, Dracula, while Mr. Albuquerque illustrates the exploration of all things related to Skinner Sweet, the first American vampire, who is more vicious and less bothered by sunlight. The only drawback to reading this book in collected form is that the reader does not get to long savor the cliffhangers with which Mr. Snyder ends most issues. (Click here for a profile on Mr. Snyder from Sept. 2011.)

title: The Business of Being | India Hicks
description: India Hicks adds another facet to her ever-growing brand with the debut of her home line for HSN this week. The author, model, designer, hotelier and mother has curated a brand that encompasses both her English upbringing and current Island lifestyle. The daughter of David Nightingale Hicks, the famed interior designer, and Lady Pamela Mountbatten, India has been surrounded by style from an early age. From fine jewelry to home goods to tropical properties, T Magazine breaks down the world of India Hicks.

title: A Rich Nod to Old Elegance
description: Few of the old-school Italian restaurants remain in San Franciscos North Beach neighborhood  the kind of places where the waiters wear red jackets, the wine list is bound in leather and the menus size makes it hard to see ones tablemates.

title: Pictures of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Serbia, Egypt, India and Syria.

title: Adam Smith Hates Bitcoin
description: There have been many good pieces written on the dubious economics of Bitcoin; I especially liked this one by Neil Irwin. One thing I havent seen emphasized, however, is the extent to which the whole concept of having to mine Bitcoins by expending real resources amounts to a drastic retrogression  a retrogression that Adam Smith would have scorned.

title: Someones Ruffled Her Feathers, and Shes in Perpetual Motion
description: At the start of Kinetic Makeover, the choreographer Milka Djordjevich stands with her back to the audience. She stands there a long time, in silence, dressed in a pink and blue top and tight sherbet-orange pants (designed by Reid Bartelme). Almost imperceptibly, she begins to sway side to side. Gradually, the swaying swells, her knees bending, her torso pitching, until she has rocked herself onto the floor in a seated position and turned her face front. . Her eyes continue to ticktock, left, right, left.

title: Lessons in Domestic Diplomacy
description: I CALLED IT THE 7:42 P.M. FIGHT. It happened every night when my wife and I gathered to discuss the detritus of our lives. Whos waking up early with the kids? Whos going to take Grandma to the eye doctor? What do you mean you forgot to pick up the milk?

title: F.D.A. Issues Warning on Workout Supplement
description: Certain workout-booster and fat-burning products, sold in recent years by retailers like GNC and Vitamin Shoppe, are illegal and may present serious health hazards to consumers, federal health regulators have determined.

title: A Premiere, Shimmering and Spectral
description: The American conductor David Robertson and the French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard share a gift for devising programs that juxtapose old and new works in fascinating ways. So it was on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, when Mr. Robertson conducted the New York Philharmonic with Mr. Aimard as soloist.

title: Can You Say Do It Again in Norwegian?
description: In January Kon-Tiki, a biopic about the Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl and his perilous 1947 journey across the Pacific on a balsa-wood raft, was nominated for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film. (It lost to Michael Hanekes Amour.) On April 26 the film will be released commercially in the United States  but in a version that is entirely in English, rather than in the original Norwegian.

title: Same Scene, Different Languages
description: A comparison of a scene from both the English-language and Norwegian-language versions of Kon-Tiki.

title: Lost Plenty of Pounds, but Not a Lightweight
description: BIG WATER, Utah  On the specification sheet for the 2013 Range Rover is an entry you dont often see applied to a luxury vehicle: wading depth, 35.4 inches.

title: A Case of Spontaneous Attraction
description: TESTED 2013 Hyundai Elantra GT

title: With Land Rover Heritage, but Destined for Asphalt Jungles
description: The new-for-2014 Range Rover Sport made its world premiere in Manhattan on March 26, on the eve of press previews for the New York auto show. Though the city might not seem to be a Range Rovers preferred habitat, the setting was entirely appropriate: the United States is the biggest market for the Sport model and New York accounts for the most sales of any city.

title: Newtown Parent to Give White House Address
description: 6:42 a.m. | Updated  Coverage of the address is available here.

title: Obamas Income Has Dropped, Their Tax Returns Show
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas personal income has plummeted in the four years since he was first inaugurated, thanks mostly to declining sales of his two best-selling books, according to his 2012 tax returns released on Friday.

title: Australias Brand Name for Ferocity, Softened by Time
description: MELBOURNE, Australia

title: Yankees Rodriguez Tied to Clinic Records Purchase
description: Former employees of a now-shuttered South Florida anti-aging clinic and others who had ties to it have told Major League Baseball that the YankeesAlex Rodriguez arranged to purchase documents from the clinic to keep them out of the hands of baseball officials, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Colleges Struggling to Stay Afloat
description: STUDENTS piling on debt to go to college might attract all the attention, but colleges have been on a borrowing spree as well, nearly doubling the amount of debt theyve taken on in the last decade to fix aging campuses, keep up with competitors and lure students with lavish amenities.

title: The Faces That Would Be Mayor
description: Portraits of candidates for mayor of New York, photographed by The Timess Damon Winter.

title: First Tastes of the 2012 Bordeaux
description: PAUILLAC, FranceI joined hundreds of wine buyers and critics for the annual tastings of the new vintage in Bordeaux this week. But amid all the talk of business, the wines themselves sometimes seemed to be overshadowed. So how does 2012 Bordeaux look?

title: Ts Spring Design Issue
description: The actress Julianne Moore, photographed by Inez and Vinoodh, is the cover subject of the Spring Design issue of T, where we learn how the natural beauty likes to play against type. Inside: discover the glories of Lowcountry cooking in Charleston, read Nicky Haslams take on how good and bad taste evolve over time, and admire the rich tones and gems inside jewelry designer Marie-Helene de Taillacs apartment in Paris. Other spots on this issues house tours: the Milan town house of the C.E.O. of Kartell, Irene Silvagnis wonderfully imperfect Provenal retreat and the landscape designer Piet Oudolfs lush home in Nantucket. Finally, take a look at a collection of Great Gatsby editions that offer an illuminating cross section of 83 years of book design. See all from the issue >>

title: Injecting a Little Levity: Heaven With Rodgers and Hart
description: For some lucky musicians, like John Pizzarelli, work and play are pretty much the same thing. At any of Mr. Pizzarellis concerts, with or without his singing and life partner, Jessica Molaskey, Mr. Pizzarelli conveys a contagious enjoyment that transports you to a place where worries recede, and you can coast along with him to a jazz-pop heaven.

title: Ah, Brains: To Eat or Not to Eat?
description: You wont find Yoricks skull in Living Dead in Denmark, the Just Kidding Theater Companys antic production at the Gene Frankel Theater. But you will find bound human heads suspended on a wall en route to your seat. Youll also find Shakespearean characters, men in drag, a villain called Lady Gaga and more zombies than you can shake a broadsword at.

title: Bach Suites, Without a Break or Pedal
description: When Andras Schiff performed Bachs six English Suites on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, he played the first four  almost 90 minutes of music  with barely a pause. In an onstage interview after the concert, the WNYC radio host John Schaefer commented that it had almost seemed like an athletic feat, one both mental and physical.

title: BBC Wont Ban Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead, Adopted as Anti-Thatcher Anthem
description: Last Updated, 6:13 p.m. The BBC on Friday rejected loud calls to ban the song Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead from its airwaves after the apparent success of a Facebook campaign to celebrate the death of Margaret Thatcher, the divisive former prime minister, by driving sales of the tune from The Wizard of Oz up the British singles chart.

title: Think Positive, and Try Not to Burn Your Bottom: Desert Island Dos and Donts
description: Some shows come with a strong-sexual-content warning. Some come with a graphic-violence warning. Not too many come with a buttocks warning.

title: Highlights of Jonathan Winterss Career
description: A selection of comedic moments from Jonathan Winters's career.

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz Trio
description: Theyre still incredibly young  but awesomely talented, and theyve gotten deeper since I first posted one of their performances:

title: Japans Rootless and Restless Workers
description: Shiho Fukada has been photographing the effects of the economic crisis in Japan, where notions of personal prosperity and lifetime employment have eroded.

title: Food, Beer and Culture Mash for Benefit
description: http://vimeo.com/61980712

title: Play at the Charlottesville, Va., Regional
description: The most successful players at the Charlottesville, Va., regional from Feb. 25 to March 3 were Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York City; Kevin Bathurst of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.; and Justin Lall of Las Vegas. They played in two knockout teams and one Swiss team and won all three.

title: Mortgage Market Shifts
description: The share of mortgage originations belonging to Fannie/Freddie vs. the F.H.A. The share of private vs. F.H.A. mortgage insurance.

title: Former Credit Suisse Executive Pleads Guilty to Inflating the Value of Mortgage Bonds
description: A former senior trader at Credit Suisse Group pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that he fraudulently inflated the value of mortgage bonds as the housing market collapsed, becoming one of the highest-ranking Wall Street executives to admit to crimes related to the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Bequest to the Boy Next Door
description: Ray Knox still owns and occasionally rides the custom-made French bicycle that he pedaled from Paris to Athens in 1984, solo, when he was 25.

title: High-Class Hand-Me-Down
description: Ray Knox was a high school senior when he inherited a 1966 Cadillac Fleetwood from a neighbor. Decades later, it remains a treasure.

title: Looking for Green on the Big Screen
description: Now that spring has (finally) brought bloom-inducing weather to the city, many of us are turning our focus to what can be done with gardens and balconies, decks and window boxes and stoops. For landscape designers, however, the lens is always and everywhere open  even in darkened movie theaters.

title: Some Classic Match-Ups of Brazilian Football
description: Some Classic Match-Ups of Brazilian Football

title: Editors Lab at the NYT
description: Next weekend, April 2021, The New York Times will host an Editors Lab event. Organized by the Global Editors Network (GEN), the Editors Lab will bring together teams from top media companies for two days of working sessions and talks. Each team will consist of a journalist, a designer and a developer. The hack event at the Times building will be the fifth in a tournament series that began in Buenos Aires and culminates at the GEN News Summit in Paris in June. Well post details next week; meanwhile, you can learn more at the GEN site.

title: Eluding Ennui and Bad Relatives
description: Repo Man

title: Vying for a Spot on the Worlds A List
description: SO NOW we know. After months of hype and speculation, the winners were announced last month. These were not the Oscars, but the World Reputation Rankings, the worlds definitive index of academic prestige, according to its publisher, Times Higher Education, a weekly magazine based in London.

title: Answers: Astronomy
description: WHATS OUT THERE? JUST DO THE MATH

title: Answers: Human Ecology
description: 1. c. Lifes boundaries are not always clear. One fungus occupies about 2,384 acres of the forest floor in eastern Oregon, the filaments extending along the root systems of trees. The Pando aspen grove, once thought to be the largest organism, consists of about 47,000 genetically identical trees on 107 acres.

title: Trimming the Ivy
description: TOM HARKIN, chairman of the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, who has represented Iowa in Congress since 1974, has announced that he will not seek re-election in 2014. Senator Harkin, a 73-year-old Democrat, is an old-fashioned, plainspoken populist  the driving force behind the 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act and a strong proponent of reforming health care.

title: Two, Three Essays? More Can Mean Less
description: DURING a staff retreat last winter, Boston Colleges admissions officers decided something had to change. Although the college was receiving more applications each year, increasingly larger shares of admitted students were choosing to go elsewhere. Between 2004 and 2011, the colleges yield  the proportion of accepted students who enroll  had declined from 32 percent to 23 percent. Some applicants, says John L. Mahoney, director of undergraduate admissions, probably werent very serious about us all along.

title: Technion
description: Technion

title: The Technion: Israels Hard Drive
description: WHEN the Technion class of 1957 graduated, its members got together and wrote a letter of complaint to their prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, who was otherwise busy building a nation. There were no jobs for us in our fields, recalls Gideon F. Inbar, an electrical engineer who is now 79. My wife kept saying, Oy, things are grim, grim, grim.

title: Signs of Easier Money for Mortgages
description: What was so unusual about Phillip Ratliffs experience in getting approval for his first mortgage was that it wasnt difficult at all  even though he could afford a down payment of only 5 percent.

title: Embracing Technology, for Better or Worse
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about financial advisers increasing interest in technology. He raises two questions about expanded use of technology: Will it help advisers do their job better? And will it be better for clients or confuse and frustrate them?

title: Glued to the Tube
description: Here are six other YouTube

title: E.P.A. Will Delay Rule Limiting Carbon Emissions at New Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency said Friday that it would delay issuance of a new rule limiting emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases from new power plants after the electric power industry objected on legal and technical grounds.

title: Design in Milan | Nikes Natural Motion
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Savory Taste of the Pampas
description: The first empanada I ever had was made by an Argentine friend in college. That countrys version of the small South American meat patty features a substantial beef filling tucked into a flaky shell, and it was love at first bite. Ive had dozens and dozens of empanadas since, made in almost as many styles, but it was the one from Gaucho Grill, an Argentine restaurant that opened in White Plains last year, that gave me the biggest thrill since my first.

title: Seven Pinots to Pair With Duck
description: Many red wine lovers consider pinot noir and duck an ideal combination. And many fans of duck think the white Pekin breed farmed on Long Island is Americas best. Thats where East End pinot noir producers come in.

title: Kosher Food Makers Inventory Seized Over Rodent Infestation
description: Fans of KoJel kosher foods like instant pudding, hot chocolate mix and instant noodle soup, brace yourselves: V.I.P. Foods, the Queens food supplier that manufactures the products, had about $1 million in inventory seized by the federal Food and Drug Administration because of widespread rodent infestation, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

title: First-Timers, Out to Charm
description: Some towns on Long Island have so many restaurants (Huntington and Rockville Centre come to mind) that competition can be fierce. Babylon is another one. That is the only explanation I can find for the scarcity of patrons on recent visits to the 11-month-old Nocturne Dining and Spirits there.

title: Advisers Urge Political Changes in Italy to Break Stalemate
description: BY GAIA PIANIGIANI

title: When Small Appliances Misbehave
description: Its not even Halloween, and Dimension Films (the Weinstein Companys horror, action and sophomoric-comedy arm) is releasing Scary Movie V, the latest installment of the slick, highly profitable parody franchise. Hollywood has certainly kept the screenwriters (the Scary Movie veterans Pat Profft and David Zucker) supplied with material: the biggest targets here are the Paranormal Activity series, Black Swan and Rise of the Planet of the Apes, with nods to Mama, The Ring, Saw and others.

title: The Woman With 1 Billion Clicks: Jenna Marbles
description: A young woman with magenta-streaked hair stands in her bathroom, speaking to a webcam. In a hushed tone, she chews over a thorny problem of young adulthood: how to apply full evening makeup when youre already inebriated from drinking all day?

title: A Mortgage Holiday for Some Borrowers Hurt by Hurricane
description: Thousands of homeowners whose properties were damaged by Hurricane Sandy and cannot make their mortgage payments have gotten another reprieve  the federal government announced Friday that borrowers with home loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration could suspend mortgage payments for up to one year while they repair their homes.

title: Bonhomie, Even if They Dont Know Your Name
description: When he was a boy, back in the 1970s, Michael Pryer often accompanied his father to a bar called Flynns, in Chatham. Over the years, he mused about turning the scruffy bar into a place where customers could order more than just a liverwurst or Taylor ham, egg and cheese sandwich  the only items the kitchen served back then, Mr. Pryer, 47, recalled over the telephone after my visits.

title: The Taste Divide
description: How does an actress design her image? In our celebrity-obsessed culture, she usually dresses in the very latest fashion and has her photographs airbrushed into superhuman oblivion. Julianne Moore, while she indeed looks ravishing in films and on the red carpet, and even in her sweatpants at morning drop off (where I see her from time to time as our children attend the same school), is not such an actress. She is someone who rather pushes the boundaries in her acting in order to inhabit the characters she plays. For this issue she collaborated with the photographers Inez and Vinoodh and the makeup wizard Peter Philips, all artists in their own right, who seek to extend our way of seeing. Here they show us a more real, and even exaggerated side of Moores natural beauty. Freckled from birth (and not in a cute way, she explains in the piece), Moores face was sprinkled by Philips with even more spots. The resulting image, unlike most cover shots, isnt retouched to perfection. The power comes from Moores striking and honest intensity, and from her scarcely made-up face, remarkable and beautiful at age 52.

title: A Chat With Raj Chetty, Clark Medalist
description: This afternoon, we caught up with Raj Chetty, the 33-year-old Harvard economist who is the latest winner of the John Bates Clark Medal, a prestigious award for economists under the age of 40. Mr. Chetty is a public economist whose work has addressed topics including the returns from education, tax policies and savings behavior, often by parsing huge troves of data. This interview was lightly edited for clarity.

title: Qualifying for a Mortgage
description: You probably know someone who has a good story to tell about how difficult it was to get a mortgage in the wake of the housing crisis.

title: Test Run: What Mobile Payments Companies Can Learn From Chipotle
description: The lingering problem with mobile payments is that its usually no more convenient to pay with a phone instead of cash or credit card. Squares wallet, for example, a feature that promises to let you pay simply by saying your name at the register of participating businesses, is clunky and has rarely worked when we have tried.

title: Lone Wolf Theory Gains Ground in Texas Deaths
description: KAUFMAN, Tex.  Soon after one of his prosecutors was shot and killed here in January, the district attorney in this rural county outside Dallas, Mike McLelland, told colleagues that he believed the victim was the target of a specific disgruntled defendant whom his office had successfully prosecuted.

title: Tax Disincentives for Working Moms
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Portions, Big Flavors and Easygoing Spirit
description: In Darien Social, a year-old place at the corner of Center Street and Boston Post Road, across from the railroad station, it looks  judging by the evening crowds  as though the town has found a new hangout for the under-40 crowd. After 7 p.m., its usually packed and noisy.

title: As the Senate Agrees to Consider Gun Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Bulls: (More Than) a Little Traveling Music
description: One could make a case that Major League Soccers schedule-maker did the Red Bulls no favors early in the season and that the club has followed suit.

title: Bill Cunningham | Dress Rehearsal
description: Spring fashions, along with the parks palette of daffodil yellow and tulip pink, set the style tone.

title: Indias Ruling on a Novartis Drug: 2 Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Along With Its Community, a Theater Reboots
description: Later this month, the Surflight Theater in Beach Haven will roll out its 64th season with shows that lend themselves to escapism. We want people to come to the theater and relax a little bit, said Ken Myers, the executive director.

title: Morsi Shows Support for Egypts Military
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsi appeared with Egypts top general on Friday as the military leader denied recent news reports that soldiers may have detained, tortured and killed civilian protesters during the 18-day uprising that ousted former President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Experiment in Oregon Gives Medicaid Very Local Roots
description: SALEM, Ore.  Some say America has been homogenized, a chain-store nation bereft of regional distinction in dialect or dinner. But now this state, at the pioneers end of the road, is testing the idea that local community difference is alive and well, and that grass-roots leadership holds the key to fixing health care in America.

title: Help for Syrian Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvesting Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Facebook Helps Reduce Prom-Dress Angst
description: Just before this years Oscars ceremony, Anne Hathaway ditched a Valentino gown for Prada when she found out that her co-star Amanda Seyfried was set to wear a similar dress.

title: Prom Night Inspired by Oscar
description: Ive got girls whipping out their iPhones, Stacey Rywelski, the manager of Davids Bridal in Long Island City, said the other day. Theyll say, What do you guys have that looks like this?

title: Obama Sees Insurers; Health Law Is Subject
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama met with insurance industry executives at the White House on Friday to coordinate the introduction this fall of the insurance marketplaces at the heart of the national health care law, and to discuss so-called rate shock if the industry sharply raises premiums.

title: Jealousy and Its Shakespearean Outcome
description: Oh, please, King Leontes. So your breathtakingly gorgeous wife flirted a little too much with your best friend after dinner. Give the woman a break. Shes got to be eight months pregnant. And youre the one who keeps inviting the man to stay longer at your house, palace, whatever.

title: Week in Pictures for April 12
description: Subjects include a real estate broker-tax preparer, a protest over fast-food restaurant pay and auditions for the School of American Ballet

title: The Well-Trained Eye of an Art Historian
description: Amy Fine Collins, a former art historian and author of the memoir The God of Driving, has been a special correspondent for Vanity Fair since 1993. Born in Fairfield, Conn., and raised in Bucks County, Pa., and Knoxville, Tenn., Ms. Fine Collins, who says she is in her early 50s, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Bradley Collins Jr., who teaches art history at Parsons the New School for Design.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Cuomo Cleared to Bring Girlfriend When He Rides State Planes
description: Sandra Lee seems to be ready for takeoff.

title: Students Told to Take Viewpoint of the Nazis
description: ALBANY  High school is full of hypotheticals, like How does one solve for x? and What happens if I skip class? But this week, students at Albany High School were given an alarming thought puzzle: How do I convince my teacher that I think Jews are evil?

title: Inflation Is Miserable. Unemployment Is Worse.
description: Unemployment makes people unhappy, according to economic research. So does inflation. But heres the part the economists are paid for: evidence that unemployment makes people more miserable than inflation.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: E-Mail Cachet and Cellphone Dial Tones
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Drop in Home Loans Takes Toll on Banks
description: Wall Street knew the craze wouldnt last.

title: Syrian Rebels Break With Group Over Qaeda Wing Alliance
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A leading coalition of Syrian Islamist insurgents broke with a more radical group on Friday, sharply criticizing its announced alliance with Al Qaedas Iraq branch as a moral and political mistake that would benefit only their common enemy, President Bashar al-Assad.

title: A Revered French Winery Breaks With a Bordeaux Tradition
description: PAUILLAC, France  As they have every April for decades, wine merchants from around the world donned their tweed jackets, tucked in their pocket squares and descended on Bordeaux this week to assess the latest vintage. In visits to revered chateaus in localities like Pomerol, Margaux and Saint-Estphe, they swirled, sniffed, spat and scored the 2012 Bordeaux.

title: Chinatown, Not the Film, but the Trial
description: A Chinatown gangster and seven or eight of his flunkies supposedly entered a gambling parlor in 2001, walked straight over to a man who owed them money and beat him. The gambler would, 12 years later, be referred to in court documents simply as Victim 1.

title: China Must Exploit Its Shale Gas
description: BEIJING

title: A Musical View of Abraham Lincoln
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  At a recent rehearsal of the Metropolitan Philharmonic Chorus, Leonard J. Lehrman, its founder and director, stopped the music briefly to speak of his emotional response to a particular moment in Steven Spielbergs recent film Lincoln.

title: In Washington, Clamming for Food and Tradition
description: OCEAN CITY, Wash.  Some razor clammers take a methodical line, a slow, eyes-down stroll through the outgoing tide, watching for the telltale quarter-size divot that marks a clams hiding spot, two feet or so below the surface.

title: Bezoss Shout-Out for His Cloud Service
description: On Friday Jeff Bezos sent a mash note to the cloud.

title: Week in Pictures for April 12
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a real estate broker-tax preparer, a protest over fast-food restaurant pay and auditions for the School of American Ballet.

title: Congress Is Socially Insecure
description: When it comes to congressmen behaving badly  and such a list it is, my friends  the prize this week goes to Representative Greg Walden of Oregon. Although I am sorry to say that his bad behavior does not involve any interesting new illicit sex issues.

title: Vows: Wedding Dress Preservation
description: The textile conservation expert Jonathan Scheer shows us what not to do when putting away a wedding gown for storage.

title: My Other Car Is a 1962 Oldsmobile Starfire
description: The Aug. 22, 2005, obituary for Edna Potvin in The Glens Falls Post-Star included a note about her car: Mrs. Potvin was well known in the Glens Falls area for the immaculate turquoise and black 1962 Oldsmobile Starfire, which she drove until the age of 90.

title: Contrasting Views on North Korea Underscore Sensitivities and Lack of Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  On the hawkish end is the Pentagons intelligence arm, the Defense Intelligence Agency, which fears that North Korea could threaten American troops with a nuclear weapon on a crude missile. On the skeptical end is the State Department, which has more doubts about Pyongyangs capabilities. And somewhere in the middle is the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Mindful of Drugs, Race Officials Will Keep Closer Eye on Kentucky Derby
description: The 72 hours before the Kentucky Derby traditionally have been filled with steam, as it is known in racetrack parlance  rumors about which horse is due for a big race and which veterinarians are working overtime to get their horses to the gate. But for the first time in the 139 years of the race, the authorities this year will know precisely who is going into which barn in the hours leading up to the race and for what reason.

title: Teachers: Will We Ever Learn?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Jenna Marbles on YouTube (and Her Dogs)
description: After The New York Times sat down with Jenna Marbles, she made a video answering some questions from the newspaper about her work, her puppies, and her magical YouTube videos.

title: Pettitte to Skip Scheduled Start Sunday Because of Back Spasms
description: Andy Pettitte was at home Thursday night when he and, in turn, the Yankees were reminded once again of their collective fragility. The 40-year-old Pettitte was getting off his couch when his lower back locked up.

title: BlackBerry Disputes Report on Z10 Phone
description: OTTAWA  BlackBerry contends that a securities analysts report about its latest phone is not only wrong, its so wrong that it should be investigated by securities regulators.

title: Longtime CUNY Chancellor to Step Down After Pushing Higher Standards
description: Matthew Goldstein, who oversaw an expansion of the citys public college system and set out to raise its prestige with a new honors college and other measures, announced on Friday that he would step down after 14 years as chancellor of the City University of New York.

title: Bomb North Korea, Before Its Too Late
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Day Edges Into Lead After Woods Hits Flagstick and Falls Back
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods was cruising. Tied for the lead in the second round of the Masters and the only player in the field who had not bogeyed a hole, he stood in perfect position in the 15th fairway.

title: Steely Leader of South Korea Is Battle-Ready
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Her mother was shot by an assassin. Her father, a staunchly anti-Communist dictator, was similarly killed. And she survived a vicious razor attack to the face.

title: Building Better Halfway Houses
description: With corrections costs exceeding $50 billion a year, federal and state officials are understandably eager to make sure that the hundreds of thousands of people released annually from prison get the drug treatment, job placement and support services they need to have a chance at crime-free lives.

title: A Phantom Ad Comes to New York
description: New York City voters have enjoyed the best and fairest campaign finance system in the country for almost 25 years. Now, a shadowy group organized as New York City Is Not for Sale is attempting to influence this years mayoral race with a secretive, independent committee much like those that have so tainted federal elections in recent years. This is the last thing the city needs.

title: The North Korea Problem
description: Secretary of State John Kerry sent several important messages to North Korea after talks on Friday in Seoul with South Korean leaders. Speaking at a news conference, he said that the United States would defend its South Korean and Japanese allies if there was conflict, that the international community would never accept the North as a nuclear weapons state, and that Washington was willing to resume long-stalled negotiations but only if the North Koreans agreed to move seriously on denuclearization.

title: A Box of Sheep
description: This week, a sheep arrived in a box. Not the whole sheep, which is still, I hope, grazing happily in a pasture somewhere in northeast Washington State. Only its fleece. Ive raised many animals but never sheep. My dad, who raised them as a farm boy, left me with a vicious prejudice against them, and the only sheep I saw as a boy did nothing to counter it. They stood  a dim, ghostly flock  in a grove they had denuded entirely of grass and undergrowth.
