It occurs to me now that this was the fault of the farmer, not of the sheep, who have no more interest in eating bare dirt than I do.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Second Round: Masters Replay
description: Big putts, slow play and changes on the leader board in the second round.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: J.C. Penneys chief executive, Ron Johnson, is ousted; Aereo, a television streaming service, wins an appellate decision; and gold prices are plummeting.

title: Joe, Jack and Frank: An Alternative History
description: In a two-page timeline for Ride the Tiger, the Long Wharf Theater program tracks the two decades from Joe Kennedys ill-judged, career-killing statement in 1940 that democracy is finished in England to the 1963 assassination of his son John in Dallas. But wise theatergoers will pay no attention at all to these hard facts. They will instead just follow along with the fancies of the playwright, William Mastrosimone, as he constructs a clever, vastly entertaining counter-history of Camelot.

title: Tasting Good Life, Opposition in Zimbabwe Slips Off Pedestal
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The guests arrived in Bentleys, Benzes and BMWs. At a plush, riverside wedding in an upscale suburb, the wine and spirits flowed and tables groaned with the ample buffet. Politicians, celebrities, diplomats and business leaders mingled to the strains of Oliver Mtukudzi, a Zimbabwean music star, serenading the happy couple with his famous love song Svovi Yangu.

title: Corrections: April 13, 2013
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Play Both Sides
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Its not easy to stack 15-letter entries, even one atop the other, and still integrate them meaningfully into a crossword puzzle. Very often, what the constructor winds up with is either junk fill, or he or she rips the section out and starts again. Dont even get me started on quad stacks.

title: The le  Vache: From Hope to Disaster
description: Virginias massive Fortress Monroe, operating under Union control from the beginning of the war, played witness to an unusual sight on the morning of April 14, 1863. For some six days prior the Ocean Ranger lay at anchor in sight of the forts guns as a steady stream of food and supplies were carried aboard. The brigs main cargo, however, consisted of passengers  specifically 453 recently freed African-Americans  about to set sail for a new life in Haiti.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Using Nature to Depict Itself
description: Ellie Irons keeps her eyes to the ground in her Bushwick, Brooklyn, neighborhood. She is looking for plant life, invasive species that pop up beside tree roots and between cracks in the sidewalk. She plucks what she finds and, back in her studio, researches their identities and their origins. Then she crushes them to produce colors she uses to paint maps tracing their journeys to New York.

title: After Conviction in 75 Murder Is Thrown Out, Victims Family Relives Pain
description: The last time Walter J. Smith saw his little sister Karen alive, on a warm spring day, March 28, 1975, she was on her way to the corner store to buy a 100 Grand candy bar. Hours later, at 1:50 a.m., her body was found in a darkened 16th-floor stairwell of the South Bronx housing project where she lived. The 8-year-old girl had been raped, stabbed and left to die  the candy bar wrapper by her side.

title: Padres Quentin Suspended After Brawl Injures Dodgers Pitcher
description: Beyond the suspensions that Major League Baseball handed down Friday for a fight between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres on Thursday night, one real cost to the Dodgers was already known: $531,250.

title: Once the Story, Now Shes Telling It
description: WAXHAW, N.C.  After weeks of hopscotching across the country on assignments for NBCs Today, Jenna Bush Hager settled her pregnant frame into an oversize leather couch here to conduct an interview. Her subject was Jackson TerKeurst, a 24-year-old Liberian college student who was adopted as a teenager by a local family.

title: From Expert Cooks, a Baroque Banquet
description: SAN FRANCISCO  New York Citys early-music scene has fostered a number of fine period-instrument ensembles in the recent past. But for a full-size orchestra of period-instrument specialists who have played together for decades under the direction of a committed and charismatic conductor, New Yorkers need to look west  and may well do so with envy. On Thursday evening the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra, led by Nicholas McGegan, gave a performance of Handels Teseo at the Herbst Theater here that confirmed its leading position in the field.

title: Rights Groups Share Concerns Over Target Killings
description: Several human rights and civil rights groups wrote a letter asking the Obama administration to take essential steps to reform the nations policy regarding drone killings.

title: Dancing Across the Decades
description: As a teenager growing up in Brooklyn, Esther Rabinowitz jitterbugged her way through the Great Depression, and even now, at age 90, she has never really stopped.

title: Social Media, Pushing Reebok To Drop a Rapper
description: The groundswell of protests that has apparently forced Reebok to end its relationship with the rapper Rick Ross has focused attention on the feminist group UltraViolet, which harnessed social media and even placed ads on Facebook in a campaign against Mr. Ross after he rapped about drugging a woman and having sex with her without her knowledge.

title: If You Dont Like the View, Just Wait a Few Measures
description: This week the Joyce Theater Foundation continued its efforts to expand its brand  and audience  with a gala presentation on Wednesday featuring a variety of companies and artists at the David H. Koch Theater. They included the Nederland Dans Theater, which also performed the next two nights. But what of expanding the art form? If you judged by these performances, this seemed to be of little concern.

title: Early in Mayoral Battle, Carriage Horses Are Drawn Into Race
description: As a political issue, it has legs. Four legs.

title: Conserving Their Energy, Knicks Shift Into Cruise Control
description: CLEVELAND  The last time the Knicks faced the Cavaliers here was a low point for Carmelo Anthony. He fell on his swollen right knee and had to leave the game. Afterward, he revealed for the first time how much the injury had been bothering him.

title: Questioning Zimbabwes Underdogs
description: As elections near, some voters who once had faith in Morgan Tsvangirais opposition party ask if it has been tainted by governing with Robert Mugabe.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. The Woolworth Building celebrates its 100th birthday this month. Can you tell me a few things about it?

title: Mets-Twins Take Field Thanks to Grounds Crew
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Shortly before the Minnesota Twins took the field for batting practice Friday, the exhausted head groundskeeper, Larry DiVito, looked around at an empty and snow-free Target Field with stoic appreciation. A little more than 24 hours after a spring storm had dumped 5.1 inches of snow downtown, DiVito described how dozens of workers had readied the field for the Mets and the Twins to play.

title: North Koreas Nuclear Threats, in Focus
description: A detailed overview of the military tension on the Korean Peninsula, with photographs, graphics and reactions from residents of the region.

title: Pizza Cravings Satisfied, Finally
description: The pizza at Totonnos in Coney Island has received enough glowing words in its nine-decade history that it doesnt need more here, except perhaps two: its back. Five months after the restaurant on Neptune Avenue was flooded during Hurricane Sandy, the three sibling owners  Antoinette Balzano, Frank Balzano and Louise Ciminieri  reopened for business on March 24.

title: Horses Enter the Race
description: Proposals to ban horse carriages and other animal rights issues surfaced at a forum for Democratic candidates during the New York City mayoral election campaign.

title: Hearing Set on Cheating Claim in Capital
description: The City Council in Washington will hold a hearing next week after a memo warning officials of cheating on standardized tests during the chancellorship of Michelle A. Rhee surfaced Thursday night.

title: An Error and a Triple Play Brighten the Yanks Night
description: It was not exactly raining Friday at Yankee Stadium. The night was cold and windy and somewhat misty, and after being exposed to that weather for a while, the skin became cold and damp.

title: A Pastime Thrives in the Northwest
description: In a tradition that goes back thousands of years, enthusiasts dig Pacific razor clams, which are sweet, meaty and at home in high-end restaurants.

title: A Day Away From the Stage
description: The soprano Deborah Voigt carries a shield and runs up and down a complicated stage set in her role as Brnnhilde in the Metropolitan Opera production of Wagners Ring cycle. But on Sundays, even Valkyries like to kick back. Generally its the one day off that I dont have to work, so I try not to schedule too many things, Ms. Voigt, 52, said. Though she has a condominium in Florida, Ms. Voigt spends most of her time these days in an apartment in Hells Kitchen, with an 11-year-old Yorkshire terrier named Steinway. The Ring cycle  Ms. Voigt sings in"Die Walkre,""Siegfried and Gtterdmmerung  runs through May 11.

title: Washington Eyes Raising State Tuition of Foreigners
description: Some Washington State legislators are proposing a 20 percent tuition surcharge for international students at the states public universities and community colleges as a way to raise revenues.

title: Nets Start Impressively and Hold On
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Nets have had a playoff spot secured for several weeks now, and their seeding  third, fourth or fifth  has been the only thing at stake since. They might have begun resting players, or relaxed a bit, or even conceded a game or two, and few would have questioned it.

title: Matching Students With Schools
description: As chief executive of the Office of Student Enrollment in New York Citys Education Department, Robert Sanft, 41, places tens of thousands of students each year in public schools. He and his team of nearly 200 handle prekindergarten admissions, gifted and talented slots and the high school matching process. A graduate of New York public schools, Mr. Sanft lives in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, with his wife, his son, a fourth grader, and his daughter, who is in prekindergarten. They attend public school.

title: Detroits Leaders Carry on, but Know Whos Really in Charge
description: DETROIT  Mayor Dave Bing made new budget recommendations to the City Council on Friday, a gloomy ritual that laid out another austere spending plan for this financially distraught city.

title: Virginia Abortion Clinic Rules Get Final Approval
description: The Virginia Board of Health on Friday gave final approval to new regulations for abortion clinics that will force them to spend large sums on renovations that abortion rights advocates say are medically unnecessary.

title: Dirt Flies at the Garden Club (Even Before Spring Planting)
description: It started with the accusations of sex behind the back pond. Of late-night parties that begot stitches and adultery. Favoritism. Misspending. Bullying.

title: When Affordable Is Just a Word
description: The spring has the real-estate press enthusiastically reporting on the construction of 432 Park Avenue, an apartment tower that its developers claim will be the tallest residential building in the Western Hemisphere. Apartments in the tower, designed by Rafael Violy and to be completed in 2015, are offered in the $20 million to $80 million range, which in the context of Ludicrously Priced Housing for Oligarchs Who Spend Most of the Year in Tax Exile on Mediterranean Yachts isnt as numbing as it might otherwise be. Such is the historical moment that a few blocks west, in another glass tower, called One 57, apartments have sold in the past year for more than $90 million.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Apr. 13, 2013
description: "I wish they would have made an example of somebody else other than a 14-year-old kid, you know?

title: Germany: Former President Wulff Charged
description: German prosecutors charged former President Christian Wulff with corruption on Friday, more than a year after he quit amid accusations that he had accepted favors from business executives before becoming president. Mr. Wulff, 53, was picked by Chancellor Angela Merkel in 2010 for the largely ceremonial post. He quit 20 months later after the revelations about vacations with rich friends and favors and gifts that he had accepted earlier in his political career. On Friday, prosecutors in Hanover accused Mr. Wulff of allowing a movie producer to pay for a family vacation in 2008, while Mr. Wulff was governor of Lower Saxony. In exchange, prosecutors said, Mr. Wulff lobbied the engineering giant Siemens to help promote one of the producers films. Mr. Wulff, who denies the allegations, rejected an offer to settle the case by paying a fine.

title: N.R.A. 500 Thrusts Nascar Into Hot Seat
description: A picture of 6-year-old Charlotte Helen Bacon was tucked into the pocket of the firesuit Michael Waltrip wore when he raced in the Daytona 500 in February.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 12, 2013

title: More Test-Taking Scrutiny at L.I. District After Coaching Accusations
description: The State Education Department said on Friday that it was requiring a Long Island school district to keep closer watch on classrooms during standardized tests because of accusations that some of its teachers may have improperly helped students during last years exams.

title: A South Korean Leader Toughened by Adversity
description: President Park Geun-hyes mettle is being tested in the Korean crisis.

title: Playing a Wizards Game on Ordinary Broomsticks
description: Not many people have heard of Macaulay Honors College, a school in New York City with 1,770 students and just one athletic team: the Marauders.

title: Three International Stars Give Islanders Ballast and Banter
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders have a reason to be grateful for the four-month N.H.L. lockout: the bond between their captain, Mark Streit, and their budding star John Tavares.

title: Autistic, and on the Airwaves
description: The participants at Lifestyles for the Disabled do not exactly seem like naturals as radio personalities.

title: A Rarity for Rangers and Islanders, With Playoff Berths at Stake
description: Fans at Nassau Coliseum will witness something rare Saturday night: a late-season game between the Islanders and the Rangers in which both teams playoff chances are on the line. It has happened only four previous times in the 40-season history of the rivalry. The Islanders hold the upper hand, having won three games and tied the other.

title: Coachella: A Heavy Lean Toward the British
description: Coachella has become one of the primary American summer music institutions, not from a loyalty to domestic acts, but because it is warm to an idea that arose around the indie-mainstream collapse of the 1990s: subcultures can be mainstreamed too. The festival, one of the primary American summer music institutions with its 90,000 or so attendees this weekend and next, relies on that.

title: The Mets Keep Pounding the Ball to Stay Warm
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Someone with a sardonic sense of humor at Target Field chose the break between the fourth and fifth innings to play the Andy Williams Christmas classic Its the Most Wonderful Time of the Year.

title: Spain vs. Germany in Champions League Semifinals
description: Each Champions League semifinal will pit a German club against a Spanish one: Bayern Munich and Barcelona will fight for the right to play the winner of Dortmund versus Real Madrid. The final is in London on May 25. In the second-tier Europa League, Chelsea will play Basel of Switzerland, and Fenerbahce of Turkey will play Benfica of Portugal.

title: Avian Flu Virus Confirmed in Beijing for First Time
description: HONG KONG  The bird flu virus that has been centered in the city of Shanghai and surrounding provinces has now been reported elsewhere in China, as a 7-year-old girl was being treated on Saturday in a Beijing hospital for avian influenza.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 13
description: The United States imposed new sanctions Friday on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, and Moscow vowed to retaliate as a fractious dispute between the two countries escalated further into a cold war-style, tit-for-tat clash. The Obama administration barred 18 Russians from traveling to the United States and froze any assets they may have here under a new law intended to punish human rights violations. A handful of other more highly placed officials, including the head of the Russian region of Chechnya, were put on a list not publicly revealed. Russian officials promised to ban a like number of Americans. Peter Baker reports from Washington and Ellen Barry from Moscow.

title: 5 Dead and Scores Missing After Boat Sinks Off Indonesia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  At least five people have died and as many as 60 were missing on Saturday after a boat carrying people believed to be seeking asylum in Australia broke apart in the Sunda Strait, a patch of water between Sumatra and the main Indonesian island of Java.

title: Kerry in China to Seek Help in Korea Crisis
description: A more recent article about Secretary of State John Kerrys trip to Asia can be found here.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: A soldier was killed and five others were injured when a grenade accidentally exploded inside an army camp in the Kupwara district in northern Kashmir, according to a Press Trust of India report on the NDTV Web site. The accident occurred when the soldiers were preparing to embark on an anti-militant operation, the report noted.

title: All Aboard Rescued After Plane Skids Into Water at Bali Airport
description: HONG KONG  A plane with more than 100 people onboard skidded off the runway and cracked in two while trying to land on the resort island of Bali on Saturday, and officials said rescuers pulled all passengers and crew members to safety from the jet after it came to rest in shallow waters.

title: Mother of a 6-Year-Old Boy Killed at Newtown Delivers the White Houses Weekly Address
description: WASHINGTON  The mother of a child killed in the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., delivered a raw plea on Saturday for the Senate to pass gun control legislation, using an avenue normally reserved for the president.

title: The Weekend Word: Mental Health
description: Todays Times

title: Beating Dead Horses
description: Slightly strange piece in BusinessWeek, sold on slightly false pretenses  I had a quick conversation with Peter Coy (while walking along Broadway, no less), which I thought was input into a larger story; instead, its just me, verbatim. Still, people may be interested in how I think about my role in this macroeconomic debate.

title: After Two-Stroke Penalty, Woods Plays On
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  As the cheers for Tiger Woods on the first tee gave way to the relative hush of patrons hoofing it to the green, a man behind the tee box turned to his wife and said, I didnt hear anybody call Tiger a cheater.

title: A Cheesy Audience
description: Patrick Watson, owner of Stinky Bklyn, practices for his performance of the national anthem at Barclays Center by singing to the cheeses in his store.

title: Mubarak Appears at Trial, Which Ends Abruptly in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Former President Hosni Mubarak sat up, waved and even smirked as he appeared at a hearing on Saturday to open his retrial on charges related to the killing of protesters at the end of his rule.

title: Coachella: When the Band Is a Second Gig
description: INDIO, Calif.,  Its nice to have a hobby  a job can be stressful, especially when you are good at doing it and it keeps the lights on.

title: North Korean Leader, Young and Defiant, Strains Ties With Chinese
description: BEIJING  The last known face-to-face contact between Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, and senior Chinese officials did not end well.

title: Assad Foes Hire Former British Diplomat to Plead Their Cause
description: LONDON  A former British diplomat with a reputation for championing underdogs has been hired by Syrias opposition coalition to help in its potentially uphill mission to persuade reluctant governments to do more to end the countrys civil war.

title: Immersing Himself to Play a Pioneer
description: There is a moment in 42, the Jackie Robinson movie released this weekend, in which Chadwick Boseman, the actor playing Robinson, gives a perfect depiction of the mentality of an athlete. Someone tells Robinson he is a hero, and while Robinson surely understood his heroic undertaking in breaking baseballs color barrier, he deflected the praise.

title: Bryant Has Surgery for Torn Tendon, Ending His Season
description: LOS ANGELES  In retrospect, it was as if the last six games, in which Kobe Bryant played all but 14 minutes, had been leading to something as inevitable as it was wrenching.

title: Chinas Theaters May Soon Show Tarantino Film
description: LOS ANGELES  Details remain sparse, but Quentin Tarantinos Django Unchained is expected to be back in Chinas theaters soon, after some further editing.

title: Men of Words, Men of Deeds
description: Midway through the second half of a close and pivotal game against Texas Southern during the 1967 football season, Coach Eddie Robinsons Grambling team mounted a drive. It ended abruptly when Gramblings center threw a forearm at the nose tackle who had been dominating him. A referee penalized Grambling and ejected the center from the game.

title: Unlikely Source Has Produced an N.F.L. Draft Prospect
description: MINEOLA, N.Y.  It was the morning of Notre Dames pro day, and the cameras, commentators and representatives from nearly every N.F.L. team gathered in South Bend, Ind., for another meticulously planned, flawlessly controlled workout at one of the most traditional spots to scour for college talent before Aprils draft.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pacers Preach Balance in Star-Driven League
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Before the playoffs began last season, Indiana Pacers Coach Frank Vogel was asked who he thought could be the teams go-to player in crunch time, with a postseason game on the line. Our depth, Vogel responded.

title: Preaching Citizenship
description: A changing attitude in evangelical congregations like the First Baptist Church of Orlando, Fla., could help sway lawmakers as they consider immigration reform.

title: For Evangelicals, a Shift in Views on Immigration
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  In the pews of the First Baptist Church of Orlando, where thousands of evangelical Christians gather on Sundays to worship and sing, a change of heart is happening on the once toxic issue of immigration.

title: Russia Bars 18 Americans After Sanctions by U.S.
description: MOSCOW  A day after the United States imposed sanctions on Russians accused of rights violations, Moscow said Saturday that it could not leave this open blackmail without response and published a list of 18 current and former American officials who will now be barred from entry to Russia.

title: Variety: Getting To The Point
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  This was a lot of fun for me, and I can tell you why.

title: Letter From London | Spring Drinks
description: Rita Konig, Ts European editor, unveils persons, places and things on her radar in her online letters from London.

title: Helping Teachers Learn
description: The school cheating scandal in Atlanta that led to criminal indictments against dozens of teachers, principals and administrators last month contains at least three lessons for states that are developing teacher evaluation systems.

title: Gifting and Politicking
description: George Washington Plunkitts timeless defense of honest graft in government has been a measure of political dodginess for the last century. I seen my opportunities and I took em, Plunkitt bragged after becoming a millionaire by exploiting the legal edge of patronage and machine politics in the Tammany Hall era.

title: Courage in Kansas
description: Nearly four years after an anti-abortion extremist opened fire and killed a Wichita abortion provider, Dr. George Tiller, as he stood in the foyer of his church, a new medical clinic offering comprehensive reproductive health services  including abortions through the first trimester of pregnancy  opened on April 3. It is in the building that once housed Dr. Tillers clinic.

title: Public Pensions in Bankruptcy Court
description: Devastated by the recession, the city of Stockton, Calif., is trying to renegotiate its debts in a bankruptcy case that could set an important precedent on whether courts can forcibly reduce the pensions of government employees.

title: When Election Regulators Are Mocked
description: It is an open scandal in Washington that the Federal Election Commission is completely ossified as the referee and penalizer of abuses in national politics.

title: Pope Francis Names Advisory Panel at Vatican
description: VATICAN CITY  In his first significant decision since becoming pontiff  and a radical step toward more democracy in the Roman Catholic Church  Pope Francis on Saturday named a group of eight cardinals from around the world to advise him in governing the church and overhauling the troubled Vatican hierarchy, which has been rocked by scandals.

title: Another Attempt at Womens Circuit, but With a Twist
description: All they have ever wanted was a league of their own. Just not three.

title: Faltering Courts, Mired in Delays
description: Outside the courtroom, the children of the murdered man waited with their mother. It had taken five years for the Bronx courts to get around to them and to the man with teardrop tattoos charged with killing their father.

title: On the Golf Course, Its All About Building Relationships
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: You Loved My Film? Thanks, Man. Spare a Dime?
description: From all available evidence, this is a new golden age for Texas independent filmmaking. Eight narrative features, either made by Texas-based directors or shot in the state, had their world premieres at this years Sundance Film Festival; more than a dozen more Texas efforts had their premieres at the South by Southwest Film Festival last month.

title: W.N.B.A. Hopes Griner Can Change Perceptions, as Well as Game Itself
description: Forget for a moment whether Brittney Griner has the skill to play in the N.B.A. There are more urgent and relevant questions. One is whether she will thrive as a primary face of the W.N.B.A.s campaign to rebrand itself in its 17th season, beginning with its first prime-time draft Monday.

title: Missing Deflation
description: Keynesians have, over all, had a very good track record in this economic crisis; one indication of just how good is the remarkable extent to which people on the other side have had attack people like me for supposed wrong predictions we never, in fact, made (you endorsed Obamas economic projections! No, I didnt).

title: At a College, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness
description: ATLANTA  The softball bats and golf clubs have been stored away. All is quiet, too, at the basketball gymnasium, the volleyball courts and the soccer field.

title: At Augusta, if You Have to Ask, The Answer Is No. So Dont Ask.
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Golf is a game of order with a 140-page rule book that is a vast compendium of what the golfer is not permitted to do.

title: Private Jets and Country Clubs Help Soften Blow of Meager Pay
description: Many Texas lawmakers are quick to name the sacrifices they make to serve: the meager state pay, the grueling hours, the time spent away from their families and their day jobs.

title: From Staten Island, a Unique Broadcast
description: Meet Totally 80s Chris, Michael the date whiz and Mystery Man, D.J.s on Lifestyles Radio, a program run by Lifestyles for the Disabled on Staten Island.

title: A Slim Chance for Lawmakers to Self-Regulate
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Heavier Trucks From Mexico Could Prove a Boon for Texas
description: Each year, just before they approach the United States border, thousands of truck drivers hauling produce from western Mexico to southern Texas stop in the city of Reynosa to lighten their loads.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) THE CAMPAIGN (2012) In this comedy about rival candidates in a North Carolina Congressional election, directed by Jay Roach, Will Ferrell, above, plays Cam Brady, a blow-dried Democrat espousing a platform of guns, God and family while violating his marriage vows at every turn. Zach Galifianakis is Marty Huggins, the sweet, wimpy son of a local politico (Brian Cox), plucked from obscurity by Republicans. Dylan McDermott plays the hatchet man dispatched to make Marty into a political machine. You can chuckle at the buffoonery, raise your eyebrows at the baroque scatological and sexual humor  Mom, they said penis again!  and conclude that The Campaign goes too far, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But then a glance at some of the clowns we do elect, perhaps especially to our national legislature, might lead you in the opposite direction. Really, the movie could not possibly go far enough unless the screenwriters (Chris Henchy and Shawn Harwell) had abandoned all invention and transcribed the script directly from C-Span.

title: When God Is Your Therapist
description: IT had never occurred to me to think of God as a therapist when I began to spend time, 10 years ago, at an evangelical church in Chicago. Like many secular observers, I was interested in the fact that people like me seemed to experience reality in a fundamentally different manner. I soon came to realize that one of the most important features of these churches is that they offer a powerful way to deal with anxiety and distress, not because of what people believe but because of what they do when they pray.

title: Think Those Chemicals Have Been Tested?
description: MANY Americans assume that the chemicals in their shampoos, detergents and other consumer products have been thoroughly tested and proved to be safe.

title: A Troubled Court System in the Bronx
description: The New York Times reporter William Glaberson explains his nearly yearlong investigation into the dysfunctional courts in the Bronx.

title: Anthony Closes in on Scoring Title
description: In 1994, David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs entered his teams final game locked in a battle with Shaquille ONeal of the Orlando Magic for the leagues scoring title. Robinson, a veteran center, needed to score 4 more points than ONeal to overtake him. Just to be safe, Robinson went on a tear, scoring a career-high 71 points  making him the fourth player to surpass 70 points in a game  and finishing with an average of 29.8 points a game. ONeal could not match him, scoring 32 in his teams finale and finishing with an average of 29.3.

title: Note to New S.E.C. Chief: The Clock Is Ticking
description: AFTER receiving unanimous support from the United States Senate, Mary Jo White was confirmed last week as the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission. At her swearing-in, she praised S.E.C. officials for vigorously enforcing the securities laws.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Lifestyle and Taxes
description: Writers discuss incentives to marry, procreate and buy a home.

title: Quietly, Indians Reshape Cities and Reservations
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Nothing in her upbringing on a remote Indian reservation in northern Minnesota prepared Jean Howard for her introduction to city life during a visit here eight years ago: an outbreak of gunfire, followed by the sight of people scattering.

title: A.B.A., or Something Unlike It
description: LIMA, Ohio  The bleachers at the high school gym were mostly empty. The visiting team, the Michiana Monarchs, was running late. Players from the home team, the Lima Explosion, were still recovering from long shifts at their day jobs: working construction, stocking shelves, teaching high school.

title: Thomas R. Frieden
description: Thomas R. Frieden is the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and previously served as New York Citys health commissioner.

title: As Indians Move to Cities, Old and New Challenges Follow
description: The migration of American Indians to cities has taken place amid hope and some concern.

title: Red Wings-Blackhawks Rivalry Will Be Readjusted by Realignment
description: CHICAGO  On a visit to Olympia Stadium in Detroit in the 1960s, the Hall of Famer Bobby Hull recalled, he was skating through warm-ups with the Blackhawks when three Red Wings fans in the front row began yelling obscenities at him. Their shouts grew louder and more disparaging, and soon the fans had climbed the glass and dangled their arms over it. Hull skated toward the glass, hooked the three fans with his stick and with a flick of his wrist sent them sprawling.

title: Balance and Bias
description: THE traditional American mass media  the crumbling, Internet-besieged edifice of newspapers and news shows, magazines and roundtables and journalism schools  evolved to believe with equal vigor in two not entirely compatible ideals.

title: Love, Love Them. Do.
description: HE was a darling of the cable news shows, which indulged his appetite for attention so frequently that he carried his own makeup kit, to be ready and pretty at a moments notice. But the lights and the cameras werent enough.

title: The Ghosts of Afghanistans Past
description: ON March 10, Afghanistans president, Hamid Karzai, shocked Western leaders by declaring that recent attacks proved that the Taliban are at the service of America. The implication was clear: terrorists were colluding with the United States to sow chaos before Americas planned withdrawal in 2014. American and European leaders, mindful of the blood and treasure theyve expended to defend Mr. Karzais government, were baffled and offended.

title: Chris Murphys Crucible
description: WASHINGTON

title: Hacktivists as Gadflies
description: Around 400 B.C., Socrates was brought to trial on charges of corrupting the youth of Athens and impiety. Presumably, however, people believed then as we do now, that Socrates real crime was being too clever and, not insignificantly, a royal pain to those in power or, as Plato put it, a gadfly. Just as a gadfly is an insect that could sting a horse and prod it into action, so too could Socrates sting the state. He challenged the moral values of his contemporaries and refused to go along with unjust demands of tyrants, often obstructing their plans when he could. Socrates thought his service to Athens should have earned him free dinners for life. He was given a cup of hemlock instead.

title: Patricia McCormick, Bullfighter Who Defied Convention, Is Dead at 83
description: During the 1950s, when young women from West Texas were typically expected to take care of the home, Patricia McCormick bucked social convention, and a long male tradition, by entering the bullfighting ring.

title: One Mans Passing
description: The photographer Joshua Bright spent more than a year visiting and taking photos of a dying man named John R. Hawkins.

title: A Good Death
description: FOR more than a year, I visited and photographed a dying man named John R. Hawkins. I had found him through the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care when I went in search of both a photo project and a profound experience.

title: How Should We Rank Margaret Thatcher?
description: ON Wednesday, Margaret Thatchers funeral, at St Pauls Cathedral in London, will put her in the company of only three other Britons in more than 200 years: Lord Nelson, the Duke of Wellington and Sir Winston Churchill.

title: The Trauma of the Pink Shirt
description: LET me tell you an odd little story, in anticipation of summer. Last June, just as New York City was turning back into a summer sweatbox, our friend Shirley called my wife and said she knew someone with a pool in New Jersey who was away for the weekend, and wouldnt mind our using it. An irresistible invitation.

title: A Big Bet on Downtown Detroit
description: Against tall odds, Dan Gilbert, the Quicken Loans chairman, wants to revive a two-square-mile stretch that was once Detroits core.

title: Finding Purpose in Tunneling Through Granite
description: This interview with  Marcus Ryu, the C.E.O. of Guidewire Software, a maker of software for the insurance industry,  was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: A Missionarys Quest to Remake Motor City
description: THE best way to experience all that is strange and a little otherworldly about downtown Detroit is to walk the streets around 5 p.m. on a weekday. At that hour, youll notice not just the peculiarity of what is around you  notably, the gorgeous, Art Deco skyscrapers alongside empty, decrepit buildings  but also what is missing. There is no traffic here. As the workday ends, cars trickle out of underground parking lots and speed off to nearby highways, but in a volume that doesnt cause delays.

title: Mounting Tensions Escalate Into Violence During Raid at Guantnamo Prison
description: WASHINGTON  Weeks of mounting tensions between the military and detainees at the wartime prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, escalated into violence on Saturday during a raid in which guards forced prisoners living in communal housing to move to individual cells.

title: John Tavares Quietly Making Case for Hart Trophy
description: Short schedule or long, the criterion for deciding who deserves the Hart Memorial Trophy does not change: it goes to the player judged most valuable to his team. So should John Tavares win the Hart Trophy this season?

title: Why Home Prices Change (or Dont)
description: WHAT prices will todays home buyers get if they sell a decade from now?

title: Hackers Post Witness List in Trial on Ex-Premiers Death
description: PARIS  Hackers broke into a major Lebanese news Web site and plastered the front page with the names of the so-called secret witnesses for the trial in the killing of the former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in an apparent bold, new move to intimidate witnesses and derail the trial.

title: Texas Official Questioned in Killings Is Held Over Alleged Threat
description: KAUFMAN, Tex.  A former justice of the peace who has been questioned in the murders of two prosecutors here was arrested early Saturday on charges that included making a threat, the authorities said.

title: The Economic Data Filters, Clogged Again
description: ROBERT HEILBRONER, the author and economist, was often asked where interest rates, the stock market and the economy were heading.

title: Mirth and Taxes
description: A study of 54 nations  ranked below  found that those with more progressive tax rates had happier citizens, on average.

title: Sometimes, We Want Prices to Fool Us
description: WHEN the board of J. C. Penney ousted its chief executive, Ron Johnson  news that broke last Monday  you might say it was, in some small way, because he didnt understand Tracie Fobes.

title: Mentors Are Good. Sponsors Are Better.
description: AS Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook tells it, what accounts for her spectacular leap to leadership is her unfettered embrace of career opportunity. By leaning in, she maintains in her new book, she has been able to join the male-dominated ranks of corporate executives.

title: My Copyright Career
description: I GREW up in a working-class family in Beverly, Mass., where my father had several jobs, including packing chemicals and working in shipping and receiving at Logan Airport. He and my mother, a preschool teacher, met at a bowling alley in 1962 and married soon after.

title: Heavens, Not Havens
description: THE words happy and taxes do not often appear together. In fact, death is the word that people associate most often with taxes, according to wordassociation.org.

title: The Furtive Tax
description: APRIL 15 is dreaded as the deadline for filing income tax returns, but in fact every day is tax day for most working people. Thats because more than half of all Americans pay more in payroll tax than in income tax. That includes nearly everyone in the bottom half of the income distribution.

title: Go Simple
description: HOW many millions of hours do you think Americans spend on government paperwork every year?

title: Palestinian Prime Minister Resigns, Adding Uncertainty to Government
description: JERUSALEM  The internationally respected prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Salam Fayyad, resigned on Saturday, raising concerns about political stability in the West Bank days after Secretary of State John Kerry proposed a broad initiative to aid the Palestinian economy there to shore up peace efforts.

title: Coachella: Day 1
description: The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival kicked off with performances by IO Echo, Of Monsters and Men and Band of Horses.

title: On Alert for Meningitis in Los Angeles
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  A potentially deadly strain of meningitis, which has left one resident brain dead, has sent a shiver through the large gay community here, as public health officials have urged residents to be on the lookout for any symptoms of the disease.

title: Coachella: Photos From Day 1
description: The photographer Chad Batka captured highlights from the first day of the music festival in California. See larger versions of the photos here.

title: Mickey Rose, TV Writer and Woody Allen Collaborator, Dies at 77
description: As Brooklyn high school buddies, Woody Allen and Mickey Rose had a dream: one day, with luck, they would open a pharmacy together.

title: Playing Catch-Up With Robocallers
description: IF this column were a TV show, what kind of TV show would it be? The Haggler is thinking dark comedy, laugh track optional. But sometimes the material here feels more like the stuff of farce. Laugh till you cry farce. As it does with the continuing Whirlpool ordeal experienced by Shira London, who e-mailed an update last week.

title: Medical Care, Aided by the Crowd
description: TWO years ago, Chase Adam, a Peace Corps volunteer in Costa Rica, was riding a bus through a town called Watsi, when a woman got on board asking for money. Her son, she said, needed medical attention and she couldnt pay for it. As the woman walked through the bus, she showed people a copy of her sons medical record. Mr. Adam, who is now 26, noticed that nearly everyone donated money.

title: North Korea Threatens Colorado City, Inaccurately
description: North Korea, which seemed to be running out of tubs to thump, found a new target for its ire in a propaganda video released Saturday on Uriminzokkiri, a government Web site.

title: Conduct at Issue as Military Officers Face a New Review
description: WASHINGTON  After a series of scandals involving high-ranking officers, the American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by their peers and the people they command on qualities including personal character.

title: A Viewers Guide to the Mayoral Candidates
description: Seeking the New York City mayors office are seven Democrats, three Republicans and one candidate on the Independence Partys ballot.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 14
description: SenatorMarco Rubio visits seven programs this Sunday, talking about immigration as he and the rest of a bipartisan group of eight senators prepare to release a proposal to overhaul the system. The Florida Republican will appear on the five major Sunday shows, as well as the programs on Telemundo and Univision.

title: Basketballs Renegade Spirit
description: Todays A.B.A., a basketball league that is not particularly professional, shares little with the original other than the name, the ball and a renegade spirit.

title: DNWR in the EA
description: Thats downward nominal wage rigidity in the euro area (and actually in neighboring countries too). Ive been talking about DNWR in the US context, but its a much bigger issue in Europe, where the whole adjustment strategy relies on internal devaluation: countries that experienced large capital inflows during the period 2000-2007 are supposed to regain competitiveness by cutting costs, and thats really hard if nominal wages have to come down.

title: My Treat
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Oh my, I loved this puzzle. Your mileage may vary. But as far as Im concerned, the only thing that would have made this puzzle better is if we had some sort of technology here at The New York Times that would make the puzzle lickable. Maybe scratch n sniff, as a second choice. But definitely lickable.

title: Robert Byrne, Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 84
description: Robert Byrne, an international grandmaster and United States chess champion who, as the chess columnist for The New York Times, analyzed top-flight matches from 1972 through 2006, the eras of Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov, died on Friday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Coachella: A Few Sparks of Creative Rock
description: INDIO, Calif.  American rock music might get a bad rap, but its cancer begins from within. Major labels have all but tabled creative ambition, meaning that even bona fide indie stars may have to content themselves with being miniscene champions for life. Early on Saturday at Coachella, there was a suite of young American bands trying to find a path out of the darkness.

title: Obamas Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Whether or not Republicans ever agree to a budget deal with President Obama, one thing seems certain: now that he has officially put Social Security and Medicare benefits on the negotiating table, opponents on his partys left will make that an issue for Democrats in the midterm elections next year  and perhaps in the 2016 presidential contest.

title: Shy No More, N.R.A.s Top Gun Sticks to Cause
description: WASHINGTON  Victims of the massacre in Newtown, Conn., had just been laid to rest when Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, met with his board of directors in early January. A national tide of grief had prompted new attacks on his group and a White House push for more gun control measures, while Mr. LaPierre  who had called for armed guards in every school  was pilloried as a gun nut on the cover of The New York Post.

title: Mystery Shrouds Rise and Aims of Rebel at Helm of Central African Republic
description: A portly sexagenarian, Michel Djotodia had dressed for his coup dtat, donning desert camouflage, a turban and sandals like those of the rebels in his region of the Central African Republic.

title: Sierra Leones Health Care System Becomes a Cautionary Tale for Donors
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  The health statistics in this battered land, still scarred from a decade of civil war, are so alarming that for a decade, donors have opened their wallets to help improve some of the worlds worst rates of maternal and infant mortality. This is the third-most dangerous place on earth to have a baby, and one of the most perilous to be a baby.

title: No Stranger to Scandal, Spitzer Says Weiner Can Come Back
description: As he considers a potential mayoral run in the wake of an online sex scandal, former RepresentativeAnthony D. Weiner has won a vote of confidence from a politician who can identify with his predicament: Eliot Spitzer.

title: Brooklyn School Takes Title at the Supernationals
description: Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn won its division at the Supernationals scholastic championships in Nashville last weekend.

title: Morneaus Homer Ruins No-Hit Bid, but Mets Harvey Stays Dominant
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It wasnt a bad pitch, but it wasnt the right pitch. Matt Harvey realized that not long after Minnesotas Justin Morneau swung at an inside slider with two out in the seventh, pulling a home run high off the right-field pole and halting Harveys bid for a second Mets no-hitter in two years and his first professional shutout.

title: Wigan Defeats Millwall in Violence-Marred F.A. Cup Semifinal
description: LONDON  There were two sparkling goals, a typically gray and rainy English day and plenty of pomp, but the lingering image from Saturdays F.A. Cup semifinal between Millwall and Wigan will be that of a young girl crying.

title: Early Signs of Parity in A.L. East, Where 90 Wins May Be Enough
description: The Baltimore Orioles unloaded on Phil Hughes on Saturday, hitting him so hard for three innings that Hughes said he could not remember the last time he had pitched so badly. Maybe there were better times to ask Hughes about the strength of the division, times when he could have been more objective. But his perspective seemed to sum up the new reality of the American League East.

title: On Leader Board Full of Challengers, Top Two Say They Have a Plan
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Controversy over Tiger Woodss two-stroke penalty for hitting from the wrong spot Friday enveloped the Augusta National Golf Club grounds for hours before play began in Saturdays third round. In the galleries, among the players and in the deliberations of tournament officials, the attention of all conversation was focused on the past, on what Woods did and did not do in the second round.

title: Hughes Returns to Mound, but Briefly
description: The grumbling began with a lone fan who had given up on Phil Hughes in the third inning. Take him out! Take him ouuuuuut! He was louder with each hard hit. Soon, a few others started to boo. By the fourth, as Hughes walked off the mound with his head bowed after being removed from the game, the crowd was more decided.

title: Attention, Second-Guessers: Golf Takes Calls (and Texts)
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  In golf, and almost no other sport, interactive, real-time communication between armchair television viewers and referees supervising the competition routinely changes rulings and alters the outcomes of tournaments. This collaboration of living room second-guessers and rules officials is an almost weekly occurrence. On Saturday, it embroiled the Masters, golfs biggest event, in a controversy that involved the games most celebrated player, Tiger Woods.

title: China Makes Inroads in Nepal, and Stanches Tibetan Influx
description: CHOSAR, Nepal  The wind-scoured desert valley here, just south of Tibet, was once a famed transit point for the Tibetan yak caravans laden with salt that lumbered over the icy ramparts of the Himalayas. In the 1960s, it became a base for Tibetan guerrillas trained by the C.I.A. to attack Chinese troops occupying their homeland.

title: Playoff Race Reanimates Rivalry, and Rangers Overtime Goal Electrifies It
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Nassau Coliseum was rocking the way it used to, decades ago, when J. P. Parise, Denis Potvin and Chico Resch were leading the upstart Islanders against the established Rangers of John Davidson, Phil Esposito and Ron Duguay. Those clashes generally ended with the Islanders on top, but that was not the way Saturday nights game ended.

title: Third Round: Masters Replay
description: Scenes from Saturdays third round at Augusta National.

title: National Title Is State Title as Yale Beats Quinnipiac
description: PITTSBURGH  Three weeks before the Connecticut neighbors Yale and Quinnipiac met on college hockeys biggest stage, they played on a much smaller one in the ECAC Hockey tournaments consolation game. Quinnipiac won that day, just as it had in the teams two meetings during the regular season.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 14
description: It should never take five years. All the good parts of New York, the high-class parts of New York, they easily get justice.

title: Javas War Wins Blue Grass Stakes; Overanalyze Takes Arkansas Derby
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Fourteen horses, the maximum number allowed, entered the starting gate for the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland Race Course. They lined up 10 across for the Arkansas Derby at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark.

title: Karina Garcia, David Magruder
description: Karina Marie Garcia and David Michael Magruder were married Saturday at St. Ann Roman Catholic Church in West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Nestor Rodriguez, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Hanna Lundqvist, Reece Dameron
description: Hanna Rebecca Lundqvist and Reece Campbell Dameron were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Resort Rancho Encantado in Santa Fe, N.M. Judge Sarah M. Singleton of New Mexicos First Judicial District Court in Santa Fe officiated.

title: Abigail Curran, Chad Horrell
description: Abigail Flicker Curran and Chad Daniel Horrell were married Saturday at the University of Virginia Chapel in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Andrew I. Walton, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Christine MacGregor, Theodore Iobst
description: Christine Elder MacGregor and Theodore David Iobst were married Saturday at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. R. Charles Grant, an associate pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Rachel Bordenstein, Eric Saar
description: Rachel Michelle Bordenstein and Eric Thomas Saar were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Brenner J. Glickman at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Jennifer Bjorklund, Jonathan Lloyd
description: Jennifer Lynne Bjorklund and Jonathan Alden Casey Lloyd were married Saturday in Griffith Park in Los Angeles. Thomas J. LaBonge, a Los Angeles city councilman who was appointed a temporary deputy marriage commissioner by Los Angeles County for the event, officiated.

title: Jennifer Young, Jay Mehr
description: Jennifer Lee Young and Jay Steven Mehr were married Saturday evening at the Manor, an event space in West Orange, N.J. David J. Issenman, a retired Superior Court judge whose chambers were in Elizabeth, N.J., officiated.

title: Brian Healy and Daniel Hantman
description: Donall Brian Healy Jr. and Daniel Harris Hantman were married Saturday at Judson Memorial Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Donna E. Schaper, the churchs senior minister who is affiliated with the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Rachel Mindlin, Matthew Rednor
description: Rachel Anne Mindlin and Matthew Benjamin Rednor were married Saturday evening by Cantor Marcos Askenazi at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Laurie Perez and Jeffrey Collette
description: Laurie Sue Perez and Jeffrey James Collette were married Saturday at Merrimans Kapalua, a restaurant in Lahaina, Hawaii, on the island of Maui. Ernest K. Puaa, a Pentecostal minister with the Harvest Chapel Church of God in Lahaina, Hawaii, officiated.

title: Abigail Collier and Christopher Buhrman
description: Abigail Ipolani Collier and Christopher David Buhrman were married Saturday in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel.

title: Alexandra Cohen, Jordan Scheiman
description: Alexandra Lauren Cohen and Jordan Leone Scheiman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Arthur Nemitoff at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y.

title: Whitney Robinson, Louie Rivers III
description: A Two-Part First Date

title: Astrid Hill and Ryan Dattilo
description: Astrid Tomilson Hill, a daughter of Janine W. Hill and J. Tomilson Hill of New York, was married Saturday to Ryan Joseph Dattilo, the son of Lori A. Dattilo and Joseph A. Dattilo of Cincinnati. The Rev. Jonathan Morris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Dana Scardigli, Christopher Chiapparelli
description: Dana Michel Scardigli and Christopher Charles Chiapparelli were married Saturday evening at the Ocean Reef Club, a resort in Key Largo, Fla. The Rev. Lee G. Ganim, a minister of the International Council of Community Churches, officiated, with Charles A. Chiapparelli, the grooms father, an associate judge of the District Court of Maryland in Baltimore, taking part.

title: Jessica Leight and Amir Satvat
description: Jessica Ellen Leight, the daughter of Margaret Bruzelius and Peter W. Leight of Amherst, Mass., was married Saturday to Amir Satvat, the son of Ashraf Owlia Satvat and Dr. Behzad Satvat of Avon, Conn. The brides father officiated at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., having received a temporary authorization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: Mariama Jerrell and Lesslie Boamah
description: Bonding Over a Poignant Story

title: Amy Purnell, Daniel Silberman
description: Amy Clements Purnell and Daniel Craig Silberman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky at Guastavinos, a restaurant in New York.

title: Julie Moon, Reid Gustin
description: Julie Won Moon and Reid Byron Gustin were married Saturday at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Annie Lawrence, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Caitlin Smith, Carlo Frevert
description: Caitlin Ashley Smith and Carlo Friedrich Frevert were married Saturday by Sandra Sander, a registrar of civil marriages, who officiated at the Rathaus Schmargendorf, a town hall in Berlin.

title: Nicole Eason, Gregory Collins Jr.
description: Nicole Michele Eason, the daughter of Marie E. Eason and Wayne S. Eason Sr. of Fort Worth, was married Saturday to Gregory Lee Collins Jr., a son of Carolyn S. Collins and Mr. Collins Sr. of Bear, Del. The Rev. S. Mark Haywood II, a cousin of the groom and a Baptist minister, officiated at the Adolphus hotel in Dallas.

title: Corrections: April 14, 2013
description: NEW YORK

title: Judge Rules Against Football Helmet Manufacturer
description: A jury in Colorado has found that Riddell, the countrys largest helmet manufacturer, was at fault for failure to adequately warn players wearing their football helmets about the dangers of potential concussions.

title: A Gangnam Style Escape From Korean Tensions
description: BEIJING  Psy. I read about this guy named Psy in Korea, the U.S. secretary of state, John Kerry, said Saturday, addressing Chinese and overseas reporters at a news briefing in Beijing, where he was visiting to discuss the high tensions on the Korean Peninsula, among other things.

title: Coachella: Raps Web-Fueled Misfits
description: INDIO, Calif.  At Coachella, everything happens more or less on time, but 2 Chainz was late. His set on Saturday afternoon was meant to start at 4 p.m., but 4:05, 4:10 and 4:15 all passed without sight of him, his band reduced to playing a minute or so of Im Different, which petered out, soon followed by boos.

title: Wayne LaPierre: Behind the Rhetoric
description: The Timess Jodi Kantor looks at how the National Rifle Associations Wayne LaPierre has drawn strength from criticism directed at him since the school shooting in Newtown, Conn.

title: Rebel Flag Flies Over a Province, and Indonesia Wants It Torn Down
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian government has given the leaders of strife-torn Aceh Province until Tuesday to annul a bylaw passed last month that declares the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the provinces official flag and seal.

title: Should You Be Paying Taxes on Your Baby Sitter?
description: If you want to hear a pin drop, ask a room of parents whether they report employment taxes for their baby sitter or nanny. My (admittedly unscientific) conclusion, drawn from four years of Manhattan motherhood, is that many families do not. In a 2011 discussion of nanny compensation on Park Slope Parents, most families reported paying their caregivers completely off the books, while very few said they paid the tax. Susan Fox, founder of Park Slope Parents, suspects the off-the-books number among her readers is well over half.

title: Milton Friedman, Currency Debaser
description: Brad DeLong links to a Forbes piece by Tim Lee from last year that I missed, which in turn quotes Milton Friedman on the macroeconomic views that prevailed in the early 1930s:

title: Venezuela Goes to the Polls
description: The Timess William Neuman reports from Caracas, Venezuela, on the morning of an election for the successor to Hugo Chvez, who died in March.

title: A Purveyor of Brie, Prosciutto and Anthems
description: Thirty minutes before Stinky Bklyn opens for business, its proprietor strolls the floor singing in a powerhouse tenor to Parmigiano-Reggiano and hickory-smoked Bentons bacon. He is not being a ham. Patrick Watson is getting his pipes in shape to sing the national anthem at the Barclays Center, where he is better known as the supplier of Stinky Brown Butter Rice Krispy Treats and the crumbled blue cheese topping on the Nathans Famous hot dogs sold at the concession stand.

title: Highlights and Analysis From Masters
description: Adam Scott, 32, became the first Australian to win the Masters, defeating Angel Cabrera of Argentina in the second hole of the sudden-death playoff Sunday.

title: Top Brass, Low Key
description: She is only 34, but there is already a statue of the glamorous trumpeter Alison Balsom standing in her hometown, Royston, England, where she grew up playing in a brass band.

title: Rubio Offers Full-Throated Support for Immigration Bill
description: Senator Marco Rubio offered an extraordinary endorsement of legislation to overhaul the nations badly strained immigration system on Sunday when, after holding back for weeks, he appeared on no fewer than seven television talk shows to explain and defend a plan that he said would be a net positive for the country, now and in the future.

title: Jackie Robinson Movie Has Strong Opening
description: Hollywood was predictably shocked over the weekend to find that a well-reviewed drama succeeded at the box office even though it was aimed at geriatric moviegoers (industry definition: anyone over the age of 25). The Jackie Robinson biopic 42 was a strong No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in about $27.3 million, according to its distributor, Warner Brothers. Legendary Entertainment spent a relatively modest $38 million to make the film, which performed best among older men, the hardest demographic for studios to reach.

title: Rat Kidneys Made in Lab Point to Aid for Humans
description: Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston have made functioning rat kidneys in the laboratory, a bioengineering achievement that may one day lead to the ability to create replacement organs for people with kidney disease.

title: For Manchester City, F.A. Cup Final Offers a Consolation Prize
description: LONDON  On Saturday, there was ugliness at Wembley, as the bloodied faces of a group of Millwall fans  who pummeled one another, and the police, in the stands in a grim episode of in-game violence  overshadowed Wigans victory in an F.A. Cup semifinal. On Sunday, the lasting image of the second semifinal at Englands national stadium was more idyllic: a sea of light blue Manchester City fans, moving in unison as they danced, cheered and whipped their scarves around in giddy celebration of a thrilling 2-1 win over Chelsea.

title: Students Face Tougher Tests That Outpace Lesson Plans
description: At Public School 10 on the edge of Park Slope, Brooklyn, parents begged the principal to postpone the lower school science fair, insisting it was going to add too much pressure while they were preparing their children for the coming state tests.

title: Kerry Says North Korea Talks Are Possible, but Hints at Conditions
description: TOKYO  Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday that the United States was prepared to reach out to Kim Jong-un of North Korea if he made the first move to abandon his nuclear weapons program.

title: Centerpiece of Gun Bill Remains in Doubt
description: The Senate could vote as early as Tuesday on expanded background checks for gun buyers  a centerpiece of broad gun legislation  but leading lawmakers said Sunday that approval of the measure remained uncertain.

title: For One Royal, History Has Added Insult to Injury
description: In February, when the British novelist Hilary Mantel delivered a lecture describing the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, as a plastic princess designed by a committee and built by craftsmen, the response was swift and in some quarters furious. Prime Minister David Cameron dismissed the remarks as completely misguided and completely wrong. The Daily Mail denounced them as a venomous attack.

title: Excerpt: 'The Call'
description: A scene from Tanya Barfield's play, a co-production between Playwrights Horizons and Primary Stages.

title: End of Palestinian Power Play Muddles the Peace Process
description: JERUSALEM  Salam Fayyad, the internationally respected Palestinian politician and economist, is widely credited with ending the chaos in the West Bank and putting things in order in his six years as prime minister. But his resignation over the weekend, the result of internal power struggles, has left the Palestinian Authority suspended in political ambiguity and confusion.

title: Mets and Twins Postpone Series Finale as Snow and Temperature Fall
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Most of the Mets never made it to Target Field from their hotel on Sunday morning.

title: South Street Seaport Museum Has More Time
description: Although the South Street Seaport Museum has yet to recover from Hurricane Sandy, the Museum of the City of New York has agreed to continue running the museum for another three months.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Orian Almog and Joanne Yun joined Media6Degrees, New York, in new posts. Ms. Almog becomes an account executive; she had been a director at Cognitive Match, New York. Ms. Yun becomes director for sales strategy and operations; she had held various posts at the New York office of Google.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Flaws Seen in Protection of Animals on the Set
description: LOS ANGELES  On a film set, even the bugs bite by the book.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Quirks and All, a Group Welcomes a Playmate
description: The Bad Plus is an odd bird. The three members of this trio individually lean on specific languages of jazz improvisation, but collectively the band hesitates to get close to any single tradition. It likes to build a crescendo past the point of comfort, or move extremely slowly, or structure a kind of pop song with irresolutions and gravitational tempo shifts and wild staggers, or pump stiff grandiosity into something simple and scratchy. It plays, a little perversely, with putting on a hard shell. It exaggerates with a straight face and builds self-contained events within themselves rather than partial re-enactments of an open-ended story, which is what most jazz is.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Wallace Appears Close to Returning and Reminding Fans He Still Plays for Knicks
description: Rasheed Wallace, the Knicks veteran with the scruffy beard, has been on the court before games for the last month practicing his jumper, mostly from behind the 3-point line. He may get the chance to do it in a situation that counts when the Knicks visit the Charlotte Bobcats on Monday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the Consumer Price Index, housing starts and industrial production for March (Tuesday); the Federal Reserves beige book (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims and leading economic indicators for March (Thursday).

title: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS  The most surprising result during the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams here last month was when Sabine Auken; Morten Bilde and Dennis Bilde (Mortens son) from Denmark; and Roy Welland of New York City defeated Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness). With 16 boards to play, Monaco led by 56 international match points and was fielding two of the worlds top-ranked pairs. With their rankings in parentheses, these were Fantoni (1) and Nunes (2); and Helgemo (9) and Helness (10).

title: Psys New Video Is a Quick Web Hit
description: The Korean pop singer known as Psy, who gained global notoriety last year when his song Gangnam Style became an Internet sensation, released a new single over the weekend, and many were quick to notice. In a little over a day, the video for the song, Gentleman, attracted more than 32 million views on YouTube after it had its premiere on Saturday during a concert in Seoul.

title: In Little Italy, Saving the Past by Rebuilding It
description: The 19th-century brick building that houses the Italian American Museum in the Little Italy neighborhood of Manhattan radiates an Old World intimacy, with its tin ceiling and its proximity to shops that still sell slices of pink prosciutto and balls of snow-white mozzarella.

title: Booksellers Hoping for Pulitzer in Fiction
description: At the Community Bookstore in Park Slope in Brooklyn last Wednesday, booksellers were happily engaged in an annual parlor game of the publishing industry: guessing which title might win the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for fiction on Monday.

title: Flaunting the Spirit of Support for the Arts
description: LINZ, Austria  This industrial city of almost 200,000 midway between Vienna and Salzburg, and the capital of the state of Upper Austria, has long had a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to culture. So it seemed, at least, in a series of slightly defensive speeches by government and arts figures on Thursday evening at the opening of the new Linz Opera House, formally known as the Musiktheater am Volksgarten, referring to the public park it adjoins.

title: Losing a Step, Nike Seeks to Regain Its Edge
description: Lost in the middle of a debate last month over a Nike ad that congratulated Tiger Woods for regaining his ranking as the worlds No. 1 golfer was that people were talking about a Nike ad.

title: This Caesar Wears an African Cloak
description: The blood runs warm in the Royal Shakespeare Companys vibrant production of Julius Caesar, now at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Experience has taught the inhabitants of the African country in which this Shakespeare tragedy has ingeniously been reset that life is tenuous and easily taken. Their fears lie close to the surface, quick to tumble into anger, despair and, on occasion, a joy that remains edged in apprehension.

title: A Childs Video Tour of Her Familys Garden
description: An enduring question these days is how to engage children with nature given how much time they spend looking at screens of one size or another. Ive written off and on aboutthe merits of hybrid experience,

title: What Makes a Crowd
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Gayle Dean was a prolific crossword puzzle constructor in the pre-Shortzian era (prior to 1993) and shes had a few puzzles since then, but we havent seen here since 2001. Ms. Dean is back today with a lesson in Yiddish.

title: Racing Against Time to Save a Young Star
description: When was the last time you were impressed by a makeover? In the hands of New Yorks finest blond-highlighters, blow-dry artists and cheekbone illusionists, almost any woman can dazzle for 24 hours. But Tara Taylors transformation in Futurology the Musical is something else.

title: Scenes from Coachella
description: More photographs from the music festival in Indio, Calif.

title: Aliens Invaded, and the Future Looks Like the Old West
description: The new television show Defiance has received so much attention for being joined at the hip to a video game that the wrong questions are being asked about it. How the TV series and the online game  which share characters and stories but take place in different parts of a post-alien-invasion earth, circa 2046  will inform each other is more than a little beside the point, especially since the shows first season is already shot and wont be affected by the game.

title: More Cracks Undermine the Citadel of TV Profits
description: For the longest time in the media business, the concept of the bundle has been foundational. Ads go with editorial content in print, commercials go with programming on television and the channels you desire are paired with ones you did not in your cable package.

title: Crossroads Guitar Festival
description: Scenes from Eric Claptons festival at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Blues Mix and Mingle With Soul, Country and Rock
description: The blues was the center of the guitar universe at Eric Claptons Crossroads Guitar Festival, two all-star concerts with more than 30 guitarists on Friday and Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Classical and Modern, Partners in the Spirit
description: After nearly 10 years on hiatus, Dance Theater of Harlem is back. Its return performance on Wednesday at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center, though flawed, gave reasons enough to celebrate. But its second program, on Friday, opened with something more heartening: Gloria, a beautiful New York premiere by the companys resident choreographer, Robert Garland.

title: Intel Tries to Secure Its Footing Beyond PCs
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  For the last several months, Andy Bryant, the chairman of Intel, has been trying to put steel in the backs of the companys employees. At meetings, he tells them that Intel must fundamentally change even though the computer chip maker still has what it takes to succeed in engineering and manufacturing.

title: Upon a Rotating Set, a Shift of Siegmunds in Wagner Performance
description: Die Walkre returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday, and the machine worked without noticeable hitches. Yes, that machine, the 45-ton set consisting of 24 rotating planks that dominates this production from the director Robert Lepage. These days an element of tension hovers over each performance from Wagners epic cycle, back for the first run this season at the Met, because you never know when the machine might malfunction, as happened on April 6 during Das Rheingold.

title: More Snow Could Be in Mets Future
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Light early-morning snow showers and an ominous forecast prompted the Minnesota Twins to postpone Sundays game with the Mets before some people had their breakfast. The Twins e-mailed the announcement at 8:53 a.m. Central time.

title: Support Grows for European Effort to Fight Tax Havens
description: DUBLIN  Europes effort to crack down on tax havens gained momentum during the weekend as the number of countries agreeing to share more bank information doubled.

title: Sabathias Star Comedic Turn
description: The Yankees C.C. Sabathia is expanding his horizons as a commercial actor. In a new spot for ESPNs SportsCenter that comes out Monday, Sabathia gives a marvelous deadpan comedic performance along with the ESPN hosts Steve Levy and Scott Van Pelt in an ad that plays off Sabathias heft.

title: BBC Tactics in Covering North Korea Are Faulted
description: As tensions escalated between North Korea and the world late last month, a small group of students from the prestigious London School of Economics crossed the border into the reclusive country for what was described by organizers as a government-sanctioned week of sight seeing, meeting with ministers, government officials and academics.

title: Knicks Win and Get What They Want: Matchup vs. Celtics
description: The scene was set Sunday afternoon at Madison Square Garden  for payback, for message-sending, for a modest celebration and for a timely, well-earned rest. All the Knicks needed on this first day of the final week of the season was a sound victory over the Indiana Pacers. That, and four quarters without anyone being bruised, battered or broken.

title: NPR Series on Race Aims to Build a Wider Audience
description: NPRs race, ethnicity and culture reporting initiative will make its broadcast debut this week with a four-part series called Changing Races for the morning and evening news programs.

title: A Trudeau Again Leads Canada Party
description: OTTAWA  Justin Trudeau was elected leader of the embattled Liberal Party of Canada on Sunday, 45 years after his charismatic and contentious father, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, assumed the same political position.

title: Random House Adds a Big Name in Fitness
description: David Zinczenko, the former Rodale Inc. executive with a talent for self-promotion and sculpturing physiques, has signed on with Random House to provide some juice to its health and fitness offerings.

title: German Elites Drawn to Anti-Euro Party, Spelling Trouble for Merkel
description: BERLIN  With less than six months to go before parliamentary elections in Germany, a new political party that is calling for an end to the European currency union is gaining strength.

title: U.S. Rethinks How to Respond to Nuclear Disaster
description: WASHINGTON  Two years after the Fukushima nuclear accident in northern Japan, the United States government is using lessons from that disaster to rewrite its plans for responding to radiation contamination, focusing on long-term cleanup instead of emergency response. But the proposals have set off vehement opposition from critics of nuclear power.

title: Coordinated Blasts Kill at Least 20 in Somalias Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Militants carried out a suicide attack on the court complex here, and a bomb was detonated later on the airport road, in a coordinated wave of violence Sunday in the Somali capital that left at least 20 people dead, officials said.

title: Once-Maligned Coin Nears Its Big Payday
description: On the rainy night of March 9, 1962, a head-on car crash scattered a quarter-million dollars worth of coins across a North Carolina highway, and the life story of a solitary collector named George O. Walton came to an end. But another story began  one of expert blunders, abiding family loyalty and long-awaited redemption.

title: Venezuela Gives Chvez Protg Narrow Victory
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In an unexpectedly close race, Venezuelans narrowly voted to continue Hugo Chvezs revolution, electing his handpicked political heir, Nicols Maduro, to serve the remainder of his six-year term as president, officials said late Sunday.

title: A Capricious River, an Indian Islands Lifeline, Now Eats Away at It
