description: MAJULI, India  Not too long ago, Ganesh Hazarika grew rice, vegetables and peas near the edge of the Brahmaputra River on a small plot that provided him a livelihood and a safety net. Then one day the river took it away. Steadily and mercilessly, it had chewed at the banks until his tiny farm fell into the water.

title: Europeans Reach Deal With Google on Searches
description: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators into whether it abuses its dominance of online search.

title: Afghan Interpreters for the U.S. Are Left Stranded and at Risk
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The first time the Taliban tried to kill him, Sulaiman was driving to his base when his truck was hit by a rocket, knocking him down a cliff.

title: For Guan, a Week to Savor
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  At the last hole, Guan Tianlang retrieved his ball from the cup after ending his first Masters with his 48th par. The fans ringing the 18th green gave him a standing ovation. They no doubt were thinking that they had not seen the last of Guan, a 14-year-old from China who finished as the low amateur.

title: A Top Producer Leaves Katie for CNN
description: Jeff Zucker, who left Katie Courics syndicated talk show, Katie, at the end of last year to take over CNN Worldwide, is bringing in one of the shows top producers to join him.

title: In Testimony, Guatemalans Give Account of Suffering
description: MEXICO CITY  They were just children when Guatemalan soldiers rampaged throughtheir villages, often killing their parents and siblings.Many fled to mountain forests, where they foraged for food and watched some of their numbers starve to death. Some were abducted and sent to other families to be raised, in cities and towns far from the life they had known.

title: A Mills Fate Weighs Heavy on a Washington Timber Town
description: HOQUIAM, Wash.  On mornings with good weather, Jack Durney has coffee in the backyard of his house overlooking the town where he grew up and now presides over as mayor, and one of the first things he focuses on these days is the boiler stack at Harbor Paper. Is there steam coming from the mill?

title: Bryant Goes Away, but Not Quietly
description: LOS ANGELES  Kobe Bryant is no stranger to social media. In recent months, he has treated his millions of followers on Twitter and Facebook to pictures of his breakfast. He has espoused the virtues of sleep aids. He has shared inspirational quotations. And, in a nod to the all-consuming commerce of his chosen profession, he has cited his various sponsors, which include watchmakers, apparel companies and an airline based in Turkey.

title: The Antisocial Network
description: Bitcoins wild ride may not have been the biggest business story of the past few weeks, but it was surely the most entertaining. Over the course of less than two weeks the price of the digital currency more than tripled. Then it fell more than 50 percent in a few hours. Suddenly, it felt as if we were back in the dot-com era.

title: If Companies Are People...
description: HERES an idea: why not tax corporations as if they were natural persons, in accordance with their newly discovered rights of free speech? That move would solve any impending fiscal crisis.

title: Branko: Return to Auschwitz
description: Branko Lustig, a Holocaust survivor and Oscar-winning producer of Schindlers List, returns to Auschwitz for the bar mitzvah he couldnt have in his youth.

title: As Wall St. Soars in Tough Era, Company Size Is a Big Factor
description: Its tough to make sense of the economy these days.

title: Branko: Return to Auschwitz
description: April 15 marks the 68th anniversary of Branko Lustigs liberation from the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp when he was not quite 13 years old. In this Op-Doc video, we follow Mr. Lustig back to Poland to visit the Auschwitz and Birkenau camps (where he was also interned) and to celebrate the bar mitzvah he could never have as a young man.

title: Daniel Reich, 39, Resourceful Art Dealer, Dies
description: Daniel Reich, a scrappy and innovative New York art dealer who held exhibitions for two years in his tiny studio apartment and, even after renting a traditional gallery, continued to show art nomadically in places like the Chelsea Hotel and a former delicatessen in Midtown, died on Dec. 25 at his parents home in Larchmont, N.Y., his sister confirmed this week. He was 39.

title: On Guns, a Mixed Report From the States
description: The good, the bad and the ugly are emerging from statehouses across the nation as lawmakers address wildly different gun proposals prompted by the Newtown, Conn., massacre in December.

title: Parties Rifts Hinder Background Check Measure in Gun Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Deep divisions within both parties over a bipartisan measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are threatening its chances as the Senate this week begins debating the first broad gun control legislation in nearly 20 years.

title: Justices Consider Whether Patents on Genes Are Valid
description: The Supreme Court is poised to take up the highly charged question of whether human genes can be patented. But another question could trump it: Has the field of genetics moved so far so fast that whatever the court decides, it has come too late to the issue?

title: Past Failures Vanish as Australian Wins Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  With two strokes using his long putter, once considered the dullest tool in his bag, Adam Scott expunged one bitter memory that was 266 days old and another that had lingered in a countrys consciousness for 17 years. Scott became the first Australian to win the Masters when he drained a 12-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole Sunday and defeated ngel Cabrera of Argentina, whose birdie bid moments earlier had died on the edge of the cup.

title: Are Human Genes Patentable?
description: BRCA1 and BRCA2, abbreviations for breast cancer 1 and 2, are the names of human genes linked to a significant increase in the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for women. In 1997 and 1998, Myriad Genetics, based in Utah, obtained broad patents on the isolated DNA it managed to extract from these genes and on diagnostic tests to find the genes.

title: Carmen Weinstein, Who Led the Jews of Cairo, Dies at 82
description: CAIRO  Carmen Weinstein, the leader of Cairos small Jewish community and the driving force behind the restoration of Maimonidess yeshiva and other monuments of Egyptian Jewish history, died on Saturday at her home here on the island of Zamalek. She was 82.

title: Europes Bitter Medicine
description: For more than two years, European leaders have pushed a cocktail of fiscal austerity and structural reforms on troubled countries like Portugal, Spain and Italy, promising that it will be the tonic to cure their economic and financial ailments. All the evidence shows that this bitter medicine is killing the patient.

title: Cowboys and Eggheads
description: My Times colleague Mark Mazzetti has a new book out that is getting a lot of attention, including some cinematic excerpts published in The Times, here and here. The Way of the Knife recounts the recent transformation of the Central Intelligence Agency from a traditional spying shop into more of a man-hunting paramilitary  custodian of lethal drones, sponsor of dark ops, employer of secret armies and shady contractors.

title: A Tax System Stacked Against the 99 Percent
description: LEONA HELMSLEY, the hotel chain executive who was convicted of federal tax evasion in 1989, was notorious for, among other things, reportedly having said that only the little people pay taxes.

title: A Missouri School Trains Its Teachers to Carry Guns, and Most Parents Approve
description: WEST PLAINS, Mo.  At 8:30 on a cloudy, frigid morning late last month in this folksy Ozark town, the superintendent of an area school strolled through the glass doors of the local newspaper office to deliver a news release.

title: Highest-Paid Hedge Fund Managers
description: A number of hedge-fund leaders had mega paydays last year by posting big returns on their investments.

title: Should Tax Rates Penalize Marriage?
Capitalism in History Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin, Here to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Condoms on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Silencing Witnesses to Animal Abuse
A Lesson at Rutgers
description: To the Editor:

title: Support for Bronx Activist
description: To the Editor:

title: Gitmo Is Killing Me
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba

title: Woodss Odd Journey Through Golfs Majors
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: David Burge, Pianist, Is Dead at 83
description: David Burge, an American pianist and composer known as an indefatigable champion of 20th-century music, died on April 1 in Warwick, R.I. He was 83.

title: Adoption Anxiety, Long Before the Child Arrives
description: Annie (Kerry Butler), the troubled heroine of The Call, a thoughtful and engrossing new play by Tanya Barfield, finds herself staring down a problem that has become more widespread as women marry later, postponing parenting choices as they become caught up in the anxious business of pursuing careers  or should I say just earning their livelihoods.

title: Hey, Diana, Smokey, Stevie: Youre on Broadway!
description: The hit parade reels on seemingly forever in Motown: The Musical, a dramatically slapdash but musically vibrant trip back to the glory days of Detroit, where the vinyl pouring out of an unassuming two-story house took the world by storm, all but paving the citys streets with gold records.

title: Stubbornness Behind Pitchers Career Path
description: CHICAGO  The questions that Chicago Cubs starter Jeff Samardzija faces today are different from the ones he used to get. Two years ago, people wanted to know if Samardzija, a former all-American wide receiver at Notre Dame, was on his way out of baseball, if he had picked the wrong sport, whether, at 26, he was a has-been football player and a never-was baseball player.

title: Weiner, Exploring Possible Mayoral Bid, Issues Policy Booklet With Familiar Ring
description: As he seeks to extend the discussion about a possible candidacy for mayor  and shift attention away from the online sex-messaging scandal that cost him his Congressional seat  Anthony D. Weiner released a 21-page policy booklet on Sunday that he described as a blueprint for keeping New York City the capital of the middle class.

title: Sir Colin Davis, British Conductor, Dies at 85
description: April 16 | Correction appended. A full obituary for Mr. Davis is published here.

title: Small Leak Is Discovered at Plant in Fukushima
description: TOKYO  Efforts to remove highly contaminated water from a leaking underground storage pool at the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant were delayed on Sunday when the plants operator said it had found yet another leak, this time in the pipes that would be used to move the water to above-ground storage containers.

title: MetroCards for the Poor? No Asking in Stations
description: The sums are a pittance  spare quarters and dimes, perhaps less in some cases  left behind on the unwanted MetroCards tossed to the station floor.

title: The Doctor Is In, but Hundreds of Miles Away
description: High in a Manhattan skyscraper near Grand Central Terminal on a recent Tuesday, 80 critically ill patients in intensive care units scattered from Georgia to New Jersey were being monitored, remotely, by a doctor scanning a dozen computer screens.

title: Restroom on Boardwalk Threatens Luxury Views
description: The residents of the Oceana, a luxury apartment complex that sits next to the boardwalk at Coney Island Avenue in Brighton Beach, take pride in their million-dollar ocean views  or, more precisely, their up to $2 million condominium ocean views.

title: Besedka Johnson, Late-Blooming Actress, Dies at 87
description: Besedka Johnson, who was plucked from obscurity and made a star by a movie producer who had spotted her swimming one summer in Southern California  when she was 85  died on April 4 in Glendale, Calif. She was 87.

title: Eldest Statesman Plays for Pure Enjoyment With Championship Hopes
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Teemu Selanne was in a deep recess of Honda Center, talking about life as a 42-year-old N.H.L. star and as the chiseled, aging face of a franchise filled with hope and Stanley Cup aspirations.

title: The Derby Dartboard
description: A points system is now being used to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in prep races and records are starts-win-place-show. An article on the Blue Grass Stakes and the Arkansas Derby on Saturday can be found here.

title: J.F.K. Runway Run
description: Runners compete in the annual 5K race at Kennedy International Airport in Queens.

title: A Different Way of Taking Off at J.F.K.
description: As a pilot, Alexander Richards spends a fair amount of his time on runways. But as he arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport in Queens early Sunday morning, he had a different flight plan in mind: he was going to run on the runway.

title: In Surprise, Recovery in China Loses Steam
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese economic recovery lost some of its momentum during the first quarter of this year, official data released on Monday showed, surprising analysts who had expected growth to accelerate on the back of ample credit, strong infrastructure spending and firm exports.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 14, 2013

title: Acclaim Comes Late for Baseball Pioneer
description: When the mayor of Cooperstown, N.Y., Jeff Katz, searched for an appropriate street to dedicate in Bud Fowlers memory, he decided on one that led to Doubleday Field, the quaint brick stadium a baseballs throw from the Hall of Fame. An old survey of the village indicated that the street had not been named, Katz said.

title: The Sight of Granderson Serves as a Welcome, if Distant, Sign
description: Perhaps the injury news for the Yankees is finally beginning to improve. The arrival of the injured outfielder Curtis Granderson in the clubhouse Sunday was a welcomed sign that some help is on the way.

title: Courts in Slow Motion, Aided by the Defense
description: The grand exhibition hall of dawdlers that is the Bronx courthouse features procrastinating prosecutors, sluggish jailers and unhurried judges. But the true masters of delay are the defense lawyers. For them, muddled memories and lost witnesses  the passage of time itself  are the ingredients for getting clients off.

title: Yankees Kuroda and Cast of Understudies Subdue Orioles
description: It has been six months since the Yankees edged the Baltimore Orioles in the American League division series, although in many respects, for the winners, it has felt like six awfully long years.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 15
description: Smaller companies face greater headwinds. Is it G.E. or Caterpillar who will be hurt? Of course not. Its Joes Deli.

title: Minnesota N.A.S.L. Club Takes a Stand for Tolerance
description: Nick Rogers, a Liverpool fan, had a cringe-worthy experience when his North American Soccer League team was relaunched, rebranded and renamed Minnesota United.

title: A Chat With the Boston Feds Chief
description: Eric S. Rosengren, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said in an interview that he wanted to see the economy adding at least 200,000 jobs a month in addition to a declining unemployment rate before he would be ready to consider scaling back the Feds efforts to stimulate the economy.

title: Avoiding Emergency Rooms
description: On a recent Sunday afternoon, a 75-year-old Philadelphia man with a fever of over 102 degrees was unable to reach his doctor. So his daughter took him to an emergency room, where the two sat for hours until he was examined by a physician who found no reason for the fever and decided to admit him overnight.

title: Word of the Day | ambiguous
description: ambiguous \am-bi-gy-ws\ adjective

title: Combating Techs Conflict Minerals With Disclosure
description: 2:49 p.m. | Updated with announcement.Some of our most advanced technology products have helped finance the deadliest conflicts of our time. Perhaps, if tech companies change some of their habits, that can change.

title: AMC Shifts a Series to Saturdays, but Not to Kill It
description: For almost a decade, Saturday night has been televisions version of Boot Hill  where series go to die.

title: Live Musics Charms, Soothing Premature Hearts
description: Even the Beatles would have had trouble recognizing their peppy song in the lullaby that Andrea Zalkin sang to the tiny, fragile baby clutched to her chest in the neonatal unit. But there was something unintentionally poignant in the title she chose for her son: Eight Days a Week is more time than can fit on the calendar. Ms. Zalkins baby, Hudson, born 13 weeks early, has had too little time.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) WONDER WOMEN! THE UNTOLD STORY OF AMERICAN SUPERHEROINES In this Independent Lens presentation, the director Kristy Guevara-Flanagan and the producer Kelcey Edwards chronicle the evolution of Wonder Woman, from her genesis in 1941 as a DC Comics character  the creation of William Moulton Marston, a Harvard-trained pop psychologist  to present-day incarnations and what she says about societys feelings toward powerful women. Among those interviewed are the 70s television stars Lynda Carter (the New Original Wonder Woman TV film and the series The New Adventures of Wonder Woman), above, and Lindsay Wagner (The Bionic Woman) and the feminist writer and activist Gloria Steinem.

title: Hedge Fund Titans Pay Stretching to 10 Figures
description: In recent years, the criticism about giant Wall Street hedge funds  those that command billions of investor dollars from pension funds, endowments and the wealthy  is that theyre simply too big to beat the market.

title: Rivals in the Showroom, Ford and G.M. Will Develop Transmissions Jointly
description: Ford Motor and General Motors announced on Monday that they would jointly develop new transmissions with 9 speeds for front-wheel-drive vehicles and 10 speeds for rear-drive cars and trucks. The new transmissions, with more forward gear ratios than either company now offers, are expected to reach the market beginning in 2016.

title: Corrections: April 15, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Rules of the Game, for Anyone Watching and Calling From Home
description: Here are a few abstract rules to look for when watching golf tournaments from your living room.

title: Final Round: Masters Replay
description: Scenes from the final round of Masters at Augusta National Golf Club.

title: In Surprise, Recovery in China Loses Steam
description: HONG KONG  Chinas newly installed leadership is facing a major challenge on the economic front, after data released Monday showed that the countrys growth had unexpectedly lost momentum in the first quarter, complicating Beijings efforts to promote higher-quality output that relies less on credit-fueled investment.

title: News Quiz | April 15, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Finishing Homework on the Bike Ride to School
description: Dear Diary:

title: Blocking of Django Unchained Taints Beijings Film Festival
Can Bengali Mishti Go Global?
description: KOLKATA In West Bengal,itseasy to findconfectionersthat havebeenmaking Bengali sweets, known as mishti,formore thana century.There, you will find sandesh (a soft, fudge-like confection made withcottage cheese and sugar), and roshogolla (balls of cottage cheese poured into hot sugary syrup) as they have been made for decades.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 15
description: NEWS In an unexpectedly close race, Venezuelans narrowly voted to continue Hugo Chvezs revolution, electing his handpicked political heir, Nicols Maduro, to serve the remainder of his six-year term as president, officials said late Sunday. William Neuman reports from Caracas.

title: San Joses Gordon Faces Discipline Over Antigay Slur
description: Tuesday, 5:07 p.m. | Updated San Jose Earthquakes forward Alan Gordon was suspended for three games by Major League Soccer on Tuesday afternoon for directing an antigay slur at an opponent during a game against Portland on Sunday night. Gordon also was fined an undisclosed amount by Commissioner Don Garber and ordered to take part in diversity and sensitivity training.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 15, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article A.D.H.D. Seen in 11% of U.S. Children as Diagnoses Rise.

title: All Politics Is Economic
description: MOSCOW  Another independent publication is closing: The print version of the biweekly Bolshoi Gorod (Big City) and its Web site.

title: John Kerry Speaks of Possibility of Peace and North Korea
description: In Kerry Says Any Talks Rely on Steps by North Korea, Michael R. Gordon writes about the latest developments in the relationship between the United states and North Korea.

title: Japans Rootless and Restless Workers
description: A dark suit jacket hangs by a shaded window, beneath a portrait of a smiling, well-dressed executive.

title: Should Colleges Fund Wellness Programs Instead of Sports?
description: Six sports teams at Spelman College, a historically black womens college in Atlanta, have been disbanded. A seventh, the tennis team, will wrap up its operations by the end of the month. The money that would have been spent on collegiate sports will now fund wellness programming for the whole campus.

title: Production of Opium by Afghans Is Up Again
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For the third year in a row, opium cultivation has increased across Afghanistan, erasing earlier drops stemming from a decade-long international and Afghan government effort to combat the drug trade, according to a United Nations report released on Monday.

title: Greece Reaches a Deal for More Bailout Money
description: ATHENS  After nearly two weeks of tense negotiations, Greece and its troika of foreign creditors said Monday that they had clinched an agreement on economic measures that Athens must enforce to secure the release of further crucial rescue money. Those measures include thousands of layoffs in the civil service.

title: Attackers Strike Across Iraq as Elections Approach
description: BAGHDAD  Attackers struck targets across Iraq on Monday morning, setting a bloody backdrop to the last week of campaigning as Iraqis prepare to vote in local elections on Saturday.

title: Colleges Report 2013 Acceptance Rates
When a House Is Just a House, and Family Means Home
description: The man who delivered the foreclosure papers was all business.

title: Mesut zil: Real Madrids Engine Room
description: The International Film Festival in Berlin earlier this year debuted a short documentary about a 17-year-old soccer player playing at Schalke in 2006. What initially began as a look at youth soccer in Germany in general turned into a focus on a certain Mesut zil. Although shy, timid and soft-spoken in conversation, his commanding abilities on the field demanded the full attention of the camera lenses and the filmmakers.

title: The Early Word: Symbolic
description: In Todays Times

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jonathan Van Meter on Being Anthony Weiners Shrink
description: Jonathan Van Meter, a contributing editor at Vogue and New York magazine, wrote this weeks cover article about the post-scandal life of Anthony Weiner, the former New York congressman, who is considering entering the mayoral race of New York City.

title: Daily Report: European Regulators and Google Reach an Antitrust Deal
description: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators into whether it abuses its dominance of online search, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times on Monday.

title: This Week in Small Business: Free Lunch?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 15, 2013
description: Update: April 16, 2013

title: Elderly Patients Routinely Prescribed Risky Drugs
description: Doctors in the United States routinely prescribe potentially harmful drugs to older patients, and the problem is particularly acute in the South, a new study shows.

title: Dish Offers to Buy Sprint, Joining Phone to TV Service
description: 9:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Separation Anxiety
description: When was the last time you masturbated? the psychiatrist asked me matter-of-factly.

title: Pianists Posts on Twitter Spur Penalty From Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A court here handed down a suspended 10-month prison term on Monday for Fazil Say, an internationally acclaimed Turkish pianist and composer convicted of insulting Islam and offending Muslims in postings on Twitter.

title: Creditors of Lehmans European Unit Could Be Completely Repaid
description: LONDON  Creditors of the European division of the defunct American bank Lehman Brothers may recover all their money, according to a report from the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers.

title: Federal Regulators Warn of 15-Passenger Van Rollover Danger
description: Spring has sprung, so more people will be out on Americas roadways soon on their way to and from warm-weather activities. Many will be riding in 15-passenger vans, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says watch out: the risk of rollover in an overloaded van is high, and rollover crashes can be fatal.

title: Opinion Report: Guns and the States
description: From the editorial page

title: Encores! Announces Casting for On Your Toes
description: The New York City Center announced on Monday that the actress Christine Baranski (The Good Wife); Irina Dvorovenko, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater; and Joaquin De Luz, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, will be among the cast in the Encores! production of Rodgers and Harts On Your Toes.

title: As Citigroups Profit Surges, Skittish Borrowers Hurt the Consumer Unit
description: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

title: Monday Reading: What to Expect From the Latest Airline Merger
Gold Does Not Glitter
description: So, the slide in gold has turned into a rout. As Joe Weisenthal says, this should be seen as really good news, because it offers strong evidence that the goldbug/inflationista view of the world  which says that we need to stop all efforts at monetary and fiscal stimulus lest we turn into Weimar  is, in fact, all wrong.

title: Dishs $25.5 Billion Offer for Sprint
description: Dish Network offered on Monday to buy Sprint Nextel for $25.5 billion in cash and stock, challenging the planned takeover of Sprint by the Japanese telecommunications company SoftBank. The offer of $7 a share is worth about 13 percent more than the SoftBank proposal, Dish said in a statement. The Dish proposal clearly presents Sprint shareholders with a superior alternative to the pending SoftBank proposal, Charles W. Ergen, chairman of Dish, said in a statement. The Dish offer, he added, would yield substantial synergies that are not attainable through the pending SoftBank proposal. SoftBank has proposed a $20.1 billion deal to acquire a 70 percent stake in Sprint.

title: Thermo Fisher Strikes $13.6 Billion Deal for Rival in Gene Sequencing Equipment
description: 9:36 a.m. | Updated

title: A Better Baby Lullaby
description: New research finds that live music played for premature babies can be beneficial, calming their heart rate and breathing, and helping their sleep and sucking ability.

title: Europe in Brief
description: Tim Duy asks, when can we all admit that the euro is a failure? The answer, of course, is never. Too much history, too many declarations, too much ego is invested in the single currency for those involved ever to admit that maybe they made a mistake. Even if the project ends in total disaster, they will insist that the euro didnt fail Europe, Europe failed the euro.

title: Lean In Software Goes Corporate
description: The networking technology that powers Sheryl Sandbergs Lean In campaign has its own ambitions to rise inside corporations.

title: Check Out Whats Under the Hoodie
description: Seeking to expand its concept of combining fashion and technology, the apparel maker HoodieBuddie recently announced its fall 2013 collection.

title: Anne Frank House Says Biebers Visit Was Positive
description: Representatives of the Anne Frank House on Monday praised Justin Bieber for his visit to the museum after a weekend in which a message he left on a guestbook there set off a maelstrom of criticism.

title: Wall Street and Gold Slump
description: The prices of stocks and gold appeared to chase each other sharply lower on Monday after a report said growth unexpectedly slowed in China.

title: Climate Change Didnt Cause the Big Drought
description: THE HAGUE  During his most recent State of the Union Address, President Barack Obama cited the Great Plains drought last year as an example of extreme weather caused by climate change.

title: Supermodel and Draft-Dodger
description: TEL AVIV  The Foreign Ministry, always on the lookout for ways to make Israels image trendier, recently asked the supermodel BarRefaeli,one of the countrys most famous celebrities, to lead an ad campaign promoting Israeli technology and innovation abroad. She agreed, free of charge. Apparently it was a success: My Instagram feed has more readers than Israels most popular newspaper, Refaeli bragged in a tweet.

title: A Conversation With: Singer Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon
description: NEW YORK CITY  On her newest album, the singer Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon has reimagined Raghupati Raghav Raja Ram, a devotional bhajan, or hymn, in different musical traditions including Brazilian bossa nova and Chinese rhythms. Some of the tunes are fast-paced, others more meditative, but the lead voice is always unmistakably Ms. Tandons.

title: Justices Refuse Case on Gun Law in New York
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court said Monday that it would not weigh in on a major Second Amendment question that has divided the lower courts: May states bar or strictly limit the carrying of guns in public for self-defense?

title: What Were Reading
description: Smithsonian: Dont fret the invasion of the cicadas. Fry them up! Here are some tips for how to collect and prepare them for eating. Our favorite is No. 2: gather twice as many as you and your family think you can eat.  Maria Newman

title: Swoon Over Augusta
description: Ever since Adam Scott dropped to his knees after his putt plunked into the cup on the second playoff hole at the Masters Sunday evening, golf has been in full swoon. The golfing gods couldnt have come up with a champion theyd love more if had they drawn him up in an animation studio. He is young and fun and personable and as the young female portion of his fan base would say, adorbs! Australians, of course, are over the moon. They can now forget that whole Greg Norman thing ever happened. And the stuffy old men in the green eyeshades who run golf? Theyd be forming a conga line if they did that sort of thing. Scott gives their moldering sport a shot of curb appeal lacking since the legend of Tiger Woods lost a battle with a fire hydrant.

title: Triple Play: Week 2 Results
description: The perhaps overachieving Mets have a better record than their crosstown rivals, but they are the correct answer to Question No. 1 thanks to the hot start by the Atlanta Braves.

title: Brown Rice and the Arsenic Conundrum
description: Ive always been a big promoter of brown rice, and I was happily testing recipes last week for short-, medium- and long-grain varieties when I remembered that there had been reports in the past year about dangerous arsenic levels in rice, particularly in brown rice. I thought about shelving the recipe tests and choosing another subject for this weeks Recipes for Health, but then I decided to take a closer look at the reports to see if there was a way to make rice viable for health-conscious rice lovers.

title: Why E.T.F.s Wont Solve Our Behavioral Problems
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Mad Men Recap: The Coca-Cola of Condiments
description: Season 6, Episode 2

title: Tip of the Week: Magnifying Smartly on the Mac
description: The Preview app included with Mac OS X does more than just open images and PDF files. While the program can zoom in and out of open PDF files (and even display the document in a full-screen view), the Smart Magnify feature in Preview for OS X 10.7 (and later) enlarges a specific area of the document quickly.

title: Kerry Meets With Parents of Diplomat Killed in Afghanistan
description: CHICAGO  Secretary of State John Kerry met here privately on Monday with the parents of Anne Smedinghoff, the young State Department officer who was killed this month in Afghanistan. She was the first State Department officer to die in the line of duty since the September attack on the United States diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Dealing With a Laid-Back Software Vendor
description: In a post published last month, Susan Parker, a member of the She Owns It business group, shared some of her frustrations about working with a software vendor that didnt seem to share her sense of urgency. Her company, Bari Jay, has been in the process of switching to new software for more than a year. During a recent conversation, Ms. Parker reviewed the status of the project, which was supposed to take three months, and she responded to reader comments on the earlier post.

title: Office-Ready, Off the Runway
description: Two executives in Milan delve into spring collections.

title: Slide Show: Scenes From Coachella
description: More photographs.

title: Supreme Court Spectator Line Acts as a Toll Booth
description: WASHINGTON  Dale Carpenter wanted to see last months pair of same-sex marriage arguments at the Supreme Court. He bought a plane ticket from Minneapolis, where he teaches law, and he turned up at the court a little after 3 oclock on the morning of the first argument.

title: With White at S.E.C., Debevoise Picks a Successor
description: Mary Beth is succeeding Mary Jo.

Look of the Moment | Zoe Saldana
description: The Girl: The actress at the MTV Movie Awards in Los Angeles.

title: 100 Years Later, Seeing the Influence of the Erector Set
description: Dave Frieder sees a connection between two of his passions: The bridges that tie the city to the rest of the world, and Erector Sets.

title: Safer Hospital Rooms
description: C. difficile contamination of hospital rooms is a leading cause of deadly infections, and human behavior may be at least as important as technological innovation in controlling it. A new study has found that imposing a three-step cleaning procedure  and supervising it carefully  can nearly eliminate the microbe.

title: Really? Eating Fish as a Child May Curb Allergies
description: THE FACTS

title: Weekend Gun Report: April 12-14, 2013
description: The weekend gun wrap-up can be so overwhelming, we figured you may need a little comic relief before delving in. Saturday Night Live opened this weekend with a sketch poking fun at Joe Manchin and Pat Toomeys middle-of-the-road gun legislation proposals.

title: Walkabout  4/15: Vandalism in Joshua Tree; More Troubles for Boeing
description: Defacing an American Gem Graffiti has become so pervasive at Joshua Tree National Parks most popular hiking spots that officials have had to close them to the public. Some say social media is to blame for the bump in vandalism. (USA Today)

title: The Boat Captain Puzzle
description: Weve got something a bit different this week several cryptic word-logic puzzles of the sort that will be featured at the upcoming Stanford Puzzle Hunt, a one-day team competition taking place Saturday at Stanford University. Before we give the puzzles a try, lets warm up with this classic boating challenge from the math educator and problem-solving expert George Polyas 1974 classic Stanford Mathematics Problem Book.

title: Hill Countrys Draft Lines Finally Flow With Shiner
description: Since it opened in Manhattan in the summer of 2007, Hill Country Barbecue Market has had draft lines. But they remained dry. Only one beer would do, and it wasnt available.

title: Off-Duty Officer Killed Boyfriend, Their Year-Old Son and Then Herself, Police Say
description: To those on the outside, the couple seemed content, spending time together on a quiet block in Brooklyn, working at solid city-paid jobs and delighting in their infant son.

title: Challenges Mount for Chinas President
description: Whatever honeymoon President Xi Jinping of China may have been having appears to be over. If you think you are having a difficult Monday, consider his challenges.

title: What Your Tax Dollars Are Buying
description: Today  and I hope this does not come as a surprise to any of you  is tax day, when we are required to settle our bills with the federal government for the year 2012. Given how much we pay to Washington every year, it seems only fair that we ask for a receipt.

title: Stir-Fried Brown Rice With Kale or Frizzy Mustard Greens and Tofu
description: I used a beautiful green Id never seen before called frizzy mustard greens for this quick and easy stir-fry. They look like a cross between frise and curly kale and have a sharp, mustardy kick. Curly kale makes a fine substitute. Also, you can substitute white rice for the brown.

title: A Long Pursuit of Self
description: Lizzy Hawker had just finished running a nine-stage race through some of Nepals wildest trails when she learned that her flight back to Katmandu, about 200 miles away, was canceled because of bad weather.

title: Isabel Leonard Wins Richard Tucker Award
description: The Richard Tucker Foundation said on Monday that the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard had won its award named after the American tenor. The award, which comes with a $30,000 prize, is conferred on singers who the foundation deems are about to plunge into major international careers, and it often makes good calls. Past winners include Angela Meade, Joyce DiDonato, John Relyea, Matthew Polenzani, Deborah Voigt and Rene Fleming.

title: Beet Greens and Rice Gratin
description: Like so many of my Mediterranean gratins, this is bound with a combination of rice and egg. Its good hot or cold.

title: Dish Network Courts Sprint
description: Dish Network is bidding to buy Sprint Nextel to be able to offer consumers a competitive package combining broadband and cellphone service.

title: Going Up a Few Feet, and Hoping to Avoid a Storms Path
description: Jim and Leah Hogan are doing some work on their house. The ground floor is stripped down to the bones, the lawn is all dug up, and sunlight is streaming inside from unusual places, like up through gaps in the floorboard and right in through the fireplace.

title: The Seasons Top Seller? Jackie Robinson
description: More than 30 years after Jackie Robinson played his last game, the baseball pioneer made a cameo of sorts in Spike Lees 1989 movie, Do the Right Thing. Lee, who also directed the film, played a pizza deliveryman named Mookie who wore Robinsons Dodgers jersey as he navigated racial tensions brewing in Brooklyn.

title: Politics Aside, the Gosnell Trial Deserves  and Is Getting  More Coverage
description: 10:34 a.m. | Updated On Friday, after hearing some complaints about The Timess coverage of the horrifying Philadelphia murder trial of Dr. Kermit Gosnell, I reviewed what had been written so far.

title: Labyrinth Theater Company Names Mimi ODonnell Artistic Director
description: The Labyrinth Theater Company, a downtown ensemble devoted to producing new plays with multiracial casts, said on Monday that the costume designer Mimi ODonnell will become its new artistic director  an appointment aimed at stabilizing the company after three years of uneven output.

title: Library Association Lists Frequently Challenged Books
description: Sadomasochism, gay penguins and Captain Underpants. This is what passed for controversial in American literature in 2012, according to the American Library Associations annual list of frequently challenged books, released on Monday.

title: Survey on Gun-Carrying Youth Adds Fodder to Stop-and-Frisk Debate
description: Heres more grist for the debate over whether the New York Police Department stops and frisks too many young members of minority groups: Among high school students in the city, more black and Hispanic young men than white young men said in a federal survey that they had carried a gun at least once in the previous month.

title: Penney Has Some Persuading to Do
description: Heres the good news: J. C. Penney appears to at least understand that it has entered the endgame.

title: Justices Seem Wary of Bold Action in Gene Patent Case
description: WASHINGTON  In a lively Supreme Court argument on Monday, the justices struggled to find a narrow way to rule on the momentous question of whether human genes may be patented.

title: A Merger Monday for Barclays
description: Barclays investment bank is having its moment in the sun.

title: Two More Are Accused of Plotting to Kidnap, Torture and Kill Women
description: Two men, including a former librarian at Stuyvesant High School, were arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on charges that they plotted to kidnap and torture women, according to a criminal complaint released on Monday.

title: To Reinvigorate Production, Alaska Grants a Tax Break to Oil Companies
description: Hoping to reverse two decades of declining oil production in Alaska, the State Legislature in Juneau has granted oil companies an estimated $750 million in annual tax relief to increase investment in the giant North Slope oil field.

title: The Top 10 Private Equity Loopholes
description: Happy Tax Day. April 15 is a good day to reflect on how much you pay in taxes and what you receive in return. Its also good to think about how your tax rate compares with what your friends, neighbors and colleagues pay.

title: Senators Absence Worries Democrats as Gun Votes Near
description: WASHINGTON  As a crucial series of gun-control votes approaches in the Senate, lawmakers on Capitol Hill are suddenly preoccupied with one question in particular: when is Frank Lautenberg coming back?

title: 20 Lifeboats, Each a Poetic Story
description: To mark the 101st anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic, the City Room comment stalwart known as Lifeboat No. 6 has bestowed upon us a mini-epic: a long, traditional-form haiku of 20 stanzas, each representing one of the lost liners 20 lifeboats. We salute him.

title: Human Genome, Then and Now
description: Eight years of work, thousands of researchers around the world, $1 billion spent  and finally it was done. On April 14, 2003, a decade ago this week, scientists announced that they had completed the Human Genome Project, compiling a list of the three billion letters of genetic code that make up what they considered to be a sort of everypersons DNA.

title: In Montana, New Controversy Over Physician-Assisted Suicide
description: 8:34 a.m. | Updated  On Monday, the Montana Senate defeated H.B. 505, which would have mandated prison sentences and fines for physicians who provide aid in dying to terminally ill patients. The vote was 27 to 23 in opposition, after which the Senate also voted to indefinitely table the bill, eliminating the need for a final vote on Tuesday.

title: Street Style: Iridescence
description: The best of readers photos from the week of April 8.

title: In These Ads, Someday Is More Than a Wish
description: A campaign for an organization that fights leukemia and lymphoma is taking a bold, assertive tack in a bid to stand out from fund-raising efforts for other causes.

title: Monday Motorsports: Shooting at the N.R.A. 500
description: Kyle Busch won both major Nascar events at Texas Motor Speedway over the weekend. But Saturday nights N.R.A. 500, named for its controversial National Rifle Association sponsorship, was marred by a shooting in a spectator area in the tracks infield that has been ruled a suicide.

title: When to Talk About Adoption, and When to Let It Go
description: When our former babysitter had her baby last week, I was among the first ones to show up to greet her son. My 4-year-old daughter came along. She handed over the presents, disputed whether she was ready to part with the board book Id tossed in, and chattered during the entire visit. She is old enough now, though, to let me sit with a featherweight bundle of day-old baby without complaint.

title: Prepaid Debit Cards More Popular, Despite Fees
description: An analysis of prepaid debit cards finds that even as more consumers use the cards as an alternative to checking accounts, fees on the cards still vary widely.

title: Housing Trends, Short and Long Term
description: 4/16/13 | Updated to reflect new figures on housing starts and building permits.

title: Kermit Gosnell and Reproductive Care
description: What does the trial of a Philadelphia doctor who is accused of performing illegal late-term abortions by inducing labor and then killing viable fetuses have to do with the debate over legal abortion?

title: Lakers Lack Bryant but Not Confidence
description: LOS ANGELES  Last summer seems so long ago for the Los Angeles Lakers. While Kobe Bryant was in London winning his second gold medal as a member of the United States Olympic mens basketball team, the stateside hype over the coming N.B.A. season was just beginning. Bryant was about to be joined by Steve Nash and Dwight Howard to form a superfriend collective to rival the Miami Heats.

title: Excerpt: 'The Nance'
description: Jonny Orsini and Nathan Lane in a scene from Douglas Carter Beane's new Broadway play at the Lyceum Theater.

title: British Writers, World Citizens: Grantas List of Young Literary Stars
description: Every 10 years since 1983, the London-based literary magazine Granta names the 20 writers it considers the Best of Young British Novelists. The list has come to be regarded as a bellwether in the literary world, since so many of the writers singled out at that early stage of their careers  starting with Martin Amis, Pat Barker and Salman Rushdie  have gone on to great critical and commercial success.

title: Antisectarian Campaign in Egypt Urges Citizens to Remove Religion From ID Cards
description: Egyptian activists have begun an online campaign against sectarianism in the wake of a deadly attack on mourners at Egypts main Coptic Christian cathedral this month.

title: Breakfast at Tiffanys Will Close on Sunday
description: The new Broadway play Breakfast at Tiffanys will close on Sunday after 17 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the producers said on Monday. The play, adapted by the Tony Award winner Richard Greenberg (Take Me Out) from the Truman Capote novella, opened on March 20 to largely negative reviews.

title: As U.S. Seeks Security Pact, Obama Is Set to Meet Putin
description: MOSCOW  President Obama has accepted an invitation to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin ahead of a Group of 20 conference in Russia this fall, officials here said Monday  signaling a new opportunity to ease tensions even as the Kremlin continues to bristle over an American effort to punish Russian citizens accused of violating human rights.

title: Micro Go Round
description: Q. Why does my microwaves turntable switch directions when I stop it and start it again? Does it affect how the food heats?

title: Rabbi Expands Tributes to Robinson Beyond the Major Leagues
description: It was April 15, 2009, when David Zaslow, a rabbi in Ashland, Ore., plopped on his living room sofa to catch some of the days baseball highlights. Born in Coney Island and raised as a devout fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers (for his call to prayer, instead of instructing the congregation to look east toward Jerusalem, he prefers to say east toward Ebbets Field), he began to tear up at the unexpected sight of a wondrous celebration. Zaslow saw that every player had worn jerseys without names that day, donning only the No. 42.

title: Grantas Best of Young British Novelists
description: On Monday, the London-based literary magazine released its latest list of the most promising young British writers.

title: Blasts at Boston Marathon Kill 3 and Injure 100
description: BOSTON  Two powerful bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday afternoon, killing three people, including an 8-year-old child, and injuring more than 100, as one of this citys most cherished rites of spring was transformed from a scene of cheers and sweaty triumph to one of screams and carnage.

title: April 15 Updates on Explosions at the Boston Marathon

title: Bush Welcomes Grandchild and Prepares to Dedicate Presidential Library
description: DALLAS  For a former president, it does not get much better than this. Over the weekend, George W. Bush welcomed his first grandchild into the world. And next week he will welcome the arrival of his other baby, a 226,565-square-foot presidential center.

Edie Ugot, the sous-chef at the restaurant, will take over April Bloomfields kitchen on Monday and offer dishes like lumpia (crispy egg rolls) and oxtail stew with Asian vegetables.

description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank normally does its best to hold the euro together, but a study it recently issued has created a furor that could do the opposite: drive a wedge in European unity.

description: I DONT mind business travel. Im an excellent flier because Im an excellent sleeper. I have absolutely no problem falling asleep really anywhere.

title: Esquire Network Debut Is Postponed
description: The new Esquire Network has pushed back the first day of its newly branded cable channel until sometime in the summer, the top executive at the channel said on Monday. The channel was to have had its debut next week.

title: Defensive Gun Use
description: The National Rifle Association maintains a blog called The Armed Citizen, which highlights defensive gun use. The latest entry, from April 9, describes three incidents: Two from 2013 and one archival example from 1969. Its not hard to see what the NRAs getting at, but just in case, a sidebar on the site states: Studies indicate that firearms are used over 2 million times a year for personal protection, and that the presence of a firearm, without a shot being fired, prevents crime in many instances. In other words, as Wayne LaPierre put it after Newtown, the only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun.

title: This Is Your Brain on Opera
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  I attended two performances of Jonathan Bergers Visitations at the Bing Concert Hall at Stanford last week here. On Friday evening I sat in the primary motor cortex. The following night, my seat was located off to the side, in Brocas area.

title: Flights May Get Rougher as CO2 Builds Up
description: As the earth gets warmer, that flight to Europe may get bumpier.

title: Relief for a Parched Delta
description: CUCAP EL MAYOR, Mexico  Germn Muoz looked out at the river before him and talked about the days when dolphins swam here, 60 miles from the sea.

title: A Battle Plan to Lose Weight
description: Laura Ward, 41, had always attributed her excess pounds to the drugs she takes for major depression. So Ms. Ward, who is 5-foot-6 and once weighed 220 pounds, didnt try to slim down or avoid dietary pitfalls like fried chicken.

title: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated  Tonight ArtsBeat live streamed a conversation with Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge, who star in the darkly comic play Orphans, opening on Broadway on Thursday. Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by Patrick Healy.

title: On Clarinet, the Composer
description: Two years ago, in the intimate Rose Studio high above West 65th Street, the German composer and clarinetist Jrg Widmann opened a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concert with a performance of his Fantasie for Solo Clarinet, inspired by commedia dellarte.

title: Trying Passenger Patience
description: One traveler criticized the body scanners at airport checkpoints as an overpriced technology that provides a false sense of security and a real sense of intrusion into our personal lives. A second called the machines a disgrace, requiring travelers to stand with arms in the air and hands overhead, for screening our entire bodies each time we fly. A third said simply, You have NOT made me feel safer!

title: Now Reopening | Amsterdams Rijksmuseum
description: While the decade-long renovation of Amsterdams Rijksmuseum left some grumbling about delays and costs, the weekends grand reopening, counted down on a huge digital clock on the neo-Gothic buildings facade, couldnt have come at a more fitting moment. In just a few weeks, the Netherlands Queen Beatrix will turn the throne over to her son Willem-Alexander, having declared that the future of the nation lies with the next generation.

title: Uncertainty After Venezuelas Election
description: The Timess William Neuman looks at Venezuelas tight presidential race and what Nicols Maduros slim victory could mean for his presidency.

title: European Lawmakers to Vote on Tougher Carbon Measure
description: LONDON  Efforts to put some bite into Europes toothless market for carbon-emission permits face a crucial vote Tuesday in the European Parliament.

title: Explosions Rock Boston Marathon
description: The Timess John Eligon reports from Boston, where two people have been confirmed dead after explosions near the race finish line.

title: Iceland and China Enter a Free Trade Agreement
description: PARIS  In its first such agreement with a European country, China signed a free-trade deal with Iceland on Monday as Beijing reached out for allies at a time when many of its trading partners are wary of its increasing economic might.

title: Science Bookshelf: Methodology
description: The titles ranked here are selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month. These titles are fundamentally based on the sciences; those for which science is more tangential or peripheral are generally excluded. Rankings reflect combined print and e-book sales for May 2013.

title: Moses Leaves Egypt, and City Opera Comes Home
description: The good news from New York City Opera is its terrific production of Rossinis Moses in Egypt (Mos in Egitto), which opened on Sunday afternoon. Here is an exciting performance of an overlooked masterpiece with a winning young cast in an imaginative staging by the director Michael Counts that boldly incorporates video elements.

title: Albums from the Flaming Lips and Bobby Avey
description: THE FLAMING LIPS

title: Finally, Maybe, We Are What We Cook
description: Michael Pollans seventh book will not substantially surprise readers of the first six. Mr. Pollan has often said that we lose touch with the basic facts of food production at our own peril, and that shared meals hold families and communities together. He has advocated fresh ingredients and sounded warning bells about why processed foods are barely worth digesting. And he is a major ingredient in his books blend of gastronomy, science and investigation, linking his own experiences to the lessons he imparts.

title: Ice Creams Identity Crisis
description: Back then, we knew something was up if our mother returned from ShopRite with a half-gallon of Breyers ice cream. It meant that another 8-year-old first communicant had feigned an understanding of transubstantiation. It meant that someone was celebrating her first birthday, or that someone had seen his last.

title: Witnesses to Chaos at Boston Marathon
description: A runner and bystanders near the explosions at the Boston Marathon describe the blasts and the chaotic scene.

title: Side Sleeping May Reduce Risk of Stillbirth
description: If pregnant women in poor countries were advised to sleep on their sides, many stillbirths might be prevented, a new study suggests.

title: Right to Win: Q. and A. With Tom Coughlin
description: Later this month, Giants draft picks may want to supplement their playbooks with another type of book, Earn the Right to Win: How Success in Any Field Starts with Superior Preparation.

title: Science Bookshelf
description: 1 SALT SUGAR FAT, by Michael Moss. Random House. A New York Times reporter reveals how food companies rely on scientific research to encourage people to consume more of their products.

title: For the Elderly, Diseases That Overlap
description: Most residents in assisted-living centers suffer from multiple ailments.

title: A Madman, but Angelic
description: My fathers laughter introduced me to the comedy of Jonathan Winters. My dad was a sweet man, but not an easy laugh. We were watching Jack Paar on The Tonight Show on our black-and-white television, and on came Jonathan in a pith helmet.

title: Photos of The Moment | Coachella

title: Scenes From Coachella
description: Last weekend the first half of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival took place in Indio, Calif.

title: At Coachella, Nostalgia Trumps Newness
description: INDIO, Calif.  At the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, which descends upon the Empire Polo Field here each April, there are two large outdoor stages, three almost as big stages under gargantuan tents and one enclosed nightclub-esque structure. All together, they played host to about 190 acts from Friday to Sunday, ranging from global superstars to promising indie bands that may never rise beyond that level.

title: Democratic Candidates Criticize Disciplining of Citys Students
description: 7:06 p.m. | Updated A tale of two cities. Wrong. A police state. Alarming.

title: Aerial Video of Boston Marathon Scene
description: Unedited footage from above the area where explosions hit Boston.

title: Contention in Making Generic Drugs
description: Generic drug makers need samples of branded drugs in order to test their products and get them approved. Increasingly, brand-name manufacturers are refusing to sell them these samples.

title: Obama on the Explosions in Boston
description: President Obama spoke Monday evening about the explosions in Boston.

title: Drug Makers Use Safety Rule to Block Generics
description: For decades, pharmaceutical companies have deployed an array of tactics aimed at preventing low-cost copies of their drugs from entering the marketplace.

title: Photographs of Syria Sweep Pulitzer Prizes
description: Rodrigo Abd, Manu Brabo, Narciso Contreras, Khalil Hamra and Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press have won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for their coverage of Syrias civil war. Javier Manzano, a freelance photographer working with Agence France-Presse, has won the Pulitzer in feature photography for his picture of two Syrian rebel fighters taking aim through a pockmarked wall in Aleppo.

title: Colin Davis, a British Conductor Known for His Exuberant Approach, Dies at 85
description: Colin Davis, one of the most acclaimed British conductors of the 20th century, who brought immense authority and an almost palpable zest to his music-making on both sides of the Atlantic, died on Sunday. He was 85.

title: Cuomo Hits the Magazine Stands, Head First
description: ALBANY  It was probably to be expected for a man whose name is invariably mentioned on a short list of 2016 presidential contenders, but Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has become a full-fledged cover boy, albeit one whose defining physical and personal characteristic seems to be his head.

title: War Zone at Mile 26: So Many People Without Legs
description: BOSTON  About 100 feet from the end of the 26.2-mile Boston Marathon, explosions shook the street and sent runners frantically racing for cover. The marathon finish line, normally a festive area of celebration and exhaustion, was suddenly like a war zone.

title: Todays Scuttlebot:  Wireless Pain and Apple Paychecks
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Egypt, Syria and France.

title: Assassinations Grow as Iraqi Elections Near
description: BAGHDAD  In the first Iraqi elections since the American troop withdrawal, Sunni candidates are being attacked and killed in greater numbers than in recent campaigns, raising concerns in Washington over Iraqs political stability and the viability of a democratic system the United States has heavily invested in over years of war and diplomacy.

title: Pope Upholds Reprimand of American Nuns Group
description: Pope Francis has reaffirmed the reprimand of American nuns issued by his predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI, and endorsed the plan to have three bishops supervise an overhaul of the nations largest umbrella group of American nuns.

title: Kuwait Gives 5-Year Term to Dissenter
description: CAIRO  A court in Kuwait on Monday sentenced a prominent opposition politician to five years in prison for insulting the countrys ruler, a crime that leaders around the Persian Gulf are prosecuting with increasing frequency in an effort to stanch emboldened protest movements, or stop protests before they start.

title: Boston Marathon Bombing Caught on Tape
description: Video shot by The Boston Globes Steve Silva captures the scene after two bombs exploded at the Boston Marathon. Warning: Footage contains some graphic language.

title: India, Long the Home of Outsourcing, Now Wants to Make Its Own Chips
description: NEW DELHI  The government of India, home to many of the worlds leading software outsourcing companies, wants to replicate that success by creating a homegrown industry for computer hardware. But unlike software, which requires little infrastructure, building electronics is a far more demanding business. Chip makers need vast quantities of clean water and reliable electricity. Computer and tablet assemblers depend on economies of scale and easy access to cheap parts, which China has spent many years building up.

title: Remembering the First Battle
description: Participants and spectators gathered on Monday for a dawn re-enactment of the Battle of Lexington, the first skirmish of what would become the American Revolution.

title: Again, Tarloff Jury Reports Deadlock
description: For the second time during nine days of deliberations, jurors in the murder trial of a schizophrenic man accused of killing a psychologist in her Upper East Side office in 2008 sent a note to the judge insisting that they were deadlocked.

title: Europe Split Over Austerity as a Path to Growth
description: WASHINGTON  In the last year, the International Monetary Fund has performed a major reassessment of how it thinks austerity harms a weak, financially troubled economy. But while warning of the perils of slow growth, it still often insists on austerity for just such economies.

title: Stupid Writer Tricks
description: One day a couple of years ago, when I found my desk drawer so full of microphone headsets that it would no longer close, I realized it was time for an intervention. I could no longer deny it: I needed to stop reading interviews with authors.

title: Nathan Azrin Dies at 82; Changed the Field of Behavioral Psychology
description: When Nathan Azrin was appointed director of treatment development at Anna State Hospital in Illinois in 1958, a majority of the patients he was expected to treat were schizophrenic, emotionally withdrawn and in many cases mute after years in institutions. Few bothered getting dressed; most spent their days in hospital gowns.

title: U.S. Sting That Snared African Ex-Admiral Shines Light on Drug Trade
description: DAKAR, Senegal  For months, they met in hotel rooms and at an army base in Guinea-Bissau, plotting the exchange of thousands of pounds of cocaine and an arsenal of weapons between South America and West Africa.

title: With Grandchild and Library, a New Chapter for Bush
description: DALLAS  For a former president, it does not get much better than this. Over the weekend, George W. Bush welcomed his first grandchild into the world. Next week he will welcome the arrival of his other baby, a 226,565-square-foot presidential center.

title: Price of Gold Takes a Flashy Fall; Other Markets Follow
description: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Senators, Seeking Support, Weigh Revisions to Background Check Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Short of votes for their compromise gun legislation, Senators Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, and Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania, on Monday considered changes to their plan to expand background checks for gun buyers as they scrambled to win needed converts.

title: An Argentine Tradition Threatens to Crumble With City Architecture
description: BUENOS AIRES  As Concepcin Martnez, her husband and two daughters pulled into the last subway station here, cheers and clapping erupted from the throngs of people, some wearing turn-of-the-20th-century dress, waiting on the platform.

title: Long Island Inquiry Includes Claim of Altered High School Exam Score
description: An investigation into whether teachers in a Long Island school district improperly coached students on standardized tests has expanded to include an allegation that administrators changed a Regents exam grade for at least one high school student, the authorities said on Monday.

title: Under Orders, French Officials Reveal Financial Worth
description: PARIS  In most any other European democracy, the disclosures might have passed quietly, yet another dull moment in the administrative tedium of the vetting of public servants.

title: Bob Perry, Big Backer of Swift Boat Ads, Dies at 80
description: Bob Perry, a homebuilder who became one of the largest Republican campaign donors in Texas and eventually the nation, gaining notoriety in 2004 as the top contributor to the Swift Boat ad campaign attacking John Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, died on Saturday at his home in Nassau Bay, Tex., near Houston. He was 80.

title: Once a Vocal Champion of a Cleaner Albany, Cuomo Appears Plaintive
description: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pushed through his ethics legislation two years ago, few clapped as loudly as the governor himself.

title: In Break With Tradition, Its Open Season on the Royal Family
description: MADRID  For decades, the members of Spains royal family were treated with profound deference by the public, politicians and the media. Their private lives generally went uninvestigated, their whereabouts unreported, and the sources of King Juan Carloss vast personal wealth were not discussed, even though he came to the throne with almost no money in 1975, after the death of Gen. Francisco Franco.

title: Yankees Veteran Newcomers Filling Leadership Gap
description: Lyle Overbay laughed when he was compared with Derek Jeter. The notion that he  a 36-year-old first baseman long removed from his best years  could fill the void left by Jeter made him giggle.

title: Collecting Data on the Habits of Passengers Underground
description: The decisions arrive with each approaching train, testing the hard-won instincts of the New York City subway rider  world-weary, antisocial and at all times strategic.

title: Stepping on Jesus
description: Im trying to think my way through the controversy provoked by a student at Florida Atlantic University who complained when his instructor asked members of the class to write the name Jesus on a piece of paper and then step on it.

title: Assads Forces Break Through Rebel Blockade of Military Bases
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Loyalist forces in Syria have breached the insurgencys extended blockade of two important northern bases, possibly opening the way for the military to strengthen supply lines and undertake a new campaign to recapture territory lost to the rebels in the north, antigovernment activist groups said Monday.

title: Dr. Kings Righteous Fury
description: CHRIS ROCK caused a stir last Fourth of July when he tweeted, Happy white peoples independence day the slaves werent free but Im sure they enjoyed fireworks. Mr. Rocks tweet may not have topped the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.s God damn America sermon, but both sentiments are of a piece, and both seem a far cry from the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s appeal to the American dream and his embrace of the magnificent words of the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.

title: Strategists Assess How a Weiner Candidacy Would Shake Up the Race for Mayor
description: Anthony D. Weiner has not declared his candidacy, hired a staff or even held a news conference. But already, New York Citys mayoral contenders are strategizing about what they have to do to prevent the former Queens congressman from making it to City Hall.

title: Tena Tries Fresh Terms for a Delicate Topic
description: BECAUSE its not the cheeriest of topics, advertising for products that treat womens urinary incontinence tends to steer clear of medical terminology. Poise, a Kimberly-Clark brand, uses the term light bladder leakage, while Tena, an SCA Personal Care brand, uses one that could just as easily describe the kitchen sink, unexpected leaks.

title: The Locker and the Closet
description: Ive been hearing the name Jackie Robinson a lot lately, and not just because a movie about him, 42, hit multiplexes on Friday and had a bigger opening-weekend gross than any baseball movie ever.

title: What Youll Do Next
description: Over the past few centuries, there have been many efforts to come up with methods to help predict human behavior  what Leon Wieseltier of The New Republic calls mathematizing the subjective. The current one is the effort to understand the world by using big data.

title: A Wrenching Adoption Case
description: The Indian Child Welfare Act was passed in 1978 to prevent state and local welfare offices from separating Indian children from their parents, many without good reason, and placing them in non-Indian homes.

title: Westchester Loses Again on Fair Housing
description: More than three years have passed since Westchester County signed a landmark consent decree to settle a fair-housing lawsuit  years the county and County Executive Rob Astorino have spent shirking their obligations, challenging the deal in court, and losing. It lost again on April 5, when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a district judges ruling that the county was in violation of terms of the court order.

title: An Ethical Breakdown
description: Despite reforms to protect patients from being harmed by medical research in recent decades, 23 academic institutions authorized a research project that failed to meet the most basic standard: providing an informed consent document to parents that accurately described the risks and benefits of the research to be conducted on extremely premature babies.

title: Online Furor Draws Press to Abortion Doctors Trial
description: PHILADELPHIA  Through four weeks, prosecutors have laid out evidence against Dr. Kermit Gosnell, a Philadelphia abortion provider on trial on charges of killing seven viable fetuses by snipping their necks with scissors and of causing the death of a pregnant 41-year-old woman during a procedure.

description: A video of the suspect and the person of interest engaging in conversation was obtained from a commercial location next to the B12 bus stop at the intersection of Albany Avenue and Rutland Road.

title: Man Sought in 3 Brooklyn Rapes in 2 Weeks
description: The New York Police Department released a video on Monday, hoping to identify a man who they say lured three women to separate spots in Brooklyn in the last two weeks and raped them. After the third attack, on Thursday night, a clear pattern had emerged, and investigators were certain that the same person was behind all of the attacks.

title: Bombs at the Marathon
description: A marathon is the most unifying of sporting events. The city that shows up to cheer on thousands of runners doesnt really know or care much about who wins; there are no sides to root for or against. Those who stand on the sidelines  as they have done in Boston since 1897  come to celebrate runners from around the world. The country or neighborhood of origin of the competitors matters far less than their stamina.

description: Energy Future Holdings, the Texas energy giant that was taken private in 2007 in a record-breaking $45 billion buyout, disclosed a potential bankruptcy plan to its creditors on Monday.

title: Trial of a Neo-Nazi in Germany Is Delayed Over Media Concerns

title: Victory Proves Gloomy for Venezuelas New Leader
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  It hardly seemed like a victory celebration. Nicols Maduro stepped onto a stage here Sunday night after being declared the winner by a narrow margin in the presidential election to replace his mentor,Hugo Chvez, but his supporters were already streaming away in droves. The long faces told the story.
