title: Tortured Soul of Burlesque Puts on Quite the Act
description: A spotlight works like a face-lift on Chauncey Miles, the title character of The Nance, the strained if heartfelt new play by Douglas Carter Beane, set in the twilight of burlesque. As portrayed with shiny expertise and dark conviction by Nathan Lane in a production that opened on Monday night at the Lyceum Theater, Chauncey looks every year of whatever age he may admit to, and then some, whenever hes not onstage.

title: It May Be High or Low
description: To Our Boston Readers: The events at the Boston Marathon today are tragic and horrifying. The Wordplay and Puzzles & Games teams hope our Boston subscribers are well and safe, and we are keeping you all in our thoughts.

title: Cuomos 12 Tax Forms Show Income Similar to 11
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos tax returns, released on Monday, show that he earned about $230,000 last year from his state salary and investment income.

title: Trusted Deputy to Liu May Be Called in Trial
description: A federal judge ruled on Monday that prosecutors may call a longtime aide to the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, to testify in the trial of two former associates charged in an illegal campaign fund-raising scheme.

title: Carnage at the Marathon
description: A pair of blasts at the Boston Marathon on Monday left three people dead, including a child, and at least 140 more injured.

title: Another Postponed Game, a Further Disturbed Routine
description: DENVER  The baseball game scheduled here for Monday night was canceled after a snowstorm passed through and covered the area with several inches of accumulation. But there was still work to be done.

title: Judge Prevents Closing of Mississippis Sole Abortion Clinic
description: NEW ORLEANS  A federal judge in Mississippi on Monday blocked part of a state law that would have forced the closing of the states only abortion clinic.

title: Indonesia: Flag Dispute Put Off
description: The Indonesian government has extended by 60 days a deadline for the government in Aceh Province to annul a new bylaw that declares the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the provinces official flag and seal, a Ministry of Home Affairs official said Monday. Zaini Abdullah, the governor of Aceh, had faced a Tuesday deadline to strike down the bylaw, which was passed by the provincial legislature last month. The dispute centers on the outlawed flag of the Free Aceh Movement, now defunct, which signed a peace agreement with the Indonesian government in 2005 that ended a 29-year civil war. The national government and armed forces oppose the use of the banner, citing multiple national laws against separatism. Officials in Aceh say the peace agreement and the provinces special autonomy status allow it to have its own flag and seal.

title: Keep Calm and Carry On
description: Just over a week ago, my wife and I took our daughters down to the Washington Mall to see the cherry blossoms, only to find our way blocked by the Cherry Blossom Ten Mile Run, whose closing stretch lay between us and the Tidal Basin. After some deliberation, we gritted our teeth and shoved our tank of a stroller through the throngs milling just beyond the finish line, elbowing the runners out of our grim parental path, until we were through the press and headed down toward what turned out to be the not-yet-blooming sakura.

title: The Return of Wallace Becomes a Cameo
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  With Carmelo Anthony, Tyson Chandler, Kenyon Martin, J. R. Smith and Amare Stoudemire not on this trip to Charlotte and the injured Marcus Camby suited but not playing, the Knicks were down to eight players for Monday nights game against the Bobcats.

title: Iran: On Africa Trip, President Will Visit a Uranium Producer
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran has started a three-nation Africa trip that includes a visit to Niger, a leading producer of uranium. Mr. Ahmadinejad, left, is also visiting Benin and Ghana. Irans state-run media did not specify the purpose of the trip beyond a desire to advance relations with all three countries. But the stop in Niger aroused speculation that Iran, which is under international sanctions over its disputed nuclear program, might be looking for outside sources of uranium, despite its claims of self-sufficiency. Last week Iran said it had opened two new uranium mines, suggesting that its supply is running low. According to the World Nuclear Association, a London-based trade group representing the nuclear profession, Niger is the worlds fourth-biggest uranium producer. Most of it goes by contract to Areva, a mining company based in France, the former colonial power in Niger.

title: No Starters, No Problem for Nets vs. Wizards
description: Before he stepped onto the podium for a pregame news conference, Nets Coach P. J. Carlesimo was handed a white sheet with a list of six names: the nights injury report. He took a look and made a slight cringe.

title: For 3 Years After Killing, Evidence Fades as a Suspect Sits in Jail
description: They brought him into the Bronx courtroom late on that first day of the trial, his prisoners chains jingling.

title: Rangers Pin Hopes on Goalie Henrik Lundqvist
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers are clinging to the last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, and their hopes are riding on (who else?) goaltender Henrik Lundqvist.

title: Jets Gather for Spring Camp Unsure Wholl Return in Fall
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Darrelle Revis, the star cornerback recuperating from a torn anterior cruciate ligament, silently motored past a cluster of reporters in his silver Mini Cooper on Monday, perhaps unsure of how many more times he will turn onto Jets Drive.

title: Carl Williams, Champ Who Ducked No One, Dies at 53
description: Carl Williams, a former heavyweight champion who built a reputation for climbing into the ring with the best boxers of his era, including Larry Holmes and Mike Tyson, died on April 7 in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 53.

title: Start-Up Lets Users Track Who Tracks Them
description: Is your Web browsing history your business  or everyone elses?

title: Immigration Overhaul Proposal Is Likely to Ignite Fierce Debate
description: WASHINGTON  The introduction of sweeping immigration legislation on Tuesday is likely to ignite a months-long battle between those who want citizenship for the nations 11 million illegal immigrants and opponents who view such an approach as amnesty.

title: Word of the Day | feint
description: feint \fant\ noun and verb

title: Cautious Call for Political Reform in China
description: BEIJING  This week marks the beginning of a sensitive political memory in China  the anniversary of the start of the 50-day-long democracy protests, nearly a quarter of a century ago, that ran until June 4, 1989, when ordinary people seized on the sudden death of a former leader seen as a political liberal to call for change.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE CENTRAL PARK FIVE (2012) The directors Ken Burns, David McMahon and Sarah Burns revisit the case of the Central Park jogger, a 28-year-old white woman who was found in the park very early on April 20, 1989, bound, gagged, nearly naked and nearly dead, and the five black and Latino teenagers who were arrested (above, Yusef Salaam, one of the accused). They argue that the convictions, and the years the defendants served for the attack, of which they were eventually absolved last year, constituted a second, racially motivated crime. Equal measures criminal investigation, cultural exhumation and a consideration of race in a presumptively postracial America, it seeks to set the record straight, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Measured in tone and outraged in its argument, it is an emotionally stirring, at times crushingly depressing cinematic call to witness. Its also frustrating because while it re-examines the assault on the jogger and painstakingly walks you through what happened to the teenagers  from their arrest through their absolution  it fails to add anything substantively new. If you followed the news, the story will be familiar; if you lived in New York in 1989, it may also feel incomplete.

title: News Quiz | April 16, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: U.S. Engaged in Torture After 9/11, Review Concludes
description: WASHINGTON  A nonpartisan, independent review of interrogation and detention programs in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks concludes that it is indisputable that the United States engaged in the practice of torture and that the nations highest officials bore ultimate responsibility for it.

title: Once Derided, Bihars Police Become Model for Other States
description: Patna, BIHAR It was 11 p.m. on a cold night in January when Raveendran Sankaran, a high-ranking Bihar police official, was woken up by a phone call from Srinagar.

The F.B.I. took the lead role in the investigation on Monday night, and the special agent in charge of the bureaus Boston office described the inquiry at a news conference as a criminal investigation that is a potential terrorist investigation. Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston.

description: Last month, the chief medical officer of Britain called antibiotic resistance a ticking time bomb and a threat as dangerous as global warming. In Europe alone, 25,000 people die every year from antibiotic-resistant bacteria  and thats only counting the infections that were picked up in supposedly sterile hospitals.

description: In Boston Marathon Blasts Kill 3, John Eligon and Ken Belson report on explosions near the marathons finish line in Boston on Monday.

description: An abomination of epic proportions. Vulgarly ostentatious. The death of the noble game.

title: UBS Lures European Deal Maker Away From Nomura
description: LONDON  William Vereker, the former joint head of global investment banking at Nomura, has joined UBS as head of corporate client solutions in Europe.

title: What People Think About Taxes
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: The Early Word: Unveiled
description: In Todays Times

title: Officials Urge Tight Security for London Marathon After Boston Bombs
description: LONDON  With security forces in many cities on alert for copycat attacks after the Boston Marathon bombings, British officials on Tuesday urged a review of security measures for the London Marathon on Sunday  the next big international race  as the police and military here prepared to deploy for another major public event with the ceremonial funeral of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday.

title: Recipe Lab Video Chat With Deborah Madison
description: Today we sat down with the author Deborah Madison to discuss her new cookbook, Vegetable Literacy, as part of Recipe Lab, a monthly feature in which you, our readers, are invited to cook with us. A replay of their discussion, featuring Julia Moskin of the Times and three home cooks, is above.

title: Should Unsupportive Relatives Be Invited to Same-Sex Wedding?
description: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Why We Have Changed Our Minds About Pittsburgh
description: In August 2012, Fred Wilson, the venture capitalist, wrote a blog post called No Battle Plan Survives the First Enemy Fire. In it, he wrote:

title: Italy Orders Seizure of $2.35 Billion in Siena Bank Inquiry
description: FRANKFURT  Italian officials on Tuesday broadened their investigation into whether the Japanese investment bank Nomura had helped hide losses at the troubled lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena by ordering the police to seize assets worth $2.35 billion.

title: Daily Report: Dishs Bid for Sprint Scrambles the Wireless Outlook
description: Smartphones, tablets and computers all pull data from the Internet, but people still pay two different bills: the high-speed connection they get at home and the wireless connection they get outside. Dish Network, the pay-TV operator, wants to bridge that gap, Brian X. Chen and Mark Scott report in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Rural Southeast Iran
description: TEHRAN  Southeast Iran was hit Tuesday by the most powerful earthquake to strike the country in 40 years, and its reverberations were felt as far away as India, but Iranian officials said the tremor had originated so deep underground, and in such a sparsely populated area, that it caused relatively few casualties and only minor damage.

title: Q&A: Printing Windows 7 Contacts
description: Q.

title: China Suggests That U.S., Projecting Power, Is Stirring Asia-Pacific Tensions
description: HAIKOU, China  China published a national defense paper on Tuesday suggesting that the United States was creating tensions in the Asia-Pacific region by strengthening its military presence and reinforcing its alliances there. The paper, released by the Ministry of Defense, did not declare that the United States was responsible, but the message was clear.

title: Hong Kong ArtWalk Remembers its Roots
description: HONG KONG  When Hong Kong ArtWalk started in 2001, a bunch of us sat down at the offices of HK Magazine, a free weekly where I was working. We drew up a map of what was then considered a new, up-and-coming neighborhood called Soho. We had cobbled together about 15 galleries and found some local restaurants to sponsor us with bottles of house wine and cheese cubes with toothpicks in them. This seemed pretty impressive to us at the time.

title: SoftBank Shares Drop After Dishs Competing Bid for Sprint
description: A day after the satellite-TV provider Dish Network offered to buy Sprint Nextel for $25.5 billion, the Japanese telecommunications giant SoftBank struck back.

title: Wheelies: Reclaiming a Record Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the web:

title: The Mental Game
description: We lose ourselves in the things we love. We find ourselves there, too.  Kristin Martz

title: April 16 Updates on Aftermath of Boston Marathon Explosions
description: 12:03 A.M. | Live Blogging Will Resume on Wednesday

title: An Unbowed Goldman Reports Profit Growth, but Caution Remains
description: 8:36 p.m. | Updated

title: More Words We Love Too Much
description: After last weeks entry on phrases that need a rest, a former colleague pointed out the enduring popularity of another journalistic clich: the firestorm.

title: Europe Vote Sets Back Carbon Plan
description: LONDON  Europe, which led the world in creating a system of emission permits to combat greenhouse-gas emissions, dealt a potential death blow to that system on Tuesday.

title: Tuesday Reading: Making Hospital Rooms Safer
Boston Bombs Were Loaded to Maim
description: BOSTON  The explosives that killed three people and injured more than 170 during the Boston Marathon on Monday were most likely rudimentary devices made from ordinary kitchen pressure cookers, except they were rigged to shoot sharp bits of shrapnel into anyone within reach of their blast and maim them severely, law enforcement officials said Tuesday.

title: In Her Iron Grip
description: LONDON  Margaret Thatcher reportedly once boasted that her greatest achievement was helping create New Labour, the neutered party that Tony Blair retrieved from the wreckage she left after destroying Britains more obdurate trade unions.

title: BlackRock Earnings Rise 10% as Investors Step Back Into Markets
description: 1:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Updating Lennon: Ono Imagines No Fracking
description: She has not yet come up with a slogan as catchy as Give Peace a Chance or even War Is Over! (If You Want It), for her campaign to stop hydraulic fracturing, or fracking. But in the latest salvo in her public quest to persuade Governor Andrew M. Cuomo of New York to find alternative approaches to extracting natural gas, Yoko Ono is modifying another of John Lennons song lyrics. On Monday evening she unveiled Imagine No Fracking, a poster art installation in the windows of ABC Carpet and Home, at Broadway and 19th Street in Manhattan.

title: Proust at the Morgan Library
description: Dear Diary:

title: Opinion Report: Boston Marathon
description: From the editorial page

title: Glencore Wins Chinas Blessing for Its $30 Billion Takeover of Xstrata
description: LONDON  The commodities trader Glencore International received final regulatory approval from China on Tuesday, clearing the way for its proposed $30 billion takeover of the mining company Xstrata.

title: Constitution Projects Report on Detainee Treatment
description: A sweeping 600-page report by a bipartisan, independent group held top American officials responsible for the torture of detainees after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: I.M.F. Lowers Estimates for Global Economic Growth for 2013
description: WASHINGTON  With economic leaders gathering in Washington for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund spring meetings this week, the I.M.F. has nudged down its estimates for world growth in 2013.

title: Microsoft Takes Aim at Amazon With a New Cloud Service
description: As president of Microsofts server and tools division, a $19 billion-a-year business devoted to databases, servers and other software products, Satya Nadella has a predictable cast of competitors to worry about. There is Oracle, VMware, SAP and a bunch of other makers of highly technical products that make everyday services like banking and airline reservations work, even if the software running them is invisible to most consumers.

title: Why Do I Think My Salary Pays for Child Care?
description: A few years ago, I wrote an eBook about how couples manage their money. As part of my research, I read The Creation of Domestic Currencies by the Princeton professor Viviana Zelizer, who studies the way economics and emotion intertwine. Dr. Zelizer writes about how in the 1920s and 30s, when wives earned money  no matter how much money it was or how important it was to the familys bottom line  it was treated as pin money and was earmarked for the more frivolous expenses. Maybe it would be used to buy a special dress for the baby. It probably would not be used to buy a house.

title: Goldmans Earnings Show Strength
description: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported profit of $2.2 billion in the first quarter, driven by strength in investment banking and lending. The earnings of $4.29 a share represented a 9 percent increase from the quarter a year earlier. The results beat analysts expectations of $3.89 a share, according to Thomson Reuters. Our strong client franchise across our businesses drove generally solid results. Still, the potential for macroeconomic instability was felt in the quarter and constrained overall corporate and investor activity, Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldmans chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. Goldmans stock rose slightly in premarket trading on Tuesday. A conference call to discuss the results is being held at 9:30 a.m.

title: Fighting for Girls Education
description: Regarding Girls Who Risk Their Lives for Education by Gordon Brown (Views, April 9): Just as the fight for civil rights defined an era for America, the current fight for girls rights to education comes at a ripe and urgent moment for Asia and the Middle East. At a time when revolutions rock false republics and new powers struggle to balance political rights with economic prosperity, women and girls are demanding a guarantee of an equal stake in the futures of their respective countries.

title: Dell Reaches a Deal With Icahn
description: 2:11 p.m. | Updated

title: Venezuelas Election
description: A close result for Hugo Chvezs chosen sucessor, Nicols Maduro.

title: Beside a Path to Citizenship, a New Path on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  A sweeping immigration bill that a bipartisan group of eight senators completed on Tuesday seeks not only to fix chronic problems in the system and bring an estimated 11 million illegal immigrants to the right side of the law. It would also reorient future immigration with the goal of bringing foreigners to the country based increasingly on the job skills and personal assets they can offer.

title: What Were Reading
description: Saveur: In 17th-century Russia, rhubarb was so valuable that much of the countrys treasury was derived from the medicinal sales of the imported rhubarb root, Dara Moskowitz Grumdahl writes. When Chinese emperors and Russian czars had a border dispute, withholding rhubarb was Chinas biggest weapon. Playing diplomatic hardball with pie filling? Who knew?  Jeff Gordinier

title: In Performance: Nathan Lee Graham of Hit the Wall
description: Ike Holters play Hit the Wall unfolds over the course of one night during the 1969 Stonewall riots that helped spark the modern gay rights movement. In this scene the actor Nathan Lee Graham, who plays Carson, a drag queen, sings the Harold Arlen-Johnny Mercer song Come Rain or Come Shine. The show continues through April 28 at the Barrow Street Theater in Greenwich Village, near where the uprising took place.

title: In Boston, Tragedy and Triumph
description: Acts of terror typically rip apart ordinary days, turn routine trips to work or school into pits of pain and heartache. That is what made the shock of Mondays blasts at the Boston Marathon finish line so different. Patriots Day in Boston is no ordinary day. Its a day to celebrate Americas essential character. The marathon itself is a stream of celebration, a parade of people defying limits, championing their determination and resolve. And then two bombs went off and rocked it all. The shock waves did not stop before reaching every last bit of our country, and beyond.

title: TouchRetouch Erases Photo Flubs
description: Why do we spot problems in a photo when its too late, as in I dont recall seeing that trash can in the park flower bed. The TouchRetouch app for Apple and Android products lets you remove that trash can  or a facial blemish, or telephone pole  that has ruined your composition.

title: Density
description: Theres an interesting discussion underway about whether rising population necessarily leads to rising land prices over time. Bill McBride of Calculated Risk says yes:

title: Agents Descend on a New York Gallery, Charging Its Owner
description: Outside the rarefied world of art dealers and collectors, where discretion is often prized nearly as much as the art itself, the Nahmad family does not attract the same recognition as some of their fellow billionaires.

title: Cycling Past an Afghan Taboo
description: In November, Shannon Galpin was riding her single-speed mountain bike through the hills outside Kabul. It was her 11th visit to Afghanistan, and she had grown accustomed to the sight of camel caravans, abandoned Soviet tanks and soldiers sweeping the desert for land mines.

title: The Hunt, a Social Commerce Site, Draws Celebrity Interest
description: Tim Weingarten, the founder and chief executive of The Hunt, remembers how he shopped for clothes in the days before the ubiquity of the Internet.

title: Maduros Gloomy Victory
description: Supporters of the newly elected Venezuelan president, Nicols Maduro, celebrated on the streets of Caracas, while the opposition engaged in energetic protests, with many demanding a recount.

title: Europe Votes to Curb Banker Bonuses
description: BRUSSELS  European lawmakers voted on Tuesday to cap banker bonuses at the regions largest institutions, as part of a major set of reforms designed to curb the financial industrys risky behavior.

title: The Gun Report: April 16, 2013
description: Sometimes a shooting can last 14 years. Thats how long it took Jerry Jackson to die after being shot and paralyzed in Kansas City, Mo. Sometimes the aftermath lasts 36 years, as it did for Walter Johnson; 20 years, as it did for Keith Cunningham;23 years, as it did for David A. Thornsley; and sometimestwo and a half, as was the case for Willie Thomas.

title: Barbra Streisand Is Taking Your Questions
description: 3:08 p.m. | Updated: Comments are now closed. Responses are published.

title: Catch of the Day
description: Its hard to believe that these soft, buttery clutches were once swimming in Lake Victoria and are now eliciting oohs and aahs on a breakfast table at Balthazar in New York. Passers-by stop to ask how to snare one of them. Nile perch leather clutches in natural beige and smoky blue gray are exquisite and surprisingly sturdy. Susan Easton, a former graphic designer who traverses the globe seeking such treasures, found the leather in Kisumu, Kenya, where she met the wives of fishmongers who skin and prepare the fish for sale. Each piece, hand-sewn by an artisan born to a family of tailors, is made from a single fish hide and is sewn along the bottom of the envelope-style clutch, which leaves a flap with an interesting, natural edge. The metal clasp is made of reclaimed brass, hammered and shaped like a fish scale. Get hooked.

title: Need a Financial Tuneup? Nominate Yourself Here
description: Is your financial life in disarray or in need of fine-tuning? Do you have a long list of money-related tasks that you cant seem to get done?

title: Mad Men City Hall vs. Real 1967 City Hall
description: When the sixth season of Mad Men opened last week on AMC (see video below), it was December 1967 in New York City, and the fictional Henry Francis had landed a post as a top-level aide in the very real Mayor John V. Lindsays administration, after working as a political operative for Lindsay last season.

title: Frank Bank, Lumpy on Leave It to Beaver, Dies at 71
description: Frank Bank, who played the sweet teenage nitwit Lumpy Rutherford on the 1950s-60s hit sitcom Leave It to Beaver, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He had celebrated his 71st birthday the day before.

title: Living Through Terror, in Rawalpindi and Boston
description: BOSTON

title: Looking for Clues in Boston Bombings
description: The Timess Michael Cooper reports on developments as the authorities begin to unravel a complex crime scene one day after explosions at the Boston Marathon.

title: How to Read Like a Reporter Who Fell Down the Rabbit Hole
description: Elizabeth Weil is a contributing writer for the magazine. Her most recent article was about a family that practices yoga together.

title: Musharraf Is Disqualified From Pakistani Elections
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court disqualified Pervez Musharraf, the countrys onetime military leader and president, on Tuesday from taking part in coming national elections, dashing his hopes of rejoining Pakistani politics.

title: To Promote Brad Pitt Zombie Movie, Paramount Plays Up the Horrors
description: LAS VEGAS -- Terrifying. Much scarier than I expected. Brad Pitt would seriously take a child to see this?

title: Starter: Lafayette, a Grand Cafe
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

title: Image of the Day: April 16
Before Gujarat Riots Raged, Warning Bells Ignored, Petition Alleges
description: NEW DELHI The Gujarat government ignored numerous warnings from its own police that violent mobs, stoked in part by right-wing Hindu leaders, were forming around the state shortly before the Godhra riots of 2002, a new legal petition claims.

title: Mistrial Declared in 08 Killing of Psychologist
description: The murder trial of David Tarloff, a schizophrenic man accused of killing a psychologist in her Upper East Side office five years ago, ended in a mistrial on Tuesday, as a jury told a judge that it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Obama: Act of Terrorism in Boston
description: President Obama spoke on Tuesday morning about the latest into the investigation of bombings at the Boston Marathon.

title: G.M. Enters the 3-Cylinder Engine Arms Race
description: Once upon a time, General Motors was intent on making the biggest, most powerful cars humankind had ever seen. But times have changed since the era of cheap gasoline, and todays car buyers tend to be more interested in miles per gallon than miles per hour. Accordingly, automakers appear to be thinking small these days.

title: Feeling For | Reed Krakoff Graphic Boxer
description: Just in time for that first springlike week, Reed Krakoff introduces a limited-edition series of his Boxer bag. Available in 20 styles, the bags palette focuses on several combinations: taupe, white and black; red, tangerine and fuchsia; lemon, lime and chartreuse; and variations of a marbleization of white and black done through exotic skins (alligator, ostrich and python) and textures (Krakoffs signature felt). The pieces are available exclusively at Saks Fifth Avenues flagship location starting April 23.

title: Obama Calls Blasts an Act of Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama went before cameras at the White House on Tuesday, he said he knew nothing more about who carried out the deadly bombings in Boston than he did the day before. But he knew enough to call them an act of terrorism.

title: Easy Riders
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  A developed city is not one in which the poor get around by car but one in which the rich get around by public transit, a former mayor of Bogot once said. Thats the vision Vietnam is trying to live up to as it becomes more prosperous.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Making Fracking Safer
Choosing a Practical Major
description: Philip A. Bean is an associate dean and dean of academic affairs at Haverford College, a private, liberal arts institution near Philadelphia.

title: Bombings End Decade of Strikingly Few Successful Terrorism Attacks in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The bombing of the Boston Marathon on Monday was the end of more than a decade in which the United States experienced strikingly few terrorist attacks, in part because of the far more aggressive law enforcement tactics that arose after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: Preppy Gets a Tweak
description: SOMETIMES A REPP TIE is just a repp tie, a madras bow tie merely a madras bow tie, a ribbon belt nothing more than a ribbon belt.

title: What Would a Fighter Jet Buy 60 Years After Eisenhowers Speech?
description: Shortly after the death of Joseph Stalin, President Dwight D. Eisenhower believed a rare opportunity existed to reset United States-Soviet relations, and he announced it to the world 60 years ago Tuesday in his 1953 Chance for Peace speech.

title: Edible Schoolyard NYC Spring Benefit
description: Early last night, a crisp spring evening, New Yorkers picked up their forks in celebration of the Edible Schoolyard NYCs recent expansion into Harlem. The industrial setting  the Essex Market  contrasted with the fresh produce and drinks on offer. Guests sipped summerlike libations (Parkside Fizz, Paris 75) and nibbled a selection of local cheeses and passed hors doeuvres before dinner. During cocktails, Diana Taylor and Elizabeth Leeds were resplendent in coordinating green dresses from Oscar de la Renta and Rag & Bone, respectively.

title: If You Like Judy Collins, Try Amy Speace
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Author Who Annoyed McCartney Will Write His Biography
description: Philip Norman, a prolific biographer whose Shout! The Beatles in Their Generation is considered by many to be among the most absorbing and comprehensive biographies of the group, and whose John Lennon: The Life was widely admired, has been signed by Little, Brown and Company to write a biography of Paul McCartney.

title: Excerpt: 'The Big Knife'
description: Reg Rogers and Bobby Cannavale in the Roundabout Theaters revival of Clifford Odetss 1949 play.

title: Security Experts Ponder Whether Any Long Race Can Be Completely Safe
description: Investigators in Boston are still sifting through evidence to determine who set the bombs that killed three people and injured scores on Monday.

title: A New Sign of a Swoon
description: Dont be fooled by the headline number  there was more evidence of a spring swoon in new government data released Tuesday.

title: Thermo Fishers Deal Shows Life in Strategic Bids
description: Corporate bidders have life in them yet. Thermo Fisher Scientific is paying $13.6 billion for the genetic test equipment maker Life Technologies, edging out a group of private equity suitors.

title: Suit Seeks to Block Arkansas Abortion Law
description: Supporters of abortion rights on Tuesday filed a challenge to the new Arkansas law banning most abortions at the 12th week of pregnancy, calling it a violation of over 40 years of settled United States Supreme Court precedent and a threat to the rights, liberty and well-being of Arkansas women and their families.

title: Holy Coding Error, Batman
description: The intellectual edifice of austerity economics rests largely on two academic papers that were seized on by policy makers, without ever having been properly vetted, because they said what the Very Serious People wanted to hear. One was Alesina/Ardagna on the macroeconomic effects of austerity, which immediately became exhibit A for those who wanted to believe in expansionary austerity. Unfortunately, even aside from the papers failure to distinguish between episodes in which monetary policy was available and those in which it wasnt, it turned out that their approach to measuring austerity was all wrong; when the IMF used a measure that tracked actual policy, it turned out that contractionary policy was contractionary.

title: Chianti and More for Traditional Italian Dishes
description: David Tanis shares his recipe for saltimbocca chicken in his column, City Kitchen. Here are some thoughts on what to drink with that dish; share your suggestions in the comments section below.

title: Manzanilla
description: Inside the chef Dani Garcas first restaurant outside Spain.

title: New York City Ballet Announces 2013-14 Season
description: The 2013-14 season of New York City Ballet will include the world premieres of ballets by Peter Martins, Justin Peck, Angelin Preljocaj and Liam Scarlett, as well as original scores by Marc-Andre Dalbavie (Mr. Martins) and Sufjan Stevens (Mr. Peck), the company announced on Tuesday.

title: Budget Would Eliminate Taxes on Forgiven Student Debt
description: President Obamas proposed budget for the 2014 fiscal year would prevent the taxation of student debt that is forgiven under federal income-based repayment plans, according to the Institute for College Access and Success.

title: Obama Doubts That North Korea Can Make a Nuclear Warhead
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said in an interview broadcast Tuesday that he did not believe that North Korea yet had the ability to miniaturize a nuclear weapon to fit atop a missile, and he said nothing would shake him from a strategy of refusing to reward the kind of provocative behavior exhibited by Kim Jong-un, the Norths leader.

title: An Import With a Foot in Spain
description: Wylie Dufresne was sitting at the end of the bar. In about three weeks he would open another restaurant of his own, but he had given himself a night off to check out somebody elses, Manzanilla. Its chef and owner is Dani Garca, a big deal in Andalusia and, as the first guy to bring liquid nitrogen into the kitchen, a member in good standing of the modernist sorcerers club. At his flagship restaurant, Calima in Marbella, Mr. Garca makes trompe loeil tomatoes and fashions chocolate butterflies with mango wings. Simply by opening Manzanilla, his first restaurant outside Spain, on East 26th Street, he has drastically increased the number of chefs in town with whom Mr. Dufresne might conceivably swap recipes.

title: The T Words
description: Terror. Torture. Name it and claim it.

title: Public Theater Season to Include Fun Home and New Apple Family Series Play
description: The Public Theaters 2013-14 season, announced on Tuesday, will include the new musical Fun Home, based on the graphic novel by Alison Bechdel, and the new play Regular Singing, the fourth and final part of the critically acclaimed Apple family series by Richard Nelson. In addition, all four plays in the Apple series  which are each set on important days or anniversaries in American civic life  will be performed at the Public in repertory, with Regular Singing opening on Nov. 22  the 50th anniversary of the Kennedy assassination.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Creates Prize to Honor Nora Ephron
description: A quintessential New York filmmaker is getting an award named for her by a quintessential New York film festival. The organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival said on Tuesday that they will introduce a new honor, the Nora Ephron Prize, named for that screenwriter and director of Sleepless in Seattle and This Is My Life, among other films, who died in June.

title: How Not to React to Boston
description: With downtown Boston still an active crime scene, one of the leading anti-immigrant voices in Congress latched on to the marathon bombings as a reason to halt immigration reform.

title: Officials Describe Chaos at Guantnamo in Weeks Before Raid on Prison
description: GUANTNAMO BAY NAVAL BASE, Cuba  Military officials on Tuesday described prison conditions here in the weeks leading up to a raid Saturday as chaotic, with detainees breaking rules with impunity, blocking cameras and windows, shouting at guards, splashing them with urine and poking sticks at them through the fencing. They said prisoners refused to go into their cells and shut their doors for a daily two-hour lockdown, and it was deemed too dangerous for guards to enter the common area to remove a troublemaker when many prisoners were freely roaming.

title: Digital Notes: Spotifys Global Ambitions
description: The worldwide competition among digital music services continues to grow as Spotify expands in Asia, Europe and Latin America.

title: A Study That Set the Tone for Austerity Is Challenged
description: 8:10 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON  In recent years, policy makers in Europe and the United States have fastened on the notion that reaching a certain heavy burden of debt would threaten future economic health  often to justify austerity budgets that increased unemployment and sapped economic strength in the here and now.

title: Bedford-Stuyvesant Historic District Triples in Size
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to triple the size of the Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, historic district, expanding its borders to include 800 more buildings.

title: Oklahoma State of Mind
description: It was F. Scott Fitzgerald  or was it Thomas Wolfe?  who established the four essential ingredients of the first novel of the smart young man from the American provinces: girl, town, youth and book. These are not independent elements. The longing for the girl is a longing to write. The elegy for the town is the elegy for youth, the girl and the book. A sentence about one is a sentence about all.

title: A Culinary Union in Barcelona
description: Three head chefs from different backgrounds have fused their culinary worlds together at Pakta.

title: After the Foam and Fame, a New Direction
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Dont expect molecular gastronomy at the Adri brothers latest Barcelona restaurant. In fact, dont even mention it.

title: Neighborhood Mourns Loss of 8-Year-Old Following Boston Blasts
description: BOSTON  Bill Richard, the father of the 8-year-old boy who was killed in Mondays deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, released a statement on Tuesday thanking everyone for their thoughts and prayers and asking for patience and for privacy as we work to simultaneously grieve and recover.

title: Speed Demons and the Velocity of Words
description: Rachel Kushners second novel, The Flamethrowers, unfolds on a bigger, brighter screen than nearly any recent American novel I can remember. It plays out as if on Imax, or simply higher-grade film stock.

title: American Airlines Resumes Flights After a Computer Problem
description: American Airlines was forced to ground all of its flights for several hours on Tuesday after a nationwide problem with its computer systems. By late afternoon, its computers were back up and its operation were slowly coming back to life.

title: Reviving the Colorado
description: The Times's Henry Fountain discusses a new agreement between the United States and Mexico that seeks to revitalize the long-parched Colorado River delta.

title: Tokhtakhounov, Alimzhan et. al. Indictment
description: Read the full indictment of the investigation into a gambling operation that focused on a Russian organized crime group that ran high-stakes poker games.

title: After Bombings, Rivers Commends Spirit of Boston
description: BOSTON  If the N.B.A. schedule allows, Celtics Coach Doc Rivers always has a set plan to watch the Boston Marathon. He leaves the teams practice site in Waltham, Mass., for the drive back to his hotel in Boston, which is a few blocks from the finish line.

title: Basketball Giant Keeps Pressing China on Rhinos and Ivory
description: Its encouraging to see Chinas basketball legend Yao Mingcontinuing his effort to educate Chinas middle class on the ecological cost of its appetite for ivory and rhinoceros horn. He put on a new push at a Beijing news conference today.

title: An Acting Debut for John Guare
description: The Atlantic Theater Company announced on Tuesday that the Tony Award-winning playwright John Guare, whose plays include Six Degrees of Separation and The House of Blue Leaves, will make his Off Broadway acting debut in its production of his new play, 3 Kinds of Exile.

title: As Shareholder Fights Heat Up, Activists Aim at Bigger Targets
description: The annual proxy season battle between shareholders and corporations appears to have reached a tipping point in favor of shareholders this year. And while some may hope that this will change public companies for the better, we may instead end up with something resembling trench warfare.

title: Preemies and Sound
description: The Times's Pam Belluck reports on a new study about the use of music therapy for premature infants.

title: Cyberwar: How Digital Threats Are Redefining National Security
Now Showing | Saturdays Surf NYC
description: Twenty years ago, if you told somebody on the West Coast that you were from New York or New Jersey and that you surf, they would look at you like you had two heads, says Danny DiMauro, a surfer and New Jersey native. The same reaction may result at the suggestion of starting a lifestyle periodical in print that is entirely free of advertising. But this week, the fellows behind Saturdays Surf NYC, a hybrid brand that acts as a surf shop, bookshop, coffee bar and mens-wear boutique, release the second issue of their biannual publication called Saturdays Magazine.

title: F.D.A. Rejects New Drug for Migraines
description: Only weeks after Allergan spent nearly $1 billion to acquire the rights to a new drug for migraine headaches, the Food and Drug Administration has rejected the product.

title: Supreme Court Rules in Favor Of 1 Worker, but Not Another
description: WASHINGTON  In a pair of 5-to-4 decisions issued on Tuesday, the Supreme Court ruled in favor of an injured airline mechanic and against a registered nurse who said her pay had been unfairly docked.

title: Sorting Through the Debris in Boston
description: Authorities are searching the cordoned streets near two explosions that struck Monday in an attempt to find any clues about what happened.

title: Europe Says Tests Show Horse Meat Scandal Is Food Fraud
description: LONDON  Two months after a horse meat scandal first gripped Europe, tests conducted by European Union countries showed on Tuesday that France had found the most beef products containing horse DNA, while Britain had detected the most traces of a painkiller banned from the human food chain.

title: Returning Home: Benjamin Lytal Talks About A Map of Tulsa
description: Benjamin Lytals novel A Map of Tulsa is the story of Jim Praley, a young man back in his hometown for a summer during college who falls in love with an artist named Adrienne. Five years later, living in New York, Jim returns to Tulsa when he learns that Adrienne has been injured in an accident. In The New York Times Book Review, Gary Sernovitz writes, Lytal asks the essential questions: how to be good; how to be an adult; how to live outside ones head; how to love unselfishly; how to understand if this girl, this town  any of it, anything at all  are indispensable, and if theyre meaningful enough to turn into art. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Lytal discussed the elements of autobiography in his book, what hes learned from being a book critic and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: In Denver, No Business Like Snow Business
description: DENVER  The day here, at least by baseball standards, began with a fairly extraordinary sight.

title: Hospitals Profit From Surgical Errors, Study Finds
description: Hospitals make money from their own mistakes because insurers pay them for the longer stays and extra care that patients need to treat surgical complications that could have been prevented, a new study finds.

title: A Recorded Legacy of Sports
description: During a 74-year career as a sportscaster, Bob Wolff collected his interviews with some of the best-known athletes in the United States. Now he is donating the collection to the Library of Congress.

title: In Asuncion, Paraguay, Small-Scale Charms and a Complex History
description: Cooking a chipa cabur in a tatakua is surprisingly like roasting a marshmallow in a campfire. After wrapping dough around a stick, you place it just barely inside the edge of the domed brick oven and rotate it slowly. Get too close to the wood fire and the exterior burns; rotate it just enough and it browns beautifully as the inside cooks through, ready to be slid off the stick and eaten hot.

title: Photo Replay: April 16

title: Sister Act | Chapin Sisters
description: Abigail and Lily Chapin have been singing together their entire lives, and performing as a band, the Chapin Sisters, for almost a decade. For their latest project, the pair decided to compose an album entirely of Everly Brothers songs  not so much as a tribute but, according to Abigail, 33, as a master class. Because the folk-pop duo began their career as a trio  their half-sister, Jessica Craven, left the group to start a family in 2009  theyd been studying the Everlys for clues as to how to move from what Abigail describes as an almost doo-wop style, in which one of us is singing and the other two were kind of backing her up, to a sound that features the kind of two-part harmonies that the Brothers are famous for, in which both singers deliver almost every line as a single storyteller.

title: Dr. Leo Galland Is Answering Your Fresh Juice Questions
description: Can 16 ounces of vegetable juice really help cleanse your body of toxins? And which toxins are we talking about? What are live enzymes, anyway, and should you be ingesting more of them? If youve got gobs of fruit (and the sugar that comes from it) squeezed into your cold-pressed juice, is that ultimately a good thing or a bad thing? Whats up with wheatgrass and liquid chlorophyll? Should fresh juice be pasteurized? Can a juice cleanse really make your skin as glowingly radiant as Gwyneth Paltrows?

title: Broadcasters Trove Is Calling All Ears
description: WASHINGTON  In their final years before moving to Minnesota, the Washington Senators struggled to keep fans interested. They were never contenders. Their statistics, generally, were so meager that their broadcaster rarely cited them.

description: As the Senate prepares to start voting on gun safety measures this week, one of Congresss most visible symbols of gun violence appeared in the Capitol on Tuesday to help rally support for her cause.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo is still doing better as an investment house than as an Internet company. Its first-quarter earnings beat analysts expectations, but much of the gain was from its investments abroad.

title: A Fantastical Tale to Set the Ears and Eyes Popping
description: LONDON  The German notion of Gesamtkunstwerk  a synthesis of disparate art forms brought together in harmonious collusion to express a unified vision  is central to Sunken Garden, a new musical-theater work that had its premiere on Friday evening at the Barbican Center. Staged by the English National Opera, and described as an occult-mystery film opera by its Dutch composer, stage director and filmmaker Michel van der Aa, it is a provocative combination of live performance and cinema, fused in subtle and arresting ways.

title: Taking Swings in the Ring, Without a Fights Stakes
description: Since Gleasons Gym opened in 1937, hundreds of the worlds greatest boxers have trained there. As it has moved around the city, from its first home in the Bronx to its current address in Dumbo, Brooklyn, it has also served as the location for countless photo shoots, commercials and movies, including Raging Bull and Million Dollar Baby. On Saturday it was home to a dance performance.

title: An Emphasis on Newtons Laws (and a Little Lawlessness)
description: SAN FRANCISCO  During the years after the Exploratorium opened in 1969 in the ramshackle Palace of Fine Arts here, did it ever think that the world had passed it by? At first, it was a countercultural revelation to start a science museum in which every visitor was treated like a chalk-smeared genius carrying out experiments. There were no objects in display cases, no signs saying, Dont touch. Every exhibit was handmade on site and was meant to look it.

description: Certain choreographers grumble at the prospect of reviving dances. Others actually relish the experience of looking back. In the case of Bebe Miller, who formed her company in 1985 and has been a regular figure on the New York dance scene in the ensuing years, such yearning has resulted in A History.

title: Pat Summerall, Star Kicker With Giants and a Calm Voice on TV, Dies at 82
description: Pat Summerall, the Giants outstanding place-kicker who went on to team with John Madden for 21 seasons in network televisions most prominent N.F.L. broadcast twosome, died on Tuesday in Dallas. He was 82.

title: Keeping His Secrets Well Up His Sleeve
description: Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay is a mouthful of a title, if not nearly as charmingly loquacious as those for some of Mr. Jays books, including Learned Pigs & Fireproof Women: Unique, Eccentric and Amazing Entertainers: Stone Eaters, Mind Readers, Poison Resisters, Daredevils, Singing Mice, etc., etc., etc., etc. Those four punctuating etc.s  what more could there be?  are an especially nice touch because they suggest that Mr. Jay has so much up his pushed-up sleeves that he couldnt possibly squeeze everything into a single title.

title: How We Got More Than Even With New York Magazine
description: Duke and Carolina never play each other until the final month of the college basketball season. And the Army-Navy game traditionally is the last contest of the college football regular season. So, yes, it seemed a wee unnatural that The New York Times Magazine and New York magazine would meet in the season opener of their media softball league on Monday night. It was pegged as our big rivalry game of the year for reasons Im not entirely clear about. I guess some of our people used to work there and vice versa. (Oh, and they also beat us last year.)

title: Where to Find Fish, Rabbit and Duck Heads in New York
description: Thanks to a renewed appreciation of Chinas rustic culinary roots, eating animal heads has become fashionable in Beijing, as Craig Smith writes in this weeks Dining section. There are restaurants solely devoted to the preparation of fish, rabbit and duck heads. In New York you may search long and hard without finding such a restaurant. Look carefully, though  not only in the warrens of a mall in Flushing, Queens, but also on Restaurant Row in Manhattan  and you may be surprised to see whats looking back. Though the cooking process may render an entire head a nearly uniform brown, theres no mistaking a rabbits incisors or a ducks bill.

But their response to the new critique is really, really bad.

title: Report on U.S. Meat Sounds Alarm on Resistant Bacteria

title: Dorothy Taubman, Therapist for Pianists, Dies at 95
description: Dorothy Taubman, who developed a method to help pianists strengthen their techniques and avoid repetitive strain injuries, died on April 3 in Brooklyn. She was 95.

title: In Grisly Image, a Father Sees His Son
description: BOSTON  When Jeff Bauman woke up in a hospital bed on Tuesday, an air tube was down his throat, both of his legs had been amputated at the knee, and his father was by his side. He tried to talk, but he could not.

title: Jeter Cuts Workload; Girardi Says Its No Setback

But a new lodging prototype is coming to town: the branded boutique hotel, which is typically small and intimate, offering patrons more personalized service.

title: As Thatcher Goes to Rest, Miners Feel No Less Bitter
description: WHITWELL, England  The old miner walks with a stick now, depleted in body and spirit, but with a pool of resentment that still surges whenever talk turns to the losing battle nearly 30 years ago to save the local coal mine from the economizing zeal of Margaret Thatcher.

description: KAUFMAN, Tex.  The contents of a storage unit  and the former elected official who had an associate rent the shed for him  have become central to the investigation into the murder of two prosecutors here.

description: After Jimmy Haslam bought the Cleveland Browns in the summer, he stood in the middle of a field at his very first practice, wearing a Browns T-shirt and shorts, a promising sign that the franchise  one of the N.F.L.s most storied, but long lagging while in the hands-off control of the former owner Randy Lerner  would finally have the attention and enthusiasm of the person in charge.

title: Indisputable Torture
description: A dozen years after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, an independent, nonpartisan panels examination of the interrogation and detention programs carried out in their aftermath by the Bush administration may seem to be musty old business. But the sweeping report issued on Tuesday by an 11-member task force convened by the Constitution Project, a legal research and advocacy group, provides a valuable, even necessary reckoning.

Two local outlets, the newspaper The Oregonian and the television station KATU, obtained a report through public records that detailed the interplay between Oregons athletic department and N.C.A.A. investigators.

title: Civil Liberties Fears Doom House Cybersecurity Bill
description: The White House on Tuesday threatened to veto a House bill that would allow private companies to share information about computer security threats with government agencies, signaling once again how difficult it is to balance civil liberties and security interests in the digital era.

title: For the Bilingual and Bicultural, a Big Dose of American Reality
description: REALITY television was the major theme on Tuesday for the bilingual cable channel Mun2, owned by Telemundo Media, a division of NBCUniversal. Executives announced 200 hours of original programming for the 2013 and 2014 seasons that focus mainly on celebrity-infused reality shows, music and sports for young, bilingual and bicultural Latinos in the United States.

title: Bring On the Next Marathon
description: Looking at scenes of the Boston sidewalk a few hours after Mondays bombing  torn clothing, bloodstains, shards of glass  I found my mind going back to a similar sidewalk in Tel Aviv in September 2003. A Hamas suicide bomber had blown himself up at a bus stop outside the Tsrifin army base, and by coincidence I was nearby and got there to witness the immediate aftermath. As I wrote then, parts of the bomber were still on the street, including his hairy leg. His shoe had been blown off, but his brown sock was still daintily on his foot. Israeli rescue workers calmly carried away the dead on stretchers, with an odd mix of horror and routine. But what I remember most was something the police spokesman said to me: We will have this whole area cleaned up in two hours. By morning, the bus stop will be repaired. You will never know this happened.

But what if rather than type these words on a keyboard we paint them on the walls of slums in Mali, Cambodia or Vietnam. Their meanings would certainly change.

Then I opened it and I read the letter and I was like, oh no! I started to cry.

title: Florida: Teachers Sue Over Evaluation System
description: Seven Florida teachers have brought a federal lawsuit to protest job evaluation policies that tether individual performance ratings to the test scores of students who are not even in their classes. The suit, which was filed Tuesday in conjunction with three local affiliates of the National Education Association in Federal District Court for the Northern District of Florida in Gainesville, says Floridas two-year-old evaluation system violates teachers rights of due process and equal protection. Under a 2011 law, schools and districts must evaluate teachers in part based on how much their students learn, as measured by standardized tests. But since Florida, like most states, administers only math and reading tests and only in selected grades, many teachers do not teach tested subjects. One of the plaintiffs, a first-grade teacher, was rated on the basis of test scores of students in a different school in her district, and another, who teaches vocational classes to aspiring health care workers, was rated based on test scores of students in grades and subjects she had never taught. This lawsuit highlights the absurdity of the current evaluation system, said Andy Ford, president of the Florida Education Association.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) THE MYSTERY OF EELS Snakelike and slimy, with a row of jagged teeth and, in some cases, a life span of more than 100 years, the eel is one of the natural worlds few enigmas, with little known about where it goes, what it does and how it dies. In this Nature episode the naturalist James Prosek tries to shed light on this creature, above, christened the North Sea siren and loves arrow on earth by the Italian poet Eugenio Montale. In Australias First 4 Billion Years: Life Explodes, on Nova at 9, Richard Smith investigates fossils for clues as to how arthropods invaded that barren continent from the ocean and spawned life on land. And Guts With Michael Mosley, at 10, explores the human digestive tract.

title: Advice From Expert on Male Sexuality, Part 2
description: Readers recently submitted questions about male sexuality to Dr. Ronald F. Levant, a professor of psychology and director of the Psychology Department Counseling Clinic at the University of Akron. Part 1 of his answers can be found here. Dr. Levant was president of the American Psychological Association and is an author or editor of 14 books, including Men and Sex: New Psychological Perspectives. Dr. Levant asked the counselors whom he supervises in his clinic, all Ph.D. students in psychology who see a broad range of clients, to help him compose answers to these questions. Thanks are given to Mike Aguilar, Brittany Baker, Natalie Grandy, Craig Libman and Arielle Riutort. Because of the large number of submissions, not every question was addressed. In particular, we were not able to answer questions on medical issues, as our expertise is psychological, not medical. This feature is closed to further questions.

title: The Tax Implications of Starting a Business With Retirement Money

As a result, I would advise my clients to stay away from the strategy.

Moynihan, Bank of Americas chief executive, said, Our strategy of connecting our customers to all we can do for them is working. The question now is whether the earnings will add to the recent optimism surrounding the bank, DealBooks Peter Eavis writes. The banks shares were down in premarket trading. title: Site to Be Seen | Christies Vintage Couture Accessories

The first such attack on that city in a year, it underscored the continuing threat from militants operating across the desert border.

title: Afghan Islamic Courts: A Pre-Taliban System With Post-2014 Potential?
description: The American military has built much of its transition strategy in Afghanistan around establishing local police forces to help keep the peace. In recent months, much has been made about the rise of indigenous anti-insurgent forces, separate from the American-sponsored local police, in the historical Taliban strongholds of Ghazni and Kandahar Provinces. Implicit in the praise for these forces is that indigenous militias of this type represent a vital local vision for the future and a sustainable means of keeping the Taliban at bay after 2014.

title: To Light Up a Room, a Liquid-Filled Bulb

title: Justices Bar Nigerian Human Rights Case From U.S. Courts

The decision limited the sweep of a 1789 law that had been used to address human rights abuses abroad.

title: Moonless on the Mississippi
description: For most Americans, their historical memory about the Civil War centers on the battles in the East, from the First Bull Run to Petersburg. But taken at its most fundamental level, the Civil War was actually a war of geographic attrition, beginning in the West. The West constituted the strategic military arena, for there, rivers ran parallel to Union lines of invasion; in the East, they ran perpendicular to them.

title: Mississippi Man Is Arrested in Sending of Suspicious Letters
description: WASHINGTON  Federal agents arrested a man on Monday suspected of sending letters feared contaminated by the poison ricin to President Obama and a Mississippi senator, according to two officials with knowledge of the case. The suspect was identified as Paul Kevin Curtis of Tupelo, Miss.

title: Section 15: Time With the Grandchildren
description: Bennie M. Ginyard, of South Ozone Park, Queens, likes to bring her grandchildren to Barclays Center to watch the Nets and grab a Nathans hot dog.

title: 9 Ways to Make the Most of an Artichoke
description: To unlock the hidden potential of the artichoke, you need to look within.

title: Is Organic Better? Ask a Fruit Fly
description: When Ria Chhabra, a middle school student near Dallas, heard her parents arguing about the value of organic foods, she was inspired to create a science fair project to try to resolve the debate.

title: How to Cut an Artichoke
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates three ways to prepare an artichoke for cooking.

title: Efforts to Revive the Economy Lead to Worries of a Bubble
description: Are we moving from the crash to the bubble, dispensing with that pesky economic recovery thing altogether?

title: Queen for a Day: Sandra Bernhard Looks Back on The King of Comedy
description: Its been 30 years since Rupert Pupkin made his notorious debut on The Jerry Langford Show, a moment that exists only within the reality of The King of Comedy, Martin Scorseses dark satire about a struggling standup (played by Robert De Niro) who kidnaps his favorite talk-show host (Jerry Lewis). But its also a more tangible milestone for the films co-star Sandra Bernhard, who played Masha, an equally unhinged fan who helps Pupkin carry out his twisted show-biz schemes: for Ms. Bernhard, The King of Comedy was a breakthrough (for which she was cast from the comedy-club scene in Los Angeles) that garnered critical praise and led her to a wider stage and screen career.

title: Wheelies: The Costly Car Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Can a Woman Win the Kentucky Derby?
description: Here is the perception: female jockeys cant ride. Theyre too weak. They dont have the fight in them. They cant close  not like men, anyway. Down the stretch, you need a jockey to carry the horse to the end, rally the winded animal and squeeze speed out of weary legs. Female jockeys cant do that. Or so goes the explanation for why, almost 50 years after women first fought legal battles to become jockeys, there are so few top jockeys who are women.

title: I Heart Artichokes
description: True story, from the wedding of two friends, circa 1977: The brides father, a louche sophisticate, and perhaps needless to say an alcoholic, asked of the grooms grandmother, a Russian immigrant of peasant stock, Isnt eating an artichoke just like sex? There was, as you can imagine, no reply.

title: Court Says Police Need Warrant for Blood Test
description: WASHINGTON  The fact that alcohol dissipates from the bloodstream over time does not by itself give the police the right to draw blood without a warrant in drunken-driving investigations, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

title: Mourners Attend Thatcher Funeral
description: NBC video of scenes from Margaret Thatchers funeral at St. Pauls Cathedral in London.

title: Disney-AMC Theaters Dispute Breaks Into Public
description: LAS VEGAS  In the annual Hollywood ritual here known as CinemaCon, studio executives visit to wine and dine movie theater owners, or exhibitor friends in the parlance of the convention.

title: Theres Something About Smartwatches
description: Rumor has it that Apple, Samsung, Google and Microsoft are all working on some sort of thingamajig that is worn around the wrist, which people are calling a smartwatch. None have arrived on the market yet, but they have everyone wondering whether or not this will be the biggest mobile device since the smartphone.

title: The Screen on a Laptop Wants to Be a Tablet
description: Lets admit it: Love it or hate it, Windows 8 was designed for touch screens. Its new facade, the colorful quilt of square tiles that I call TileWorld, was born for finger operation.

title: With a Bill Now in the Senate, Immigrants Weigh the Possible Impact
description: LOS ANGELES  In another era, Justino Mora might have been ashamed to talk about his mother coming across the border from Mexico illegally. But today, he calls her decision to immigrate more than a decade ago heroic.

title: Hiking Through History, With Your Daughters
description: The best miracle happened outside the town of Portomarn. Thered been a number of them on this family trip  with my wife and two daughters  walking the ancient pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostela, Spain. That July morning my youngest daughter, Yancey, and I stepped out of a forest and onto a field  and, it seemed, into a previous century.Hundreds of pilgrims milled about, locals sold trinkets, jugglers wandered by, musicians played, people handed out refreshments and offered showers at a community center.

title: Wild Cuban Days (if Youre Canadian, Maybe)
description: I wouldnt have thought Beyonc and I and my mother and Jay-Z had much in common, but as we all traveled to Cuba recently I am feeling so sympathetic and empathetic I am wondering if I shouldnt give them a call and set up a lunch.

title: Excerpt: 'The Assembled Parties'
description: Jessica Hecht, left, and Judith Light in a scene from Richard Greenberg's new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Vain Glorious | Aqua Spin Classes
description: Aqua spinning, the fitness fad thats swept over France, has just landed stateside with the newly opened Aqua Studio in TriBeCa. As the name implies, there are elements taken from traditional spinning  fat-blasting and calorie-burning moves, upbeat soundtracks, and friendly (but firm) instructors  but there are also benefits that only exercising in water can boast. For starters, theres the draw of a low-impact, high-resistance workout. The water supports your body weight and reduces stress on joints while generating resistance, which encourages your legs to move in a safe and controlled manner. Devotees also claim that aqua spinning can help smooth dimpled thighs. Aqua Studios founder Esther Gauthier, a French expat, says, Moving in water generates a natural massage that drains the lymphatic system and improves the appearance of cellulite. But most important, being in the water is simply fun. Theres something about throwing on a bathing suit and splashing in water that takes the typical emotional edge off of exercising: your muscles are getting a serious workout, while your mind feels buoyant and light. After my first session, I felt rejuvenated and energized, not wiped out (like I do after an intense run), and left the studio with a spring in my step. Sorry, guys: for the moment, Aqua Studio is for the ladies only.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Ticket to Ride, but Whos to Pay?

title: Q&A: Is Europe Still a Sure Thing?
description: Bank closings in Cyprus. Labor protests in Greece. Government spending cuts in Portugal. Surging unemployment in Spain.

title: Fishs DNA May Explain How Fins Turned to Feet
description: In the hope of reconstructing a pivotal step in evolution  the colonization of land by fish that learned to walk and breathe air  researchers have decoded the genome of the coelacanth, a prehistoric-looking fish whose form closely resembles those seen in the fossils of 400 million years ago.

title: Cardiff City Is Going to the Premier League
description: Thousands of fans ran onto the field in south Wales Tuesday night as Cardiff City overcame 51 years in the lower divisions of English soccer to earn promotion to the Premier League.

title: Election Has Yankees Cervelli Worried for Venezuela
description: Francisco Cervelli stood at his locker Tuesday, shook his head and pointed in the direction of the field, recalling the day two years ago that Henrique Capriles Radonski, the man who came within a whisker Sunday of becoming the president of Venezuela, visited Yankee Stadium.

title: Whats Going On in There? Modeling the Inner Workings of the Brain
description: A three-dimensional visualization, using yellow fluorescent protein labeling, of long-range connecting neurons in a clarified adult mouse brain. Go to related article and more videos

title: Marlins Find Themselves Home Alone
description: MIAMI  In the shadow of the soaring home run sculpture, below a sports bar and above a nightclub, Noel Rodriguez sipped a beer and watched his favorite team lose by seven runs Monday night. He wore a bright orange jersey, No. 7, with Jose Reyess name stitched on the back. He paid $100 for it last year, he said, and within months it was obsolete.

title: Ill Have a Chlorophyll Fizz on the Rocks, Please
description: The other day I did something that I probably hadnt done since I was 10 years old. I sat on a stool and drank juice.

title: Writers and the Women They Worship
description: These three delightfully deranging books offer alternatives to your staid biographies. Theyre a bit dangerous, a bit rude  free from the tyranny of good taste. The authors, first-rate obsessives, riff on the women whove consumed them  bearing out Frank Bidarts line, What you love is your fate, with mischief, feeling and a rare frankness. Thats the thing about obsession. It cant be faked.

title: Top Obama Officials Differ on Syrian Rebels in Testimony to Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Sharply different perspectives within the Obama administration concerning the Syrian opposition emerged publicly on Wednesday when Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made separate appearances before Congress.

title: Blame The Pundits, Too
description: Still Reinhart-Rogoffing; I think its important to be clear that R-R arent the only ones at fault here. In particular, the people who cited their work dont have the right to claim innocence, because how could they know that they were being given bad data?

title: Terry de Havilland
description: A lot of my stuff terrifies buyers, Terry de Havillandsays, chuckling. A desire to show the shoe-buying public what theyre missing spurred the designer, who made some of the most memorable footwear of the 1970s, to open a three-month-long pop-up boutique in Londons Carnaby Street area beginning on April 20. Its his first stand-alone retail venture since his Kings Road shop, Cobblers to the World  where Led Zeppelin, Anita Pallenberg and Bianca Jagger bought their platforms  closed in 1979. Though he makes other styles, including a fetching Cuban-heeled boot for men, de Havilland will forever be associated with the platform, which he learned to make at his fathers knee; his parents had a shoe business that catered to showgirls in postwar London, and it was those original designs that prompted him to resuscitate the platform for the glam rock generation and again more recently for customers like Kate Moss. I think they empower women, he says. They give you your own little stage to stand on.

title: Why So Little Terrorism?
description: With ricin-laced letters suddenly showing up in Washington D.C., I worry a little that Im tempting fate by writing about the rarity of organized terrorism in early 21st century America. But hopefully one more post wont hurt. So, picking up where my last one left off, here are three theories about why our culture seems to be producing relatively few people with the combination of ideological commitment, organizational competence and zeal that has sparked and sustained terrorist campaigns in other times and places:

title: Looking Overseas, Businesses Learn to Master Currency Exchange
description: Jean-Paul Tennant is in the adventure business, but that does not mean he enjoys taking risks. He is chief executive of a travel company, Geographic Expeditions, that specializes in arranging ambitious trips to exotic lands, places where unstable local currencies can make financial transactions a challenge.

title: A Protective Case for Your Phones Glass
description: Which is more vulnerable, the plastic or aluminum housing on the back of your phone, or the glass screen on front? It would seem to be the glass screen. And screen protectors abound; the latest, the Impact Shield, is from the case maker Tech21.

title: Mark Sanford Wont Get Money From G.O.P. for House Bid
description: National Republicans on Wednesday backed away from Mark Sanford, the former South Carolina governor who is now running for Congress, after court documents alleged that he trespassed at his ex-wifes house.

title: Living in Floral Park, Queens
description: This community is popular because it offers Long Island-style living without the high property taxes of Nassau County.

title: Urban in Name (and Taxes) Only
description: When Mohsima and Nafisur Rahman decided about a year and a half ago that the time had come to leave their two-bedroom rental in Jamaica Estates, their list of reasons for moving was long.

title: Does Your Business Face Foreign Currency Exposure?
description: Jean-Paul Tennant is chief executive of a travel company, Geographic Expeditions, that specializes in arranging ambitious trips to exotic lands. In late 2006  as explained in our just-published small-business guide to handling foreign-currency exposure  Mr. Tennant booked travel for eight clients who wanted to explore northern India.

title: Pedro Ramrez Vzquez, Architect, Is Dead at 94
description: Pedro Ramrez Vzquez, the architect who led many of Mexicos landmark Modernist construction projects of the mid-20th century, including museums, the countrys largest sports stadium and the shrine that attracts its most important religious pilgrimage, died on Tuesday, his 94th birthday, in Mexico City.

title: In China, Questions About Cancer Care as Rates Rise
description: BEIJING  China has many dedicated oncologists who care deeply about their patients, and as cancer rates rise  partly as the result of environmental pollution, but also because of factors like an aging society  they have their work cut out for them.

title: He Beliebes in Himself
description: Before performing in the Dutch city of Arnhem last Friday, Justin Bieber paid a visit to the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam. In the museum guest book, he wrote, Truly inspiring to be able to come here. Anne was a great girl. Hopefully she would have been a belieber. Who could possibly take offense?

title: Video Shows an Angry Putin Threatening to Dismiss Officials
description: MOSCOW  A Kremlin-linked Web site on Wednesday leaked a video clip of an angry President Vladimir V. Putin threatening to dismiss top officials, fueling speculation that Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev and members of his cabinet are in danger of being fired.

title: A Contemporary Near San Jos
description: Overlooking a golf course, a five-bedroom with a pool is on the market for $1.6 million.

title: Keeping Their Art to Themselves
description: Iman Thomas would be the first to say that she is just not a cardigan kind of person. Nonetheless, her dresser drawers bulge with those demure long-sleeved sweaters, in colors ranging from rainbow to black.

title: Knicks Say Wallace, Still Ailing, Will Retire
description: Rasheed Wallace, the 6-foot-11 power forward who wore a scruffy beard, shouted Ball dont lie! to referees and recorded 317 technical fouls in his 16-year career, made the surprising  and not so surprising  decision to retire from professional basketball. Again.

title: Public Opinion Stands Behind Democrats on Gun Measures
description: As the Senate prepares to vote on a series of gun measures Wednesday afternoon, recent polls show a slim majority of Americans place a higher priority on enacting new gun laws to reduce gun violence over protecting the right to own guns. Yet, support for toughening up gun laws has dropped since the Newtown, Conn., school shooting in mid-December.

title: House Hunting in ... Costa Rica
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY ON A GOLF COURSE IN COSTA RICA

title: Properties for $795,000
description: Homes in Hillsborough, N.C., Lewes, Del. and Oakland, Calif.

title: Tibetan Woman Kills Herself by Self-Immolation
description: BEIJING  A young Tibetan mother has killed herself by self-immolation to protest Chinese rule, according to reports by Radio Free Asia and Voice of America, two news organizations financed by the United States government.

title: Introducing The Daily Dog-Ear
What You Get for ... $795,000
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C.

title: Complaints About Money Transfers
description: Millions of people use money-transfer services, like Western Union or MoneyGram or smaller competitors, to send cash in the United States or outside.

title: Berlins New Entry on the Summer Festival Calendar
description: Theres a new summer festival in town, and that town is Berlin. From June 27 to July 14, the city will host Foreign Affairs, an ambitious multi-arts festival whose program was announced this week in Berlin by the artistic director, Matthias von Hartz.

title: Calling Superfans of The Last Five Years
