Just through an arched underpass, the communitys expansive entrance plaza, Station Square, unfolds with arcaded sidewalks, a domed tower and what could be some sort of Anglo-German manor house in subtly colored and intricately patterned brickwork. It is a disorienting transition, like stepping into a blurred fantasy of the past.

title: Harvey Dominates in Duel vs. Strasburg
description: Manager Terry Collins has not tried to shield Matt Harvey from the attention, and Harvey has maintained his stated desire to be the best pitcher in baseball. But to justify that attention, and legitimize that desire, Harvey had to prove something Friday in the first marquee matchup of his young career.

title: One by One, 30-Odd Not Guilty Pleas in Betting Case
description: Wearing luxury suits and faded jeans, with nicknames like Blondie and Joe the Hammer, the defendants occupied most of the benches on one side of the Manhattan courtroom. The 30-some suspects arraigned on Friday afternoon were charged this week with participating in an international operation of illegal gambling and money-laundering worth more than $100 million.

title: The Mind of a Terror Suspect
description: While the Boston area lay paralyzed by a lockdown, with one terror suspect dead and another on the loose as a massive manhunt filtered through the areas arteries, we got a better sense of the second young man.

title: New Faces Back Pettitte and Continue to Power Yankees
description: TORONTO  Andy Pettittes final regular-season start of 2012 was at Rogers Centre on Sept. 29. When he looked around that day, he saw Derek Jeter, Nick Swisher, Curtis Granderson, Russell Martin and Alex Rodriguez.

title: Where the Party Was, a Movement Began
description: Cornell University, starting in 2007, has acquired about 80,000 artifacts including fliers designed by Buddy Esquire and Phase 2 in its Hip-Hop Collection.

title: Becoming Mark Twain
description: By early February 1863, Samuel Langhorne Clemens must have felt glad that he was more than 18 months removed from any direct participation in the Civil War. No longer risking his life in a guerrilla war in northern Missouri, he was a newspaper editor in the Nevada Territory, causing some local scandals with his acerbic political commentary and tall tales. Although he occasionally wrote about the war raging back East, Clemens mainly focused his columns on mocking the territorial legislature or relating humorous anecdotes about the citizens of Nevada. Surely, though, he must have sometimes thought about his own war experiences in the summer of 1861.

title: A Bronx Genre Gone Global
description: The message was explicit: come in peace, ladies for free. Proper attire required, no sneakers allowed. 9:30 p.m. until. Be there yall.

title: In Queens, Finding Refuge From Unrest in Egypt
description: Its Tuesday afternoon, and a few dozen of the faithful members of St. Mary and St. Antonios Coptic Orthodox Church in Ridgewood, Queens, are singing in the liturgy during observation of the Great Lent, the 55 days of prayer and fasting that precede Orthodox Easter, on May 5. The women wear white lace coverings over their hair, and smoky-sweet incense wafts through the air as the ancient melodies fill the icon-rich sanctuary. As at all services here, a screen projects the words being sung or spoken in three languages simultaneously: English, Arabic and Coptic.

title: Decades Later, State Seeks Release of Report on Attica Uprising
description: More than 40 years after an uprising at Attica left 43 people dead, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman is planning to ask a judge to make public a trove of investigatory findings that have been hidden from public view for decades.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 19, 2013

title: Still Dreaming of the City of Light
description: The avant-garde playwright and director Richard Foreman, who is 75, founded the Ontological-Hysteric Theater in 1968, and for years the theater performed his playful, disorienting and theory-infused works at St. Marks Church in the Bowery. He also makes film and video, and released the movie Once Every Day in February. Mr. Foreman, who was awarded a MacArthur Fellowship in 1995, lives in SoHo with his wife, Kate Manheim, 68, an actress and artist. When he is not in rehearsals for his new play, Old-Fashioned Prostitutes (A True Romance), opening at the Public Theater on April 30, he spends his Sundays at home, reading, watching television and ruminating on France and SoHo as they used to be.

title: Photo Replay: April 20
description: A view of the day in sports from gymnastics in Moscow to auto racing in Bahrain.

title: New Liberal, Old Liberal
description: When you live in the country, as a friend who, several years ago, moved from Brooklyn to a college town in Vermont observed recently, your interaction with local politics becomes intimate and ritualized. Perhaps you spent years in New York never being able to recall the name of the sole City Council member from your district, but once you relocate to a quiet place somewhere in New England, you inevitably know all the names of the members of your board of selectmen. You see them at dinner parties; you recognize their children; you talk about easements, sewage redirection, the specter of a new lane on Route 5A.

title: State Dept. Sees Little Progress on Global Human Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The human rights picture in many countries remained deeply troubling last year, the State Department said Friday, with the Middle East facing the harsh realities of incomplete and contested transitions, Russia and Iran cracking down on activists, and many governments harshly suppressing both new and traditional media.

title: Rangers Recipe: Good Bounces, Bad Opponents, Ugly Goals
description: BUFFALO  The Rangers are suddenly an offensive juggernaut  but it helps that they are playing bad teams.

title: E.P.A. Issues Plan on Tainted Water From Power Plants
description: Power producers would have to curb the tainted water they discharge into waterways under a proposal issued by the Environmental Protection Agency on Friday, the latest in a series of rules focused on utilities that burn coal. The agency proposed four options for regulating the waste from power plants, which are the top source of pollutants in streams, rivers and other waters. The final rules would have the most impact on coal-fired plants, which are the primary source of the pollutants, and would be phased in beginning in 2017. The Sierra Club, which sued the agency to issue the rules, said the announcement was an important step. When finalized in their strongest form, the Environmental Protection Agencys common-sense and affordable standards will save lives, prevent children from getting sick, and ensure our water is safe to drink and our fish safe to eat, said Michael Brune, the groups executive director.

title: N.B.A. Still Weighing Sale of Kings
description: The N.B.A.s board of governors will not vote on the sale of the Sacramento Kings until the week after next at the earliest, Commissioner David Stern said. The finance and relocation committees are still gathering information about the competing bids to buy the club, and they will probably recommend a winning bid to the board of governors toward the end of next week. The board of governors then must take seven business days to consider the recommendation.

title: Increased Security for Central Park Race
description: New York Road Runners has increased security at its four-mile race this weekend in Central Park in response to the bomb attacks at the Boston Marathon. In an e-mail message to club members, Road Runners told entrants in the City Parks Foundation Run to arrive early on Sunday and expect to go through a security screening. Runners were asked to avoid taking bags to the race. Those who do will have the contents transferred into clear bags.

title: Surviving Chinas Latest Earthquake, but Afraid to Go Home
description: YUXI, China  Many residents of this tiny village in the mountainous region of southwest China spent Saturday night in tents and makeshift shelters, too scared to sleep in their flimsy homes after an earthquake killed 188 people early that morning.

title: A Borough Laces Up Its Gloves
description: Now that the Barclays Center is midway through its maiden season of organizing fights, Brooklyn gyms are again alive with the sounds of thumping gloves.

title: Brooklyn Gets a Rematch
description: Two weeks before fight night, the Brooklyn boxer Danny Jacobs was in headgear and a padded pelvic girdle, taking rounds in an underground sparring ring at the Starrett City Boxing Club. The club, in the basement of a high-rise building near Jamaica Bay, was in the old-school mold: duct-taped heavy bags and pitted concrete floors  the sort of place where only a fighter in training would have spent such a beckoningly sunny April day.

title: Many Achievements, but Not the Grandiose Kind
description: By turning away from a powerful offer, Senator Patrick Leahy  is shaping his legacy in a quieter way.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Greece looks at civil service layoffs, Japan reports a wide trade deficit, and earnings season is good to Goldman Sachs, not so good to Google.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) SEEKING A FRIEND FOR THE END OF THE WORLD (2012) As global calamity looms, Dodge (Steve Carell), a nebbishy New York insurance salesman whose wife has fled, embarks on a road trip with the girl next door (Keira Knightley, above with Mr. Carell) to find his long-lost high school love in this comedy directed by Lorene Scafaria. Connie Britton, Rob Corddry and Patton Oswalt round out the cast as Dodges friends, who encourage him to react to imminent doom the way they would: by throwing off all inhibitions. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film a sweet, whimsical and seriously misguided romp through end times, which goes very gentle into that good night. The problem is not that Ms. Scafaria takes her grave subject too lightly, he said. Laughter is an entirely appropriate response to something so abstractly awful as an unstoppable meteor speeding toward earth. But, he added, it seems downright unfair that billions of people have to die so that a middle-aged sad sack can cop a cuddle with a cute, younger bohemian neighbor.

title: An End to the Boston Manhunt
description: On the streets of Watertown, Mass., residents and police officers celebrated after a suspect was brought into custody.

title: Rape of 5-Year-Old Girl Sets Off New Furor in India
description: NEW DELHI  Hundreds of demonstrators besieged New Delhis police headquarters on Saturday to protest the kidnapping, rape and torture of a 5-year-old girl last week.

title: Meanwhile, Sunil Tripathi Is Still Missing
description: NEW YORK CITY In a bizarre twist in an ongoing mysterious yet tragic story, Sunil Tripathi, the 22-year-old Brown University student who has beenmissing since March 16, was one of Americas most wanted criminals for several hours early Friday, at least in the eyes of the media. The 62 130-pound senior, who is from Radnor, Pa., and has an Indian father and an American mother, was falsely cited on social media as one of the Boston Marathon bombers before his name wascleared in connection with the attacks.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 20
description: The teenage suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, whose flight from the police after a furious gunfight overnight prompted an intense manhunt that virtually shut down the Boston area all day, was taken into custody Friday night after the police found him in nearby Watertown, Mass., officials said. The suspect, Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, 19, was found hiding in a boat just outside the area where the police had been conducting door-to-door searches all day, the Boston police commissioner, Edward Davis, said at a news conference Friday night. Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston and William K. Rashbaum and Michael Cooper report from New York.

title: Bombing Inquiry Turns to Motive and Russian Trip
description: WASHINGTON  With one suspect dead and the other captured and lying grievously wounded in a hospital, the investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings turned on Saturday to questions about the mens motives, and to the significance of an overseas trip one of them took last year.

title: Ex-President of Pakistan Ordered Held 2 More Weeks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani antiterrorism court on Saturday extended by two weeks the detention of the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf, ensuring that the legal wrangling surrounding the retired general will continue in the run-up to elections on May 11.

title: The Weekend Word: Developments
description: Todays Times

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: A team comprising professionals from 11 companies began a visit to the state Friday as part of a central government program to train unemployed youth in Jammu and Kashmir, The New Indian Express reported. The government sanctioned 10 billion rupees, or $185 million, for the program in 2012, the report noted.

title: The Non-Secret of Our Non-Success
description: Chris Giles of the FT reports that central bankers are worried that they are flying blind; he quotes Lorenzo Bibi-Smaghi, formerly of the ECB governing board, saying We dont fully understand what is happening in advanced economies.

title: The Good Glitch
description: Ive been cynical about the likelihood that the Reinhart-Rogoff fiasco would lead to any real change in policy, and I still have doubts. But reflecting on the debate so far, Im wondering a bit if I have been too cynical  or at any rate, cynical in the wrong way. For my vague, unquantifiable sense is that the debacle is changing the conversation quite a lot, even among the guys in suits. And it was the coding error that did it.

title: April 20 Updates on Aftermath of Boston Marathon Explosions
description: 7:27 P.M. | Men Held Saturday Unrelated to Marathon, F.B.I. Says

title: An Earth Day Thought: Litter Matters
description: My maternal grandfather, I. Henry Stern, was the person in my life who most impressed on me the merits of cleaning up after yourself  and others if need be. When you enter a room, hed say, leave it better than you found it. Click here for more Dot Earth trash talk. Heres an Earth Day weekend Twitter post showing one way such attitudes matter:

title: After Boston and Tsarnaevs, Russians Urge U.S. to Rethink Chechnya
description: LONDON  Russian commentators are speculating that a Chechen connection in the Boston Marathon bombings will force the United States to reassess its view of the Kremlins actions in the troubled Caucasus region.

title: Tensions High After Riot at Syrian Refugee Camp in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordanian demonstrators restricted access to the regions largest camp of Syrian refugees for several hours on Saturday, delaying water delivery, after a riot in the camp injured 10 Jordanian security officers, one of them critically, officials said.

title: Suspects With Foot in 2 Worlds, Perhaps Echoing Plots of Past
description: Three years ago, when Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was assigned by his high school English teacher to write an essay on something he felt passionate about, he chose the troubled land of his ancestors: Chechnya. He wrote to Brian Glyn Williams, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth.

title: Mike Mills: A Rock Star of Fantasy Sports
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Mike Mills rose from a chair and strolled out to his car, but not to fetch a musical instrument to perform songs from the catalog of R.E.M., his seminal alternative-rock band. A fantasy draft of Masters golfers, involving Mills and a dozen others at a house not far from Augusta National Golf Club, had just concluded. And with baseball games in the East winding down, Mills was retrieving a laptop to take stock of his fantasy teams.

title: A Family Line Runs From a 1950s Knick to a Current Celtic
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  The man lay in a hospital in Raleigh, N.C., no longer able to fight the pancreatic cancer that had ravaged his body.

title: A Flighty Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  This was a flighty, feathery, fluffy, fun solve. Its good to be back on the successfully solved acrostic bandwagon again.

title: California Tries to Regain Fuller Control of Prisons
description: VACAVILLE, Calif.  On the sprawling grounds of the state prison, built here in 1955, a new three-story, $24 million treatment center for mentally ill inmates stands out because of its freshly painted walls and rooftop solar panels. Inside, on a recent morning, psychologists and social workers were leading group therapy sessions for inmates in large, brightly lighted rooms while individual meetings were being held in smaller offices.

title: Debate Over Delaying of Miranda Warning
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations announcement that it planned to question the Boston Marathon bombing suspect for a period without first reading him the Miranda warning of his right to remain silent and have a lawyer present has revived a constitutionally charged debate over the handling of terrorism cases in the criminal justice system.

title: With Rangers, Nash Still Finds Playoffs Playing Hard to Get
description: It was supposed to be easy for Rick Nash this year with the Rangers, but he is the protagonist in another uphill struggle to the playoffs, as he has been every season since joining the N.H.L. in 2002.

title: Italian Lawmakers, After Stalemate, Re-elect President to Second Term
description: ROME  In a bid to quiet growing political chaos, Italian lawmakers on Saturday elected President Giorgio Napolitano to a second term, turning to him as the last best hope to break a profound deadlock.

title: Mixed Martial Artist Is Mighty, Yet Measured
description: Jon Joness signature move, the spinning elbow, is a relatively high-risk martial arts strike that he delivers toward an opponents head with no regard for his own safety. Its the kind of maneuver that can make a highlight show  for better or worse.

title: A Texas Town Mourns the First Responders Who Paid With Their Lives
description: WEST, Tex.  Three-tenths of a mile from this towns own ground zero, barely more than 24 hours after an explosion at a fertilizer plant tore through peoples houses and hearts, dozens of firefighters and emergency responders stood at attention.

title: Two Cheers for Web U!
description: I LEARNED many fascinating things while taking a series of free online college courses over the last few months. In my history class, I learned there was a Japanese political plot to assassinate Charlie Chaplin in 1932. In my genetics class, I learned that the ability to wiggle our ears is a holdover from animal ancestors who could shift the direction of their hearing organs.

title: Moving Ahead With Common Core
description: New York City parents are understandably nervous about tough new state tests that were rolled out last week. And some parents whose children have already taken the tests are outraged. They shouldnt be: the tests, which measure math and English skills, are an essential part of rigorous education reforms known as Common Core that seek to improve reasoning skills and have been adopted by 45 states.

title: The Right to Remain Silent
description: Under the Constitutions Fifth Amendment, no one can be compelled to be a witness against himself in a criminal case. The prosecution cannot use a defendants decision not to testify in court as evidence of guilt. Nor, as a result of the landmark Miranda case, can it use as evidence of guilt a suspects decision to remain silent after being arrested.

title: The Man Who Saved CUNY
description: Matthew Goldstein walked into a deeply troubled place when he became chancellor of the City University of New York 14 years ago. The political infighting and chaotic management at CUNY had become so destructive that a task force report described it as an institution adrift, one caught in a spiral of decline. Now, after successfully reorganizing what had become a disjointed academic jumble and slowly restoring the prestige of a giant public university that serves nearly half a million students, Mr. Goldstein has said he will retire this summer.

title: Immigration and Fear
description: Much of the country was still waking up to the mayhem and confusion outside Boston on Friday morning when Senator Charles Grassley decided to link the hunt for terrorist bombers to immigration reform.

title: A New, Flexible Kerry
description: John Kerry made his first trip to Asia as secretary of state this month amid rising tensions with North Korea and returned home on Monday with things a bit quieter, although with North Korea nobody really knows whats next. Bouncing from Seoul to Beijing to Tokyo, the new secretary showed a commendable impulse for common-sense diplomacy, including engagement with adversaries like the North. The policy questions are: Will a White House with a proclivity for adversarial responses support his diplomatic approach? And how well will it play not only in the Oval Office but with troublesome states like North Korea?

title: Hack the Newsroom: Editors Lab at the NYT
description: At 9:00 this morning, The New York Times opened its doors to journalists, designers and developers from major media organizations for two days of hacking as part of the the Editors Lab series of events. See below for a full roster of teams and participants, and you can read our blog post from earlier this week for more details about Editors Lab and the Global Editors Network.

title: Daring to Knock on the Boardroom Door
description: STEVEN ROMICK didnt set out to be a shareholder activist. As managing partner of First Pacific Advisors and overseer of the $11 billion FPA Crescent fund, Mr. Romick has more than enough on his plate. Keeping a low profile is usually fine with him.

title: Doubted by Scouts, a College Ace Rises Quickly
description: Michael Roth pitched his first game above rookie ball on April 9, working five innings for the Class AA Arkansas Travelers. Three nights later, after a game in Frisco, Tex., Roth was called into an office with Manager Tim Bogar and the pitching coach, Mike Hampton. He had no reason to expect what was coming.

title: Some Iraqis Doubt Benefits of First Vote Since U.S. Departure
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq held its first election since the withdrawal of American troops under security so tight on Saturday that the only way for many voters to reach polling places was to walk. But the election, for local councils, was carried out largely free of violence, even as apathy prevailed among many Iraqis who questioned what benefits they have received from a young democracy still marred by political dysfunction, corruption and violence.

title: No Bully in the Pulpit
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Model of Restraint in the Race for News
description: THE TIMES, it is safe to say, had a very good week. On Monday, it won four Pulitzer Prizes  the third most in its history and twice as many as any other news organization this year.

title: The Tangle of the Sexes
description: MEN and women are so different they might as well be from separate planets, so says the theory of the sexes famously explicated in John Grays 1992 best seller, Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus.

title: How to Put America Back Together Again
description: UNTIL we fully understand what turned two brothers who allegedly perpetrated the Boston Marathon bombings into murderers, it is hard to make any policy recommendation other than this: We need to redouble our efforts to make America stronger and healthier so it remains a vibrant counterexample to whatever bigoted ideology may have gripped these young men. With all our warts, we have built a unique society  a country where a black man, whose middle name is Hussein, whose grandfather was a Muslim, can run for president and first defeat a woman in his own party and then four years later a Mormon from the opposition, and no one thinks twice about it. With so many societies around the world being torn apart, especially in the Middle East, it is vital that America survives and flourishes as a beacon of pluralism.

title: Maya Angelou
description: Maya Angelou is a best-selling author, poet, historian, civil rights activist, playwright, actress, filmmaker and professor. Her most recent book, Mom & Me & Mom, was published this month.

title: In New York, No Ping to the Sound of Bat Hitting Ball
description: The old-fashioned crack of bats hitting baseballs has returned in force this spring in New York, as youth baseball leagues, especially in Brooklyn, have been shifting away from metal bats. The latest to change is the Prospect Park Baseball Association, among the citys largest youth organizations with about 2,100 players, which switched to wood bats for those as young as 9 this season.

title: Questioning the Missionof College
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Worlds Away From Here
description: AND now for some counterprogramming. You probably missed it, what with the Boston Marathon bombing, the ricin-laced letters, the fertilizer plant explosion and an entire city locked down while cops hunted the bombing suspect, but we discovered another world last week. Two, actually  both somewhat larger than Earth, circling a star with the sadly unromantic name of Kepler 62, 1,200 light-years away.

title: Is It Time for Off-the-Shelf Birth-Control Pills?
description: WHEN a federal judge recently ordered the Food and Drug Administration to make the morning-after pill available to women of all ages without a prescription, the ruling was a political embarrassment for the Obama administration and unleashed protests from abortion foes and abstinence advocates. But that controversy may look like a tempest in a teapot compared with a broader and no less heated discussion that is roiling the medical community: should birth-control pills of any type require a doctors prescription? Or should they be available, like Tylenol, on pharmacy shelves?

title: The Benefits of Church
description: ONE of the most striking scientific discoveries about religion in recent years is that going to church weekly is good for you. Religious attendance  at least, religiosity  boosts the immune system and decreases blood pressure. It may add as much as two to three years to your life. The reason for this is not entirely clear.

title: Boston Attacks Turn Spotlight on Troubled Region of Chechnya
description: WASHINGTON  The possible motivations of the two brothers linked to the Boston Marathon bombings are as yet publicly unknown. Of Chechen heritage, they lived in the United States for years, according to friends and relatives, and no direct ties have been publicly established with known Chechen terrorist or separatist groups.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Gas Drilling and Our Energy Future
description: Readers discuss whether natural gas from shale is a promising resource or a misguided risk.

title: The Transition Game, to Official From Player
description: As a layup by Nets center Brook Lopez dropped through the basket during a recent game, the Charlotte Bobcats inbounded the ball and Haywoode Workman tore down the court, just as he had done for eight years as a guard in the N.B.A. But now he wears a different uniform: that of a referee.

title: Nets Ploy: Intimidate With Shirts
description: Barclays Center has a somewhat forbidding atmosphere for visiting teams. The music pumped through the arenas loudspeakers, hand-selected by the mix-tape artist J. Period, has an aggressive attitude. The black-clad Brooklynettes dance team has a decidedly adult attitude. And the Nets, in black home uniforms that are in stark contrast with typical N.B.A. fashion, certainly look tough, even if their game is based on offensive execution more than any sort of intimidation.

title: A New Nets Era, but Much Has Been Left Behind
description: The question inevitably comes twice a year: once in November, when the N.B.A. season usually starts, and again in the spring, when the playoffs near.

title: Need Motivation? Declare a Deadline
description: AT a meeting last Tuesday, I told my colleagues that I would finish this column  which is about deadlines  by noon on Thursday. I spent part of Tuesday afternoon searching the word deadlines on Google, but didnt make much progress. By late afternoon, I felt a tiny knot of fear in my stomach. What if I let my co-workers down? So I wrote something silly just to get started. This paragraph.

title: Italian Bureaucracy Threatens Pompeii
description: A site no stranger to misfortune, the ancient city must now face a possible new hazard: Italys red tape.

title: Pompeii Falling From Grace
description: Pompeiis ruins are a Unesco World Heritage site, but despite money from the European Union, the Italian government is struggling to maintain them.

title: The Hand That Feeds Us
description: During the weekly exchange of peace handshakes several months ago at the small church around the corner from where I live in Chicago, a fellow congregant met my extended hand with a firm grip and said, I heard that you lost your job  you must be scared. Then she followed up with a Peace be with you and moved on to another parishioner.

title: The Latest Threat to Pompeiis Treasures: Italys Red Tape
description: POMPEII, Italy  Destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79, Pompeii survived excavation starting in the 18th century and has stoically borne the wear and tear of millions of modern-day tourists.

title: The First Race to the Top
description: FOR the nearly 50 million students enrolled in Americas public schools, tests are everywhere, whether prepared by classroom teachers or by the ubiquitous testing industry. Central to school accountability, they assume familiar shapes and forms. Multiple choice. Essay. Aptitude. Achievement. NAEP, ACT, SAT.

title: Sprinting Toward the End
description: DEATH is a sniper, Nora Ephron wrote in I Feel Bad About My Neck, her 2006 best seller. It strikes people you love, people like you, people you know, its everywhere. You could be next.

title: Sure, Your References Like You. But What Would Your Critics Say?
description: This interview with Nancy Aossey, president and C.E.O. of the nonprofit International Medical Corps, which provides health care training, relief and development programs, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Building Blocks, Not Blockbusters
description: You remember last years N.F.L. draft, the one with the two franchise quarterbacks at the top, the one that produced a rookie class that may have made more of an immediate impact than any other?

title: Big Data, Trying to Build Better Workers
description: BOSSES, as it turns out, really do matter  perhaps far more than even they realize.

title: Reaching G-Forces, but First the Pedals
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Mash the gas pedal the moment the light changes, race to the next signal and hit the brakes. Thats a typical commute for some drivers.

title: With a Week to Go, a Scramble for the Postseason
description: This strangest of recent N.H.L. regular seasons enters its final week with playoff positioning still largely unresolved.

title: Swedens Closet Racists
description: STOCKHOLM

title: An Instant Path to an Online Army
description: ITS been true for a while that if you need to transcribe an audio recording, find contact information for a company, summarize an article, or perform any number of routine tasks, an anonymous online worker can do the job for a small payment. Amazons Mechanical Turk, for example, recently listed 230,000 available microtasks.

title: Before Housing Bubbles, There Was Land Fever
description: SINCE 1997, we have lived through the biggest real estate bubble in United States history  followed by the most calamitous decline in housing prices that the country has ever seen.

title: Hispanics, the New Italians
description: THE German immigrants of the 19th century were so devoted to their native language that Americans wondered if the new arrivals would ever assimilate. The Irish who followed were said to be too devoted to a foreign pope to embrace American democracy.

title: With Brittney Griner, Elena Delle Donne and Skylar Diggins
description: The W.N.B.A. is counting on its top three rookies  Brittney Griner (Phoenix), Elena Delle Donne (Chicago) and Skylar Diggins (Tulsa)  to raise the leagues profile as it embarks on its 17th season next month. The three women remember playing one another in Amateur Athletic Union competition, and they most recently led their college teams to the N.C.A.A. tournament, Griner with Baylor, Delle Donne with Delaware and Diggins with Notre Dame. These are excerpts from their conversation last Wednesday with reporters and editors at The New York Times.

title: If Its Underground, Maybe Its Price Is, Too
description: IN waves of intense selling, an array of commodities extracted from beneath the earths surface  from gold and silver to oil, aluminum and copper  has fallen sharply in price this month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Bet on the Future of Downtown Detroit
description: To the Editor:

title: In Memory of a Friend, Teacher and Mentor
description: I WAS 12 years old when I entered the Hawthorne Avenue Annex in February 1946. The Annex, a 15-minute bus ride for me from the main high school, was where you went in those days as a freshman at Newarks Weequahic High. The first teacher I had to face on the first hour of my first day at the Annex was Bob Lowenstein. Dr. Lowenstein. Doc Lowenstein. He was fresh from serving in World War II, unlike most high school teachers he was unassumingly in possession of a Ph.D., and what was recognizable even to a 12-year-old was that this was a formidable man who did not gladly suffer fools.

title: After Night of Terror in Boston Suburb, a Dawn of Doughnuts and Relief
description: WATERTOWN, Mass.  All of Boston rode a roller coaster of emotions last week, from horror at the bloody bombings during the annual marathon to a grim wait under lockdown while the suspects were pursued, to pure euphoria once the second suspect was captured in a parked boat.

title: In Love With My Planet
description: Photographs from Sebastio Salgados surprising new work, Genesis, are a testament to the joy, innocence and repose in earths Edenic corners.

title: In Love With My Planet
description: Dominique Browning spoke with Sebastio Salgado, the documentary photographer and author, about the inspiration for his forthcoming bookGenesis.

title: In Love With My Planet
description: Sebastio Salgado, one of the worlds most admired photojournalists, has spent a lifetime relentlessly training his eye on human degradation and suffering. His photographs, though beautiful, are often full of despair. Mr. Salgados new work, Genesis, is a testament to something altogether different: the joy, innocence and repose in earths Edenic corners.

title: A Closer Look at the Bombing Suspects Twitter Account
description: At 8:04 p.m., five hours after the Boston Marathon bombings on Monday, the Twitter account belonging to the 19-year-old suspect captured Friday night posted this message:

title: Turning Toward the Sun
description: I WAS born in Pretoria, South Africa. My father was a chiropractor, and my mother operated a massage therapy college where students came to learn reflexology, massage techniques and natural health therapy. Im the youngest of three boys, and I have a younger sister.

title: Relatives of Flotilla Raid Victims Reject Compensation From Israel
description: ISTANBUL  As Israeli and Turkish officials prepared for talks on Monday to restore relations, frozen since Israels deadly raid on a Turkish-led flotilla to Gaza, relatives of the nine people killed said Saturday that they would reject the compensation promised by Israel until it fully removes restrictions on the movement of goods and people in Gaza.

title: Manhunts Turning Point Came in the Decision to Release Suspects Images
description: WASHINGTON  With thousands of tips pouring in from the public, investigators for the Federal Bureau of Investigation were homing in on the Boston Marathon bombing suspects on Thursday morning  or so they thought.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 21
description: With one suspect dead and the other in custody in the wake of the Boston Marathon bombings, the Sunday shows will turn to discussions of what happens next in the story that transfixed the nation last week.

title: McGradys Spurs Stint Recalls Magical Game
description: When Tracy McGrady spoke with the media after his first shootaround Wednesday with the San Antonio Spurs, he was breathing a little hard and was covered in a sheen of sweat. By his own admission, he had spent much of that last month on the couch. It was clear he was happy to be back in the N.B.A. Reporters there asked him about whether he knew this was happening, about his time with the Qingdao Eagles in China and about whether he had yet experienced any ribbing from the Spurs about one particular game he played against them back in 2004.

title: A Hush Falls Where Rockets Once Roared
description: After the Space Shuttle program ended in 2011, Titusville, Fla., a boomtown born of the space race, started to lose its footing.

title: Yankees Recover in 11th to Edge Blue Jays
description: TORONTO  The moment that Aaron Loup turned to throw to third base was the instant that Vernon Wells sensed victory was imminent.

title: Other Austerity Bloopers
description: While the Reinhart-Rogoff fiasco is fresh in our minds, its worth recalling the other paper that swept through the ranks of the VSPs, briefly becoming orthodoxy, what everyone knew, until people took a hard look at the data. Remember Alesina and Ardagna? That was the paper that supposedly showed that spending cuts were actually expansionary, because of Confidence (TM). It was so influential that Peter Coy at BusinessWeek wrote,

title: Suspects With Feet in Two Worlds
description: A small glimpse at life in the Russian republic of Dagestan, which was once home to Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

title: Free Lightroom 5 Photo Editing Software
description: Adobe Systems has begun giving away the newest version of its photo editing software, Lightroom 5. But there is a catch.

title: Thrown for a Curve in Rhode Island
description: You have to imagine what it was like being Don Carcieri in the harsh winter of 2010. As Rhode Islands governor, a Republican in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, he had come into office seven years earlier as a business executive turned politician, vowing to retool the states corroded economy.

title: Front Flips
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Well done, and exactly what the title offered, yes? Jonah Kagan is back and his theme rolled right off my crayon and into the grid (what, you thought I used a pen or a pencil?) The title is Front Flips, and the theme takes familiar phrases, flips the first or front word, and clues them in a punny way. Nice, neat, pretty cleanly filled, and just the thing for a relaxing Sunday solve.

title: Knicks Arent Perfect, but the Result Is
description: The orange shirts were twirling, the volume was swelling, the fans were standing, and in the midst of Madison Square Gardens happy mayhem, Carmelo Anthony was surveying and directing, with a calm certainty.

title: Devastation and Frustration in Aftermath of Quake
description: People slept outside ruined homes and tried to reach relatives in Lushan County in China, only to be turned away by the police because of a landslide.

title: Bombing Suspects Immigration Story Adds Layer to Debate on Overhaul
description: WAYNE, Pa.  With the television in her pizzeria showing an endless loop of the Boston manhunt on Friday, Bessie Kontis glanced up at scenes of the quasi-military lockdown and shuddered.

title: Legal Questions Riddle Boston Marathon Case
description: The capture of the Boston Marathon bombing suspect raises a host of freighted legal issues for a society still feeling the shadow of Sept. 11, including whether he should be read a Miranda warning, how he should be charged, where he might be tried and whether the bombings on Boylston Street last Monday were a crime or an act of war.

title: Conservative Koch Brothers Turning Focus to Newspapers
description: Three years ago, Charles and David Koch, the billionaire industrialists and supporters of libertarian causes, held a seminar of like-minded, wealthy political donors at the St. Regis Resort in Aspen, Colo. They laid out a three-pronged, 10-year strategy to shift the country toward a smaller government with less regulation and taxes.

title: Before Game, Knicks and Celtics Stand Together
description: Carmelo Anthony grabbed a microphone and spoke to the crowd at Madison Square Garden before the Knicks faced the Boston Celtics in Game 1 of their first-round playoff series.

title: $300 Million Scholarship for Study in China Signals a New Focus
description: HONG KONG  The private-equity tycoon Stephen A. Schwarzman, backed by an array of mostly Western blue-chip companies with interests in China, is creating a $300 million scholarship for study in China that he hopes will rival the Rhodes scholarship in prestige and influence.

title: Mets, Minus Harvey, Go Back to Receiving Their Punishment
description: A theme has emerged early in the season for the Mets: there is a distinct difference in the games in which Matt Harvey pitches and the games in which he does not.

title: Rewinding History, Bush Museum Lets You Decide
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Tex.  More than four years after leaving office, former President George W. Bush has a question for America: So what would you have done?

title: A Presidential Center for the 21st Century
description: After the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum is officially dedicated on Thursday, visitors will be able to see the 43rd presidents term through his eyes.

title: At Forum, Animosity and Jeers for Quinn
description: Members of the audience called her a liar, an opponent relentlessly attacked her, and the moderator at one point had to beg the scornful crowd to let her speak.

title: Storm Thorgerson, Album Designer, Dies at 69
description: Storm Thorgerson, a British graphic designer whose comic, disturbing, semi-surreal images for the covers of albums helped illustrate the era of psychedelic rock, died on Thursday. He was 69.

title: Specialists See Tools to Treat Pain in Video Games
description: WASHINGTON  Fifteen-year-old Reilly woke up one morning with a sharp, stabbing pain in his left leg that soon spread to other parts of his body. The pain, which started early last year, forced him to quit soccer, and he spent the next four months being poked, prodded and scanned by doctors.

title: Hilary Koprowski, Who Developed First Live-Virus Polio Vaccine, Dies at 96
description: It was a brew to rival any in Macbeth. The main ingredients were rat brain and a fearsome, carefully cultivated virus.

title: A Montana Loophole Leaves a Bitter Taste With Bar Owners
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  It was Saturday afternoon, and that meant the pale ale was flowing inside Draught Works, the latest brewery to open in this beer-loving college town. People swooned over the Czech pilsner and the coffee stout. A string band plucked away. As parents ordered another round, their children darted around the tables like giggling schools of fish.

title: Knicks vs. Celtics
description: Led by Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks defeated the Celtics in Game 1 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Danes Rethink a Welfare State Ample to a Fault
description: COPENHAGEN  It began as a stunt intended to prove that hardship and poverty still existed in this small, wealthy country, but it backfired badly. Visit a single mother of two on welfare, a liberal member of Parliament goaded a skeptical political opponent, see for yourself how hard it is.

title: As Perry Ponders Next Political Move, Let the Guessing Begin
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Optometrists Seek Negotiating Power With Insurers
description: A group of Texas optometrists is lobbying the State Legislature for more power to negotiate contracts with health insurance companies, and the measure they are supporting could hit consumers wallets, some business advocates say.

title: Mistaken Identity After Blasts
description: While law enforcement agencies hunted for the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing, there was a another round-the-clock search, in Providence: for a philosophy student who left his apartment near Brown University on March 16 and has yet to return.

title: Kerry Says U.S. Will Double Aid to Rebels in Syria
description: ISTANBUL  Secretary of State John Kerry announced Sunday morning that the United States would double its aid to the Syrian opposition, providing $123 million in fresh assistance.

title: Seeking to Pare Standardized Tests, Legislators Take Aim at Testing Firm
description: As the Texas Legislature moves to uproot the states standardized testing program amid an outcry from parents and school leaders, state lawmakers have focused their criticism on Pearson, the publishing and testing company that develops the tests.

title: F.B.I. Interview Led Homeland Security to Hold Up Citizenship for One Brother
description: Department of Homeland Security officials decided in recent months not to grant an application for American citizenship by Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of two brothers suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings, after a routine background check revealed that he had been interviewed in 2011 by the F.B.I., federal officials said on Saturday.

title: Psychedelia Redux for Billy Gibbons and His Old Band
description: Before the beards, cars and fuzzy guitars, Billy Gibbons led the Moving Sidewalks, a loud, bluesy Houston-based quartet that helped draft the blueprint for ZZ Top while building on the late-60s psychedelic rock movement that was blooming simultaneously in Texas, San Francisco and other locales.

title: Mourning First Responders in Texas
description: Fertilizer plant explosion claims one-fifth of the mostly volunteer fire department of West, Tex.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 20, 2013

title: Feeling for Boston Gives Way to Need for Victory
description: A smattering of boos began to form in the (relatively) cheap seats to the left of the press area as Paul Pierce was announced with Carmelo Anthony for a joint pregame salute to the besieged city of Boston. Quickly, and thankfully, the truly infantile among the Madison Square Garden crowd were hushed into submission.

title: In Retirement, a Champion Is a Crusader for the Game
description: Former chess champions are often content to rest on their laurels. Not Garry Kasparov.

title: With Chandler Not at His Best, Martin Steps In to Fill the Void
description: A towel was around Tyson Chandlers neck for the entire fourth quarter in the Knicks 85-78 victory against the Boston Celtics. He wore his warm-up T-shirt over his white jersey. He clapped and cheered on his teammates, especially Kenyon Martin.

title: A Week of Terror in Boston
description: It was a tumultuous week in Boston, from the excitement of the marathon, to the horror of the bombing and the tension of a manhunt, to elation at the capture of a fugitive suspect.

title: Avalanche in Colorado Kills Five Snowboarders
description: DENVER  Five snowboarders were killed Saturday afternoon after apparently setting off an avalanche atop Colorados Loveland Pass, a popular spot for backcountry enthusiasts, a law-enforcement official said.

title: Up From Thatcher Funeral Floats Memory of Long-Ago Handbagging
description: LONDON There will have been many among the 2,300 invited guests at Margaret Thatchers funeral who were handbagged by the Iron Lady, and dined happily off the experience for years after she had left public life.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: 4 Goals, 3 Points
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Another sporting event involving a team from the Boston area was played in the shadow of the Monday bomb explosions at the Boston Marathon; this one involving the New England Revolution and the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer on Saturday night.

title: Poetry: No Venue Necessary
description: Poets in Unexpected Places is a collective of New York City poets dedicated to returning their art form to public spaces.

title: Nets Enjoy Celebration but Know They Still Have Work to Do
description: The Nets transformed Barclays Center into a grand postseason stage, with dark T-shirts and luminous bracelets, banners and baked goods, fireworks and a drum line, one glorious self-tribute after another.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 21
description: Americans refuse to be terrorized. Ultimately, thats what well remember from this week.

title: U.S. Rebounds From Early Loss in Fed Cup
description: Despite boasting one of its strongest lineups in a decade, the United States Fed Cup team found itself in an early hole Saturday in Delray Beach, Fla., against the heavy underdog Sweden, before eventually drawing even by the end of the day.

title: Corrections: April 21, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Nets vs. Bulls
description: The Nets beat the Chicago Bulls, 106-89, in Game 1 of their playoff series.

title: Kaveri Arora, Michael Turner
description: Kaveri Banka Arora and Michael Seth Turner were married Saturday at the Fairmount Park Horticulture Center in Philadelphia. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated. Rabbi Fred V. Davidow led a Jewish ceremony in the evening.

title: Laura Napoli, Gregory Coordes
description: Laura Ann Napoli, the daughter of Sandra M. Napoli and Joseph A. Napoli of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday to Gregory Douglas Coordes, a son of Dr. Cordie C. Coordes of St. Louis and the late Dr. Kathleen Coordes. The Rev. Eric Olsen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Shrine of St. Joseph in St. Louis.

title: Howard Zar and Raymond Kurdziel
description: Howard Arthur Zar and Raymond Joseph Kurdziel were married Saturday in the art gallery of the Lyndhurst estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Karen Pearl, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Donna Kerr, Patricia Dawson
description: Donna Hanneman Kerr and Dr. Patricia Lucille Dawson were married Saturday in Seattle at the home of Benjamin G. Danis and Gerald A. Prosio, friends of the couple. The Rev. David K. Shull, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Jamie Neuthaler, Aaron Books
description: Jamie Leigh Neuthaler and Aaron Scott Books were married Saturday evening at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York. Rabbi Lisa Rubin, the brides sister-in-law, officiated.

title: A Little Ruse That Worked
description: Dr. Gisel Herminia Diaz, the daughter of Magalis S. M. Nuez of San Francisco de Macors, Dominican Republic, and Fausto J. Diaz of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Dr. Ismael C. Cubero, the son of Cynthia Cubero and Candido Cubero of Monroe, N.J. The Rev. Donald C. Baker, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at St. Teresas Church in Manhattan.

title: Jennifer Sessions, Christopher ONeill
description: Jennifer Viola Sessions and Christopher John ONeill were married Friday evening at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Shauna Kanter, a Universal Brotherhood minister who is registered with the New York City Clerk, officiated.

title: Elena John and Joseph Toce III
description: Elena Josephine John and Joseph Paul Toce III were married Saturday by the Rev. James M. L. Grace, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Church Cathedral in Houston.

title: Rachel Isaacs, Melanie Weiss
description: Rabbi Rachel Marissa Isaacs and Melanie Anne Weiss were married Friday in a civil ceremony at Beth Israel Congregation in Waterville, Me., where Rabbi Isaacs is the spiritual leader. Robert Sezak, a Maine notary, officiated. On April 28, Rabbi Carie Carter is to lead a religious ceremony at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn, with Rabbi Dr. David Ellenson taking part.

title: Michelle Schmoker, Alexander Davis
description: Michelle Kathleen Schmoker and Alexander Stuart Davis were married Saturday by the Rev. Richard N. Morrison at Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Phoenix.

title: Emily Verellen, Darnell Strom
description: Emily Kate Verellen and Darnell Omari Strom were married Saturday evening at Carondelet House, an event space in Los Angeles. Ken Biberaj, a friend of the couple who was appointed a temporary deputy marriage commissioner by Los Angeles County for the event, officiated.

title: Sylvia Vellino, Joshua Herlands
description: Sylvia Mary Vellino and Joshua Irving Herlands were married Saturday by Rabbi Allan Smith at the Radisson Lackawanna Station Hotel in Scranton, Pa.

title: Adventurers Dedicated to Public Service
description: Megan Joan Roberts and Philip Matthew Mabe Jr. were married Saturday at Skytop Lodge, a resort in Skytop, Pa. The Rev. Bethany A. Hannon, an aunt of the bride and a minister in the Church of the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness in Los Angeles, officiated.

title: Melissa Williams, John Omartian
description: Melissa Mae Williams and John Crawford Aram Omartian were married Saturday at the Inn at Willow Grove in Orange, Va. Donald L. Hughes, a marriage commissioner of Orange County, Va., officiated at a secular ceremony that was led by Antha Nicole Williams, the brides sister. The ceremony included a reading of Union, an essay by Robert Fulghum.

title: Lancy Fuller and Matthew Wright
description: Lancy Denise Fuller and Matthew Keith Wright were married Saturday evening at the Gwinnett Environmental and Heritage Center in Buford, Ga. The Rev. Bobby Bolton, a minister at Victory World Church, officiated.

title: Lincy Cherian, Michael Hartman
description: Dr. Lincy Ann Cherian and Michael Patrick Hartman were married Saturday in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Michael Lopez, a minister affiliated with All Saints Universal Church, officiated.

title: Penelope Daulton, Thom Sesma
description: Penelope Oldham Daulton and Thom Sesma were married Saturday at St. Malachys, a Roman Catholic Church in New York known as the Actors Chapel. The Rev. Richard D. Baker, its pastor, performed the ceremony with assistance from the Rev. George Drance, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Writing His Way Into Her Heart
description: Blair Courtney Baker, a daughter of Wendy A. Baker and Douglas C. Baker of Altadena, Calif., is to be married Sunday to Zachary Wolf Kline, the son of Thomas R. Kline of Philadelphia and the late Paula Wolf Kline. Rabbi Melissa Buyer is to officiate in the New York apartment owned by the grooms father.

title: In China, the Shared Grief of Losing a Single Child Like Lu Lingzi
description: BEIJING  In a dignified letter, the parents of Lu Lingzi, the 23-year-old Chinese student killed in the Boston Marathon attack, asked people to remember their daughter by helping make the world a better place, as she had wanted to.

title: Clowning Around
description: Kim Jong-uns nuclear act fails to convince China or the U.S.

title: Hagel, in Israel, Presses U.S. Agenda on Deterring Iran
description: JERUSALEM  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel opened a weeklong visit to the Middle East on Sunday by pressing an American agenda focused on deterring Iran  including a significant new weapons deal for Israel  coupled with a strong caution that it would be premature for Israel to opt for unilateral strikes on Tehrans nuclear program.

title: No City for Little Boys
description: We live in New York City by choice. The idea was that it would be an informative experience for our children. City kids are hip and cultured and privileged to a purview that inspires worldliness. For the most part, I agree with those points, but Im starting to think that, ultimately, this is not the best place for little boys to be raised.

title: San Francisco Hangout Becomes Casualty of Tech Boom
description: Since 1999, The Grove restaurant, with its warm, woodsy interior and comfort food, has marketed itself as San Franciscos living room. Its customers, who have a habit of lingering for hours, seem to agree.

title: A Deal That Seemed Inevitable: Revis Is a Buccaneer
description: The day after the Jets season ended, cornerback Darrelle Revis said he expected to play for the team in 2013. More than that, Revis said that he wanted to lead the Jets return to prominence and that there was nowhere else he would rather be.

title: Editors Lab: Newsgaming Ideas
description: The latest hack event in the Editors Lab series kicked off yesterday at the Times building. Eleven media teams got right to work and generated some ideas on the theme of newsgaming. Project ideas are subject to change, but heres a summary of the brain waves thus far:

title: On the Train, or at the Laundromat, Your Poem Begins  Now
description: New York City is invited to a poetry reading.

title: Scientific Management Redux: The Difference Is in the Data
description: I wrote a Sunday column about the rise of what is being called work force science. Lots of companies are embracing the trend, but anyone familiar with business history might reasonably ask, Whats really new here?

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (13, 49) THE BLETCHLEY CIRCLE Nine years after putting their extraordinary talents to use at Bletchley Park, Britains code-breaking headquarters during World War II, four seemingly ordinary women piece together clues they hope will solve a series of murders. Leading the charge is Susan (Anna Maxwell Martin, above), now a homemaker and mother of two, who wangles her way into Scotland Yard when she thinks she has detected a pattern to the killings. But when the police dismiss her theory, she turns for assistance to her former colleagues  Millie (Rachael Stirling), conversant in 14 languages and good with maps; Lucy (Sophie Rundle), with her photographic memory; and Jean (Julie Graham), their onetime supervisor  who, like Susan, have returned to civilian life and kept their intelligence work secret from even those closest to them. While the solving of the mystery is fairly conventional, these amateur detectives arent, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. The three-part mystery doesnt have a preachy tone, but it does have a message, and its similar to the one in Call the Midwife, the British series, leading in at 8, that follows young nurses who after the war helped women in the poorest sections of London deliver babies, usually in tenement homes, on top of rags and newspapers, she said, adding that both series find a clever, entertaining way to pay tribute to women who in their time were often overlooked and underestimated, and nevertheless found ways to never be ordinary.

title: Destructive Creativity
description: Still thinking my way through the Reinhart-Rogoff debacle and related issues, and I think theres an important point to be made here about the state of macroeconomics.

title: Kerry Asks Turkish Leader to Postpone Trip to Gaza
description: ISTANBUL  Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday that he had urged Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to put off his visit to Gaza to avoid disrupting efforts to revive peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Small Majority Approved of Miranda Rights for Terror Suspects
description: The capture of Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, 19, a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, has revived a debate over how terrorism cases are handled in the United States, including whether suspected terrorists should be read their Miranda rights, which include the right to an attorney and the right to remain silent, and how quickly.

title: Oblivion Tops Weekend Box Office
description: The celebrity tabloids continue to pick apart Tom Cruise; moviegoers continue not to care. Oblivion, Mr. Cruises latest big-screen adventure, was a stronger-than-expected No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, with ticket sales of about $38.2 million.

title: Barbra Streisand in Pictures
description: A look back at the career of Barbra Streisand, who is being honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Boston Begins to Say Goodbye to Victims of the Bombings
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  Boston began to say goodbye on Sunday to those it lost last week. Its leaders  religious as well as political  fanned out, in front of naves and cameras, to do what they could to reassure grieving parishioners and constituents that the danger had passed. Or that for those who are gone, life, as Cardinal Sean P. OMalley put it, is not ended, merely changed.

title: Taliban Attacks in Northwest Pakistan Are Reshaping Ballot
description: NOWSHERA, Pakistan  When Shahid Khan started talking, his gunmen clambered onto a schools rooftop, scanning the surrounding hills with flashlights, anticipating a possible attack.

title: City Report Shows More Were Near Poverty in 2011
description: The rise in New York Citys poverty rate as a result of the recession has apparently eased, but not before pushing nearly half of the citys population into the ranks of the poor or near-poor in 2011, according to an analysis by the Bloomberg administration.

title: China Presses Crackdown on Campaign Against Graft
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities have detained six anticorruption activists in recent days, expanding their crackdown on a citizen-led campaign that, on the surface at least, would appear to dovetail with the new leaderships war on official graft.

title: Mets Designate Laffey in Anticipation of Marcums Debut
description: The Mets recalled the left-hander Robert Carson from the minors and designated the left-hander Aaron Laffey for assignment.

title: The 6 People Streisand Wants at Her Dinner Party
description: At a gala on Monday night Barbra Streisand will receive the Film Society of Lincoln Centers Chaplin Award for lifetime achievement. The society cited in particular her work on Yentl, the first movie to credit a woman as director, writer, producer and star, along with other big-screen turns behind the camera (Prince of Tides and The Mirror Has Two Faces) and in front of it (Funny Girl and For Petes Sake).

title: A Comedy Show That Comes via a Hashtag
description: Next week, Comedy Central will host a five-day comedy festival that includes a lineup of legends like Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner alongside popular young comics like Amy Schumer and the director Paul Feig.

title: Luis Surez Bites an Opponent, Again
description: Video: Suarez bites Ivanovic?

title: Festive and Defiant, London Runs a Marathon for Boston
description: LONDON  Six days and 3,300 miles from the bombings in Boston, the London Marathon was held Sunday under an azure sky, in what runners called perfect conditions, with no security scares and the minds of virtually all involved soaring westward to the victims of last Mondays attack.

title: Greenhouse for French Baroque Opera
description: On Friday evening the conductor William Christie and his period-instrument ensemble Les Arts Florissants presented Le Jardin de Monsieur Rameau at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a program of semi-staged French Baroque opera selections by Rameau and his contemporaries. The title, The Garden of Mr. Rameau, is a pun on Mr. Christies vocal training program, Le Jardin des Voix (The Garden of Voices), which in turn alludes to the flowering of the instrumental groups name, itself taken from a Charpentier opera.

title: A Table for One, Please
description: Before the official start of Rosie Herreras Dining Alone at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Friday night, one of its performers, the debonair Octavio Campos, was already planted at the head of a long table and speaking to his guests. But there was a catch. Mr. Camposs friends were life-size cutouts.

title: Boldly Navigating Schumanns Forest
description: Mitsuko Uchida can easily fill Carnegie Hall with a blockbuster program: the last three piano sonatas of Schubert, say, which she played in 2012, or the last three of Beethoven, which she performed there most recently in 2009. But this superb pianist showed on Thursday evening that her fan base will by now follow wherever she wants to go.

title: A Moment of Silence in London
description: London Marathon runners observed a moment of silence on Sunday to honor the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings.

title: The Way to Slay Wagners Dragon
description: In Wagners Siegfried the young title hero eventually learns the meaning of fear. It seems believable that he manages to emerge confidently from his encounter with the cartoonish dragon of Robert Lepages staging, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon with Jay Hunter Morris in the role. That he succumbs to fear in the final scene, however, seemed less credible.

title: Exploring Some Ties, People and Situations That Bind
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The choreographer Jasmin Vardimon, born in Israel, formed her company in 1997 in London, where she has found much popular success and a post as associate artist at Sadlers Wells. Except for once, in Texas, though, her troupe had not appeared in the United States until a run last week in the Peak Performances series at Montclair State University here. First impression: Ms. Vardimon is familiar with the work of Pina Bausch.

title: How Shakespeare Shuffled Off This Mortal Coil
description: Robert Brustein lovingly kills off William Shakespeare in The Last Will, a speculative version of the end of Shakespeares life that completes Mr. Brusteins trilogy on him.

title: Slaughter Reported Near Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian opposition activists said Sunday that government forces had killed at least 80 people in a town south of Damascus, and then carried out mass arrests as the residents tried to bury the bodies.

title: Lopez and Nets Dominate Game 1, but Their Work Is Not Finished
description: At 7 feet tall, with broad shoulders and tree-trunk legs, Brook Lopez is massive even by N.B.A. standards. But in the Nets 106-89 Game 1 victory against the Chicago Bulls on Saturday night at Barclays Center, Lopez repeatedly sneaked undetected into the heart of the Bulls defense. He had six layups in the first half alone, often by expertly drifting to the blind spots of Bulls defenders to create passing angles for his teammates.

title:
Struggle at Home
Intrudes on Chechen
Haven in America
description: NEEDHAM, Mass.  Four days after the Boston Marathon bombings, Ali Tepsurkaev was at work on a construction site on Nantucket when his boss approached him to deliver the news: the two prime suspects had been identified as ethnic Chechens.

title: Police Release Thermal Imaging Video of Boston Suspects Capture
description: The Massachusetts State Police on Sunday released new video showing the final moments of Friday nights standoff with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, before he was taken into custody.

title: Mets Get Contributions From Unlikely Sources, Including a National
description: The Mets 2-0 victory against the Washington Nationals on Sunday afternoon was formed from an amalgam of strange and pleasant surprises.

title: Appalachian Strains With a Bach Twist
description: The environment of his native state of Kentucky is a palpable presence in the lyrics of the singer, songwriter and cellist Ben Sollee, whose concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday evening was the season finale of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series. In Prettiest Tree on the Mountain, the image of a former lover, a redhead who moved to California, was compared to a glimpse of a robin outside his window and to the reddening of leaves as he walks through the hills.

title: After Freedom, Peace Is at Stake
description: Rectify, a new series about a Georgia man who is freed after 19 years on death row, traces the history of the Sundance Channel in reverse. For about an episode and a quarter, its very good television. But over the rest of its six-episode first season it resembles nothing so much as a bad indie film, the kind of slow and tepid bummer that used to fill Sundances late nights and afternoons when it was a full-time movie channel.

title: Nova Loses Control, and Yankees Lose Finale
description: TORONTO  Ivan Nova knew that the best words to describe some of his errant pitches this season, including a few on Sunday, would not have been appropriate for the television camera that was trained on his face. He refrained from using them but left no doubt about their content.

title: A Chechen Family Reacts to Bombings
description: A Chechen family that settled in the suburbs of Boston over a decade ago is particularly disheartened to hear that the marathon bombing suspects have been linked to Chechnya.

title: Russia Wins NEC Cup in Yokohama
description: The final of the NEC Cup in Yokohama, Japan, on Sunday was easily won by Russia: Andrei Gromov, Alexander Dubinin, Evgeni Gladysh and Mikhail Krasnosselski from Russia; and Sjoert Brink from the Netherlands. They defeated Mixed (Sabine Auken from Denmark; Roy Welland, Reese Milner, Hemant Lall and Jacek Pszczola from the United States; and Michal Kwiecien from Poland) by 153.5 international match points to 53. Mixed conceded after 48 of the scheduled 64 boards. The winners shared $12,000 and the runners-up $6,000.

title: Tales From the Prison of International Notoriety
description: Shes a complete blank, the playwright John Guare once said, trying to explain the public fascination with Amanda Knox, the American student accused (along with two men) of murdering her housemate Meredith Kercher during a sex escapade gone awry in Italy. You can project anything on to her. Is she Henry Jamess Daisy Miller, an innocent young girl who goes to Europe for experience? Or is she Louise Brooks, the woman who takes what she wants and destroys everything? Or is she Nancy Drew caught up in Kafka?

title: Volume Set to Fortissimo
description: Keiji Haino lives among the class of improvisers who roam so far from what we usually call form  meaning, basically, rules  that they make you question whether what theyre doing is music. When you arrive at that question, generally, the jokes on you. If you feel nothing for the music, you can walk away. If you feel something for it, you may start to notice that it possesses its own unity, its own rules. Anyway, its not Mr. Hainos problem. I am not an anarchist, he has said. I am anarchy.

title: Cambodian Toe-Tapping Going Global
description: The troubadour wielding a stringed instrument and singing praises, dance tunes, love songs, histories or wry comments is a nearly universal figure in traditional music, from Appalachian banjo pickers to Moroccan gnawa musicians to West African griots to Japanese minyo singers. Kong Nay, who performed at the Asia Society on Saturday night, is one of them, playing the Cambodian style called chapei: singing in a hearty voice and playing the chapei dang weng, a long-necked, two-stringed lute.

title: You Said It, Brother
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Vowel run. Talk amongst yourselves.

title: Facing a War Zone Rife With Cartels and Zombies
description: In 2010 a 20-year-old criminology student with a new baby volunteered for a job no one else would take: chief of police in the tiny Mexican border town of Prxedis Gilberto Guerrero, a place overrun by rival drug gangs. (To give you a sense of either the courageousness or foolhardiness of her decision: her predecessor had been tortured and beheaded.) The international news media quickly anointed this remarkable young mother, Marisol Valles Garca, as the bravest woman in Mexico. She proceeded by publicly withdrawing from the drug war, which she said she would leave to the feds; hiring more female officers, who didnt carry guns; and focusing her police forces efforts on community building and teaching family values, which she hoped would keep the gangs at bay.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Fox Renews Glee for 2 More Seasons
description: The Fox musical Glee, which defied the ratings odds when it had its debut in 2009, will remain on the network through 2015 in a deal announced on Friday. The network ordered two more seasons of the series, giving the co-creator Ryan Murphy and the other producers an unusual opportunity to plan story lines for the characters well into the future. The current season of Glee, its fourth, attracts about 8.7 million viewers a week and routinely ranks among TVs top 10 shows for 18- to 34-year-olds. In a statement Mr. Murphy thanked Fox and the studio that produces the series, 20th Century Fox Television, for their support. The fourth season has toggled between the high school glee club in Ohio and the graduates who are at a performing arts college in New York. Mr. Murphy has hinted in interviews that he wants the fifth season to focus on just one of the locations, but he has not said which one.

title: Reporter for Government Radio Is Killed in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A Somali journalist was shot to death on Sunday outside his home in Mogadishu by unknown gunmen, becoming the fourth journalist killed in his country this year, officials said.

title: Free Downtown Blues
description: The blues musician B. B. King and the rock group Los Lobos will be the headliners at the third annual Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival, which will be held on July 10 and 11 in a plaza outside the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan. Other acts include the rock trio Los Lonely Boys, Alejandro Escovedo and the rhythm-and-blues group the James Hunter Six. The concerts, presented by Brookfield Office Properties, are free to the public.

title: Anna Merz, Rhino Guardian and Champion, Dies at 81
description: Anna Merz, who went to Kenya seeking a serene retirement but became so appalled by the slaughter of black rhinoceroses that she helped start a reserve to protect them, becoming a global leader in the fight against their extinction, died on April 4 in Melkrivier, South Africa. She was 81.

title: The Pressure to Be the TV News Leader Tarnishes a Big Brand
description: Like a lot of Americans, when I woke up on Friday morning and found out there was a manhunt in the Boston area for the remaining suspect in Mondays bombing at the marathon, I turned on CNN.

title: The Falling Price of Carbon Credits
description: The European Unions Emissions Trading System was intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by setting a market price on them. The system, set up in three phases, requires polluters to acquire credits to offset their emissions. A glut of credits, combined with lower demand because of the weak economy, has driven down the price to close to zero.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Push to Have Boston Suspect Questioned as Enemy Combatant
description: WASHINGTON  Some Republican lawmakers want President Obama to declare the surviving Boston bombing suspect an enemy combatant in order to question him without a lawyer and other protections of the criminal justice system, intensifying a recurring debate over how to handle terrorism cases arising inside the United States.

title: Electric-Taxi Experiment Asks if Citys Cabbies Can Spare the Time to Plug In
description: The taxis are not entirely yellow. Their drivers are allowed to refuse certain fares. Even the smell is different, with no oil-rich odor greeting riders at the door.

title: Officials Visit to Japanese Shrine Could Anger Neighboring Countries
description: TOKYO  Members of the cabinet of Japans conservative prime minister visited a war shrine in Tokyo over the weekend, local news reports said Sunday, symbolic gestures that could anger South Korea and China at a time when Japans relations with both nations have been rocky.

title: Princeton Chooses Its Provost to Become Its Next President
description: Princeton University announced on Sunday that Christopher L. Eisgruber, a constitutional scholar who has been the universitys provost for nine years, would be its next president.

title: Callahan Helps Rangers Oust Devils From Playoff Picture
description: If revenge is best served cold, Rangers fans feasted on Sunday, nearly 11 months after the Devils eliminated their team from the 2012 Eastern Conference finals.

title: Is American Nonviolence Possible?
description: The choice is not between violence and nonviolence but between nonviolence and nonexistence.

title: Sports Goggles Can Provide Vital Data and Distraction
description: Oakley, the eyewear company, makes a $600 ski goggle that comes with a warning in the package: Do not operate product while skiing.

title: In Europe, Paid Permits for Pollution Are Fizzling
description: LONDON  On a showery afternoon last week in West London, a ripple of enthusiasm went through the trading floor of CF Partners, a privately owned financial company. The price of carbon allowances, shown in green lights on a board hanging from the ceiling, was creeping up toward three euros.

title: Rape of Girl, 5, Draws Focus to Child Assault in India
description: NEW DELHI  The case of a 5-year-old girl who was raped, tortured and nearly killed last week has shocked India, stirring memories of a gang rape on a medical student in December. Over the weekend as the girl was being treated at a hospital here, doctors tended to another child in a nearby bed.

title: A Top Strikers Reputation Is Marred by Another Bite Mark
description: Maybe Luis Surez blacked out. Maybe he lost his bearings. Maybe he has always had an abiding love for the remarkable drama and character development of vampire fiction. All we can know for sure is that whatever Surezs motivation late in the second half Sunday, he delivered what was almost surely a stunning, and grossly unhygienic, farewell.

title: Harsh Treatment at Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: In an Overhaul, Clorox Aims to Get Green Works Out of Its Niche
description: GREEN WORKS, Cloroxs line of environmentally friendly housecleaning products, is using Earth Day to introduce a fund-raising promotion on Twitter as part of an overall revamp of its marketing strategy.

title: In Atlanta, Two Churches Lie in New Stadiums Path
description: ATLANTA  Football, God and rebuilding are among the most enduring themes here in the largest city in the Deep South.

title: To Self-Publish or Not? A Word of Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Europes Leaders Hear Call to Do More to Spur Growth
description: WASHINGTON  For another year, the annual spring meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund ended with a single, strong message aimed at Europe: Do more.

title: Chinas Energy Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid for College Students
description: To the Editor:

title: A Catholics Personal God
description: To the Editor:

title: Stream the High Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Rights Tear at an Indian Reservation
description: RONAN, Mont.  In a place where the lives and histories of Indian tribes and white settlers intertwine like mingling mountain streams, a bitter battle has erupted on this land over the rivers running through it.

title: Obama and the Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Feelings About Inequality: Its Complicated
