description: How much do Americans care about rising income inequality? Surveys send mixed signals.

title: Straight Talk From a Professor of Flimflam (but Dont Ask His Age)
description: Breakfast with the grand illusionist Ricky Jay happened to come on a morning when the newspapers carried articles on some well-known figures who have given others reason to wonder if they are con artists.

title: The Jobless Trap
description: F.D.R. told us that the only thing we had to fear was fear itself. But when future historians look back at our monstrously failed response to economic depression, they probably wont blame fear, per se. Instead, theyll castigate our leaders for fearing the wrong things.

title: A Cash Register Without Buttons or Bells
description: Designers are providing an increasing array of choices as retailers use iPads in place of  traditional cash registers.

title: With Tablets, Businesses Ring Up at More Fanciful Cash Registers
description: SEATTLE  The humble cash register, a device that seems sprung from the imagination of an accountant, has become the darling of designers, adding a dash of style to the most ordinary daily transactions.

title: Cancer Centers Racing to Map Patients Genes
description: Electric fans growl like airplanes taking off and banks of green lights wink in a basement at Mount Sinais medical school, where a new $3 million supercomputer makes quick work of huge amounts of genetic and other biological information.

title: Activists Death in Egypt Spurs Charges of Police Abuse
description: CAIRO  Mohamed el-Gindy spent three days in violent protests around Tahrir Square. In a television interview, he promised a backlash if the new Islamist government tried to recreate the Egyptian police state.

title: From Phenom to Everyday N.B.A. Player
description: HOUSTON  At the peak of Linsanity last season, a certain 6-foot-10-inch fan walked into a sports bar to marvel at Jeremy Lins abrupt and dizzying performance with the Knicks.

title: Web Helps Musicians Sell Shares of Royalties
description: As a songwriter and producer for stars like Natalie Cole, Aretha Franklin and Whitney Houston, Preston Glass receives a comfortable stream of music royalties. But when he needed to make a substantial investment to embark on the next phase of his career  as a performing artist in his own right  he had few options to raise the money, he said.

title: Investigators Dig for Roots of Bomb Suspects Radicalization
description: WASHINGTON  The two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings were armed with a small arsenal of guns, ammunition and explosives when they first confronted the police early Friday, and were most likely planning more attacks, the authorities said Sunday.

title: Conservative Tobacco Magnate Wins Presidential Race in Paraguay
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  Horacio Cartes, a Paraguayan tobacco magnate, faced various challenges during his presidential bid. He was pressed to explain why antinarcotics police officers apprehended a plane carrying cocaine and marijuana on his ranch in 2000; why he went to prison in 1989 on currency fraud charges; and why he had never even voted in past general elections.

title: A Blogger on Trial
description: IF you set out to design a political nemesis who would give Vladimir Putin the shivers, you might well come up with Aleksei Navalny. That is why the trial of the popular Russian activist on Wednesday is the most important political trial in Russia in decades.

title: Two Sunday Running Events in Manhattan Are Minor, but Security Isnt
description: A swarm of police officers was deployed. Radiation sweeps were conducted. Trash cans and parked cars were unceremoniously removed. There were bomb-sniffing dogs, capable of picking up the scent of chemical vapors drifting in the wind.

title: Search for Home Led Suspect to Land Marred by Strife
description: MAKHACHKALA, Russia  Tamerlan Tsarnaev had already found religion by the time he landed in Dagestan, a combustible region in the North Caucasus that has become the epicenter of a violent Islamic insurgency in Russia and a hub of jihadist recruitment. What he seemed to be yearning for was a home.

title: A Modern City in East Midtown?
description: WE are told that New York needs to be lofted back into global competitiveness. That the city isnt modern enough. Take the area around Grand Central Terminal. With 80 percent of the building stock in the neighborhood now over 50 years old, we hear, our city is falling behind, and current zoning restrictions inhibit redevelopment.

title: Along the Route, Main Streets, Hills and a New Kind of Heartbreak
description: HOPKINTON, Mass.

title: Opposition Leader Rallies Italians in Protest After President Is Re-elected
description: ROME  He is not a member of Parliament or one of the 1,007 grand electors who selected a president on Saturday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 21, 2013

title: Chinese Auto Buyers Grow Hungry for Larger Cars
description: SHANGHAI  The models wore traditional cheongsam dresses and medieval Chinese armor as well as the usual rainbow of shiny miniskirts at the Shanghai auto show this weekend, but the many midsize cars and sport utility vehicles on display made it look almost like an American auto show.

title: Monte Carlo Streak Ends for Nadal
description: Perhaps the tightest grip on an event in professional sports ended Sunday when Novak Djokovic defeated Rafael Nadal, 6-2, 7-6 (1), in the final of the Monte Carlo Masters, ending Nadals streak of eight straight titles and 46 consecutive victories at the event.

title: U.S. Box Office Heroes Proving Mortal in China
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods global business strategy, which counts on huge ticket sales in China for high-budget fantasies in 3-D and large-screen Imax formats, is coming unhinged.

title: Trouble at the Chinese Box Office
description: Hollywood blockbusters, which fared well in Chinese movie theaters last year, fell on hard times in the first quarter. Iron Man 3, filmed partly in China, is the next test case.

title: When Offense Is Not Enough, the Knicks Defense Comes Through
description: The Knicks knew the key to their Game 1 victory Saturday against the Boston Celtics.

title: One Mad Power Grab, Many Dramatic Roles
description: The Scottish play, or Macbeth as it is known to laymen and superstition-free theater folk, sounds more Scottish than usual in the Broadway production that opened on Sunday night at the Barrymore Theater. The murderous general of the title is portrayed by the Scotland-born Alan Cumming, whose rich, rolling accent brings a whiff of the green highlands with it.

title: After Arrest in Rapes, Another Man Is Sought in 2nd Brooklyn Case
description: Two days after the arrest of a convicted sex offender in a series of rapes in Brooklyn, detectives on Sunday were searching for a man in connection with another sexual assault pattern in the borough.

title: Restyled as Real Estate Trusts, Varied Businesses Avoid Taxes
description: A small but growing number of American corporations, operating in businesses as diverse as private prisons, billboards and casinos, are making an aggressive move to reduce  or even eliminate  their federal tax bills.

title: How to Handle a Terrorism Case
description: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina apparently has a thermal-imaging device for detecting the motivation of the man arrested on suspicion of bombing the Boston Marathon. He and three other Republican lawmakers declared  without the benefit of evidence  that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev should be considered an enemy combatant, not a criminal, and should be held by the military without access to a lawyer or the fundamental rights that distinguish this country from authoritarian regimes.

title: Broken Justice in the Bronx
description: Quietly over time, the gleaming glass building near Yankee Stadium that houses the Bronx criminal courts has become a place where delay and dysfunction are the norm and central ideals of the American justice system  especially the promise of a speedy trial  have been disgracefully subverted.

title: Visa Reforms for Skilled Workers
description: The immigration reform bill introduced by a bipartisan group of senators last week would make it easier for skilled workers to come to this country while toughening rules to prevent abuse in temporary work visas.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released includes existing home sales for March (Monday); new home sales for March (Tuesday); durable goods orders for March (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and first-quarter gross domestic product and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

title: New Leader Named for Enforcement Unit at S.E.C.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) THE ISLAND PRESIDENT (2012) The director Jon Shenk visits the Maldives, an archipelago of about 1,200 low-lying islands in the Indian Ocean, and follows the efforts of Mohamed Nasheed, above, the countrys president from 2009 to 2012, as he tries to save the nation, a haven for wealthy tourists, from being swallowed by rising seas thought to be caused by global warming. It is in the nature of political leaders, especially in democracies, to be optimistic, to insist that solutions can be found to even the most intractable problems, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Topical, politically engaged documentaries, particularly those made by American filmmakers, share in this tendency, offering implicit reassurance even as they deliver bad news about the state of the world. Mr. Shenks film, presented here by Independent Lens, is buoyant and spirited enough to keep those demons temporarily at bay, Mr. Scott added. It is impossible, while watching it, to root against Mr. Nasheed or to believe that he will fail. But the hope that infuses this movie makes it all the more upsetting to walk out of the theater and contemplate a looming disaster that the worlds leaders seem unable to prevent.

title: Claudio Pizarro: Soccers Best Third-Choice Striker

But look at what follows: dozens upon dozens of killings, some accidental, some the result of a momentary rage, some clearly premeditated. Few of these other killings made the front page or the nightly news, but they add up to a country with a serious gun crisis that needs to be faced squarelyand dealt with by our society.

title: The Ghost of Gun Control

In the late 19th century, after early death claimed her family members one by one, she became convinced that her family was cursed, haunted by the ghosts of those killed by the Winchester repeating rifle. Sarah decided that she had to move out West and begin building a house, which would confuse and trap the ghosts that were haunting her and her family name. She settled in San Jose, Calif., and once construction on her home began, it continued until her death in 1922.

Believe it or not, I still havent changed the phone system in our office that I posted about months ago. I have given up on it for now, moved on to higher priorities. As owners, we concentrate on pleasing our customers and whatever urgent issues arise during the day, and we let other issues  even important ones, sometimes  take a back seat.

Products of the Silver Lake scene in Los Angeles that gave rise to the likes of Silversun Pickups and the bands current tour-mates Local Natives, the dream pop trio of Cameron Parkins, Sarah Chernoff and Max St. John wrote the song nearly two years ago in the early stages of creating their record. It wasnt something that was necessarily intentional, Parkins says, but it was the beginning of summer for us in Los Angeles, and we really wanted to capture the excitement that people have around that time.

title: Video: On the Street, East of West Egg
description: Even F. Scott Fitzgerald could not have imagined the extravagance of Tiffany & Companys Blue Book Ball Thursday night to introduce its collection of jewelry inspired by the jazz age and the new movie version of The Great Gatsby. Tiffany built a blue box over the skating rink at Rockefeller Center, with suspended aerialists and the Tiffany Diamond Dancers. The buffets were almost unimaginable. And, a rarity at New York high-profile events, most of the women wore their own dresses and jewels. Many guests were Asian, some in native dress. Tiffanys focus on the era coincides with a forceful trend in mens wear, a 21st-century take on the Gatsby style, bottom row, seen on men passing the stores facade, marked with fountains of tape. On April 17, the store held a reception, bottom left and right, for the new designs, and young people dressed in the spirit. Not to be missed are the windows, each one a glittering gem, by Christopher Young.

title: Now Showing | Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion
description: Peacocking, the preening of fastidiously dressed males of the fashion flock, has been exhaustively documented of late by international street fashion photographers who track willing prey in their natural habitats: outside fashion shows, fabulous parties and glitzy store openings where the rare birds tend to gather. The origin of this dandy species, Beau Brummel (1778-1840), and his fanciful progeny are the subject of the exhibition Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion at the Museum of Art Rhode Island School of Design, opening April 28. The curators, Kate Irvin and Laurie Brewer, from the schools department of costume and textiles, have capitalized on this recent surge of interest in the artistry and craftsmanship of mens wear with their study of clothing and ephemera honoring the aesthetic provocateur. Aided by an archive that includes the personal wardrobe of Richard Merkin, a legendary RISD professor, painter and dandy-in-residence, the curators constructed a thematic, rather than chronological, exploration into what they term the always provocative dandy stance. Delving deeper than the decorative surface, they contrast the social subversion of dandy revolutionaries, who express political views through their personal wardrobes, with a dandy historians appreciation of tailoring tradition, while a connoisseur prides self-expression over societal conformity. Thom Browne says in the accompanying catalogs preface that Rebellion comes from being perfectly comfortable doing my own thing and having the drive to make challenging statements in mens wear. According to the curators, by kicking at the boundaries of taste, the dandy is indeed much more than the commonly criticized superficial person devoted only to the outer shell.

title: No-Interest Card Offers Making a Comeback
description: Recently, I got something in the mail that I havent seen in awhile: an offer of a credit card with a zero percent introductory rate that stretched for 18 months  for both new purchases and balance transfers.

title: Really? An Occasional Drink Is O.K. During Pregnancy
description: THE FACTS:

title: How the F.B.I. Trails Terrorists
description: The Timess Michael Schmidt on how the F.B.I. pursues terrorism leads, like the 2011 inquiry about Tamerlan Tsarnaev.

title: Return of the the Fly Room; Time, Explained
description: PERFORMANCE

title: Two Archbishops Are Kidnapped Outside  Northern Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Two Syrian archbishops from Aleppo were abducted on Monday while traveling outside that besieged northern city, the official news media and antigovernment activists reported, making them the most senior church clerics to become entangled as victims in the two-year-old civil war.

title: Criminal Complaint Against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev
description: One of the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing was charged.

title: Linking Stress to Diabetes and Heart Disease
description: High levels of cortisol  the so-called stress hormone  have been associated with cardiovascular disease in some studies, but not in others. This may be because measuring cortisol in blood or saliva at one point in time may pick up acute stress, but it fails to account for long-term stress.

title: Another Scourge in His Sights
description: CHICAGO  In his home office, Dr. Donald R. Hopkins has statues of the Hindu smallpox goddess and the Yoruba smallpox god. And, floating coiled up in a glass jar, something that looks like a yardlong strand of capellini but is actually one of the last Guinea worms on earth.

title: Met Opera Announces Outdoor Performances
description: The Metropolitan Opera released the performers, dates and places on Monday for the free park recitals it sponsors every summer in lieu of full-scale opera performances, which were suspended after 2007 because of the cost. The soprano Erin Morley, the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard and the tenor Stephen Costello, accompanied by the pianist Bradley Moore, will sing at Central Parks SummerStage on July 16 and at Brooklyn Bridge Park on July 19.

title: North Carolina Man Tied to Gun Left in Hotel Lobby
description: The man who inadvertently set off a sweeping police investigation when he hid his pistol under a cushion in a World Trade Center hotel lobby  minutes before the Boston Marathon bombing  was a tourist simply in a hurry to stow it and get back to his tour group, a relative said on Monday.

title: In Performance: Michael Urie
description: In Buyer & Cellar, Michael Urie plays Alex, an actor who works in Barbra Streisands basement, and Barry, his boyfriend whos worked up about the stars relationship to her hometown, Brooklyn.

title: Kik, a Messaging App, Raises Additional $19.5 Million
description: Kik, a popular mobile messaging app that also lets people share videos, drawings and voice messages, just got a little more gas in the tank for its race against rivals like WhatsApp, GroupMe, MessageMe and Facebook Messenger.

title: The Ease of Stir-Fry
description: In Whats for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diners Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: MOCA Gala
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Earthquake Response and Political Tensions Return to the Spotlight
description: The challenges continue for Chinas new leadership.

title: Strike Grounds Most Lufthansa Flights
description: PARIS  A widespread strike all but grounded the German flag carrier Lufthansa on Monday, affecting around 150,000 passengers around the world amid a battle over wages as the airline pushes ahead with a $2 billion restructuring program.

title: Therapy for the Golden Years, Crowdsourced Canines, Mind Games
description: Abby Ellin on the increasing numbers of older people turning up in therapy, Carl Zimmer on an effort to see why Spot runs or fetches or ignores you, and David Dobbs on how play contributes to human success.

title: Creating Youphoria the Nordstrom Way
description: Nordstrom, the conservative, upscale Seattle-based retailer, is going after a younger, hipper customer with a new, quirky regional online brand campaign.

title: A New Look
description: You may notice that we have something of a new look: A man holding semaphore flags at the top of the page to replace the caricature of me that was created by the artist Christoph Neimann when we started the blog in November, 2011. That icon  my kids called it Lego Andy  served well when the only writers for the blog were Juliet Lapidos and myself, but now more members of the editorial board are contributing regularly.

title: Fill-In | The Enduring Romance of Super Mario
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first nine paragraphs of the article The Enduring Romance of Super Mario by Alex Vadukul.

title: How Therapy Can Help in the Golden Years
description: Marvin Tolkin was 83 when he decided that the unexamined life wasnt worth living. Until then, it had never occurred to him that there might be emotional issues he wanted to explore with a counselor.

title: S.&P. Seeks Dismissal of U.S. Suit Over Rating of Mortgage Debt
description: 7:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Nollywood: Censored at Home, Available on the Internet
description: Nigerias movie industry  often dubbed Nollywood  has been a source of pride and escape for years for many of Nigerias 160 million residents.But the recent banning of a Nigerian documentary on corruption and the countrys oil wealth, Fuelling Poverty, has left many crying foul.

title: Trucking Industry Is Set to Expand Its Use of Natural Gas
description: The natural gas boom has already upended the American power industry, displacing coal and bringing consumers cheaper electricity.

title: Obama to Attend Memorial Service for Victims of Texas Blast
description: President Obama will attend a memorial service this week for the victims of the fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., in what will be his latest foray as the countrys comforter in chief.

title: Deficits Fall in Europe, but Debt Rises
description: PARIS  An austerity push in Europe helped to reduce government budget deficits in 2012 for a fourth consecutive year, official data showed on Monday, but in relation to gross domestic product, national debt burdens grew.

title: Avian Affairs
description: Q. Does bird mating ever cross the species line?

title: Monday Motorsports: Sato Scores Historic IndyCar Victory
description: Takuma Sato scored his first IndyCar Series victory on Sunday with a strong performance at the Toyota Grand Prix in Long Beach, Calif. Sato, whose previous best finish was as the runner-up at Edmonton last year, is the first Japanese driver to win in the Indy car racing series. The victory was also the first for A.J. Foyts racing team since 2002.

title: When Is a Chimp Not a Chimp?
description: Up there on my totally mundane list of repeat New Years resolutions each year, right after drink more water, is listen to more podcasts. I know theres great stuff happening out there in podcastland  I just havent succeeded in carving out a regular place in my schedule for exploring it. The subway is too loud and my headphones are too weak for podcasts to join me on my commute, and if I took podcasts on my runs, theyd prevent me from enjoying shouted snippets of conversations from passing cyclists in fancy spandex.

title: The Small Picture: Delivering the Goods
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Gingers Youthful Adventures
description: Most of us know fresh ginger as that thick-skinned, aggressively spicy little fist in the winter greenmarket, or that shrunken knob in the crisper drawer of the refrigerator. But in April and May, if you look hard enough, youll discover a whole new root: spring ginger.

title: Fukushima Plant Operator Should Prepare Better, U.N. Watchdog Says
description: TOKYO  The operator of Japans stricken Fukushima nuclear plant should stop relying on stopgap measures and better prepare for the unexpected, the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency said Monday, even as a cooling system at the plant was once again shut down because of a dead rat.

title: Cassava and Mental Deficits
description: Konzo, a disease that comes from eating bitter cassava that has not been prepared properly  that is, soaked for days to break down its natural cyanide  has long been known to cripple children.

title: Rushdie on the Midnights Children Script: If I Want to Hack Stuff Out, Ill Hack Stuff Out
description: Salman Rushdies sprawling novel Midnights Children, published in 1981, tells the story of Saleem Sinai, a boy born at the stroke of midnight on Aug. 15, 1947, the very moment when India gained independence from British rule. The books many characters, elements of magical realism (Saleem can telepathically communicate with other children born at the same time), and vast spatial and temporal canvas have made it notoriously difficult to film. The BBC had planned an adaptation in the 1990s, and before that producers involved with Richard Attenboroughs Academy Award-winning biopic Gandhi had approached Mr. Rushdie about a possible movie version. The movie will finally make it to the screen on Friday, written by none other than Mr. Rushdie. During a recent interview, he talked about the experience of turning his own novel into a screenplay. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Two Are Accused in Canada of Plotting Train Derailment
description: OTTAWA  The Royal Canadian Mounted Police on Monday announced the arrest of two men who are accused of planning to derail a passenger train in an Al Qaeda-linked plot.

title: Redefining a Little Library
description: He browsed the books like a giant looking for something to read. Some were small enough to fit into a fold of his hand. Many of the books were illegibly small, and he didnt know what they were all about. But reading them was never the point.

title: City Says It Will Represent Officer in Occupy Protesters Lawsuit
description: Following a decision by the Manhattan district attorney not to prosecute a police commander for his actions at Occupy Wall Street protests in 2011, the city said on Monday that it was now in a position to represent him in a federal civil lawsuit.

title: The Lies We Tell in the Exam Room
description: Soon, medical practice will be practically perfect.

title: Playing for All Kinds of Possibilities
description: When it comes to play, humans dont play around.

title: Father and Son and Aspergers
description: When John Elder Robison was teaching his young son, Cubby, the finer points of etiquette almost two decades ago, he noted that in addition to please and thank you, its nice to include a salutation while making a request.

title: Ratings War Zone Is a Rough Place to Start the Day
description: Brian Stelters book on the nefarious network morning show wars ends up being like a breakfast made not quite to order.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Amazon Pilots, and Facebook in Iowa
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Ralph Lauren Corp. Agrees to Pay Fine in Bribery Case
description: The clothing retailer Ralph Lauren has agreed to pay about $1.6 million to resolve charges that it made illegal payments and gifts to foreign officials, including perfume, dresses and handbags, in the latest case highlighting the governments aggressive crackdown on overseas bribery by American companies.

title: Nest Labs Reaches for a New Market
description: Even before Nest Labs unveiled its first product in October 2011, the start-up had a strong trailing wind of Silicon Valley buzz.

title: No E-Mail Response? Life Goes On
description: This past Saturday, I wrote my Shortcuts column on why people dont respond to e-mails. And boy, did I get a lot of responses. Clearly many readers out there are fuming over their in-boxes.

title: A&E Networks Chooses Programmer as New Chief
description: The A&E Networks on Monday promoted Nancy Dubuc, one of the most successful programmers in cable television, to become its next chief executive, overseeing channels like A&E, History and Lifetime.

title: Matilda Opens Big at Broadway Box Office
description: The new Broadway musical Matilda, which arrived from London this spring with exceedingly high expectations  and opened April 11 to some of the best reviews of the season  joined the million-dollar club of top-selling shows last week with a gross of $1,129,419, according to box office data provided by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The show, based on the Roald Dahl childrens novel about a young girl persevering against cruel parents and a sadistic headmistress, sold nearly $2 million in tickets the day after opening and now has advance sales totaling nearly $20 million.

title: Rage After Child Rape in India
description: Protesters besieged police headquarters in New Delhi, outraged by reports of the rape and torture of a 5-year-old girl.

title: More Than 180 Dead After Nigerian Military and Insurgents Clash in Village
description: DAKAR, Senegal  One of the deadliest clashes between Islamist insurgents and security forces in northern Nigeria has destroyed much of a fishing town on the shore of Lake Chad, killed more than 180 people and highlighted the brutal tactics of Nigerian soldiers in combating the nearly four-year uprising.

title: Transcript of the Boston Bombing Suspects Bedside Hearing
description: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, was charged in a criminal complaint and appeared before a federal magistrate who came to his bedside at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center

title: The Boston Case, From Many Angles
Concept Cars From the Shanghai Auto Show
description: International motor shows offer some of the best opportunities for auto manufacturers to strut their stuff, both in terms of what is and what could be. In the latter vein, the worlds car designers showed off an impressive array of bold-looking concepts at the Shanghai auto show over the weekend, bringing revered nameplates back to life in modern skin and introducing wild new ideas that could someday become automotive norms.

title: At the Coachella Music and Arts Festival
description: Looks from the second weekend of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

title: This Tablets Top Attraction? Its $80 Price.
description: If youre not sure that you need a tablet, $200 is a lot to spend just to find out. But Ematic has reduced the risk with the Genesis Prime, a 7-inch Android tablet computer that lists for $80.

title: Thoughts on the Boston Lockdown
description: For about thirty minutes late on Friday, during a slightly shamefaced press conference announcing that the authorities had shut down all of Boston to catch a teenage fugitive and then failed to catch him, it looked like there might be a modest media backlash against the decision to put an entire American metropolis on lockdown to hunt a single bomber. But thenDzhokhar Tsarnaev was spotted in a backyard boat, the police and Feds accepted the applause of a grateful city, and the conversation turned swiftly to Miranda rights, radical Islam, and how the press covered the whole grisly affair.

title: Q&A: Replacing a Dead Drive
description: Q.

title: Shrinking Europe Military Spending Stirs Concern
description: BRUSSELS  Alarmed by years of cuts to military spending, the NATO secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, issued a dire public warning to European nations, noting that together they had slashed $45 billion, or the equivalent of Germanys entire military budget, endangering the alliances viability, its mission and its relationship with the United States.

title: In Parents Embrace, Infants Heart Rates Drop
description: New mothers quickly learn that babies quiet down when carried and rocked. Now researchers say that this calming response is actually a coordinated set of reactions, involving the nervous, motor and cardiac systems.

title: Q. and A.: The Senate Immigration Bill
description: On Friday, the Senate Judiciary Committee began hearings on a sweeping bill to overhaul the immigration system. The 844-page bill includes a pathway to citizenship for immigrants here illegally, new border security measures, a mandatory nationwide system to verify the legal status of newly hired workers, two new guest worker programs and a host of changes to the legal immigration system.

title: Carrying a Torch for Pure Academic Ballet
description: LONDON  Alexei Ratmanskys production of the three-act Prokofiev ballet Romeo and Juliet is engaging for both its individual and ensemble choreography, lively in its storytelling and visually attractive, with discreetly traditional Renaissance settings. It had its premiere in Toronto in 2011 with the National Ballet of Canada, which last week danced it at Sadlers Wells Theater here with four casts of lovers. Of the six versions I have seen by choreographers alive today, this is much the best.

title: Section 15: The Happy Arena
description: Wonder why everyone is so friendly at the Barclays Center? Ushers went through hospitality training from Disney professionals.

title: Amazon Broadens Its Terrain
description: David Blum does not have a regular table at the Four Seasons or host celebrity parties at the top of the Standard Hotel.

title: Original Pilots, Judged by the Masses
description: Amazon delivered its first bundle of original content on Friday, pilots for eight comedies (and six childrens shows) that could become series on Amazon Instant Video. The digital twist is that not only can the public see these pilots, but it can also rate and review them, information Amazon says it will weigh in deciding which series are made.

title: Subtly Married Flavors
description: The Staatskapelle Dresden, which played at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Friday evenings, is an orchestra with a great history and reputation, but it has never appeared in the United States often enough to become really familiar here.

title: A Star, Vital and Vulnerable
description: Of todays pop stars, Kesha is the most irregular, the most collaged  it can seem as if she were made from factory-overrun parts. And her talent is purposefully slack. She can sing and rap and do plenty of other things well, but shed rather hide behind a lecherous sneer and a snotty attitude, projecting a sense that things might fall apart at any moment, just as they should.

title: Serving Up a Spectrum of Chopin: Preludes, Ballades, Mazurkas, tudes
description: Some artists are almost universally admired, while others evoke wildly different reactions in listeners. The Italian pianist Maurizio Pollini has long conjured a disparate response: Some hear profundity in his work, others dispassion.

title: Building A Mystery
description: Jared Bernstein shakes his head at what he calls weirdness at the Washington Post, citing an editorial and a commentary by Robert Samuelson. I second his views, but Id like to point out something else about Samuelsons piece.

title: Study Charts 2,000 Years of Continental Climate Changes
description: A comprehensive new analysis of temperature changes over the continents through 2,000 years has found that a long slide in temperatures in most regions preceded the unusual global warming of recent decades, but with a lot of regional variability and other fascinating details. A National Science Foundation news release has ample background.

title: Wanted: Mistresses, Must Be Married
description: Among Offenbachs many operettas La Prichole is generally considered his most charming. Well, charming is not the word to describe the director Christopher Aldens new production for the New York City Opera, which opened on Sunday afternoon at City Center. Its zany, demented, surreal, strangely dark  anything but charming.

title: No Comment Necessary: Mark Sanfords Ad
description: Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina best known for disappearing in 2009 to hike the Appalachian trail (actually to go on vacation with his mistress), was never going to have an easy time getting elected to Congress. But his job prospects dimmed considerably last week when allegations came to light that hed trespassed on his ex-wifes property.

title: Game Theory: Jane Austen Had It First
description: Its not every day that someone stumbles upon a major new strategic thinker during family movie night. But thats what happened to Michael Chwe, an associate professor of political science at the University of California, Los Angeles, when he sat down with his children some eight years ago to watch Clueless, the 1995 romantic comedy based on Jane Austens Emma.

title: New Albums from Phoenix and Boney James
description: PHOENIX

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photos from China, India, Boston and Bhutan.

title: Internet Sales Tax Bill Gains Ground in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  It has been labeled a tax grab and a bureaucratic nightmare by conservative antitax activists, an infringement on states rights and a federal encroachment on the almost-sacred ground of Internet commerce.

title: In China, Breathing Becomes a Childhood Risk
description: BEIJING  The boys chronic cough and stuffy nose began last year at the age of 3. His symptoms worsened this winter, when smog across northern China surged to record levels. Now he needs his sinuses cleared every night with saltwater piped through a machines tubes.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Budget Deficit
description: For four years, during and in the wake of the recession, the federal budget deficit ballooned to more than $1 trillion. But because of belt-tightening in Washington and a strengthening economy, it has started shrinking  and fast.

title: In San Antonio, Viva la Fiesta!
description: Texans love to boast about the republic they enjoyed after divorcing Mexico, but no place celebrates the six flags over the state quite the way San Antonio does. The city has started its celebration of its history called Fiesta, whose signature event is the Battle of the Flowers parade on Friday.

title: The Best of Newsgaming at the Editors Lab
description: This past weekends Editors Lab at the Times building was a lot of good fun  and it produced a lot of great work.

title: Flights Delayed Across Country Amid Budget-Cut Furloughs of Air Controllers
description: WASHINGTON  Flights were delayed by up to two hours across the country on Monday, the first weekday that the nations air traffic control system operated with 10 percent fewer controllers. Pilots, gate agents and others were quick to blame furloughs caused by mandatory across-the-board budget cuts, but the Federal Aviation Administration said it was too soon to tell.

title: Architects Announce Opposition to MoMA Plan for Former Museum Site
description: Richard Meier, Thom Mayne, Steven Holl, Hugh Hardy and Robert A.M. Stern are among the prominent architects who on Monday called for the Museum of Modern Art to reconsider its decision to demolish the former home of the American Folk Art Museum.

title: A Bears Brain Surgery, Babies Consciousness and More
description: Youre up in space  weightless  with a wet washcloth. What will happen when you wring it out?

title: Boston Attack Shows Need for Immigration Overhaul, Ryan Says
description: CHICAGO  Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, said on Monday that he did not believe the Boston Marathon bombings should prevent immigration overhaul talks from moving forward in Washington.

title: Building Beauty at Auction
description: Next month Rizzoli will publish the interior designer Michael S. Smiths fourth book, Building Beauty: The Alchemy of Design, a vividly illustrated tour through his process of decorating a Malibu, Calif., beachfront property.

title: Protests Against Same-Sex Marriage Bill Intensify in France
description: PARIS  On Tuesday afternoon, France is expected to become the 14th country to legalize marriage for all couples, regardless of gender or sexual orientation.

title: Italian President, Starting Second Term, Deplores Impasse
description: ROME  As President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy was sworn in for a second term on Monday, he used his inaugural address to scold Italys bickering political parties for creating the impasse that led to his re-election.

title: Turkey Criticizes Kerry Over Request to Postpone Visit to Gaza
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey chastised Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday, describing his request that its prime minister postpone a visit to the Palestinian territory of Gaza as a display of arrogance. The Turkish criticism signaled resilient tensions in the friendly relationship with the United States and suggested that the Gaza visit would proceed.

title: Mets Add to Pitching Corps
description: The Mets signed the right-hander D.J. Mitchell to a minor league contract, the team announced Monday.

title: Greek Basketballs Adopted Son Ponders Major Goodbye
description: ATHENS  Vlado Jankovic feels more at home on the Panionios basketball court than other players. On walls of the tiny arena are images of his father, Slobodan Jankovic, who was known as Boban and who was paralyzed in a fluke accident in a game 20 years ago. Fans still sing songs about Boban at each game.

title: U.S. and China Put Focus on Cybersecurity
description: BEIJING  The United States and China held their highest-level military talks in nearly two years on Monday, with a senior Chinese general pledging to work with the United States on cybersecurity because the consequences of a major cyberattack may be as serious as a nuclear bomb.

title: More Fliers May Qualify for Security Shortcuts
description: THE other day I blurted out during a radio interview that I hate to travel, which is admittedly a fairly odd statement given that I have been writing about travel here for more than 14 years.

title: That Coconut Scent, No Bikini Required
description: SINCE being introduced in 1969, the sun care brand Hawaiian Tropic has struck a chord with more than its share of adolescent boys. Miss Hawaiian Tropic bikini pageants, for example, began in 1983, while the 1995 DVD Playboy: The Girls of Hawaiian Tropic, Naked in Paradise, dispensed with swimwear altogether. And from 2006 to 2010, the Hawaiian Tropic Zone near Times Square, featuring waitresses in bikinis, called itself the hottest place on earth.

title: Alfredo Guevara Valds, 87, Steward of Cuban Cinema and Castro Ally, Dies
description: HAVANA  Alfredo Guevara Valds, a Marxist intellectual and ally of Fidel Castro who presided over Cubas powerful state-financed film industry and its many acclaimed movies for much of the Castro era, died here on Friday. He was 87.

title: Boeing Team Begins Repairs of 787 Dreamliner Batteries
description: Teams of Boeing engineers and technicians began fanning out across the globe on Monday to modify the battery systems of the companys 50 grounded 787 Dreamliner jets to expedite getting the planes back in the air.

title: A Presidential Pat for Young Scientists
description: Praising the work of young scientists and inventors at the third White House Science Fair, President Obama on Monday announced a broad plan to create and expand federal and private-sector initiatives designed to encourage children to study science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

title: Twitter Signs Lucrative Deal With Advertising Agency
description: Twitter continued its march into the advertising world with the news on Monday that the social media company had signed a deal with one of the largest advertising agencies in the world, the Starcom MediaVest Group, part of Publicis Groupe.

title: German Soccer Hero Faces Prison Amid Record Run and Scandal
description: BERLIN  To say Uli Hoeness led a charmed life does not do him justice.

title: Robert Earl Holding, Wide-Ranging Entrepreneur, Dies at 86
description: Robert Earl Holding, a Western entrepreneur who made his first fortune in the 1950s running a 24-hour service station in an otherwise desolate stretch of Wyoming and became a billionaire whose assets included oil refineries and ski slopes, among them Sun Valley Resort in Idaho, died last Friday in Salt Lake City. He was 86.

title: How Writers Interact With the World
description: The image has been handed down throughout the long iconography of the West, most effectively transmitted in the image of Saint Jerome: the writer as a recluse, weaving spirited collocations of words in hushed seclusion. Jerome may have a lion at his feet, but he lacks other company  and, of course, he has no Wi-Fi. His condition is distinctly different from that of the modern writer; her room is not only well-lighted and likely lion-free, but also furnishes an Internet connection, through which the worlds tumult pours.

title: Subscribers Help Propel Netflix Gain
description: When Ted Sarandos, the chief content officer for Netflix, told GQ in an interview published three months ago that the goal is to become HBO faster than HBO can become us, maybe he was on to something.

title: Rutgers Hires Eddie Jordan as Coach
description: Rutgers is set to introduce Eddie Jordan as the universitys new basketball coach on Tuesday, less than a month after the former coach Mike Rice was fired after video of him abusing his players  including shouting homophobic slurs at them and throwing balls at them  was broadcast on television and on the Internet.

title: Fed Still Owes Congress a Blueprint on Its Emergency Lending
description: After the Federal Reserve lent more than $1 trillion to big banks during the 2008 financial crisis, Congress required the central bank to devise specific ways of protecting taxpayers when doling out emergency loans to financial institutions.

title: Co-Directors for S.E.C. Signal Shift
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ushered in a new era of leadership on Monday, appointing a former federal prosecutor turned defense lawyer to help run the unit that polices the front lines of financial fraud.

title: Only an Accident
description: JUST after lunch break one infernal Houston afternoon in 1995, I slammed the door of the company truck, cranked the engine, and punched the gas so hard that the truck fishtailed onto Jensen Drive. Beside me sat my co-worker Charlie. In his lap, he clenched a blood-drenched wad of paper towels over what had been, minutes before, his left thumb. The severed thumb, packed hurriedly on ice in a cup, rode in the center console.

title: Breaking Laws and Fighting Fire Ants in a Rush to the Texas Bluebonnet Fields
description: CHAPPELL HILL, Tex.  It is bluebonnet season in Texas, when hayfields and grazing pastures are transformed into seas of indigo bloom. And while Vermonters take pride in their fall foliage and Washingtonians love their cherry blossoms, Texans can be near fanatical about bluebonnets, sometimes ignoring property laws and personal safety to wade into their fragrant midst.

title: Revis Calls Trade to Bucs a Blessing
description: Cornerback Darrelle Revis met John Idzik, the Jets new general manager, for the first time April 15, and a few days later, they had a more substantial conversation. It was then, Revis said, that, contrary to months of informed speculation otherwise, Idzik said that the Jets wanted to keep him.

title: Coverage of Boston Manhunt Delivers High Ratings to CNN
description: Despite some critical reviews of its performance during coverage of the manhunt to find the perpetrators of the bombing at the Boston Marathon, CNN attracted one of its biggest audiences in a decade to its all-day reporting on Friday.

title: New Mexico Horse Meat Facility Moves a Step Closer to Operation
description: Amid the unfolding horse-meat scandal, a New Mexico slaughterhouse has moved closer to becoming the first in the United States since 2007 to be allowed to process horses for human consumption.

title: Granderson Rejoins Yanks for Day; His Return to Action Will Take Longer
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Curtis Granderson was back with his teammates Monday in the Yankees clubhouse at Tropicana Field. It was the first time he had been with them since he said goodbye March 28 when the team broke camp. But Granderson still has several hurdles to clear before he can rejoin his teammates permanently.

title: Immigrant Kids, Adrift
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Confidence Questions
description: By now, many of you have seen the main Web video in the Dove Real Beauty campaign. It shows a police sketch artist sitting behind a curtain. He interviews women he cant see about their own faces and he draws them, based on their descriptions. Then he asks other people to describe the faces of those same women and makes another sketch.

title: Malicious but Delicious
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Children Facing Deportation
description: To the Editor:

title: Do the Police Belong in Our Public Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Confirmation Too Long Delayed
description: The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to hold a long-overdue vote on Tuesday on President Obamas nominee to lead the embattled agency responsible for overseeing Medicare, Medicaid and the implementation of health care reforms. The committee ought to set aside its deep partisan divisions and unanimously endorse Marilyn Tavenner to be the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. The full Senate should then confirm her.

title: When Your Name Is Prominent, but You Are Not
description: IVE been flying most of my career. As a musician in the early days, I was flying all the time between New York and Los Angeles, and then I started working with Jim Henson and I was adding London into the mix.

title: The Year in Hacking, by the Numbers
description: Security experts like to say that there are now only two types of companies left in the United States: those that have been hacked and those that dont know theyve been hacked.

title: Justices Weigh Conditions in Awarding U.S. Grants
description: WASHINGTON  The question for the Supreme Court on Monday was whether groups receiving federal money to combat AIDS abroad may be required to adopt policies opposing prostitution. The answer, judging from the justices comments in the first half of the argument, seemed to be that the First Amendment bars attaching that kind of condition to federal grants.

title: Free Speech and an Anti-Prostitution Pledge
description: A 2003 federal statute, called the United States Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Act, finances a wide range of public health initiatives to treat and prevent disease around the world.

title: The Smart Trend in Hotels
description: At the InterContinental Miami hotel, guests in the lobby can call up the drink menu and flag down a server to order using a touch screen on the coffee tables. The Park Hyatt Tokyo and Park Hyatt Seoul give guests free access to over 2,300 international newspapers on their smartphones or tablets using the hotels Wi-Fi network and an app called PressReader.

title: More Help for Syrian Rebels
description: There was more horror in Syria over the weekend, where scores of bodies, most of them civilians, were discovered in a Damascus suburb. The victims are believed to have died in a weeklong offensive by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, who seems to have no misgivings whatever about a slaughter, including the use of airstrikes and missiles, that has claimed more than 70,000 lives so far during two-and-a-half years of war.

title: State Department Criticized by E.P.A. on Pipeline Report
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency sharply criticized the State Departments impact statement for the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline, saying the report failed to adequately consider the climate change impacts of building the pipeline or to realistically assess alternative pipeline routes or modes of transport.

title: Dropping the Ball
Credit History Discrimination
description: People fall behind on their bills for many reasons  a recession that costs them jobs, a divorce, an illness. Now comes a further obstacle to getting their lives in order: employers who screen job applicants based on credit histories.

title: In Gun Bill Defeat, a Presidents Distaste for Twisting Arms
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska, asked President Obamas administration for a little favor last month. Send your new interior secretary this spring to discuss a long-simmering dispute over construction of a road through a wildlife refuge, Mr. Begich asked in a letter. The administration said yes.

title: Stern Words, and a Pea-Size Punishment, for Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Regulators in Germany, one of the most privacy-sensitive countries in the world, unleashed their wrath on Google on Monday for scooping up sensitive personal information in the Street View mapping project, and imposed the largest fine ever assessed by European regulators over a privacy violation.

title: Day Centers Sprout Up, Luring Fit Elders and Costing Medicaid
description: Scores of elderly Russian immigrants played bingo under the chandeliers of a former funeral parlor in Brooklyn on a recent Monday, with a free dinner and door-to-door transportation from anywhere in the city.

title: Celtics List of Things to Improve Has a Bit of Everything
description: From Paul Pierces perspective, the Celtics need to do a lot of things better. Pierce did not say the Celtics should panic after losing Game 1 of their best-of-seven series with the Knicks, 85-78, on Saturday. But he said that in order to win Game 2 on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Celtics needed to learn from their mistakes.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Apr. 23, 2013
description: I just woke up to the fact that I have a mind of my own. Talk about a late bloomer.

title: China: Prison for Preachers
description: The Chinese authorities have sentenced to prison seven underground church leaders who were arrested last April and charged with belonging to an illegal cult, according to a Christian rights group. The preachers, who officiated illegal Pentecostal congregations in Henan Province, were given terms from three to seven-and-a-half years, according to court documents released by ChinaAid, a Texas-based group. The verdicts were issued by the Ye County Peoples Court on April 1, but lawyers for the four women and three men said they were not notified until last week.

title: Officials Say They Had No Authority to Watch Older Suspect
description: WASHINGTON  Amid questions about whether the F.B.I. missed an opportunity to discover that one of the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings may have become an extremist, law enforcement officials defended their actions on Monday, saying they had no legal basis to monitor him in the months leading up to the attack.

title: Shrovetide: Beauty in Eye of Beholder
description: The beautiful game was, and is not always, beautiful.

title: A Watchdog That Isnt Watched
description: At the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs Business Integrity Commission holds a czars sway over a sometimes unruly 113-acre operation.

title: Their Home Is a Castle, Like It or Not
description: AMSTERDAM, N.Y.  Susan Phemister assumed it would be easy to flip a castle.

title: For Sale: Castle, Mint, Moatless
description: A couple renovates a castle in upstate New York but has had to slash the price below $1 million.

title: In Tax Fight, Amazon Hands Baton to eBay
description: Lets rename it the eBay loophole.

title: For Wounded, Daunting Cost; for Aid Fund, Tough Decisions
description: WASHINGTON  For victims of the Boston Marathon bombings, the terrible physical cost may come with a daunting financial cost as well.

title: A Changed Smith Gets Sixth Man Honor
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Corrections: April 23, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Sat on a Wall, Had a Great Fall, Then Took a Bow
description: Suspense is not a selling point for Mayday Mayday, a solo show written and performed by the English actor Tristan Sturrock that opened on Monday night at St. Anns Warehouse. Although uncertainty as to how the narrative will turn out is generally considered a good thing at the theater, thats definitely not the case here.

title: With a Vulture but No Angels
description: Just let the woman speak, for pitys sake.

title: After Long Playoff Wait, Warriors Experience Is Brief
description: To his credit, David Lee is not using the word cursed. Lee, the All-Star power forward for the Golden State Warriors, tore his right hip flexor in Saturdays Game 1 loss to the Denver Nuggets, a quick ending to the first playoff appearance of his career. But he is trying to maintain a positive attitude about his misfortune.

title: Some Call It Pop
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I grew up in one of the most cosmopolitan towns in the world, New York City, and thought I had heard everything until I went off to college in upstate New York. They speak an entirely different language up there, and it soon became apparent to me that I was going to get myself in trouble if I ventured out without someone who was willing to translate for me. SODA became pop, sprinkles on ice cream became jimmies (I misheard that one, and assumed that the young man asking me if I wanted jimmies just had an odd, third-person way of coming on to women), and Im sure there were more that Im forgetting. My point is, never send your kids off to school in another region without a dictionary.

title: Hundreds Gather at Services Held for Marathon Victims
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  With the horror of the Boston Marathon bombings a week in the past, two communities carved out space for quiet remembrance on Monday, bidding farewell to Krystle Campbell and Lu Lingzi, the two young women claimed by the blasts at the races finish line.

title: Richie Havens, Folk Singer Who Riveted Woodstock, Dies at 72
description: Richie Havens, who marshaled a craggy voice, a percussive guitar and a soulful sensibility to play his way into musical immortality at Woodstock in 1969, improvising the song Freedom on the fly, died on Monday at his home in Jersey City. He was 72.

title: Victims Call on Horace Mann for Inquiry
description: Jon Seiger said he was abused by eight teachers at Horace Mann, the elite Riverdale preparatory school, while he was a student there in the 1970s. Ron Klepper said he was abused so often that he was too frightened to go to school. Edward Bowen said he drank and took drugs for years, trying to escape the memories of his abuse at the hands of a music teacher. Daniel Shapiro said he had spent 35 years believing he was alone in being abused.

title: Kings Seek Repeat of Late-Season Magic
description: LOS ANGELES  Hours before the Los Angeles Kings clinched a playoff berth Saturday, General Manager Dean Lombardi leaned back against a locker room stall and put his hands behind his head and his feet up to shoot the breeze about baseball.

title: His Own Man Now
description: Vlado Jankovic was 3 when his father, Boban, was paralyzed while playing for Panionios. After his fathers death, Jankovic became the star of Panionios, and the neighborhood embraced him.

title: Tenants Seek to Void Deal With Owner Over Rents
description: A major settlement between rent-regulated tenants and a large New York City landlord may be at risk after some of the tenants complained that they were not eligible for millions of dollars in compensation.

title: Agent Regrets Abrupt End to Liu Inquiry
description: The federal agent who posed as a businessman in order to investigate the campaign financing of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, said on Monday that his superiors had prematurely ended the undercover operation, even though he felt there were indications that campaign officials were involved in irregularities.

title: Woodson Mentor-Turned-Consultant Has Celtic Roots as Player and Coach
description: BOSTON  In the Knicks current media guide, his name is at the bottom of the basketball staff list, below all the assistants, the advance scouts, a coaching adviser and even the equipment manager.

title: E. L. Konigsburg, Author, Is Dead at 83
description: E. L. Konigsburg, a childrens author and illustrator who twice received the nations highest award in childrens literature  she won it in 1968 for her second book, edging out the runner-up, which was her own first book  died on Friday in Falls Church, Va. She was 83.

title: In Questions at First, No Miranda for Suspect
description: A senior United States official said Monday that federal authorities invoked a public safety exemption to standard criminal procedures and questioned Dzhokhar Tsarnaev on Sunday without telling him that he had the right to remain silent, in order to learn whether he knew of remaining active threats.

title: At Mayoral Forum, a Focus on the Environment
description: As a sharp-tongued Republican in a liberal stronghold, John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of the Gristedes grocery chain, prides himself on being called a rebel. But he was unusually defiant, even by his standards, at a mayoral forum on environmental sustainability on Monday.

title: In Stop-and-Frisk Trial, Reliance on Memory Hinders Efforts to Get to Truth
description: The two men appeared in quick succession, a police lineup turned on its head. The men were police officers, ordered to a courtroom on Monday so a witness could identify them as the officers who had stopped and frisked him.

title: Gift to Help Cornell Tech School Offer an Innovative Program
description: Cornell Tech, the applied sciences graduate school that Cornell University has planned for Roosevelt Island, has received a gift of $133 million that will help it offer an unusual two-year, two-degree masters program.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 22, 2013

title: Rays Light Hitters Show Pop Against Sabathia While Yankees Bats Fizzle
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  C. C. Sabathia has not pitched very well against the Tampa Bay Rays since he joined the Yankees in 2009. He has won just 3 of his 19 starts against them in that period, and he has been even less successful here at Tropicana Field.

title: Intersection: Bold on Burnside
description: Tiffany Trinidad, a resident of the Bronx and student at the High School of Fashion Industries, draws fashion inspiration from Kanye West and Tumblr.

title: In a Corner of China, Boxings New Frontier
description: Inside the Friars Club, at a table near the back, Bob Arum leaned forward. His eyes widened. His voice rose. Here came another vision, another sell  the next future of boxing, which followed the last next future of boxing, which followed the future of boxing before that  and Arum had seen it, experienced it and planned to capitalize on it.

title: Victims Remembered as Boston Suspect Is Charged
description: Services were held on Monday for two of the marathon bombing victims as the surviving suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, was formally charged.

title: Fighting Out of Corner, the Bulls Prevail in Round 2
description: The festive sounds of fireworks and drums in Saturdays playoff-opening celebration at Barclays Center were replaced on Monday with the slap of a hand across the wrist, the thwack of a body landing firmly on the parquet floor. Forget a sea of blackouts by Nets fans. This was black-and-blue, Chicago Bulls basketball at its gritty best.

title: Boston Symphony Announces New Season
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra on Tuesday disclosed plans next season to tour China and Japan, perform Brittens large-scale War Requiem, present Beethovens five piano concertos with Yefim Bronfman as soloist and put on a concert performance of Salome by Strauss  all without a music director. The orchestra released its programs for 2013-14, which will be the third season since James Levine stepped down as its music director for health reasons after already missing a number of concerts in previous years.

title: Manufacturing Growth Slows in China
description: HONG KONG  Growth in Chinas important factory sector slowed in April, a closely watched monthly index released Tuesday showed, adding to concerns that the pace of overall economic growth in China may be faltering.

title: Word of the Day | linguistic
description: linguistic \liN-gwis-tik\ adjective

title: Game 2: Nets vs. Bulls
description: The Bulls pulled away in the third quarter and held on to beat the Nets to even their best-of-seven playoff series at one game apiece.

title: Prigioni Is Likely to Return; Chandler Says He Feels Fine
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Pablo Prigioni will probably be back in the Knicks starting lineup Tuesday night for Game 2 against the Boston Celtics.

title: Old Sore Spots Flare Up in China-Japan Disputes
description: TOKYO  Japanese lawmakers paid their respects at a shrine to those killed in war, including those executed as war criminals, in what the local news media described as the biggest group visit by Parliament members in recent memory.

title: When Love Marriage Needs a Little Help
description: After decades of fixing arranged marriages for their children, Indian parents are taking on a new challenge: trying to orchestrate their kids love marriages.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) THE RETIREMENT GAMBLE For many Americans, retirement is more dream than reality, with 6 in 10 people believing theyll have to delay retirement; only 14 percent very confident that they will be able to live comfortably once theyve stopped working; and 17 percent believing that they will never retire at all, according to this Frontline episode. In this investigation of the financial services industry, Martin Smith uses his own retirement fund as a case study to look at the rise of the 401(k), the hidden fees and the shady financial advisers that can add years to an employees working life.

title: Campaign Aide Says Bachmann Knew of Payments to State Senator
description: The former chief of staff for the presidential campaign of Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, released an affidavit on Monday describing how Ms. Bachmanns campaign allegedly made payments to an Iowa state senator to work on the campaign.

title: News Quiz | April 23, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Thai Billionaire Offers $6.6 Billion for Discount Retailer
description: HONG KONG  CP All, the Thai operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores owned by the billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont, said on Tuesday that it would pay more than $6 billion to acquire the discount retailer Siam Makro in the biggest takeover announced in Asia this year.

title: Chinas Criticism of U.S. on Human Rights Draws Support (and Mockery)
description: BEIJING  Gun shootings in America are unceasing, how is it qualified to talk about human rights?

title: IHT Quick Read: April 23
description: NEWS Levels of deadly pollutants up to 40 times the recommended exposure limit in Beijing and other cities have struck fear into parents and led them to take steps that are radically altering the nature of urban life for their children. Edward Wong reports from Beijing.

title: Jonas Kaufmann, Nina Stemme Named Best Singers at Opera Awards
description: Nina Stemme and Jonas Kaufmann won the awards for best male singer and best female singer, and the Frankfurt Opera House took the prize for best opera company at the first annual Opera Awards  Monday night. The ceremony was held at the Hilton Park Lane in London.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 23, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the exhibition review Finding Painterly Drama in Lifes Delicate Perch.

title: Cinnamon Challenge Can Damage Lungs
description: In Consequences of the Cinnamon Challenge, Anahad OConnor writes about the very real dangers of the wildly popular dare.

title: Car Explodes Outside French Embassy in Libya
description: CAIRO  A car bomb destroyed about half of the French Embassy in Libya early Tuesday, officials said, in the most significant attack against a Western interest in the country since the killing last September of the American ambassador, J. Christopher Stevens.

title: Israel Says It Has Proof That Syria Has Used Chemical Weapons
description: TEL AVIV  Israel declared Tuesday that it had found evidence that the Syrian government repeatedly used chemical weapons last month, arguing that President Bashar al-Assad was testing how the United States and others would react and that it was time for Washington to overcome its deep reluctance to intervene in the Syrian civil war.

title: Who Says New York Is Not Affordable?
description: One of the first things you learn when living in New York is that what qualifies as wealthy somewhere else seems barely middle-class here. On the Upper West Side, where I live, its hard not to feel as if Manhattan is impossibly expensive for young professionals. The average nondoorman, one-bedroom apartment in the neighborhood rents for about $2,500 a month. Oatmeal-raisin cookies at Levain Bakery cost $4 each. A pair of sensible, unstylish walking flats from Harrys Shoes can set you back $480. I suppose, by comparison, that the $198 chefs menu at Jean-Georges doesnt sound so ridiculous.

title: Protecting the Right to Photograph, or Not to Be Photographed
description: Nick Turpin has run dozens of street photography workshops in Europe, but nothing compares to Paris, where his students are often confronted by furious pedestrians who dont want to be in anyones picture.

title: Do Bystanders Have a Responsibility to Intervene When There is Trouble?
description: Have you ever witnessed someone doing something wrongwhether a bully picking on someone weaker or someone committing a crime? If so, what did you do? Why?

title: Leaving India for the Ivy League
description: After receiving a dream acceptance, I have chosen to enroll at Cornell University. It offered me an excellent financial aid package and has a highly reputed computer science department.

title: A Frank Lloyd Wright House Meets an Old Cadillac
description: Classic cars have a way of getting the rusty pieces of long-dormant memories moving again. The 1966 Cadillac that was the subject of the Auto Ego feature on April 14 did just that for Michael Moran of Evanston, Ill.

title: The Early Word: Lost in Translation
description: Todays Times

title: Why Tim Cook Is Like Steve Ballmer
description: On Monday, Matthew Panzarino of the Next Web, a tech news site, tweeted an ironic message that read Fire Tim Cook!, along with a link to a couple of charts showing the steady upward march of Apples revenue and profit over the last few years.

title: Golds Declining Price Is a Reversion to the Mean
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Remembering Pat Summerall, the Football Player
description: In the spring of 1958, Pat Summerall was at a post office in Lake City, Fla., when he read in the local newspaper that hed been traded to New York. There, he was on a Giants team that played a major role in establishing the popularity of pro football. While he was still playing, he began what turned out to be a 40-year career in broadcasting. Summerall died on April 16 in Dallas from cardiac arrest. He was 82. A few thoughts:

title: Dozens Killed in Battles Across Iraq as Sunnis Escalate Protests Against Government
description: BAGHDAD  Gun battles erupted in cities with Sunni majorities across Iraq on Tuesday after security forces from the Shiite-led government stormed a Sunni protest encampment in a village near the northern city of Kirkuk. The clashes left dozens dead and wounded, and raised fears that the sectarian civil war that is roiling Syria might spill into Iraq.

title: Iran Rejects Canadian Terrorism Charge
description: LONDON  Iran on Tuesday strongly rejected Canadian police assertions that a planned terrorist attack to derail a passenger train was linked to elements of Al Qaeda on its soil, saying there was no shred of evidence to substantiate the claim, reports by Iranian state media said.

title: What They Said: Former Chief Justice Jagdish Sharan Vermas Death
description: Jagdish Sharan Verma, former chief justice of India, passed away on Monday after suffering multiple organ failure. Mr. Verma, 80, served as the 27th chief justice of India from March 25, 1997, until his retirement on Jan. 18, 1998. Having begun his legal career in 1955, he has also served as the chairperson of the National Human Rights Comission and the first chairperson of the News Broadcasting Standards Authority.

title: Why I Pay What I Pay
description: Sometimes, when I sit down to write, I focus on documenting a recent experience. Other times, I think about things that I would like to know about other businesses but have never seen publicly discussed. This post is the latter. Its about how business owners decide what to pay their employees.

title: Credit Suisse Sells Private Equity Business to Blackstone
description: LONDON  The Blackstone Group has agreed to buy a private equity business owned by Credit Suisse.

title: Daily Report: Europes Biggest Privacy Fine Is Pocket Change to Google
description: Regulators in Germany, one of the most privacy-sensitive countries in the world, unleashed their wrath on Google on Monday for scooping up sensitive personal information in the Street View mapping project and imposed the largest fine ever assessed by European regulators over a privacy violation, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

title: Should Sunday Become Sun Day?
description: On Earth Day, NASA released a stunning video view of three years of activity on the Sun recorded by the Solar Dynamics Observatory satellite. This imagery, speaking both of the stability and turbulence of the star that makes life here possible (and could greatly disrupt it) prompted me to think we should consider a slight shift in the spelling of Sunday  to Sun Day. My Twitter note has the video and my proposal:

title: Q&A: Linking a Samsung Tablet to a TV
description: Q.

title: Cameron Gets Warning From Both Sides
description: LONDON  It may not be every day, or in every land, that the practitioners of the state religion and the national security agencies issue parallel warnings to the prime minister about his handling of the economy, but that is what is happening to David Cameron.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Q. and A.: Whoopi Goldberg
description: Looks at the lives of Richard Pryor and Gore Vidal, a peek inside the creative process of the Broadway actress Elaine Stritch  several documentaries at this years Tribeca Film Festival focus on notable figures in arts and entertainment. These include a name that may not be as well known but whose cultural impact was significant: Moms Mabley.

title: Salesforce Wants to Remake Marketing  and Itself
description: The head of Salesforce.com has what he hopes will be a major new product. What he really thinks it is about, though, is remaking his company for the age of social media.

title: Bright Passages
description: Sparkling prose, from the Bronx to Paris to the obit page, over just a few days last week.

title: Markets Jump on Hopes for European Action
description: The beleaguered euro zone remains stuck in recession, according to data published Tuesday, increasing pressure on the European Central Bank to find a way to stimulate growth soon.

title: Trap Denial
description: OK, probably going on too much about this, but I want to return briefly to the issue of puzzled economists, specifically Allan Meltzer.

title: EBay Joins Sales Tax Fight
description: It was once Amazon that led a lobbying campaign in Washington to prevent online merchants from having to collect state and municipal sales taxes from customers. Now, eBay has taken up the cause as the issue is moving through Washington in earnest for the first time, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. A bill introducing such a tax cleared a procedural hurdle in the Senate, setting it up for a vote this week.

title: Tuesday Reading: Consequences of the Cinnamon Challenge
Separate but Equal
description: JERUSALEM  The rain didnt deter many observant Jews from visiting the Western Wall on a recent Sunday. And I wasnt surprised to see more men than women, and more Orthodox men than other Jews. After all, the men have the luxury of access to a spacious covered area, where only they can pray, as long as they dont stray from Orthodox customs. Women have a much smaller covered area and on rainy days many are forced to weather the elements.

title: Strangers From Boston
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Folly
description: As I have been writing a lot lately, the clean little secret of the global economic crisis is that standard economic theory actually performed pretty well.

title: Shapeways Raises $30 Million to Bring 3-D Printing Mainstream
description: Three-dimensional printing still largely feels like a novelty or hobbyist technology, best for creating quirky trinkets, fancy desk adornments and pieces of jewelry. The dream that the average person will be able to print out a steak knife, a replacement screw or a new chair at home, as easily as microwaving popcorn  still feels a bit far-fetched.

title: MF Globals Trustee Sues Firms 3 Top Executives
description: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

title: On Repeated Book Reviews and the Hat Trick
description: Its beginning to feel like Nathaniel Rich Month at The Times. The authors new novel was reviewed in the Arts section on April 10, then again in the Sunday Book Review on April 14. Mr. Rich also wrote an essay for the Sunday Book Review, with many references to that novel, Odds Against Tomorrow. In addition, the Editors Choice section of the Sunday Book Review listed Mr. Richs novel second on its list.

title: Horse Doping Scandal Rocks Dubais Rulers
description: LONDON  The horseracing world has been shaken to its fetlocks by revelations of a doping scandal at the top prize-winning Godolphin stable, owned by Dubais ruling Maktoum family.

title: Therapy Can Still Help
description: Older adults appear increasingly willing to seek psychological help, even at advanced ages, Abby Ellin reports in todays Science Times. Therapy no longer carries the same stigma it once did, even among the so-called Greatest Generation, and therapists now discount the idea that people in their 70s and 80s cant change their thinking.

title: Background Checks for Pressure Cookers
description: Republicans get fired up about a terror weapon thats not a gun.

title: Demographics of Homicide and Suicide Victims Reveal Differences
description: More people killed themselves last year in New York City than were murdered, the authorities have said, a consequence of the citys plunging murder rate. A peek behind the numbers reveals some interesting differences.

title: The Gun Vote and 2014: Will There Be an Electoral Price?
description: Did the senators who voted against a proposal last week to expand background checks on gun buyers take an electoral risk?

title: How Chinas Leftover Women Are to Blame
description: BEIJING  Feminists are concerned that some Chinese women in their late 20s who are doing well in their careers but are labeled leftover women for not having married yet, may be their own worst enemies.

title: What Were Reading
description: Food Republic: A hotter oven, a shorter cooking time, a pizza that doesnt dry out: Domenico DeMarco of the legendary DiFara shop in Brooklyn shares a few tips with Americas Test Kitchen.  Patrick Farrell

title: The Dynasty Business
description: Maybe Manchester United winning the Premier League on Monday was a sign. Perhaps big-money off-season acquisition Robin Van Persie scoring a hat trick in the pivotal drubbing of Aston Villa signals that this is the year of the dynasty. This plays on the heartstrings of any hopeful superpower. Maybe the Miami Heat will repeat as N.B.A. champions and not lose a playoff game. Could Duke basketball go undefeated?
