Green Bay win the next three Super Bowls? Perhaps the Yankees can hold themselves together with Ace bandages and Advil and limp their way to a World Series!

title: Baucus, Powerful Montana Democrat, Will Leave Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Under friendly fire in the Capitol and squeezed politically at home, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the powerful chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a man often at odds with fellow Democrats, announced Tuesday that he would retire in 2014 after four decades in Congress.

title: Allan Arbus, Psychiatrist With Zingers on M*A*S*H, Dies at 95
description: Allan Arbus, who left the successful fashion photography business he and his wife, Diane, built to become an actor, most memorably playing the caustic psychiatrist Maj. Sidney Freedman on the hit television series M*A*S*H, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

title: The Gun Report: April 23, 2013
description: The arsenal found with the surviving Boston Marathon bombing suspect upon his arrest Friday included at least four firearms, one of which was an M-4 carbine rifle, a weapon similar to ones used by American forces in Afghanistan, the Times reported Sunday. Together, the Tsarnaev brothers fired about 80 rounds in a shootout with police officers, yet it appears neither brother was licensed to carry firearms.

title: Midsummer Night Swing Announces Lineup
description: This year, the organizers of the Midsummer Night Swing concert series at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center are taking few chances with the program: they have announced a lineup heavy with New Yorks established big bands, including the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, Vince Giordano & the Nighthawks and Arturo OFarrill and the Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra.

title: In Performance: Michael Urie of Buyer & Cellar
description: In Jonathan Tolinss one-man play Buyer & Cellar, Michael Urie plays Alex More, a struggling gay actor who is hired to work in Barbra Streisands Malibu basement. In this scene, Alexs boyfriend, Barry, also played by Mr. Urie, gets worked up about Ms. Streisands relationship with her hometown, Brooklyn. The show continues through May 12 at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

title: Jelly That Outgrew Peanut Butter
description: Rainy days, cool weather and the jet stream are playing havoc with spring. My plans for pickling asparagus and making rhubarb jam have been delayed. But eager to begin canning, I made this jelly from leftover wine.

title: Boeing Acknowledges Tests Underestimated 787 Battery Risks
description: WASHINGTON  Boeing acknowledged on Tuesday that its original tests of the lithium-ion batteries on its 787 planes underestimated the risks of fire, though it defended its previous assessment that such a hazard was extremely unlikely.

title: Decoding Dog Behavior
description: Brian Hare, an associate professor at Duke University, has created a new method to research dog behavior, using the Internet and citizen science.

title: Same-Sex Marriage and the French Family
description: While activists demonstrate over President Franois Hollandes politics, French parents debate the legalization of adoption for gay married couples.

title: In New York City, Cheaper (and Later) Pedicures
description: I have written a column for The New York Times Magazine about the cost of living in New York, which is actually relatively cheap if youre wealthy and have standard wealthy-person tastes. It was based largely on research by Jessie Handbury, an economics professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, which looked at the groceries that rich versus poor people buy, and how much those different bundles of groceries cost in rich versus poor cities.

title: A.T.M. Surcharge Fees on the Rise
description: Anyone who uses A.T.M.s to get cash knows that you usually pay a penalty for using a machine outside your own banks network. A recent government report documents just how much those fees have increased in recent years.

title: Therapy and the Elderly
description: Abby Ellin sits down with The Timess Michael Mason to discuss the increasing number of seniors seeking mental health counseling.

title: Buckets of Blickets: Children and Logic
description: A game developed by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, hopes to show how imaginative play in children may influence development of abstract thought.

title: Reed Krakoff to Go Solo, Leaving Coach Next Year
description: Reed Krakoff will spend another year shepherding both Coach and his own brand and then go solo, he said today.

title: Now Showing | Urs Fischer
description: The artist Urs Fischer may humbly refer to his ambitious exhibition occupying 65,000 square feet of Los Angeles MOCAs two venues as pretty much a sculpture show, but its more than that. Fischer and Jessica Morgan, the Tate Moderns curator, have designed a stunning visual presentation collecting more than 10 years of Fischers artworks into a formal exercise in high contrasts  order built from disarray, precision from destruction  presented through radical scale shifts, disharmonious color schemes and surprisingly cohesive textural oppositions.

title: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
description: The portrait investigators have begun to piece together of the two brothers suspected of the Boston Marathon bombings suggests that they were motivated by extremist Islamic beliefs but were not acting with known terrorist groups  and that they may have learned to build bombs simply by logging onto the online English-language magazine of the affiliate of Al Qaeda in Yemen, law enforcement officials said Tuesday.

title: Republicans Object to Reids Call for Budget Negotiating Committee
description: For nearly two years, Congressional Republicans made the Senates failure to pass a budget plan Exhibit A in their indictment of what they called the Democrats manifest failure to grapple with the governments fiscal misfortunes.

title: Sentencing Postponed in Lauryn Hills Tax Case
description: A federal judge scolded Lauryn Hill on Monday for failing to pay back taxes but put off for two weeks her sentencing for tax evasion, The Associated Press reported.

title: Whats French for Family?
description: Amid an historic and acrimonious debate in France over marriage rights for same-sex couples, Stefania Rousselle profiles two French families on opposite sides.

title: Kitty Carlisle Hart and Kristin Chenoweth on Life in New York
description: Kitty Carlisle Hart and Kristin Chenoweth were interviewed by Ben Brantley after watching the new documentary "Broadway  The Golden Age: By the Legends Who Were There."

title: Kitty Carlisle Hart and Kristin Chenoweth on Lucky Breaks
description: Kitty Carlisle Hart and Kristin Chenoweth were interviewed by Ben Brantley after watching the new documentary "Broadway  The Golden Age: By the Legends Who Were There."

title: Wimbledon Joins In by Hiking Its Prize Money
description: Three of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments have yet to be played this year, but the players have won convincingly.

title: Is an Online Sales Tax in Store for You?
description: The Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin discusses a proposed federal bill to help states collect more taxes on Internet sales.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Champions League Semifinals, Barcelona at Bayern Munich
description: Coverage and live analysis from Times reporters, editors and others of Tuesdays Champions League semifinal between Barcelona and Bayern Munich. And make sure to come back on Wednesday for the second semifinal: Real Madrid vs. Dortmund.

title: Bayern Munich Opens Wallet, Shakes Bundesliga Again
description: BERLIN  The headline on the German 24-hour news channel n-tv read simply: Earthquake in the Bundesliga. Bayern Munich opened the teams ample coffers once more and paid a reported $48 million to nab the brilliant young midfielder Mario Gtze from archrival Borussia Dortmund.

title: Rangels Lawsuit Against the House Leadership
description: Representative Charles B. Rangels lawsuit in federal court seeks to have the Houses censure against him overturned.

title: Original Review: The Trip to Bountiful
description: Brooks Atkinsons review of Horton Footes play, which opened on Broadway in 1953 and starred Lillian Gish.

title: Amid Much Tumult, France Approves Marriage for All
description: PARIS  With a definitive vote by the lower house of Parliament, France on Tuesday became the worlds 14th nation, and the third in just two weeks, to approve marriage rights for same-sex couples.

title: Noahs Gritty Effort Reflects Tough Lesson
description: For one night in what has been a long and grueling season devoid of Hollywood flourish, Joakim Noah and the Chicago Bulls produced the kind of happy ending Noah had wanted to see for the superstars in his life, from way back when as well as now.

title: Multinationals Hasten to Invest in Indonesia
description: BEKASI, Indonesia  When Marcos A. Purty arrived here in 2011 as the chief of General Motors Indonesian operations, he found a mothballed auto plant.

title: College Ends Free Tuition, and an Era
description: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, which is one of the last tuition-free colleges in the country but has been under severe financial strain, announced on Tuesday that for the first time in more than a century it will charge undergraduates to attend.

title: Ask Well: Double the Workout, Double the Benefits?
description: Question:

title: Obama on Boston Suspects Arrest
description: President Obama praised Boston citizens and law enforcement officials on the night the marathon bombing suspect was taken into custody.

title: Thai Magnate Loads Up on Debt for Big Deals
description: Thailands richest man is rediscovering the joy of debt. Fresh from leveraging up to buy a stake in the Ping An Insurance Group of China, Dhanin Chearavanont is borrowing $6 billion to finance a takeover of Siam Makro, a cash-and-carry company. Combining that group with his 7-Eleven convenience store chain makes sense  as long as Southeast Asias financial boom keeps the cash flowing.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: One Seven-Year Term?
Reading a Bedtime Story Together from Afar
description: Kindoma Storytime combines e-books with video sharing features. So now you can share a bedtime story with your child or grandchild from anywhere, if you both have iPads, good Wi-Fi, and have downloaded the free app from iTunes.

title: Image of the Day: April 23
A Potential Pioneer, Just Looking for a Job
description: Alan Gendreau would seem an unlikely pioneer. He is a former kicker for Middle Tennessee State, the leading scorer in Sun Belt Conference history, a little-known 23-year-old who wants a shot at the N.F.L.

title: The Flattening of Design
description: It might sound audacious to think that Microsoft, the arbiter of uncool, was at the forefront of design a few years ago. But it was.

title: Putting a Dollar Value on a Facebook Fan
description: As noted in Mondays Dashboard summary of the weeks small-business news, a social media marketing firm, Syncapse, has published a report that says the average value of a Facebook fan is $174.17. Seeking further details about the calculation and its potential impact on a small-business owners social media investment, we reached out to the companys chief executive, Michael Scissons, and had the following conversation, which has been edited and condensed.

title: Parks, Museums and Budget Cuts
description: The across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester may have vanished from public consciousness a couple of news cycles ago, but travelers visiting national parks and monuments and museums in Washington this summer will find sporadic reminders of them, testimony at a recent Congressional hearing suggests.

title: Crisscrossing a Region of Strip Malls and Ghosts
description: W. J. Cash, the author of The Mind of the South (1941), was a newspaperman, a Mencken devotee and a manic-depressive. When he killed himself, not long after his book was published, he was newly married and had a fresh Guggenheim fellowship in his pocket.

title: Rangel Sues to Overturn Censure
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Charles B. Rangel is suing his colleagues in the House, claiming that his constitutional rights were violated in 2010 when lawmakers voted to censure him for a series of ethics violations, including failing to pay his taxes properly and accepting rent-stabilized apartments in Manhattan at below-market rent.

title: HSBC to Cut 1,150 Additional Jobs in Britain
description: LONDON  HSBC said Tuesday that it planned to cut about 1,150 jobs in Britain as the bank adjusts to new regulations for wealth advisers.

title: Talking Talent | Judith Light
description: The Emmy- and Tony Award-winning actress Judith Light, best remembered as the glamorous divorce Angela Bower in the 1980s sitcom Whos the Boss? stars as Faye, the matriarch of a wealthy Upper West Side family in turmoil in The Assembled Parties, running through June 2 at Manhattan Theater Clubs Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Like her Tony-winning character Silda in Other Desert Cities, Light has clearly mastered the role of a Jewish woman facing personal and familial crisis with equal doses of wit and wisdom. Penned by Richard Greenberg and directed by Lynne Meadow, The Assembled Parties provides Light with a role that proves she is a Broadway force to be reckoned with.

title: Sheila Birnbaum Leaves Skadden for Quinn Emanuel
description: Sheila L. Birnbaum, one of the countrys top product liability defense lawyers, is switching firms.

title: Dangerous Liaisons Meets AC/DC
description: In the Lives essay I wrote for last Sundays magazine, a brilliant live band from Boston called the Upper Crust makes an important cameo. I knew about them because my friend Ted Widmer used to be one of their three guitarists (he also wrote for me at George magazine), and they had this shtick that sounded ridiculous until you witnessed it  they dressed up as 18th-century aristocrats and played heavy metal. Actually, it was ridiculous after you witnessed it too, but that was the point. The reason it worked, among other things, was that their songs were surprisingly great, and the band could fill a room with an energy that inspired villainy. The altercation I wrote about at a 1996 show at Brownies in the East Village was apparently not uncommon. We had a lot of extremes, people who loved the humor, and then a lot of people who got out of control, Widmer says. It seemed to make people go crazy. There were a lot of fights breaking out at gigs in the early days.

title: Key Step in Checking Chemical-Arms Use Is Also Hardest
description: The most important step in conclusively determining whether chemical weapons have been used is for independent experts to get prompt, unfettered access to the site of the suspected attack, according to Physicians for Human Rights, the American organization that was one of the first to document Iraqs use of poison gas against its Kurdish population in 1988.

title: Bush's Choice for Fed
Cake as Art
description: http://vimeo.com/claypix/modernartdesserts

title: With Bruising Beauty, Bulls Halt Nets Rhythm
description: With his perpetually stressed look, Bulls Coach Tom Thibodeau hardly cuts the figure of an artist. And when his team snarled and clawed its way to a 90-82 victory over the Nets in Game 2 of their first-round playoff series Monday night, it did not call to mind the grace and nuance of the N.B.A.s most revered performers.

title: Randazzos Clam Bar
description: Inside the Sheepshead Bay restaurant that was badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy last October.

title: In Hacking, A.P. Twitter Feed Sends False Report of Explosions
description: Hackers hijacked the Twitter account for The Associated Press on Tuesday and sent out an erroneous message reporting explosions at the White House that injured President Obama.

title: The Star Is Dressed in Red
description: The regulars at Randazzos Clam Bar know what to order. I was still learning the ropes, though, so I invited suggestions.

title: Philadelphia Abortion Doctor Is Cleared on Some Counts
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday threw out three of seven murder charges against a Philadelphia doctor charged with killing viable fetuses while performing abortions.

title: Security, Privacy and Bloomberg
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York has become a national leader on many important issues  showing real courage on gun regulation, for example.

title: Guest Post | Primary Sources Meet Free Web 2.0 Tools for Common Core Learning
description: We invited staffers at Primary Source to do a guest-blog version of a presentation we saw them make at the International Society for Technology in Education conference last summer.Because the organization specializes in helping educators use primary sources, like newspapers, to teach about world histories and cultures, its writers chose three well-known tech tools  Google Docs, QR codes and LiveBinders  and showed how they might be matched creatively with Times articles and other resources to teach three topics that draw on both current and historical Times reporting.What tech tools do you use to teach with primary resources? Wed love to hear more ideas, especially if, like these tools, theyre free. Katherine Schulten

title: Learning (and Rapping) About 401(k)s
description: My futures holding a jobWorking hard all dayThrowing money in the bankToward my 401(k).

title: The Exploding Floral Inevitable
description: It seemed like a never-ending winter this year in the Northeast. Every time warm weather emerged in the past few weeks, another blast of cold quickly followed, leaving us skeptical as to whether spring would ever really come. Perhaps thats one of the reasons why Fong Qi Weis series Exploded Flowers seemed so apt when I came upon it on one one of my favorite art and design blogs, Colossal. Wei disassembled and photographed 20 varieties of flowers, arranging each blossoms pieces to emphasize its radial symmetry. Its a graphic and colorful way of looking at one of natures most recognizable symbols of spring. Wei started the series in 2011 and finished last November; the images have been making the rounds on various design blogs recently because five of the pictures won second place as a series in the 2012 International Photography Awards. For more of Weis images, check out the entire series.

title: Maybe Mad Men Lawyers Knew More Than Lindsays
description: Last week, we reported that the Mad Men character Henry Franciss new job as a deputy mayor of New York City did not put him at odds with residency laws, because the city had no such laws in 1967 and 1968, when the new season of Mad Men is set.

title: Mixed Martial Arts Gets a Lift From Cuomo
description: ALBANY  After years of being knocked around  and knocked out  of legislative sessions in New York, mixed martial arts seemingly got a little shot of good news from the governors corner on Tuesday.

title: Polls Show Growing Resolve to Live With Terror Threat
description: Public opinion surveys conducted since the bombings last week at the Boston Marathon indicate that most Americans  while convinced future attacks are quite likely  dont feel personally threatened by terrorism, and an increasing share of the public is skeptical about sacrificing personal freedoms for security.

title: Focus Shifts in Ricin Case as Charges Are Dropped
description: Criminal charges were dropped Tuesday against a Mississippi man accused of mailing poisoned letters to President Obama and two other officials.

title: Choosing a Scholarship Over a College Name Brand
description: A recent Wealth Matters column (Measuring College Prestige vs. Cost of Enrollment) described an unemployed father whose daughter was offered a full scholarship to college. Yet he planned to pay a $32,000 annual tuition bill so she could attend her more prestigious first-choice college instead.

title: Naming the New Twitter-Induced Flash Crash
description: 4:14 p.m. | Updated  One more proposal I liked, from Boston Universitys Austin Frakt: hash crash.

title: Barbra Streisand, at a Gala and in Memory
description: What am I doing here? a smiling former President Bill Clinton asked the plush, volubly appreciative crowd packed into Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening. He may have been the effective warm-up act for his friend Barbra Streisand, to whom he was about to present the 40th annual Chaplin Award. Yet when Mr. Clinton sauntered in, taking over host duties with the silky ease of a man accustomed to working the biggest stage in the world, there was no doubt who the biggest star in the room was. For almost anyone else, he would have been a tough act to follow.

title: Women of the Senate Are Obamas Latest Dinner Guests
description: The informal caucus of women in the Senate  now a record 20 strong  will take its monthly bipartisan dinner tradition on Tuesday night to the White House, where they will meet with President Obama to discuss budget issues and other legislative matters.

title: Musicals Writer Is Called to Star Onstage
description: At least he knows the part really, really well.

title: The Town With a Homing Signal
description: On a recent afternoon at the Dolphin Bookshop, on a hilly corner of Main Street and Shore Road, Patti Vunk was gift-wrapping books. It might be cheaper to go online; it might be easier to go online, said Ms. Vunk, explaining the book emporiums survival in the age of e-readers, but Port Washington residents want us to be here.

title: Running Toward the Boston Marathon Chaos
description: An improvised explosive device is meant to disrupt as well as kill and maim. This is a central element to guerrilla warfare tactics used by terrorists worldwide. The idea is that the device will not only cause physical harm but also incite fear, which will lead to chaos and more fear.

title: Living in Port Washington
description: This community on the North Shore of Long Island is studded with marinas, yacht clubs and golf courses, and offers an easy commute to the city.

title: Rivals Challenge Quinn on Term-Limit Stance That Helped Bloomberg
description: As the Democratic mayoral candidates meet at near-daily forums leading up to the September primary, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, is increasingly finding herself on the defensive over her 2008 decision to support lifting the term limits law and allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek a third term.

title: Look of the Moment | Kate Hudson
description: The Girl: The actress at the premiere of Reluctant Fundamentalist during the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Le Bernardin Will Expand to Accommodate More Diners
description: Eric Ripert and Maguy Le Coze, the owners of Le Bernardin, have signed a lease to expand their their restaurant on West 51st Street, a plan that will allow them to add more private dining rooms by early next year.

title: At S.E.C., White Adds to Her Roster of Top Officials
description: A day after Mary Jo White shuffled the leadership of her enforcement unit, the Wall Street regulator announced on Tuesday that she hired a new lawyer to help run the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Israel and Palestinians Agree on U.N. Work in Jerusalem
description: PARIS  Israel and the Palestinians agreed on Tuesday to renewed involvement by Unesco, the United Nations cultural agency, in the Old City of Jerusalem. The agreement was a small but significant breakthrough in the often highly politicized workings of the agency.

title: Court Rules for Immigrant on Deportation in Drug Case
description: WASHINGTON  The social sharing of a small amount of marijuana by immigrants lawfully in the United States does not require their automatic deportation, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Dark Touch
description: From Carrie to Firestarter, the horror genre is filled with girls who have special powers  to move objects, or ignite flames  that can be used for good or evil. In the film Dark Touch, an 11-year-old named Neve, the only survivor of a massacre that killed her parents and brother, finds she has similar powers. What she does with them, and who she turns them against, makes the film more of a grisly revenge story than a tale of supernatural chicanery.

title: National Park Sites Are Free This Week, but Two Remain Closed
description: This week, all of the National Park Service sites in New York City are free to visitors  except for the two best known to most of them.

title: Healthy, Meet Delicious
description: There was a time when few of us thought about what we ate, but thats been turned upside down since the reigning wisdom first decried salt, then cholesterol, then saturated fat, then almost all fat, then red meat, then carbohydrates and so on. Recent culprits include so many foods and foodlike substances that at least twice a week someone asks me: Whats left to eat? I feel like nothing is safe.

title: Parole Granted for Political Consultant in a Corruption Case
description: ALBANY  Hank Morris, the onetime political adviser to disgraced former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, was granted parole on Tuesday, five months after Mr. Hevesi was released.

title: Super-Awesome Sylvia Selections
description: A maker, tinkerer and online celebrity, Sylvia Todd has attracted more than a million views on YouTube of the show she produces and hosts, called Sylvias Super-Awesome Maker Show. Not bad reach for an 11-year-old.

title: A Science Star Already, Tinkering With the Idea of Growing Up
description: Sylvia Todds desk is not tidy. Its cluttered with small robots (including a solar-powered grasshopper), motors, wires, resistors, a soldering iron and an array of other gadgets and tools.

title: It Works Out to a New Show a Week for a Cable Giant
description: How determined is one of the largest cable television companies, Scripps Networks Interactive, to increase the original programming it offers viewers and advertisers? For the 2013-14 season, the six channels operated by the company plan to add 52 new series.

title: The Cello, Big and Bowed, as the Star
description: It wasnt on the scale of the dozens-strong Piatigorsky International Cello Festival, held in Los Angeles last year. In numbers, it even fell a bit short of the straightforwardly named 12 Cellists of the Berliner Philharmonic.

title: Racing to Spread Word About New Health Plans
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  President Obama and the Democrats passed the 2010 health care law to make medical insurance available to more than 30 million people who do not have it. But with recent studies showing that as many as three-fourths of those people are unaware of their new options, health care providers are joining community organizers and insurance companies in an ambitious effort to spread the word in the six months remaining before the health plans become available.

title: 30 Years Later, Forged Hitler Diaries Enter German Archives
description: BERLIN  When the German newsweekly Stern announced in April 1983 that it had acquired Hitlers previously undiscovered diaries, the magazines exclusive prompted a worldwide sensation. The editors promised to later hand over 60 handwritten volumes to West Germanys Federal Archives for posterity.

title: Students Protest at Culinary Institute
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.  About 90 students at the Culinary Institute of America walked out of classes Tuesday to protest what they called a weakening enforcement of educational standards, including a requirement that applicants have experience in a professional kitchen.

title: For a Clam Dish, Wines With a Snap
description: Pasta with clams, one of the recipes in Mark Bittmans new Flexitarian column, is one of my favorite dishes and is easy as can be when it comes to wine. The combination of olive oil, garlic and clam broth boiled in a rich, briny sauce practically demands a lively, lean, high-acid, somewhat austere white. Italy is full of good examples; just distinguish between mundane industrial bottles and those made with care. Good pinot grigio, Soave or Orvieto, to name three frequently abused wines, are fine choices, as are fianos and falanghinas from Campania. Avoid oakiness and lush textures; the wines want to have snap. Alternatives from farther afield? Chablis comes immediately to mind: a fresh, young modest Chablis. You have beauty in all these combinations.

title: Theater Program For Youth Who Stutter Will Expand
description: Our Time, an arts organization in Manhattan for children and teenagers who stutter, announced on Monday night that it will expand to offer more after-school theater programs and speech therapy this fall and open new locations in Westchester County, Long Island, and northern New Jersey.

title: Finding the Flavors of Charleston, S.C.
description: Before Ted Lee and his brother, Matt, became the ambassadors of Southern cooking known as the Lee Bros., they were just those Yankees who moved from New York to Charleston, S.C., as children. Their status as outsiders gave them a sense of wonder as it relates to the food of Charleston, Ted said recently.

title: How to See the New Pope in Rome
description: So youre off to Rome and in addition to seeing the Colosseum, you want to see the new pope. But how?

title: Excerpts From 'The Oprah Winfrey Show'
description: The following are excerpts from a transcript of "The Oprah Winfrey Show" from Jan. 26, 2006, featuring the author James Frey and Nan A. Talese, the publisher of his book:

title: The U.S., China and the Middle East
description: Vali Nasr, a former senior State Department policy expert, talks to The Timess Marcus Mabry about America and Chinas role in the Middle East.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Washington, India, Yemen and France.

title: The Liberaltarian Democrats
description: I havent written anything about the entirely predictable demise of the post-Newtown gun control push, but this passage from Politicos coverage of last weeks Senate vote seemed worth a comment:

title: Germanys Complicated Relationship With Google Street View
description: Germany is one of the most privacy-sensitive countries in the world. So when Google started taking pictures of buildings and homes for its Street View maps, some people were outraged, even though it was legal.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google Glass Delay and 3-D Escher Models
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Noting a Centennial, and Filling In a Rsum Gap
description: During his 30 years of experience as a leading choral conductor in New York, Kent Tritle has performed a wide range of repertory. But there was one major 20th-century work he had somehow never conducted: Brittens War Requiem.

title: Rendering Loves Woes With Voice, Flute and Outrage
description: Treat em mean, keep em keen.

title: Former Head of Dewey Pays to Settle Mismanagement Claims
description: The former head of the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has agreed to pay more than half a million dollars to resolve claims that mismanagement led to the firms collapse, according to court papers filed in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan late Monday.

title: Front Burner
description: In a weekly column, Florence Fabricant recommends things to read, taste, covet, order, cook, give and more.

title: Flashdance on Broadway Is Delayed Again
description: The Broadway-bound musical Flashdance, based on the 1983 movie about a female welder who wants to be a dancer, is being delayed again as its producers continue to work on the show. The musical, which has received mixed reviews in cities on its current national tour, was scheduled to have a $12 million production on Broadway starting in August, after being delayed twice earlier.

title: Regulators to Restrict Big Banks Payday Lending
description: 8:53 p.m. | Updated

title: Strong Quarter for Smartphones Bolsters AT&T
description: Americans infatuation with smartphones and high-speed Internet helped AT&T post billions of dollars in profit in its first quarter this year.

title: Whole-Grain Pasta With Mushrooms, Asparagus and Favas
description: Pasta companies have made great strides when it comes to whole-grain pasta. On the small scale, Community Grains in Northern California is producing some excellent pasta with its amazing whole-wheat flour, and on the larger commercial scale, companies like Barilla are selling better and better products. I used Barilla penne for this springtime mix.

title: The Times Shifts on Illegal Immigrant, but Doesnt Ban the Use
description: As the debate over a new immigration bill preoccupies Washington, a quieter debate over the use of the term illegal immigrant has stirred up the countrys newsrooms.

title: Two Scoops of New York Basketball
description: New York basketball has been down for a while, and it certainly has never had two N.B.A. title contenders. William C. Rhoden thinks a hoops version of a subway series would be a great remedy.

title: Boomers and Divorce: Share Your Experience
description: In Unhitched, divorced baby boomers tell the story of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward. If you are a divorced boomer and you and your ex are willing to be interviewed for this series, please fill out the form below. We are particularly interested in couples who split after lengthy marriages or civil unions or who were divorced more than once  another area where boomers have, for better or worse, led the way.

title: The Check Is in the Mail, From Apple
description: Over the next few days,some customers who purchased an iPhone 4 in 2010 will receivea check for $15 in the mail. Special thanks to Apple.

title: Hugh R. Frater
description: Mr. Frater, 57, is the chief executive of Berkadia Commercial Mortgage, a joint venture of Berkshire Hathaway and the Leucadia National Corporation. The company, which is based in Horsham, Pa., provides loans to multifamily and other commercial developments as well as loan servicing, managing about $200 billion in mortgages.

title: Apples Buyback Takes a Bite Out of Its Cash Pile, Temporarily
description: Apple Inc. is poised to put much more of its giant rainy day fund to use, announcing an eye-popping increase in its stock-buyback program by more than $50 billion.

title: As Profit Slips, Apple Looks to Reward Shareholders
description: Apple has found a big investor that still has faith in its future: itself.

title: April 23 Updates in the Aftermath of the Boston Marathon
description: 12:04 A.M. | Latest Word on Boylston Reopening

title: In Iceland, a Festival of Present and Future
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Visitors to Thingvellir National Park, just over 30 miles outside of Reykjavik, can stand on the North American continental plate one minute, and Eurasia the next, by simply crossing a rocky gorge: its a divergent boundary where the worlds face is ripping apart slowly. In Reykjavik a different kind of upheaval was evident last weekend, as the Iceland Symphony Orchestra presented its second annual Tectonics Festival at the Harpa Concert Hall and Conference Center here on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The festival also engaged in shifting borders, but convergence, rather than separation, was the chief process in play.

title: Immigration Bill Would Aid Security, Napolitano Says
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation to overhaul the nations immigration laws would further strengthen the countrys security system to guard against cases like the Boston Marathon bombings, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano told the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday in the last of three hearings on a bipartisan immigration proposal.

title: Pop Relief From the Generationals
description: Innocence was regained for an hour or so last night during a late set by the New Orleans duo the Generationals at the Bowery Ballroom onthe Lower East Side. Theyve been roaming the indie circuit for a few years, and a couple of their songs  When They Fight, They Fight and Ten-Twenty-Ten  have been heard in movies or in TV shows or commercials. Even if they did leave out one of my favorite tracks, Carrying the Torch, the reaction to last nights show proved that salvation can still be found in well-written three-minute pop songs with freshly showered hooks, delivered at full nozzle.

title: Volume Rises in Las Vegas Arms Race
description: Over the last few years the center of the electronic dance world in the United States has shifted to Las Vegas, where top D.J.s now earn some of their biggest paychecks from casino megaclubs.

title: F.A.A. Says Furloughs Delayed 1,200 Flights
description: WASHINGTON  The furlough of air traffic controllers delayed more than 1,200 flights on Monday, the first weekday of the unpaid leaves, the Federal Aviation Administration said Tuesday as lawmakers criticized the agency for how it was handling the automatic budget cuts.

title: A Heartland Without Soul
description: Expand or die.

title: The Young Salinger, Mordant Yet Hopeful
description: On Nov. 18, 1941, a struggling Manhattan author wrote to a young woman in Toronto to tell her to look for a new piece of his in a coming issue of The New Yorker. This short story, he said, about a prep school kid on his Christmas vacation, had inspired his editor to ask for an entire series on the character, but the author himself was having misgivings. Ill try a couple more, anyway, he wrote, and if I begin to miss my mark Ill quit.

title: Taking Inspiration From a Visionary Scientist
description: Last week New York Live Arts devoted its first Live Ideas festival of panel discussions, screenings and performances to the neurologist and writer Oliver Sacks. The choreographer Donna Uchizono had the daunting task of creating a dance based on Awakenings, Dr. Sackss classic 1973 book about sleeping-sickness patients who had been frozen for decades in a trancelike state before being awakened by a new drug.

title: Temptations and Trouble
description: Apple does a spot-on, if unknowing, impression of a Lifetime movie as it burbles with bathos, tragic illness, cheap coincidences, gratuitous alcoholism and tearful confessions of star-crossed love. It even has cheesy transition music. About the only thing missing is your ability to change the channel.

title: Seeking Proof on Syrian Chemical Weapons
description: The Timess David E. Sanger on what the Obama administration is looking for before it moves on intelligence suggesting that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria used chemical weapons.

title: A Pas de Deux for Sisters, Even Offstage
description: MIAMI BEACH  On a recent afternoon here in the spacious rehearsal halls of Miami City Ballet, where palm trees frame oversize windows, the sisters Patricia and Jeanette Delgado rehearsed Jerome Robbinss Dances at a Gathering and swapped pointers. As Jeanette struggled in a high lift over her partners head, Patricia, sprawled on the floor below, stretching, suggested that her sister soften with the music. Later Jeanette returned the favor  as Patricia came out of a fast turn, Jeanette advised her to roll down through your foot to stop the momentum.

title: Video: Two Scoops of New York Basketball
description: New York basketball has been down for a while, and it certainly has never had two N.B.A. title contenders. A hoops version of a subway series would be a great remedy.

title: Threatening Protectionism
description: Its not just banks who dislike higher capital standards. Now, European Union officials are complaining about them, too.

title: Lasry Out of the Running for Ambassador to France
description: The billionaire hedge fund manager Marc Lasry will not be moving to the ambassadors mansion in Paris.

title: Einhorn Supports Apples Big Payouts
description: Apples huge gift to investors has at least one big fan: David Einhorn, the prominent hedge fund manager who took on the company over its payouts to shareholders.

title: Jason Segel to Write Childrens Book Series
description: The actor Jason Segel is venturing into childrens books with a middle-grade series to be published by Random House, the publisher said on Tuesday.

title: Bayern Munich Subdues a Stunned Barcelona
description: Bayern Munich made a brutally efficient case that it is the team to beat in the Champions League this season, humbling visiting Barcelona, 4-0, on Tuesday in the first leg of their semifinal at Allianz Arena. Thomas Mller scored two goals and set up two others for Bayern, which did not so much change places with Barcelona atop the pedestal as shove the visitors off it.

title: Flawed Bidding Process Leaves Dell at a Loss
description: The private equity firm Blackstone Group has exited the stage for Dell, abruptly bringing down the curtain on a budding takeover contest. It has the elements of a farce, and Dells board has no one to blame but itself.

title: In Hard Times, Open Dissent and Repression Rise in Vietnam
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  His bookshelves are filled with the collected works of Marx, Engels and Ho Chi Minh, the hallmarks of a loyal career in the Communist Party, but Nguyen Phuoc Tuong, 77, says he is no longer a believer. A former adviser to two prime ministers, Mr. Tuong, like so many people in Vietnam today, is speaking out forcefully against the government.

title: The Legacy of an Author Lingers at the Met
description: Walking up the granite stairs of the Metropolitan Museum of Art from the Great Hall on Tuesday, Alison Watts immediately thought about how she had taken the same steps as the luckiest brother and sister duo in literature.

title: Restoring Sea and Romance to a French Treasure
description: MONT-ST.-MICHEL, France  A dispatch in The New York Times in August 1944 described the view of Mont-St.-Michel that American soldiers saw, racing their tanks across the Norman hills into Avranches. Built for war as well as worship, the writer noted, the Mont seems to float on the sea as gracefully as a ship under full sail, catching all the changing colors of the clouds.

title: Court Backs E.P.A. Veto of Mining Permit
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to revoke a mining permit to protect streams and wildlife, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday. The decision was a victory for the agency, which in 2011 retroactively vetoed a permit granted by the Bush administration in 2007 to allow a subsidiary of Arch Coal of St. Louis to dump tons of mining waste into several West Virginia rivers and streams. The veto was declared illegal in a 2012 decision by Judge Amy Berman Jackson of Federal District Court, who called it an illegal power grab. But on Tuesday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled unanimously that the Clean Water Act and Congressional intent gave E.P.A. the authority to retroactively revoke a mining permit. The ruling affects a proposed mine known as Spruce No. 1, which would have involved dynamiting the tops off mountains to get at coal. Kim Link, a spokeswoman for Arch Coal, said in an e-mail: Were disappointed in the decision, which was related to the procedural aspects of the proceeding. The case will now go back to the district court for a decision on the merits.

title: Judge Allows Phone Apps for Hailing Yellow Taxis
description: A State Supreme Court justice on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit aimed at stifling New York Citys plans to allow taxi riders to hail yellow cabs using smartphone apps, ruling that a pilot program to test the apps could proceed.

title: Financing Energy-Efficient Vehicles
description: The Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (A.T.V.M.) loan program provides loans to automotive companies for the development of energy-efficient vehicles, like hybrid or electric cars and trucks, and the systems and infrastructure to support them.

title: Fearing Price Increases, Iranians Hoard Goods
description: TEHRAN  Iranians rushed to supermarkets to buy cooking oil, red meat and other staples on Tuesday, stockpiling the goods over new fears of price spikes from a change in the official exchange rate that could severely reduce the already weakened purchasing power of the rial, the national currency.

title: Breaking Down on the Road to Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  No one answers the phones these days at Fisker Automotive. Its visionary founder has quit; its employees have been laid off or put on furlough without pay. Production of its sleek plug-in hybrid car, the Karma, ended months ago.

title: Gay Marriage Measure Advances in Rhode Island
description: Rhode Island took a step on Tuesday toward becoming the 10th state to approve same-sex marriage when a major legislative committee forwarded a marriage bill to the State Senate.

title: New Threat in Nigeria as Militants Split Off
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Nearly four years into Nigerias bloody struggle with Islamists in its impoverished north, a new threat has emerged with deadly implications, this time for Westerners as well as Nigerians: local militants who openly claim to be inspired and trained by Al Qaeda and its affiliate in the region.

title: A Met Approaches Rarefied Air
description: To be overly excited by a few games at the start of a long baseball season can be tricky. Jumping the gun and engaging in hyperbole will often end in backlash and embarrassment. So after four immensely impressive starts by Matt Harvey, is it wise to toss aside all restraint about the Mets young and currently unhittable pitcher? Is it time to just start piling on the praise and look for historical comparisons?

title: Coke Looks Beyond Spotify for Music Promotion in India
description: A year ago, Coca-Cola teamed up with Spotify for what it described as a global marketing partnership, and last fall Coke participated in a $100 million financing round for Spotify.

title: 21 Years After a Murder, an Alibi Witness Is Willing to Testify
description: At the sound of the name Everton, Joann Butler could be heard over the phone drawing a deep breath.

title: Drone Strikes Turn Allies Into Enemies, Yemeni Says
description: WASHINGTON  A Yemeni man who studied at an American high school told Congress on Tuesday that a drone strike on his village in Yemen last week terrified his neighbors, turning them against the United States in a way that terrorist propaganda had failed to do.

title: Bringing Back a Behemoth
description: Last year, the Lahontan cutthroat trout became the first confirmed catch of a fish that for decades was believed to have gone extinct.

title: Canada: Suspects Appear in Court Over Charges in Derailment Plot
description: The two men charged with plotting to derail a Canadian passenger train with the assistance of Al Qaeda denied the charges in court appearances on Tuesday. A lawyer for one suspect said his client, Raed Jaser, was in a state of shock and disbelief and described him as a legal resident for about 20 years. The other suspect, Chiheb Esseghaier, tried to deny the terrorism charges he faces before being cut off by a judge. The police say the men were aided by a group in Iran affiliated with Al Qaeda. In London, an Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman said that there was no shred of evidence.

title: Showdown for Westchester and U.S. Over Desegregation Agreement
description: Four years after Westchester County entered into a landmark desegregation agreement with the federal government, relations between the two sides are hanging by a thread amid federal threats of contempt suits and revocation of money. The showdown is raising unsettling echoes of the disastrous 27-year-long court fight over housing that virtually bankrupted Yonkers, the countys largest city.

title: Economists Agree: Solutions Are Elusive
description: Last week the International Monetary Fund hosted a conference of some of the worlds top macroeconomists to assess how the most intense crisis to have shaken the industrialized economies since the Great Depression has changed the professions collective understanding of how the world economy works.

title: 20 Pounds? Not Too Bad, for an Extinct Fish
description: PYRAMID LAKE, Nev.  For most fishermen a 20-pound trout is a trophy, but for Paiute tribe members and fish biologists here the one Matt Ceccarelli caught was a victory.

title: Britain: Man Convicted of Fraud Over Fake Bomb Detectors
description: A British businessman who sold the Iraqi security forces more than 6,000 fake bomb detectors based on $20 golf ball finders bought from the United States was convicted of fraud on Tuesday in Britains central criminal court. The businessman, James McCormick, 56, was described in court as having made more than $75 million from sales of the fake device in Iraq and Georgia, among other places, claiming they could detect bombs, drugs, currency and ivory, and track objects up to 3,280 feet below ground. The devices, sold for up to $40,000 each, had no working electronics and were completely useless. They were widely used at checkpoints in Iraq, giving a false sense of security. An Iraqi general, Jihad al-Jabiri, former head of the Baghdad bomb squad, has been jailed in the scam, along with other police officials.

title: With Juice and Vegan Trends, a Company Aims for National Exposure
description: Organic Avenue, the tiny purveyor of high-end juices, fresh salads and specialty foods like cashew scallion cream cheese and Thai collard wraps, has hired a new chief executive with the goal of turning its new owners dreams of a national chain into reality.

title: Camelot in Canada?
description: CANADA has never had much truck with serial ruling clans. The closest weve come to a dynasty was Guy Lombardo and His Royal Canadians, a dance band (not actually by appointment of Her Majesty the Queen; that self-conferred honorific was meant to charm impressionable Americans) made up of four brothers, and sometimes a sister, who ruled generation after generation wherever it is that dance bands rule. But packing an orchestra with that monogenerational cluster seemed less dynastic than incestuous.

title: Dithering While Damascus Burns
description: WASHINGTON

title: Hazy Future for Thriving S.E.C. Whistle-Blower Effort
description: For years, Wall Streets top enforcers lacked the firepower to thwart financial misdeeds like Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme. But now that the Securities and Exchange Commission has turned to sophisticated statistical tools and financial experts, one of the most effective weapons in its new enforcement arsenal may be a more traditional one: whistle-blowers.

title: A Chinese Threat to Afghan Buddhas
description: In Afghanistan, a Chinese mining company threatens to destroy the remains of an ancient Buddhist city, which archaeologists are now racing to excavate.

title: Lawmakers Plead Not Guilty to Charges in Bribery Scheme
description: WHITE PLAINS  A state senator and a New York City councilman pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges that they plotted to bribe Republican Party bosses to place the senator on the ballot in the citys mayoral race.

title: A Chinese Threat to Afghan Buddhas
description: When I first traveled to Afghanistan in 2004, I immediately fell in love with the country and its people, and I was optimistic that the young people in Kabul would soon have better lives. Yet my hopes dimmed as I learned about a revolving door of exploitation at the hands of the Russians, Americans and now the Chinese  who have begun mining Afghanistans plentiful natural resources and threatening priceless national heritage sites.

title: Goodbye to All That
description: On April 13, Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority resigned. It was an easy development to miss, but not one to be ignored. It was very bad news, because Salam Fayyad was the Arab Spring before there was an Arab Spring. That is, he was what the Arab Spring was supposed to lead to: a new generation of decent Arab leaders whose primary focus would be the human development of their own people, not the enrichment of their family, tribe, sect or party. That Fayyads brand of noncorrupt, institution-focused leadership was not sufficiently supported by other Palestinian leaders, the Arab states, Israel and America is really depressing. It does not bode well for the revolutions in Egypt, Syria or Tunisia  none of which have a Fayyad-quality leader at the helm.

title: Smoking? Combat? Wait Till 21, Young Recruits Say
description: Nicole Michell Phipps, a soft-spoken 21-year-old woman in a furry hood who showed up at the Navy recruitment center in Harlem on Tuesday, said she was drawn to the military in search of more structure in her life.

title: A Round of Hugs for Goodell and Draftees
description: Gerald McCoy could finish his N.F.L. career with hundreds of tackles and game-changing plays as a defensive tackle for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and it would make little difference. In one incredibly vital way, McCoys legacy is already secure, his influence evident every April.

title: Senators Say Case Indicates That Problems Persist in Agencies Data Sharing
description: WASHINGTON  As investigators sought answers to what or who may have radicalized the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings, leading lawmakers said Tuesday that potentially important clues about at least one of the men might not have been widely shared within investigative circles months before the attack.

title: Free the Attica Report
description: The violence in 1971 at Attica resulted in 43 deaths and left many unanswered questions about what happened at the maximum security prison in western New York. The state attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, now wants a judge to allow the release of a 1975 review of the riot and the retaking of the prison by force.

title: Japans Unnecessary Nationalism
description: Since taking over as Japans prime minister in December, Shinzo Abe and his conservative Liberal Democratic Party have been juggling a packed agenda of complicated issues, including reviving the countrys economy, coping with the aftermath of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami and managing prickly relations with neighbors like North Korea. Stirring up extraneous controversy is counterproductive, but thats exactly what he and his nationalist allies in Parliament have done.

title: A Common Sense Immigration Ruling
description: Federal immigration law prohibits the attorney general from letting a noncitizen stay in the United States for any reason if he is convicted of an aggravated felony. The immigration system has held that every conviction for marijuana distribution is such a felony.

title: Minus Youkilis, Yankees Are Without Another Much-Needed Right-Handed Bat
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Kevin Youkilis was not in the starting lineup for the third straight game Tuesday because of a back problem, and the timing could not have been worse for the slumping Yankees.

title: Outlet Mall With Fashion Ambition Rises Near Chicago
description: ROSEMONT, Ill.  A new outlet mall under construction here  the first enclosed mall to be built in the Chicago area in over a decade  is both a departure for the outlet industry and a major new attraction for this close-in Chicago suburb long known as a convention and business hub.

title: Fate of Clerics Held in Syria Is Disputed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Christian advocacy group and the television network Al Jazeera reported the release on Tuesday of two Syrian archbishops who had been seized on a road trip outside their home city of Aleppo 24 hours earlier. But others said the archbishops were still held by unidentified kidnappers, in a day of conflicting accounts about the fate of the pair, the most prominent clergymen drawn into Syrias civil war.

title: New Hosts Fill Companies Need for Meeting Space
description: Commercial tenants have found themselves in a quandary in the last few years thanks to the make-do-with-less downturn. Some companies have shed underused office space in an effort to cut costs, but many of those same companies still require comfortable, high-tech rooms for large events like employee orientations, brainstorming sessions and shareholder meetings.

title: Budget Cuts, Minus the Inconvenience
description: On Monday, after the sequester cuts forced the Federal Aviation Administration to begin furloughs for air traffic controllers, delays began to build up at airports around the country. Travelers had to wait, but nothing delayed Republicans from scurrying away from all responsibility. Speaker John Boehner started using the Twitter hashtag #ObamaFlightDelays, the latest effort in his partys campaign to blame all the pain of the sequester on the Obama administration while claiming all the credit for its effect on reducing the deficit.

title: Lost in Space
description: When James Gleick was my editor on the City Desk of The Times, he would often stare into space.

title: For Dodgers, Expensive Plans Go Astray
description: There was no attendant at the door of the visiting Los Angeles Dodgers clubhouse at Citi Field at 3:30 on Tuesday afternoon, so the greatest pitcher in their history strolled right in. At 77, Sandy Koufax looks as fit as he was in his prime. He does not need a plastic badge to identify himself.

title: Would-Be Liu Donor Testifies That Defendant Said She Would Repay
description: They had once dated, had attended high school and Rutgers together, and had remained friends. He had even bought her a $1,500 Louis Vuitton handbag and hoped to rekindle their relationship.

title: Safety Agency Backs Limits to Car Devices
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration released guidelines on Tuesday aimed at lessening the risks of distracted driving, recommending that automakers voluntarily limit the functions of electronic devices built into vehicles.

title: Accounting Board Picks Next Chairman
description: Russell G. Golden was named the chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board on Tuesday, taking up the debate over the convergence of global rules.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Apr. 24, 2013
description: If the system is not fixed, it will collapse on its own.

title: Unraveling Boston Suspects Online Lives, Link by Link
description: It is Americas first fully interactive national tragedy of the social media age.

title: U.S. Accuses Novartis of Providing Kickbacks
description: Federal prosecutors in New York filed a lawsuit on Tuesday accusing Novartis of providing illegal kickbacks to pharmacies, in the form of discounts and rebates, to promote use of one of the companys drugs.

title: Selling Ad Time on the Big Screen With a Small-Screen Approach
description: AMONG the more interesting trends so far this year on Madison Avenue has been the expansion of upfronts, as media companies that never made sales presentations before the coming television season begin doing so. In some instances, that emulation of televisions peddling of commercial time extends beyond parties and red-carpet events with celebrities.

Birth Control in Drugstores

title: Resistant Bacteria in Meat
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Resentenced to Life in Prison, Terrorist Plans to Appeal
description: Nearly 20 years after he served as Osama bin Ladens personal secretary in Sudan, and a dozen years after he was convicted of conspiring to commit terrorism, Wadih El-Hage emerged from a dark cell in a federal prison to be resentenced for his crime on Tuesday.

title: The Trip to Bountiful
description: Scenes from the Broadway revival of Horton Footes play.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 23, 2013

title: Plan for Ice Center in Bronx Armory Moves Forward
description: The Kingsbridge Armory towers over the northwest Bronx, a massive empty shell that has long defied redevelopment efforts and haunted generations of city leaders.

title: Corrections: April 24, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Home Is Where the Years Disappear
description: The title destination in Horton Footes Trip to Bountiful, which has been revived at the Stephen Sondheim Theater, is said to be a small, obscure town in Texas. But on the evidence of the performance of Cicely Tyson, who stars in the production that opened on Tuesday night under Michael Wilsons slow-handed direction, Bountiful is a code name for the Fountain of Youth.

title: A Rise to Power, Disco Round Included
description: Discothques make strange bedfellows. To confirm this dangerous fact of life, just boogie on down  and you must  to the glittery new dance palace at the Public Theater. There youll find yourself dancing hip by pelvis with one of the most notorious power couples of the 20th century.

title: S.E.C. Is Asked to Require Disclosure of Donations
description: A loose coalition of Democratic elected officials, shareholder activists and pension funds has flooded the Securities and Exchange Commission with calls to require publicly traded corporations to disclose to shareholders all of their political donations, a move that could transform the growing world of secret campaign spending.

title: At Full Speed
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Tennis is a very popular game, and maybe that explains why I feel like Ive done this puzzle before. Not the whole thing; just the theme. Still, the fill and the theme entries were enough to keep me entertained through the solve, and thats, as Martha Stewart would say, a Good Thing.

title: Mets Summon an Outfielder From the Minor Leagues, and Even He Is Surprised
description: Juan Lagares stood in front of his new locker at Citi Field on Tuesday with a huge smile on his face. He had arrived in New York only a few hours earlier after catching a red-eye flight from Colorado.

title: A Health Provider Strives to Keep Hospital Beds Empty
description: CHICAGO  On a stormy evening this spring, nurses at Dr. Gary Stucks family practice were on the phone with patients with heart ailments, asking them not to shovel snow. The idea was to keep them out of the hospital, and that effort  combined with dozens more like it  is starting to make a difference: across the city, doctors are providing less, but not worse, health care.

title: Petraeus to Join CUNY as Visiting Professor
description: David H. Petraeus, who resigned as director of the Central Intelligence Agency last November after having an extramarital affair with his biographer, will serve as a visiting professor at the City University of New York next academic year, the university announced on Tuesday.

title: Edward de Grazia, Lawyer Who Fought Censorship of Books, Is Dead at 86
description: Edward de Grazia, a lawyer and teacher who in the 1950s and 60s broadened the scope of what Americans would be allowed to read by helping to defeat government bans on sexually explicit books, died on April 11 in Potomac, Md. He was 86.

title: Mayoral Candidates Begin to Release Their Income Figures
description: Joseph J. Lhota, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, reported almost $2 million in income last year, far more than any other leading candidate for mayor, according to returns released on Tuesday.

title: Two Groups in Grief Refuse to Stand Still
description: BOSTON  In the days after the marathon bombings, the slogan We are one Boston became a rallying cry for this bleeding city. It flashes on L.E.D. signs that display route numbers on the front of city buses. It is echoed in the name of the One Fund Boston, a charity set up to aid victims of the attack, which killed three people and injured, at last count, 264.

title: Shakuntala Devi, Human Computer Who Bested the Machines, Dies at 83
description: Shakuntala Devi, an Indian mathematical wizard known as the human computer for her ability to make incredibly swift calculations, died on Sunday in Bangalore, India. She was 83.

title: Senator Max Baucus Will Not Run in 2014
description: Max Baucus was elected to the House from Montana in 1974 and to the Senate four years later. He said Tuesday that he would not seek a seventh term.

title: The World Is Watching: A Russian Bloggers Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard J. Phillips, Stalwart Conservative, Dies at 72
description: Howard J. Phillips, a pillar of conservative activism who ran for president three times on the ticket of a political party he helped found, died on Saturday at his home in Vienna, Va. He was 72.

title: Yankees, Showing Other Sides of Their Game, Pull Out Win
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Within an instant of unleashing a fat pitch to Jose Molina in the seventh inning Tuesday night, Phil Hughes thought he had blown the game. Molina hit the pitch for a single that tilted a taut, compelling game in favor of the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: At Republican Forum, McDonald Promises to Make the Economy His Focus
description: George T. McDonald, a Republican candidate for mayor, can be an uneven performer in public. He likes to explain his economic plan by arguing that the Bronx should produce more applesauce, and he sometimes jokes about commuting by skateboard.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Mets Lose Lead, and the Game, but Hope Niese Heals Quickly
description: Right after his 54th pitch on Tuesday night, Jon Niese stumbled off the mound and performed an awkward 720-degree spin. He could not get out of the way of a comebacker, and as the game whirred on around him, he limped toward home plate, took a few wobbly steps up the first-base line and then bent over, hands on his knees.

title: New York City Storm Victims May Get Federal Reimbursement for Repairs
description: New York City residents who used their own money to repair damage caused by Hurricane Sandy may be reimbursed with federal money, after the city reversed its position.

title: Rangers Miss Chance to Clinch but Have Two More
description: SUNRISE, Fla.  The Rangers simply had to beat the last-place Floria Panthers Tuesday to earn a trip to the playoffs. Instead, they lost, 3-2, in hard-to-believe fashion.

title: Galaxy S4 Puts More Features Into the Same Package
description: Were No. 2, went the old Avis slogan. We try harder.

title: Do We Have to Cool Down After Exercise?
description: Do you often, if guiltily, skip cooling down after exercise? A small but soothing body of new research suggests that you arent missing out on much.

title: A Warm Welcome
description: N.F.L. draft picks get a lesson on public displays of affection from Commissioner Roger Goodell.

title: Word of the Day | repugnance
description: repugnance \ri-pg-nn(t)s\ noun

title: Warner Bros. Enlists Walmart Stores to Promote Man of Steel
description: LOS ANGELES  Which is more powerful: Superman or Walmart?

title: In Game 2, Knicks Reiterate Message
description: In another time, another spring, the duel would have been tantalizing, electric and potentially epic: Carmelo Anthony versus Paul Pierce, for control of the Eastern Conference. The names alone inspire visions of a classic playoff scoring battle.

title: Celtics Fade Once Again as Knicks Press Hard
description: The Boston Celtics had to listen for three days about how their offense scored only 8 points in the fourth quarter of Game 1. For the first half of Game 2 on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, they looked as if they had overcome that humiliation.

title: Make Wall Street Choose: Go Small or Go Home
description: WASHINGTON

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 5:35 P.M. (Starz) THE IDES OF MARCH (2011) George Clooney, Grant Heslov and Beau Willimon received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for this political drama, which Mr. Clooney, above, also directed and stars in as Mike Morris, a Pennsylvania governor turned dream candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. Ryan Gosling plays Stephen Meyers, a strategist who becomes involved with an intern (Evan Rachel Wood) with a powerful father and a secret that could derail Stephens career and the Morris campaign. Philip Seymour Hoffman and Paul Giamatti are senior advisers battling for Stephens loyalty. And Marisa Tomei is a reporter trying to get at the truth. Mr. Clooney handles the plot complications with elegant dexterity, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Mr. Willimons play Farragut North, loosely based on Howard Deans 2004 Democratic presidential primary campaign. As an actor he works best in long, understated scenes that allow him to play with nuances of charm and menace, so it is not surprising that, as a director, he gives the rest of the cast room to work, Mr. Scott added. But the parts of The Ides of March  quiet scenes between Mr. Gosling and Ms. Wood; swirling, Sorkinesque exchanges of banter; any time Ms. Tomei or Max Minghella (as a campaign worker grooming himself to be the next Stephen Meyers) are in the room  are greater than the whole.

title: Game 2: Knicks vs. Celtics
description: The Knicks defeated the Celtics, 87-71, and took a 2-0 lead in their first-round playoff series.

title: News Quiz | April 24, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Coat With Pockets for Every Gadget
description: There have been multi-pocket gadget jackets before, but have any had the carrying capacity of a clown car? The Scottevest Tropiformer looks like a normal jacket, but you can just keep pulling stuff out of it.

title: Credit Suisse, Citing Large Profit, Says Transformation All but Complete
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse reported on Wednesday that profit rose sharply in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, when the bank booked large charges on its own debt.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 24
description: NEWS Multinational companies are racing to invest in factories and other operations to cash in on rising consumer demand in Indonesia, Southeast Asias biggest economy and most populous nation, with an estimated 251 million people. Joe Cochrane reports from Jakarta.

title: Knicks Slow Garnett by Forcing Him Into Foul Trouble
description: Kevin Garnett was a solid defender when he was on the court Tuesday. The problem for Garnett and the Celtics was that he only played in half of Bostons 87-71 loss in Game 2.

title: Australia Arrests the Professed Head of LulzSec, Which Claims a C.I.A. Hacking
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The federal police in Australia have arrested the professed leader of a prominent international hacking collective known as LulzSec, which is perhaps best known for its assertions of being behind a cyberattack that shut down the Central Intelligence Agencys public Web site in 2011.

title: Glimpses From the Life of Chinas Jailed Nobel Laureate
description: BEIJING  Liu Xiaobo, the jailed Nobel Peace laureate serving an 11-year term for subversion after calling for an end to one-party rule and greater democracy in China, has recently been reading a popular nonfiction book about the history of Soviet Communism and Russian intellectuals in the 19th and 20th centuries, as well as Christian philosophical texts. He has also gained weight, said Mo Shaoping, a Beijing lawyer.

title: Barclays Earnings Decline Sharply on Restructuring Costs
description: LONDON  The British bank Barclays said on Wednesday that first-quarter pretax profit dropped 25 percent as it set aside money to pay for a major overhaul of its operations.

title: A Conversation With: Godrej Group Chairman Adi Godrej
description: MUMBAI Adi Godrej is the chairman of The Godrej Group, a privately held, 116-year old Indian consumer goods conglomerate.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 24, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article At a College, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness.

title: Texans Flock to Bluebonnet Fields
description: In Breaking Laws and Fighting Fire Ants in a Rush to the Texas Bluebonnet Fields, Kate Murphy writes about the seasonal rush to the blooming bluebonnet fields in Texas.

title: Building Collapse in Bangladesh Leaves Scores Dead
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A building housing several factories making clothing for European and American consumers collapsed into a deadly heap on Wednesday, only five months after a horrific fire at a similar facility prompted leading multinational brands to pledge to work to improve safety in the countrys booming but poorly regulated garment industry.

title: Lloyds Bank Plans I.P.O. After Branch Sale Collapses
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Wednesday that it was planning an initial public offering of part of its branch network after a deal fell through to sell the division to a rival British lender, Co-operative Bank.

title: What Would You Teach the World in an Online Video?
description: Have you ever watched an Internet video that teaches how to do something, or explains an idea or problem? Have you ever considered making a video like that?

title: A Life Sold on Photography
description: Paul Kwileckis day job was running a hardware store, but his passion was documenting his hometown, Decatur County, Ga. In the 1960s, the self-taught photographer wrote to such luminaries as Ansel Adams and David Vestal, hoping to get an honest assessment of his work.

title: President of Italy Nominates Center-Left Official as Premier
description: ROME  After months of political paralysis capped by a week of turmoil, President Giorgio Napolitano on Wednesday named Enrico Letta, a high-ranking official in the center-left Democratic Party, to form a broad coalition government to try to steer Italy out of political chaos and its worst recession since World War II.

title: South Korea and U.S. Fail to Reach Deal on Nuclear Energy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea and the Obama administration delayed the deadline for a deal that Seoul had hoped would allow it to begin making its own fuel for its civil nuclear energy program, but that the United States feared would undermine its attempts to curb nuclear proliferation.

title: The Early Word: Consideration
description: In Todays Times

title: Wheelies: The Chrysler Cacciatore Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Future of Driving
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Ranking Top 5 Quarterbacks in N.F.L. Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, nowavailable for download.Examples of his work can be foundat his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: Amherst, Yale or Elsewhere?
description: In this admissions process, every choice I face means the stakes become greater.

title: 21 Dead in Clash with Gangsters in Western China
description: BEIJING  At least 21 people were killed Tuesday in fighting in far western China between security officers and gangsters, according to a propaganda bureau spokeswoman for the regional government of Xinjiang, where the conflict took place.

title: South Korea Offers Aid to Business in Shuttered North Korean Complex
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Wednesday announced financial aid for 123 South Korean factories left stranded in an industrial zone in North Korea as the North showed no signs of allowing the complex to reopen.

title: Heavyweight Champignon
description: The waitress placed a steak knife on the table, and everyones eyebrows went up. No one had ordered steak. There was an appetizer course coming. We didnt need a steak knife.

title: Up for Discussion: Can Employees Be Rehabilitated?
description: At a recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about the odds of rehabilitating an employee who isnt working out. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, started the discussion by explaining why she was focused on becoming better at ensuring she has the best possible employees.

title: Monsters of the River at One Moment in Time
description: Lesley de Souza, a research biologist at John G. Shedd Aquarium, writes from Guyana, where she studies the regions rich aquatic wildlife, including the arapaima, one of the largest freshwater fishes in the world.

title: Obamas Style and the Vote on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Domo Arigato, Mr. Roboto  I Mean, Mr. Smith
description: Noah Smith says Im Voltron the Invincible. Pardon me while I blush.

title: Pivotals Audacious Plan
description: Pivotal, an ambitious creation of the data storage giant EMC and its hefty affiliate VMware, on Wednesday said it would make cloud-based industrial software applications faster than anyone has before, and announced it had the means to do so  a $105 million investment from General Electric.

title: Britain Offers Hand to Smaller Businesses
description: LONDON  With Britains moribund economy struggling to avert a return to recession, a government-backed lending program was extended and reworked Wednesday in the hope of freeing up borrowing to credit-starved small and medium-size companies.

title: NBCUniversal Plans an Upfront for Its Digital Properties
description: Remember how the Florida citrus growers ran commercials asserting that orange juice was not just for breakfast anymore? The NBCUniversal division of Comcast, in its seemingly continuous efforts to convince Madison Avenue that it is not just about the problematic NBC television network anymore, plans to share an ambitious slate of digital initiatives with advertisers and agencies on Wednesday evening.

title: Vietnams Bilingual Experiment
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  At a handful of schools across Vietnam, children from ethnic minorities are finding something rare when they enter a classroom: They understand what the teacher is saying.

title: Daily Report: Fisker Automotive Captured Imaginations but Failed to Deliver
description: With technical problems, management turmoil and mounting losses, Fisker Automotive offers a cautionary tale of alternative-fuel vehicles and government subsidies for start-up businesses, Bill Vlasic reports in The New York Times.

title: Mean Cuisine
Blacklisted, From a Childs View
description: Among the few things I share with Eugene ONeill  although I am not nearly as brilliant or as important  is that we are both playwrights, we both chose to write about our parents, and our parents were actors. One thing we dont share is that my parents were blacklisted in the 1950s and were unable to work in television and film for almost a decade.

title: Martian Watch Brings Wristphone Technology to Earthlings
description: An outfit called Martian Watches has created one of the most advanced options yet to put smartphone technology on your wrist.

title: Tip of the Week: Customize the Microsoft Office Ribbon
description: The Ribbon  Microsofts tabbed, consolidated command bar for its Office programs  can be overwhelming to new users, but a little customization can make it feel more comfortable. In Office 2010 and Office 2013 for Windows, you can create a personal tab on the Ribbon and add all your favorite most-used commands to it for quicker access.

title: Wednesday Reading: Exploring a Flexitarian Diet
North American Sales Lift Fords Results
