description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said on Wednesday that its net income improved 15 percent in the first quarter to $1.6 billion, as record results in North America compensated for losses in Europe and South America.

title: Uncertainty on Whistle-Blower Program
description: The use of whistle-blowers at the Securities and Exchange Commission has proved effective. A tipster bolstered an investigation into a trading blowup that almost took down Knight Capital; another aided the discovery that Oppenheimer & Company had overstated the performance of a private equity fund; and a whistle-blower helped the government pursue a Ponzi scheme in Texas, Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report in DealBook.

title: An Unfortunate Meeting of Doppelgngers at the Airport
description: Dear Diary:

title: Could Syrias Civil War Create Jihadis in Europe and the U.S.?
description: LONDON  Two Belgian mothers, worried for the fate of sons who left home to join Islamist rebels in Syria, reportedly traveled to Turkey this week to urge the authorities there to stem the transit of foreign volunteers heading for the conflict.

title: Despite 787 Setbacks, Boeing Reaffirms Outlook as Earnings Beat Estimates
description: Boeing reported a first-quarter profit on Wednesday that topped analysts estimates, and it said the recent problems with the lithium-ion batteries on its 787 Dreamliner jets would not keep it from hitting its profit and revenue goals for the year.

title: On a Field at M.I.T., 10,000 Remember an Officer Who Was Killed
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  More than 10,000 people, many of them uniformed police or military officers, gathered Wednesday on a tightly secured athletic field at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to remember Sean A. Collier, the campus police officer who the authorities say was gunned down by the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.

title: Readers Find an Online Ad Jarring Next to Boston Coverage
description: I heard from a number of readers on Monday who were disturbed by a juxtaposition of images on The Timess home page  an interactive feature related to the bombings in Boston last week, and an advertisement for a Sundance Channel show, Rectify.

title: Transit Worker in Queens Is Fatally Struck by a Train
description: A transit worker was struck and killed by a train while on the job early Wednesday, falling from a catwalk area above the tracks and into the path of an E train in Queens, officials said.

title: The Return of Jon Winkelried, Sort of
description: With a number of high-profile investments under its belt, Thrive Capital is turning to a former top Goldman Sachs executive to help provide advice on its growth plans.

title: When Food Isnt the Answer to Hunger
description: When the Indian Ocean tsunami hit in December 2004, killing more than a quarter-million people, the great global humanitarian machine sprung to life. First on the list of donations, of course, was food  bags of food began arriving by airlift and sea, especially into Aceh, the hardest-hit region.

title: What Were Reading
description: Modern Farmer: If you love chickens but hate the year-round commitment, there is an answer: rent, already. Try Rent-a-Chicken in Traverse City, Mich. Really.  Glenn Collins

title: New Medical Exam Policy for Sexual Assault Cases
description: Techniques for collecting and analyzing evidence in rape cases have evolved over the last decade, as has the understanding of the psychological effects of sexual assault. But how health practitioners, law enforcement officers, prosecutors and others respond after a rape still varies widely across the country.

title: Nowhere to Go
description: A new ad criticizes Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, for her role in the closing of St. Vincent's hospital.

title: Bouncing Back
description: Certain phrases cycle in and out of child-rearing vogue, with executive function and emotional intelligence and kinetic learning zooming before parental headlights and then passing into oblivion until the next generation comes along. At our current moment, resilience is front and center, in large part courtesy of Paul Toughs excellent book on education, How Children Succeed. And to this parent, at least, it seems as good a conceptas anyto cling to and to encourage.

title: Glinda Would Be at Ease
description: IF THE FLICKERING CANDLE of my memory serves, it was in a feminist-studies class (very de rigueur in the early 1990s) that I first read Warning, the famous poem by the English writer Jenny Joseph that begins: When I am an old woman I shall wear purple/With a red hat which doesnt go, and doesnt suit me.

title: The Gun Report: April 24, 2013
description: Dear Senator Max Baucus,

title: States Push to Get the Most Out of Marijuana Taxes
description: DENVER  If marijuana is legalized and properly regulated, its proponents have long said, it could generate millions of dollars in state tax revenue. But how the drug should be taxed has proved to be a thorny question.

title: More Car Sharing From Hertz
description: The car-sharing unit of the rental car company Hertz is expanding in the coming months, the company said. The service, Hertz 24/7, will extend a car-sharing model that had been available in urban areas and college campuses in the United States, and in five other countries, to suburban and rural areas. It also will improve ease of use, with self-service features including keyless entry and a flexible rental term. Hertz said that the rollout, which will eventually provide service to the vast majority of Americans, will begin in late summer in the United States, followed soon after in Europe, and later in China.

title: Made in America. Craved Everywhere Else.
description: It is one of our largest exports, a product made in America from start to finish and craved by businesses and consumers around the world. And the latest edition will be released in October. We speak, of course, about the $100 bill.

title: How Accurate Is The Prime Ministers Economic Advisory Council?
description: On Tuesday, the Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister released its annual economic review for the financial year 2012-13. According to the report, the Indian economy is projected to grow by 6.4 percent in the coming year. I believe we have reached the bottom. The economy will now continue to grow at a faster rate, the council chairman, C. Rangarajan, said in releasing the report.

title: Not Your Everyday Swedish Label
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: For Sale at the Botanical Garden, an Important Pair of Chairs
description: If youve been looking to score some important patio furniture, this weekends Garden Sculptures and Antiques Fair at the New York Botanical Garden might be the place to do it. The fair, which the garden calls the countrys original, largest and most important venue for authentic garden antiques, will feature garden-related artworks and furnishings from 1750 to the present.

title: Film Singer Shamshad Begum Dies at 94
description: Shamshad Begum, a legendary Bollywood and Hindi film singer, has died in Mumbai after a prolonged illness, her family said Wednesday. She was 94.

title: Leave Family Playtime Alone
description: Dear public relations representative for an unnamed organization,

title: The Samsung Galaxy S4 Review Roundup
description: Samsungs new flagship smartphone, the Galaxy S4, will arrive in stores over the next week in the United States. Analysts expect this phone to be a potent challenger to the iPhone, but several technology writers who got the device early agree that the Galaxy S4 is good, but not great. Many felt the new software features were gimmicky and cumbersome.

title: Strategic Posturing Behind the Suit Against Corzine
description: Louis J. Freeh, the bankruptcy trustee for the failed futures firm MF Global, filed a lawsuit aimed at pinning its collapse squarely on Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive, and two of his top lieutenants. And unlike in many other suits, Mr. Freeh has not named other groups like a companys directors.

title: Fight Over Political Donations
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been flooded with calls to require publicly traded corporations to disclose to shareholders all of their political donations.

title: Online Shopping, With Sales Tax Added
description: Attention, all you online shoppers out there: your sales-tax-free party may soon be over.

title: A Wholesaler Finds Himself in Competition With Retail Clients
description: Based in Miami, Source Outdoor is a five-year-old importer and wholesaler of patio and deck furniture owned by Gerald Shvartsman. From humble beginnings, in which he tried to sell his first containers of goods himself, Mr. Shvartsman, 35, has expanded his one-man start-up to encompass more than 50 employees and sales in 2012 of $7 million.

title: Image of the Day: April 24
Guggenheim Hires Lehman Veteran in Continued Hiring Spree
description: Guggenheim Partners signaled its intention to continue building out its investment bank on Wednesday, announcing that it had hired Glenn H. Schiffman, a longtime deal maker at Lehman Brothers.

title: Given Clean Slate by Knicks, Martin Writes a New Ending
description: Here came Kenyon Martin, finished with postgame-interview-room duties, following an earnest Knicks public-relations employee through the exit and into the corridor. A reporter was well positioned there to shoot Martin a follow-up question. Like an express train scheduled to run through local stations, Martin was not supposed to stop.

title: Should a Wholesaler Abandon His Most Profitable Sales Channel?
description: We just published a case study about a Florida importer and wholesaler of outdoor furniture facing a sales dilemma born of entrepreneurial chutzpah.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Champions League Semifinals, Real Madrid at Borussia Dortmund
description: Talk of the balance of power in Europe, in geopolitical terms, is usually fraught with history, buzzwords and bad memories.

title: Kerry Meets Top Afghan and Pakistani Officials
description: TERVUREN, Belgium  Secretary of State John Kerry hosted a meeting on Wednesday with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan and Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, Pakistans army chief, to try to ease regional tensions as NATO approaches the end of its combat mission in Afghanistan.

title: Properties for $975,000
description: A neo-Classical-style home in Atlanta, an 18th-century colonial in New Lebanon, N.Y., and a wood cabin in Wilson, Wyo.

title: What You Get for ... $975,000
description: ATLANTA

title: In Mexico, Eco Concerns Where Sea Lions Romp
description: Something big zoomed by in my peripheral vision. I whipped around for a better look, but whatever it was had disappeared into the permanent twilight of the underwater world. Was it a gigantic grouper? A small whale?

title: Giving Fast Food a Good Name in Washington, D.C.
description: Washingtons culinary scene has traditionally been known for its power restaurants: clubby spots, often run by celebrity chefs, where political movers-and-shakers cut deals and charred steaks. But recently, the city has embraced the flip side of fine dining. Several casual spots have opened, offering fresh, inexpensive, vibrant fare that gives fast food a good name.

title: In Gas-Drilling Fight, Opposites Attract, and Distract
description: There are passionate and well-meaning people arrayed all around the issues surrounding Americas enormous shale-gas resource and the communities on the surface above it. Ive met landowners and residents and scientists in Pennsylvania and upstate New York with powerfully articulated positions against and for drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

title: Comparing the Valuations Behind Amazon and Apple Shares
description: And people wonder why its hard to understand the stock market.

title: Is Gun Control Dead?
description: Is gun control dead after the Senate failed to pass so much as an expansion of background checks?

title: A Town House in Barcelona
description: With a pool in the basement, a courtyard out back and a terrace on the roof, this property is on the market for $3.013 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Barcelona
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH A POOL IN BARCELONA

title: The Snicker Factor
description: Gandhi said, First they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they fight you, then you win. But sometimes, things proceed in the opposite direction. Colbert does Reinhart-Rogoff.

title: 779 Goals, 887 Assists and 2 Lives
description: John Tavares may be reaching the end of his outstanding lacrosse career with the Buffalo Bandits, but it has always been a second job.

title: Test Run: Splitsider Presents, an Online Movie Hub
description: The other night, a friend invited me to a screening of The Exquisite Corpse Project, a documentary about comedy writers trying to collaborate on a movie.

title: A Lacrosse Star Who Is a Math Teacher First
description: BUFFALO  Ask the Islanders star John Tavares about his most influential role models, and he will tell you he has always looked up to his uncle John.

title: The Lieber Codes
description: In October 1861, a legal scholar and historian named Francis Lieber presented the first in a series of lectures entitled The Laws and Usages of War at the Columbia Colleges new law school in New York City. Though the talks, which ran through the following March, were long and often rambling, they drew up to 100 people each and afterward appeared in The New York Times and other newspapers around the country. The public, eager for insight into how the worsening war would and should be fought, devoured his every word.

title: For Silicon Valley High Fliers
description: Mineta San Jose International Airport, Silicon Valleys launchpad in San Jose, Calif., received the citys approval this month to negotiate a lease with Signature Flight Support to build an elite corporate jet center. Five of the seven hangars in the 29-acre, $82 million facility will be reserved for planes owned by Google executives, including Eric Schmidt (above).

title: Gadgets to Help Tend a Garden
description: Picture a tiny drone that arises from your vegetable garden to shoo away hungry deer. Or maybe a houseplant that, when youre away, meanders through your rooms like a cat following a sunbeam. Or one that posts a request for water on Twitter.

title: Feeling For | Gilbert Albert Interchangeable Rings
description: In honor of this weeks celebration of Earth Day, T is feeling for the Swiss jeweler Gilbert Alberts rings with interchangeable stones. The bands, available in silver or gold, hold pearl-shaped gemstones that can be swapped out on a whim. There are more than 80 different precious stones to choose from, ranging from the standard amethyst, tigers-eye and lapis lazuli to the more grand leopard jasper, chrysoprase and mother-of-pearl. This collection gives recycle, reuse, reduce a whole new meaning.

title: Ask Well: Healing Plantar Fasciitis
description: Question:

title: Gary Shteyngart to Publish Memoir
description: Gary Shteyngart will follow up his three best-selling novels with a memoir, his publisher, Random House, announced on Wednesday. Mr. Shteyngarts editor, David Ebershoff, described the book as the candid and deeply poignant story of a Soviet family that comes to America in 1979 to find its future.

title: Chinese Officials Order Questioning of Exiled Activists Relatives
description: HONG KONG  Chinese prosecutors on Wednesday ordered two relatives of a prominent human rights advocate who lives in exile in the United States to face questioning over allegations that they harbored a criminal, in what one family member considered to be retaliation against the activists stepped-up criticism of the government.

title: George Improves His Game, and Has an Award to Show for It
description: With his 27-point, 10-rebound, 8-assist performance in a 110-87 win over the Milwaukee Bucks Sunday night, LeBron James served quick notice that his imminent Most Valuable Player Award will be mere window dressing on what is looking like yet another march to the N.B.A. finals for the Heat.

title: U.N. Expert Says Bahrain Canceled Visit in Torture Inquiry
description: GENEVA  A United Nations expert who was due to visit Bahrain next month to look into reports that the authorities there have abused and tortured protesters in detention said on Wednesday that the Bahraini government had effectively canceled the trip.

title: Johnson Sits Out Nets Practice With Foot Ailment
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Nets prepare for Game 3 of their first-round N.B.A. playoff series with the Chicago Bulls, there is a chance they will be without Joe Johnson, one of their All-Star playmakers.

title: Mayor and Mets Pitch Start of All-Star Voting
description: Major League Baseball, the Mets and the New York mayors office held a joint news conferenceWednesday morning to mark the start of balloting for the All-Star Game, which will take place July 16 at Citi Field.

title: After Rape of Child, Indian Media and Protestors Make Common Cause
description: NEW DELHIOver the past few days, following the rape of a five-year-old girl, the Indian government has been rocked once again by the alliance of the news media and Delhis street protesters. In my latest Letter From India I argue that Delhis new breed of demonstrators are getting better at street protests and sustaining the interest of journalists, while the government has yet to learn how to create a smart and dignified self-defense.

title: New Xbox Console Will Be Revealed on May 21
description: Its official: Microsoft, as expected, will unveil its new Xbox video game console on May 21.

title: Surez Barred 10 Games for Biting Opponent
description: Liverpool striker Luis Surez was suspended for 10 games by Englands Football Association on Wednesday for biting an opponent during a Premier League game, but the reaction of Surez and his club to the decision threatened to further stain the reputations of both.

title: Hunting Down Ramps in Early Spring
description: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

title: Paul Verhoeven on 'Tricked'
description: The director Paul Verhoeven discusses his latest project "Tricked," a film with a crowd-sourced script.

title: How Is Math Beautiful? Exploring by Creating
description: Overview | How is mathematics beautiful? How can the beauty and elegance of mathematics be communicated?

title: Down Payment Rules Are at Heart of Mortgage Debate
description: It seemed an easy fix to prevent the excesses of the housing market: make home buyers put more money down.

title: Test Your Economic Literacy
description: The Department of Education on Wednesday released its latest report on the economic proficiency of 12th graders, based on the test scores of nearly 11,000 students tested in 2012. It found little change in average economic literacy compared to test scores from 2006, although students in the lower part of the score distribution (at the 10th and 25th percentiles) made gains.

title: A Lost Language
description: Haughty for heavy.

title: A Week to Celebrate Henry Millers Brooklyn Connections
description: The Henry Miller Memorial Library, a nonprofit bookstore and arts center in Big Sur, Calif., where the novelist lived between 1940 and 1962, is sending envoys east to assert Millers presence  in spirit, anyway (he died in 1980)  in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where he spent nearly a decade. The librarys Big Sur Brooklyn Bridge Festival, which opens on May 12 and runs for a week, will include an exhibition, readings, panel discussions, comedy and musical performances.

title: Willkommen, Again? Roundabout Planning Another Cabaret Revival
description: Roundabout Theater Company is planning a revival of the famed musical Cabaret at Studio 54 in early 2014 with Alan Cumming starring as the M.C.  the role for which he won a Tony Award in 1998 for a Cabaret revival by Roundabout that ended up running at Studio 54 as well.

title: Caesars Blinds Market With Science
description: The private equity owners behind Caesars Entertainment have been working overtime in their financial laboratory. Apollo Global Management and TPG are following last years microscopic initial public offering with a spinoff and rights issue concoction. Aiming to raise $1.2 billion, the complex transaction mostly seems designed to buy still more time for the ailing $31 billion leveraged buyout.

title: Short-Term Payday Loans Can Become Long-Term Traps
description: Payday loans and deposit-advance loans are intended to be short-term options for emergency cash, but they can turn into long-term debt traps for borrowers, a new federal report says.

title: If You Like Bob Dylan, Try Jake Bugg
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: In Defense of Regulatory Capital Trades
description: Glenn Blasius is the chief executive of Ovid Capital Advisors LLC. He has worked with many large international banks on regulatory capital transactions involving real risk transfer over the last decade.

title: In Israel, OMalley Talks Jobs, Foreign Policy and, of Course, 2016
description: JERUSALEM  Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland said Wednesday that he would spend the second half of this year mulling whether to run for president in 2016. He seems already to have a campaign theme: jobs and innovation.

title: Tribeca Video: Paul Verhoeven Discusses Tricked
description: With his latest film project Tricked, Paul Verhoeven worked with a list of screenwriters that rivaled the length of the script itself. In this video interview at the Tribeca Film Festival, the Dutch director, best known in America for Hollywood hits like Robocop and Basic Instinct, discusses how he and his team assembled the crowd-sourced work of multiple writers to create the screenplay for Tricked.

title: Follow-Up to Gangnam Style Hits No. 5
description: Two months ago, Billboard began incorporating YouTube views in the formula for computing its all-important Hot 100 singles chart, allowing viral-video smashes to reach No. 1 even if they trailed other songs in sales and airplay, two of the charts other criteria. Sure enough, Baauers Harlem Shake, a huge hit online, sailed to No. 1 in the first week of the new chart.

title: Jones Tops Final Scouting Rankings for Draft
description: Defenseman Seth Jones, the most highly regarded African-American prospect in N.H.L. history, was ranked the top North American skater available in the draft, which will be held June 30 in Newark.

title: The Mike Brown Redux in Cleveland
description: You can excuse pretty much anyone not living inside Cavaliers owner Dan Gilberts head for being more than puzzled over the news that the Cavs had re-hired Mike Brown as their head coach. Because yes, its the same Mike Brown who was jettisoned after two 60-win seasons, as a sacrificial lamb in the desperate attempt to keep LeBron James from doing the superteam thing elsewhere, which didnt work. And its the same Mike Brown who lasted five games into his second season as the clearly wrong choice to coach the Lakers.

title: Richie Havens, 1941  2013
description: In 1971, around when I first heard the voice that was Richie Havens, I was 7 years old. Radio was the way you formed your musical brain and mine was hungry. It was a good time for that. The pop airwaves were almost completely integrated. The Stones, the Beatles, and CCR mingled with Stevie Wonder, Marvin Gaye, the Temptations, the Isleys, the Jacksons and even the Osmonds into one dizzying sonic mix. I learned to love practically everything. But some things leapt out.

title: Intersection Video: Bold on Burnside
description: In the latest installment of the Intersection street style video series, we headed up to Burnside and Grand Avenues in the Bronx and met residents who draw style inspiration anywhere from Rihanna to the No. 4 train. We interviewed Tiffany Trinidad, a student at the High School of Fashion Industries, who sews her own clothes and praises Kanye West for bringing leather back.

title: Darren Johnson
description: Darren Johnson on how the hoarding taskforce works.

title: Cuts Impact Is Severe, F.A.A. Chief Tells Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Amid an increasingly partisan atmosphere, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration told skeptical Republicans on Wednesday that automatic budget cuts had forced the F.A.A. to run somewhat like a starving airline: it has reduced its inventory of spare parts, stopped hiring and training new employees, and cut back on modernization.

title: Minaret on a Storied Syrian Mosque Falls
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fighting between Syrian insurgents and government forces in Aleppo left one of the Middle Easts most storied mosques severely damaged on Wednesday, its soaring minaret toppled by explosives. Each side accused the other of responsibility for the destruction at the Umayyad Mosque in Aleppos walled ancient city, a Unesco World Heritage site.

title: Rising Violence in Iraq Spurs Fears of New Sectarian War
description: BAGHDAD  In what appeared to be a new phase in an intensifying conflict that has raised fears of greater bloodshed and a wider sectarian war, Iraqi soldiers opened fire from helicopters on Sunni gunmen hiding in a northern village on Wednesday, officials said.

title: A New Approach to Cutting Health Costs
description: A strategy offers financial incentives for health care providers to cut costs by keeping patients out of the hospital.

title: Shopping Snapshots: April 25
description: Culottes are just the thing for the in-between season; F-Troupe has colorful canvas espadrilles; Saturdays Surf NYC has rain gear for men; and Basta Surfs neoprene swimwear.

title: F.A.A. Chief Testifies
description: Michael Huerta, administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, testified before a House Appropriations subcommittee about the effect of automatic budget cuts on air travel. (C-SPAN)

title: Russian Opposition Leader Asserts Innocence at Trial
description: MOSCOW  Aleksei A. Navalny, the opposition leader and one of the most prominent politicians to go on trial in modern Russia, used his first full day in court on Wednesday to say the trial would prove his innocence, even if the judge convicted him.

title: Soybean Harvest
description: In Chacabuco, Argentina, soybeans are loaded onto a truck on Thursday. Argentina is one of the worlds leading exporters of soybeans.

title: John Drews
description: John Drews on how the hoarding taskforce works.

title: How Do You Find the Best Green Cars?
description: Spring is in the air, and Earth Day is just behind us. Apparently, that means its green car choosing season, at least for the people who take the time to determine such things. But with the list of more environmentally friendly cars and trucks at an all-time high, choosing the best one can be tough.

title: Capital One Settles Accusations It Understated Loan Losses
description: Federal regulators on Wednesday accused Capital One and two of its executives of understating millions of dollars in auto loan losses suffered during the financial crisis.

title: Documenting a Growing Force in Fashion
description: THROUGHOUT THE RECENT and meteoric rise of Asian-Americans in fashion, there have been numerous milestones, as when Alexander Wang was named the creative director of Balenciaga last year, or when Jason Wu designed Michelle Obamas first inaugural gown in 2009 (and her second one this year). Before them, beginning in the 1980s, came a handful of pioneers, like Vera Wang and Anna Sui.

title: New York Bridal Fashion Week | Spring 2014
description: Wedding dress designers debuted their spring 2014 collections last weekend. Here, a selection of our photos.

title: Samsung Delays Release of Security Software for Galaxy Phones
description: In February, Samsung Electronics introduced Knox, a version of Android with security features to make the companys phones more suitable for businesses, expected for release this spring. But the company has delayed the release of the software until summer, according to two people briefed on the companys plans.

title: Irelands New International Food Festival
description: Between them, the collected works of the presenters at the inaugural Ballymaloe Literary Festival of Food and Wine, taking place from May 3 to May 6, would constitute the beginnings of a library, or at least a very impressive cookbook collection. Darina Allen, arguably Irelands most famous cook and visible advocate of its food culture, has lured many of the worlds most revered and prolific food writers to attend the three-day event outside the Irish city of Cork. This is an international food festival with a difference. Far from being staged in the usual hotel ballroom or university lecture hall, it will take place among the bucolic surrounds of Ballymaloe, the family estate made famous first by Myrtle Allens seminal country house restaurant, and then by her daughter-in-law Darinas cooking school and picturesque organic farm.

title: The Bad Economy Behind the Health Care Slowdown
description: In todays paper, I took a look at a major innovation in health care delivery, one that Obama administration officials think might play a big role in holding down health costs in the future. It is called accountable care, and the general idea is to enlist doctors and nurses in the fight to control spending.

title: Scouting Report
description: Collaborations

title: Stepping In for Mayoral Candidates, Surrogates Are Left Out of a Debate
description: As latecomers slipped into their seats on Wednesday for an early morning mayoral debate on housing development, they could have been forgiven for feeling a bit confused.

title: Nice Work to Close on Broadway
description: The Broadway musical Nice Work if You Can Get It, a venture involving the heirs of George and Ira Gershwin and several veteran theater producers to showcase famous songs by the brothers, will close on June 15 after 27 preview performances and 478 regular performances, the producers announced on Wednesday. The Jazz Age-style show, which originally paired Tony Award winner Matthew Broderick as a playboy with Tony nominee Kelli OHara as a bootlegger, opened last April to mixed reviews and never caught real fire at the box office. (Ms. OHaras role is now played by Tony nominee Jessie Mueller.)

title: Eggs, Too, May Provoke Bacteria to Raise Heart Risk
description: For the second time in a matter of weeks, a group of researchers reported a link between the food people eat and bacteria in the intestines that can increase the risk of heart attacks.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Boston, Egypt and Greece.

title: Best Actor in a Spritzing Role
description: The Australian actor Eric Bana is known for rugged, physically impressive characters with a sensitive side. But for being a cologne spokesman?

title: U.S. General Sees Hope for Chinese Help on Korea
description: BEIJING  After three days of talks here, Americas top military officer said Wednesday that he believed China wanted to limit the nuclear ambitions of North Korea but that it remained unclear how China would work toward that goal.

title: Third Staal Brother Joins Hurricanes
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The Staals of Thunder Bay, Ontario, are on the verge of becoming only the third family to send as many as four brothers to the N.H.L.

title: Tap a Word in a Sentence Three Times and Its Yours
description: Philtrum. Salubriousness. Thaumaturge. These are three of my favorite words, but theyre not common ones. So you may be reaching for a dictionary right now.

title: Cost of Storm-Debris Removal in City Is at Least Twice the U.S. Average
description: WASHINGTON  The cleanup of New York after Hurricane Sandy has cost taxpayers at least twice as much as the national post-disaster average, according to the Army Corps of Engineers, which city officials selected to help handle the huge job.

title: The High Spark of Low-Heeled Shoes
description: If the mens department is ruled by revenge of the nerds (horn rims, bow ties), womens fashion can look surprisingly like (dare we say?) the triumph of frump. Dowager classics like frame handbags, cardies and costume jewelry are the height of chic  and now comes the low block heel.

title: City Expands Recycling Program to Include Hard Plastics
description: Updated, 6:08 p.m. | New Yorkers, your days of expending precious brain cells trying to determine whether that yogurt cup or plastic takeout container goes in the trash or the recycling bin have come to an end.

title: Taking the Paraguayan Route to Iguaz Falls
description: Visitors to Iguaz Falls, the 1.7-mile-long snaking series of waterfalls that is South Americas chaotic response to buttoned-down Niagara, have three choices: one, the Brazilian side (where its spelled Iguau), known for its panoramic views of thefalls; or two, the Argentine side, with its pathways winding above, below and all but straight through the tumbling cascades.

title: Time Magazine Honors 100 Influential People
description: The annual Time 100 gala, held this year on Tuesday night, is the kind of place where politicians (Joe Biden) fraternize with celebrities (a cleavage-baring Christina Aguilera.)

title: Successful Shoulders, Rubbing Together
description: The Time 100 gala is the kind of event at which politicians (Joe Biden) fraternize with celebrities (a cleavage-baring Christina Aguilera); hedge fund managers (David Einhorn) share the red carpet with reality TV stars (Padma Lakshmi) and senators (Rand Paul); singers (Raphael Saadiq) try to catch the eye of moguls (Harvey Weinstein), explaining, I hear Harvey is a live guy, and celebrities confess their crushes on other celebrities.

title: Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan
description: The Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan, started on Monday and will finish on Friday.

title: Mark Odom
description: Mark Odom on how the hoarding taskforce works.

title: On One Phone App, Looks Are Everything
description: The quickest hookups in New York these days arent happening behind the velvet ropes of No. 8, on the bar stools of Dorrians or in the coed bathroom of the Electric Room.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Families are in distress this month: a high school student may or may not have jumped from the roof of her private school; a suburban marriage frays at the seams; an adventurous teenager learns about the mother she never knew; and a woman flees a polygamous cult with her two daughters in tow.

title: Zuckerberg Unbound
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: Goodell Meets With Browns Owner
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell met Tuesday with Cleveland Browns owner Jimmy Haslam, whose truck stop company, Pilot Flying J, has been raided by the F.B.I. and I.R.S. and is under investigation for allegedly failing to pay rebates owed to trucking customers.

title: Lauren Bush Lauren Is Making a Name for Herself
description: For Lauren Bush Lauren, the strikingly attractive niece of one president and the granddaughter of another, as well as the daughter-in-law of a legendary figure in the world of American fashion, its not easy to go unnoticed.

title: Unmanned Killers, and the Men Behind Them
description: Over the last couple of years, numerous authors have reported on specific aspects of Americas counterterrorism effort, including the Navy SEAL team operations, the bin Laden raid, other targeted killings and the drone strikes.

title: Cora Viega
description: Cora Viega on her role within the Orange County Taskforce on Hoarding.

title: N.F.L. Will Advise Teams on Discrimination Policy
description: The N.F.L. will distribute to its teams in the next few weeks an information sheet that will reinforce its antidiscrimination policy and will lay out in detail what constitutes discrimination based on sexual orientation and what team members can do about it. The distribution of the information sheet comes after players said they were asked during the Scouting Combine if they liked girls.

title: Eric Hull
description: Eric Hull on how the hoarding taskforce works.

title: Dina Bagues
description: Dina Bagues on how the hoarding taskforce works.

title: Making a Name by Uncovering a Lost Case
description: The news, when it came, was short and sweet. Standing on a Florida golf course last week, Gilbert King looked at his phone and saw a two-word text message from an old friend: Dude. Pulitzer.

title: Dark Songs Pierced With Rays of Cheer
description: Would the baritone Nathan Gunn have done things differently had he known that the concert he presented on Monday night at Zankel Hall would take place during the early blush of spring rather than the waning weeks of winter? The program, planned for February and delayed by illness, found him joined by the pianist Julie Gunn, his wife, and the Pacifica Quartet for a darkish mix of songs with English texts.

title: Obamas Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
description: DALLAS  President Obama has left little mystery about how he views his predecessor. The failed policies of George W. Bush wiped away a budget surplus and squandered the legacy of bipartisan foreign policy. Mr. Bush put two wars on a credit card, led the country away from our values and crashed the economy.

title: Memories of a Bedtime Book Club
description: The wine boxes and masking tape are out, because Ive begun to pack up the last, best books in my childrens picture book library.

title: For Northwestern, a Second Home at Wrigley
description: CHICAGO  It has been something of a challenge for Northwesterns athletic teams to leave a footprint in Chicago, the nations third-biggest media market, when they play their home games in suburban Evanston, where the university is located.

title: Domingo Zapatas Best-Known Work May Be Himself
description: Some artists shun the spotlight, letting galleries promote their work while they keep to their studios. Others are savvier, stoking just enough buzz to get the art cognoscentis attention.

title: Luminous Time Capsule, Bobbing Alongside the Present
description: Jonas Mekas calls his blissed-out new movie Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man. Its an honest, direct title for a transcendently lovely and delicate work created from images that didnt make it into the filmed diaries he made from 1960 to 2000. During those years, he produced some of his most enduring films, like Walden and Lost Lost Lost. He also published I Had Nowhere to Go, his often haunting memoir that traces his early life as a Lithuanian refugee during World War II, and his later struggles both as a displaced person in Europe after the war and then as an immigrant living, working, yearning and shooting his first films in New York City.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitter Corrections and YouTube Money
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Welcoming the Gods Back to Their Majestic Gloaming
description: Perhaps it is time to stop talking about the machine. Sure, Robert Lepages 45-ton set for the Metropolitan Operas current production of Wagners Ring cycle is loud, gimmicky and exorbitantly expensive. But so are many top restaurants in this city and that has never stopped New Yorkers from clambering over one another to get a table.

title: All Systems Are Go, and Tested
description: The alto saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman puts his trust in systems, though hes too rigorous to let any premise go untested. During his first set at the Stone in the East Village on Tuesday night, he kept setting up patterns and disrupting them, in variable cycles. Working as usual with Five Elements, his flagship band, he created the feeling of a meticulously honed aesthetic subjected to unrelenting pressure.

title: Scaling Up a Classic Style
description: People looking for vintage hooked rugs cant always find what they want in the size they need. Our customers were always asking for something larger, said Ramin Hakimi, a partner with Kevin Rahmanan in Rahmanan Antique & Decorative Rugs, a dealer in antique and vintage carpets. To meet the demand, the men started an offshoot company, the New England Collection, reproducing, in modern sizes, designs taken from their inventory of classic American hooked rugs. The range now also includes rag rugs, needlepoints and flat-woven styles, including dhurries, Aubussons, and Persian-style kilims. The monochromatic design shown here was adapted from a 19th-century New England model, with tweaks to the palette and pattern. It was woven in cotton on different-size hooks to create a variation in depth. The 6-by-9-foot carpet is $3,942. Information: (212) 683-0167 or necrugs.com.

title: Sales at Eskayel, Serena and Lily and Others
description: Eskayel is taking 35 percent off all pillows, through Sunday (the 24-inch square Dynasty Pillow in slate, regularly $225, is about $146); (347) 703-8084,eskayel.com.

title: A Table That Is Pure but Not Simple
description: If the Frazier side table, by the architecture and furniture design firm Khouri Guzman Bunce Ltd., looks old, that may be because its materials are borrowed from other industries. The top is borosilicate glass intended for telescope lenses and lab equipment. (The glass is available with a mirrored finish, which makes the subtle, character-building imperfections stand out even more.) The base is silicon bronze, with a 95 percent copper content, the most durable of all bronzes, and one that is used primarily for sculpture casting. (The base is also available in brass, blackened steel and nickel.) Rather than welded, these two pieces are screwed together, which produces a visually light effect and reveals that the frame is solid metal, rather than plated. You can go anywhere and find a plated table, said David Khouri, a partner in the firm. I want people to think about how this ones made. A standard-size table is 22.5 inches high and 19.5 inches wide. Prices start at $7,250: (212) 420-7866 or kgb-limited.com.

title: Brightening Up a Cancer Centers Thrift Shop
description: In February, the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center asked the textile and carpet designer Madeline Weinrib to transform its charity thrift shop on the Upper East Side into an occasional pop-up boutique for designer sample sales. With all the consignment shops around, and people selling their furniture on eBay, it has taken a lot of business away from the charity thrift shops, said Ms. Weinrib, who is based in Manhattan. From May 3 to 5, she will fill the 2,500-square-foot space at 1440 Third Avenue with pillows, rugs, rolls of fabric to be sold by the yard, clothing, handbags, totes, napkins and furniture. Products will be sold at 40 to 70 percent off retail. Eighteen-inch-square pillows, shown above and below, originally $350 to $575, will be $179 to $299. Home delivery is not available, but even rugs and furniture pieces will be small enough to carry. The sale will take place from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 535-1250.

title: Check In Under Jay
description: Fans of The Great Gatsby may recall that the novels title character frequented the Plaza in Manhattan. So did F. Scott Fitzgerald, and in homage to the author and to the new Baz Luhrmann movie remake of his masterpiece, the hotel has created the Fitzgerald Suite.

title: How a Dogg Became a Lion
description: The rechristening of Snoop Dogg (n Snoop Doggy Dogg) into Snoop Lion, the extremely chill reggae superhero, at first didnt seem much like an evolution. Hed long been low-key, long had an air of knowing semi-spirituality, long been preoccupied with smoking weed. Did he really need to don Rastafarian drag too?

title: Quinn to Allow Vote on a Profiling Bill
description: Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, said on Wednesday that she would not support a proposed bill to open state courts to claims of racial profiling by the Police Department, but would allow the bills sponsors to submit it for a vote.

title: Yard Shows Are Becoming Harder to Find
description: The Tin Man sent his regrets.

title: Scrap-Iron Elegy
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  For a long time, Joe Minter managed to share a yard with his wife, Hilda, their two sons and 100,000 of their neighbors. His scruffy three-bedroom house filled up most of a small city lot, just up the hill from Martin Luther King Jr. Drive. But somehow he made it work.

title: One of the Last Great Yard Shows in Alabama
description: Joe Minters African Village is an ever-expanding sculptural display that surrounds his Birmingham, Ala., home.

title: Umbrella Stands
description: What New Yorker hasnt amassed a random collection of umbrellas, from the $5 one bought on the street during a rainstorm to the full-size model that never seems to work on narrow sidewalks?

title: Shopping for Umbrella Stands
description: Shopping for umbrella stands with Emanuel Frattini Magusson.

title: From Ingenious to the Fantastical
description: The lofts of 135 Plymouth Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn.

title: The Art of Digging In
description: The ceiling of Mark Winkels apartment sprouts foam flowers as big as a mans torso, several trapeze swings and a half-dozen chandeliers and pendant lights entwined with 1,000 roses. These last flourishes are the remnants of a Valentines Day brunch that Mr. Winkel, a puckish 37-year-old events producer who favors suits and ties (even at home), held for a few friends.

title: How Does a Chair Look Presidential?
description: In the Bush family, Texas jockeys with Maine as the favored homeland, a theme that seems to have continued with the George W. Bush Presidential Center, on the campus of Southern Methodist University, in Dallas. It opens May 1 and is furnished throughout by Thos. Moser, the Auburn, Me., producer of handmade furniture.

title: Your Chance to Snoop
description: Spring, when nature puts itself on open display, is also the season for peeking into private havens. Scores of house and garden tours are being organized, from Brooklyn to San Francisco, and will continue through the fine months. Heres your chance to see hidden gardens in Boston or midcentury modern houses in Philadelphia. Or you can take in kitchen-focused residences in Larchmont, N.Y. (with tastings from local chefs). Many of the events are fund-raisers, so while youre contemplating a reflecting pool or admiring a connoisseurs art collection, your entry fees will be at work. Unless otherwise noted, all tours are self-guided.

title: Gawking Encouraged
description: A guide to house tours around the country.

title: Now Listening | Luke Winslow-King
description: At the age of 19, the New Orleans-based musician Luke Winslow-King, originally from Cadillac, Michigan, set out for a domestic tour with his blues band singing Woody Guthrie songs. But when they finally made it to the Big Easy, their car was stolen, with all their instruments inside. Most everything was later recovered, and so the city  coupled with the fact that they were able to borrow instruments from supportive locals to continue their tour  left a big impression on the young artist. Its almost like these things happened in my life that changed my course, but put me back to where I needed to be, says Winslow-King, who then quickly moved to the Crescent City, where he started busking on Frenchmen Street while studying music at the University of New Orleans.

title: Scientist Says Pollution From China Is Killing a Japanese Islands Trees
description: YAKUSHIMA, Japan  A mysterious pestilence has befallen this islands primeval forests, leaving behind the bleached, skeletal remains of dead trees that now dot the dark green mountainsides. Osamu Nagafuchi, an environmental engineer with a passion for the island and its rugged terrain, believes he knows the culprit: airborne pollutants from smog-belching China, hundreds of miles upwind.

title: Niese Likely to Start on Sunday
description: One day after he was knocked out of a game when he took a comebacker to his right ankle, Jon Niese said he expected to make his next scheduled start, Sunday against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Europe Struggles in Shale Gas Race
description: IN eastern Poland, politicians are still hoping to join the shale gas energy revolution, but lately they have had to curb their enthusiasm.

title: When Algae on the Exterior Is a Good Thing
description: AS an energy source, algae may be growing up.

title: Mobile Chargers Prepare for Their Day in the Sun
description: WHETHER youre comparing restaurant menus while sitting in the park or turning on the air-conditioner before getting home, life is becoming increasingly mobile thanks to smartphones and tablets. And with new apps appearing constantly, the possibilities for this kind of connected living could be endless  if only the batteries lasted long enough.

title: How to Charge Millions of Electric Cars? Not All at Once
description: PROPONENTS of electric vehicles like to talk about a not-too-distant future when plug-in cars become ubiquitous, with millions being driven by their owners on the daily commute.

title: By 2023, a Changed World in Energy
description: HOUSTON

title: Slow Start on Environment in Second Obama Term
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Next Nuclear Reactor May Arrive Hauled by a Truck
description: WASHINGTON

title: From Power Plant to Civic Renewal Centerpiece
description: THE work starts next month and, once it is complete in about two years, a revitalized 7.8-acre site at the edge of downtown Austin, Tex., will offer new office spaces, shops and a high-rise apartment complex along Lady Bird Lake.

title: Power Grids Iffy, Populous Areas Go for Generators
description: AFTER Tropical Storm Irene pummeled the Northeast in 2011, Keith and Barbara Wolff realized it was time to act. Though they were spared during Irene, several other storms had cut the power to their home in Brookfield, Conn., forcing them to throw out food, wear sweaters to keep warm and find coffee shops to recharge their cellphones and laptops.

title: Harvard Medical School Plans to Close Primate Research Lab
description: About 2,000 monkeys at a Harvard Medical School research center will be moved to other laboratories around the country as the school shuts down the troubled center, an official with the National Institutes of Health said Wednesday.

title: Playing With Light in the Darkness
description: Every other year, the Festival des Arts Visuels, which is devoted to photography and held in Vevey, Switzerland, selects an artist to receive $42,000 to fund a new project. As a member of the festivals jury last week, I helped review the work of 750 photographers from 63 countries. The winner was Augustin Rebetez, a young Swiss whose photos, videos and drawings can be frightening yet weirdly playful and touching. Awkward home scenes, with walls that come to life and beds that breathe, are filled with demented twists and creepy characters. The fairytale world of his videos is as unsettling as the early work of David Lynch and the claymation art of Nathalie Djurberg  but also tender in the way that Tim Burtons work can be.

title: Some Love for 3 Achy Workhorses Linking Staten Island and New Jersey
description: As a child, Angela Goethals had a fantasy about the 7,100-foot-long structure between Staten Island and Elizabeth, N.J., that she still calls my bridge, even though it no more belonged to her than the George Washington Bridge belonged to Washingtons heirs or the Lincoln Tunnel belonged to Lincolns.

title: The Ad Campaign: Quinn, Development Interests and the Closing of a Hospital
description: Critics of Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on Wednesday released an attack ad asserting that Ms. Quinn allowed St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village to close three years ago. The critics political committee, called NYC Is Not For Sale 2013, says that its mission is to defeat Ms. Quinns mayoral bid and that it does not represent any particular candidate. Its leaders are from Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group which opposes horse-drawn carriages; and Wendy Kelman Neu, chief executive of Hugo Neu Corporation, a recycling company. The ad is to air on television.

title: New Technology Inspires a Rethinking of Light
description: AFTER the joy of the birth itself, parenthood sometimes brings the unwelcome news that a newborn has jaundice and must wear goggles and be placed under special lights. Imagine how different this experience might be if there were no goggles, just a warm blanket covering the tiny body, a healing frequency of blue light emanating from its folds.

title: Paid Games on Smartphones Expected to Outpace Hand-Held Consoles
description: When I was a kid I carried around a little backpack that held my Nintendo Gameboy, a Sega Game Gear and several dozen game cartridges for each portable system. Todays children simply carry around a smartphone and can play hundreds of thousands of games on a single device. No backpack or external game cartridges are required.

title: 2 U.S. Agencies Added Boston Bomb Suspect to Watch Lists
description: WASHINGTON  Despite being told in 2011 that an F.B.I. review had found that a man who went on to become one of the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings had no ties to extremists, the Russian government asked the Central Intelligence Agency six months later for whatever information it had on him, American officials said Wednesday.

title: Ranking Top 5 Running Backs in N.F.L. Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: The Digital Ad Industry Gets Dressed Down in Washington
description: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, a West Virginia Democrat, lambasted the digital advertising industry on Wednesday for failing to voluntarily honor privacy requests from online consumers called Do Not Track signals.

title: Wikipedias Sexism Toward Female Novelists
description: I JUST noticed something strange on Wikipedia. It appears that gradually, over time, editors have begun the process of moving women, one by one, alphabetically, from the American Novelists category to the American Women Novelists subcategory. So far, female authors whose last names begin with A or B have been most affected, although many others have, too.

title: Westchester Leader Acts on a Fair-Housing Bill
description: Facing a threat of a contempt lawsuit by the Justice Department, the Westchester County executive, Robert P. Astorino, sent county legislators a letter on Wednesday asking them to pass a law forbidding landlords to discriminate against renters based on their source of income, as required under the countys 2009 fair-housing settlement.

title: Evidence and Economic Policy
description: Henry Blodget says that the economic debate is over; the austerians have lost and whatshisname has won. And its definitely true that in sheer intellectual terms, this is looking like an epic rout. The main economic studies that supposedly justified the austerian position have imploded; inflation has stayed low; the bond vigilantes have failed to make an appearance; the actual economic effects of austerity have tracked almost exactly what Keynesians predicted.

title: Barclays and Credit Suisse Post Strong Earnings in Investment Banks
description: LONDON  As European policy makers push financial institutions to cut back on their risky trading activity, some of the regions largest banks are becoming more reliant on their investment banking operations to bolster performance.

title: Ex-Carnival Operator Admits Bribing Lawmaker for Permits
description: A former carnival operator pleaded guilty on Wednesday to lying to federal agents about paying more than $10,000 to a lawmaker to secure permits for his carnival business.

title: Feared Fiend to Gentle Friend
description: Anyone familiar with cable television knows that plenty of adults believe in monsters. But the parents of Wanda, the heroine of the new family musical Wandas Monster, must not be fans of series like Finding Bigfoot. Wanda cant convince them or her brother that a creature lives in her closet.

title: Hallucinogens Lead to Arias
description: In 2007, if Joseph Kecklers largely autobiographical new work, I Am an Opera, is to be believed, Mr. Keckler had a bad trip on hallucinogenic mushrooms.

title: Trying to Burnish Its Image, J.&J. Turns to Emotions
description: FOR the corporate overseers at Johnson & Johnson, the last few years have been a challenge.

title: The N.P.P.A.s Best of Photojournalism
description: The National Press Photographers Association announced the winners of its 2013 Best of Photojournalism contest on Tuesday.

title: Rents Still Too High, So a Former Candidate Is Back
description: Its finally a mayoral race. Jimmy McMillan, bewhiskered avatar of the Rent Is Too Damn High party, entered the scrum on Wednesday with the Rent Is Too Damn High anthem, a song and video produced for him by the folks at the blog AnimalNewYork.

title: Building Collapse Near Dhaka, Bangladesh
description: The collapse of an eight-story building in Bangladesh that housed several garment factories injured hundreds of people.

title: Texas Fertilizer Plant Fell Through Regulatory Cracks
description: WEST, Tex.  In the moments after a fire broke out at a fertilizer plant here last week, some of the volunteer firefighters and other first responders who rushed to the scene appeared to have known that there were tons of dangerously combustible ammonium nitrate inside, but others did not.

title: Investigations Expand in Hacking of A.P. Twitter Feed
description: Three federal agencies are now investigating an incident Tuesday in which hackers hijacked the Twitter account for The Associated Press and momentarily erased $136 billion from the stock market after they posted a fake Tweet reporting that there had been explosions at the White House that injured President Obama.

title: Boom Times in Paraguay Leave Many Behind
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  Walk into the headquarters of the central bank of Paraguay, a sprawling seven-story structure surrounded by flowering silk floss trees, and the message is clear: officials proudly display charts showing a dizzying economic boom, with growth reaching 13 percent this year, making Paraguay the fastest-growing country in the Americas.

title: House Majority Leaders Quest to Soften G.O.P.s Image Hits a Wall Within
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader, has been trying for months to remake the image of the Republican Party, from one of uncompromising conservatism to something kinder and gentler.

title: Amazon Plans an Internet Video Device
description: SEATTLE  Amazon created the Kindle to breathe life into electronic books. Now it is preparing a device to bring Internet video to television sets.

title: Revenue in Decline, Zynga Promotes a Game Sequel
description: Zynga just cannot win.

title: Free College Options Still Exist, for Those Willing to Build Ships, Milk Cows or Salute
description: When the trustees of Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art voted this week to start charging for an undergraduate degree, it ended the institutions lengthy reign as the most famous tuition-free private college in America.

title: Marcum Joins the Mets
description: Shaun Marcum on Wednesday settled into his Citi Field locker inside the Mets clubhouse for the first time since signing with the team this winter.

title: Are Myanmars Hopes Fading?
description: CHIANG MAI, Thailand

title: No Room for Radicals
description: JUST hours after the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing were identified as Muslims, Representative Peter T. King of New York, the Republican chairman of the House Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence, called for an increased surveillance of Islamic communities in the United States. I think we need more police and more surveillance in the communities where the threat is coming from, he told National Review. The new threat is definitely from within.

title: Learning From China, but What?
description: BEIJING

title: A Draft Short on Passers but Long on Talent
description: They headed to Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan last year bearing posters labeled Hope, with the face of the president of the United States replaced by that of a quarterback  a cluster of fans who would start chanting Robert Griffin IIIs name well before the Washington Redskins were even on the clock.

title:
U.S. Says It
Suspects Assad
Used Chemical
Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  The White House said on Thursday that American intelligence agencies now assess, with varying degrees of confidence, that the Syrian government has used chemical weapons, but it said it needed conclusive proof before President Obama would take action.

title: Politics of Paranoia
description: Out-of-control federal government. An immediate and immense Muslim threat. Gun grabbing, national registries and eventual mass confiscations. Tyranny.

title: Joint Effort Seeks Drugs for Autism
description: With the diagnosis of autism on the rise and drug companies facing major setbacks in developing successful treatments, the University of California, Los Angeles will lead a $9 million effort financed by the National Institute of Mental Health to find effective drugs, officials said Wednesday.

title: Canadas Oil Minister, Unmuzzled
description: The last time your friendly scribe sought an interview with Joe Oliver, Canadas minister of natural resources, he was turned down flat. It was February last year. Oliver had made a series of impolitic remarks about the efforts to block the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which, if its ever built, would import oil from the tar sands of Alberta to refineries along the Gulf Coast  and which Canadians believe that the United States would be nuts to reject.

title: Corporate Donations and the S.E.C.
description: The Supreme Courts Citizens United decision that triggered an avalanche of corporate political spending also contained a proposal for greater public disclosure from corporations that would prefer to write their checks in the shadows. Transparency, the court advised, would let voters decide for themselves whether elected officials are in the pocket of so-called moneyed interests.

title: Updating an E-Mail Law From the Last Century
description: Steven Warshak, a Cincinnati businessman who built an empire selling male sexual enhancement drugs, was convicted of wire fraud several years ago, based in large part on his e-mail correspondence, which authorities had extracted via a subpoena under a 1986 law governing electronic privacy.

title: Were Chemical Weapons Used in Syria?
description: Its not hard to imagine that President Bashar al-Assad, desperately clinging to power, might use chemical weapons against the Syrian people. He has already pummeled them with warplanes and missiles and shows no signs of ending a bloody onslaught that has lasted more than two years. But while he may be capable of using weapons of mass destruction, there is no proof that he has done so.

title: Moving Past the Last Balkan War
description: At a time of disillusionment about the state of the European Union, a diplomatic deal between Serbia and Kosovo highlights some of the more positive features of the institution that won last years Nobel Peace Prize but fumbled the euro crisis. The tentative agreement signed last Friday not only shows that the European Union can perform well but also that it remains an attractive destination for countries that aspire to membership.

title: Jets Remodeler Refined His Style Over the Years
description: John Idzik worked in the Tampa Bay front office in 1997 when the Buccaneers set out in the draft to improve the N.F.L.s lowest-scoring offense. They focused on a certain running back, and after ascertaining that another team was also in pursuit, they maneuvered to select him with the 12th pick.

title: On Beyond Fear
description: The homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, testified on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the Senates bipartisan immigration bill. For hours, in a calm and methodical manner, she flipped each confrontational line of questioning on its head. No, the bill would not loosen security at borders and ports. It would tighten it. The bill would not weaken immigration enforcement, but strengthen it  adding resources and improving the governments ability to keep unwanted people out and to catch fugitives, identify thieves and terrorists.

title: Unit Aims to Improve Citys Elections Board
description: A New York City agency said on Wednesday that it was creating a unit to investigate fraud, waste and corruption problems at the Board of Elections, long a bte noire of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: 2 Tangled Lives Collide, Again, in Ricin Case
description: TUPELO, Miss.  Paul Kevin Curtis and James Everett Dutschke have a lot in common, though they would probably not like to think of it that way.

title: Is the Hijab Worth Fighting Over?
Defending the Indigent
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Sex Trafficking
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. and A. at Bush Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Flaws, Bronx Courts Aim for Swift Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Joy (and Despair) of Cooking
As Bird Flu Spreads to Taiwan, Governments Act to Prepare
description: BEIJING  The new strain of avian influenza that has infected more than 100 people in China in the last two months has, for the first time, been reported outside mainland China.

title: Despair Drives Guantnamo Detainees to Revolt
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  In the early afternoon quiet, guards in camouflage fatigues walked the two-tiered cellblocks of Camp Six, where the most cooperative of the 166 terrorism suspects held in the military prison here are housed. From a darkened control room, other guards watched banks of surveillance monitors showing prisoners in white clothing  pacing, sleeping or reading  in their cells.

title: Streaming on Yahoo, Its S.N.L.
description: When they were performing on Saturday Night Live three decades ago, Al Franken, Bill Murray and Eddie Murphy surely didnt expect they would ever be streamed on computers and phones. In fact, they probably would have made fun of the idea.

title: GE Capital Cuts Gun Shop Purchase Loans
description: GE Capital, General Electrics lending arm, recently stopped offering consumer financing programs to retailers whose main business is selling guns, in response to the industry changes, new legislation and tragic events.

title: A Three-Way Battle for Two Playoff Spots
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Thursdays games could decide the postseason fates of the Rangers, the Winnipeg Jets and the Ottawa Senators, who are fighting for the last two playoff spots in the Eastern Conference. Or, the suspense could drag out a little longer.

title: Officers Killing Spurred Pursuit in Boston Attack
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Officer Sean A. Collier was 27, not much older than the Massachusetts Institute of Technology students he watched over as a campus police officer, and he sometimes joined them in a game of darts or Xbox. So when an ambulance staffed by students rolled past his parked patrol car last Thursday night, he flashed his blue lights to say hello. The students answered with their red lights.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 24, 2013

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Apr. 25, 2013
description: The situation is not sustainable. We need an exit strategy.

title: If Not Yellen at the Fed, Perhaps One of These
description: Handicapping the candidates to succeed Ben S. Bernankeas Federal Reserve chairman has much in common with predicting the outcome of a golf tournament: Theres a good chance that the winner will not be one of the early favorites.

title: Possible Fed Successor Has Admirers and Foes
description: WASHINGTON  In July 1996, the Federal Reserve broke the metronomic routine of its closed-door policy-making meetings to hold an unusual debate. The Feds powerful chairman, Alan Greenspan, saw a chance for the first time in decades to drive annual inflation all the way down to zero, achieving the price stability he had long regarded as the central banks primary mission.

title: In a First, Judge Orders Legal Aid for Mentally Disabled Immigrants Facing Deportation
description: A federal judge in California has ordered immigration courts in three states to provide legal representation for immigrants with mental disabilities who are in detention and facing deportation, if they cannot represent themselves. The decision is the first time a court has required the government to provide legal assistance for any group of people before the nations immigration courts.

title: Boston Attack Spotlights Struggle Half a World Away
description: KIZILYURT, Russia  With an automatic weapon at his side and a black flag behind him, the Islamic rebel explained in a video why he had gone to war with his government. As is often the case in the broiling Muslim insurgency here in the North Caucasus, his complaints were intensely local: a police commander had announced a policy of harassing and threatening family members of suspected militants.

title: Crazy Talk
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This is the type of puzzle where the reveal hits you in two parts: first, you might have filled in enough of the four theme answers  a diverse list of items, to say the least  and noticed the payoff at 50 Across to note that certain letters in the theme answer make up a magicians phrase.

title: Corrections: April 25, 2013
description: INTERATIONAL

title: A Schmoozy Cobra, About to Be Bitten
description: Chances are you are not a movie star. Chances are equally good that this state of affairs is not likely to change soon. But if youve ever wondered what it might be like to explore that golden realm where the gods and goddesses of the screen dwell, race over to the Booth Theater, where you can enjoy an audience with a woman who consorted almost exclusively with box office luminaries, or twinklies as she affectionately calls them.

title: Subtler Harm From Bombs: Some Victims Lose Hearing
description: Initially preoccupied by the severe injuries sustained by victims of the Boston bombings, hospitals are now grappling with a more subtle medical consequence: widespread hearing loss among those closest to the blasts.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,182 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Ascendant German Clubs Signal Shift in Continental Power
description: Changes in the balance of power in Europe can take centuries, but when it comes to soccer, a revolution happened swiftly, in 180 minutes on the field. For the second consecutive day, a German club not only defeated but also thoroughly outplayed a Spanish one.

title: Trinity Church Split on How to Manage $2 Billion Legacy of a Queen
description: There has never been any doubt that Trinity Church is wealthy. But the extent of its wealth has long been a mystery; guessed at by many, known by few.

title: At Trial, Liu Aide Tells of Offering to Reimburse Campaign Donors
description: A longtime aide to John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and current Democratic candidate for mayor, testified on Wednesday that she had offered to reimburse donors for their contributions to Mr. Lius campaign, a tactic that prosecutors have said was part of an illegal fund-raising strategy used by some Liu aides.

title: Gases to Be Dispersed Across City (Exhale: Its a Test)
description: On three separate days this July, invisible and odorless gases will be released in subway stations and at street level in all five boroughs of New York City. But officials in the New York Police Department will not be alarmed  it was their idea.

title: Syrias Shifting Strategy
description: As the war continues, Syrian officials are trying to convince Western countries that they should not support rebel forces, saying many are extremists allied with Al Qaeda.

title: From Terrorizing Streets to Making Them Safer
description: In its blunt retelling of Central Harlem, the documentary opens with Dedric Hammond standing in front of a Chinese takeout restaurant near the spot where he was shot the first time. Bullets had a circular presence in his life, beginning when he was known on the streets simply as Bad News, a name he got for being a shooter.

title: Knicks Have Bostons Numbers: Up 2, 2 to Go
description: The emotions will be powerful Friday night at Bostons TD Garden, a mix of cathartic release and desperation. This much, the Knicks and Celtics both know and expect.

title: Syrian Prisoners Talk, as Jailers Look On
description: Syrian officials picked prisoners to meet with New York Times journalists. Interviewed in front of their jailers, they described a range of goals.

title: Texas: Skepticism on Immigration Law
description: In a preliminary ruling, a federal judge found that the Obama administration violated immigration law with a program last year that offered reprieves from deportation to hundreds of thousands of young illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children. The ruling on Tuesday came in a lawsuit brought by immigration enforcement agents against Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano. Judge Reed OConnor rejected most of the administrations arguments and found that the agents were likely to succeed in the case. He delayed a final ruling, asking both sides to submit more information by May 6.

title: Obama Tells Democratic Donors Hell Keep Reaching Out to G.O.P.
description: DALLAS  President Obama vowed Wednesday night to continue trying to work with Republican lawmakers even if doing so irritates some of his Democratic supporters who think he is a sap.

title: Carlesimo and Nets Searching for Right Combinations
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Thibodeau, the coach of the Chicago Bulls, is known as a taskmaster who can run his key players into the ground. In his teams Game 2 victory over the Nets, Thibodeau used nine players who each had at least 10 minutes of action and made important contributions.

title: Syria Plays on Fears to Blunt American Support of Rebels
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  As Islamists increasingly fill the ranks of Syrian rebels, President Bashar al-Assad is waging an energized campaign to persuade the United States that it is on the wrong side of the civil war. Some government supporters and officials believe they are already coaxing  or at least frightening  the West into holding back stronger support for the opposition.

title: Harvey Stumbles, but Mets Prevail With a Slam
description: The Mets scratched their way back late Wednesday, to the point where a simple fly ball would have been enough to give them an unlikely come-from-behind win. They got one, and then some, as Jordany Valdespin crushed a game-ending grand slam that attached a stirring exclamation point onto the their 10-inning, 7-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Citi Field.

title: Wrong Pitch Results in First Loss for Pettitte
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Andy Pettitte clearly did not want to go into a detailed discussion about the curveball that he felt decided the game. He said the location was not the problem. It was the pitch itself.

title: Bob Edgar, Lawmaker and Liberal Leader, Dies at 69
description: Bob Edgar, a Methodist minister who pushed for liberal reforms as a six-term Pennsylvania congressman, a leader of American churches and president of the lobbying group Common Cause, died Tuesday at his home in Burke, Va. He was 69.

title: Suzuki Collects Two Hits and Gets a Promotion
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  After collecting two hits, including the game-winning single in the ninth inning on Tuesday, Ichiro Suzuki was promoted to the No. 2 spot in the batting order Wednesday.

title: Word of the Day | pivotal
description: pivotal \pi-v-tl\ adjective

title: Study Ties Autism Risk to Creases in Placenta
description: After most pregnancies, the placenta is thrown out, having done its job of nourishing and supporting the developing baby.

title: The Shadow Lobbyist
description: There has been a quiet upheaval in the lobbying industry.

title: A Messenger for the Internet of Things
description: The vision of the Internet of Things is inspiring, if much-hyped. Billions of digital devices, from smartphones to sensors in homes, cars and machines of all kinds, will communicate with each other to automate tasks and make life better.

title: South Korea: Ultimatum on Talks
description: South Korea gave North Korea until Friday to respond to its proposal for dialogue on a joint industrial park or face a grave measure on the future of the factory complex, which has been the only remaining symbol of economic cooperation between the two Koreas. A statement from the Souths Unification Ministry stopped short of clarifying whether the decision it was contemplating involved pulling out 176 South Korean managers remaining in the Kaesong factory park in North Korea or even terminating the joint economic project.

title: North Korea Issues Threat at Ceremony for Military
description: SEOUL, South Korea  On an anniversary known for military showmanship, North Korean generals on Thursday declared that their forces were ready to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles and kamikazelike nuclear attacks at the United States if threatened.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) BLACK SWAN (2010) Natalie Portman, above, in the role that earned her an Academy Award, stars as Nina, a ballet dancer teetering on the verge of insanity as she tries to break out of the corps and into the dual lead of Swan Lake: the Swan Queen and her villainous black swan twin. Mila Kunis is Lily, the sultry newcomer who is everything the increasingly tormented Nina is not, as their companys artistic director, Thomas (Vincent Cassel), points out. The result is a witchy brew of madness and cunning, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film, directed by Darren Aronofsky, which also received Oscar nominations for best director, best picture and others.

title: Chinese Opera Performers See Fewer Faces in the Audience
description: BANGKOK  Sleep like dogs, eat like pigs, dress like angels.

title: The Dodgers See Harvey, and Come Away Impressed
