title: A Sustainable Soap Box Racer
description: Teenagers from all over New York City will demonstrate soap-box derby cars they made from recycled materials at a Street Games festival in an East Harlem park on Saturday.

title: Week in Pictures for April 26
description: Subjects include boxings return to Brooklyn, a pop-up poetry jam in the subway and life inside a castle in Amsterdam, N.Y.

title: Wounded by Missing the Playoffs, the Devils Refuse to Blame Injuries
description: NEWARK  Martin Brodeur said he believed that the Devils, who missed the playoffs one year after their stunning run to the Stanley Cup finals, fell victim to the lockout-shortened, 48-game schedule.

title: The Boston Bombing and Immigration
description: In the days since the Boston marathon attack, a number of Republican lawmakers have demanded a delay in immigration reform because the two bombers were fairly recent immigrants.

title: Big Ticket | 25 Columbus Circle, Sold for $13 Million
description: Perched high in the south tower of the Time Warner Center at 25 Columbus Circle, a glassy corner condominium with unobstructed northern and eastern views of Central Park and the cityscape from every room sold for $13 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: The Largest Falcon Hospital in the World
description: Its in Abu Dhabi, and it has operating rooms, an intensive-care unit and an ophthalmology department.

title: Its Vacation: Lets Go on a Killing Spree!
description: Its a hazard of just about any cross-country trip: irresponsible travelers who mar a beautiful view with litter or are insufferably loud or disrespect the rules of the road. Its not the end of the world, but it can certainly put you off your tea.

title: An Estate Plan for the Not-So-Wealthy
description: The high threshold for the estate tax  $5.25 million, or $10.5 million for a couple  makes it unlikely that most people will have to worry about the tax, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week. But that doesnt mean that most people can forget about an estate plan, he says.

title: Why Communitys Low Ratings Dont Necessarily Mean Cancellation
description: Could NBCs Community be saved from cancellation once again?

title: A Heavy Lift Onto the Screen
description: When Henry Jamess novel What Maisie Knew was published in 1897, the movies were in their infancy  the brothers Lumire had exhibited their first motion pictures just two years earlier  and theres no evidence that in the 19 years of life that remained to James he ever cared a jot for the new medium; it wouldnt have met his standards. The movies have since avenged that slight in a way that seems at least arguably Jamesian: They have paid his work the ambiguous tribute of their attention. Dozens of adaptations of his difficult, delicate fictions have been produced since his death, all trying (and most failing) to capture something of his essence, the elusive beast in the verbal jungle.

title: An Uncertain Lure for Samsungs Digital Store
description: With the release of Samsungs Galaxy S4 smartphone this weekend, the company will open a digital store that offers music, video, games and books.

title: All the Dreaminess of Reality
description: MEXICO CITY  The foremost enfant terrible of Mexican cinema, Carlos Reygadas knows how to get a reaction. Whether serving up bloodshed and deeply unerotic sex in transgressive melodramas like Japn (2002) and Battle in Heaven (2005) or contemplating the enigmas of faith and love in the Mennonite adultery drama Silent Light (2007), his films are invariably primed to stir debate: the shock of the new or the emperors new clothes?

title: Rebuilding, With an Eye on the Rafters
description: DETROIT  The end of the N.H.L. regular season is usually more break time than crunchtime for the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Family, Not Willing to Forget, Pursues Art It Lost to Nazis
description: Lt. Alexandre Rosenberg of the Free French forces pounded on the boxcars. Hold your fire, he told his men. There might be prisoners inside the train they had stopped outside Paris in August 1944. Slowly, a few of the heavy doors slid open, and a handful of worn German soldiers straggled out.

title: Jack McInerney: The New New Thing in M.L.S.
description: The M.L.S season is still young but through the first seven weeks, no player is playing as well as Philadelphia Union forward Jack McInerney.

title: Divorce Whisperer? Mediating With Parents Isnt Easy
description: For some couples, deciding where to seat narcoleptic Uncle Reginald is the least of their wedding planning worries. Those with divorced parents are assured of having quite a few more hours of anxiety as they engage in additional negotiations with them.

title: The Brain: Our Food-Traffic Controller
description: IMAGINE that, instead of this article, you were staring at a plate of freshly baked chocolate chip cookies. The mere sight and smell of them would likely make your mouth water. The first bite would be enough to wake up brain areas that control reward, pleasure and emotion  and perhaps trigger memories of when you tasted cookies like these as a child.

title: Celtic Greens in Boston: A Guidebook in One Color
description: BOSTON  He holds the record for most games in a Boston Celtics uniform, for a player with the surname Green.

title: Financial Opposites in a Life Together
description: Jennifer and Scott Bartone were married in October after a seven-year courtship. But they did not have a serious conversation about money until this week.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: Battleship
description: Is there life after college? If the only horse race you watch is the Kentucky Derby, you might not think so.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom colonial in Harrington Park, N.J., and a five-bedroom stone and cedar contemporary on Long Island.

title: Week in Review: High-Value Domestic Dispute
description: Millionaires clash over socialites child support claims. | Businesses take a wary approach to disclosures using social media. | Market delay in Chicago points again to technology. | Down payment rules are at heart of mortgage debate. | Hazy future for S.E.C.s thriving whistle-blower effort. | Regulators to restrict payday lending. | Fed still owes Congress a blueprint on its emergency lending. | Co-directors for S.E.C. signal shift. | And Andrew Ross Sorkin says that in a tax fight, Amazon handed the baton to eBay.

title: Hes a Mess, and That Makes It Funny
description: You never forget your first time, but the way you recall it changes.

title: Cooking Squid at Home
description: Do you love ordering calamari in restaurants? Melissa Clark shows that its just as easy to prepare squid in your own kitchen.

title: Searing Squid Is a Slippery Task
description: Squid is easy to cook but hard to sear. It releases so much moisture when it hits the pan that it tends to steam rather than brown. And since it cooks so quickly (two to three minutes will do it), it is usually done before much of the liquid evaporates.

title: Their Rules, So Theyll Break Them
description: Fitz and the Tantrums, the kinetic Los Angeles sextet led by Michael Fitzpatrick, emerged in 2009 and was almost immediately lumped into a neo-soul scene with acts like Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Kashmir, Iraq and China.

title: Grants Life
description: Charles Traub embarks on a photographic journey to capture the places made great by Ulysses S. Grants indomitable spirit.

title: Fan of Marriage Makes a Commitment
description: Tracy McMillan is no stranger to drama. Until her reality-series debut on Ready for Love, the new NBC dating show, she was a television writer whose credits included critically lauded series like Mad Men and the United States of Tara. But perhaps the most compelling narrative she can take credit for her is her own life.

title: Back From the Abyss
description: Few companies stocks have recovered from the kind of plunge Netflix experienced in 2011 after it tried to raise prices and spin off its DVD business. But this year its the best-performing stock in the S.& P. 500.

title: Netflix Bounces Back
description: House of Cards was part of Netflixs effort to overcome a bungled attempt to adapt to the digital landscape. James B. Stewart, a columnist for The New York Times, discusses the companys turnaround.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Clinton co-op with two-bedrooms, an Upper West Side apartment with beamed ceilings and a Greenpoint condo with an office and playroom.

title: An Appraisal: George Jones in Real Life and Real Time
description: Early in 1977, a couple of years after he and Tammy Wynette had divorced, the country music star George Jones played a show at the Stardust Inn in Waldorf, Md., his first in the Washington area in several years. I was then a young pop music critic at The Washington Post, so it fell to me to write a profile of the notoriously hard-drinking singer.

title: Squid, or Scallops
description: The video above is a lesson in searing squid, a companion to the recipe in this weeks column: sauteed squid with chiles, mint and lime.

title: Dutch Man Said to Be Held in Powerful Internet Attack
description: Dutch authorities say police officials in Spain have arrested a man believed to be connected to an online attack on a spam-fighting site that snarled the Internet last month.

title: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
description: It was wedged in a narrow, inaccessible space between two buildings, about three blocks from the World Trade Center site. And there it remained, hidden from view, for more than 11 years. Ground zero slowly gave way to a new tower. Protesters gathered nearby, angry over a planned Islamic center.

title: Goodbye, George Jones
description: To honor George Jones, who died today in Nashville, age 81, here is an unusual video. It is a real-life, pulled-from-the-headlines, celebrity-dysfunction, drunken-arrest, legal-mess, career-lowlight reel  that also happens to be a sweet, sweet duet with Dolly Parton:

title: Sweet Deals as Strawberries Glut Market
description: Good news for berry lovers is not so good news for berry farmers.

title: In Promoting His City for 2020 Games, Tokyos Bid Chairman Tweaks Others
description: With less than five months to go before the International Olympic Committee chooses a city to host the 2020 Summer Games, the three remaining bidders  Istanbul, Madrid and Tokyo  are increasing their efforts to win over delegates and the public.

title: Man Sentenced in Plan to Bomb Manhattan Synagogue
description: The man who prosecutors said was the lesser participant in a foiled 2011 plot to blow up the largest synagogue in Manhattan in order to kill Jews and spread fear around the world was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 26
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Redistricting Likely to Hamper Democratic Efforts in 2014, Study Finds
description: Thanks largely to the way Congressional districts were drawn in the latest round of redistricting, even a dramatic wave election like the one in 2008 that swept President Obama into power and added to Democratic majorities in Congress would do little to alter the composition of the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, a new, nonpartisan study found.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 26
description: More photographs.

title: Hula Hoop Marathon in the Buff, in Silence
description: On Wednesday, at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn, a man and a woman, both naked, hula-hooped in silence for 35 minutes. That may sound like a caricature of masturbatory performance art, but most of the work sustained interest, even fascination. To begin with, there was the suspense of whether the performers could keep their hoops going the whole time. They did.

title: Sibling Rivalry
description: Based on the Ford Fusion, the 2013 MKZ reflects Lincolns ongoing attempt to distinguish itself from its Ford relatives.

title: Artifacts | The Rocks at 30 Rock
description: In the age of the camera phone, its human nature to snap away at anything unusual. Those passing through Rockefeller Center over the next seven weeks will no doubt fall prey to that temptation when they encounter Human Nature, a constellation of nine towering bluestone figures that the artist Ugo Rondinone has set on the plaza in front of 30 Rock. No sooner were the giant evocations of fossilized humanity unveiled than they acquired a nickname. Its Ugohenge, the painter Elizabeth Peyton said at a dinner at the Monkey Bar last Tuesday to celebrate the shows opening. Isnt that what everyones calling them?

title: What Is Different About This Explosion?
description: Watch this very brief video clip of a Honda Civic hatchback being destroyed by an explosion from within. Does something seem odd about the blast? (No, the answer is not that the skin of the passenger-side door almost destroyed my camera.)

title: Behind the Scenes in Covering Boston
description: The Timess Richard L. Berke spoke with Katharine Q. Seelye, Boston bureau chief, and Brent McDonald, a video journalist, about the role of smartphones and social media in covering the Boston bombing.

title: Mayoral Candidates Quizzed on Use of Drones
description: Public safety has been a major issue in the campaign for mayor of New York this year, and for weeks the candidates have talked at length about whether they would replace the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, whether they would continue to allow the Police Departments stop-and-frisk practice, and whether the department should be monitored by an inspector general. But on Friday, during a forum on technology, the candidates got a question that posed a new test of their views on police practices: Should the department be allowed to use unmanned drones?

title: The Medium Term Is Not The Message
description: Ezra Klein tries to broker peace:

title: George Joness New York
description: Hardly anybody would have looked for an I  NY bumper sticker on George Joness tour bus. The story of him and New York was he just didnt want to come here, said Jack Grace, a singer and songwriter who books performers for the Rodeo Bar in Manhattan.

title: Your Agenda for Fiscal Health Day
description: A couple of weeks ago, I asked Bucks readers to nominate themselves for a financial tuneup, a day where I would come to their home and help them get through their long list of money-related tasks that have been neglected over the course of the past year.

title: Where Share the Road Is Taken Literally
description: Woonerf is what the Dutch call a special kind of street or group of streets that functions as shared public space  for pedestrians, cyclists, children and, in some cases, for slow-moving, cautiously driven cars as well.

title: Italian Soul, Now Supersize
description: TESTED 2014 Moto Guzzi California 1400 Custom

title: The Secret Ingredient Is Ford Fusion
description: Id like to make a confession: Im a Lincoln owner.

title: Street Smarts: From Holland, Bright Ideas for Highways
description: If cars, traffic and navigation can be smart, is there any reason for roads to remain as dumb as bricks?

title: LivingSocial Hack Exposes Data for 50 Million Customers
description: LivingSocial, the daily deals site, told its employees Friday that it had been breached, and said that data for 50 million users might have been compromised.

title: This Week's Best-Seller Lists
description: The Times's John Williams and Gregory Cowles discuss traits of femininity in "The Athena Doctrine" and Ayn Rand's influence on Iris Johansen, author of "Taking Eve."

title: Debt and Growth Data
description: Ive had some requests for data sources on debt and growth; good point. So, its all in the public domain. The IMF public debt database  offers a downloadable spreadsheet of debt/GDP ratios going back in some cases to 1791. For GDP, the easy source for 1950 onwards is the Total Economy Database; you want the file on output, labor, and labor productivity. If you want to push further into the past, the Maddison Project has spreadsheets going back in some cases to the year 1000.

title: Friday Night Music: More Luscious Lucius
description: Just enjoy.

title: Twitter Shows Its Rude Side
description: What accounts for the galloping lushness of bad manners on Twitter? A recent incident may shed some light.

title: Smuggling a Captive Audience Across a Border
description: Congress is preparing to consider a sweeping reform of the nations immigration system, but one shift in the terms of the public debate is already being signaled: News organizations have recently declared that they will find alternatives to the term illegal immigrants. The point is that although the immigrants may be in the country illegally, they themselves are not illegal.

title: Staying Effervescent Against the Odds
description: The actress Heather Graham, 43, plays a small-town grain-elevator operator in the recently released film At Any Price. Born in Milwaukee, she lives in New York and Los Angeles.

title: A Troubled Introduction for a Crucial New Model
description: DETROIT  The redesigned 2013 MKZ sedan was meant to herald a new era for Lincoln, the longtime luxury division of Ford that was recently rechristened the Lincoln Motor Company. The MKZs arrival, originally set for the late fall of 2012, was ballyhooed in an expensive advertising campaign and an insistent public relations blitz.

title: The Year of the Cat
description: According to the Chinese lunar calendar, the Year of the Snake began on Feb. 10. But by most other standards, 2013 is shaping up to be the Year of the Cat. In the first week of February, Hasbro, makers of the Monopoly board game, announced they were replacing one of the traditional tokens, the flat iron, with a curvaceous silver pussycat. Ailurophobes howled, blaming the all-powerful cat lobby (so teased a reporter on NPR), but the evidence suggests that public taste alone explains the switch. There are 86 million cats in American households, and in a Facebook survey, the nimble cat instantly leapt ahead of the regular Monopoly retinue to become players piece of choice  nearly twice as popular as the Scottie Dog, and three times more popular than the Car and Battleship. Take that, cat detractors!

title: Israel: Military to Stop Using Shells Containing Phosphorus
description: The Israeli military said on Friday that it planned to remove shells containing phosphorus from active use within about a year. The munitions, typically used to illuminate a battlefield or to create a smokescreen to mask troop movements, will be replaced with a new type of shell that uses gas, the military said. Israeli and international human rights organizations accused Israel of using white phosphorus munitions improperly during Israels three-week military offensive against Hamas and other militant groups in Gaza in the winter of 2008-9. Such munitions are not prohibited under international law, but they are not supposed to be used in civilian areas, because white phosphorus is highly flammable and, like napalm, it can burn flesh. Israel maintained that its use of shells containing phosphorus did not violate international law.

title: A Den Mother for Art Spectacles
description: The children were too close to the stanchions, and Anne Pasternak wasnt having it. You cant touch the ropes or the horses wont come visit you, she trilled.

title: The Size of a Gumball, or Bigger Than Jumbo
description: WANTAGE, N.J.  Most mornings outside the gates of Tier Haus Farms here, several cars drive up to investigate the contents of an ordinary-looking cooler. Inside are eggs, freshly collected from beyond the gates by Carolyn Gerdes, an owner of the hilly, 70-acre property. Instead of having a traditional farm stand, Ms. Gerdes accepts orders by text, e-mail and phone for eggs, then leaves them for her regular customers to pick up when she is not available to hand them off directly.

title: At Musical Buffet, the Entree Need Not Be Served First
description: Life is uncertain. Eat dessert first. At first glance, the program for Thursday evenings concert at Alice Tully Hall by the Swedish Chamber Orchestra with the soprano Nina Stemme put me in mind of this much-quoted maxim by Ernestine Ulmer. The substantial fare appeared to have been reserved for the second half, which was given over to Brahmss Symphony No. 1.

title: Electrosoul, With a Heartfelt Sweetness
description: That Coco O could sing was not in question. For about a half-hour on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge, shed been slithery, teasing, sensual, ecstatic. The carefree soul songs of Quadron, the duo for which she is the frontwoman, demand all of those things.

title: The Growing Pains of Jonathan Krohn
description: Its almost a job requirement for a 13-year-old to do things that will make him cringe as an 18-year-old. Some regret a death-metal phase, others a Bieber haircut. Jonathan Krohn says that his big embarrassment is his stint as a conservative pundit.

title: Vows: Marci and Seth
description: An admitted Hebrew school dropout, Seth Lindenman never thought hed marry a rabbi. When he proposed to Rabbi Marci Bellows, he got a whole congregation.

title: A Dinner Menu Brimming With Bacon
description: Corey Wry, a native of Manchester, Conn., went off to culinary school and returned to open three hometown eateries, including a wildly popular burger joint, Coreys Catsup and Mustard, that was featured on Guy Fieris Food Network show Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives. His newest restaurant, the awkwardly named CWs Chops N Catch, offers comfort food at affordable prices.

title: Jets, Picking Geno Smith, Are Talk of the Town Again
description: Minutes before the Jets drafted West Virginia quarterback Geno Smith on Friday night with the 39th pick, the NFL Network analyst Mike Mayock exclaimed that he didnt believe Smith would land in New York because hes perhaps not a franchise quarterback and it would create a circus.

title: Sauvignon Blanc, Suited to the Season
description: Few vegetables are tougher to match with wine than green asparagus, which is synonymous with spring. My go-to white for the job is sauvignon blanc, because its characteristic aromas and flavors  commonly called green, herbal, herbaceous or vegetal  echo those of asparagus.

title: Beach Boys Win Fight, and Lose It
description: The Beach Boys have won an eight-year legal battle over a collection of their memorabilia, including more than 50 handwritten scores for hits like Good Vibrations and Surfin U.S.A. But it is a partial victory, as binding arbitration has forced the band to agree to sell the memorabilia and split the money with other investors, lawyers and corporate entities who say they have a legal claim to it, court records show.

title: An Outspoken Speaker, Seeking to Quell the Unruly
description: LONDON

title: Netherlands Wins Yeh Brothers Cup
description: The Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan, was won on Friday by the Netherlands, represented by Bauke Muller, Simon de Wijs, Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees, who are reigning Bermuda Bowl champions. In the 48-board final they defeated the team Italy Lavazza by 102 international match points to 78.5. The Italian players were Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Antonio Sementa. (Maria Teresa Lavazza and Guido Ferraro were part of the team but did not play in the final stages.) Third was Denmark, made up of Sabine Auken, Morten and Dennis Bilde (father and son) and Roy Welland of New York City, who won the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in St. Louis last month.

title: Google Search Terms Can Predict Stock Market, Study Finds
description: The terms people search for on Google have been used to forecast how many Americans have the flu, travel plans and the price for which cars sell. Now a scientific study shows that Google search can be used to predict the stock market.

title: Authentic, From the Name to the Tortillas
description: The restaurant Cinco de Mayo in Calverton would be a fitting place to celebrate the Mexican holiday of the same name next Sunday. The Mexican food served here is authentic, down to the house-made corn tortillas.

title: It Came From Outer Space, Bearing Secrets
description: Hamesima X is a mystical tract seemingly reincarnated in the ultra-cheesy body of a 1980s straight-to-video thriller. Despite its outlandish premise, its a classic example of a feature-length foregone conclusion, in which a sulky skeptic is shown the light. In this Israeli film  directed by Yuval Ovadia, Or Yashar and Prosper Malka  a Mossad agent interrogates a mysterious visitor from outer space only to find religion himself.

title: Youkilis Out Again
description: Infielder Kevin Youkilis, who has not played since April 20, was once again out of the lineup on Friday with back spasms.

title: A Racial Divide Closes as Students Step Up
description: ABBEVILLE, Ga.  Mareshia Rucker watched in frustration last weekend as several dozen classmates in tuxedos and gowns walked into an Art Deco theater for her high schools white prom.

title: Bill Cunningham | Sketching in Pastels
description: The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion.

title: Why Not Have City Opera Go Home to City Center?
description: Last spring, reflecting on the completion of New York City Operas first season as an itinerant company bringing productions to the people in theaters throughout the city, George Steel, its general and artistic director, defended his decision to abandon Lincoln Center and argued that things were going well.

title: Philosophical Dialogues Made Physical
description: In his book Le Danseur des Solitudes, the French philosopher Georges Didi-Huberman focuses on the experimental flamenco dancer Israel Galvn to explore the isolation of a solo. A solo is not necessarily a lonely act, he writes, but a complex solitude populated by images, dreams, ghosts, memories. Stillness is virtuosic; empty space is charged with energetic force.

title: Colorful Serendipity for a Schools Sculpture
description: It may not be in quite the same league as finding the remains of Richard III under a parking lot in Leicester, or fragments of Chinese pottery dating back 20,000 years. But last week the discovery of a thousand or more shards of colorful Tiffany glass, stumbled on while clearing the site of a former Tiffany factory for a new school building in Corona, Queens, is expected to give a sculpture commissioned for the school more authenticity than originally hoped for by the agency that ordered it and the artist who is making it.

title: Frenchman Will Return to China Prized Bronze Artifacts Looted in 19th Century
description: BEIJING  One of Frances wealthiest businessmen has agreed to return to China two bronze animal heads that were looted from the imperial Summer Palace near Beijing by invading French and British troops in the 19th century, according to a report on Friday by China Radio International, a state news organization. To China, the looting of the palace epitomizes the humiliation it suffered at the hands of imperial Western powers during the Second Opium War.

title: A Couples Financial Tuneup
description: Tara Siegel Bernard, a reporter for The Times, helped Jennifer and Scott Bartone set aside a day to fine-tune finances and make headway on the money-related tasks that never seem to get done.

title: A Look Into the Future of Midtown
Mormons Endorse Plan to Admit Gay Scouts
description: The Mormon Church has declared its support for the Boy Scouts of Americas proposal to end a longstanding ban on openly gay youths, while continuing to bar gay adult leaders.

title: Nets Extend General Managers Contract
description: CHICAGO  The owner of the Nets, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, has been known for trying to make splashy moves and pursuing big names to lead his team, whether it be LeBron James, Dwight Howard or the former coach Phil Jackson.

title: Israel Sees U.S. Response to Syria as Gauge on Iran
description: JERUSALEM  As President Obama wrestles with how to respond to new assessments that Syria appears to have used chemical weapons, leaders in Israel say they will be watching for clues about how he might handle the Iranian nuclear issue in the future.

title: The Warsaw Ghetto Uprising and Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Profile Custody Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Firsts in the First Round
description: No running backs and nine offensive linemen were taken in the first round. A look at the number of picks at each position in the first round since 1967, when the A.F.L. and N.F.L. first combined their drafts.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Allowing Gay Scouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Bubls Charm Offensive
description: Mr. Bubl is promoting his sixth studio album, To Be Loved.

title: CUNY Chancellors Tenure
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Typical Subway Crooner
description: The Michael Bubl charm offensive hit the ground running this week. On Tuesday, the release date for his sixth studio album, To Be Loved (Reprise), Mr. Bubl put in a shift as guest co-host on Today and later taped an interview with Nightline. On Wednesday he was booked heavily with radio spots plugging the album and its insistently perky lead single, Its a Beautiful Day.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Attack Video and Bells Voice
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Knot Tied? Check. Vine-Covered Cottage? Check.
description: There were so many things to take in during Tuesdays presentation of A Marriage: 1 (Suburbia), a performance and installation by Nick Vaughan and Jake Margolin that has taken over the upstairs and downstairs theaters, hallways, stairwells and other nooks and crannies of Here Art Center.

title: For Zuckerberg, a Big Payout From Facebook Stock
description: Facebook shares may have been on a roller coaster ride in the year since they made their debut on Wall Street, but they havent been too shabby for its top executives. Mark Zuckerberg exercised stock options worth $2.3 billion, according to a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission late Friday  and sold about half, to cover his tax bill.

title: The Season When Local Chefs Go Wild
description: In early April, a supermarket flier trumpeted: Burst into spring! Featured in the ad were imported blackberries, California strawberries and salad mixes in plastic clamshells from a corporate farm out West. That blackberries, strawberries and baby greens grown in distant climes had been available right through the winter here in Westchester County, for a price, seemed lost in all the enthusiasm.

title: Europe Facing More Pressure to Reconsider Cuts as a Cure
description: BRUSSELS  Unemployment has surpassed Great Depression-era levels in Southern Europe. Recession is drifting to the once resilient economies of the north. Even some onetime hawks on government spending say they cannot cut any more.

title: Internet Sales Tax Coming Too Late for Some Stores
description: Anita Demetropoulos, a Maine shopkeeper, figured she would never see the day when her most relentless competitor, Amazon, would be forced to collect sales tax.

title: With Winters Gone, Can We Be Far Behind?
description: (This is part one of a two-part article.)

title: Cano Carrying Injury-Riddled Yankees
description: Robinson Canos hot streak to begin the season has been especially important with so many starters out of the Yankees lineup due to injury.

title: The Great Gatsby: Whats in a Cover Design?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Filmmaker Held in Venezuela Sought to Show Political Divide, Friends Say
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Just a few weeks ago, Tim Tracy spoke of his time shooting a documentary in Venezuela as a rollicking adventure and a filmmakers dream. Now he is under arrest, accused by the Venezuelan government of a different kind of adventure: taking part in what officials here said was a plot to destabilize the country and incite a civil war.

title: In Texas Blast, Horseman Died Trying to Save Creatures He Loved
description: WEST, Tex.  The emergency responders who rushed to the fire at a fertilizer plant here in the minutes before a deadly explosion gave their lives trying to protect the towns people and property. Buck Uptmor gave his for its horses.

title: A Libertarian Case for Expanding Gun Background Checks
description: NAPLES, Fla.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Japanese authorities approved Boeings fixes to its 787 Dreamliners, Chinas factory output slows and recession threatens to spread in Europe.

title: Enjoying a Well-Rounded Career in Music
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  Cynthia Daniels, a Grammy-winning recording engineer and producer, has amassed a long list of famous clients: Beyonc, Sarah Jessica Parker and Alec Baldwin, to name a few.

title: A Blow to British Horse Racing
description: NEWMARKET, England  It is called the sport of kings and it has been in this haven of racecourses, stables and studs since the 17th century, when King Charles I and his courtiers made the 100-mile journey here by horse-drawn carriages.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: In Room 306 of the Lorraine Motel, the Last Night
description: We really do have a complicated relationship with the British, especially when it comes to stage and screen drama. Show Americans a grand English manor, some lords and ladies with upper-crust accents, period costumes and class-specific crises, and we practically declare a religion. Look at all the Downton Abbey converts.

title: Grading the Notable Second-Round Picks
description: The first night of the 2013 N.F.L. draft didnt possess the star power many of us anticipated, but it set up an intriguing Day 2. With many prospects in both rounds projected to start immediately, we saw why this was considered such a deep draft. Lets run through some of the interesting choices.

title: The Death of a Countess in Exile
description: They knew her as the slender, straight-backed woman with an independent streak and a head for numbers. She told them she had immigrated from Hungary, and her colleagues at Merrill Lynch did not pry with more questions.

title: After Attack, Suspects Returned to Routines, Raising No Suspicions
description: BOSTON  Just five hours after the bombs exploded at the Boston Marathon last week, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, was back at his computer, doing what he did almost every day, posting a message on Twitter.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Yankees Cervelli Breaks Hand and Nova Leaves With Elbow Pain
description: The depleted Yankees could hardly afford to lose more players to injury, but in less than three innings on Friday, the Yankees lost their starting battery  possibly for a significant duration.

title: The Magic That Storytelling Can Do
description: The imperceptible magic that pervades human existence and the power of myth to assuage sorrow are invoked by the playwright Stefanie Zadravec as she entwines the lives of strangers in The Electric Baby, a gently touching new drama at the Two River Theater Company in Red Bank.

title: In Trek North, First Lure Is Mexicos Other Line
description: CIUDAD HIDALGO, Mexico  With her leg snapped and folded excruciatingly over her shoulder, Elvira Lpez Hernndez lay flat on a railroad bed as the freight train hurtled above her, clinging tightly to two things: the railroad ties beneath her and the memory of the 4-year-old daughter she had left behind in Guatemala.

title: Mexicos Porous Southern Border
description: Seeking to enter the United States illegally, a growing number of Central Americans are entering Mexico, often under the gaze of Mexican authorities.

title: A Song of Lament for Syria
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Apr. 27, 2013
description: "These are people I see in class every day. Whats wrong with dancing with me, just because I have more pigment?

title: Pushing the G.O.P. to Support Gay Rights
description: When the Rhode Island State Senate tallied up the votes against a same-sex marriage bill passed there on Wednesday, something was missing: Republicans.

title: Instant Photographs, Lasting Images
description: Edwin Land, who founded Polaroid, the company famous for introducing and popularizing instant photography, in 1937, took inspiration for a famous model from home. An anecdote recounted on the companys Web site says Mr. Land was moved to develop the Land Camera (which was introduced to the public in 1948 and produced instant black-and-white prints in about a minute) by his 3-year-old daughter, who wondered why a camera could not instantly produce pictures after they were taken.

title: Father Gets Off L.I.R.R., Leaving Children Behind
description: Around 4 a.m. last Saturday, aboard a commuter train sidling through Long Island, a faint whimpering began to fill the sixth car somewhere east of Wyandanch.

title: Corrections: April 27, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Holy Smoker
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  When I travel internationally, I like to immerse myself as much as possible into the local culture, which for me, is primarily about what local foods I can eat (Im kidding. Ive been known to skulk around museums too, mainly because they are known to have very clean restrooms.)

title: Teo Finally Comes Off the Board; Most Quarterbacks Dont
description: It seemed fitting that Aaron Rodgers was rewarded with a lavish contract extension that could make him the highest-paid football player in history  for five years and $110 million, according to multiple reports  just minutes before the second round of the N.F.L. draft began Friday night.

title: How to Build a Spoon
description: I have seen the future, and it is in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: At 79, Still Keeping Brooklyn Bubbling
description: Eli Miller, who turns 80 in June, is the senior man among the few remaining seltzer deliverymen in New York City.

title: As Old as the Bottles
description: Eli Miller, 79, New York Citys senior seltzer man, hoisted crate after crate of seltzer  weighing 70 pounds apiece  into his van and then draped himself over them.

title: Statute Prevents Pursuit of Horace Mann Abuse
description: The Bronx district attorneys office said Friday it could not pursue any cases of alleged sexual abuse at Horace Mann, an elite private school in the Bronx, because the statute of limitations had been exceeded.

title: With Lineup Already Clicking, Mets Move Wright to the Cleanup Spot
description: Offense has not been a significant concern for the Mets this season, but in lieu of consistent pitching, Manager Terry Collins continues to search for more runs. He unveiled his latest experiment Friday night when the Mets faced the Philadelphia Phillies, moving David Wright from third in the order to the cleanup spot.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 26, 2013

title: Thunders Championship Chances Take a Tumble With a Knee Injury to Westbrook
description: N.B.A. stars have been dropping like flies in the playoffs. David Lee of the Golden State Warriors was lost for the postseason. Steve Nash of the Los Angeles Lakers was seen being carted around in a wheelchair. Tony Parker of the San Antonio Spurs and Joakim Noah of the Chicago Bulls are playing through injuries.

title: The Hugs Are Free, as Advertised, but Not Always Welcome
description: The sign is simple, eight big letters on a piece of cardboard, but when Jermaine Himmelstein takes it outside and holds it over his head and smiles, it acts like a strong magnet.

title: E.P.A.s Keystone Report Card
description: In the bland, formal language of interagency correspondence, the Environmental Protection Agency has written a trenchant review of the State Departments most recent effort to assess the consequences of building the Keystone XL pipeline. The E.P.A.s letter, issued Monday, at the end of the public comment period on the departments latest draft environmental impact statement, is hardly a favorable report card.

title: The Next Step in Drug Treatment
description: The mandatory-sentencing craze that drove up the prison population tenfold, pushing state corrections costs to bankrupting levels, was rooted in New Yorks infamous Rockefeller drug laws. These laws, which mandated lengthy sentences for nonviolent, first-time offenders, were approved 40 years ago next month. They did little to curtail drug use in New York or in other states that mimicked them, while they filled prisons to bursting with nonviolent addicts who would have been more effectively and more cheaply dealt with through treatment programs.

title: Congress Rushes to Aid the Powerful
description: Congress cant pass a budget or control guns or confirm judges on time, but this week members of both parties found something they could agree on, and in a big hurry: avoiding blame for inconveniencing air travelers. The Senate and House rushed through a bill that would avert furloughs to air traffic controllers, which were mandated by Congresss own sequester but proved embarrassing when flights began to back up around the country.

title: Leaving Behind the Noise of the City
description: Rashid Perkins still remembers that first day. One summer morning, when he was 7, he left his home in Jamaica, Queens. At the Port Authority Bus Terminal, he said goodbye to his mother and boarded a bus that would take him to Needham, Mass., for a two-week stay with a host family, a trip sponsored by the Fresh Air Fund.

title: The Morose Middle Class
description: The Middle Class is in a funk, its view of the future growing dim as fear rolls in like a storm.

title: A Generals Life
description: Charles Traub embarks on a photographic journey to capture the places made great by Ulysses S. Grants indomitable spirit.

title: A Party With Crunch
description: Salvation, Murray Hill style, means a party, at once visual, visceral, tangy and rowdy. The chef April Bloomfields newest venture with Ken Friedman strays far from their gastropubs, the Breslin and the Spotted Pig, and into Mexican, Asian and Middle Eastern territory.

title: Man Charged in Killing of a Bronx 2-Year-Old Riding in a Van in 2006
description: For seven years, Joanne Sanabria has held candlelight vigils and mourned her 2 1/2-year-old son, David Pacheco Jr., who was killed in his car seat by a stray bullet near a busy Bronx intersection in 2006.

title: Three-Hit Shutout Drops Mets Below .500 for First Time This Year
description: Just as David Wright was getting set to step inside the batters box in the bottom of the first inning, something went very wrong for the home plate umpire, Brian ONora. He sprinted off the field and into the Mets dugout.

title: Democrats Said to Discuss Plan for Bronx District Attorney to Resign
description: With the prosecution record of the longtime Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, under fire, the boroughs Democratic leaders have been discussing a plan that would ease the way for him to step down within months, according to several people familiar with the idea.

title: Grant in Pictures
description: The story of Ulysses S. Grant is an American epic practically without equal. Hollywood couldnt dream it up. Even today, Grants complicated persona and unquenchable will to victory enthrall historians and fiction writers alike.

title: A Bit of Writing, and Various States of Loll
description: In novels like The Wife"and The Ten-Year Nap, Meg Wolitzer has explored themes of marriage, sex, gender politics and family. Her real domestic life is spent on the Upper East Side, where she lives with her husband, Richard Panek, 54, who is also a writer; their younger son, Charlie, who is 18; and the familys dog, Jet, a 5-year-old Havanese. The couples older son, Gabriel, 22, is a senior at the University of Chicago. Ms. Wolitzer, 53, said she usually treated Sundays as a lighter writing day, carving out time for rest, Mexican food and an occasional cheap massage. Her newest book, The Interestings, was published this month by Riverhead Books.

title: Giants Top Pick Blends Intellect, Intensity and Drive
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Justin Pugh, the Syracuse offensive tackle taken by the Giants in the first round, is a bruising, 6-foot-4, 305-pound all-American whom one of his college coaches on Friday called fiery, hard-nosed and eager to knock people down.

title: Wang Is on the Yankees Radar
description: The former Yankee Chien-Ming Wang  whose 2008 foot injury derailed a promising young career  continued his strong start in the minors by allowing just one run in six and two-third innings for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Thursday. In 12 innings this season, Wang  who was signed to a minor league contract in the off-season  has a 0.75 earned run average.

title: In Taking  a Quarterback, the Jets Give Up on Another
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

title: Kathryn Davis, Donor Who Made the Hudson Her Cause, Dies at 106
description: Kathryn Wasserman Davis, who contributed tens of millions of dollars to cleaning the Hudson River and promoting peace through an organization she founded when she was 100, died on Tuesday at her home in Hobe Sound, Fla. She was 106.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. Can you tell me about an enemy agent in Manhattan during World War II called the Doll Lady?

title: Born, a Century Ago, to Be Wild
description: Members of the Queensboro Motorcycle Club in Queens, formed in 1910, show no sign of letting up.

title: North Korea Expected to Indict American It Is Holding
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American tour operator is facing indictment in North Korea on charges that he tried to overthrow the government there, the Norths official Korean Central News Agency said Saturday.

title: The Bikes and the Fury
description: In a very short time, New Yorkers will have the opportunity to show the world that they are just as virtuous, well-intentioned and offended by sloth as people in Copenhagen or Geneva or any other of a number of cities where mindful living and wonderful yogurts reign. The citys long-anticipated bike share program is scheduled to make its debut in May, allowing New Yorkers to pick up and deposit rental bikes at hundreds of locations, most of them, so far, in some of the wealthiest neighborhoods. Anyone waking up on a Sunday morning in TriBeCa, finding nothing in her refrigerator and hankering to go to Smorgasburg in Dumbo, Brooklyn, for instance, will now be able to do that with relative ease.

title: Knicks, in a Stomping, Close In on a Sweep
description: BOSTON  The suspense had long since dissipated, along with the Boston Celtics spirit, but Carmelo Anthony was still on the parquet floor late Friday, dribbling, firing, skipping with a childlike glee and then, finally, making a slow, purposeful walk to the bench.

title: Engines Revving, for 103 Years
description: Few clubs would want their headquarters in the Willets Point section of Queens, a massive, muddy cluster of auto repair shacks  but the Queensboro Motorcycle Club is perfectly happy wedged in there among the junkyards and salvage shops.

title: Yanks Lose Cervelli and Nova to Injury but Salvage a Win
description: The 2013 Yankees, with a cast of has-beens and unknowns, have prided themselves on persevering, and Fridays game was a case in point. In the first three innings, the Yankees lost their starting pitcher and catcher, possibly for a significant amount of time, but they ultimately prevailed against the Toronto Blue Jays, 6-4.

title: He Left a Fortune, to No One
description: When Roman Blum died last year at age 97, his body lingered in the Staten Island University Hospital morgue for four days, until a rabbi at the hospital was able to track down his lawyer.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (Sundance) A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992) Craig Sheffer portrays the writer Norman Maclean as a quiet, scholarly young man, and Brad Pitt (above right, with Mr. Sheffer) is Paul, his wilder, more magnetic brother, in this adaptation of Mr. Macleans 1976 autobiographical story about the sons of a Presbyterian minister (Tom Skerritt) coming of age in western Montana between Prohibition and the Great Depression  and finding expression for their emotions through fly-fishing. These are men for whom the physical is inseparably entwined with the spiritual, men for whom both aspects of life are best appreciated knee-deep in a rushing river on a glorious day, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Between the novellas well-known first sentence (In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly-fishing) and its elegiac last line (I am haunted by waters), A River Runs Through It circled gracefully among the landmarks of Mr. Macleans early years without violating the distant perfection of those memories. She added: Its easy to recognize Robert Redfords reverent film version of this beautifully spare novella as a labor of love. While the film is more lavish than Mr. Macleans story, and hence less commandingly precise, it radiates much the same seriousness of purpose. The same thoughts embraced by Mr. Maclean  of family and history, of the unbridgeable distances between men, of a wild natural landscape as a pathway to spiritual grace  are ably reflected on the screen.

title: Central Michigan Fan Celebrates No. 1 Pick
description: Usually after the first round of the N.F.L. draft, football fans in Michigan can proudly point to players selected who wore maize and blue or green and white during their high-profile Big Ten careers.

title: With Crowd Behind Them, Celtics Go Nowhere Again
description: BOSTON  Doc Rivers said he felt his Boston Celtics team lost its spirit on Friday, an unimaginable concept given everything that appeared to be favoring them heading into Game 3 of their first-round playoff series against the Knicks.

title: Game 3: Knicks vs. Celtics
description: The Knicks crushed the Celtics to take a 3-0 lead in the teams best-of-seven playoff series.

title: After Plans to Build Titanic II, Australian Billionaire Forms a New Political Party
description: SYDNEY, Australia  An Australian billionaire who is perhaps best known for his efforts to build a seaworthy replica of the Titanic says he will use his vast fortune to form a new political party to compete in federal elections scheduled for September.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 27
description: NEWS After years of insisting that the primary cure for Europes malaise is to slash spending, the champions of austerity, most notably Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, find themselves under intensified pressure to back off from unpopular remedies and find some way to restore faltering growth to the worlds largest economic bloc. On Friday, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain, who once promoted aggressive budget cuts, became the latest leader to reject European Union targets for reducing deficits. Andrew Higgins reports from Brussels.

title: Hong Kong Retains Allure as Retail Mecca
description: HONG KONG  Amid bouquets, camera-wielding photographers and a bustling crowd of curious onlookers, Uniqlo opened a flagship store in the heart of one of Hong Kongs busiest shopping districts on Friday  underlining the citys unrelenting attraction for retailers seeking exposure to the giant mainland Chinese market.

title: Off the Bottom but Not Yet in the Clear in La Corua
description: Stability breeding consistency doesnt seem to be an adage favored by La Liga clubs, although the facts should perhaps be given more thought by trigger-happy presidents. Last seasons three relegated clubs  Villarreal, Sporting Gijon and Racing Santander  all changed managers at least once during the season. One would be forgiven, then, for being unforgiving of Deportivo la Coruas Primera Division status when in February, languishing at bottom of the league, they appointed their third manager of the campaign.

title: Obama and G.O.P. Spar Over Direction of Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama sparred with Congressional Republicans on Saturday over who was to blame for long flight delays this week, but neither side moved closer to a consensus on how to minimize the broader impact of federal spending cuts on the public.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Four policemen were killed in a village in north Kashmir on Friday in an ambush by suspected militants, The Indian Express reported.

title: Lessons From the Sunday Papers
description: In case you were curious, the new ideal Indian man is very fair, very handsome and works at a Multi National Company (MNC) in the National Capital Region (NCR).

title: Banking Advice From Britains Businessman Archbishop
description: LONDON  The Church of England was once known as the Conservative Party at prayer.

title: American Austerity, An Update
description: There is some tendency among economic commentators to think that austerity policies in a deeply depressed economy are mainly a European thing; you even find a fair number of people imagining that the United States is still engaged in fiscal stimulus. But the truth is that federal stimulus is years behind us, while state and local governments have cut back, so the overall story is one of fiscal contraction thats smaller than in Europe, but not by that much.

title: Justin Pugh, One Jolly Giant on Draft Day
description: The Giants seemed very pleased with their first-round draft selection: offensive lineman Justin Pugh of Syracuse, at No. 19 over all. The only concern might be his health after he was smothered by fans and family  in a raucous celebration following the Giants phone call on Thursday night. Luckily, hes a big boy.

title: The Ignoramus Strategy
description: A while back Noah Smith described one common strategy for arguing against Keynesian economics, and yours truly in particular: Relentlessly pretend to be an ignorant simpleton. Of course, as always, this strategy is most effective if you arent pretending, and really are an ignorant simpleton.

title: An Earth Scientist Explores the Biggest Climate Threat: Fear
description: Heres a Your Dot contribution pushing back against apocalyptic depictions of the collision between humans and the climate system  written by Peter B. Kelemen, the Arthur D. Storke Professor and vice chair in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences at Columbia University. Kelemen has done a lot of interesting work on possible ways to capture carbon dioxide from air (none being easy or cheap):

title: Boozer Increases His Scoring, Rebounding and Grinning
description: CHICAGO  Carlos Boozer strode to the United Center lectern after the Bulls Game 3 victory over the Nets on Thursday night. He was wearing a gray sports coat with a periwinkle and lavender windowpane pattern and a pair of baggy bluejeans, a clashing ensemble that could have been a metaphor for his three-year tenure with the team.

title: Building Cars to Drive in the Park
description: Teenagers from all over New York City will demonstrate soap-box derby cars they made from recycled materials at a Street Games festival in Thomas Jefferson Park in East Harlem today.

title: We Can Never Get Comfortable': Q. and A. With a Rescue Paramedic
description: Part of an elite group, Syndie Molina is one of 104 rescue paramedics among the roughly 3,000 emergency medical technicians and paramedics employed by New York City. She works from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. at the Fire Departments Emergency Medical Services Station 4 in downtown Manhattan. Ms. Molina, 35, lives in Nassau County with her 9-year-old son.

title: Oops: Bale Scores, Sort Of
description: Gareth Bale scored his 19th goal of the Premier League season and it was probably one of the easiest  and strangest  of his career with Tottenham Hotspur.

title: Harvards Playoff Duo, Divided by 65 Years
description: During Harvard road games in the 1945-46 season, arena announcers tended to mangle the pronunciation of Saul Mariaschins surname.

title: U.S. Seeks to End 80 Years of Failure in a Tournament
description: The United States has one of the most stunning championship droughts in elite-level mens sports.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shifting Focus, Federal Agents Arrest New Suspect in Ricin Case
description: A former taekwondo instructor was taken into custody early Saturday by federal authorities in Mississippi, accused of mailing letters containing the poison ricin to the president, a United States senator and a local judge.

title: Rebels From Darfur Stage Attack in Neighboring State
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Rebels from the Darfur region in Sudan on Saturday attacked a town in a neighboring state about 300 miles southwest of Khartoum, the capital, in one of their boldest offensives in years.

title: Diagnosing the Wrong Deficit
description: IN the spring of 2010, a new patient came to see me to find out if he had attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. He had all the classic symptoms: procrastination, forgetfulness, a propensity to lose things and, of course, the inability to pay attention consistently. But one thing was unusual. His symptoms had started only two years earlier, when he was 31.

title: Variety: A Top Diagramless
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I need to learn to count better. Lets all take a collective breath and thank the universe that I dont have to write Numberplay, our weekly math puzzle blog, or The New York Times would be getting a lot more e-mails than it already does.

title: Knicks Ripping Series Out of Celtics Hands
description: BOSTON

title: London Team Is Built on One Religion but Has Evolving Identity
description: LONDON  About 90 minutes before kickoff on a recent Saturday, Guy Morris sped through traffic near the northwest edge of the city on his way to an important game. Munching on an apple as he wove his way toward the field, Morris considered what seemed to be a relatively simple question:

title: Why People Marry
description: How marriage is delayed, and why.

title: Islamist Rebels Create Dilemma on Syria Policy
description: CAIRO  In Syrias largest city, Aleppo, rebels aligned with Al Qaeda control the power plant, run the bakeries and head a court that applies Islamic law. Elsewhere, they have seized government oil fields, put employees back to work and now profit from the crude they produce.

title: In the Season of Marriage, a Question. Why Bother?
description: ITS surprising how many people still marry. As everyone knows, its a risky proposition; the divorce rate, though down from its peak of one in two marriages in the early 1980s, remains substantial. Besides, you can have a perfectly respectable life these days without marrying.

title: Ill Have Anothers Triumphs Put to Song
description: I was one of many horse racing fans that fell in love last year with Ill Have Another as he partnered with jockey Mario Gutierrez to win the Robert B. Lewis Stakes, Santa Anita Derby, Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes. Bettors put the odds of this achievement at about 7,500 to 1. Gutierrezs rides were masterful, and Ill Have Anothers come from behind victories in the Derby and Preakness left the crowds screaming for more. Like all his fans, I was disappointed that an injury the week of the Belmont Stakes led to his retirement and sale to stud.

title: From Work in Progress to Polished No. 1 Pick
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, Mich.  They tend to fly under the radar here. This hardscrabble Midwest town, huddled in the shadow of Big Ten country, is not accustomed to the spotlight.

title: When Assimilation Stalls
description: THE immigration legislation percolating in the Senate has been pitched as an all-things-to-all-factions compromise. Illegal immigrants will be regularized, but most of them will have to wait at least a decade to gain citizenship. There will be more visas and new guest-worker programs, but also stiffer enforcement on the border and in workplaces.

title: Judgment Not Included
description: AS police investigators peel away the layers of the Boston Marathon bombing, there are two aspects of this unfolding story to which I want to react: the mind-set of the alleged bombers and the role of the Internet in shaping it. Important news about both was contained in a single Washington Post article on Tuesday.

title: Sunday Dialogue: A Single Seven-Year Term for the President?
description: Would a constitutional change make our leaders more accountable and effective, or less?

title: More Than Problem-Solving
description: MY parents raised us in Dallas, where my father practiced law, first at a large firm, then at his own practice. My parents met while attending a Spanish-language summer program in college. I have a sister who is seven years younger.

title: Dispelling Stereotypes, on Stage and Off
description: IF the unemployment statistics still seem disappointing for those hoping to join or rejoin the work force, consider this: The unemployment rate for Americans with disabilities is 75 percent higher than for those with no disabilities, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Sleeping With Guns
description: NINE MILE FALLS, Wash.

title: When Companies Get It Right
description: EVERY few weeks, the Haggler receives e-mail from happy customers eager to praise companies that have treated them well. Given the howls of dismay and fury that typically fill the Hagglers in-box, these letters are startling and exotic  like finding a yogi in a mosh pit. When enough unsolicited huzzahs pile up, the Haggler likes to present them in a column.

title: Rebalancing a Portfolio? Dont Break the Seesaw
description: PORTFOLIO rebalancing  periodically resetting a mix of stocks and bonds by taking profits from outperforming investments and buying cheaper, underperforming ones  has always posed a challenge.

title: A Baseball Memoir With a Somber Side
description: There is a 13-year-old in Tucson named Dallas Green. He loves swimming and is certified in scuba diving. His grandfather sends him antique coins every month for his collection. He plays baseball as best he can, the way his father, his grandfather and especially his sister would have wanted.

title: Todays Dream House May Not Be Tomorrows
description: HOUSES are just buildings, but homes are often beautiful dreams. Unfortunately, as millions of people have learned in the housing crisis, those dreams dont always comport with reality.

title: A Battered Dream, Then a Violent Path
description: BOSTON  It was a blow the immigrant boxer could not withstand: after capturing his second consecutive title as the Golden Gloves heavyweight champion of New England in 2010, Tamerlan Anzorovich Tsarnaev, 23, was barred from the national Tournament of Champions because he was not a United States citizen.

title: Guards Who Are Front and Center
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Golden State Coach Mark Jackson started it, after Game 2 of the playoff series between the Warriors and the Denver Nuggets, when he proclaimed that his two starting guards were the best shooting tandem in N.B.A. history.

title: My Son, the Terrorist
description: Despite incontrovertible evidence to the contrary, Zubeidat Tsarnaeva, mother of the Boston bombing suspects, has defiantly proclaimed her sons innocence in several interviews. I can think of only one other person who would take such a stance...

title: When Your Data Wanders to Places Youve Never Been
description: A FEW weeks ago, a friend received a flier in the mail inviting her to an event in Manhattan for patients with multiple sclerosis.

title: Heading the Wrong Way
description: At first glance, the latest economic growth report, released Friday, appears to show the economy revving up. In reality, the economy is either stuck in low gear, or worse, slowing to a stop as budget cuts harm not only the users of overstretched government services but the overall economy. This precarious situation urgently calls for more federal spending, not less, though that message has been lost on Congress.

title: Astros Can Visualize Success; Having It Is Another Matter
description: BOSTON

title: Silver Foxs Pink Slip
description: WASHINGTON

title: Jad Abumrad
description: Jad Abumrad is the creator and co-host of Radiolab, a syndicated public radio program that has a cultlike following. The show blends science, sound, psychology and philosophy to reveal something deeper about the human condition.

title: Wikipedias Sexism
description: Early last week I noticed something strange on Wikipedia. It appeared that, gradually, over time, the volunteer editors who create the site had begun moving women, one by one, from the American Novelists category to the American Women Novelists subcategory. Female authors whose last names began with A or B had been most affected.

title: Acquired Tastes: Knicks and New York
description: Most of my adult life, I have hated New York City.

title: Another Alleged Drug Kickback Scheme
description: Two federal lawsuits charging a prominent drug company with making fraudulent kickbacks to promote sales of its drugs raise disturbing questions about how to control fraudulent behavior in the pharmaceutical industry, behavior that appears to be on the rise. The company is Novartis Pharmaceuticals, the American subsidiary of a Swiss-based multinational. Novartis denies any wrongdoing and vows to defend itself in court.

title: Variations on a Gene, and Tools to Find Them
description: CANCERS were once named strictly for the tissue where they originated in the breast, prostate or other part of the body. Now, in the age of genetically informed medicine, cancers may also come with a more specific lexicon: the names of mutated genes deep within tumors that cause cells to become cancerous.

title: The Lesson of Boston
description: IF only it were as simple as the drones coming home to roost. That would be comforting somehow. In giving us a tidy cause, it would give us a clear remedy: rain less death in distant lands, and worry less about death in our own.

title: Food Aid Reform
description: Food aid is one of the most important tools of American foreign policy. Since the mid-1950s, the United States has spent nearly $2 billion annually to feed the worlds poor, saving millions of lives. But the process is so rigid and outdated that many more people who could be helped still go hungry. Reforms proposed by President Obama will go a long way toward fixing that problem and should be promptly enacted by Congress.

title: The Fastest Rowers Dont Always Make the Fastest Boat
description: This interview with  Jen Guzman, C.E.O. of Stella & Chewys, a pet food company based in Milwaukee, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Coping With Playoff Passion
description: The number of physical fouls that N.H.L. officials and the league did not punish during the regular season may provide a clue to how closely they will uphold the rules in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Trying to Slam the Bailout Door
description: THERES a lot to like, if youre a taxpayer, in the new bipartisan bill from two concerned senators hoping to end the peril of big bank bailouts. But if youre a large and powerful financial institution thats too big to fail, you wont like this bill one bit.

title: How Big Data Is Playing Recruiter for Specialized Workers
description: WHEN the e-mail came out of the blue last summer, offering a shot as a programmer at a San Francisco start-up, Jade Dominguez, 26, was living off credit card debt in a rental in South Pasadena, Calif., while he taught himself programming. He had been an average student in high school and hadnt bothered with college, but someone, somewhere out there in the cloud, thought that he might be brilliant, or at least a diamond in the rough.

title: Vanishing Southeast Division Has Had Much More Sunshine Than Success
description: WASHINGTON  After one final game Saturday night between the Florida Panthers and the Tampa Bay Lightning, the sun will set on the Southeast Division, a remarkably poor division by N.H.L. standards and across the four major North American professional sports leagues as well.

title: Germans Dominance Is Peak of a Long Climb
description: BERLIN  The German soccer club Borussia Dortmund was at the edge of bankruptcy in 2003, unable to pay its players salaries. Rescue came from an unlikely source when rival Bayern Munich lent the club $2.6 million.

title: A Realm of Their Own
description: At a studio in Montreal, the Ubisoft team pays close attention to detail while creating the video games into which millions of people escape.

title: Where the Artists Are the Superheroes
description: When Tchae Measroch leaves work, his hands usually bear a fresh cut or bruise. He works, often on his knees, in a small room crowded with an odd mix of items: a dried-grass hula skirt, a car door, baseball bats, swords and knives of varying length, a camouflage net typically used to disguise military equipment from enemy eyes.

title: The Great Degrader
description: Ive been focused on economic policy lately, so I sort of missed the big push to rehabilitate Bushs image; also, as a premature anti-Bushist who pointed out how terrible a president he was back when everyone else was praising him as a Great Leader, Im kind of worn out on the subject.

title: The Art of the Hunt
description: THE next time you visit an art museum, look around  not at the paintings, but at the people in the galleries. Its a fair bet that women will outnumber men; even government statistics say so. More women than men study art, too, at both undergraduate and graduate levels. Art appreciation is a female predilection and so, you would think, is collecting. To buy art, you have to shop. Need I say anything about which sex has a proclivity for browsing  an essential element of buying, um, visual art?

title: Whither Moral Courage?
description: WE find it easier, in these confused times, to admire physical bravery than moral courage  the courage of the life of the mind, or of public figures. A man in a cowboy hat vaults a fence to help Boston bomb victims while others flee the scene: we salute his bravery, as we do that of servicemen returning from the battlefront, or men and women struggling to overcome debilitating illnesses or injuries.

title: The Dark Side of Energy Independence
description: JUST as the world was writing off America as a declining power, the country now finds itself on the cusp of realizing one of its longstanding goals: energy independence.

title: The Adulterous Sins of Our Father Figures
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass.

title: Scouting Report on Ryan Nassib, Chosen by Giants in Round 4
description: The Giants grabbed another Syracuse player in the draft, trading up to take quarterback Ryan Nassib in the fourth round Saturday. Matt Waldman, a scouting expert who ranked the quarterbacks for the Fifth Down before the draft, rated him third, ahead of the new Jet Geno Smith (5th). He gives a fuller report:

title: Discovery Near 9/11 Site Stirs Memories
description: For years, Lilia Tahlov tried to push it out of her thoughts. The horrible day, as she calls it, when the sky turned black and her teeth chattered incessantly.

title: Sabathia Is Uneven Again, but Hafner Provides Enough for Win
description: Designated hitter Travis Hafner faced a great deal of uncertainty when he surveyed his options during the off-season. Hafner, a former Cleveland Indians star, had never been a free agent. The freedom to choose his next destination was exciting, but he was also nervous about finding the right spot. Hafner, 35, was headed toward the twilight of his career, if he had not already reached it, and a successful final chapter required the best fit.

title: Italy Forms New Coalition Government to End Months of Political Stalemate
description: ROME  Ending a crushing two-month political stalemate that had spooked European leaders, Prime Minister-elect Enrico Letta formed a rare coalition government on Saturday uniting left and right  and including a record number of women and Italys first nonwhite minister  to steer Italy, with the euro zones third-largest economy, out of the doldrums.

title: Giants Trade Up for Syracuse Quarterback
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Maneuvering to move up six spots early on the third day of the N.F.L. draft, the typically staid Giants chose Syracuse quarterback Ryan Nassib with a fourth-round pick Saturday, the highest the team has taken a quarterback since it chose Philip Rivers at No. 4 in 2004 and then traded him for the top pick, Eli Manning.

title: F.A.A. Says Air Traffic Staffing Is Returning to Normal
description: After a week of air-traffic slowdowns, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Saturday that it had suspended its employee furloughs and was returning to normal staffing levels, while President Obama sparred with Congressional Republicans over who was to blame for the delays.

title: In South Carolina Congressional Race, Drama Outpaces Discussion of Issues
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Mark Sanford has taken to debating a life-size poster of Nancy Pelosi on the streets. His Democratic opponent, Elizabeth Colbert Busch, issued a tribute to Margaret Thatcher, the conservative former British prime minister who died last month.

title: Russians Go on TV to Say Sanctions Wont Matter
description: MOSCOW  Just two weeks after the Obama administration imposed sanctions on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, Russian officials organized a very public so what? on Saturday, gathering officials on the list and assuring them in televised meetings that condemnation by the United States government would not hurt their careers. The jocular tone of the meetings suggested, in fact, that it might help.

title: Illegal Districts Dot New Delhi as City Swells
description: NEW DELHI  New Ashok Nagar is a typical crosscut of Indian urban chaos: Dust rises off battered, narrow lanes, tangles of telephone and electricity lines hang between poorly constructed, mismatched brick buildings. Sewage overflows from uncovered channels. And people are in the streets, in the doorways, everywhere.

title: Departing French Envoy Has Frank Words on Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It is always hard to gauge what diplomats really think unless one of their cables ends up on WikiLeaks, but every once in a while, the barriers fall and a bit of truth slips into public view.

title: Immigrants Pay Lower Fees to Send Money Home, Helping to Ease Poverty
description: The first time Carmen Gonzalez sent money back to her family in Mexico, in 1991, Western Union charged her a $12 fee to wire $100. She earned that $12 working for six hours in a clothing factory in midtown Manhattan, which paid her $2 an hour.

title: Marcum Keeps It Close; Bullpen Hands It Over
description: The Mets do not expect Shaun Marcum to be the second coming of Christy Mathewson. When they signed Marcum in the off-season to a one-year deal, the Mets were merely looking to stabilize their rotation in the wake of R. A. Dickeys departure to the Toronto Blue Jays. They wanted a veteran who could eat some innings and win some games, a reliable arm for a staff in dire need of one.

title: My Dark Times: A Survivors Story
description: Last October, Habibullah, a 22-year-old student from Quetta, Pakistan, joined 34 Hazara asylum seekers on a boat bound for Christmas Island, a small Australian territory about 240 miles off the Indonesian coast. Within 24 hours the boat had sunk in a storm. This is his account of his ordeal.

title: Celebrity Guest Solver Elayne Boosler: Soft Ts
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Ive written a few times about the Extremely Spunky Border Terrier who lives with me as the brains behind the Wordplay organization, and its rare to find someone who loves dogs even more than I do. I think Ive finally met my match in Elayne Boosler.

title: Many Openings at State Agency Go to Those With Ties to Cuomo
description: ALBANY  New York States economic development agency created a new position last June, and then found a candidate to fill it: a young man named Willard Younger, who had just graduated from Colgate University with a degree in classics and religion. He became a special projects associate, at a salary of $45,000 a year, according to state personnel records.

title: Rangers Will Face Capitals in Round 1
description: All systems are go entering the playoffs for the surging Rangers, who are looking a lot more like last seasons supremely competent team, and a lot less like the bumbling outfit they were for the first two-thirds of the season, as they prepare to face the Washington Capitals.

title: 4 Young Brothers Die in Fire at Camp for Syria Refugees in Jordan
description: JERUSALEM  Four young brothers who had fled the civil war in Syria were killed in a fire that engulfed four tents in the Zaatari refugee camp near Jordans northern border, the aid worker who runs the camp said Saturday.

title: No Rich Child Left Behind
description: Heres a fact that may not surprise you: the children of the rich perform better in school, on average, than children from middle-class or poor families. Students growing up in richer families have better grades and higher standardized test scores, on average, than poorer students; they also have higher rates of participation in extracurricular activities and school leadership positions, higher graduation rates and higher rates of college enrollment and completion.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 28
description: National security and foreign affairs share the limelight on the Sunday political shows this week, featuring conversations about the investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings and the response to new developments in Syrias civil war.

title: Bulls Are the Ones Left Standing After Triple Overtime
description: CHICAGO  The locker-room floor was strewn with towels, torn bandages and ice. Eyes were red and gaits were stilted. After two games and two losses, after 63 minutes in a triple-overtime thriller on Saturday, this is how the Nets left Chicago.

title: Ready (or Not?) for a Great Coming Shale Boom
description: SWEETWATER  About a year ago, talk began circulating in this West Texas town about a huge oil-producing formation called the Cline Shale, east of the traditional drilling areas around Midland.

title: Reviving an Old Series the New Way: Fan-Financing
