description: Around 10 p.m. on a recent Friday night, roughly 500 people at the Dog and Duck Pub in Austin gathered around a man holding an iPad. The man was Rob Thomas, the creator of the cult-hit television series Veronica Mars, and he was staring at the device, counting down the final seconds of a 30-day campaign on Kickstarter, the crowd-source-financing Web site, to raise money for a film adaptation of that teen noir series.

title: Loans Borrowed Against Pensions Squeeze Retirees
description: To retirees, the offers can sound like the answer to every money worry: convert tomorrows pension checks into todays hard cash.

title: Rapid Growth Creates Cities Within Cities in India
description: Indias crowded urban centers are divided not only by class but also by the legal status of where people live.

title: Lowering Standards to Earn a Diploma Could Raise Voters Ire
description: Of the three primary arguments about public schools under way in Austin, two are relatively easy for lawmakers to sell to the voters who put them in office.

title: Valeant and Actavis Talks Fall Through, for Now
description: Merger talks between Valeant Pharmaceuticals and another drug maker, Actavis, have fallen through, a person briefed on the matter said on Saturday, potentially ending what would have been one of the biggest health care deals of the year.

title: Lawmakers Take on Texas Truancy Laws
description: SAN ANTONIO  When she can focus on class, Rachel Hebert thrives as a student in the Northside Independent School District here. But Rachel, 17, has cerebral palsy, and medical complications often keep her from getting to school.

title: Fleeing Pakistan Violence, Hazaras Brave Uncertain Journey
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Stranded in a dingy hotel in the heart of this port city, waiting for the smugglers call, Hussain felt at once trapped and poised for freedom.

title: Game 4: Bulls vs. Nets
description: The Bulls erased a 14-point deficit late in regulation and outlasted the Nets in triple overtime to take a 3-1 lead in the first-round playoff series.

title: Barkley Learns That Bad Things Can Come to Those Who Wait
description: Matt Barkley finally heard his name called Saturday at the start of the fourth round of the N.F.L. draft, but after his precipitous descent, football players are going to hear Barkleys name much more often. College football players.

title: When One Mans Game Is Also a Marauding Pest
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  At first he thought it was a deer, perhaps the big-antlered buck he had seen before and hoped to bag someday.

title: Feral Swine Spread to the North
description: State officials are scrambling to deal with an invasion of roaming behemoths that damage property and kill livestock.

title: All Nippon Airways Takes Dreamliner With Improved Battery on Test Flight
description: HANEDA AIRPORT, Japan  All Nippon Airways, the largest operator of Boeings 787 Dreamliners, made its first test flight Sunday of a jet fitted with fortified batteries. The two-hour trip is expected to pave the way for a full resumption of flights three months after burning batteries on two planes grounded the entire 787 global fleet.

title: Small in Stature Only, Robinson Scores 23 in the Fourth to Ignite the Bulls
description: CHICAGO  Early in the fourth quarter Saturday, Gerald Wallace set a hard screen on Nate Robinson in the Nets backcourt. Robinson weighs 35 pounds less and is 10 inches shorter than the 6-foot-7, 215-pound Wallace, and the collision had the feel of a puppy running into a Mack truck.

title: With Flick of His Elbow, Knicks Smith Throws Celtics a Lifeline
description: BOSTON  J. R. Smiths road to redemption was never going to be a simple, straight line. It was destined to be jagged, full of potholes and perilous hairpin turns. There were bound to be detours, even now, in the midst of his finest season.

title: Smiths Elbow Gives Angry Celtics Emotional Foothold in Series
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  Has J. R. Smith managed to do in one swoop what Doc Rivers couldnt do in three games and a capacity crowd at TD Garden couldnt do Friday night: awaken the catatonic Celtics with a much-needed jolt of energy?

title: Tournament Seeks to Turn the Game Into an Art Form
description: The Alekhine Memorial tournament began last weekend as an unusual attempt to highlight chess as an art form.

title: Jets Take Passer but Few Players to Surround Him
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For a team desperate to find answers in the first draft orchestrated by its new general manager, John Idzik, the Jets completed a process critical to their rebuilding with an inordinate number of questions.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 27, 2013

title: Leo Branton Jr., Activists Lawyer, Dies at 91
description: Leo Branton Jr., a California lawyer whose moving closing argument in a racially and politically charged murder trial in 1972 helped persuade an all-white jury to acquit a black communist, the activist and academic Angela Davis, died on April 19 in Los Angeles. He was 91.

title: Shamshad Begum, Unseen Singer of Indian Film, Dies at 94
description: Shamshad Begum, a star singer in India during the early years of Hindi cinema, died on Tuesday at her home in Mumbai. She was 94.

title: Phone Calls Discussing Jihad Prompted Russian Warning on Tsarnaev
description: The Russian warning to the United States government in 2011 about Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of two brothers accused in the Boston Marathon bombing on April 15, was based on two intercepted telephone calls discussing jihad, both involving his mother, a law enforcement official said on Saturday.

title: Feminist Editor Dies in Motorcycle Accident
description: Update, April 29 | Read Ms. Thoms obituary.

title: N.F.L. Draft Selections by Round for 2013
description: A full list of N.F.L. draft picks with teams, schools and positions.

title: Who Rules the Street in Cairo? The Residents Who Build It
description: CAIRO  The telltale signs in post-revolutionary Egypt are not just the riots and rapes, the mega-traffic snarls and sectarian battles. There is also the highway ramp in Ard El Lewa.

title: The Egyptian Revolutions Transformation of Cairo, Block by Block
description: After decades of not being able to make decisions about their city, Cairenes are taking its development into their own hands.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Audiences Pick Their Favorites
description: A film that won over the Tribeca Film Festivals jury has proven popular with the events audiences as well.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 28
description: The view on him was that he was a boxer and you would not want to mess with him.

title: Obama Takes a Turn as Comedian in Chief
description: WASHINGTON  Accustomed to the role of target, President Obama exacted a light-hearted revenge on his tormentors in the news media and Congress on Saturday night with a joke-filled riff at the capitals premier star-studded gala.

title: Corrections: April 28, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Kathryn Sims, Kevin McQuarrie
description: Kathryn Lee Sims and Kevin Andrew McQuarrie were married Saturday in Chicago at St. Michaels in Old Town Church. The Rev. Thomas M. Santa, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Marie Otterbein, Jeffrey Muehlethaler
description: Marie Sarah Otterbein and Jeffrey Charles Muehlethaler were married Saturday at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York. The Very Rev. Frederick L. Cain, an episcopal vicar of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh, performed the ceremony.

title: Bridget Bland, Mychal Bogee
description: Bridget Gabrielle Bland and Lowery Mychal Bogee were married Saturday in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Joe Wadas, a Roman Catholic priest now affiliated with CITI Ministries, performed a nondenominational ceremony in Monterey Square.

title: David Gardiner and David Branham III
description: David Scott Gardiner and David Conrad Branham III were married Friday by Marie R. Lennon, a deputy city clerk, at the Brooklyn Municipal Building.

title: Margaret Frank, Alan Hsu
description: Margaret Mercedes Frank and Dr. Alan John Hsu were married Saturday at the Long Beach Museum of Art in Long Beach, Calif. Priscilla A. Munson, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Allison Floeting, Steven Chanin
description: Allison Millar Floeting and Steven Henry Chanin were married Saturday evening at the Brazilian Court hotel in Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard Polirer officiated.

title: A First Date That Almost Wasnt
description: Marietta Pasqua Dindo and Bradley Taylor Danforth were married Saturday evening at Greystone in Piedmont Park, an event space in Atlanta. The Rev. Reeda Allen, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated.

title: Sarah Burleson, Benjamin Branham
description: Sarah Marguerite Burleson and Benjamin Michael Branham were married Saturday evening at Salvage One, an event space in Chicago. The Rev. Ron Crowley-Koch, a Norbertine Catholic priest, officiated. Father Crowley-Kochs wife, the Rev. Mary Grace Crowley-Koch, a minister of the Federation of Christian Ministries, took part in the ceremony.

title: Eliza Gardiner, Kristian Stensland
description: Eliza Weld Gardiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel S. Gardiner of Brookline, Mass., was married Saturday to Kristian Donald Stensland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Stensland of Snohomish, Wash. Phyllis Gardiner, an aunt of the bride, officiated at the Fairmont Copley Plaza in Boston, having received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: Jessica Zimmerman, Matthew Lawrence Jr.
description: Jessica Erin Zimmerman and Matthew Harold Lawrence Jr. were married Friday at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Verona, N.J. David Strader, a deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: Amanda Sadacca, Marc Avigdor
description: Leigh Amanda Sadacca and Marc Avigdor were married Saturday at the Pond in Central Park. Juliette A. Portnoy, the sister of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony, officiated.

title: Going the Distance
description: Suzanne Markette Weaver and Stephen Curry James were married Saturday in Louisville, Ky. Judge Boyce F. Martin Jr. of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, with chambers in Louisville, officiated at the home of Chris T. Radtke and Dr. Norman D. Radtke, friends of the couple.

title: Marielle Kress, Eric Goldstein
description: Marielle Julia Kress and Eric Loren Goldstein were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Robert N. Levine at the Pierre hotel in Manhattan.

title: Alexandra Garrison, Norman Barnett
description: Alexandra Veronica Garrison and Norman Lewis Barnett were married Saturday at St. Paul of the Cross Catholic Church in Atlanta. The Rev. Jerome McKenna, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Chandra Ram, Jay Wilder
description: Chandra Anne-Marie Ram and Jay Randall Wilder were married Saturday at Gallery 1028, an event space in Chicago. Chetan Ghai, a friend of the groom who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Allina, Justin Lott
description: Elizabeth Anne Allina and Justin Fair Lott were married Saturday at Middleton Place, a plantation and house museum in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. William P. Billow, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: How About Back in the U.S.S.R.?
description: Caroline Latimer Stewart, a daughter of Iris L. Stewart and David B. Stewart of Lakeland, La., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Robert James Colvin Jr., the son of Lynne H. Colvin and Mr. Colvin Sr. of Danville, Calif. The Right Rev. James M. Coleman, a retired Episcopal bishop of West Tennessee and an uncle of the bride, officiated on Alma Plantation, which is run by the brides family, at the home of Mrs. Hampton Pitcher Stewart, the brides paternal grandmother.

title: Paige Kollock and Raed Fakih
description: Paige Terry Kollock and Raed Fakih were married Saturday at the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the ceremony, which included a poem by Khalil Gibran and other readings in Arabic.

title: Tovah Tripp, William Rafelson
description: Tovah Bass Tripp, the daughter of Ellen Bass and Steven J. Tripp of Westfield, N.J., is to be married Sunday to William Matthew Rafelson, a son of Constance S. Rafelson and Dr. Stephen A. Rafelson of Moorestown, N.J. Rabbi Douglas Sagal is to officiate at the Maplewood Country Club in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Helen Lamphere and Renny McPherson
description: Helen Morehouse Lamphere, a daughter of Louise Woolworth Lamphere and Gilbert Hicks Lamphere, both of Manhattan, was married Saturday to Forbes Reynolds McPherson, the son of Tina Sloan-McPherson and Stephen M. McPherson of Manhattan. The Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Jessica Lohrman, Jason Prager
description: Jessica Marie Lohrman and Jason Thomas Prager were married Saturday in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Bruce V. Puckett, a minister of the Church of the Nazarene, performed the ceremony at the Duke University Chapel.

title: Kate Wilkinson, Cornelius Armentrout
description: Kate Roseanne Wilkinson and Cornelius Van Schaack Armentrout were married Saturday evening at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn. Suanne Bonan, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Marci Bellows, Seth Lindenman
description: Rabbi Marci Nanette Bellows and Seth Jason Lindenman are to be married Sunday in Lincolnshire, Ill. Rabbi Ilyse Glickman is to officiate at the Lincolnshire Marriott Resort, with Cantor David Rosen taking part.

title: Emily Chaloner and Justin Haan
description: Emily Beth Chaloner, the daughter of Susan E. Yohalem of Boston and Robert S. Chaloner of East Hampton, N.Y., was married Saturday to Justin Harris Haan, a son of Linda Zane Haan and Rick A. Haan of Morristown, N.J. Rabbi Brian Zachary Mayer officiated at Cornerstone Gardens, a sculpture garden in Sonoma, Calif.

title: Daniele Harmon and Ray Klien
description: Daniele Ann Harmon and Ray Tristyn Klien were married Friday evening. The Rev. Jonathan M. Brown, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Bridgeview Yacht Club in Island Park, N.Y.

title: Amanda Rosenhaus, Joseph Roth
description: Amanda Rachel Rosenhaus, a daughter of Jayne and Richard Rosenhaus of Aventura, Fla., was married Saturday to Joseph Harris Roth, the son of Wendy and Ben Roth of Deerfield, Ill. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York.

title: An Open Spot on the Family Tree
description: Amy Marie Pederson and Anthony Gilfillan Converse were married Saturday at the Dakota in New York, in the apartment of the grooms parents, Sue Ann Converse and Tony Converse. The older Mr. Converse, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Jessica Eisenberg, Daniel Cole
description: Dr. Jessica Eve Eisenberg, the daughter of Jean Grossman-Eisenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. William M. Eisenberg, was married Saturday in Manhattan to Daniel Charles Cole, the son of Myra R. Cole and Peter A. Cole of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson officiated at the Yale Club.

title: Julia Heming, Jeffrey Segal
description: Julia Fyrwald Heming and Jeffrey Raanan Segal were married Saturday at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Joe Haley, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Colleen McStravick, Christopher Areson
description: Colleen Patricia McStravick, the daughter of Nanette M. McStravick and James W. McStravick of Wayne, Pa., was married Saturday to Christopher Robert Areson, the son of Nicole Malladot Areson and David C. Areson of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John Guest, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, Fla.

title: Waves Are Different After Sandy, and Some Surfers Say Better
description: Walking down Beach 90th Street in Rockaway offers a glimpse of a neighborhood in the midst of an uphill battle: windows are shuttered, lawns are littered with debris and a beach is unprotected by its boardwalk. Yet as Rockaway slowly recovers, block by block, one crucial element is back, and, according to some, better: the wave.

title: Confidence Issues Linger as the Dreamliner Soars Again
description: BEIJING  For nearly two hours on Sunday morning a Boeing Dreamliner 787 cruised the skies above Japan, with Boeing chief of commercial aircraft, Ray Conner, and the All Nippon Airways president, Shinichiro Ito, on board.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: What explains this increasing perversion in society, where even children arent spared? Debarshi Dasgupta and Prachi Pinglay-Plumber ask in Outlook magazine (print only). The authors survey the increasing number of reports of child sex abuse and ask what it is about Indian society that is causing this phenomenon. According to the National Crime Records Bureau between 2001 and 2011 there has been a three-fold increase in registered cases of child sex abuse, from 2,113 in 2001 to 7,112 a decade later. In speaking with experts in the field and those who deal with victims and perpetrators of child sex abuse, the authors find that it is not easy to determine a direct cause for the increase in sex abuse among minors. They find that offenders vary in behavior and psychology and therefore it is both hard to draw any generalizations and create effective means of prevention.

title: Contrary to Reports, the Champions League Final Isnt Set Yet
description: Will you be watching the second legs of the Champions League semifinals this week  Borussia Dortmunds visit to Real Madrid on Tuesday, and Bayern Munichs journey to Barcelona a day later? We ask because, if you havent heard, the outcome is a foregone conclusion, what with last weeks blowouts and the era of Spanish dominance being over and German soccer ascendant and plates shifting and all that.

title: Monetarism Falls Short (Somewhat Wonkish)
description: The central debate over macroeconomic policy is, of course, between Keynesians and Austerians. And at this point the Keynesians have overwhelmingly won the debate everywhere except where it matters  the intellectual basis for austerity economics has collapsed, but actual austerity continues apace on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Knaves, Fools, and Me (Meta)
description: One criticism I face fairly often is the assertion that I must be dishonest  I must be cherry-picking my evidence, or something  because the way I describe it, Im always right while the people who disagree with me are always wrong. And not just wrong, theyre often knaves or fools. How likely is that?

title: 3 Shot Near Premiers Office as Italys Cabinet Is Sworn In
description: ROME  Two military police officers and a passer-by were shot and wounded on Sunday in a crowded square outside the office of Prime Minister Enrico Letta and near the presidential palace, where his new government was being sworn in.

title: At Least 8 Killed in Taliban Attacks on Candidates in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Taliban attacks on election candidates in northwestern Pakistan killed at least eight people and wounded dozens on Sunday, adding to a growing toll of militant violence before elections scheduled for May 11.

title: Months After Newtown, Sorting Boxes of Grief
description: What do we do with the things people leave behind? What does it mean to move on, from the death of someone you love, or a divorce, which is a death of a different kind?

title: Red Bulls Rewind: Cahill Saves the Day
description: Tim Cahills long (inter)national nightmare of answering questions about not scoring goals is over  at least for now.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: Never Say Die
description: As the arrival of Derby Week brings horseracing fans simmering anticipation for the first Saturday in May to a full boil, it also provides an opportunity for some reflection on the sports rich history. Below, an excerpt from Never Say Die: A Kentucky Colt, the Epsom Derby, and the Rise of the Modern Thoroughbred Industry.

title: Boeing Jet Returns to the Air, but Its Only a Start
description: HANEDA AIRPORT, JAPAN  Katsuhiro Ogami, a top engineer at All Nippon Airways, could not sit still Sunday on the airlines first test flight of a Boeing 787 Dreamliner jet fitted with fortified batteries. He peered, and peered again, at a monitor hooked to the planes batteries for any signs of overheating.

title: Rushing to Replace Picnic Tables Lost to Storm
description: This spring has been no picnic for Chris Gruber and his staff of carpenters, who work for New York City and make much of the equipment used at its parks and beaches.

title: Disruptions: Brain Computer Interfaces Inch Closer to Mainstream
description: Last week, engineers sniffing around the programming code for Google Glass found hidden examples of ways that people might interact with the wearable computers without having to say a word. Among them, a user could nod to turn the glasses on or off. A single wink might tell the glasses to take a picture.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE GOOD WIFE Season 4 concludes as Alicia (Julianna Margulies), Will (Josh Charles) and Diane (Christine Baranski) race through emergency court proceedings on the night of the election for governor. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, above with Chris Noth, left, appears as himself.

title: Mary Thom, an Editor Who Shaped Feminist Voices, Dies at 68
description: Mary Thom, a chronicler of the feminist movement and former executive editor of Ms. magazine, died Friday in a motorcycle accident in Yonkers. She was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Writing Coach Becomes a Listener
description: The written word looms over William Zinsser. The many hundreds of books in his Upper East Side apartment stand at attention, as if awaiting instruction from this slight man in a baseball cap and sunglasses who, for a half-century, has coached others on how to write.

title: Top Lieutenant of Dimon Is Departing JPMorgan
description: A senior executive in the inner circle of Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chases chief executive, is leaving, the latest departure after the bank reported a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year.

title: An Italian Leader and a Political Acrobat
description: ROME  To select the cabinet that he presented Saturday to President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy, Prime Minister Enrico Letta, the new head of government, relied on what are widely acknowledged as his consummate skills: an ability to negotiate and a gift for building bridges, even between forces that barely speak to each other.

title: Pain & Gain Leads Sluggish Box Office
description: Two new movies, Michael Bays Pain & Gain and the star-studded romantic comedy The Big Wedding, left audiences underwhelmed  both pictures received a C-plus score in exit polls  as an overall North American box-office slump continued over the weekend.

title: Lawmakers Call for Stronger U.S. Action in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on Capitol Hill took President Obama to task Sunday for what they characterized as dangerous inaction in Syria, while Democrats urged the White House to step up its humanitarian response to the two-year-old civil war that has killed 70,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands more.

title: Wealth Gap      Among Races     Has Widened Since     Recession
description: WASHINGTON  Millions of Americans suffered a loss of wealth during the recession and the sluggish recovery that followed. But the last half-decade has proved far worse for black and Hispanic families than for white families, starkly widening the already large gulf in wealth between non-Hispanic white Americans and most minority groups, according to a new study from the Urban Institute.

title: After 103 Years, Still Rolling in Queens
description: The Queensboro Motorcycle Club, founded in 1910, has had its clubhouse for 70 years wedged among the auto salvage shops in the Willets Point section of Queens.

title: Figuring Out the Games Seasonal Rhythms
description: I feel sorry for people who never have to put their golf game in hibernation. Sure, they live where the weather is generally warm. They play golf whenever they feel like it. They can keep their swing thoughts fresh and their bodies limber.

title: As Obama Faces Crises Abroad, His Foreign Policy Approval Is Down
description: Crises have flared abroad in the last several weeks, in North Korea and Syria, just as public opinion surveys have shown a dip in Americans approval of President Obamas handling of foreign policy.

title: Humanity Still Blooms in a Desert Bordering Mexico
description: Though relatively dispassionate bipartisanship has asserted itself in the immigration debate lately, its still not hard to find meanspiritedness in some quarters. A man at a recent town-hall meeting held by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, suggested that the best way to stop those who would enter the United States without authorization was with a gun.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Robbed at Gunpoint, Some Bronx Victims Resist
description: The first armed robbery attempt was in October, on a residential Bronx block near an elevated train stop. The victim fought back. He was shot in the leg.

title: Bombings Trip Up Reddit in Its Turn in Spotlight
description: In the days after the Boston Marathon bombings, the social media and entertainment site Reddit had the breakout moment it had been waiting for  but not the one it expected.

title: Iceland Ousts Government That Steered It Out of Crisis
description: LONDON  Voters in Iceland have ousted the center-left government that restored the country to solvency after the 2008 financial crisis, paving the way for the return to power of the center-right parties that many people blamed for causing the crisis.

title: Overbay Helps Yankees Sweep Dickey and Blue Jays
description: The injured starting shortstop, third baseman and first baseman are not expected on the field soon, and the outfielder who had 43 home runs last season (Curtis Granderson) is in Florida rehabilitating after an injury. Sundays lineup had only one legitimate preseason All-Star candidate (Robinson Cano) and two players who were released during spring training this year. Even General Manager Brian Cashman, who broke his leg in a sky-diving accident, is still on the mend.

title: The New Look of Public Relations
description: A GIANT in public relations is spinning in a new direction, reshaping itself in significant ways that underscore how agencies of all kinds are being made over to better serve marketer clients in the 21st century.

title: Terry Jabs Knicks as Celtics Stay Alive
description: BOSTON  Jason Terry was upright again Sunday afternoon, his chin and his jump shot in working order, his conviction strong and his missions clear: Save the Boston Celtics season. Extend an era. If at all possible, irritate the Knicks just a little bit more.

title: Researchers Put Sense of Touch in Reach for Robots
description: Finding and recognizing objects by touch in your pocket, in the dark or among items on a cluttered table top are distinctly human skills  ones that have been far beyond the ability of even the most dexterous robotic arms.

title: Augie Boehm at the Honors Bridge Club in Manhattan
description: Augie Boehm of New York is almost as well known a pianist as he is a bridge expert. On May 13 he will give his 35th annual recital at the Weill Recital Hall in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are still available at the box office.

title: Villainous Christmas and Biker Heroines
description: Joe Hill takes a cheery little Oedipal swipe at his father in the acknowledgment pages of his throat-grabbing new novel, NOS4A2. He describes the two of them riding back roads on motorcycles, Mr. Hill on his Triumph. His father, a Harley snob, admires the Triumph but says its engine reminds him of a sewing machine.

title: Mets Tinker With Offense but Are Unable to Fix It
description: Before Sunday afternoons series finale against the Philadelphia Phillies, Terry Collins met with his coaching staff at Citi Field. The Mets had lost three straight games, their offensive slumbering and their relief pitching edging close to the realm of unmitigated disaster. Something needed to change.

title: Ruminating on Love and Desire
description: Whenever the New York Philharmonic takes a break from Lincoln Center to play at Carnegie Hall there is usually a special program suited to the occasion. So it was on Friday night for a concert conducted by Alan Gilbert.

title: Opinions and Feelings, Years in the Making, Play Out
description: In the 1960s, when she was in her 20s, Annette Peacock figured out how to write slow, spacious, long-form, highly original piano ballads as if the notes were falling naturally from her fingers, and that sounded, when ideally replayed, as if she were composing them all over again. She sang them with the full range of her voice, making them twice as good, with a kind of severe passion, only semi-sentimental, following their unsettling, unresolving melodic trajectories. They were somewhere between rudimentary and very achieved: new lieder, or some radically decelerated soul-jazz hybrid, or melted torch numbers.

title: American Crossword Puzzle Tournament  Brooklyn or Stamford? A Special Message from Will Shortz
description: The 37th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament will be held March 7-9, 2014, at the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott, where the event has been for the past six years. Our contract with the hotel runs through then.

title: An Artist Brushes Off the Constraints of Chart-Friendly Songs
description: I think its fair to say that Im probably not really known for my three-minute pop songs, the English singer and multi-instrumentalist Steven Wilson said from the stage of the Best Buy Theater during his concert there on Friday night. However, very occasionally, I can write something that clocks in at under 15 minutes that I think, you know what?, thats not bad, he continued as preface to Postcard, a four-and-a-half-minute ballad.

title: Rocky Musical Is Heading to Broadway
description: The new stage musical Rocky, an adaptation of the Oscar-winning film about a streetwise boxer from Philadelphia, is coming to Broadway next year, with preview performances set to begin in February at the Winter Garden Theater, the lead producers announced on Sunday.

title: Self-Mockery in Movement, and Divination in Ritual
description: What connects the choreographers Souleymane Badolo and Cynthia Oliver? He was born and raised in Burkina Faso. She was born in the Bronx but raised in the Virgin Islands. Whatever African heritage they might have in common, it seems a thin pretext for their sharing a program. But so it was at New York Live Arts on Thursday.

title: Heres to the First 48, in Lessons of Word and Song
description: During one section of Gabriels Guide to the 48 States, which received its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra stood and sang a sacred harp hymn, a genre of a cappella choral music that evolved in the South. The excerpt came under the heading Alabama, one stop on a musical voyage from the young composer Gabriel Kahane that was commissioned by Orpheus to celebrate its 40th anniversary this year.

title: Giving a Wide Berth to Artists of Cable TV
description: We used to turn on the television to see people who were happier, funnier, prettier versions of ourselves. But at the turn of the century, something fundamental changed and we began to see scarier, crazier, darker forms of the American way of life.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Attention, Audience; Attention, Shoppers
description: LOS ANGELES  Is Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorfs a film or an ad?

title: Stormy Relationship, Forgiving Followers
description: As Rihanna, one of the pop worlds most successful women, goes from arena to sold-out arena on her latest tour  which was to hit the Prudential Center in Newark on Sunday night and head to the Barclays Center in Brooklyn this weekend  the news media and her fans have been eager for updates on her relationship with the singer Chris Brown.

title: Man Refusing to Testify Before Grand Jury in Times Square Bombing Case
description: A Brooklyn man has said that he will refuse to testify before a federal grand jury that is believed to be looking into the explosion of a homemade bomb in Times Square in 2008, setting the stage for a confrontation that could send him to jail for contempt of court.

title: Once Upon a Landscape
description: When the artist Carol Bove was a girl, growing up in Berkeley, Calif., she once helped a friend of her fathers build a fish-shaped junk sculpture on the mud flats of nearby Emeryville, in a kind of guerrilla art park that free-spirited sculptors kept alive and weird for decades beginning in the 1960s.

title: Admitted at the Door
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  C.W. Stewart has laid out a feast for us today, except that were going to have to pry it out of the fingers of some well-known movie stars. Im up for it if you are.

title: Kenneth I. Appel, Mathematician Who Harnessed Computer Power, Dies at 80
description: Kenneth I. Appel, who helped usher the venerable mathematical proof into the computer age, solving a longstanding problem concerning colors on a map with the help of an I.B.M. computer making billions of decisions, died on April 19 in Dover, N.H. He was 80.

title: NBC Renews 5 Dramas
description: NBC really does have a batch of shows that are working, despite a rough patch this spring that even induced a presidential-level joke on Saturday night. Last week NBC announced it was renewing five drama series, including two, Revolution and Chicago Fire, that the network introduced this season. Grimm, arguably the networks most reliable drama, was another show that was renewed; it holds up Friday night for the network and has experienced a ratings increase of 14 percent this season. The ratings for Law & Order Special Victims Unit have descended to just about survival level, but that show will return in a move that has been a ritual for the network for 15 years. Parenthood, the well-regarded family drama that performed well this year (up 8 percent), had been truncated to only 15 episodes, a sign that the network did not have the most faith in its endurance before this season started. That was also a sign that cost was a factor in considering its fate: Parenthood has a big budget and an enormous cast, with several star-name actors, including Lauren Graham, Peter Krause and Dax Shepard. A renewal order had been in some doubt until last week because of those budget concerns, but NBC announced that Parenthood would be back and with a full order of 22 episodes. The NBC announcement didnt stop President Obama from taking a little shot at the networks prime-time woes at the White House Correspondents Dinner on Saturday night. Joking about his recent performance at a basketball demonstration, the president said: I took 22 shots and made 2 of them. Thats right, 2 hits and 20 misses. The executives at NBC asked, Whats your secret?

title: American Academy Announces Newest Class
description: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences announced on Wednesday that Bruce Springsteen, Pete Seeger and Herbie Hancock would be among the 198 newly elected members of its 2013 class. Among the other artists, writers, scientists and philanthropists who will be inducted in a ceremony scheduled for Oct. 12 in Cambridge, Mass., are Robert De Niro and Sally Field; the poets Annie Dillard and Natasha Trethewey; and the filmmaker Jonas Mekas, a co-founder of the Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan.

title: With Bags of Cash, C.I.A. Seeks Influence in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For more than a decade, wads of American dollars packed into suitcases, backpacks and, on occasion, plastic shopping bags have been dropped off every month or so at the offices of Afghanistans president  courtesy of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Sudan Says It Took Back Town Struck by Rebels
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Sudans government said that its troops had regained control of a town attacked by members of a rebel alliance, but some of the towns residents lashed out at local officials for failing to provide adequate security, state media and witnesses said Sunday.

title: Court Ruling Takes a Stand on Essential High-Tech Patents
description: The high-tech patents wars are fed by the value of patents as weapons for extracting rich sums from companies and competitors.

title: Beastie Boys Sign a Memoir Deal
description: If the Beastie Boys wrote a book, you might expect it to depart from standard memoir form. Rather than a strict narrative patiently winding its way from bygone days, such a book might  in keeping with the groups hypereclectic style  be a pastiche of voices, images, irreverent humor and pop-culture reference points.

title: On Borges, Particles and the Paradox of the Perceived
description: In 1927 a young German physicist published a paper that would turn the scientific world on its head. Until that time, classical physics had assumed that when a particles position and velocity were known, its future trajectory could be calculated. Werner Heisenberg demonstrated that this condition was actually impossible: we cannot know with precision both a particles location and its velocity, and the more precisely we know the one, the less we can know the other. Five years later he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for having laid the foundations of quantum physics.

title: Iraq Revokes Licenses of Al Jazeera and 9 Other TV Channels
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs government on Sunday revoked the operating licenses of Al Jazeera and nine other television channels, saying that they were inciting sectarian conflict. All but one of the channels are aligned with Sunni financial backers, and the move was widely perceived as a crackdown on dissent by the Shiite-led government that is facing an increasingly violent Sunni uprising.

title: During Jury Selection, Trying to Erase Politics From a Politicized Fraud Trial
description: As jury selection began two weeks ago in the fraud trial of two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller who is now running for mayor, the judge sought to weed out potential bias or other disqualifying factors.

title: Sheik Said to Pursue Soccer Franchise for Queens
description: The Russian entrepreneur Mikhail D. Prokhorov owns the Nets basketball team. Red Bull, the Austrian-based energy drink company, owns the Red Bulls soccer team. Now a member of the royal family of Abu Dhabi is poised to become the latest foreign owner of a New York-area professional sports franchise.

title: Israel Says It Is Not Seeking U.S. Intervention in Syria
description: A senior Israeli official said Sunday that Israel was not urging the United States to take military action in Syria, despite intelligence assessments asserting that the government of President Bashar al-Assad recently used chemical weapons in the civil war gripping its country.

title: New Suburban Dream Born of Asia and Southern California
description: SAN MARINO, Calif.  Beneath the palm trees that line Huntington Drive, named for the railroad magnate who founded this Southern California city, hang signs to honor families who have helped sponsor the centennial celebration here this year. There are names like Dryden, Crowley and Telleen, families that have lived here for generations. But there are newer names as well: Sun, Koo and Shi.

title: Art Links High Line to Its Past
description: Carol Boves work links the High Line to its feral origins.

title: Venture Capitalists Are Making Bigger Bets on Food Start-Ups
description: What if the next big thing in tech does not arrive on your smartphone or in the cloud? What if it lands on your plate?

title: Pockets of Asian Growth
description: The growth of Asians has outpaced that of Hispanics in the last 10 years, especially near Californias urban centers.

title: Deal Gives News Site a Presence on Cable TV
description: The Huffington Post has found a partial home on cable television for its eight-month-old Internet channel, HuffPost Live, courtesy of Mark Cuban.

title: Clashes in Iraq Carry Worries of a New Civil War
description: BAGHDAD  In the final days before the United States withdrew its troops from Iraq, American intelligence officers worried that a future Sunni insurgency here might be led not by Al Qaeda but by an organization whose leaders are former high-level members of Saddam Husseins Baath Party.

title: A Plus-Size Giant With Big Talent
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If Pablo Sandoval hits a home run for every pound between his listed 240 and his actual weight, he may end up as the National Leagues most valuable player. From the standpoint of body mass and natural ability, it is not such an outlandish proposition.

title: Center Will Offer New Tools for Measuring the Impact of Media Beyond Numbers
description: LOS ANGELES  What is the difference?

title: A New York City Trek the Census Might Love
description: At the edge of a quiet residential street in Brooklyn, Moses Gates stood atop a large pile of rocks, surrounded by nearly two dozen people.

title: Tears and Rage as Hope Fades in Bangladesh
description: SAVAR, Bangladesh  The mother stood at the edge of the wreckage, pressing her lips to photos of her two children  Asma, who had worked in a garment factory on the fourth floor, and Sultan, who worked on the fifth.

title: Group Shows Covert Video of a Bronx Abortion Clinic
description: An anti-abortion group that previously released several videotapes of undercover visits to abortion clinics released another video on Sunday of a staff member at a Bronx clinic describing late-term abortion procedures. The group likened the practices to those at the clinic of Dr. Kermit Gosnell, the Philadelphia doctor charged with killing viable fetuses.

title: Two Informants: Hollywood vs. Reality
description: A look at the link between two D.E.A. informants: one, a character played by Benicio Del Toro in the movie Traffic, the other, a former adviser to Mexicos drug czar, now living as a fugitive.

title: The Wealth Gap
description: The gap between the wealth of different races grew during the recession, with the average white family now about six times as wealthy as black and Hispanic families.

title: De Informante a Fugitivo
description: Luis Octavio Lpez Vega era vez un poderoso jefe de polica en Mxico, y un valioso informante de la DEA. Hoy vive huyendo, dejado a la deriva por Estados Unidos y buscado por el gobierno mexicano.

title: From Informant to Fugitive
description: Luis Octavio Lpez Vega was once a powerful police chief in Mexico and a valued D.E.A. informant. Today he lives on the run, set adrift by the United States and sought by the Mexican government.

title: New Look at a C.I.A. Officers Death
description: STRASBOURG, France  The new government of Georgia is taking a new look at one of the unsolved mysteries left over from the chaotic collapse of the Soviet Union: the shooting death of a C.I.A. officer, Freddie Woodruff, on a dusty road on the outskirts of the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, 20 years ago.

title: The Takeaway Aims to Add Local Flavor to News Reports
description: As public radio stations around the country search for more compelling midday programs and ways to be more local, the producers of The Takeaway are pushing to fill that void, with a reformulated show that includes more perspectives from reporters at local stations, instead of presenting a purely national perspective.

title: Two Classics of the Soaps Are Heading to the Web
description: On Monday the soap operas All My Children and One Life to Live will start their second lives, and Jeffrey Kwatinetz and Rich Frank will start to find out if theyre right.

title: A Drug War Informer in No Mans Land
description: The forecast called for record snowstorms, and Luis Octavio Lpez Vega had no heat in his small hide-out.

title: Un Informante de la Guerra Contra el Narcotrfico en Tierra de Nadie
description: El pronstico del tiempo haba advertido sobre tormentas rcord de nieve, y Luis Octavio Lpez Vega no tena forma de calentar su pequeo escondite.

title: Obama to Nominate Charlotte Mayor to Transportation Post
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday plans to nominate Anthony R. Foxx, the mayor of Charlotte, N.C., to be the next secretary of transportation, choosing a rising young African-American from the South to balance out a cabinet criticized for a lack of diversity.

title: Calling 911 Shouldnt Lead to Jail
description: PARENTS of drug-addicted kids learn the hard way that when we think things cant get worse, they do. As a teenager, my son, Nic, was addicted to methamphetamine, heroin and other drugs. At 20, he had used most of the illicit drugs known to man. But one night, partying with a couple of friends in his basement apartment in Brooklyn, the combination and volume caused him to overdose. One of his friends called 911.

title: Valeants Talks to Take Over Another Drug Maker Are Said to Fall Through
description: Merger talks between Valeant Pharmaceuticals and another drug maker, Actavis, have fallen through, according to a person briefed on the matter, potentially ending what would have been one of the biggest health care deals of the year.

title: Ditch the King. Hire an Actor.
description: AMSTERDAM

title: Greek Parliament Passes Plan for Layoffs
description: ATHENS  Greeces Parliament late Sunday approved a contentious plan to dismiss 15,000 civil servants by the end of next year as part of a new package of economic measures that the country must enforce to clinch crucial financing from foreign creditors.

title: The Story of Our Time
description: Those of us who have spent years arguing against premature fiscal austerity have just had a good two weeks. Academic studies that supposedly justified austerity have lost credibility; hard-liners in the European Commission and elsewhere have softened their rhetoric. The tone of the conversation has definitely changed.

title: Russian Security Forces Kill 2 Suspected Rebels in Dagestan
description: MAKHACHKALA, Russia  Russian security forces in Dagestan killed two men in a counterterrorism operation on Sunday; officials said one of the men was a suspect in a series of bomb attacks on local police convoys.

title: A Haven for the Deaf Draws Federal Scrutiny Over Potential Discrimination
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  When the subsidized housing complex for senior citizens opened its doors here last year, it already had a waiting list. Designed by a deaf architect to fit the needs of the deaf, its units have video phones and lights that flash when the phone or the doorbell rings. Wiring in common areas pipes announcements made through loudspeakers into residents hearing aids.

title: Predatory Lenders
description: Federal banking regulators are clamping down on the small but growing number of banks that emulate the predatory practices of storefront payday lenders. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency last week proposed solid new guidelines for the banks they oversee. The Federal Reserve, which oversees other banks that do this, needs to pick up this same theme and follow suit.

title: Wins and Losses in the Fight Against Tobacco
description: Cigarette packages are unlikely to carry graphic warning labels anytime soon as a result of separate actions by the Supreme Court and the Food and Drug Administration. That is a setback, though perhaps temporary, for the federal governments campaign to reduce the health damage caused by this highly lethal product. The silver lining is that the Supreme Court left intact most of the F.D.A.s powers to regulate this industry.

title: Erasing History
description: One of my favorite coffee-table books is an odd volume called The Commissar Vanishes, a portfolio of doctored photographs from Stalins Russia. When Stalin purged one of his fellow Bolsheviks, the comrade who fell from favor was duly cropped or airbrushed out of official photographs. The Commissar Vanishes juxtaposes the before and after. Here is the party stalwart grinning alongside Lenin in Red Square; and now  poof!  hes gone. Person, un-person. History, un-history.

title: Congressional Restraints on Gun Safety
description: One of the cynical arguments that Senate members recently invoked in ducking their responsibility to enact stronger gun controls was that the government first needed to enforce laws already on the books. The hollow, Catch-22 reality of this position has been underlined by a new inspector generals report pointing out that a severely understaffed and underfinanced federal firearms agency failed to inspect nearly 60 percent of the nations 125,000 licensed gun dealers in the last five years.

title: Next Steps on Military Sexual Assaults
description: In the last big health survey of active-duty American military personnel, conducted in 2011 and released last week, one in five female service members said they had been subjected to unwanted sexual contact since joining the military. That shocking statistic squares with other alarming indicators of the militarys pervasive culture of sexual misconduct. It also underscores the urgent need to change that culture.

title: Taking Aim at History
description: Kevin Krigger, who will ride Goldencents in the Kentucky Derby, will be attempting to become the first black jockey to win the race since Jimmy Winkfield won in 1901 and 1902.

title: History Aside, Jockey Kevin Krigger Is Just Out to Win
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Every day at 5:15 a.m., Kevin Kriggers alarm clock goes off. Sometimes he hits the snooze button; sometimes he turns off the alarm, and his fiance has to coax him out of bed. But once he does rise, he never regrets it.

title: Where OSHA Falls Short, and Why
Adult Day Care Centers
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisiting Childrens Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Online College, Beyond the Hoopla
Industrial Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: The Urban Fire Next Time
description: FOR the past several years all the ingredients have been in place for an urban crisis. Unemployment has hovered above 15 percent in many of our most distressed cities. High-poverty neighborhoods have spread beyond cities and into the suburbs. The housing collapse has left large sections of communities boarded up.

title: Endangering Our Beaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Going to Church Make You Healthier?
description: To the Editor:

title: Twitter Speaks, Markets Listen and Fears Rise
description: Could the global economy hinge on 140 characters?

title: Turning the Tables on the News Media Tease
description: Much like a friend who cant let you get to the punch line of a joke without getting there first, the Twitter feed @HuffPoSpoilers takes away the fun of the teasing headlines that The Huffington Post sends out about its articles.

title: Agents Pore Over Suspects Trip to Russia
description: F.B.I. agents are working closely with Russian security officials to reconstruct Tamerlan Tsarnaevs activities and connections in Dagestan during his six-month visit last year, tracking meetings he may have had with specific militants, his visits to a radical mosque and any indoctrination or training he may have received, law enforcement officials said Sunday.

title: Game 4: Knicks vs. Celtics
description: The Celtics blew a 19-point lead, but Jason Terry scored Bostons final 9 points in overtime to deliver a victory and force a Game 5.

title: Push to Require Online Sales Tax Divides the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation that would force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes from their customers has put antitax and small-government activists like Grover Norquists Americans for Tax Reform and the Heritage Foundation in an unusual position: theyre losing.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 28, 2013

title: Young Inmates Find a Voice Through Short Films
description: An expectant hush fell over more than 300 young adults packed into a theater at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center as a screening of short films was about to start. Amirah Harris was palpably excited  this would be not only her first time seeing her work on the big screen, but also her first time seeing it outside of jail.

title: Archiving in the Digital Era
description: Want to see Einsteins family tea set? How about scripts from The Carol Burnett Show? Archivists are the specialists who protect and display these objects for posterity, now more online than ever.

title: Celtics Muster a Days Worth of Defiance
description: BOSTON  Paul Pierce said he felt an almost surreal calmness Sunday. He did not think about the big picture  that it was perhaps his last game of the season, or maybe his career  but he did pick up his phone and make dinner reservations for Tuesday night in New York.

title: Leaving Cloister of Dusty Offices, Young Archivists Meet Like Minds
description: Their gatherings take place at locations as disparate as the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan or the Bohemian Hall and Beer Garden in Queens, but they always reflect their consummate knowledge of New York. And when the conversation turns to topics like chaos or historys turning points, no one is in a hurry to go home.

title: A Nasty, Epic Real Estate Battle With Stakes 102 Stories High
description: On the day it opened in 1931, the Empire State Building carved out a special place on the New York skyline, but it has also been at the center of a succession of battles for control by equally larger-than-life figures, including Donald J. Trump and Leona Helmsley.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include personal income and spending, pending home sales and the Dallas Feds manufacturing activity (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller Home Price Index, the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index and consumer confidence for April (Tuesday); A.D.P. employment for April, the I.S.M. manufacturing index for April and United States vehicle sales for April (Wednesday); the trade deficit for March and weekly initial jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for April (Friday).

title: Knicks Hit Bump on Road to Next Round
description: BOSTON

title: Massachusetts Voters Reminded Senate Primaries Are at Hand
description: BOSTON  Getting voters attention for a special election at an unexpected time of year is hard enough. It is even harder when the airwaves have been taken over by wall-to-wall coverage of a major disaster of the sort that struck the Boston Marathon two weeks ago.

title: Adolph Herseth, 91, Trumpeter With Chicago Symphony, Dies
description: Adolph Herseth, the principal trumpeter of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for 53 years and one of the most accomplished and influential orchestral trumpeters of his time, died on April 13 at his home in Oak Park, Ill. He was 91.

title: Donald Shirley, a Pianist With His Own Genre, Dies at 86
description: Donald Shirley, a pianist and composer who gathered classical music with jazz and other forms of popular music under a singular umbrella after being discouraged from pursuing a classical career because he was black, died on April 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Parks Win Wraps Up the L.P.G.A. Tours Successful Return to Dallas
description: DALLAS  With a final round of four-under-par 67, Inbee Park on Sunday became the first woman since Sandra Spuzich to win a regular L.P.G.A. Tour event in this city, her victory the golfing equivalent of reviving a dormant oil patch.

title: Do Markings Matter? Not in the Starting Gate
description: Horses are identified by markings: Colors, like chestnut, bay, dark bay or brown, gray or roan, are the most popular ones. And white socks, stars, stripes and stockings are among the other ways that horses are identified.

title: After Triply Hard Loss, Nets Must Find  Heart to Stay With  Bulls
description: The Nets did not practice on Sunday, but most of the team was at the training complex anyway, receiving treatment on sore limbs and largely licking the wounds from a three-overtime heartbreaker in Game 4 on Saturday that put them behind by 3-1 in the first-round playoff series against the Chicago Bulls.

title: James Asks Wade to Sit, Then Picks Up the Slack
description: MILWAUKEE  LeBron James and Dwyane Wade have pushed each other on the court since James joined the Miami Heat in the summer of 2010. On Sunday, James exerted his influence off the court.

title: As Playoffs Near, Stepans Game Value Exceeds Name Value
description: When the Rangers open their first-round playoff series against the Capitals in Washington on Thursday, all eyes will be on the bigger names like Rick Nash, Ryan Callahan and, of course, Alex Ovechkin. But the key to the Rangers success may lie with a forward who does not have the same name recognition, but appears well on his way: center Derek Stepan.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 29
description: I feel like Im running in place. After so many years, its exhausting.

title: Questioning the Pelvic Exam
description: In America, when a woman goes to her gynecologist, she is typically given a pelvic exam whether or not she has symptoms or concerns that might warrant one. Thats one reason an estimated 63.4 million pelvic exams are performed annually in this country.

title: Word of the Day | knead
description: knead \ned\ verb

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE QUEEN OF VERSAILLES (2012) The director Lauren Greenfield traces the lives of David Siegel, the billionaire founder of the Westgate Resorts time-share business, and his wife, Jackie, a former model 31 years his junior, as they embark on the construction of what is to be the largest home in America. The couple, above, plan to build a 90,000-square-foot mansion with 10 kitchens, a 6,000-square-foot master suite, a bowling alley, two tennis courts and a roller rink, modeled after the palace of Versailles in France and with room for their 8 children, 19 household employees and array of pets. But their blueprints dont take into account the financial crisis. On the eve of the Sundance Film Festival in January 2012, Mr. Siegel sued Ms. Greenfield for defamation, alleging that The Queen of Versailles depicted Westgate Resorts in an array of defamatory, derogatory and damaging ways. Ms. Greenfield won the directing award at the festival, where this documentary was nominated for the grand jury prize.

title: Corrections: April 29, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: My Happy Inflation Days
description: When I was a young man, I loved inflation.

title: News Quiz | April 29, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: At the Post Office, Praying for Delivery
description: Dear Diary:

title: IHT Quick Read: April 29
description: NEWS The collapse of a building in Bangladesh, the Rana Plaza, is considered the deadliest accident in the history of the garment industry, having claimed at least 377 lives. Jim Yardley reports from Savar, Bangladesh.

title: Farewell to an Enigmatic Chinese Bishop
description: BEIJING  Hundreds of people gathered Monday at St. Ignatius Cathedral in Shanghai for the funeral of Bishop Aloysius Jin Luxian, a towering figure of Chinese Catholicism who died Saturday at 96.

title: Bomber on Motorcycle Kills 9 During Rush Hour in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber killed 9 people and wounded 29 on a busy road here early on Monday, officials said, in the latest episode of violence as Pakistan moves nervously toward elections scheduled for May 11.

title: At Madurais Chithirai Thiruvizha Festival, Crowds, Flowers and a Golden Horse
description: The city of Chennai, formerly Madras, may be the most famous of Tamil Nadus cities, but the historical and cultural heart of Indias southernmost state is arguably Madurai.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 29, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article In a Rare Show at Radio City, Two Prizefighters Will Take the Stage.

title: After Etihad Deal, Indias Airlines May Attract More Foreign Interest
description: MUMBAI  Could the economic reforms introduced by the Indian government in September save Indias beleaguered aviation industry?

title: New Prom Challenges Tradition in Georgia
description: In A Racial Divide Closes as Students Step Up, Robbie Brown writes about four students who have made history in Wilcox County, Ga.:

title: Syrian Prime Minister Escapes Assassins Bomb
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Prime Minister Wael Nader al-Halqi of Syria escaped what appeared to be an assassination attempt on Monday in an upscale neighborhood of Damascus, where a car bomb exploded near his convoy, according to state-run media and opposition accounts. The blast was the latest in a series of attacks on high-ranking Syrians targeted by insurgents in the civil war.

title: Livin La Vida Rio
description: David Alan Harveys (based on a true story) is an unusual mix of classic documentary images of Rio de Janeiro and casual shots of Mr. Harveys personal experiences there, including photographs of his muses  several Brazilian women who assisted him.

title: Have You Ever Felt Embarrassed by Things You Used to Like?
description: As we grow up and experience new things, our beliefs often change, just as our ideas about how we want to look and act also evolve over time.

title: The Welfare Queen of Denmark
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Peggy Orenstein on Rethinking Her Stance on Mammograms
description: Peggy Orenstein, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover article on the public-relations machine fueling breast-cancer awareness and what it means for patients health. She is the author of several books, most recently Cinderella Ate My Daughter: Dispatches from the Front Lines of the New Girlie-Girl Culture.

title: Does the College Major Matter? Not Really
description: Jeffrey J. Selingo is the editor at large of The Chronicle of Higher Education and the author of College (Un)Bound: The Future of Higher Education and What It Means for Students, to be published May 7 by New Harvest. This post is adapted from the book.

title: Van Goghs True Palette Revealed
description: AMSTERDAM  The Bedroom, Vincent van Goghs 1888 painting, with its honey-yellow bed pressed into the corner of a cozy sky-blue room, is instantly recognizable to art lovers, with his signature contrasting hues. But does our experience of this painting change upon learning that van Gogh had originally depicted those walls in violet, not blue, or that he was less a painter wrestling with his demons and more of a deliberate, goal-oriented artist?

title: 10 Syrians Dead or Missing in Ship Collision Off Greece
description: ATHENS  At least 10 Syrian sailors were dead or missing after two cargo ships collided off the coast of the Peloponnese region in southwestern Greece early Monday, the Greek authorities said.

title: Another Russian Trial
description: ZUBOVA POLYANA, Russia  After the court hearing was over, a shell-shocked group of activists, lawyers and journalists looked for an explanation for what had happened. The decision hadnt surprised anyone: As expected, the judge denied parole for the leader of the punk band Pussy Riot, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova. But the court hearing itself had unraveled suddenly.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 29, 2013
description: Updated | April 30, 2013

title: This Week in Small Business: 6,297 Chinese Restaurants
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: International Schools Boom as More Seek Education in English
description: HONG KONG  A century ago, there were only a handful of international schools in the world, mostly set up by Western corporations so overseas employees would have a place to educate their children. (Shell has had one in Borneo since the 1920s, after it discovered oil there in the 1910s).

title: Confronted by Renewed Legal Problems, Chief of Santander Resigns
description: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Daily Report: Hoax on Twitter That Moved Markets Raises Worries
description: Could the global economy hinge on 140 characters?

title: Why Jarvis Jones Was Perfect Pick for Steelers
description: From a conceptual standpoint, Pittsburghs selection of the Georgia pass rusher Jarvis Jones might be the best pick in the 2013 N.F.L. draft. Just about every mock draft had Pittsburgh taking the Georgia pass rusher 17th over all (which is where he wound up). We have no idea if Jones will ultimately prove those mockers and Steelers General Manager Kevin Colbert right. Many believe he will, but only time will tell.

title: Another Departure at JPMorgan
description: Frank J. Bisignano, co-chief operating officer of JPMorgan Chase, is leaving the bank to become chief executive of the payment processing firm First Data Corporation, according to a statement on Sunday by the banks chief executive, Jamie Dimon. Matthew E. Zames, who shared the chief operating officer role with Mr. Bisignano, will take over all aspects of the job, effective immediately, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook.

title: Crossing the TMZ
description: No, not DMZ  TMZ. I dont know how much people pay attention to Technorati these days, or even how they compile their index, but this is still fun to see:

title: Monday Reading: Europes Hostels Go Upscale
The Italian Miracle
description: Italy is a mess. Yes, it has a prime minster, finally; but the chances of serious economic reform are minimal, the willingness to persist in ever-harsher austerity  which the Rehns of this world tell us is essential  is evaporating. Its all bad. But a funny thing is happening:

title: Irish Woman Loses Appeal for Assisted Death
description: DUBLIN  A terminally ill woman in the final stages of multiple sclerosis does not have the right to an assisted death, the Irish Supreme Court ruled Monday.

title: Financiers Charity Gala Goes the Way of Canaps
description: LONDON  Every spring, top financiers would mingle with royalty and guests like Madonna, Bill Clinton and Kevin Spacey for a gala to raise money for programs to improve literacy in India and fight AIDS in Africa.

title: Guinness Record Holder Dies Performing Stunt Over Teesta River
description: Year after year, stunt after stunt, Indians have had their names imprinted in the Guinness Book of World Records, that official chronicler of human achievement that is often the gatekeeper of the eclectic and the bizarre. One Indian man has the worlds longest mustache, while another was once lauded for the worlds longest fingernails. Yet another struggled to retain his records in the book by attempting all sorts of titles: from writing on a grain of rice to stacking the tallest single column of coins.

title: Noisy Courtship, Quiet Breakup
description: It was 13 months ago that the Jets welcomed Tim Tebow to the team, introducing him in their spacious field house at a news conference attended by more than 200 members of the news media that snarled traffic around the teams facility in Florham Park, N.J.

title: Scent Notes | Highland Breeze
description: Obsessed with W. B. Yeatss epic poem The Wanderings of Oisin, the perfumer David Seth Moltz traveled to Ireland and Scotland to collect inspiration for HYLNDS, his latest collection for the Brooklyn-based D. S. & Durga. What emerged from his travels are three unisex scents that each evoke the lands in the Celtic myths Yeats drew upon: one is Isle Ryder, an accord of jasmine, gorse and poplar bud that conjures Finlaggan, ruins of a castle in the middle of a lake on the peaty island of Islay.

title: Chrysler Reports a Profit Drop of 65%
description: DETROIT  Chrysler Group said Monday that its net income fell 65 percent in the first quarter, to $166 million, as the automaker spent heavily to prepare for new product introductions.

title: Alibaba Buys a Stake in Chinas Twitter
description: 5:32 p.m. | Updated

title: Derby Dartboard: 2013 Race Preview
description: The Timess horse racing experts, Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert, break down this years story lines and make their picks for the 2013 Kentucky Derby.

title: Video: A Conversation With the Traffic Screenwriter Stephen Gaghan
description: Life imitates art in a New York Times article that looks at the events that inspired Steven Soderberghs movie Traffic. The article focuses on a former Mexican police official who helped hunt down drug traffickers, much like the character Benicio Del Toro so memorably portrayed in the Oscar-winning movie.

title: A Wire-to-Wire Ride on the Americas Best Racing Bus
description: The excitement of a horse race is legendary  the starting gate bursts open, hooves thunder, silks flash, legs claw frantically forward, the crowd roars, a horses nose crosses the finish line. In less than two minutes, a mini-drama is enacted. The stands are full of passionate fans, some who almost won and some who did and are on top of the world. Horse racing is a sport with a long and rich history as well as a colorful present. This kind of energy is a primal experience that most people only read about in books and watch in movies and television.

title: The Protectionist Non-Surge
description: Update: The paper was by Eichengreen and Irwin, not ORourke  sorry, Doug.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: Eli Miller is closing in on 80 years old, and hes still delivering seltzer to customers in Brooklyn. Why? In his words: I dont want them to have to drink that dreck you buy in the supermarket.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Weekend Gun Report: April 26-28, 2013
description: Jennifer and I made a decision a few weeks ago to stop writing a Saturday gun report and instead do a weekend roundup. One thing weve since discovered is that there are so many shootings on the weekends that it is hard to keep track of them all. It also makes for very discouraging reading, as you can see.

title: Honda Recalls 44,000 Fit Sports Over Stability Control Issue
description: A switch in tire brand may be the cause of a recall of nearly 44,000 2012-13 Honda Fit Sport models. Tests conducted by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration uncovered a problem with the cars electronic stability control system. Honda said in a report filed with the safety agency that the software would be updated on the electronic stability control, which it called Vehicle Stability Assist.

title: When Chaos Is More Than a Theory
description: After a strange set of events, Monday became the day to pick through the rubble of the weekend.

title: Immigration Reform and the Lessons of 2012
description: My Sunday column sounded some skeptical notes about the immigration reform being considered in the Senate, raising the question of whether an America whose native-born working class is facing a slow-burning socieconomic crisis is really in an ideal position to assimilate low-skilled immigrants at an increasing clip. What I didnt say is that these intertwined issues working class dysfunction and the hard path to assimilation are part of why the Republican elites political theory of immigration reform looks so dubious.

title: Billions of Cellphones Polluting the World
description: THE HAGUE  Once considered a status symbol, cellphones have become ubiquitous.There are  now 6.8 billion mobile subscriptions worldwide, 800 million more than at the end of 2011.

title: Paid Sick Leave Has Some Business Owners Feeling Ill
description: When the advocates at Family Forward Oregon sought to muster support among businesses in Portland for a local paid sick leave ordinance, they found a sympathetic ear in Tony Fuentes. Mr. Fuentes and his wife operate Milagros Boutique, which sells cloth diapers and clothing for babies and children on Portlands northeast side.

title: The Economist Looks to Colleges for New Readers
description: The Economist magazine is headed to campuses around the country to encourage students, teachers, professors and others in the academic community to become readers.

title: Mad Men Recap: Was This the Worst Episode Yet?
description: Season 6, Episode 4

title: For Jozy Altidore, 30 Goals and One Brand New Fan
description: There are certain moments in life where we feel truly humbled. Whether youre a doctor, a teacher or a professional athlete, everyone has been in a situation where they are dealt a reality check and experience something seemingly bigger than life itself.

title: Why Doctors Are Sued
description: What kind of medical error accounts for most malpractice payments: Surgical mistakes? Overdoses? Obstetric errors?

title: Michele Davis to Join Morgan Stanley
description: Michele A. Davis, a prominent Washington insider, has been named to run the corporate communications department at Morgan Stanley.

title: Justices Decline to Take Case on Alabama Immigration Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday declined to consider a case concerning a tough 2011 Alabama immigration law that makes it a crime to harbor or transport immigrants not authorized to be in the United States or to induce them to enter or live in the state. The move left in place an appeals court ruling blocking the law.

title: Whats Important About Money to You?
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archivedon the Bucks blog.

title: Clean: Overcoming Addiction and Ending Americas Greatest Tragedy
description: The view that drug use is a moral choice is pervasive, pernicious, and wrong. So are the corresponding beliefs about the addicted  that theyre weak, selfish, and dissolute; if they werent, when their excessive drug taking and drinking began to harm them, theyd stop. The reality is far different. Using drugs or not isnt about willpower or character. Most problematic drug use is related to stress, trauma, genetic predisposition, mild or serious mental illness, use at an early age, or some combination of those. Even in their relentless destruction and self-destruction, the addicted arent bad people. Theyre gravely ill, afflicted with a chronic, progressive, and often terminal disease.

title: Addicts Father, Now Advocate
description: Addiction swallows lives whole, and not only with overdose, illness and concentric cycles of rehab and relapse. A less onerous but still tenacious kind of post-traumatic stress disorder may develop as well, with recovered addicts and their families compulsively reliving the past in private  or, like David Sheff and his son Nic, in public.

title: A Lifes Work, Interwoven With Horse Racing
description: Shecky Greene. My family used to have a hat pool for the Kentucky Derby. Someone writes the horses names on slips of paper and puts the slips in a hat. Then you pay $5 and pull a name. Thats your horse. If he wins, you get the money.

title: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Victorious at Richmond; Piquet Hits Below the Belt
description: Kevin Harvick found a hole in traffic ahead of him on a green-white-checker restart at the end of the 400-lap Nascar Sprint Cup event at Richmond International Raceway on Saturday night, rallying from seventh place to snatch the victory. Clint Bowyer finished second and Joey Logano third. Fourth place went to hard-luck Juan Pablo Montoya, who had appeared to be in the lead until a yellow flag came out with six laps to go; he was one position ahead of Harvick on the restart, but got tied up in slower traffic.

title: Dukkah: Nut and Spice Mixes for Seasoning and Snacking
description: I think dukkah could be the next big thing.

title: Stocks React to Social Media Mishaps
description: The Timess Amy Chozick discusses the fallout of a hacked Twitter message that dropped stock prices last week and is now raising questions in the markets.

title: Kodak Spinoffs Clear the Path for Emergence From Bankruptcy
description: Kodak said on Monday that it would spin off its document and personal imaging units to its British pension plan for $650 million in cash and noncash considerations, a move that paves the way for Kodaks exit from bankruptcy protection.

title: Made in Africa
description: From Ethiopia to Kenya, a flurry of local manufacturers and craftsmen have partnered with Western apparel brands to make stylish shoes produced and sourced entirely on the African continent. There are rubber-soled cotton canvas low-tops from Mombasa, suede tennis shoes from Addis Ababa and crepe-soled nubuck loafers that incorporate materials from Mauritius, Liberia and South Africa.

title: Is 100 Years a Life Sentence? Opinions Are Divided
description: WASHINGTON  If people who are too young to vote commit crimes short of murder, the Supreme Court said in 2010, they should not be sentenced to die in prison.

title: Second Thoughts About the S.E.C.s Whistle-Blower Program
description: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: The 64 Mathematicians Puzzle
description: Physics professor Marco Moriconi has contributed a number of terrific puzzles to Numberplay including Gas Stations, Ant on a Rubber Band, Student Groups, the Five-Pirate Puzzle and Spaghetti Loops. This week we feature a slightly-altered version of another one of his favorites.

title: Video: On the Street, Sketching in Pastels
description: The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion. The green of the trees is as fresh as the grass on a Swiss mountainside, forming a lacy canopy over all. Cherry blossoms are ready to bloom, and art students set up their easels in the parks. Women headed to a lecture on ecosystems at the American Museum of Natural History. On Earth Day, 100 young volunteers, all employees of Macys, spread mulch around the trees surrounding the museum and painted its fence. And what would spring be without balloons, their bright colors reflected in a red pleated shawl.

title: Apple and the Debt Market
description: Apple may need to make its i.o.u.s as desirable as iPhones.

title: As East Midtown Girds for Taller Buildings, Squat Relics Endure
description: Barbara Connolly has rented an apartment in the same slender town house for 42 years. Her neighbors include three small brownstones, two well-worn stoops, a Halal Indian restaurant wedged into a narrow storefront, and an income-tax preparation company a flight up from the street. And also the Chrysler Building.

title: Spicy Egyptian Dukkah With Chickpea Flour
description: Dukkah is very popular in Egypt, where it is made with chickpea flour, sesame seeds, sometimes dill seeds, and spices. I like to toast the chickpea flour.
