I use the mixture, which is adapted from a dukkah in The Arab Table, by May S. Bsisu, not only as a condiment for vegetables and bread, but also as a coating for fried fish or vegetables.

title: Chinese Tourist Boat Heads Toward Disputed Islands
description: A cruise ship carrying Chinese tourists has embarked on a trip to the Paracels, a group of islands in the South China Sea that are claimed by both China and Vietnam. Vietnamese news reports said the ship left the coast of mainland China on Sunday despite protests against any such trip by the Vietnamese government in early April.

title: As Jobs Lag, Fed Is Viewed as Unlikely to Do More
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is making modest progress in its push to reduce the unemployment rate. But that is not the jobs goal Congress actually established for the Fed. The central bank is supposed to be maximizing employment. And on that front, it is not making progress.

title: Curious Incident Dominates at Olivier Awards
description: The London stage adaptation of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time, based on the best-selling novel from 2003, has won seven Olivier Awards  Britains equivalent of the Tony Awards  tying the record set last year by the musical Matilda.

title: Jet Debris Near 9/11 Site Is Identified as Wing Part
description: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | Plane wreckage found last week behind a building in Lower Manhattan and apparently deposited there in the Sept. 11 attacks is part of a wing flap  not part of the landing gear  from a jumbo jet of the same model as those that crashed into the World Trade Center, the Police Departments chief spokesman said on Monday.

title: Triple Play: Week 4 Results
description: The Marlins Giancarlo Stanton found his power stroke just in time to affect two of our questions last week. He hit three homers over the weekend to become the answer to No. 1. And his two home runs on Sunday helped the Marlins avoid a sweep and score 13 runs in their series against the Cubs.

title: With the Words Im Gay, an N.B.A. Center Breaks a Barrier
description: In 12 seasons as an N.B.A. player, Jason Collins has never been an All-Star or a scoring leader or even a full-time starter, but on Monday he shattered one of the last great barriers in professional sports.

title: Cruz Breaks With Senate Tradition While Criticizing Colleagues
description: In his short time at the Capitol, Senator Ted Cruz, a freshman Republican from Texas, has shown little regard for long-standing rules of decorum. But on Friday, he publicly discussed the closed-door dealings of the Senate Republican Conference  and trashed his colleagues in the process.

title: Next Big Challenge for Health Law: Carrying It Out
description: WASHINGTON  This month, a political organization aligned with House Republicans sent an e-mail to reporters attacking President Obamas health care law.

title: Hazelnut Dukkah With Fennel Seeds and Mint or Thyme
description: Some versions of dukkah, like this one, are herbal as well as spicy.

title: Street Style: Neon
description: The best of readers photos from the week of April 22.

title: The Met and Israel Museum Buy Illuminated Jewish Manuscript Before Its Auctioned
description: A 15th-century illustrated volume of the Mishneh Torah that was to be the star of a Sothebys auction on Monday was withdrawn from the sale and bought jointly by the Israel Museum in Jerusalem and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Widely considered one of the finest illuminated Hebrew manuscripts ever created, it was from the collection of the New York philanthropists Judy and Michael Steinhardt, who are selling their world-class collection of Judaica at Sothebys on Monday.

title: Ralph Lauren Case Shows the Benefits of Cooperation
description: The Ralph Lauren Corporations settlement of an investigation into whether it made illegal payments and gifts to foreign officials shows once again just how much a companys cooperation can provide it with the benefit of a slap on the wrist by the government rather than the trumpeting of embarrassing details.

title: Emeli Sand Bests a Beatles Chart Record
description: The Beatles fended off all contenders for half a century, but the Scottish singer-songwriter Emeli Sand has toppled one of the bands longest-standing chart records. Ms. Sands debut album, Our Version of Events, has spent the last 63 weeks in the British top 10, surpassing the 62 consecutive weeks that the Beatles debut, Please Please Me, spent in the top 10 in 1963 and 1964.

title: Freedom for Californias Indians
description: On April 27, 1863, nearly five months after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, California abolished its system of forced apprenticeship for American Indians. Under the apprenticeship provisions of the states Act for the Government and Protection of Indians, several thousand California Indians, mostly children, had suffered kidnapping, sale and involuntary servitude for over a decade.

title: The Play Date Gun Debate
description: Returning from a play date, my 6-year-old son tumbled through the door and announced, Did you know so-and-sos dad has guns? The concept, in and of itself, wasnt surprising. Wed recently moved to a bucolic town in northern Michigan where many families were recreational hunters. But the fact that I didnt know any real details about the situation  whether the guns were locked away or who had access to them  suddenly made me nervous.

title: For Nets, No Overtime and No Surrender
description: The Nets did not give the impression they were a team playing its last game of the season on Monday. They prepared as if Game 6 in Chicago was inevitable. There was no fire-and-brimstone pregame speech by a veteran teammate to rouse emotions.

title: The Disappearing One-Handed Backhand
description: If you simply glance at the top tier of tennis, you might think the one-handed topspin backhand is alive and very well. Roger Federers is especially versatile. Richard Gasquets is downright electric. Grigor Dimitrovs helped him nearly upset Rafael Nadal in Monte Carlo recently.

title: Jason Collins Breaks a Barrier. But Will He Find Another N.B.A. Job?
description: Jason Collins, who played for the N.B.A.s Boston Celtics and Washington Wizards last season, on Monday became the first active male athlete in a major American team sport to publicly announce that he is gay.

title: After a College Decision, a Fear of Getting It Wrong
description: While everyone else was getting their acceptance letters, learning about their aid packages, and weighing their future college options, I spent the week doing something a little different: I visited Williams College, the school Im committed to attend for the next four years, to try to get a taste of what my future is going to look like.

title: Supreme Court Backs State Restrictions on Who Can Ask for Information
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that states were free to let only their own citizens make requests under their freedom of information laws. The court also dismissed a case concerning the right to a speedy trial for poor criminal defendants, after it had been briefed and argued. And the court declined to consider a case concerning part of a tough 2011 Alabama immigration law, leaving in place an appeals court ruling blocking the law.

title: Going Supersonic
description: Virgin Galactic's rocket-powered SpaceShipTwo breaks the speed of sound on April 29, 2013.

title: Big City Book Club: Building Rockefeller Center
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated Weve concluded the live portion of our online discussion. But you can still share your thoughts on Great Fortune, by Daniel Okrent, in the comments section below.

title: Image of the Day: April 29
Decoded: Soaps Find New Life Online
description: The television shows All My Children and One Life to Live begin their second life as Internet-only shows through the efforts of an ambitious production company.

title: Teenage Years in the Stroke Belt
description: The Southeastern United States has a rate of stroke higher than that of the rest of the country, but it is only partly explained by known risk factors like high blood pressure and obesity. Now researchers have found a risk factor independent of the others: living in the Southeast as a teenager.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts a Profit and Agrees to Raise Its Capital Reserves
description: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Alloy Digital, New York, agreed to acquire the Digital Broadcasting Group, a video distribution and content-production network also known as DBG. Financial terms were not disclosed. Chris Young, chief executive at DBG, becomes chief marketing officer at Alloy Digital. Joseph Gomes and Rick Kleczkowski, who founded DBG, are to also become senior executives at Alloy Digital.

title: A Brains GPS, Eating Like a Local (Monkey), Weakness in AIDSs Armor
description: Two Norwegian scientists on what a rat brain knows about location; new research into how some traveling primates take digestive cues from their hosts; demystifying talk of a cure for H.I.V./AIDS.

title: A New Home for Health Questions
description: Thank you for visiting Consults. Because so many readers are eager to submit questions to health experts and reporters, The Times has launched a new online platform that replaces this blog: Ask Well, a feature of the Well blog. While older posts will remain available here in Consults, new health questions should be submitted to Ask Well.

title: Dropping the Temperature to Heat Up the Crowd
description: NEWARK  There were so many moving parts onstage at the Prudential Center here on Sunday night: the dancers, sinuous and authoritative; the band, sturdy and loud; the large screens of various shapes and sizes that flashed images that changed with the mood; even the stage itself, which had a big rotating circle at the center.

title: Why Burke Could Work in the N.B.A.
description: Listed at 6 feet, 190 pounds, Trey Burke will not be confused with point guards like Syracuses Michael Carter-Williams, who is 6-6 and 185, or Oklahoma States Marcus Smart, who is 6-4 and 225.

title: A Sense of Where You Are
description: TRONDHEIM, Norway  In 1988, two determined psychology students sat in the office of an internationally renowned neuroscientist in Oslo and explained to him why they had to study with him.

title: Massacre in Nigeria Spurs Outcry Over Military Tactics
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  Days later, the survivors faces tensed at the memory of the grim evening: soldiers dousing thatched-roof homes with gasoline, setting them on fire and shooting residents when they tried to flee. As the village went up in smoke, one said, a soldier threw a child back into the flames.

title: Ask Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood About the Tonys and the Theater Season
description: 5:02 p.m. | Updated  ArtsBeat is no longer taking questions for this feature.

title: Lew Names Chief of Staff at Treasury
description: The Obama administrations second-term staff reshuffling continued on Monday, as Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew named Christian A. Weideman as his new chief of staff. Mark A. Patterson, who has served in the role managing the Treasury Departments day-to-day operations since President Obama took office in 2009, plans to depart at the end of May.

title: Charity Promotes a New York State of Mind
description: A charity devoted to helping the poor in New York City is playing up its roots in its first advertising campaign.

title: Sarah Silverman Comedy Special, We Are Miracles, Coming to HBO
description: At this point in her comedy career, there would seem to be few things that Sarah Silverman hasnt done. Among the remaining items would be starring in her own HBO comedy special, but you can now cross that off: the cable network said on Monday that it had signed Ms. Silverman to record a comedy performance called Sarah Silverman: We Are Miracles, which it plans to show in the fall.

title: The Exodus From JPMorgans Executive Suites
description: The departure of Frank J. Bisignano adds to an exodus of top executives from JPMorgan Chase in recent years.

title: Afghan Leader Confirms Cash Deliveries by C.I.A.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai acknowledged Monday that the Central Intelligence Agency has been dropping off bags of cash at his office for a decade, saying the money was used for various purposes and expressing gratitude to the United States for making the payments.

title: Doctor-Patient Deceit (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Overworked Trainees (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cured of AIDS? Not Yet
description: What to make of all the recent cured of AIDS headlines? An American in Berlin, a baby in Mississippi and 14 patients in France are all alive without treatment.

title: Both Sides Rest in Trial of a Philadelphia Abortion Doctor Charged With Murder
description: PHILADELPHIA  They are known as Baby Boy A, Baby C, Baby D and Baby E, all of whom prosecutors call murdered children and the defense calls aborted fetuses  the very difference in language encapsulating why anti-abortion advocates are so passionate about drawing attention to the trial of Dr. Kermit Gosnell, which wrapped up here on Monday with summations by both sides.

title: Grid Cells: Crystals of the Brain
description: The grid cells that Edvard I. Moser and May-Britt Moser found in the brains of rats generate such precise patterns that a review article the couple wrote was titled Crystals of the Brain.

title: Fill-In | Anarchy in the Met
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first six paragraphs of the article Anarchy in the Met by Jon Caramanica.

title: Video: A Rescued Beaver Returns to the Water
description: Heres a sweet little piece of animal news: a sickly beaver found three weeks ago along the East River was nursed back to health and released Sunday in the city by a animal-rescue group based on Long Island.

title: Look of the Moment | White House Correspondents Associations Dinner
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Rising Tide of Substance Abuse
description: Americas 78 million aging baby boomers are heading into retirement with more than their considerable wealth, health and education. They are also bringing into their golden years an epidemic of drug and alcohol abuse and mental illness that has yet to be recognized, according to a recent Institute of Medicine report.

title: How a Fiat-Chrysler Merger Could Work
description: It took about a generation before Italian immigrants to the United States adopted the ways of their new home and shook off those of the old country. Italys premier industrial enterprise may do it in a matter of years. A spat over Fiats plans to fully acquire Chrysler, Detroits No. 3 car maker, could hasten the process.

title: OConnor Regrets Bush v. Gore
description: Now she tells us. More than 12 years after the fact, retired Justice Sandra Day OConnor said it was probably a mistake for the Supreme Court to hear Bush v. Gore and anoint George W. Bush as president of the United States.

title: N.B.A. Player Cites Representative Kennedy in Decision to Come Out
description: BOSTON  One bright June day last year, Joseph P. Kennedy III marched in Bostons gay pride parade, waving energetically to the spirited crowd that had gathered along the route. At his side was Barney Frank, the gay congressman from the Fourth District of Massachusetts, whom Mr. Kennedy was campaigning to replace after he had announced his retirement.

title: Credit Eased for Stay-at-Home Spouses and Partners
description: Stay-at-home spouses and partners may find it easier to get credit cards under a regulation revised by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: Inflation Nation Not
description: Hey, does anyone remember the great inflation panic of 2011? All the usual suspects were issuing dire warnings about soaring inflation, and ridiculing the Fed for focusing on core inflation rather than headline changes. So, hows it going?

title: Wired for Crime; Competition in Science
description: BOOKS

title: TimesTalks | New Digital Age: Preview
description: Googles Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen speak with The Timess David Carr about their book, which examines the impact of technology on society in the future.

title: Electric Cars Rally on Connecticuts Back Roads
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  What a day, sparks all over the place, said Leo Cirino, president of the Westport Electric Car Club, at the clubs EV Road Rally here, where on Saturday some 33 electric and plug-in hybrid cars took part in an approximately 40-mile drive.

title: The New Digital Age: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces Googles Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen.

title: I Thought I Was Bulletproof': William Friedkin Looks Back on the 70s
description: No one had a decade of moviemaking quite like William Friedkin did in the 1970s. Starting with his 1970 film adaptation of Mart Crowleys play The Boys in the Band, Mr. Friedkin, the Chicago-born and bred director, went on to make the 1971 crime drama The French Connection, which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned Mr. Friedkin the Oscar for best director; and the smash horror hit The Exorcist, which brought in nearly $200 million in its original 1973 release, and turned a generation of moviegoers off pea soup. But Mr. Friedkin finished out the decade with misfires and cinematic oddities, like Sorcerer, his 1977 remake of Clouzots Wages of Fear; his comic 1978 crime caper The Brinks Job; and the thriller Cruising, released in 1980, which starred Al Pacino as an undercover police officer investigating murders in Manhattans gay S&M clubs.

title: The New Digital Age: Five Billion
description: Part 2: Schmidt and Cohen explain their claim that five billion people will be joining the two billion currently online over the next five years.

title: The New Digital Age: Permanent Change
description: Part 3: Schmidt and Cohen discuss fiber optic technology, and talk about the permanent societal changes that come with increased connectivity.

title: First Active N.B.A. Player Says Hes Gay
description: The Timess William C. Rhoden discusses the coming out of Jason Collins and how the N.B.A. players decision could ripple through the world of sports.

title: The New Digital Age: Closed Societies
description: Part 4: Schmidt and Cohen reflect on recent advances in artificial intelligence, and explain how technology is transforming life in the developing world and in closed societies.

title: The New Digital Age: Not Being Evil
description: Part 5: Schmidt and Cohen talk about how Googles Dont be evil mantra has impacted the work they do.

title: The Truth About Brushing
description: Q. Why dont we use hot water to brush our teeth?

title: The New Digital Age: Human Judgment
description: Part 6: Schmidt and Cohen discuss online privacy and security and explain what they think individuals should do to protect themselves.

title: The New Digital Age: Dont Be Stupid
description: Part 7: Schmidt and Cohen reflect on the dangerous consequences of greater interconnectivity, and talk about Chinas provocative technological policies.

title: The New Digital Age: Terrorists
description: Part 8: Schmidt and Cohen discuss the ways that technology might make societies more or less susceptible to terrorism.

title: The New Digital Age: Easy Activism
description: Part 9: Schmidt and Cohen explore the impact of technology on political freedom around the world.

title: The New Digital Age: Mainstream Media
description: Part 10: Schmidt and Cohen talk about the role of established media in an increasingly connected and empowered world.

title: The New Digital Age: Power Laws
description: Part 11: Schmidt and Cohen discuss the core scarcity of attention on the web and the challenges content creators face in finding an audience.

title: The New Digital Age: Vulnerable People
description: Part 12: Schmidt and Cohen explain what Googles responsibility is to vulnerable people using their technology in repressed societies.

title: The New Digital Age: Your Identity
description: Part 13: Schmidt and Cohen reflect on the future of personal identity and the problems that may come with increasingly visible aggregated identities.

title: Charlotte Mayor Is Chosen as Transportation Chief
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced on Monday that he would nominate Anthony R. Foxx, a Democrat and the mayor of Charlotte, N.C., to be the next transportation secretary, saying Mr. Foxxs local government experience would help him manage the nations roads, bridges and airports.

title: Walkabout  4/29: FAA Suspends Furloughs Despite Typos; Dreamliners Fly in Ethiopia
description: Furloughs Forestalled A typo kept President Barack Obama from signing legislation designed to end budget-related air traffic controller furloughs blamed for widespread flight delays. (CNN)

title: Amazons Boom in Cloud Partners
description: You can tell when a technology is really taking hold. In addition to picking up customers, it generates other businesses that require their own care and feeding. And some of those businesses can illustrate how much more business is out there.

title: New Doubts About Ginkgo Biloba
description: Millions of Americans take ginkgo biloba supplements to boost memory and prevent dementia. Studies have never found any solid evidence that ginkgo does any such thing, but it did not seem to be doing much harm.

title: In France, White Trumps Green
description: Hunting for white asparagus in France, where the vegetable is a revered sign of spring.

title: Seeking the Ardent Life, Finding It and Sharing It
description: Edna OBriens fourth novel, August Is a Wicked Month (1965), displayed one of the best author photographs of the 20th century. Its reprinted on the cover of Country Girl, Ms. OBriens new memoir.

title: Grim Economics Shape Frances Military Spending
description: PARIS  France will effectively freeze its military spending for the next several years, cutting nearly 10 percent of defense jobs while using more money for high-tech equipment, in a bid to maintain its ability to conduct overseas operations like the one in Mali, the government said Monday.

title: Worthy of Versailles
description: MAGESCQ, France  I have come to regard it as the asparagus paradox.

title: The New Digital Age: Give Kids Phones
description: Part 14: Schmidt and Cohen explore technologys potential future impact on education and medicine.

title: After Decades, Gillette and BBDO Ad Agency Part Ways
description: One of the longest lasting relationships on Madison Avenue, between the Gillette mens grooming brand and the BBDO advertising agency, is coming to an end.

title: When Killing Is No Longer for the Good
description: Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile.

title: Is Talk of a Cure for AIDS Premature?
description: Michael Mason and Donald G. McNeil, Jr. talk about new developments in the treatment of the virus.

title: Two Clear Favorites and One Broken Jaw
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins and the Chicago Blackhawks were the class of the N.H.L. during the regular season, the runaway champions in the Eastern and Western Conferences. So there is no way they will meet in the Stanley Cup finals in June. The last time the top team in each conference advanced to the finals was 2001; before that, it was 1991. In hockey, poetic justice has nothing to do with the playoffs.

title: Europe Bans Pesticides Thought Harmful to Bees
description: PARIS  The European Commission will enact a two-year ban on a class of pesticides thought to be harming global bee populations, the European Unions health commissioner said Monday.

title: Euro Zone Releases Next Set of Loans for Greece
description: ATHENS  Euro zone officials on Monday approved the release of 2.8 billion euros, or $3.7 billion, in loans to Greece, the countrys Finance Ministry said, paving the way for the approval of an additional 6-billion-euro installment at a meeting of the currency unions finance ministers in mid-May.

title: Ants Become Job-Hoppers as They Age
description: Ants change careers as they age, transitioning from caretakers to cleaners and then foragers, according to a new study that tracked more than 1,000 ants for 41 days.

title: How Much Exercise to Work Off This Sandwich?
description: If calorie counts wont deter people from overeating, maybe the threat of exercise will.

title: Inside N.B.A. and Out, Words of Support (Mostly) for Collinss Revelation
description: The public response Monday to Jason Collinss announcement that he was gay was overwhelmingly supportive, at least among other professional athletes.

title: Alabamas Loss, Alabamas Gain
description: Alabamas attempt to enact its own foreign policy  a sweeping immigration law that criminalizes the undocumented and people who help them  has been knocked around in the federal courts, and has just been buffeted again. The Supreme Court on Monday declined to review a lower courts decision blocking the part of the law that forbids transporting or harboring anybody who is in the country illegally.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Asian Festival

title: Russian Bank Sells Shares in $3.3 Billion Offering
description: MOSCOW  VTB, Russias second-largest bank, announced on Monday that it had found buyers for all the shares it intended to place in a $3.3 billion secondary stock offering.

title: Outside the Comfort Zone and Into Sketch Comedy
description: Amy Schumer, a breath of foul-mouthed fresh air as a stand-up comic, seems noticeably less revolutionary in her new series on Comedy Central, Inside Amy Schumer, which begins on Tuesday night. Its primarily a sketch show, and what you get is the same sort of sketch-comedy roulette Saturday Night Live has been serving up for years: The good bits are hilarious; the others often kind of just lie there.

title: Side by Side by Audience
description: The choreographer Anna Sperber is all about clean edges. She sets her new evening-length duet, The Superseded Third, seen Friday at the Chocolate Factory, on a long wooden platform. Shiny and gray, the horizontal structure is bracketed by two walls.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, the Czech Republic, Syria and Gaza City.

title: No Real AIDS Cure, but a Step Forward
description: The Timess Donald G. McNeil Jr. explains the unusual cases in which H.I.V. has seemingly been killed with drugs, and what can be learned from them.

title: Love, but Thats Only Part of His Story
description: When Paul Williams and Charles Fox were invited in the late 1970s to write the theme song for The Love Boat, Mr. Williams recalled during his opening night at the Caf Carlyle last Tuesday, they took it to the singer Jack Jones expecting the television series to last for four episodes at most. Little did they know that it would continue for a decade and that the tune The Love Boat would become a staple  and running joke  of Mr. Joness shows.

title: Where Foxes Are Wise and Humans Are Troubled
description: A majority of characters in Janaceks enchanting Cunning Little Vixen are animals. In presenting this great Czech opera, first performed in Brno in 1924, most companies seize on the chance to create fanciful animal costumes and beguiling sets that evoke leafy forests.

title: Jack Dorsey Talks Square and Wearable Devices
description: Many technology enthusiasts have had their eye on Glass, Googles monocle that looks like something out of Star Trek. But the Internet-connected eyewear doesnt really pique the interest of Jack Dorsey, chief executive of the mobile payment system Square and a co-founder of Twitter.

title: Spending Cuts Threaten to Delay Research, Obama Tells Scientists
description: At a moment when scientists are on the brink of making breakthroughs that could significantly improve human lives, broad spending reductions that went into effect in March threaten to stall their progress for up to two years, President Obama told a gathering of scientists on Monday.

title: A Reporter Eats and Drinks the News
description: Charlie Gasparino, a senior correspondent with the Fox Business Network and Fox News, is known (some might say notorious) for his dogged, determined pursuit of scoops on the titans of Wall Street. He is known, too, for his unusual habit of going on the air and chatting about what he had to eat (and drink) the night before. Mr. Gasparino, 51, met for a late lunch at San Pietro, one of his Midtown haunts.

title: A Jazz Pianist Who Specializes in Disorientation
description: There were many possible points of entry to Vijay Iyers immersive three-part concert at Zankel Hall on Saturday night, but the most illuminating was also the most deceptively simple. Maybe Ill play a standard, Mr. Iyer said casually, introducing a solo piano mini-set near the programs midpoint. Then he began a murky, unsettled, slow-rumbling prelude, only gradually recognizable as the songbook ballad Body and Soul.

title: New Generation Greets the Complexities of the Past
description: Charles Ivess Symphony No. 4, performed recently by the New York Philharmonic, features music of such metrical complexity that two conductors are often used to keep order. Similarly, Elliott Carter suggested that two conductors should marshal the disparate elements of the coda of his Double Concerto (1961), which received an excellent performance on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall by the American Soundscapes ensemble.

title: A Blank Canvas to Create Smart Limbs
Level Global to Pay $21.5 Million to Settle S.E.C. Case
description: Level Global Investors, one of the largest hedge funds ensnared by the governments insider-trading crackdown, has agreed to pay more than $21.5 million in fines and penalties to resolve its role in the investigation.

title: Most Banks Could Still Profit Under Tough New Overhaul Proposal
description: Most banks would still make good money under a tough new piece of financial overhaul legislation introduced in the Senate last week.

title: Motown: The Musical Surges at Box Office Ahead of Tony Nominations
description: As Broadway producers and performers gird themselves for the 2013 Tony Award nominations on Tuesday morning, several shows are already fortified by strong ticket sales  so much so that Tony nominations may not make much of a difference.

title: Occidental Petroleum Chief to Stay Until End of 2014
description: HOUSTON  Bowing to investor pressure, Occidental Petroleum on Monday announced that its chief executive, Stephen I. Chazen, would continue to serve in his position, but only through the end of 2014 to help find a successor.

title: Obama Hails 150th Year of Academy of Sciences
description: President Obama helped the National Academy of Sciences celebrate its 150th year of service to the country by giving a speech at the groups annual meeting today. There were some pretty nice laugh lines, including:

title: Debating Age Limits on Tobacco
description: The New York City Council has taken up a proposal to raise the minimum age for tobacco purchases to 21 from 18, the strictest such limits in any major American city.

title: $15 Million Gift and New Name for Community College
description: For prestigious private colleges, where donations that top $100 million are increasingly common, $15 million might buy naming rights to a new building or a laboratory. But for a community college, a donation of that size is both rare and transformative, and so New Yorks newest community college is getting a new name: the Stella and Charles Guttman Community College.

title: As Fliers Chase Low Fares, Fees for the Extras Add Up
description: YOU couldnt hear the American Airlines gate agent mumbling into his tinny microphone about yet another delay at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport because he was being drowned out by the voice of the woman who makes those annoying security announcements.

title: Table Talk | One Leicester Street
description: Unlike conventional hoteliers and restaurateurs, the Singapore-based Peng Loh, owner of Unlisted Collection  a growing family of hip, design-focused boutique hotels and restaurants in Singapore, London and Shanghai  opens properties based on one simple principle: opportunity. Rather than actively pursue new projects from the ground up, Loh waits for the right situation to present itself. And his newest hotel, One Leicester Street in Londons Chinatown, which opens May 1, is no exception.

title: Your Brain on Computers: Readers Respond
description: My Disruptions column this weekend looked at a nascent technology through which you can control computers, smartphones and robotic arms with your mind.

title: Privately Financed Spaceship Roars Closer to Space
description: For the more than 500 space tourists who have signed up for a trip on Richard Bransons Virgin Galactic, Monday was a milestone: the day the spaceship that will be carrying them aloft made its first powered flight and broke the sound barrier for its first time.

title: Are Doctors Nicer to Thinner Patients?
description: Are doctors nicer to patients who arent fat?

title: New Albums From Iggy and the Stooges, Darcy James Argue and Kenny Chesney
description: IGGY AND THE STOOGES

title: 100 Years Ago, Mayor Had a Ready Trigger Finger
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs campaign for stricter gun regulation might have been, well, gun shy about recruiting one of his predecessors, John Purroy Mitchel.

title: As Election in Iran Nears, Ahmadinejads Critics Are Piling On
description: TEHRAN  Just six weeks before Irans presidential election, politicians and clerics have declared open season on President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his government, in one instance calling him a coward and likening him to a drunk driver.

title: No Comment Necessary: Spying on Muslims
description: Via The Daily Beast

title: Tebow to Canada? Not So Fast
description: Tim Tebow, after being released by the Jets on Monday, is without a job, and his prospects of latching on with another N.F.L. team are uncertain. The Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League own Tebows negotiating rights. So, off to Canada he goes, right?

title: Its Monkey See, Do and Dance
description: Forty five minutes of monkey impersonations? Dressed only in undershirts and shorts, seven male dancers of the Cambodian Amrita Performing Arts institution held the audiences attention on Sunday evening at the Guggenheim Museum with unfailing skill and charm. The dancers are all specialists in the role of the monkey from the Cambodian classical masked dance known as Lakhaon Kaol; but here only one of them ever donned a mask, and then only briefly. The production, choreographed by Emmanule Phuon, was called Khmeropdies III: Source/Primate; Im sorry I missed the chance to see parts I and II.

title: Philosophy That Stirs the Waters
description: BOSTON  On a recent sunny afternoon, Daniel Dennett showed up at the community boathouse on the Charles River ready for philosophical and nautical action.

title: Diller Gives Bleak Assessment of Newsweek
description: Barry Diller, whose IAC/InterActiveCorp decided last year to turn Newsweek into a digital-only publication, on Monday gave a stark assessment of its chances to succeed.

title: Alexander Graham Bells Voice, Animals in Space and More
description: Hear my voice  Alexander Graham Bell, the father of the telephone said on April 15, 1885, enunciating carefully, his voice recorded on a wax-and-cardboard disc at an experimental sound laboratory he ran in Washington. At the time, Bell was trying feverishly to develop audio technology that would best his archrival, Thomas Edison, who had recorded Mary Had a Little Lamb on embossed foil in 1877, according to the Smithsonian Institution, which owns a collection of Bells artifacts.

title: Sacramento Kings Are Likely to Stay Put
description: The N.B.A.s relocation committee on Monday unanimously recommended that the leagues owners reject a request to move the Sacramento Kings to Seattle, a decision that will probably keep the team in California and settle a contentious bidding war.

title: Whose Art Is It Anyway?
description: The United States Second Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last week on a copyright dispute that pitted the photographer Patrick Cariou against the artist Richard Prince. The court decided in favor of Prince, reversing a 2011 federal ruling in which he was found to have used Carious photographs illegally in a series called Canal Zones. The case might have broad implications for photographers and artists. As a photo editor, I can sympathize both with a photographers desire to protect his original work and with the concerns about limiting artistic freedom through the fair-use exception.

title: A Too-Close View of Airport Security in Action
description: IM a fashion designer and co-founder of Ankasa, a home furnishings company. Im traveling all the time and really get a lot of inspiration on my trips to Asia. Im there about every 45 days, and then travel domestically quite a bit, too. My wife thinks Im on a plane all the time. I dont think shes wrong.

title: Fewer, Bigger Travel Sites
description: The online travel search business is consolidating, as two of the biggest online travel agencies, Priceline.com and Expedia.com, buy smaller search engines.

title: Video: TimesTalks With Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen
description: Bits live streamed a conversation with Eric A. Schmidt, executive chairman of Google, and Jared Cohen, director of Google Ideas, about how the Internet is reshaping people, places and things. Mr. Schmidt and Mr. Cohen are the authors of a new book, The New Digital Age. Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by David Carr.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hacking for Murder, and Talent Shortage Doubts
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: 50 Best Restaurants Awards Announced; Eleven Madison Park Is No. 5
description: Noma, a tiny rough-hewn restaurant in Copenhagen, has spent three years at the top of the Worlds 50 Best Restaurants list, generated annually by the British trade publication Restaurant Magazine.

title: The Warnings Behind the Numbers
description: On its face, Fridays announcement that the nations gross domestic product expanded at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter was good news, following as it did an only marginally positive result for the previous three-month period.

title: A Ban on Some Italian Cured Meat Is Ending
description: The United States Department of Agriculture will relax a decades-long ban on the importation of many cured-pork products from some regions of Italy starting May 28, greatly increasing the number and variety of salumi in markets and restaurants here.

title: After Boston Bombing, American Ties With Russia Improve
description: MOSCOW  After President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke by telephone on Monday, a top Russian official said cooperation between the leaders intelligence services had noticeably intensified in the past few days, though he said Russia had not been able to provide valuable intelligence about the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing, Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

title: Really? The Claim: Evening Primrose Oil Soothes Eczema
description: THE FACTS:

title: Hoopla of TV, Wooing Ads to Digital Media
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS by giant media companies about new series and other programming ventures. Appearances by pop-culture personalities like the rappers Lupe Fiasco and MC Hammer. Performances by singers like the Lumineers, dancers and circus acts. Free breakfasts, lunches, hors doeuvres and drinks. Goody bags filled with giveaway items that include smartphone covers, computer monitor cleaning cloths and cookies.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,188 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Dreaming of Julia, a Top Filly, to Race in Kentucky Oaks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The best 3-year-old in North America  based on any measure of past performance  will not enter the starting gate for the 139th Kentucky Derby on Saturday at Churchill Downs.

title: Rangers Focus on Special Teams and Getting Healthy
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers practiced Monday for the first time since learning that the Capitals will be their first-round opponents in a series that starts Thursday in Washington.

title: Fire on the Roof
description: A roof deck fire in Alphabet City was quickly contained Sunday. But firefighters fear that there will be more as New Yorkers look forward to warm weather, barbecues and holiday weekends.

title: Bad Reviews for Patron at Restaurant in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Andrea Bentez simply did what many rich, connected Mexicans have always done: she used her influence to step on the lower born. Witnesses said that when she was not given the table she wanted on Friday at Maximo Bistrot, a popular Mexico City restaurant, she called in inspectors who worked for her father at the countrys main consumer protection agency to shut it down.

title: Blaming Europes Central Bank
description: FRANKFURT  There are certainly plenty of people who could be blamed for the economic crisis in Cyprus that caused worldwide anxiety last month. The potential culprits include Cypriot bankers who bet too heavily on Greece and a communist-led government that dithered as the losses piled up.

title: How Sports Illustrated Broke the Jason Collins Story
description: The anticipation that a male in a major team sport would announce he was gay had been building for weeks, along with the frenzy among sportswriters trying to break the story.

title: Steering Frances Economy, and Attacked From All Sides
description: PARIS  Pierre Moscovici protects his iPhone with a cover featuring a portrait of Lon Blum, a hero of Frances Socialist Party and three times prime minister, the last after emerging from Buchenwald and Dachau. Mr. Moscovici, Frances minister for finance and the economy, needs a good dose of Mr. Blums courage these days, under attack not just from the right but from within his own party.

title: Housing Authority Is Sued Over Slow Pace of Repairs
description: To fix a water leak last month, workers cut out a piece of wall behind the stove in Pian Tams apartment at the Alfred E. Smith houses in Lower Manhattan. Then they covered the opening with plastic and told her that they would come back later to plaster the wall.

title: Even VW Now Feels the Weight of Europes Economic Troubles
description: The troubled European car market is now dragging down even Volkswagen, the regions leading automaker, as vehicle sales on the Continent have declined to their lowest levels in decades.

title: Cervellis Positivity Faces Yet Another Test
description: The way Francisco Cervelli was calculating it Monday afternoon, he had five weeks and five days until he could return from a broken finger. But whos counting?

title: Janos Starker, Master of the Cello, Dies at 88
description: Janos Starker, one of the 20th centurys most renowned cellists, whose restrained onstage elegance was amply matched by the cyclone of Scotch, cigarettes and opinion that animated his offstage life, died on Sunday at a hospice in Bloomington, Ind. He was 88.

title: Day of Firsts for a Spaceship
description: For the more than 500 space tourists who have signed up for a trip on Richard Bransons Virgin Galactic, Monday was a milestone: the spaceship that will be carrying them aloft made its first powered flight and broke the sound barrier for its first time. In a telephone interview after the test flight over Mojave, Calif., Mr. Branson said the craft would go to space at the end of this year or in the first quarter of next year. He and his children are to be the first passengers. Over the past two and a half years, SpaceShipTwo has made a series of unpowered tests, gliding to a landing. On Monday, a carrier aircraft lofted SpaceShipTwo to 47,000 feet before letting it go. The engine fired for 16 seconds, accelerating SpaceShipTwo to Mach 1.2  1.2 times the speed of sound  and pushing it to an altitude of 55,000 feet, about 10.5 miles. More test flights will follow before the start of commercial operations.

title: Roof-Deck Blaze on a Warm Day Presages Summer Barbecue Fires
description: One minute, sunshine and spring blossoms were the only things descending from the sky, the next moment it was ashes, soot and fire-hose water cascading from the first roof-deck fire of the year in Lower Manhattan on Sunday afternoon.

title: Preschool Financing Has Dropped, Study Finds
description: State financing for preschool fell by more than $548 million, or close to 10 percent, in the 2011-12 school year, the largest annual drop in a decade, according to a report released Monday.

title: 7 Killed in Plane Crash in  Afghanistan
description: Seven people were killed on Monday when a civilian cargo plane crashed shortly after taking off from Bagram Air Base, northeast of Kabul, according to an international military spokesman. The police chief of the surrounding area, Ezmarai Nasiri, said the plane crashed soon after it took off and its tail caught on fire. There was no information late on Monday about whether the plane was carrying cargo or its intended destination. It belonged to National Air Cargo, a military contractor based in Orchard Park, N.Y., outside Buffalo. Military officials said that the cause of the crash was being investigated, but that there had been no enemy activity in the area at the time.

title: Stiff Neck and Spasms Send Wright to Bench
description: MIAMI  David Wright was held out of Mondays game against the Marlins with what he described as spasms and stiffness in his neck. Wright said he was optimistic that he would return Tuesday, but he used the word hopefully at least a half-dozen times in a brief interview with reporters before the game.

title: Lakers Move From What Happened to What Now
description: LOS ANGELES  The Lakers off-season began Monday after a season so grisly there is no certainty that any player in uniform for Sundays finale will be back.

title: Flow of Tainted Water Is Latest Crisis at Japan Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO  Two years after a triple meltdown that grew into the worlds second worst nuclear disaster, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant is faced with a new crisis: a flood of highly radioactive wastewater that workers are struggling to contain.

title: Publisher Is Backing Off a Book About Cuomo in Favor of One Written by Him
description: ALBANY  HarperCollins is backing away from plans to publish a biography of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo by one of New Yorks best-known political journalists, and instead has agreed to publish a memoir by the governor.

title: Debt and Growth: A Response to Reinhart and Rogoff
description: AMHERST, Mass.

title: A City That Turns Garbage Into Energy Copes With a Shortage
description: OSLO  This is a city that imports garbage. Some comes from England, some from Ireland. Some is from neighboring Sweden. It even has designs on the American market.

title: Studying the Dark Art of Leaking Deal Talks
description: Psst.

title: The Power of I Dont Know
description: My friend Alicia likes to mock me by mimicking the tone of online comments on my writing, affecting the snarky hauteur that is the Internets default: Kreider makes the audacious claim that his cat is more attractive than all other living cats, shell say. According to Kreider, pie is a perfectly acceptable breakfast, or Kreider would have it that pants are purely optional. Shes making mild fun of my sporadic blips of Internet celebrity, but I think shes more heavily amused to hear commenters citing her feckless goofball friend as though I were some eminent authority, solemnly parsing my passing opinions as though they were official policy statements. Alicias an artist, too, and understands how audiences tend to ascribe magisterial intention and control to artists, when more often were just making it up as we go, doing the best we can by deadline.

title: Bangladesh Needs Strong Unions, Not Outside Pressure
description: BANGLADESH, my country, is again in tears. Last week in Savar, a suburb of Dhaka, the capital, a poorly constructed building that housed garment factories and other businesses collapsed. More than 300 have been confirmed dead, and the final death toll could well exceed 700.

title: Clothed in Misery
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Italys New Premier Puts Stimulus First
description: ROME  Italys new prime minister, Enrico Letta, said Monday that he would move quickly to stimulate growth and jobs, while easing some of the unpopular austerity measures enacted to strengthen Italys public finances and ease its cumbersome debt.

title: Basketballs Gay Paragon
description: I heard a lot of talk Monday about how perfect Jason Collins, the basketball player who just came out, is. Perfect as in straight from central casting. (Or maybe I should say gay from central casting.)

title: Investigators Obtain DNA From Widow of Bombing Suspect
description: Federal authorities are closely scrutinizing the activities of the wife of the dead Boston Marathon bombing suspect in the days before and after the attacks.

title: Technology Start-Ups Take Root in Berlin
description: BERLIN  Near the Rosenthaler Platz subway station here, signs of the citys high-tech future blend seamlessly with its communist past.

title: Jim Thorpes Place in America
description: A bittersweet restlessness has long been tied to the legend of Jim Thorpe, the Olympic champion and American Indian whose gold medal feats mesmerized the nation a century ago.

title: A States Duty to Indigent Defendants
description: On Monday, the Supreme Court should have said that every state has the duty to pay for counsel for indigent criminal defendants and ensure them a speedy trial. The court should also have ordered an appeals court in Louisiana to reconsider its decision to uphold a conviction for murder and armed robbery. The court did neither. Its five conservative justices simply refused to decide the case, leaving the conviction and a life sentence in place.

title: The Mayor Rethinks Recycling
description: On recycling in New York City, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has come a long way. After taking office 11 years ago, Mr. Bloomberg eliminated a major chunk of the citys recycling program to save money. Many New Yorkers were outraged. He was, they said, littering the earth as well as missing a chance to convert waste to energy.

title: Ill-Considered Advice on Syria
description: To hear Senator John McCain of Arizona and Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina tell it, the way forward on Syria is clear. The United States should be doing more  directly arming the rebels seeking overthrow President Bashar al-Assad, establishing a no-fly zone. This is not a new line for these two legislators and others in Congress who share their views. But it has gathered force since the Obama administration disclosed last week that it believes Mr. Assads forces have used sarin gas against Syrians.

title: 5 Are Convicted in Kosovo Organ Trafficking
description: PARIS  Five people were convicted Monday in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, in connection with an elaborate organ-trafficking network that lured poor people to the country to sell their kidneys and other organs to wealthy transplant recipients from Israel, the United States, Canada and Germany. Organs sold for as much as $130,000 each.

title: Immigration Splits Senator From Mentor
description: WASHINGTON  Jim DeMint helped makeMarco Rubio a Senate star  and he could be forgiven for regretting it.

title: Engaged or Detached?
description: Lets say you are a young person beginning to write about politics and policy. You probably have some idea of what you believe, but have you thought about how you believe it? That is to say, have you thought about where you will sit on the continuum that stretches from writers who are engaged to those who are detached?

title: Lost Every Day
description: Meet a Colorado woman with a rare neurological disorder who has no sense of direction, even in her own home.

title: Tim Taylor, Yale and 94 Olympic Coach, Dies at 71
description: Tim Taylor, who was the winningest coach in the history of Yale University hockey and coached the 1994 United States Olympic team and four national teams in the world championships, died on Saturday in Branford, Conn. He was 71.

title: Lost Every Day
description: Many people, myself included, have a gnawing primeval fear of becoming hopelessly lost. This Op-Doc video examines that fear in a most extreme form. My subject is Sharon Roseman of Denver, who gets lost every day  in the streets shes lived in for 20 years, even in her own house. When she wakes, her walls seem to have moved overnight. Her world can be transformed in the blink of an eye.

title: Another Executive Leaves JPMorgan, Raising Questions as Vote Nears
description: 10:35 a.m. | Updated

title: Once Again Standing In for the Mayor: Someone Who Wants His Job
description: As mayoral news conferences go, this one had all the usual Bloomberg trappings: a powerful commissioner, an Ivy League academic, an innovative pilot program and money from a private charity.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 29, 2013

title: Fines for Agents Who Show Illegal Dwellings
description: The frenzied process of finding an apartment in New York City just got even more fraught  not for prospective tenants, however, but for real estate agents.

Limiting Antibiotics in Animals

description: To the Editor:

Natural Gas, Not Diesel
description: To the Editor:
