description: To the Editor:

title: Player and League Stand at a Frontier
description: Like it or not, fair or not, the N.B.A. is under the microscope now, or once again, this time as a test case in how a major sports league responds to an active player declaring he is gay.

title: Park Deals Chip Away at Citys Gems
description: Sheik Mansour bin Zayed al-Nahyan is a smart-looking fellow, whether clad in Burberry blue or desert white.

title: Whats Odd About the Ends
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This kind of theme always reminds me of the I Love Lucy scene where Ricky shows us just how difficult it is for people learning English as a second language to adapt to all of its eccentricities. Lucy is trying to improve her pronunciation so that she can teach their soon-to-arrive baby good English, and in the middle of trying some of her speaking exercises, Ricky gets his tongue severely twisted:

title: In Its Defense, Police Dept. Cites Laziness of Its Officers
description: The picture painted in court of the New York Police Departments officers was not pretty.

title: Struggling to Contain Radioactive Wastewater
description: Operators of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant are struggling to find places to store radioactive water.

title: Talks to Settle Wages Keep Last Lights on at Joint Korean Complex
description: SEOUL, South Korea  All the remaining South Korean factory managers in an industrial park in North Korea returned home early Tuesday, as political tensions drove the two Koreas to sever their last economic ties.

title: A Hike With Sally Jewell
description: The Timess John M. Broder takes a challenging hike with the new interior secretary, Sally Jewell, as she tackles her government role.

title: New Interior Chief Savors a Steep Learning Curve
description: SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK, Va.  Sally Jewell bounded up a granite boulder near the peak of Old Rag Mountain and turned back to her hiking companion, who was staring up at the smooth rock that offered no obvious hand- or footholds.

title: The Detainees Dilemma
description: Fadhel Hussein Saleh Hentif is one of about 100 detainees on a hunger strike in the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. He was captured in 2001 by Pakistanis after crossing the border from Afghanistan, and, by 2002, he was in the American naval detention facility. He was 20 years old. He has been there since.

title: Antique Film of Black Ballplayers Surfaces, and Their Diamond Is a Plantation
description: ATLANTA  Buried in storage at a sprawling antebellum Georgia plantation is a film clip that has baseball enthusiasts buzzing.

title: Lacking His Best Pitch, Pettitte Is No Match for A.L.s Worst Team
description: While the Yankees have been receiving plaudits and tributes for their surprisingly successful start to the season, the Houston Astros have been fulfilling all expectations in their inaugural season in the American League by starting out as the worst team in the league.

title: Colleges Adapt Online Courses to Ease Burden
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Dazzled by the potential of free online college classes, educators are now turning to the gritty task of harnessing online materials to meet the toughest challenges in American higher education: giving more students access to college, and helping them graduate on time.

title: Wells Shows He Still Has Bat Speed in a Fast Start for the Yankees
description: When the Yankees traded for Vernon Wells in late March, after a rash of injuries to their everyday lineup, it seemed as if they had put a price on their desperation: $13.9 million. That was the amount they agreed to pay Wells through 2014, an exorbitant sum for a player with a .258 on-base percentage the last two seasons.

title: Adapting to Blended Courses, and Finding Early Benefits
description: BOSTON  At Bunker Hill Community College, students worked in small groups, writing step-by-step instructions for making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. But when a classmate was assigned to follow their instructions as literally as possible, it became clear that removing the bread from its bag was an important, forgotten step.

title: All Puns Aside, Weiner Makes Lucrative Name in Consulting
description: Anthony D. Weiner has demystified the details of the 906-page Affordable Care Act for an electronic medical records company.

title: Former Governor Sanford and Rival Debate in House Race
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The elephant in the room raised its trunk and blew about a half-hour into the only debate between former Gov. Mark Sanford, a Republican, and Elizabeth Colbert Busch, the Democrat with whom he is vying for a vacant seat in Congress.

title: Mature From the Start, Captain Serious of the Blackhawks Continues to Grow
description: CHICAGO  Jonathan Toews celebrated his 25th birthday on Monday by sitting at his locker after Blackhawks practice, a bank of cameras trained on him, a host of microphones in his face and a cacophony of questions hurled at him. He spoke in his familiar Western Canadian accent and with the same measured tones as always.

title: For Millennials, a Tide of Cynicism and a Partisan Gap
description: WASHINGTON  Andy Welsh of Portland, Ore., was so enthusiastic about President Obamas first run for the White House that he voted absentee while spending a semester abroad in Spain. But Mr. Welsh, now 26 and an aspiring diplomat, said the gridlock in Washington has been a real bummer ever since.

title: The Race to Lead Asias Confederation
description: It is never easy in the recent unpredictable world of the Asian Football Confederation.

title: Word of the Day | inimitable
description: inimitable \()i-ni-m-t-bl\ adjective

title: Corrections: April 30, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 30
description: I still love the game, and I still have something to offer. My coaches and teammates recognize that. At the same time, I want to be genuine and authentic and truthful.

title: Less Than Harveys Best Still Qualifies as Strong, if Futile
description: MIAMI  Before the right-hander Matt Harvey took the mound Monday for his sixth start of the season, he kept to himself in the visitors clubhouse at Marlins Park. He reclined on a big leather chair, tapped his iPad and seemed not even remotely interested in making small talk with his Mets teammates.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) AMANDA KNOX IN HER OWN WORDS  A DIANE SAWYER EXCLUSIVE Ms. Knox is the American college student in Italy who was convicted in the 2007 murder of her roommate Meredith Kercher and served four years of a 26-year sentence before the conviction was overturned in October 2011. On Tuesday, Ms. Knox, above left, with Diane Sawyer, speaks in her first television interview since the acquittal. She also reacts to the recent ruling by the Italian Supreme Court that has extended her legal battle and put her freedom on the line again.

title: For an Encore, Robinson Delivers a Game That Is Steady, Not Spectacular
description: The moment was set for Nate Robinsons encore Monday night: stage lighting, New Yorkers familiar with his game and a team fighting for its season.

title: Game 5: Nets vs. Bulls
description: On the brink of elimination, the Nets fought back and battered the Bulls on the boards to force a Game 6.

title: News Quiz | April 30, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Conversation With: Director Feroz Abbas Khan
description: The 13th annual New York Indian Film Festival will open on Tuesday evening in Manhattan with the premiere of Dekh Tamasha Dekh, which was directed by Feroz Abbas Khan. The five-day festival is a showcase of more than 40 features, short films and documentaries, presented by the Indo-American Arts Council, a Manhattan-based nonprofit.

title: Chinese Cruise to Disputed Paracel Islands Angers Vietnam
description: BEIJING  To many Chinese, the voyage of the Coconut Fragrance Princess, the first cruise ship touring the disputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, according to Chinese media reports, is about tourism: enjoying the azure water, sun and seafood of Chinas Maldives, as the announcers on Liaoning Satellite TV put it.

title: Groundbreaking Surgery for Girl Born Without Windpipe
description: PEORIA, Ill.  Using plastic fibers and human cells, doctors have built and implanted a windpipe in a 2 -year-old girl  the youngest person ever to receive a bioengineered organ.

title: IHT Quick Read: April 30
description: NEWS Two years after a triple meltdown that grew into the worlds second worst nuclear disaster, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant is faced with a new crisis: a flood of highly radioactive wastewater that workers are struggling to contain. Martin Fackler reports from Tokyo.

title: DreamWorks to Take Its Characters to Macau Resort
description: DreamWorks Animation SKG is bringing its DreamWorks Experience  the chance to play and dine with DreamWorks characters in a themed resort setting  to the Chinese gambling haven of Macau.

title: A King Takes the Throne, and a Nation Celebrates
description: AMSTERDAM  To the cheers of tens of thousands of people crammed shoulder to shoulder outside the royal palace here, Willem-Alexander of the House of Orange-Nassau became the Netherlands first king in 123 years on Tuesday as his mother, Queen Beatrix, ended a 33-year reign with the stroke of a pen, signing the act of abdication in an ornate chamber at the palace.

title: 4-Year-Old Rape Victim Dies in India
description: NEW DELHI  A 4-year-old girl who was raped and dumped near a crematorium in central India died on Monday evening from cardiac arrest, hospital authorities said Tuesday.

title: UBS Posts $1 Billion First-Quarter Profit
description: 4:22 p.m. | Updated LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS, buoyed by strong performances in its wealth management and investment banking operations, reported first-quarter earnings on Tuesday that sharply exceeded analysts expectations.

title: Cost-Cutting Helps Lloyds Bank Earn $2.3 Billion
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Tuesday that first-quarter net profit rose to 1.5 billion ($2.3 billion) from the period a year earlier, as it continued to reduce costs and shed assets.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 30, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article As Old as the Bottles.

title: Hundreds Killed in Bangladesh Garment Factory Collapse
description: The questions below rely on information from the following articles: Tears and Rage as Hope Fades in Bangladesh (April 28, 2013) and Building Collapse in Bangladesh Leaves Scores Dead (April 24, 2013).

title: Is It Crazy to Think We Can Eradicate Poverty?
description: At a news conference during the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in late April, Jim Yong Kim held up a piece of paper with the year 2030 scribbled on it in pen. This is it, said Kim, the genial American physician who took over as president of the World Bank last summer. This is the global target to end poverty.

title: How Big a Deal Is It That an N.B.A. Player Came Out as Gay?
description: Jason Collins, an N.B.A. center in his 12th season, announced that he is gay in a Sports Illustrated cover story this week. He is the first active player in the N.B.A., N.F.L., N.H.L. or Major League Baseball to come out.

title: The Dude Abides on the Other Side of the Lens
description: We highly recommend viewing the slide show in full-screen mode.

title: South Korea Pulls Bosses From Plants in North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  All the remaining South Korean factory managers in an industrial park in North Korea returned home early Tuesday, as political tensions drove the two Koreas to sever their last economic ties.

title: Wealth Inequality and Political Inequality
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: The Early Word: Protg
description: Todays Times

title: A Retrenched BP Tops Profit Forecasts
description: LONDON  BP reported a first-quarter profit of $4.2 billion on Tuesday after adjusting for inventory changes and one-time items, handily beating analysts forecasts.

title: When a Friend Chooses a College, Be Happy or Be Quiet
description: Scott Anderson is a former college counselor and the director of outreach for the Common Application.

title: The Beatings Must Continue
description: Sometimes economists in official positions give bad advice; sometimes they give very, very bad advice; and sometimes they work at the OECD.

title: Gazan Killed After Israeli Is Stabbed to Death in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian militant was killed in an Israeli missile strike in Gaza on Tuesday hours after an Israeli civilian was stabbed to death by a Palestinian in the West Bank. The two attacks, coming against a backdrop of growing tensions, were the first such killings in months and raised the specter of further confrontation.

title: Bill Courtney Offers Leadership Lessons on the Field and in Business
description: A couple of weeks ago, I took to Twitter with the following imperative: If you havent seen the film Undefeated, you should asap. @IamCoachBill is a real #leader who draws out the true #character of his players.

title: Poll Shows Isolationist Streak in Americans
description: Americans are exhibiting an isolationist streak, with majorities across party lines decidedly opposed to American intervention in North Korea or Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Lesbian Daughter Tells Mother, Address Wedding Invitations My Way
description: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: The Faces of Difference
description: TEL AVIV  I was impatiently waiting my turn to get on the Sunday morning radio show. The previous segment, involving two lawyers debating sexual harassment allegations against a well-known TV personality, went overtime after one of the lawyers asked, Can I add something about the new currency bills? The bills? the anchorman replied. We will discuss the bills controversy at the second half of the show. But the lawyer insisted: He just wanted to say that the notes design was an outrage. The other lawyer barged in: We can agree on this.

title: Daily Report: Acquisitions Shrink the Number of Travel Search Sites
description: The online travel search business is consolidating, as two of the biggest online travel agencies, Priceline.com and Expedia.com, buy smaller search engines, Harriet Edleson reports on Tuesday in The New York Times.

title: Obama Considers Expanding Support for Syrian Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is once again considering supplying weapons to Syrias armed opposition, senior officials said Tuesday. Such a decision would be a policy shift for the Obama administration, which has stepped up its nonlethal aid but stopped short of lethal weaponry and has expressed reluctance about greater military entanglements in the Syrian civil war.

title: Unemployment in Euro Zone Continues to Rise
description: The euro zone jobless rate rose to a record 12.1 percent in March, a sharp reminder that unemployment remains among the regions biggest problems.

title: Kinky Boots Leads With 13 Tony Nominations; Tom Hanks Gets Nod for Lucky Guy
description: The new Broadway musical Kinky Boots led the pack with 13 nominations for the 67th annual Tony Awards, including for best musical, director, actor, score and choreographer, while its chief rival Matilda had 12 nominations in many of the same categories. The nominations were announced at 8:30 a.m. on Tuesday. The revival of Golden Boy had the most nominations of any play, eight, with the new Tom Hanks play Lucky Guy close behind with six nominations. Lead acting nods went to only a handful of the Hollywood stars performing on Broadway this season  Mr. Hanks, Laurie Metcalf, Holland Taylor and Cicely Tyson; among those snubbed were Bette Midler, Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson and Al Pacino. Among the surprises were snubs of Motown for a best musical nomination and its star, Brandon Victor Dixon, for best actor. Fill out your ballot here. A slide show of the nominees is  here.

title: Turnover at JPMorgan
description: The departure of yet another JPMorgan Chase executive, Frank J. Bisignano, has heightened concerns about persistent executive turnover and raised questions about who might succeed Jamie Dimon, the banks chief executive and chairman, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook.

title: Tuesday Reading: Handling the Play Date Gun Debate
A Director Calls for Lights, Camera and Depression
description: Dear Diary:

title: Prosecutors Raid South Korean Spy Agency in Presidential Election Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  State prosecutors raided the headquarters of the National Intelligence Service of South Korea on Tuesday to investigate accusations that the spy agency used its agents and hired bloggers to influence the presidential election in December.

title: Senior Congressman and Newcomer Win Senate Nods in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  Representative Edward J. Markey, who has spent almost four decades in the House, has cleared the first hurdle in his drive to become a United States senator, easily defeating a fellow congressman, Stephen F. Lynch, in Massachusettss Democratic primary on Tuesday.

title: Furniture Thats Simply Chic
description: This month, the interior decorator James Huniford unveils a brand-new Chelsea showroom and a sophisticated furniture collection, made up of the type of pieces the designer previously created only as one-offs for his high-profile clients. The designs, Huniford says, are meant to be user-friendly  scale and contemporary livability are paramount, and dimensions, as well as upholstery, are all customizable. This is furniture that inhabits that elegant territory somewhere between modern and classic. A tufted slope-armed sofa ($7,800) is refreshed with a casual low-slung profile; a campaign-style side table ($4,800) is cheekily updated with a not-remotely-portable stone slab and chains; and a two-tiered occasional table ($5,800) has a brass base with an industrial feel. I like the tension between contrasting materials, the designer says. Metal and stone, wood and glass.

title: Jawbone Buys Sensor Start-Up for $110 Million
description: On Tuesday, Jawbone, which makes wireless headsets and music accessories, announced that it acquired BodyMedia, a company that sells wearable sensors, for about $110 million.

title: Semiautonomous Cadillacs Hit the Road for Testing
description: It seems inevitable that there will be more and more cars with a computer rather than a human being behind the wheel in the years to come, and Cadillac has joined the race for auto autonomy. The company said Monday that it had begun testing a semiautonomous car, a vehicle that can handle driving functions without operator input in certain situations.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from April 24 to April 28 with 965 adults throughout the United States.

title: Energy Agreement Hidden by Climate Disputes
description: This Twitter item leads to a Grist/Climate Desk piece on Political ideology affects energy-efficiency attitudes and choices, a fascinating new study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences that, in part using light bulb choices, shows how polarization over the merits of cutting greenhouse gas emissions appears to torque the behavior of conservatives away from commonsense energy choices.

title: Young Voters More Partisan, Poll Says
description: Young voters have become less idealistic and more partisan, according to a new poll conducted by Harvard Universitys Institute of Politics.

title: Tony Award Nominations: Who Got Snubbed?
description: Tony voters might want to lie low today if they dont want to get devoured by Bette Midler, whose unrecognized turn as the superagent Sue Mengers in the one-woman show Ill Eat You Last was perhaps the most glaring of snubs when the nominations were announced on Tuesday morning. Ms. Midler, an A-list star making her return to Broadway after an absence of some 40 years, was well-received for her performance as Ms. Mengers, a tough-as-nails Hollywood player, in Ill Eat You Last. But neither she nor this original comedy, written by John Logan (a Tony Award-winner for Red), received a nomination. (Still, shell always have Rochelle, Rochelle: the Musical.)

title: Still Coring After All These Years
description: Blogging is a bit like teaching the same class year after year; inevitably there are moments when you feel exasperated at the classs failure to grasp some point you know you explained at length  then you realize that this was last year or the year before, and it was to a different group of people.

title: Video: The Most Exciting Two Minutes in Sports
description: Our friends at TicketCity sent us this motion graphic video, which takes a look at performance trends at the Kentucky Derby throughout the years. Enjoy.

title: Judge Orders Blood Bags Destroyed in Doping Case
description: A Spanish judge ordered on Tuesday the destruction of more than 200 blood bags seized in a raid of a major European doping ring that catered to elite athletes, thwarting an effort to uncover possibly one of the biggest doping scandals in history.

title: Amid Hunger Strike, Obama Renews Push to Close Cuba Prison
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Tuesday that he would recommit himself to closing the Guantnamo Bay prison, a goal that he all but abandoned in the face of Congressional opposition in his first term and that faces steep challenges now.

title: An Archbishops Take on Banking
description: Since the crisis, bankers and their defenders have frequently made two somewhat contradictory claims about the financial industry: The first is that banks deserve government support because they are crucial to the smooth functioning of the economy. The second is that policy makers should not regulate banks too much because that would limit innovation.

title: Hulu Says Number of Paid Subscribers Has Doubled
description: Hulu, the online video Web site that has both free and paid services, said Tuesday that it had doubled its number of paying subscribers in the last year, to four million.

title: Looking Beyond Crisis, Deutsche Bank Issues Shares to Shore Up Its Books
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated

title: A 15% Gain In Earnings At Sirius XM
description: The satellite radio provider Sirius XM Radio on Tuesday reported continued growth for its first quarter and announced that its interim chief executive, James E. Meyer, was taking the job permanently.

title: Netflix Prison Series Gets July Release Date
description: Though there was once a time when Netflix was most closely associated with its bright red DVD-return envelopes, the company  now better known as a video-streaming service  is hoping that orange will be its color this summer. On Tuesday, Netflix announced that it has scheduled its next original series, Orange Is the New Black, a comedy-drama set in a womens prison, to have its premiere on July 11; and, as has become its custom, it will make all thirteen episodes of the series available for viewing at once.

title: What Were Reading
description: PBS Food: What went into William Randolph Hearsts favorite snack, Welsh rarebit: homemade cheese and butter, home-brewed beer, freshly baked bread and enough cash to keep it all going.  Julia Moskin

title: A Tablet Stand That Is a Sound Improvement
description: It is no surprise to anyone with a tablet that the tiny rear-facing speakers arent very good.

title: As Earnings Season Rolls On, European Banks Show Signs of Health
description: 4:55 p.m. | Updated

title: A Sudden Change That Took Years
description: It is a meaningful day in any world when you can stand back and watch progress happen. Thanks to Jason Collins, Monday was that day in sports. Here was an athlete in a mens team sport willing to be the first to acknowledge he is gay. But the progress is what happened next. Applause. Almost universal, at least from all meaningful corners. A call from the president. N.B.A. teammates lauding his courage. It was like watching a generational change happen in five minutes.

title: 2013 Tony Award Nominations
description: Scenes of this years nominated shows and performers.

title: Q&A: Breaking the Bluetooth Bond
description: Q.

title: Storm Effort Causes a Rift in a Shifting Occupy Movement
description: Not long ago, the Occupy Wall Street movement seemed poised to largely fade from the national conversation with few concrete accomplishments beyond introducing its hallmark phrase, We are the 99 percent.

title: Champions League Semifinals: Final, Dortmund 0, Real Madrid 2
description: Brilliant in the first leg and brave in the second, Borussia Dortmund advanced to the UEFA Champions League final on Tuesday, but only after fighting off Real Madrid over 10 final, frantic minutes.

title: The Cost to Consumers of a Data Breach
description: A new analysis of a huge data breach last year in Utah estimates that more than 120,000 cases of fraud will occur as a result of information stolen.

title: Not Too Much of a Good Thing
description: A reader sent me an e-mail expressing outrage that I should blithely sing the praises of ramps in my column without any mention of their imminent demise. Calling it an idiotic, irresponsible piece of journalism, he said I should be ashamed. Clearly, by urging cooks to savor ramps, I was simply another ignorant foodie who thinks wild-foraged food is there for the picking in vast unlimited quantities, and I had not done my research. How dare I suggest that the woods were full of ramps?

title: President Backs F.B.I. Handling of Boston Suspect in 11
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama offered his support Tuesday for the F.B.I.'s handling of a Russian intelligence tip about a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, even as the nations intelligence chief announced a review of whether more could have been done to thwart the attack.

title: Frank Bruni on the Jason Collins Story
description: The Op-Ed columnist Frank Bruni discusses Jason Collinss decision to become the first openly gay player in N.B.A. history.

title: Opera America Program to Aid 13 Companies
description: Thirteen opera companies across the United States will share $300,000 in grants awarded by Opera America in the first year of its new Building Opera Audiences program. The grants, which range from $7,500 to $30,000, are for programs meant to increase first-time opera attendance, and to increase return visits.

title: Positive Response to Jason Collins
description: The Timess John Branch on reactions to Jason Collins and how the N.B.A. veteran has broken barriers in the sports world by publicly stating he is gay.

title: Feeling For | Harry Winston Sunflower Collection
description: The late jeweler Harry Winston was quoted as saying (in a 1954 article in The New Yorker) that fine jewelry represents what man has done to perfect nature. In the jewelry houses latest interpretation of the sunflower, which is being introduced this week, his words ring true. Drawing inspiration from the motif initially conceived in the 1950s as a one-of-a-kind high jewelry piece, the current iteration features a central diamond (the seeds) flanked by smaller diamonds (the petals), all of which is set in platinum. The collection includes a pendant necklace, drop earrings and studs. Also sprouting this spring are colorful versions of the sunflower earring, featuring a ruby, sapphire or emerald center stone.

title: Wheelies: The Lavishly Expensive Roadster Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Art of the Leak in Deal-Making
description: The Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman discuss the strategic use of leaked information.

title: Cuomo Asks Con Ed to Freeze Bonuses for Top Executives
description: 1:55 p.m. | Updated Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called on Tuesday for Consolidated Edison to freeze extra bonuses paid to senior executives for their response to Hurricane Sandy, other storms and a monthlong lockout of 8,000 workers last year.

title: Onward, Not Upward, for UBS
description: The new-look UBS is starting to deliver. The first full quarter of the strategy announced on Oct. 29 has broadly answered the critics of the Swiss bank. UBS shone in trading and capital markets financing, returning to its traditional strength in equities. Investment bank stability helped the wealth management business, too.

title: My Sons Grades Are Too High
description: My childs report card is too good. But according to his teachers, Im crazy to complain.

title: Interior Departments No. 2 Stepping Down
description: David J. Hayes, the deputy secretary of the interior since the early days of the Obama administration, said on Tuesday that he would leave the post at the end of June.

title: The Gun Report: April 30, 2013
description: Jennifer and I are both traveling today so we will dispense with the usual introduction. Here is our typically grim Gun Report, which, when you think about it, needs no introduction.

title: Humbled by the Souvenirs of War
description: I usually forget about most dreams right after I wake, but I never forget the ones that involve combat. I collect those dreams and save them, locking them in a fortified mental safe I rarely open because the images may turn into nightmares. The war dreams are the pictures I never took. They are the souvenirs of war, the thoughts that continue to humble me. Some people might think that remembering such experiences would have destructive side effects. But for me, the dreams are a reminder of how valuable life is.

title: A Compelling Gamay to Accompany an Omelet
description: Pairing decisions are part analytical and, importantly, part emotional. Almost nothing will go better with this creamy, pungent, savory ramp omelet by David Tanis than those two amplifiers of umami, fino sherry and Champagne. Thats the rational choice, yet what I want most is gamay, the grape of Beaujolais. Why? Back in the old days, when being able to prepare a perfect omelet was considered evidence of cooking ability, my custom for my first meal on any trip to France was to stop in at a cafe or bar  vin for an omelet, with a glass of the easygoing house Beaujolais. For me, this combination was comfort and beauty. Nowadays, I might choose a gamay from the Loire Valley, or one of the few American versions, like Edmunds St. Johns, which I think come closer to those lighthearted yet compelling wines. The rational choice? Maybe not, but it sure felt like a great one.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Art of Teaching
Redskins to Give Jarboe an Opportunity in Minicamp
description: The long, strange, Dirty South journey of Josh Jarboe continues.

title: Jim Brown, Still a Hometown Hero
description: MANHASSET, N.Y.

title: Image of the Day: April 30
Add a Designer to the Flight Crew
description: When Qantas Airlines decided to revamp the uniform for its flight attendants, it did what any self-respecting carrier would do these days: it enlisted a Paris-based designer (Martin Grant) and showcased the collection (navy shift dresses and suits with flashes of red and fuchsia) using a supermodel (Miranda Kerr) in a fashion show.

title: Highlights From Obamas News Conference
description: The president answered questions Tuesday on topics ranging from the Boston bombing investigation to Syria to Jason Collins.

title: Opening Up Paraguays Landlocked Guair Region
description: The priest faltered a bit as he climbed the stairs to the museum, housed in an attic above a church in Itap, Paraguay, a town founded as a Franciscan mission in 1672. My guide and I had roused him from his siesta by clapping our hands repeatedly  the Paraguayan equivalent of a knock on the door. Fumbling with multiple locks and a ring of too many keys, he finally got the doors open and led us through the neatly displayed, modest treasures. I had to read the signs; his eyesight wasnt up to the task: A 1752 wooden figure of St. Bonaventure, arms outstretched. Nineteenth-century baptismal documents. Metal meal containers from the Chaco War against Bolivia in the 1930s. Then he stopped before a simple black frock hanging from a wooden beam. First cassock of Father Severiano Nelson Vega, I read, blessed by the Monsignor on March 19, 1958.

title: Maria Shriver Is Returning to NBC
description: Nearly a decade after she left NBC, Maria Shriver is returning to it as a special anchor, covering womens issues for television and the Web.

title: Q. and A. With Jason Collins
description: On the day after Jason Collins made history by becoming the first active athlete in any of Americas four major sports leagues to acknowledge that hes gay (see my column here), he hopped on the phone from Los Angeles to talk briefly with me about the reaction to his announcement, and the road he traveled to this juncture.

title: Combing the Backside in Search of the Next Big Horse
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. As the sun rose above the iconic Twin Spires on Tuesday, the backside at Churchill Downs began to come alive. Owners and trainers made small talk with reporters, and fans lined the rail to catch a glimpse and snap a picture of their favorite Derby and Oaks horses.

title: Video: The Art of the Leak
description: The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman discuss the strategic use of leaked information in deal-making.

title: Newspapers Post Gains in Digital Circulation
description: The nations newspapers suffered a slight decline in total circulation over the last six months compared with the same period the year before, but they benefited from an increase in digital subscriptions, which now make up nearly 20 percent of all daily circulation.

title: Living in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn
description: Tucked in the south-western corner of Brooklyn along the Verrazano Narrows, the community has retained its population and home values.

title: A NORC, Up Close and Personal
description: Fort Hamilton, the square-mile-size southern half of Bay Ridge, which takes its name from the local Army garrison, is not a place that people tend to leave. Judging from the numbers, this magnetism has effectively turned it into a NORC, or naturally occurring retirement community.

title: Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival to Celebrate Kronos Quartet
description: As part of its 40th anniversary, the Kronos Quartet will present Kronos at 40, a five-day program that will include 28 free performances on Lincoln Centers plazas during the opening week of this years Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival, which runs from July 24 through Aug. 11. The ensembles programs will include 11 premieres (including four newly commissioned works), and collaborations with dancers, pop musicians and indie classical performers. They are also the groups first New York performances with its new cellist, Sunny Jungin Yang.

title: Cannes Adds Jim Jarmuschs Vampire Film
description: Only Lovers Left Alive, a vampire film by Jim Jarmusch, has been added to the lineup in competition at the Cannes Film Festival, its organizers said.

title: Routledge to Publish Porn Studies Journal
description: Pornography has made increasing nonclandestine appearances on college campuses, thanks to events like Sex Week, which has drawn criticism for spicing up educational offerings workshops with sex-toy raffles and lectures by porn stars. Soon, campus types will also be able ponder the mysteries of sexuality through a less obviously titillating medium: a full-fledged scholarly journal dedicated to pornography.

title: Looking for Answers: Making Sense of the Boston Marathon Bombing
description: Overview | What prompts two brothers to kill and maim innocent people? Were Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev foreign-backed terrorists, embittered immigrants or just plain crazy? And can the United States government do a better job of preventing these events from happening again?

title: Rolston, an American Hockey Stalwart, Announces Retirement
description: Brian Rolston, a veteran of 17 N.H.L. seasons and the last active member of the 1996 United States team that won the World Cup of Hockey, announced his retirement Tuesday.

title: Bulls Defense Bears Brunt of Mounting Injuries
description: Few teams soldier through injuries with the pride and confidence of the Chicago Bulls, but even they were not be able to handle the mounting body count in Game 5. The Nets overwhelmed the Bulls depleted defense and raided the lane in a 110-91 victory, staving off elimination and sending the series back to Chicago for Game 6 on Thursday.

title: Finding Gay-Friendly Tour Operators and Places
description: As more countries propose legislation to legalize same-sex marriage, destinations and travel companies are increasingly marketing themselves to gay travelers. But John Tanzella, president of the International Gay and Lesbian Travel Association, warned that not all those who talk the talk necessarily walk the walk.

title: Report Cites Large Release of Sewage From Hurricane Sandy
description: Over 10 billion gallons of raw and partly treated sewage gushed into waterways and bubbled up onto streets and into homes as a result of Hurricane Sandy  enough to cover Central Park in a 41-foot-high pile of sludge, a nonprofit research group said in a report released on Tuesday.

title: In This War, the Enemies Are on All Sides
description: A Delicate Truth, John le Carrs new thriller, is anything but delicate: its ponderous, heavy-handed and obvious  everything that his wonderful early Smiley novels, which traded in moral ambiguity and psychological nuance, were not.

title: Le Petit Paris
description: A wave of change is coursing through the French city of Nantes, bringing cool new eateries, hotels and culture.

title: Health Care Law Is Working Fine, Obama Says in Addressing Criticism
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that his health care law was working fine, and he played down concerns that the law could disrupt coverage or lead to higher premiums for people who already had health insurance.

title: On an Unhappy Anniversary for Seles, Wondering What Might Have Been
description: Twenty years to the day after Gunter Parche, a deranged Steffi Graf fan from Germany, plunged a knife into the upper back of then-world No. 1 Monica Seles at a clay court event in Hamburg, the footage of the attack is still hard to watch.

title: A Brain's GPS
description: May-Britt Moser and Edvard I. Moser of the Kavli Institute for Systems Neuroscience talk about what a rat brain knows about location.

title: Transcript of Obamas News Conference
description: Following is a transcript of a news conference by President Obama at the White House on Tuesday, provided by Federal News Service. Click on a topic below to navigate to that section of the conference.

title: Mexicos Curbs on U.S. Role in Drug Fight Spark Friction
description: MEXICO CITY  In their joint fight against drug traffickers, the United States and Mexico have forged an unusually close relationship in recent years, with the Americans regularly conducting polygraph tests on elite Mexican security officials to root out anyone who had been corrupted.

title: Carbones Take on Potatoes Anna
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

title: How Are You Celebrating Queen Beatrixs Abdication?
description: Subjects of the Dutch colony of Nieuw-Amsterdam, arise! After 33 years as your benevolent overseer, your queen has forsaken you.

title: The Mediterranean Diets Brain Benefits
description: A large new study confirms that sticking to the Mediterranean diet  fish, poultry, vegetables and fruit, with minimal dairy foods and meat  may be good for the brain.

title: Gotham Chamber Opera Announces New Season
description: Gotham Chamber Opera, a small, feisty company that has become known for its thoughtful productions, particularly of Baroque and contemporary works, and for casting promising young singers in principal roles, will undertake collaborations with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Philharmonic and Trinity Wall Streetduring its 12th season, which opens on Oct. 23.

title: Larry Davids Comedy Piece Missed the Mark
description: About three weeks after 9/11, Clyde Haberman and his editors took a chance. He wrote and they published an NYC column in The Times that employed a light and humorous touch on the subject of the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: lyse Palace to Put Wine Up for Bid
description: PARIS  The dreaded phantasm of economic austerity has finally knocked its bony fingers on the door of the lyse Palace, which announced on Tuesday that it would auction off 1,200 bottles of its finest wines, renew its cellar with more modest vintages and return the surplus to the state budget.

title: To Satisfy Its Investors, Cash-Rich Apple Borrows Money
description: 9:00 p.m. | Updated

title: How Immigration Reform and Demographics Could Change Presidential Math
Saison
description: Inside the San Francisco restaurant where awaiting the next thrill is part of the fun.

title: SoftBanks Chief Talks Up Takeover Bid for Sprint
description: 7:50 a.m. | Updated

title: Parental Quest Bears Fruit in a Kidney Disease Treatment
description: Reluctant to say it aloud, Natalie Stack wrote her 12th birthday wish on a restaurant napkin: To have my disease go away forever.

title: The Republican Health Policy Trainwreck
description: A few weeks ago,Ezra KleinandBen Domenechhad a fairly detailed back-and-forth culminating inthis mano-a-mano exchangeabout whether a Republican or conservative alternative to Obamacare actually exists. You can read or watch them go at it and form your own judgment, but I think the answer is pretty straightforward: A conservative alternative or alternatives, yes; an alternative that Republican lawmakers are ready to vote for, no.

title: Reunited Neutral Milk Hotel Announces Limited Tour Dates
description: Neutral Milk Hotel, the 1990s indie-rock band known for its experimental sound, obscure lyrics and cult following, is reuniting for the first time in over a decade for a series of shows next fall, the band announced on its Web site.

title: The Long Wait for Wage Protections
description: More than three million home health aides  a lifeline for the elderly who are neither in institutions nor able to manage lifes mundane tasks on their own  are learning exactly how sclerotic the nations regulatory processes can be.

title: Critics of Police Would Make New Yorkers Less Safe, Bloomberg Says
description: With criticism of the police infusing the Democratic race to succeed him, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday offered a staunch defense of the New York Police Department, as well as a spirited attack against its critics.

title: The Restaurant Critic Hits the Road
description: My restaurant review this week tackles Saison, a tasting-menu restaurant in San Francisco that makes extraordinary demands on diners and rewards them with cooking that is at least as extraordinary. I had mixed feelings about the place a year ago, but my second meal there, early this spring, was one of the most compelling Ive had on the job.

title: Before Rewards, Demands
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the most compelling meals Ive had on the job was served to me early this spring by a restaurant here called Saison. About a year ago, I had one of the most maddening meals in my career, also at Saison.

title: In a Newsy Month, CNN Gets a Big Bounce, Fox News a Little Bounce and MSNBC a Drop
description: Breaking news is always good news for CNN, and Aprils ratings are the latest example.

title: Missing the Big Picture
description: President Obama used the better part of a rare news conference this morning to explain why Congress bears much of the responsibility for three of his most prominent failures: the pain of the sequester, the inability to close Guantnamo, and the problems implementing health-care reform. Theres no doubt that hes right, particularly on the first two, but the questions and answers this morning missed the big picture: By tying up the White House with short-term matters like these, Republicans and many Democrats in Congress are making it impossible to even discuss the overriding issues that will determine the countrys economic prospects.

title: An Evening with Salter, Ford  and Bascombe
description: The acclaimed novelists Richard Ford and James Salter shared the stage at the 92nd Street Y on Monday night, accompanied by a surprise guest Frank Bascombe.

title: In Misdemeanor Cases, Long Waits for Elusive Trials
description: Francisco Zapata keeps a copy of the Constitution on his cellphone. So when the police stopped, frisked and charged him with misdemeanor marijuana possession, he wanted what that cellphone document promised.

title: Next Concert Season at the Met Will Include Music in Galleries
description: The major shift of emphasis that the Metropolitan Museum made in its concert series this season, the first programmed entirely by Limor Tomer, as general manager of concerts and lectures, will carry at least through another season and seemingly far into the future, Ms. Tomer announced on Tuesday. She has largely abandoned the traditional series of classical recitals and chamber concerts in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in favor of nontraditional events related to Met exhibitions and, in many cases next season, actually taking place in the galleries.

title: Stravinsky Inspires a Festival to Get It Together, Fast
description: The Trinity Choir, the resident professional ensemble at Trinity Church on Wall Street in Lower Manhattan, is not unfamiliar with the notion of big undertakings. In recent years this superb chorus has released a reference-quality set of Haydns masses on the Naxos label, made a Grammy-nominated recording of Handels oratorio Israel in Egypt for Musica Omnia, and sung with the Rolling Stones in Brooklyn.

title: Before the Hot Flashes Come the Flashbacks
description: When asked why she wrote Scrambled Eggs, Robin Amos Kahn, in a Q. and A. provided with that plays press materials, replied, I went to a career coach who encouraged me to write my story because he thought I was funny.

title: Union Chief Recommends Delay in Use of Test Scores
description: Warning that a new set of academic standards was on the verge of falling into the dustbin of history, the leader of a national teachers union called on Tuesday for school systems to postpone using new tests to evaluate teachers and promote students.

title: A Sisterhood Against Terror
description: The former C.I.A. analysts Cindy Storer and Barbara Sude dont have the cheekbones or flame-red hair of Jessica Chastain, who played an analyst in the Oscar-nominated drama Zero Dark Thirty. They look like the women next door, a reality emphasized in the HBO documentary Manhunt (on Wednesday night) by an early scene of Ms. Storer driving out of her suburban cul-de-sac in a station wagon with an American flag mounted in a rear window.

title: Shopping Snapshots: May 1
description: Art is in the air, and on your dress; Piamita bikinis, inspired by a cat; Elder Statesman designer creates a J. Crew line and other shopping news.

title: The Knick Fan Blues
description: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But William C. Rhoden says they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.

title: Video: The Knicks Fan Blues
description: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But right now they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.

title: Finding John Kerrys Senate Replacement
description: Two weeks after the Boston Marathon bombings, Massachusetts voters will choose the candidates hoping to fill John Kerrys vacated Senate seat.

title: 3 Years After Bruins Collapse, Goalie Stands Tall
description: BOSTON  Tuukka Rask saw firsthand what a hot goalie can do in the playoffs: he can win the Stanley Cup. Tim Thomas did it for the Boston Bruins two years ago. Rask, a spectator in 2011, sees no reason it cannot happen again.

title: Now Showing | The Source Family
description: There is a particular feeling that is both satisfying and unsettling when the reality of a legend fails to deviate from the fantasy. The Source Family, the subject of a documentary by Maria Demopoulos and Jodi Wille opening tomorrow at the IFC Center, is such a pure expression of an archetypal 1970s psychedelic subculture that it feels like an ornate and elaborate invention. More than 100 young men and women belonged to this utopian commune, which was led by a self-made spiritual leader who called himself Father Yod. By the time of his death he had 13 wives and was believed, by his followers, to be God.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: This Season, a More Measured Tortorella
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  You know its getting close to crunch time when John Tortorella starts feeling aggrieved. After practice here on Tuesday the Rangers coach was answering a routine question about team chemistry entering the playoffs when he embarked on an R-rated tangent that accused reporters of misrepresenting his relationship with Marian Gaborik, who was dealt to Columbus at the April 3 trade deadline.

title: In Venture Capital Deals, Not Every Founder Will Be a Zuckerberg
description: Its the dream of entrepreneurs to sell their company for millions of dollars. But the dirty secret of venture capital is that the dream can be dashed as the venture capitalists make millions in a sale, leaving the founders with nothing.

title: In Central Park, Hunt for an Intruder, the Snakehead Fish, Is On
description: The Harlem Meer, in the northeastern corner of Central Park, has long been a refuge for city people looking to indulge their inner Huck Finns, whiling away a lazy summer afternoon fishing for bass, yellow perch and black crappies.

title: Consumer Spending Without Consumer Confidence
description: Consumer spending is usually a sign of consumer confidence. But thats not the case in todays fraught economy.

title: Stormy Weather Can Set the Stage for Sounds Both Old and New
description: The Miller Theater at Columbia University has long been a hot spot for adventurous programming. But in promoting The Baroque Vanguard, the second of three concerts in the theaters Bach, Revisited series, which took place on Saturday night, the presenters may have overstated its novelty.

title: Navigating the Supermarket Aisles
description: Michael Moss, left, and Michael Pollan visit a typical supermarket and talk about cooking and the food industry.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, the West Bank and New York.

title: Grandma Looked Good in It, and So Does Dad
description: Its an ordinary day at the beach. Big Sis is primping in sunglasses. Grandpa is doing push-ups. Little Sis is pretending to be a ballerina and turning cartwheels. But wait  why is Dad slipping on a womans bathing suit?

title: Pots and Pans, but Little Pain
description: By the time most Americans reach adulthood, the supermarket ceases to hold surprises. But Michael Pollan, one of the most prominent voices on food today, a man who knows the nuances of the grocery store inside and out, was struck by the sight of the cheese aisle.

title: Credit Reports More Accurately Reflect Debts Discharged in Bankruptcy
description: When you file for personal bankruptcy protection and have debts discharged by the court, your credit report is supposed to be updated to reflect that you no longer have to pay those bills.

title: Revisiting a Rossellini Classic to Find Resonances of Today
description: The 1950s are full of movies that were initially greeted, by critics and audiences, with indifference or derision, only to be hailed as masterpieces in hindsight. Vertigo, The Searchers and The Sweet Smell of Success are among the best-known examples of this kind of revisionism. Another, only slightly less famous, is Roberto Rossellinis Viaggio in Italia, a film so maligned and neglected in 1955, the year of its American release, that it did not receive a review in The New York Times.

title: In Performance: Deborah Cox
description: Deborah Cox, accompanied by Nick DiFabbio on guitar, sings Someone Like You from the Broadway revival of the musical Jekyll & Hyde, at the Marquis Theater.

title: How Commune Became Cult
description: For anyone looking to teach a master class in brainwashing techniques, The Source Family might be an excellent place to start. Documenting the hippy-dippy lifestyle and hedonistic principles of Hollywoods favorite 1970s cult  led by the self-professed guru and suspected bank robber Jim Baker, a k a Father Yod  Maria Demopoulos and Jodi Willes disturbing film is an object lesson in psychological manipulation.

title: Juggling Primal Conflicts of Innocence and Sin
description: Mesmerizing, mysterious, willfully perverse, the Mexican movie Post Tenebras Lux opens with two scenes, one realistic, the other fantastical. In the first a toddler roams across a muddy country field at dusk as thunder booms and dogs chase cows, horses and donkeys.

title: Rejection Is a Process
description: Beth Kissileff has taught at Carleton, Smith and Mount Holyoke Colleges, and the Universities of Minnesota and Pittsburgh. She is the editor of a forthcoming anthology: Reading Genesis (Continuum Books, 2013).

title: Scene City: Politicos and the Stars Who Portray Them
description: After the White House Correspondents Dinner, a party hosted by Bloomberg and Vanity Fair.

title: A Visual Way to Navigate Among Comments
description: When it comes to comments on the Internet, there are often two distinct buckets. One,a sludge of vitriol and anger toward the author of a post or story. The second, too many comments to navigate where the good input from readers is often lost in Bucket No. 1.

title: The TV Teaser That Depresses
description: Its only Tuesday, but we can already declare a winner in the competition for the Most Attention-Getting Press Release Teaser of the Week. Its Animal Planet, which on Tuesday morning sent around an e-mail with this in the subject field: The Search Is on for the Best Hooker in America.

title: Front Burner
description: To Taste: Aiding Animals, Veterans and That Sweet Tooth

title: No Judging About Gay Players on Basketball Courts
description: The West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village, known far and wide as the Cage, draw some of the toughest and best streetball players from across the city. And on Tuesday, as the sporting world absorbed the news that the journeymen N.B.A. center Jason Collins had come out as gay, the denizens of the Cage said, by and large, that it made no difference to them.

title: In Defense of Education, Books as Armor
description: 4:31 p.m. | Update:  According to the organizers of the book-shield project, members of the New York City Police Department confiscated the book shields that were to be used for the May Day events at Cooper Union today.

title: The Last Days of The Office
description: The sitcom, which paved the way for a new style of filmed comedy, will show its series finale on NBC on May 16.

title: Ben Foldss 24-Hour Musical
description: The indie-rock songwriter composed and developed a short work in one night as part of The 24 Hour Musicals.

title: Four Musicals, Coming Right Up
description: Ben Folds, the indie-rock songwriter, spent most of Sunday watching people on the streets of New York and thinking about what might make them burst into song.

title: President Obama on Guntanamo
description: Speaking at the White House on Tuesday, President Barack Obama said he would try to close the Guntanamo Bay prison. (NBC)

title: Gray Matter in Moments of Triumph and Defeat
description: A new competition show on the Discovery Channel is searching among 10 people with very good brains to find the one with the best brain of all. But over on the National Geographic Channel a peppy little audience-participation series has been demonstrating that the brain is easily fooled and not to be trusted. How are our brains supposed to process these conflicting signals about our brains?

title: Its Kinky Boots vs. Matilda in Tony Nominations
description: Traditional song-and-dance shows about scrappy underdogs dominated the Tony Award nominations on Tuesday, with four  Kinky Boots, Matilda, Bring It On and A Christmas Story  taking every slot in the race for best Broadway musical. Serious fare suffered, with the gritty Hands on a Hardbody edged out for best musical and The Testament of Mary  a monologue by the mother of Jesus  quickly announcing a closing date after its lead actress, Fiona Shaw, did not receive a Tony nomination.

title: Americans on Terror Threats
description: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Americans views on security issues after the Boston Marathon Bombings.

title: A Field That Once Looked Bleak Attracts Young Careerists
description: THE allure of the travel industry as a career, recently seen as dated as a Pan Am stewardess pillbox, is surging as more people take jobs in a sector bolstered by renewed spending.

title: For Healthier Flying, Pack a Pair of Walking Shoes
description: CHRISTOPHER BERGER, 42, an exercise physiologist and professor at the University of Indianapolis, has an uncommon view of airports and business travel.

title: Plan to Do Work in Coach? Youd Better Not Count on It
description: WHEN you travel for business, do you have every intention of getting work done on the plane? If youre in business class, you could be good to go. If youre in coach, good luck with that.

title: A Corporate Retreat for Team-Building, With a Taste of Wine
description: IT seems counterintuitive for companies to take their employees somewhere where the alcohol begins to flow even before lunch is served. But wineries around the world are increasingly accommodating businesses asking for meeting space, catering and even wine-making lessons for their workers.

title: Dispatches From the Foxholes of Business Travel
description: FREQUENT business travelers are called road warriors for a reason  most of them have a collection of war stories, ranging from minor annoyances to full-combat nightmares.

title: Craving Wi-Fi, Preferably Free and Really Fast
description: TRAVELERS hitting the road with their mobile electronic devices have three questions about staying connected away from home: will there be Wi-Fi, how much will it cost and how well will it work?

title: Airports and Hotels in Emerging Markets Outpace the West
description: FROM Asia to Africa to the Middle East and the Americas, the business of business travel is booming in emerging countries. And it shows.

title: Frustrated Air Travelers, the T.S.A. Chief Shares Your Pain
description: JOHN S. PISTOLE was named administrator of the Transportation Security Administration in July 2010 after 26 years at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He recently answered questions about the agencys policies. The interview was edited and condensed.

title: In-Room Entertainment Turns Away From TV
description: LEN MARKIDAN, a 26-year-old marketing consultant based in San Francisco, is the type of business traveler who forced LodgeNet, the hotel guest-room entertainment provider, to file recently for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Premium-Class Service, Long Before Fliers Board
description: WASHINGTON

title: Measuring the Benefits of Tech Tools
description: When I was a young reporter we could not afford cellphones. I remember waiting in line for a pay phone in downtown Mexico City one afternoon to call in the news about the auction to privatize the phone company Telmex, driving those behind me crazy while a copy editor on the other end patiently typed it into those glowing green letters of an earlier information age.

title: Ethics Panel, Upset by Delay, Vows to Release Report on Lopez
description: New York State ethics regulators, frustrated that their report examining allegations of sexual harassment by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez has not been released to the public, say they will disclose it themselves if the Legislature and prosecutors fail to do so shortly.

title: The Art of Orly Genger
description: Images of the artists work.

title: Poll Finds Strong Acceptance for Public Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  Americans overwhelmingly favor installing video surveillance cameras in public places, judging the infringement on their privacy as an acceptable trade-off for greater security from terrorist attacks, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Results of Poll of Americans on Terror Threats
description: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Americans views on security issues after the Boston Marathon Bombings.

title: Obama Ally Likely Pick for F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is expected on Wednesday to nominate Tom Wheeler, a venture capital investor and fund-raiser in Mr. Obamas presidential campaigns, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, two administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Plane Carrying Mexican Officials Crashes, Killing 6
description: An airplane belonging to the attorney generals office crashed on Tuesday in central Mexico, killing all six people on board, the authorities said. The dead included the crew, two federal agents and a prosecutor who were returning to Mexico City from Zacatecas State after helping with the arrest of people suspected of being members of the Zetas, one of the countrys most violent gangs. The cause of the crash is under investigation. The plane, a Beechcraft King Air 300 built in 1985, had unspecified mechanical trouble Monday night, forcing it to return to Zacatecas and delaying the return of the group, the attorney generals office said in a statement.

title: Times-Picayune Plans a New Print Tabloid
description: Nearly one year after The Times-Picayune of New Orleans announced that it would print only three days a week, the paper said it planned to roll out a three-day-a-week tabloid edition.

title: Jailed Official in Ukraine Gets Decision in Her Favor
description: MOSCOW  Before she went to jail a year and eight months ago, Yulia V. Tymoshenko joked that she carried a toothbrush and a bottle of water in her purse in case of arrest.

title: After Catching 15 Innings, a Day of Rest for Buck
description: MIAMI  John Buck arrived Tuesday afternoon in the visitors clubhouse at Marlins Park and declared himself rested and ready to play. Manager Terry Collins quickly scuttled those plans. There was no way Buck was starting for the Mets on Tuesday, not after he caught all 15 innings of their loss to the Marlins on Monday night, a marathon that extended into early Tuesday morning.

title: Douglas R. Lebda
description: Mr. Lebda, 43, is the chairman and chief executive of Tree.com, a public company based in Charlotte, N.C., and the parent of LendingTree.com, an online marketplace that matches mortgage borrowers with lenders.

title: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
description: The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it would make the most widely known morning-after pill available without a prescription to girls and women ages 15 and older, and also make the pill available on drugstore shelves, instead of keeping it locked up behind pharmacy counters.
